div1.head: f

div2.entryFree:
alphabetical letter f *
The twentieth letter of the alphabet: called faA='N [and faA]. (TA.) It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice], and of those termed $afawiy~ap [or labial]: (TA:) it is a radical letter, and not augmentative: (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np:) sometimes it is substituted for v; thus in the conjunction vum~a, as in the saying jaA='a zayodN fum~a EamorNw [“ Zeyd came, then 'Amr ”]; and in Alv~uwmu, “ the well-known herb so called [?], ” for which they say Alfuwmu; and in Aljadavu, “ the grave, ” or “ sepulchre, ” for which they say Aljadafu, but using for the pl. A^ajodaAvN, and not A^ajodaAfN, accord. to IJ, (MF, TA,) [unless, app., by poetic license, for] the latter pl. is used by Ru-beh. (R and TA in art. jdf.) -A2- fa is a particle having no government: (Mughnee, * K, * TA:) or it governs a mansoob aor.; as in the saying, maA taA^otiynaA fatuHad~ivanaA [Thou dost not come to us, that thou mayest talk to us]; (Mughnee, K, TA;) accord. to some of the Koofees; (Mughnee;) but the truth is, that the aor. is here mansoob by A^ano, meant to be understood, (Mughnee, TA,) as is said by MF, and the like is said by J, (TA,) though the A^ano in this case is necessarily suppressed: (I'Ak p. 295:) and it is said (Mughnee, K, TA) by Mbr (Mughnee) to govern the gen. case in the saying [of Imra-el-Keys],
famivoliki HubolaY qado Taraqotu wamuroDiEK
[Many a one like thee, even such as was pregnant, have I visited by night, and such as was suckling]; but the truth is, that what here governs the gen. case is rub~a, meant to be understood; (Mughnee, TA;) like as it often is in the case of wa, as is said in the Lubáb. (TA.) ― -b2- It occurs used in three manners; in one whereof it is an adjunctive to an antecedent, and denotes three things: ― -b3- one of these is order; and this is of two sorts; relating to the meaning, as in qaAma zayodN faEamorNw [Zeyd came, and after him 'Amr]; and relating to a verbal statement, which is an adjoining of an explicit clause to an implicit antecedent, as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 34] faA^azal~ahumaA A@l$~ayoTaAnu EanohaA faA^axorajahumaA mim~aA kaAnaA fiyhi [And the Devil caused them both to slip, or fall, from it (i. e. from Paradise), and ejected them from that state of enjoyment in which they were]: (Mughnee, K: *) ― -b4- the second thing that it denotes when used as an adjunctive to an antecedent is proximate sequence, and this is in everything [i. e. in every case] according to the estimate thereof; (Mughnee, K; *) [meaning, according to the relative, or comparative, estimate of the time implied; for, as is said in an explanation of the words thus rendered, in a marginal note in my copy of the Mughnee, “ the long period is sometimes esteemed short by comparison; ” or it may be defined as a particle denoting sequence in a case in which is an uninterrupted connection between two events;] one says tazaw~aja fulaAnN fawulida lahu [Such a one took a wife, and, in uninterrupted connection with his doing so, a child was born to him,] when there did not intervene between the two events aught save the period of gestation, (Mughnee, K, *) and so if it were a period protracted [beyond the usual length]; and you say daxalotu AlbaSorapa fabagodaAda [I entered El-Basrah, and, in uninterrupted connection with my doing so, Baghdád,] when you did not stay in El-Basrah nor between the two towns: and this sequence is not necessarily implied by the f that denotes causality; as is shown by the correctness of one's saying A_ino yusolimo fahuwa yadoxulu Aljan~apa [If he become a Muslim, he will consequently enter Paradise]; the delay between the two events [by death &c.] being well known: (Mughnee:) ― -b5- [or, accord. to J,] the adjunctive f occurs in three cases, in the first of which it denotes order and proximate sequence with association; you say, Darabotu zayodFA faEamorFA [I beat Zeyd, and next 'Amr]: (S: [the second and third of these cases will be mentioned in the course of this art:]) ― -b6- and it is said to occur sometimes in the sense of vum~a, (Mughnee, K, * TA, *) denoting conjunction in an absolute manner, with delay; (TA;) as in the saying [in the Kur xxiii. 14] vum~a xalaqonaA A@ln~uTofapa EalaqapF faxalaqonaA A@loEalaqapa muDogapF faxalaqonaA A@lomuDogapa EiZaAmFA fakasawonaA A@loEiZaAma laHomFA [Then we made the sperm a lump of clotted blood, then we made the lump of clotted blood a bit of flesh, then we made the bit of flesh bones, then we clothed the bones with flesh]: (Mughnee, K, TA:) ― -b7- and sometimes in the sense of wa, (Mughnee, K, * TA, *) denoting conjunction in an absolute manner, without order; (TA;) as in the saying (of Imra-el-Keys, TA), bayona Ald~axuwli faHawomali [as though meaning Between Ed-Dakhool and Howmal]; (Mughnee, K, TA;) the right reading of which is asserted by As to be with wa; but it is replied that the implied meaning is bayona mawaADiEi Ald~axuwli famawaADiEi Hawomali [amidst the places of, or pertaining to, Ed-Dakhool, and the places of, or pertaining to, Howmal; the former places and the latter being contiguous; and we may therefore understand these words as relating to an antecedent command to pause]; this phrase being allowable like the saying jalasotu bayona AlEulamaA='i faAlz~uh~aAdi [I sat amidst the learned men and the devotees]: it has been said that maA is here suppressed before bayona, and that fa is used in the place of A_ilaY; but this usage of fa is strange: (Mughnee:) ― -b8- the third thing that it denotes when used as an adjunctive to an antecedent is relation to a cause: (Mughnee, K, * TA: *) this is the second of the three cases mentioned by J, who says, (TA,) it is when what precedes it is a cause of what follows it; and it denotes adjunction and proximate sequence without association; as in the sayings Darabahu fabakaY [He beat him, and he consequently wept,] and Darabahu faA^awojaEahu [He beat him, and consequently pained him,] when the beating is the cause of the weeping and of the pain: (S, TA:) used in this manner, i. e. to denote relation to a cause, it is generally such as adjoins a proposition, as in [the saying in the Kur xxviii. 14] fawakazahu muwsaY faqaDaY Ealayohi [And Moses struck him with his fist, and consequently killed him]; or a qualificative, as in [the saying in the Kur lvi. 52-54] laA=kiluwna mino $ajarK mino zaq~uwmK famaAliy^uwna minohaA A@lobuTuwna fa$aAribuwna Ealayohi mina A@loHamiymi [Shall surely be eating from trees of Zakkoom, and consequently filling therefrom the bellies, and drinking thereon of hot water]. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b9- Another manner in which it is used [the second of the three manners before mentioned (Mughnee)] is as a connective of an apodosis, i. e., of the complement of a conditional clause, (Mughnee, * K, * TA,) when this is of a kind not fit to be itself conditional, i. e., to be a protasis. (Mughnee.) It is thus used when the complement is a
nominal proposition; as in [the saying in the Kur vi. 17] waA_ino yamosasoka bixayorK fahuwa EalaY kul~i $aYo'K qadiyrN [And if He cause good to betide thee, He is able to do everything]: (Mughnee, K, TA:) this is the third of the three cases mentioned by J, who says, (TA,) this is when it is used for the purpose of inception, in the complement of a conditional clause; as in the saying A_ino tazuroniY faA^anota muHosinN [If thou visit me, thou wilt be a welldoer]; in which what follows fa is a new proposition, grammatically independent of what precedes it, one part thereof governing another; for A^anota is an inchoative, and muHosinN is its enunciative; and the proposition has become a complement by means of the f: (S, TA:) ― -b10- or, (K,) secondly, (Mughnee,) the complement may be a verbal proposition, like the nominal, and it is one of which the verb is aplastic; as in [the saying in the Kur xviii. 37 and 38] A_ino tarani A^anaA A^aqal~a minoka maAlFA wawaladFA faEasaY rab~iY A^ano yuw^otiyani [If thou seest me to be possessing less than thou in respect of wealth and children, it may be that my Lord may give me]; and [the saying in the Kur ii. 273] A_ino tuboduwA A@lS~adaqaAti faniEim~aA hiYa [If ye make apparent the alms, very good, as a thing, is it, i. e. the doing so]: (Mughnee, K:) ― -b11- or, (K,) thirdly, (Mughnee,) the verb of the complement may be one belonging to a new proposition, grammatically independent of what precedes it, as in [the saying in the Kur iii. 29] A_ino kunotumo tuHib~uwna A@ll~`ha faA@t~abiEuwniY [If ye love God, follow ye me]: (Mughnee, K:) ― -b12- or, (K,) fourthly, (Mughnee,) the verb of the complement may be a pret., as to the letter and as to the meaning; either properly, as in [the saying in the Kur xii. 77] A_ino yasoriqo faqado saraqa A^axN lahu mino qabolu [If he steal, a brother of his hath stolen before]: or tropically, as in [the saying in the Kur xxvii. 92] wamano jaA='a biA@ls~ay~iy^api fakub~ato wujuwhumumo fiY Aln~aAri [And whoever shall have done that which is evil, their faces are inverted in the fire of Hell], this [latter] verb being used as though signifying what has already happened to denote the certain assurance of the event's happening: (Mughnee, K: *) ― -b13- fifthly, when the f is coupled with a particle relating to futurity; as in [the saying in the Kur v. 59] mano yarotad~a minokumo Eano diynihi fasawofa yaA^otiY A@ll~`hu biqawomK yuHib~uhumo [Whoever of you revolteth from his religion, God will bring a people whom He loveth]; and in [the saying in the Kur iii. 111] wFmaA tafoEaluwA mino xayorK falano tukofaruwhu [And what ye do of good, ye shall not be denied the reward of it]: (Mughnee: omitted in the K; as is also what here next follows:) ― -b14- sixthly, when the f is coupled with a particle to which is peculiarly assigned the first place in a proposition, as in the saying,
faA_ino A^aholiko fa*iY HanaqK laZaAhu
EalaY~a yakaAdu yalotahibu A@lotihaAbaA
[a verse similar in itself, and probably in its sequel (which is not quoted), to one by Rabee'ah Ibn-Makroom (in Ham p. 29), app. meaning And if I perish, many a one having rage in his bosom, whose fire kindled against me almost flames with a vehement flaming; fa*iY HanaqK being for farub~a *iY HanaqK]; for rub~a is meant to be understood, and to it peculiarly belongs the first place in the proposition: (Mughnee:) ― -b15- the f must also be used when the complement of a conditional clause is imperative; as in the saying A_ino A^akoramaka zayodN faA^akorimohu [If Zeyd treat thee with honour, treat thou him with honour]: or prohibitive; as in the saying A_ino yukorimoka zayodN falaA tuhinohu [If Zeyd treat thee with honour, treat not thou him with contempt]: or negative, either by means of lano [as in an ex. above] or by means of maA; as in the saying A_ino A^akoramota zayodFA famaA yahiynuka [If thou treat Zeyd with honour, he does not treat thee with contempt]: (TA:) ― -b16- when the verb of that complement is an aor., affirmative, or negative by means of laA, the f may be introduced or omitted: in the former case you may say A_ino tukorimoniY faA^ukorimuka meaning faA^anaA A^ukorimuka [i. e. If thou treat me with honour, I will treat thee with honour]; and you may say A_ino tukorimoniY A^ukorimoka [which is the more usual] if you do not make it [i. e. Akrmk] the enunciative of a suppressed inchoative [i. e. of A^anaA]: and in the case of the negative by means of lA you may say A_ino tukorimoniY falaA A^uhiynuka [If thou treat me with honour, I will not treat thee with contempt; and you may omit the f as is more usual]: (TA:) ― -b17- and sometimes the f is suppressed in the case of necessity in verse [on account of the metre]; as in the saying,
mano yafoEali A@loHasanaAti A@ll~`hu ya$okuruhaA
[Whoso doth those deeds that are good, God will recompense them, i. e., the deeds], (Mughnee, K,) meaning faA@ll~`hu: (K:) or, (Mughnee, K,) accord. to Mbr, who disallows this even in verse, (Mughnee,) the right reading is
mano yafoEali Alxayora faAlr~aHom`nu ya$okuruhu
[Whoso doth that which is good, the Compassionate will recompense it]; (Mughnee, K;) and it is absolutely disallowable: (K:) or it occurs in chaste prose, (Mughnee, K, *) accord. to Akh; (Mughnee;) and hence the saying [in the Kur ii. 176] A_ino taraka xayorFA A@lowaSiy~apu lilowaAlidayoni waA@loA^aqorabiyna [If he leave wealth, the legacy shall be to the two parents and the nearer of other relations]; and the trad. respecting that which one has picked up, or taken, of property that has been dropped, faA_ino jaA='a SaAHibuhaA waA_il~aA A@sotamotiEo bihaA [And if the owner thereof come, restore thou it to him; and if not, or otherwise, benefit thyself by it]: (Mughnee, K:) ― -b18- when the verb of the complement of a conditional clause is a pret. as to the letter but future as to the meaning intended [yet not importing certainty, so that it is not like the saying in the Kur xxvii. 92, cited above], the f may not be prefixed to it; as in the saying A_ino A^akoramotaniY A^akoramotuka [If thou treat me with honour, I will treat thee with honour]: and likewise when it is pret. as to the [proper] signification but [an aor. as to the letter and] future as to the meaning intended; as in the saying A_ino A^asolamota lamo tadoxuli Aln~aAra [If thou become a Muslim, thou wilt not enter the fire of Hell]. (TA.) ― -b19- And as the f thus connects the apodosis with its protasis, so it connects the like of the apodosis with the like of the protasis; as in the saying Aal~a*iY yaA^otiyniY falahu dirohamN [Who comes, or shall come, to me, for him is, or shall be, a dirhem]: by its being introduced in this case, one understands what the speaker means, that the obligation to give the dirhem is a consequence of the coming: otherwise the saying would be ambiguous. (Mughnee.) Thus also it occurs after a clause commencing with the conditional particle A^am~aA, q. v. (Mughnee in art. A^am~aA; &c.) ― -b20- It also occurs in the cases here following, prefixed to an aor., which is mansoob by means of A^ano, meant to be understood, (S, TA, and I'Ak p. 295,) but necessarily suppressed: (I'Ak ibid.:) ― -b21- thus in the complement of a command; (S, TA, and I'Ak p. 296;) as in Aiy^otaniY faA^ukorimaka [Come thou to me, that I may treat thee with honour]: (I'Ak ibid.:) [and] you say zuroniY faA^uHosina A_ilayoka [Visit thou me, that I may do good to thee]; (S, TA;) to which J adds, you do not make the visiting to be the cause of the doing good; what you [would] say being, it is of my way to do good always; but [there seems be an omission here in the copies of the S, for, as] IB says, if you make A^uHosin to be marfooa, [not mansoob,] saying faA^uHosinu A_ilayoka, [the meaning is, for I will do good to thee, for] you do not make the visiting to be the cause of the doing good: (TA:) the demand, however, in this and similar cases, must not be indicated by a verbal noun, nor by an enunciative; for when it is so indicated, the aor. must be marfooa; as in Saho faA^uHosinu A_ilayoka [Be silent, then I will do thee good]; and in Hasobuka AlHadiyvu fayanaAmu Aln~aAsu [The discourse is sufficient for thee, so the people shall sleep]: (I'Ak p. 296:) ― -b22- also in the complement of a prohibition; (S, and I'Ak p. 296;) as in laA taDoribo zayodFA fayaDoribaka [Beat not thou Zeyd, for he may beat thee, or lest he beat thee]: (I'Ak ibid.:) ― -b23- and in the complement of a prayer; as in rab~i A@noSuroniY falaA A^uxo*ala [My Lord aid me, so that I may not be left helpless]: (I'Ak ibid.:) ― -b24- and in the complement of an interrogation; (S, and I'Ak p. 296;) as in halo tukorimu zayodFA fayukorimaka [Wilt thou treat Zeyd with honour, that he may treat thee with honour?]: (I'Ak ibid.:) ― -b25- and in the complement of a petition with gentleness; (S, and I'Ak p. 296;) as in A^alaA tanozilu EinodanaA fatuSiyba xayorFA [Wilt thou not alight at our place of abode, that thou mayest obtain good?]: (I'Ak ibid.:) ― -b26- and in the complement of a demanding with urgency the performance of an action; as in lawolaA taA^otiynaA fatuHad~ivanaA [Wherefore dost thou not come to us, that thou mayest talk to us?]: (I'Ak p. 296:) ― -b27- and in the complement of an expression of
wish; as in layota liY maAlFA faA^ataSad~aqa minohu [Would that I had wealth, that I might give alms thereof]: (I'Ak ibid.:) ― -b28- and in the complement of an expression of hope, in like manner as in the case next before mentioned, accord. to the Koofees universally; as in the saying in the Kur [xl. 38 and 39] laEal~iY A^abolugu A@loA^asobaAba A^asobaAba A@ls~am`waAti faA^aT~aliEa [May-be I shall reach the tracts, or the gates, the tracts, or the gates, of the heavens, so that I may look], accord. to one reading: (I'Ak p. 298:) ― -b29- and in the complement of a negation, (S, and I'Ak p. 295,) i. e., of a simple negation; as in maA taA^otiynaA fatuHad~ivanaA [Thou dost not come to us, that thou mayest talk to us; a saying mentioned before, in the first of the remarks on this particle]. (I'Ak ibid.) ― -b30- It is also prefixed as a corroborative to an oath; as in fabiEiz~atika [which may be rendered Now by thy might, or nobility, &c.], and fawarab~ika [Now by thy Lord]. (TA.) ― -b31- The third manner in which it is [said to be] used is when it is redundant, so that its being included in a saying is like its being excluded: but this usage is not affirmed by Sb: Akh allows its being redundant in the enchoative, absolutely; mentioning the phrase A^axuwka fawujida [as though meaning Thy brother, he has been found; but h`*aA is app. meant to be understood, so that the phrase should be rendered, fully, this is thy brother, and he has been found]: Fr and ElAalam and a number of others restrict its being allowable to the cases in which the enunciative is a command, as in the saying,
waqaAy^ilapK xawolaAnu faA@nokiHo fataAtahumo
and in the saying,
A^anota faA@noZuro liA^aY~i *aAka taSiyru
or a prohibition, as in the saying zayodN falaA taDoribopu; but those who disallow its being so explain the first of these three exs. by saying that the implied meaning is h`*ihi xawolaAnu, [so that the saying should be rendered, fully, Many a woman is there saying, This is Khowlán (the tribe so named), therefore marry thou their young woman; and in like manner the implied meaning of the third ex. is h`*aA zayodN falaA taDoribohu This is Zeyd, therefore do not thou beat him;] and the implied meaning of the second ex. is AunoZuro faA@noZuro, [so that the saying should be rendered, fully, Look thou, and look to what result thereof thou wilt eventually come,] the former AnZr being suppressed, and its implied pronoun, A^anota, expressed: the saying
waA_i*aA halakotu faEinoda *`lika faA@jozaEiY
[meaning And when I perish, on the occasion thereof manifest thou impatience, or grief, &c., the second f being redundant,] is an instance of poetic license. (Mughnee.) -A3- [As a numeral, f denotes Eighty.]
faA * and fA='N Names of the letter f, q. v. -A2- faA as a prefixed n. in the accus. case, syn. with fam, see voce fuwhN, in art. fwh.

R. Q. 1 faA^ofaA^a * , (T, M, Msb,) inf. n. faA^ofaA^apN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) He reiterated the letter f (Mbr, T, S, M, Msb, K) in his speech; (S, M, K;) or was as though the letter f predominated upon his tongue; (T;) or had an impediment in the tongue, the letter f predominating in the speech. (M.) You say, fiyhi faA^ofaA^apN [In him is a fault of reiterating the letter f in his speech; &c.] (S, K.) [See also faA^ofA='N.]
faA^ofaA^N * : see what follows.

faA^ofaA='N * (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ faA^ofaA^N, (T, M, Msb, K, [and thus accord. to my copy of the Mgh,]) both mentioned by Lh, (T,) A man in whom is what is termed faA^ofaA^apN, expl. above; (T, S, M, K;) or who reiterates the letter f much when he speaks; (M;) or who cannot utter the word unless with an effort, commencing with the like of the letter f, and then pronouncing with effort the letters of the word correctly: (Mgh:) or one who reiterates his words much in speaking: (TA:) fem. with p. (T, Msb.).

8 AifotaA^ata EalaY~ *
He said of me what was false: (AZ, S, O:) or AftA^t EalaY~a AlbaATila he forged against me what was false: (K:) and AftA^t EalaY~a maA lamo A^aqulo he forged against me what I did not say. (M.) -A2- And AftA^t EalayonaA He was alone in his opinion against us; none sharing it with him: (ISh, T, TA:) or AftA^t biraA^oyihi he was alone, or singular, in his opinion: (ISk, S, O, K:) and in like manner in his affair, or case. (ISk, TA.) This verb, thus used, (not known to Az with a radical hemz in this sense except as mentioned by ISh and ISk, TA,) is mentioned with hemz by AA and AZ and ISk and others: it is therefore not from Alfawotu, unless it be an instance of the application of hemz to that to which it does not properly belong, as in the cases of Hal~aA^otu Als~awiyqa, and lab~aA^otu biAlHaj~i, and ravaA^otu Almay~ita. (S, O.) [See also art. fwt.] -A3- Aufotuy^ita, in the pass form, He (a man, O) died suddenly: (O, K:) but this, app., [if not a mistake for Aufotulita,] should be Aufotiyta, without hemz, from mawotu AlfawaAti. (TA.)

fuw^ayotN * , applied to a man and to a woman, One who follows his, or her, own opinion only. (From a marg. note in a copy of the S. [Thus pronounced by AZ: by others, fuwayotN, without hemz: see art. fwt.])

1 faA^adahu * , (T, S, M, A, L, K,) aor.
faAa^a , inf. n. faA^odN, (M, L,) He, or it, hit, struck, smote, affected, or hurt, his (a man's, K) fuw^aAd [or heart, &c.]: (S, M, L, K:) he hit, or smote, him, (AZ, T,) or shot, or shot at, and hit, or smote, him, namely a gazelle, (A,) or an animal of the chase, (AZ, T,) in his fuw^aAd. (AZ, T, A.) ― -b2- And, said of a disease, (S,) and of fear, (A,) It smote, or affected, his fuw^aAd: (S, A:) or, said of fear, it rendered him cowardly. (K.) ― -b3- And fuy^ida, (T, M, A, L, K,) inf. n. faA^odN; (M, L;) and fay^ida; (K;) He had a disease in his fuw^aAd: (T:) or he had a complaint thereof: (M, L, K:) or he had a pain therein: (K:) or he was, or became, hit, struck, smitten, affected, or hurt, therein. (A.) -A2- faA^ada Alxubozapa, (T, S, M, L,) or Alxuboza, (K,) aor. as above, and so the inf. n., (M, L,) He put the cake of bread, or lump of dough, (T, S,) or the bread, (K,) into the hot ashes; (T, S, K;) and baked it therein: (T:) or he toasted [or baked] (M, L) the cake of bread, or lump of dough, [or the bread,] in the hot ashes. (M, * L.) And faA^ada All~aHoma (S, M, L, K) fiY Aln~aAri, (M, L, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (L,) He roasted the flesh-meat [in the fire]; as also ↓ AftA^dhu. (S, M, L, K.) ― -b2- And faA^ada liloxubozapi, (S, L,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (L,) He made for the cake of bread, or lump of dough, a place in the hot ashes, or in the fire, to put it therein [for the purpose of baking it]. (S, L.) -A3- faA^ada lifulaAnK He acted well, or kindly, to such a one, in his affair, in absence: so in the “ Nawádir ” of Lh. (TA.)

5 tfA^~d *
i. q. tawaq~ada [i. e., when said of fuel, It burned, burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed]: (M, L, K:) [and] so when said of the heart [i. e. It became excited with ardour, or eagerness]. (M, L, K. *) And i. q. taHar~aqa [It burned much, as a quasi-pass. v.]: (so in copies of the K, in SM's copy and in my MS. copy and in the CK:) or, as in MF's copy of the K, taHar~aka [it was, or became, in a state of motion, or commotion]: (TA:) [See what is said of the derivation of fuw^aAdN.]

8 AftA^dwA *
They lighted a fire (M, A, L, K) for the purpose of roasting. (A) -A2- See also 1, latter half.
faA^odN * : [see 1, of which it is the inf. n.: and] see the paragraph here following.

fuw^aAdN * (S, M, A, Msb, K, &c.) and fawaAdN, which is strange, (K,) but said by Esh-Shiháb to be a dial var., and to be without reason disallowed by AHát; (TA;) of the masc. gender only; (Lh, M, L, K, &c.;) The heart; syn. qalobN [q. v.]; (S, M, A, L, Msb, K, &c.;) of man, and of an animal other than man: (M, L:) so called because of its tafaA^~ud (T, M, L, K) i. e. tawaq~ud [or ardour]; (M, L, K;) or because of its pulsation, and commotion; [for which reason also the heart is said to be called Alqalobu, from Alt~aqal~ubu;] for it is said that the primary meaning of ↓ faA^odN is “ motion, ” and the “ putting in motion: ” (MF, TA:) or the heart is thus called only when its tafaA^~ud, i. e. its tawaq~ud, is regarded: and most authors make a distinction between fuw^aAd and qalobN; the latter of which is said to have a more special signification than the former: (TA:) and the former is said to be [the pericardium,] the gi$aA=',
(L, TA,) or the wiEaA=', (TA,) of the qalob: (L, TA:) or the middle thereof: (L:) or the interior thereof: (TA:) the qalob being its Hab~ap [q. v.], (L, TA,) or its suwayodaA=': (L:) or fuw^aAdN signifies the appendages of the mariYo' [or œsophagus], consisting of the liver and lungs and qalob [or heart]: (K:) pl. A^afoy^idapN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) the only pl. thereof known to Sb. (M, L.) ― -b2- Also The mind, or intellect: and this, it is said, may be the meaning of the phrase [in the Kur liii. 11], maA ka*aba A@lofuw^aAdu maA raA^aY, (TA,) or mA ka*~aba, another reading, i. e. [The mind] did not disacknowledge, or deem improbable, what he saw. (Jel.) [Hence,] Hid~apu Alfuw^aAdi i. q. *akaA='N [meaning Sharpness, or acuteness, of mind, in a man: and sharpness of spirit in a beast]. (S in art. *kw.) [And Hadiydu Alfuw^aAdi i. q. *akiy^~N meaning Sharp, or acute, in mind, applied to a man: and sharp in spirit, applied to a beast:] one says farasN Hadiydapu Alfuw^aAdi [A mare sharp in spirit]; and in like manner naAqapN [a she-camel]: (S and K in art. rwE:) and naAqapN ruwaAEapu Alfuw^aAdi, and ruwaAEu Alfuw^aAdi, a quick, spirited, vigorous, she-camel; sharp in spirit; syn. $ahomapN *akiy~apN. (K in that art.) [And TaAra fuw^aAduhu His mind or intellect, fled: and his courage. (See $aEaAEN: and TaAra.)]

fay^iydN * : see mafow^uwdN, in two places. -A2- Also, (T, M, L,) applied to bread [or dough], (M, L,) and so ↓ mafow^uwdN, (M, L, K,) and ↓ mufotaA^adN, and ↓ A^ufow^uwdN, (K,) Baked on the fire: (T:) or put into hot ashes, (L, K,) and baked therein: (L:) or toasted [or baked] in hot ashes. (M, L.) And the first, (T, S, M, &c.,) applied to flesh-meat, (S, M, L,) Roasted, (T, S, M, L, K,) as also ↓ mafow^uwdN, (M, L, K,) on the fire: (T:) or roasted upon live coals; as also ↓ mufoA^adN [evidently, I think, a mistranscription for ↓ mufotaA^adN]. (L.) ― -b2- And fay^iydN signifies also Fire or a fire [for baking &c.]. (T, L, K.)

A^ufow^uwdN *
A place which one makes, for a cake of bread, or lump of dough, in hot ashes, or in a fire, to put it therein [for the purpose of baking it]: (S, M, * L, K: *) pl. A^afaAy^iydu. (L.) ― -b2- See also fay^iydN.
mufoA^adN * : see fay^iydN.

mifoA^adN * (T, S, M, L, K) and ↓ mifoA^adapN (S, L, K) and ↓ mifoA=dN (T, M, L, K) The [iron instrument, with which flesh-meat is roasted, called] saf~uwd, (T, S, M, L, K,) [or] with which one roasts and bakes. (L, TA.) And [in the CK “ or ”] the first, (S, L, K,) and the second and third also, (accord. to the K,) the piece of wood, or wooden implement, with which the [fire in the kind of oven called] tan~uwr is stirred: pl. mafaAy^idu. (S, L, K.)
mifoA^adapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mifoA=dN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

mafow^uwdN *
Hit, struck, smitten, affected, or hurt, in his fuw^aAd [or heart, &c.]: (S, A, L:) smitten, or affected, by a disease therein: (S, L:) or by pain therein. (L.) ― -b2- A man without a heart; having no heart; as also ↓ fay^iydN: (Ks, S, L:) weak-hearted: (T, L:) a coward; (T, M, L, K;) and so ↓ fay^iydN: (T, K:) in this sense it has no verb. (AAF, IJ, M, L.) -A2- See also fay^iydN, in two places.
mufotaA^adN * : see fay^iydN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A place of fuel: (T, L:) a place in which a fire is lighted for roasting. (A.)

1 fay^ira * , aor. yafoA^aru, It (a place) became abundant in faA^or [i. e. rats, or mice]. (Msb.) -A2- faA^ara, (J, O,) aor. as above, (K,) inf. n. faA^orN, (TK,) He dug; (K;) or dug as does the faA^or [i. e. rat, or mouse]: (M, TA:) and, (K,) as some say, (M, TA,) he buried, and hid. (M, * O, K, TA.)

faA^orN * [A kind of animal,] well known, (M, K,) [the genus mus; the rat; the mouse; and the like]; with ', (Lth, S, Msb,) and without '; (Msb;) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: (Lth, T:) [in the S and O and Msb, faA^orN is said to be pl. of faA^orapN, but in the last is added, like tamorapN and tamorN, showing that by pl. is meant coll. gen. n.:] the pl. of fA^r, (Lth, T, M, K,) or of fA^rp, (O, Msb,) is fiy^oraAnN (Lth, T, M, O, K, Msb) and fiy^irapN: (M, K:) accord. to IAar, (T, TA,) ↓ fuw^arN, like SuradN, (O, K, TA,) is applied to the male: (T, O, K, TA:) but this last word occurs in the phrase AlfaA^or Alfuw^ar, [in which AlfA^r is evidently used in a sense mentioned below, namely, “ the muscles, ” as is indicated in the T and O,] and, accord. to some, [Alfuw^ar is a corroborative epithet, for they say that] this phrase is like layolN laAy^ilN and yawomN A^ayowamu: (O:) faA^orapN is applied [accord. to some] to the female; (M;) or [more correctly] to the male and the female, (M, K,) like as HamaAmapN is applied to the male and the female of the [genus] HamaAm. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also Musk: (M, K:) this is sometimes called faA^orN because it is from the [animal, or from a kind of animal, called] faA^or, as some say. (M.) ― -b3- And faA^orapu Almisoki signifies The bag, follicle, or vesicle, (naAfijap, S, M, O, K, or naAfiqap, T,) of musk: (T, S, M, O, K:) and is also without '; (M, Msb;) or it should correctly be mentioned in art. fwr, [as being called faArapN] because of the spreading (fawaraAn) of its odour: or it may be with ' because it has the appearance, or form, of the [animal called] faA^orap. (O, K.) It was said to an Arab of the desert A^atahomizu AlfaA^orapa, (K, TA, in the CK A^atuhomazu AlfaA^oru,) [meaning Dost thou pronounce fArp with hemz?], and he replied, [understanding the animal so called to be meant,] Alhir~apu tahomizuhaA, (K,) meaning, [The cat] bites it. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence, app., by a synecdoche, faA^orapu Almisoki is applied to The mush-animal, or Tibet-musk; moschus moschiferus:] El-Jáhidh says, I asked a perfumer, of [the sect of] the Moatezileh, respecting [the animal called] fA^rp Almsk, and he said, it is not a mouse, or rat, (fA^rp,) but is more like a young gazelle: it is found in the region of Tubbat [or Tibet]; and is hunted; and the man who catches it binds tightly its navel, [or rather its umbilical follicle,] which being pendent, the blood collects in it; then it is slaughtered; and when it is quiet, he cuts out the bound navel, and buries it in barley ($Eyr) until the congealed blood becomes converted into strong-scented musk. (TA.) ― -b5- And faA^orapu AlA_ibili signifies The sweet odour of the camels, [likened to that of the vesicle of musk,] which diffuses itself from them when they have pastured upon the herbs and their blossoms, (S, O,) or, as some say, upon the [plant called] xuzaAmaY [q. v.], (O,) and then drunk, and returned from the water, with their skins moist: (S, O:) so says Yaakoob. (S.) Thus in a verse cited voce *afirN. (S, O. [Therefore faA^orapN *aforaA='u should there be rendered A pungent sweet odour like that of a vesicle of musk. But see faArap, in art. fwr.]) -A2- AlfaA^oru signifies also (assumed tropical:) The muscles: (T, O:) and faA^oru Almatoni (assumed tropical:) the flesh on either side of the back-bone; as also yaraAbiyEu Almatoni. (T. [See also AlfaAru, in art. fwr.]) -A3- And A species of trees; with and without ': (M:) and faA^orapN [as its n. un.] a tree [of that species]. (K.) -A4- Also A certain well-known measure, or quantity, of wheat: in this sense an adventitious word. (O.)
fuw^arN * : see faA^orN, first sentence.

fay^irN * A place abounding with faA^or [rats, or mice]. (S, O.) You say A^aroDN fay^irapN, (O, K,) and A^aroDN ↓ mafoA^arapN, (S, O, K,) Land abounding with fA^r: (K:) or land containing fA^r. (S, O,) [In my copy of the Msb, I find ↓ makaAnN mafoA^arN.] ― -b2- Milk, (M, K,) and food, (TA,) into which a rat, or mouse, (fA^rp,) has fallen. (M, K, TA.)

faA^orapN * n. un. (but said by some to be fem.) of faA^orN [q. v.] ― -b2- Also, (S, M, O, K,) and ↓ fuw^orapN, (M, K, in the O written fuw^arap,) both with and without ', (M, O,) A flatus (S, M, O, K) that collects (S) in the pastern (S, M, O, K) of a camel, (S,) or of a beast, (M, K,) or of a horse; (O;) which issues (S, M, O, K) when it is felt, (S,) or when it is stroked, and collects when it is left to itself. (M, O, K.)
fuw^orapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
fiy^orapN * and fiy^arapN: see fay^iyrapN.
fuw^aArapN * : see the paragraph here following.

fay^iyrapN * (T, M, O, K) and ↓ fuw^aArapN (M, K) and ↓ fiy^orapN (Lth, T, O, K) and ↓ fiy^arapN, and also without ', (K,) Fenugreek (Hulobap) cooked until its foam boils up, when it is put into a press (miESar), and clarified, then dates are thrown upon it, and the woman in the state following childbirth sups it (Lth, T:) or fenugreek (Hulobap) and dates cooked for the woman in the state following child-
birth, (M, O, K,) who drinks it, (M,) and for the sick. (O.)
mafoA^arN * ; and its fem., with p: see fay^irN.

1 faA^asa * , (S, M, O, K,) aor.
faAa^a , inf. n. faA^asN, (M, K,) He struck (AHn, S, O, Msb, K) him, or it, (S, O,) or a tree, (AHn, M,) with a faA^os: (AHn, S, M, O, K:) he cut him, or it, (M,) or a tree, (TA,) therewith: (M:) he clave, (M, O, K,) or split, (T, O,) a piece of wood, (M,) or one's head, (O,) therewith. (M, K.) ― -b2- He hit (S, K) a man (S) in the faA^os of the head. (S, K.) -A2- He ate wheat, or other food. (O, K, * TA.)

faA^osN *
A certain implement of iron, (M,) with which one digs; [i. e., a kind of hoe; thus called in the present day; generally having a blade more long than wide, and a short handle; altogether resembling an adz:] (Kr, M:) and with which one cuts; [i. e., an adz; and an axe; both also thus called in the present day; more commonly the former; used for cutting, cleaving, and splitting, trees and wood, (see faA^asa,) and for hewing, forming, or fashioning, wood &c.: (see also qaduwmN:)] (M:) a thing well known: (A, K:) [applied also to a pickaxe: (see SaAquwrN:)] the ' in this word may be suppressed: (Msb:) it is of the fem. gender: (M, Msb, K:) the pl. (of pauc., O) is A^afow^usN (M, O, Msb, K) and (of mult., O) fuw^uwsN, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) and, accord. to some, fuw^osN. (TA.) ― -b2- faA^osu All~ijaAmi [A certain part of the bit; namely,] the [tongue of] iron that stands up towards [so I render here the particle fiY] the Hanak [here meaning the palate, against which it is made to press when the rein is drawn hard for the purpose of checking the horse]; (IDrd in his book on the Saddle and Bridle, [in one part of which he likens to it the tongue of a buckle,] S, M, A, O, K;) the iron that stands up in the $akiymap; (T;) or, as some say, that which is in the middle of the $kymp, between the misoHalaAni: (ISh:) the $kymp is the iron that lies across in the mouth, [i. e., the bit-mouth, or mouth-piece of the bit,] and the misoHal is an iron [i. e. a ring of iron, one of a pair of rings which are inserted each into the other, in the place of our curbchain,] beneath the Hanak [here meaning the part between the two sides of the lower jaw]: (IDrd:) or, as some say, [and among them Kr.] the transverse iron in the bit; (M;) but this assertion requires consideration. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yaluwku lisaAnahu fiY AlkalaAmi kamaA yaEoliku Alfarasu faA^osa All~ijaAmi [Such a one mumbles his tongue in speaking like as the horse moves about in his mouth the fA^s of the bit]. (A.) ― -b3- faA^osu Alr~aA^osi, (S, O, K,) or faA^osu AlqafaA, (M,) The edge of the qamaHoduwap [or hinder part of the back of the head], that projects above the back of the neck; [i. e., the small protuberance above the back of the neck:] (S, O, K:) or the hinder part of the qmHdwp. (M.) ― -b4- faA^osu Alr~aHaY The [protuberant] part of the [nether, or lower,] mill-stone, in the middle of which is [fixed] the axis. (Kzw, description of Ursa Minor.) ― -b5- And hence, AlfaA^osu The Constellation of Ursa Minor. (Idem, same place.) ― -b6- faA^osu Alfami The extremity of the mouth, in which are the teeth. (M.) ― -b7- AijoEalo h`*aA AlA^amora faA^osFA waAHidFA means Make thou this affair to be [uniform, or] of one way or mode or manner. (ISk, TA in art. bA^j.)

2 tafoy^iylN * is of the measure tafoEiylN from AlfaA^olu: (O, K, * TA: *) [and is app. syn. with tafaA^~ulN, signifying The auguring, &c.; or it may signify the auguring, &c., much: accord. to the TK, faA^~alahu bihi means jaEalahu yatafaA^~alu bihi he made him to augur, &c., by it; but this, as is very often the case in the TK, is app. said only on the ground of conjecture: the only ex. that I have found, to show its true meaning, is that which here follows:] Ru-beh says,
laA yaA^oxu*u Alt~afoy^iylu waAlt~aHaz~iY
fiynaA walaA qa*ofu AlEidaY *uw AlA^az~i
[which seems evidently to mean, The auguring, &c., or auguring, &c., much, and the divining, will not have any effect upon us; nor the enemies' noisy reviling or reproaching]: but AA has related it otherwise, substituting Alt~aA^ofiyku [lit. the lying] for Altfy^yl; and has explained it as meaning the enchanting; because it is a turning of a thing from its proper way, or mode. (O, TA.)

5 tfA^~l bihi * , (ISk, S, M, MA,) or ↓ tfA='l, (AZ, T, Msb,) or both, (K, TA, [accord. to the latter of which, it seems that the latter v. is formed from the former v., for the purpose of alleviating the pronunciation, and has become the popular form,]) He augured, or augurated, good, by it, or from it; or regarded it as a good omen; i. e., something uttered in his hearing: (AZ, ISk, T, S, M, * MA, Msb, K:) or so, and likewise evil; (AZ, T, Msb, K;) accord. to the usage of some of the Arabs: (T:) [but in the latter case they generally said, taTiy~ara minohu (q. v.): and in like manner they used these verbs in relation to the cries and flights of birds, and the motions of gazelles, &c.; as is stated in several of the lexicons, voce baAriHN, &c. See also 2 and 8: and see faA^olN.]
6 tafaA~a^a see the next preceding paragraph.

8 Aifotiy^aAlN * [in my copies of the S written AifotiyaAl] is of the measure AifotiEaAlN from AlfaA^olu: (S, K, * TA: *) [in the PS and TK, it is said to be syn. with tafaA^~ulN: it seems, however, that in the ex. here following, its exact signification, and whether it be used in an act. or a pass. sense, is doubtful; and that it is trans. without a prep.:] El-Kumeyt says, describing horses,
A_i*aA maA bdato taHota AlxawaAfiqi Sad~aqato
biA^ayomani faA^oli Alz~aAjiriyna A@fotiy^aAluhoA
[app. meaning, When they appear beneath the standards, (perhaps standards set up as winningposts,) the regarding them as of good omen, or their being regarded as of good omen, (by reason of their excellent performance,) verifies the happiest augury of the diviners: with respect to its being made fem. in this ex., though not regularly fem. in form, see SarofN, third sentence]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [It has also another signification:] Fr says, AifotaA^alotu Alr~aA^oYa is with hemz which is originally [a letter] other than hemz [app. meaning that the v. is originally Aifotayalotu, which becomes changed by rule to Aifotalotu; and that the signification is the same as that of fay~alotu Alr~aA^oYa, I declared, or esteemed, the judgment, or opinion, weak; or pronounced it to be bad, and wrong, or erroneous: perhaps the substitution of hemz for the medial radical letter is for the purpose of giving to the phrase a double meaning: or the hemz may be the original letter, and the phrase may be used ironically]. (O, TA.)

faA^olN * , (T, S, M, O, Msb, K,) and faAlN without ' is allowable, (Msb,) A good omen; (PS;) contr. of TiyarapN: (T, M, Msb, K:) it is when a man is sick, and he hears another say yaA saAlimu [O safe]; or seeking, and hears another say yaA waAjidu [O finder]: (ISk, T, S, O, K: *) or it is when one hears a good saying, and augurs good by it: (Msb:) [therefore] it is said in a trad., kaAna yuHib~u AlfaA^ola wayakorahu AlT~iyarapa [He (the Prophet) used to like the fA^l, and dislike the Tiyarap]: (T, S, O:) [or it signifies so, and likewise an evil omen: i. e.] it is used in relation to a good saying and to an evil saying, (AZ, T, Msb, K,) by some of the Arabs: (T:) it is said in a trad. [of the Prophet], yuEojibuniY AlfaA^olu AlS~aAliHu [The good fA^l pleases me]; which shows that there is a sort of fA^l that is good and a sort that is not good: (TA:) and [in like manner] TaAy^irN is applied to that which is good and that which is evil: (K in art. Tyr:) the pl. is A^afow^ulN [properly a pl. of pauc.], (S, O,) or fuw^uwlN [a pl. of mult.], (M,) or both: (K:) El-Kumeyt says,
walaA A^asoA^alu AlT~ayora Eam~aA taquwlu
walaA tataxaAlajuniY AlA^afow^ulu
[And I will not ask the birds respecting what they say, nor shall omens, or good omens, contend with me as though pulling me in different directions]. (S, O.) ― -b2- laA faA^ola Ealayoka means No harm shall befall thee; (T, O, K;) and no evil fortune; and no mischief. (T.)
fay^ilu All~aHomi * , (O, K,) or All~aHomi ↓ fayoA^alu, (T,) or both, (TA,) A man having much flesh. (T, O, K, TA.) [See also fay~ilN, in art. fyl.]

Alfiy^aAlu *
A certain game of the boys (T, S, O, K,
TA) of the desert-Arabs, (TA,) with earth, or dust: (T:) they hide a thing in earth, or dust, and then divide it, and say, In which of them (S, O, K, TA) twain (S, O, TA) is it? (S, O, K, TA.) [See also AlfayaAlu, in art. fyl.]
fayoA^alu All~aHomi * : see fay^ilu All~aHomi, above.
mufaAy^ilN * [or mufaAyilN (M and TA in art. fyl)] A boy playing at the game called Alfiy^aAl. (S, O. *)

div2.head: fAlw* &c.
div2.entryFree: faAluw*N * and faAluw*ajN and faAluw*aqN: see art. fl*.

1 faA^ama * , [or faA^ama AlEu$oba, as is shown by an ex. in the S and TA,] aor.
faAa^a , [inf. n. faA^omN, TK,] He (a camel) filled his mouth with herbage; (IAar, S, K;) as also fay^ima, (K, TA,) like fariHa; (TA; [in the CK faA^~ama;]) and ↓ tafaA='ama. (AA, T, K, TA.) ― -b2- And faA^ama, (T,) or faA^ama mina AlmaA='i, aor. as above, (K,) He satisfied his thirst with drinking of water. (T, K.) ― -b3- And faA^ama fiY Al$~araAbi He drank with his mouth, not with his hand nor with any other thing, a gulp, or a draught, (nafasFA,) of the wine, or beverage; (T, TA;) said of a man: (TA:) app. from A^afoA^ama signifying “ he filled ” a vessel: and SaA^ama signifies the same. (T, TA.) -A2- See also 4.

2 faA~a^a see 4. ― -b2- tafoy^iymN signifies also The making wide a leathern bucket. (T, TA.) ― -b3- And [app. as inf. n. of fuy^~ima, first signifying The being made wide, and then, as a subst.,] largeness, bulkiness, or corpulence, and wideness. (TA.) ― -b4- See, again, 4.

4 AfA^m *
He widened, (S, M, K,) and added to, a [camel's saddle such as is called] qatab, (S, K,) and [such as is called] a raHol, (S,) or a [woman's camel-vehicle such as is called] hawodaj, in its lower part; (M;) and ↓ fA^~m, (S, M, K,) inf. n. tafoy^iymN, (S, K,) signifies the same: and the epithets ↓ mufoA^amN and ↓ mufaA^~amN are then applied thereto. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- [And He widened a leathern water-bag by inserting a third skin between the two other skins: see the pass. part. n. below, and see also $aEiybN.] ― -b3- And He filled a vessel (T, TA) or a leathern bucket: (TA:) and so A^afoEama. (T, TA.) ― -b4- A^ufoy^ima HaArikuhu His (a camel's) withers became full of fat: (S:) [or] so HaArikuhu ↓ fay^ima, like fariHa [in measure], accord. to the K, but correctly fuy^ima, like EuniYa: (TA:) [or the latter verb is app. ↓ fuy^~ima: for] the epithets applied thereto [whether to the camel or to the withers is not clearly shown] are ↓ mufoA^amN (S, TA) and ↓ mufaA^~amN, meaning fat, and wide within: in the K, erroneously, mifoA^amN and mifoA=mN, like minobarN and miHoraAbN. (TA.)
6 tafaA~a^a see 1, first sentence.

qaTaEuwhu fuw^amFA * , [the latter word] like Surad, (K,) or qaTaEuwA Al$~aApa fuw^omFA fuw^omFA, (so in the T accord. to the TT,) i. e. [They cut it, or the sheep, or goat,] into a number of pieces. (T, K.)

fiy^aAmN *
A thing that is spread to sit upon or to lie upon, (S, M, K,) pertaining to the [women's camel-vehicles called] ma$aAjir [pl. of mi$ojarN], (M,) or to [those called] hawaAdij, (K,) or to both of these: (S:) or, as some say, a hawodaj that is widened in its lower part by something added thereto: or a burden equiponderant to another burden, like a sack with a small mouth, with which the vehicle of a woman is covered; one being placed on one side, and another [app. close to the former] on the other side: (M:) pl. fuw^umN [with two dammehs]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- [And A piece that is added to a leathern water-bag. (See $aEiybN; under which it is loosely explained: and see 4 in this art.)] -A2- Also A company of men: (T, S, M, K:) a pl. having no proper sing.: (S, K:) the vulgar say fiyaAmN, without ': (S:) [or] they say fayaAm: (thus in the T accord. to the TT:) [but ISd says,] fayaAmN and fiyaAmN have this meaning; otherwise I should say that fiyaAm is a modified form, for alleviation, from fiy^aAm. (M in art. fym.)
A^afoA=mN * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] The four parts whence the water pours forth, between the extremities of the cross-pieces of wood (AlEaraAqiY), of the leathern bucket. (Th, M.)

mufoA^amN * : see 4, first sentence. ― -b2- mazaAdapN mufoA^amapN [A leathern water-bag] widened with a third skin (T, M) between the two [other] skins: [see $aEiybN:] and in like manner dalowN mufoA^amapN [app. meaning a widened leathern bucket]. (M.) ― -b3- And siqaA='N mufoA^amN [A skin for water or milk] filled. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 4, last sentence.
mufaA^~amN * : see 4, first and last sentences.

div2.head: fAnyd and fAny*
div2.entryFree: faAniydN * and faAniy*N: see art. fnd.

div2.head: fA^w and fA^Y
div2.entryFree: 1 faA^awotu raA^osahu * , inf. n. faA^owN; and faA^ayotuhu, inf. n. faA^oYN; I split, or clave, his head, i. e. a man's, with the sword: (AZ, T, S, M:) or I struck, or smote, the upper part of his skull so that it opened from over his brain. (Lth, T.) ― -b2- And faA^ayotu AlqadaHa I split, or clave, or cracked, the bowl. (M.) And faA^awotuhu biAlEaSaA I smote, or struck, him with the staff, or stick. (IAar, M.) faA^owN and faA^oYN both signify The act of smiting, or striking: and the act of splitting, or cleaving. (K.)

4 AfA^Y *
He (a man, TA) lighted upon, or became in, what is termed a faA^ow: or he inflicted a wound of the head such as showed the whiteness of the bone, or such as laid bare the bone. (K, TA.)
5 ta1a2~a3a see the next following paragraph.

7 AnfA^Y *
It became split, or cloven, (S, M, K,) or cracked; (M, K;) said of a bowl [&c.]; (S, M;) as also ↓ tfA^~Y: (M, TA:) it opened, or became opened: (M, K:) it opened so as to form a break, or breach: (T, M, K:) it became laid open, uncovered, or exposed to view. (T, TA.)

faA^owN *
An interval, (S, M,) or a low, or depressed, place, (xafoD, so in one of my copies of the S,) between two mountains: (S, M:) and, accord. to Lh, (M,) a cleft (M, K) in a mountain, (M,) or between two mountains. (K.) And A waTo' [or depressed tract], (M, and so in copies of the K,) or waTiYo', (so in other copies of the K,) meaning soft, or smooth, or plain, place, (TA,) between two stony tracts of the kind whereof one is termed Har~ap. (M, K.) And, (M, K,) as some say, (M,) A clear, open, space among sands. (M, K.) And, (M, K,) accord. to As, (M,) A low, or depressed, tract of good land surrounded by mountains, (M, K,) and such as is of an elongated form, and such as is not of that form. (M.) And (as some say, TA) A narrow place in a valley, leading to a wide space, (K, TA,) of which the upper part has no place of exit. (TA.) And (as some say, TA) A smooth place. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also The night; (M, K;) so says Aboo-Leylà but of questionable correctness. (M.) ― -b3- And The place, or time, of sunset. (K.)

fiy^apN *
A party, portion, division, or distinct body; or a company, or congregated body; syn. firoqapN, (T,) or TaAy^ifapN, (S,) or jamaAEapN; (M, K;) of men: (T, M:) [see more in art. fyA^, to which it belongs accord. to some: accord. to others,] it is originally fiy^wap [app. fiy^owapN] (T) [or fiy^owN (see art. fyA^); or fiy^oYN or fiy^oyapN (see what follows)]; the p being a substitute for the [final radical letter, which is w or] Y: (S:) the pl. is fiy^uwna (S, M, K) and fiy^aAtN. (M, K.) El-Kumeyt says,
taraY minohu jamaAjimahumo fiy^iynaA
meaning [Thou wouldst see, in consequence thereof, their skulls become] scattered fragments. (S.)
faA^owaY * The head, or glans, of the penis. (M, K.)
faAy^iyapN * or faAy^iy~apN (accord. to different copies of the K) An elevated, expanded place. (K.)

AlfaAwaAniyaA *
i. q. Euwdu AlS~aliybi, [both of which appel-lations are now applied to The common peony, pæonia officinalis, and this is what is meant in what here follows,] i. e. the khynA, [app. for kahoyaAnaA, which is a Pers. word, meaning the plant above-mentioned,] a plant less than a cubit [in height], having a purple flower, not found except in the day of the sun's taking its abode in Libra; (TA;) [its root has, from ancient times, and in various countries, been held in high repute for medicinal properties; and various fancied virtues (some of which are supposed to be partly dependant upon particular aspects of the moon and certain stars, and several of which are mentioned
in the TA,) are ascribed to it:] it is hot, attenuant, resolutive, diuretic, has the property of stopping hæmorrhage, and is beneficial as a remedy against the niqoris [i. e. gout, or particularly podagra,] and epilepsy (AlS~aroE), even by its being suspended [on the patient]. (K.) [See also yaboruwHN, in art. brH.]

1 fat~a * , (S, M, O, Msb,) aor.
fatu3a , (M, Msb,) inf. n. fat~N, (Lth, T, M, Msb, K,) He crumbled a thing, or broke it into small pieces, with his fingers: (Lth, T, TA:) or he broke (a thing, M) with his fingers: (M, K:) or [simply] he broke a thing: (S, O:) or (M) he bruised, or brayed, (M, K,) a thing: (M:) and ↓ ft~t, (M, TA,) inf. n. tafotiytN, (O,) signifies the same; (M, TA;) or [rather] he broke [a thing, or crumbled it with his fingers,] much. (O.) You say of a man, fat~a Alxuboza, (A, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (Msb;) and ↓ ft~thu; He crumbled the bread with his fingers. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, *aA mim~aA yafut~u kabidiY (assumed tropical:) [lit. This is of what crumbles, or crushes, my liver; like as we say, “ of what breaks my heart ”]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And kal~amahu bi$aYo'K fafat~a fiY saAEidihi (assumed tropical:) He told him, or spoke to him, of a thing, and it [crushed, or] weakened, or enervated, him. (M, K, * TA.) And fat~a fiY EaDudiY wahad~a rukoniY (O, TA) (assumed tropical:) He broke my strength, and dispersed, or separated, my assistants. (TA.) And fat~a fiY EaDudi fulaAnK i. e. fiY A^aholi bayotihi (assumed tropical:) He sought to injure such a one by diminishing, or impairing, [in number or power,] the people of his house. (T, O. [See also art. EDd.]) The verb in this phrase is also used in the pass. form. (O.)
2 fat~a3a see the preceding paragraph, in two places.
5 tafat~a3a see the paragraph here following.

7 Anft~ *
It became crumbled, or broken into small pieces, with the fingers: (TA:) or it became broken with the fingers: (M, TA:) or [simply] it became broken: (S, O:) or it became bruised, or brayed: and ↓ tft~t signifies the same; (M, TA;) or [rather] it became broken [or crumbled with the fingers] much. (S, O.)

R. Q. 1 fatofatapN * [inf. n. of fatofata] The drinking, of camels, less than satisfies thirst. (O, K.) ― -b2- [And it is also trans.:] one says of a pastor, fatofata A_ibilahu He drove back his camels from the water when they had not satisfied their thirst. (IAar, T, O.) -A2- And fatofata A_ilayohi, inf. n. fatofatapN, He spoke secretly to him: one says, maA h`*ihi Ald~anodanapu waAlfatofatapu [What is this whispering, and secret speaking?]. (A, TA.)

fat~N *
A fissure in a rock: (IAar, T, O, K:) as also vat~N: (IAar, T:) pl. futuwtN. (IAar, T, O.) -A2- maA fiY yadiY minoka Hat~N walaA fat~N There is not in my hand, from thee, aught. (O.) -A3- A^uwl`y^ika A^aholu bayotK fat~K and ↓ fut~K (Fr, T, O, K *) and ↓ fit~K (Fr, T, K) Those are the people of a house dispersed, or scattered, (Fr, T, O, K. *)
fut~N * and fit~N: see what next precedes.

fat~apN * , (M, A, and so in some copies of the S,) or ↓ fut~apN, (so in other copies of the S,) or both, (K,) or the latter and ↓ fit~apN, (T, O,) The thing, (S, O,) or piece of dung, (T, M, A, K.) [i. e.] of dry dung, (CK,) of the camel, (T, M, A, K,) or of the horse or any solid-hoofed animal, (T,) that is broken, or crumbled, (S, M, A, O, K,) and put beneath the zanodap, (T, S, O,) or put beneath the zanod, on the occasion of striking fire, (M,) [i. e.] in which one strikes fire. (K.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN laA yusaAwiY fat~apF, meaning [Such a one is not worth] a crumbled piece of dung of the camel. (A.) ― -b2- Also, i. e. fat~apN and ↓ fut~apN, (K,) or the latter [only], (AA, T, O,) A kutolap [i. e. lump, or compact portion,] of dates. (AA, T, O, K.)
fut~apN * and fit~apN: see the next preceding paragraph; the former in two places.

futaAtN *
Broken bits or particles, (T, S, M, A, O, Msb, K,) and (A) such as have fallen off, (T, A,) of a thing, (S, O, Msb,) [as] of coloured wool, (T, A,) and of wool in general, (T,) and of musk, and [crumbs] of bread. (A.)
fatuwtN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

fatiytN *
i. q. ↓ mafotuwtN [i. e. Crumbled, or broken into small pieces, with the fingers: or broken with the fingers: or simply broken: or bruised, or brayed]; (T, S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ fatuwtN. (M, K.) ― -b2- And particularly, (Lth, T, S, M, A, Mgh, O, Msb,) and so ↓ fatuwtN, (S, M, A, Mgh, O,) Crumbled bread, (Lth, T, S, &c.,) like sawiyq. (A, Mgh.) ↓ fatiytapN has a more special signification than fatiytN, [being a n. un., meaning A mess of crumbled bread,] (Mgh, Msb,) and is said to be eaten by a woman in order that she may become fat. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And fatiytN signifies also A thing that falls, (Lth, T, M,) and becomes crumbled, (Lth, T,) or breaks off. (M.)
fatiytapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

bayonahumo fataAfitu *
Between them is secret speaking, [or between them are secret speakings, for fataAfitu is app. pl. of the inf. n. fatofatapN used as a simple subst., (see R. Q. 1,)] not heard nor understood [by others]. (O, K.)
mafotuwt * : see fatiytN.

1 maA fatiy^a * , (Fr, * T, Msb, K,) aor.
fataAa , (Fr, T, Msb;) and mA fataA^a, [aor.
fataAa ;] (K;) and mA fatuw^a, (Fr, * T, K,) aor.
fatuAa ; (Fr, T;) He did not cease [doing a thing; being incomplete, or non-attributive, verbs]; (T, Msb, K;) as also ↓ maA A^afotaA^a; (AZ, T, K;) this last of the dial. of Temeem; (AZ, T, M;) the first of the dial. of Keys and others: (AZ, T:) you say maA fatiy^otu A^a*okuruhu, (AZ, T, S, O, Msb, *) or maA fatiy^otu A^afoEalu, (M,) and mA fataA^otu, (AZ, T, S, O, M,) aor.
fataAa , inf. n. fato'N (AZ, T, M) and futuwo'N; (M;) and mA fatuw^otu, aor.
fatuAa ; (Fr, O;) and ↓ mA A^afotaA^otu; (AZ, T, S, M, O;) I did not cease [remembering him, or doing such a thing]: (AZ, T, S, M, O, Msb: *) these verbs are used only in negative phrases, in this sense; but sometimes the particle of negation is suppressed, it being, however, meant to be understood; (T, S, M;) as in taA@ll~`hi tafotaA^u ta*okuru yuwsufa, (T, S, O, K,) in the Kur [xii. 85], (T, S, O,) meaning maA tafotaA^u, (S, O, K,) thus in all the copies of the K [and in the S and O], but correctly laA tafotaA^u, [i. e. By God, thou wilt not cease remembering Joseph,] accord. to all the grammarians and the expositors of the Kur-án: (TA:) for the oath that is not accompanied by the sign of affirmation denotes negation. (Bd in xii. 85.) ― -b2- And fatiy^a Eanohu, (O, K,) inf. n. fato'N, (O,) He forgot it, and abstained, or desisted, from it; (nasiyahu waA@noqadaEa Eanohu, O, and so in some copies of the K; in other copies of the K Anq*E or Anf*g; [both of which are evidently mistranscriptions;]) namely, an affair, or event: (O, TA:) or this is used only in negative phrases. (K.) -A2- fataA^a, as a complete [i. e. an attributive] verb, signifies He stilled, quieted, or made to cease, syn. sak~ana, or, as some say, (TA,) he abated, or allayed, syn. kasara, and extinguished: thus says Ibn-Málik, as on the authority of Fr; and it is correct: AHei has erred in charging him with having committed a mistake: (K, TA:) for he says that it is a mistranscription for favaA^a, with the three-pointed v: it is mentioned also by IKoot and IKtt: and Fr states that one says, fataA^otuhu Eani AlA^amori meaning I made him to cease (sak~anotuhu) from the affair: and fataA^otu Aln~aAra meaning I extinguished the fire. (TA.)
4 A^afotaAa see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

1 fataHa * , (S, A, MA, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
fataHa , (K,) inf. n. fatoHN, (Msb,) He opened, (MA,) i. q. faraja, (Msb,) and [app. he unlocked,] contr. of A^agolaqa, (Msb, K,) a door; (S, A, MA, Msb;) and so ↓ ft~H, and ↓ AfttH; (K;) or you say ↓ fat~aHotu AlA^abowaAba [I opened the doors], this verb being with teshdeed to denote multiplicity [of the objects]; (S;) and ↓ AstftH signifies the same as ↓ AfttH; (S, * K;) i. e. each of these signifies he opened a door; (TK;) you say Al$~aYo'a ↓ AisotafotaHotu and ↓ AifotataHotuhu [I opened the thing; and the former signifies also I sought, or demanded, the opening of the thing]; (S, TA;) and AlbaAba ↓ jaA='a yasotafotiHu [He came opening the door; or seeking, or demanding, the opening of the door; the latter being the more obvious meaning]. (A, TA.) ― -b2-
[Hence,] one says, fulaAnN laA yufotaHu AlEayonu EalaY mivolihi [Such a one, the eye will not be opened upon the like of him]. (A.) ― -b3- And fataHotu AlqanaApa, inf. n. as above, I opened the conduit, in order that the water might run, and irrigate the seed-produce. (Msb.) ― -b4- And fataHa bayona rijolayohi [He made an opening between his legs; he parted his legs; like faraja bayonahumaA]. (S in art. rhw.) ― -b5- And fataHa A^aSaAbiEa rijolayohi [app. He parted his toes; if not a mistake for fataxa, as it seems probably to be from the fact of its being expl. as meaning] he inclined the ends of his toes towards the back, i. e. the upper part, of his foot. (Mgh.) ― -b6- fataHato, said of a she-camel, [and of a sheep or goat (see fatuwHN),] She had wide orifices to her teats; as also ↓ AftHt; (S, K;) and ↓ AfttHt. (TK: but this I do not find in the K.) ― -b7- [The following meanings are tropical.] ― -b8- fataHa, (A, Msb, TA,) inf. n. fatoHN; (K;) and ↓ AfttH; (K, TA;) (tropical:) [He laid open by invasion, to (EalaY) such a person, or such a people, (see an ex. voce TarafN,) i. e.] he conquered, won, or took by force, (Msb,) a country (A, Msb, K, TA) of the unbelievers, (A, TA,) or of a people with whom there was war. (K, TA.) ― -b9- [fataHahu lahu (assumed tropical:) He granted it, permitted it, allowed it, or made it to be unrestricted, to him. See Ksh and Bd in xxxv. 2.] ― -b10- fataHa Almu$okila (assumed tropical:) He explained, or made clear, that which was dubious, or confused. (Bd in vii. 87.) And AifotaHo sir~aka EalaY~a laA EalaY fulaAnK (tropical:) [Open, or reveal, thy secret to me; not to such a one]. (A, TA.) ― -b11- [Hence,] fataHa Ealayohi (tropical:) He taught him, informed him, or acquainted him. (TA.) [You say, fataHa Ealayohi bika*aA (assumed tropical:) He taught him such a thing, informed him of it, or acquainted him with it.] ― -b12- And hence, (TA,) (tropical:) [He prompted him; i. e.] he recited to him (namely, an Imám, A, Msb, or a reciter, A, TA) what he was unable to utter [by reason of forgetfulness], in order that he might know it. (Msb, TA. *) And fataHa EalaY mani A@sotaqoraA^ahu (tropical:) [He recited something to him who desired him to do so, the latter being unable to do it]. (TA.) ― -b13- And, said of God, (tropical:) He aided him against his enemy; or made him to be victorious, to conquer, or to overcome; syn. naSarahu. (A, Msb.) ― -b14- futiHa EalaY fulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one became fortunate; possessed of good fortune; favoured by the world, or by worldly circumstances. (A, TA.) ― -b15- fataHa A@ll~`hu Ealayohimo futuwHFA kaviyrapF (tropical:) is said of persons who have been rained upon [as meaning God bestowed upon them many, or abundant, first rains]. (A.) ― -b16- fataHa bayonahumo, (A,) or bayona Aln~aAsi, (Msb,) or bayona AlxaSomayoni, (K,) inf. n. fatoHN, (T, Msb, K,) and futaAHapN (S, * K) and fitaAHapN are syn. therewith [app. as inf. ns.], (K,) and futuwHapN and fitaAHN, (L,) in the dial. of Himyer, (TA,) He judged (T, Msb, K, TA) between them, (A,) or between the men, (Msb,) or between the two litigants. (K.) You say, AifotaHo bayonanaA Judge thou between us: (S:) thus in the Kur vii. 87. (TA.) And maA A^aHosana fitaAHatahu How good is his judging, or judgment ! (A.) ― -b17- [fataHa AlHarofa, a conventional phrase in grammar and lexicology, He pronounced the letter with the vowel-sound termed fatoH: and he marked the letter with the sign of that vowel-sound.]
2 ft~H * : see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- [Also, said of a medicine &c., It opened the bowels; acted as an aperient: and it removed obstructions: see the act. part. n.]

3 fAtHhu * [He addressed him first]. One says, Almuluwku laA tufaAtaHu biAlkalaAmi (tropical:) [Kings shall not be addressed first with speech]. (A.) ― -b2- And, (A, K, * TA,) inf. n. mufaAtaHapN and fitaAHN, (assumed tropical:) He commenced a dispute, debate, discussion, or controversy, with him: (TA:) or (tropical:) he summoned him to the judge, and litigated with him. (A, K, * TA.) ― -b3- And fAtHhu signifies also (tropical:) He bargained with him and gave him nothing: in the case of his giving him, one says fAtkhu. (IAar, TA; and O and K in art. ftk.) ― -b4- And fAtH (assumed tropical:) He compressed (K, TA) his wife. (TA.) ― -b5- [Also (assumed tropical:) He rendered a thing easy: ― -b6- and (assumed tropical:) He was liberal. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
4 A^afotaHa see 1, in the second quarter of the paragraph.

5 tafat~aHa see 7, in three places. [Hence,] tft~H Aln~aworu The blossom [or blossoms] opened. (MA.) And tft~H AlA^akim~apu Eani Aln~awori The calyxes burst open [from over the blossoms, so as to disclose them]. (TA.) ― -b2- [tft~H fiY AlkalaAmi is like our phrase (assumed tropical:) He showed off, or made an ostentatious display, in speech, or talk.] And you say, tft~H bimaA Einodahu mino maAlK A^awo A^adabK (L, in the K mino mulokK waA^adabK,) (assumed tropical:) He boasted of, or boasted himself in, or made a vain display of, what he had, or possessed, of wealth, or of good education, or polite accomplishments: (L, K: *) and tft~H bihi EalayonaA (assumed tropical:) He boasted of it, or boasted himself in it, against us. (L.)
6 tafaAtaHaA kalaAmFA bayonahumaA * (assumed tropical:) They two talked together with a suppressed voice, exclusively of others [i. e. so as not to be heard by others]. (K.)

7 AnftH * quasi-pass. of fataHa, said of a door, (S, A, Msb, TA,) It opened, or became opened or open; (Msb;) as also ↓ tft~H: (TA:) or the latter is quasi-pass. of fat~aHa, so that you say, AlA^abowaAbu ↓ tafat~aHati [The doors opened, or became opened or open]. (S.) ― -b2- And AnftH Eanohu It (anything) became removed from over it, or from before it, (i. e. another thing,) so as to disclose it, or expose it to view. (TA.) [And ↓ tft~H has a similar meaning, but is properly said of a number of things.]

8 A_ifotataHa see 1, first sentence, in three places; and again, in the second quarter of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- One says also, AfttH AlS~alaApa (tropical:) (A, MA) He opened, or commenced, prayer: (MA:) AifotitaAHu AlS~alaApi meaning (tropical:) The saying Aall~`hu A^akobaro the first time [in prayer, i. e., before the first recitation of the Opening Chapter of the Kur-án]. (TA.) And AifotataHotuhu bika*aA (assumed tropical:) I commenced it with such a thing. (Msb.) And maA A^aHosana maA A@fotutiHa EaAmunaA bihi (tropical:) [How good is that with which our year has commenced !]; said when the sign, or token, [or prognostic,] of plenty, or abundance of herbage, has appeared. (A, TA.)

10 A_isotafotaHa see 1, first sentence, in three places. ― -b2- A=tiY baAba Aljan~api faA^asotafotiHu is a saying of Mohammad, meaning I shall come to the gate of Paradise and seek, or demand, or ask for, the opening thereof. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer, the first of the trads. mentioned therein, and thus expl. in the margin of a copy of that work.) ― -b3- AstftHhu AlquroA=na (tropical:) He desired, or asked, him to explain the Kur-án. (MA.) ― -b4- AstftHhu AlA_imaAmu (tropical:) [The Imám desired, or asked, him to prompt him; i. e., to recite to him what he was unable to utter by reason of forgetfulness: see fataHa Ealayohi]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- And AstftH signifies also (assumed tropical:) He sought, desired, demanded, or asked, aid against an enemy, or victory. (S, Msb, K.) One says, AstftH bihimo (assumed tropical:) He sought, &c., aid, or victory, by means of them. (L, from a trad.) And AstftH A@ll~`ha (tropical:) (A, TA) He desired, or asked, God to grant aid, or victory, (TA,) lilomusolimiyna EalaY Alkuf~aAri [to the Muslims against, or over, the unbelievers]. (A.) ― -b6- Also (assumed tropical:) He sought, desired, demanded, or asked, judgment. (L.)

fatoHN * inf. n. of fataHa [q. v.]. (Msb, &c.) ― -b2- [As a subst.,] (tropical:) Conquest of a country: (K, TA:) pl. futuwHN (TA) [and pl. pl. futuwHaAtN]. yawomN AlfatoHi means particularly (assumed tropical:) The day of the conquest of Mekkeh: (L:) and also (assumed tropical:) The day of resurrection. (Mujáhid, L.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Aid against an enemy; or victory; syn. naSorN; as also ↓ fataAHapN. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Means of subsistence, with which God gives aid: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) The first of the rain called AlwasomiY~; (L, K;) as also ↓ fatuwHN [which see again in what follows]: (K:) or the first of any rain; as also ↓ futoHapN: (L:) pl. of the first futuwHN, (A,) or ↓ fatuwHN, with fet-h to the f, (L,) [see the mention of this voce fayoHN,] but MF strongly reprobates this latter form, and observes that faEuwlN as a pl. measure is absolutely unknown. (TA.) One says, A^aSaAbati AlA^aroDu futuwHN (tropical:) [First rains fell upon the land]. (A.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Water running (S, K, TA) from a spring or other source: (S, TA:) or water running upon the surface of the earth: (AHn, TA:) or water for which a channel is opened to a tract of land for its irrigation thereby: (L:) or a river, or rivulet, or canal of running water. (T, TA.) maA suqiYa biAlfatoHi fafiyhi AlEu$oru, and maA suqiYa fatoHFA, (L,) fatoHFA being here in the accus. case as an inf. n., i. e. maA futiHa A_ilayohi maA='u AlA^anohaAri fatoHFA, (Mgh, L, *) occurring in a trad., means In the case of that (relating to the several sorts of seed-produce, and palm-trees,) which is
irrigated by means of the channel opened to conduct to it the water of the river [or rivers], the tithe [of the produce shall be taken]. (L.) ― -b7- The place of insertion of the tang of the iron head that enters into the shaft of an arrow: (K, * TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b8- The fruit of the tree called naboE, resembling the Hab~ap xaDoraA=' [or fruit of the pistachia terebinthus], (K, TA,) except that it is red, sweet, and round; eaten by men. (TA.) ― -b9- [As a conventional term in grammar and lexicology, A certain vowel-sound, well-known: and ↓ fatoHapN signifies The sign of that vowel-sound.]

futuHN * a word of the measure fuEulN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (S.) You say baAbN futuHN A wide, open, door: (S, K:) or a large, wide, door. (Msb.) And qaAruwrapN futuHN A wide-headed bottle or flash: (S, K:) or a bottle, or flash, having neither a stopper nor a case: (Ks, S, Msb, K:) because, if so, it is open. (TA.)
fatoHapN * : see fatoHN, last sentence.

futoHapN *
An opening, or intervening space; syn. furojapN: pl. futaHN. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also fatoHN. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A boasting of, or boasting oneself in, or making a vain display of, what one has, or possesses, of wealth, or of good education, or polite accomplishments. (L, K, * TA.) One says, maA h`*ihi AlfutoHapu A@l~atiY A^aZoharotahaA (assumed tropical:) What is this boasting, &c., which thou hast exhibited? (L.) IDrd thinks it to be not [genuine] Arabic. (L.)

fatoHaY *
Gain, profit, or increase obtained in traffic; syn. riboHN; [so accord. to the L; accord. to the copies of the K, erroneously, riyHN i. e. “ wind; ”] mentioned by Az, on the authority of Ibn-Buzurj: a poet says,
A^akul~uhumu laA baAraka A@ll~`hu fiyhimu
A_i*aA *ukirato fatoHaY mina AlbayoEi EaAjibu
[Are all of them, (may God not bless them,) when gain arising from selling is mentioned, in a state of wonder?]. (L.)
fatuwHN * A she-camel having wide orifices to her teats; (S, K;) and so a ewe or a she-goat: pl. futoHN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also fatoHN, in two places.
fataAHapN * : see fatoHN, fourth sentence.

futaAHapN * [see 1, near the end]. -A2- AlfutaAHapu, thus in the L and other lexicons, without Y after the H, but in the K ↓ AlfutaAHiyapu, there said to be with damm and without teshdeed, (TA,) A certain bird, different from that called Alfat~aAHu, (K, TA,) tinged with redness. (TA.)

fitaAHapN * [see 1, near the end]. ― -b2- [As a subst.,] (tropical:) The office of judge: one says, fulaAnN wul~iYa AlfitaAHapa (tropical:) Such a one was appointed to the office of judge. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And [(tropical:) Litigation, or altercation:] one says, bayonahumaA fitaAHaAtN (tropical:) Between them two are litigations, or altercations. (A, TA.)
AlfutaAHiyapu * : see AlfutaAHapu.

fat~aAHN * [An opener: and an unlocker. ― -b2- And hence, (assumed tropical:) A conquerer. ― -b3- And], in the dial. of Himyer, (TA,) (tropical:) A judge; one who decides between litigants: (S, Msb, K, TA:) it is like ↓ faAtiHN, but [this signifies simply judging, and the former] has an intensive signification. (Msb.) Alfat~aAHu, as an epithet applied to God, in the Kur xxxiv. 25, means (assumed tropical:) The Judge: or, accord. to IAth, (assumed tropical:) the Opener of the gates of sustenance and of mercy to his servants. (TA.) ― -b4- bayotN fat~aAHN means A wide, or an ample, house or tent. (El-Fáïk, TA.) ― -b5- And Alfat~aAHu signifies A certain bird, (K,) which is black, and which moves about its tail much, or often; white in the base of the tail, beneath it; and there is a sort thereof red; (TA;) also called A^um~u EajolaAna: (O in art. Ejl:) pl. fataAtiyHu, (K,) to which is added in the K, “ without A and l; ” but there is no reason why it should not have Al prefixed to it; and perhaps it should be correctly “ without A and t, ” i. e. it is not pluralized with A and t [as an affix to the sing.], as in the L &c. (MF, TA.)
faAtiHN * [Opening: &c.]: see fat~aAHN.

faAtiHapN * (tropical:) The commencement, or first part, of a thing: (S, A, * K:) pl. fawaAtiHu. (A.) faAtiHapu AlkitaAbi, (Msb,) or faAtiHapu AlquroA=ni, (TA,) [and simply AlfaAtiHapu, (assumed tropical:) The opening chapter, or exordium, of the Kur-án,] is [said to be] so called because the recitation in prayer is commenced therewith. (Msb.) One says also, qaraA^a faAtiHapa Als~uwrapi waxaAtimatahaA (tropical:) He recited the first part, or portion, of the chapter of the Kur-án and its last part, or portion. (A.) And fawaAtiHu AlquroA=ni signifies (tropical:) The first parts, or portions, of the chapters of the Kur-án. (K, TA.) [See also mufotataHN.]

mafotaHN *
A place in which things are reposited, stowed, laid up, kept, preserved, or guarded; a repository; syn. xizaAnapN and maxozanN: [and a hoard; syn. xaziynapN:] and treasure; or buried property; syn. kanozN: (K, TA:) pl., in both senses, mafaAtiHu. (TA.) The pl. as occurring in the Kur xxviii. 76 is said to signify treasures or buried property (kunuwz) and hoards (xazaAy^in [as pl. of xaziynapN, not of xizaAnapN]): or hoards (xazaAwy^n) of wealth, which Az says is the most probable meaning: (L, TA:) or it there means keys, as pl. of ↓ mifotaHN; (Ksh, Bd;) and it is said that they were of skins, of the measure of the finger, and were borne upon sixty mules, (Ksh, L, TA,) or seventy; but this is not a valid explanation. (L, TA.)
mifotaHN * see the next preceding paragraph, and the next but one following; the latter in two places. ― -b2- Also A conduit (qanaAp) of water. (TA.)

[
mufat~iHN * , applied to a medicine &c., Aperient; having the property of opening the bowels: and mufat~iHN lils~udadi deobstruent; having the property of removing obstructions.]

mifotaAHN * (S, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ mifotaHN (Msb, K) A key; an instrument with which a lock is opened; (Msb;) [a key] of a door; and of anything that is closed, or locked; (S;) an instrument for opening, (K, TA,) i. e. anything with which a thing is opened: (TA:) pl. of the former mafaAtiyHu and mfaAtiHu, said by Akh to be similar to A^amaAniY~u and A^amaAnK; (S;) or mfAtyH is pl. mifotaAHN, and mfAtH is pl. of ↓ mifotaHN [as well as of mafotaHN]. (Msb.) ― -b2- mifotaAHuhaA AlT~uhuwru, said by the Prophet, in relation to prayer, means (tropical:) That which is as though it were the key thereof is the thing [or water] with which one purifies himself; being the means of removing the legal impurity that prevents one's addressing himself boldly to the act of prayer. (Msb.) ― -b3- And A^uwitiytu mafaAtiyHa Alkalimi, or mafaAtiHa Alkalimi, accord. to different relaters, occurring in a trad., i. e. I have been given the keys of words, means [I have been given] an easy faculty, granted by God, for the acquirement of eloquence and chasteness of speech, and the attaining to the understanding of obscure meanings, and novel and admirable kinds of knowledge, and the beauties of expressions and phrases, which are closed against others, and difficult to be learnt by them. (L.) ― -b4- And AlmifotaAHu signifies also (assumed tropical:) A certain brand upon the thigh and neck (K, TA) of a camel, in the form of what is [properly] thus called. (TA.)

mafotuwHN * An opened, or unclosed, [and an unlocked,] door. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And (assumed tropical:) A light, or bright, colour; a meaning probably post-classical. ― -b3- For other significations, see its verb.]
mafaAtiyHu * , (unparalleled [in form] among sing. words, MF,) applied to a she-camel, Fat: pl. mafaAtiyHaAtN: (K:) mentioned by Seer.(TA.)

mufotataHN * is an inf. n. [signifying The act of opening and commencing &c.]: and a n. of place and of time [signifying a place of opening and commencing &c. and a time thereof: and also the opening portion of the Kur-án; as shown voce xaAtamN, q. v.]: and is a commonly-known and chaste word: though it has been said that muxotatamN [which has the contr. significations] is not a chaste word: (TA in the present art.:) this, however, is not correct; for it is a chaste word, and of frequent occurrence. (TA in art. xtm.)

yawomN munofatiHN baAlmaA='i * (tropical:) A day [of clouds] bursting, or opening vehemently, with rain. (A.) ― -b2- AlHuruwfu AlmunofatiHapu (assumed tropical:) The letters of which the utterance requires the opening of [that part of the mouth which is called] the Hanak; (TA;) all the letters of the alphabet except S, D, T, and Z. (K, TA.)

1 fatixa * , [aor.
fataxa ,] inf. n. fataxN, He, or it, had
one, or another, of the qualities denoted by the following explanations of fataxN: (L:) the primary signification is softness, or suppleness: (As, S, L:) in a man, it is width, or breadth, and softness, or suppleness, of the hand and foot: (S:) or it signifies laxness, and softness, or suppleness, (L, K,) and width, or breadth, (L,) in the joints: (L, K:) or softness, or suppleness, in the joints &c.: (L:) or width, or breadth, and length, of the hand and foot: (L, K:) and in a lion, it is width, or breadth, of the claws, and softness, or suppleness, of the joints: (L:) in camels, i. q. TaraqN [i. e. weakness in the knees; &c.; as inf. n. of Tariqa, q. v., the having weakness in the knees; &c.]; (L;) or in camels it is the like of TaraqN: (K, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, Taroq:]) and in the legs, or hind legs, (fiY Alr~ijolayoni,) it is length of the bone, and paucity of the flesh. (L.) -A2- fataxa, (T, S, A, Mgh, K,) aor.
fataxa , (TK,) inf. n. fatoxN; (S, TA;) and ↓ ft~x, (K,) inf. n. tafotiyxN; (TA;) He made [or spread] wide his A^aSaAbiE [here meaning toes], and made them lax: (K:) or he bent, and made supple, his toes in his sitting [in prayer]: (S:) or he bent his toes towards the sole of the foot in prostration; so accord. to Yahyà Ibn-Sa'eed: (TA:) or he (a person [sitting] in the act of Alt~a$ah~ud [q. v.]) made his toes supple, and pressed the joints thereof towards the sole of the foot: (A:) or he bent his toes towards the upper side of the foot, (T, Mgh, TA,) not towards the sole thereof. (T, TA.) [See also fataHa.]
2 fat~axa see the preceding paragraph, latter half.

4 Aftx *
He (a man, TA) was, or became, fatigued, (K,) or relaxed and fatigued, (TA,) and out of breath. (K, TA.)

5 tafat~axato * is said of a woman [as meaning She put on, or wore, a ring of the kind termed fataxap, or rings such as are termed fatax]. (A: in which it is added, wakaAnato nisaAw^uhumo yatafat~axona fiY A^aSaAbiEihin~a AlEa$ori [And their women used to wear fatax upon their ten fingers or toes; i. e. upon all their fingers and the thumbs or upon all their toes].)

fataxN * : see fataxapN. ― -b2- Also Any [little bell such as is termed] julojul, (K,) thus in all the copies of the K that we have, but in the L any xaloxaAl [i. e. anklet], (TA,) that does not make a sound. (K, TA.) -A2- And The inner side of the part between the upper arm and the fore arm; as also ↓ fataxapN. (TA.)
fatoxapN * : see what next follows.

fataxapN * (S, L, K, &c.) and ↓ fatoxapN, (K,) the latter disapproved by MF, but mentioned by more than one of the leading authorities respecting strange words, (TA,) A xaAtam [here improperly used as meaning simply ring] without a stone, or gem: (A:) or a ring (Haloqap) of silver without a stone, or gem; if having in it a stone, or gem, it is called xaAtamN: or a xaAtam [meaning ring] (L, K) of large size, (K,) upon [a finger of] the hand and [upon a toe of] the foot, (L, K,) with, and without, a stone, or gem: (L:) or a ring (Haloqap), (L, K,) of silver, (K,) worn on the A_iSobaE [i. e. finger], (L,) like a xaAtam: (L, K:) pl. ↓ fataxN [or rather this is a coll. gen. n. of which fataxapN is the n. un.] (S, A, L, K) and fataxaAtN (S, L, K) and futuwxN (L, K) and fitaAxN: (L:) the women sometimes put them upon their toes: (S:) or they are properly upon the toes: (IB:) the women of the Time of Ignorance used to put them upon their Ea$or [i. e. ten fingers or toes]. (L.) -A2- See also fataxN.
futuwxN * The joints of the claws of the lion. (K.) ― -b2- And a pl. of fataxapN [q. v.]. (L, K.)

A^afotaxu *
Having the quality termed fataxN [expl. in the first sentence of this art.]: as an epithet applied to a man, wide, or broad, in the hand and foot, with softness, or suppleness: (S:) or it signifies lax, or relaxed, and soft, or supple, and wide, or broad, in the joints: or soft, or supple, in the joints &c.: (L:) and, applied to a lion, wide, or broad, in the fore and hind feet, with softness, or suppleness: (L, K: *) fem. fatoxaA='u: and pl. futoxN.
