(A, O, L, K.) ― -b3- Hulibati Aln~aAqapu fiY faxi*ihaA is a phrase mentioned by Fr, meaning (assumed tropical:) [The she-camel was milked] in her half-month [app. at the period commencing half a month after her parturition]. (O.)
faxo*aA='u * A woman that holds a man firmly between her thighs, (Msb, K, TA,) by reason of her strength. (TA.)
mafoxuw*N * A man hit, or hurt, in his thigh: (M, L:) or whose thigh is broken. (A.)

1 faxara * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faxara , (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. faxorN (S, O, Msb, K) and faxarN (S, O, K) and faxaArN, (K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) or it is a mistake for fixaArN, accord. to some, and this may be an inf. n. either of faxara, for there are many instances of the same kind, or of faAxara, (MF,) or faxaArN, with fet-h, is post-classical, and therefore not allowable, (Th, O,) and faxaArapN and fix~iyraY and fix~iyraA='u; (K;) and ↓ Aftxr; (S, O, Msb, K;) and ↓ tfAxr; (L in art. ftH;) [He gloried, or boasted; i. e.] he gloried in, boasted of, boasted himself in, or praised or commended himself for, certain properties, or particular qualities: (K:) he enumerated, or recounted, the particulars of his ancestral nobility or eminence, or his own glorious or honourable deeds or qualities: (S, TA:) or he arrogated to himself greatness and nobility: (TA:) or he contended for superiority by reason of honours arising from memorable deeds or qualities, and from parentage or relationship, and other things relating to himself or to his ancestors: (Msb:) or he contended for superiority by reason of things extrinsic to himself, such as wealth, and rank or station. (TA.) You say faxarotu bihi [I gloried in it, or by reason of it; &c.]. (Msb.) And ↓ tfAxr bimaA Einodahu He gloried in, boasted of, or boasted himself in, what he possessed. (L in art. ftH.) And faxara baEoDuhumo EalaY baEoDK One party of them boasted against another [bika*aA in such a thing or quality &c.]. (K.) ― -b2- Also faxara, inf. n. faxorN, He magnified himself by boasting. (TA.) ― -b3- faAxarahu fafaxarahu, (S, O, K,) aor.
faxura , (O, K, [in two copies of the S written
faxara , contrary to analogy in a verb signifying surpassing in a contest, accord. to most of the grammarians,]) inf. n. faxorN: (S:) see 3. ― -b4- faxara fulaAnN Alyawoma EalaY fulaAnK fiY Al$~arafi waAljaladi waAlomanoTiqi Such a one excelled to-day such a one in nobleness and hardiness and speech. (ISk, TA.) ― -b5- faxira, aor.
faxara , (O, K,) inf. n. faxarN, (TA,) He disdained, or scorned. (IAar, O, K, TA.) ― -b6- faxarahu Ealayohi: see 4.
2 fax~ara see 4.

3 faAoxara ↓ faAxarahu fafaxarahu, (ISk, S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. of the former mufaAxarapN (Msb, K) and fixaArN, (K,) [and aor. of the latter
faxura , or, accord. to some,
faxara , (see 3 in art. xSm,)] He vied, or competed, with him, or contended with him for superiority, in faxor [i. e. glorying, or boasting, &c., or in glory, or excellence, i. e. he emulated, or rivalled, him therein, and he surpassed him, or overcame him, therein; and, simply, he vied with him, and surpassed him]: (Msb, * K:) or he contended with him for superiority in generousness or nobleness of father and mother: (ISk, S:) and he surpassed him, or overcame him, therein. (ISk, S, Msb, K.)

4 Afgrhu Ealayohi * ; (ISk, S, O, K;) and ↓ fx~rhu Elyh, inf. n. tafoxiyrN; (ISk, S, O;) or Elyh ↓ faxarahu, aor.
faxara , (AZ, O, * K,) inf. n. faxorN; (AZ, O, TA;) He judged him, or made him, to excel, or to have excelled, him in faxor [or glorying, or boasting, or glory, or excellence]. (ISk, S, O, K.) ― -b2- A^afoxarato She (a woman) brought forth none but such as was faAxir [or goodly, &c.]. (Lth, O.)

5 tfx~r * (S, TA) and ↓ tfAxr (TA) He magnified himself; he was, or became, proud, haughty, or disdainful; syn. of the inf. n. of the former taEaZ~umN, and takab~urN; (S, TA;) and that of the latter taEaAZumN. (TA.)

6 tfAxrwA * [They vied, or competed, or contended for superiority, one with another, in faxor, i. e., glorying, or boasting, or in glory, or excel-lence, i. e. they emulated, or rivalled, one another therein; and, simply, they vied, one with another;] they boasted together, one party against another. (S, * K.) tfAxrwA fiymaA bayonahumo They boasted among themselves of their several causes of boasting. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places; and 5.
8 A_ifotaxara see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] Aftxrt zawaAxiruhu (tropical:) [Its herbs] became tall. (A, TA.)

10 Astfxrhu *
He bought it faAxirFA [i. e. of a good, a goodly, or an excellent, quality], namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, (Lth, O,) or a thing. (K.) And in like manner the verb is used in relation to the giving [and app. the taking] in marriage. (O.)

faxorN * [Glory: excellence: originally an inf. n.: as also fuxorapN.] You say Ealayohimo ↓ A_in~ahu la*uw fuxorapK, i. e. faxorK [Verily he possesses glory, or excellence, above them: or perhaps the meaning of this phrase may be verily he has a disposition to boast himself against them]: and h`*aA ↓ maA laka fuxorapu, i. e. faxoruhu [Thou hast not the glory, or excellence, of this]. (Lh, TA.)
fuxorN * and fuxurN Thickness of an udder, with contractedness of the orifices of the teats, and with paucity of milk. (TA.)
fuxorapN * : see faxorN, in two places.
fixorapN * [A manner of glorying, or boasting]. You say faxara fixorapF HasanapF [He gloried, or boasted, in a good manner]. (Lh, TA.)
faxaArN * [said in the Msb to be a simple subst.: see 1].

faxuwrN * : see faAxirN. ― -b2- Also A she-camel great in the udder, contracted in the orifices of the teats: (As, S, O:) or great in the udder, having little milk; (K, TA;) and likewise applied to a ewe or she-goat: or that yields thee what she has of milk, and has nothing remaining thereof. (TA.) ― -b3- And A thick udder, contracted in the orifices of the teats, and having little milk: (K, TA:) erroneously repeated in the K among words ending with z. (TA.) ― -b4- And A palm-tree great in the trunk, thick in the branches. (S, O, K.) ― -b5- Also, and ↓ fayoxarN, (O, K,) which is likewise with z, (TA,) both applied to a horse, (O, K,) and the latter to a man also, (O,) Great in the yard, (O, K,) and long therein: (K:) and the latter, applied
to a penis, great; mentioned by IDrd as with z: (TA:) and the pl. is fayaAxiru. (K, TA.)

faxiyrN * One who vies, or competes, or contends, with another in glorying, or boasting, &c., (O, K,) or for superiority in generousness or nobleness of father and mother; (S;) i. q. mufaAxirN; (K;) like xaSiymN (S, TA) in the sense of muxaASimN. (TA.) You say jaA='a fulaAnN faxiyrF vum~a rajaEa A^axiyrFA [Such a one came contending with others in glorying, or boasting, &c.: then returned last, or meanest]. (A.) ― -b2- Also Overcome in faxor [i. e. glorying, or boasting, &c.]. (K.)

fax~aArN *
Baked pottery; baked vessels of clay: (Msb, voce xazafN:) or baked clay: before it is baked, it is called xazafN and SaloSaAlN: (Msb in the present art.:) or i. q. xazafN: (S, O, K:) or a kind of xazaf of which earthen vessels, or jars, mugs, &c., are made: (TA:) or earthen vessels; vessels made of potters' clay: pl. of [or rather a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is] fax~aArapN. (K.)
fix~iyrN * : see the paragraph here following.
fix~iyrapN * : see the paragraph here following.
fix~iyraA='u * : see the paragraph here following.

faAxirN * an epithet from faxara in the first of the senses expl. above; as also ↓ faxuwrN: (K:) [the former signifies Glorying; boasting; &c.: and the latter, the same as] ↓ fax~iyrN one who glories, or boasts, much; (S, O, TA;) as also ↓ fix~iyraA='u: (O, TA:) and ↓ fix~iyrapN one who glories, or boasts, very much. (O, * TA.) ― -b2- A thing, (S, O, Msb,) or anything, (K,) [superb, grand; as though glorying, or boasting;] good; goodly; excellent; of excellent quality. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Dates not yet ripe (busorN) that grow large, and have no stones: (S, O, K:) as though they boasted against others. (TA.)
fayoxarN * : see faxuwrN, last sentence.

faAxuwrN *
A species of sweet-smelling plants; (S, TA;) i. q. rayoHaAnu Al$~uyuwxi; (K, TA;) thus called by the people of El-Basrah; accord. to AHn, the marow [or marum] having broad leaves; and said to be that of which there have come forth, in its midst, jamaAmiyH [pl. of jum~aAHN, q. v.], like foxes' tails, with a red, sweet-smelling blossom in the middle thereof: the physicians assert that it cuts short the [sleep termed] subaAt. (TA.) ― -b2- [A meaning assigned by Golius to this word belongs to funaAxirapN.]

mafoxarapN * and mafoxurapN A thing in which one glories, or boasts himself; (K;) a cause of glorying or boasting; a generous quality or action, or a generous quality that is inherited by generation from generation; syn. maA^ovarapN: (S, O:) pl. mafaAxiru. (Msb.)

1 faxuma * , aor.
faxuma , (S, M, K, &c.,) inf. n. faxaAmapN, (S, &c.,) He (a man, S) was, or became, large, big, bulky, or thick. (S, M, K, &c.) ― -b2- And He was, or became, great in respect of estimation, rank, or quality. (So accord. to an explanation of the inf. n. in the KL [agreeably with an explanation of the epithet faxomN].) See also mufax~amN, below. ― -b3- And one says also faxuma AlA^amoru [meaning Great in estimation is the thing or affair or event or case!]. (K in art. bx, in which see baxo.)

2 tafoxiymN * is syn. with taEoZiymN [as signifying The magnifying a man, honouring him, or treating him with respect or reverence or veneration]: (S, K, TA:) one says, A^atayonaA fulaAnFA fafax~amonaAhu meaning [We came to such a one] and we magnified him, or honoured him, and paid him high respect: and ↓ tfx~mhu signifies [the same as fx~mhu, i. e.] He magnified him, or honoured him, &c.; syn. A^ajal~ahu, and EaZ~amahu. (TA.) ― -b2- tafoxiymu AlHarofi is the contr. of A_imaAlatuhu [i. e. it signifies The pronouncing of the word with the broad sound of the lengthened fet-h (approaching to the sound of “ a ” in our word “ ball ”)]: (S:) [and also with a full sound of the letter l:] or Alt~afoxiymu is the abstaining from AlA_imaAlap; (K, and Kull p. 127;) and the contr. of Alt~aroqiyqu; i. e. i. q. Alt~agoliyZu; and signifies the inclining of A towards the place of utterance of w, as in the word AlS~alawpu; and the uttering of l from the lower part of the tongue [i. e. with the tongue turned up], as in the word Aall~`h [i. e. in the word All~`h not immediately preceded by a kesreh]: (Kull ubi suprà:) it is [predominantly] peculiar to the people of El-Hijáz, like as AlAmAlp is to the tribe of Temeem. (TA.) -A2- See also what next follows.

5 tafax~ama [tfx~m signifies He magnified, or aggrandized, himself; as is shown by a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. fyl; in which verse it is said in the M that ↓ fax~amuwA means tafax~amuwA. -A2- And it is also trans., like 2:] see 2, first sentence.

faxomN * [seems to signify primarily Large, big, bulky, or thick. And hence,] A man having much flesh in the balls, or elevated parts, of the cheeks. (TA.) ― -b2- [And predominantly,] Great in estimation, rank, or quality; (S, K, TA;) applied to a man: (S, TA:) pl. fixaAmN: the fem. is faxomapN. (TA.) And it is likewise applied to Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect or honour]. (TA.) ― -b3- And to speech, or diction, (manoTiq,) meaning Strong; sound, or correct; or chaste, clear, or eloquent, and comprehensive; syn. jazolN. (S, K.)
faxomapN * fem. of faxomN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A great army or military force. (TA.)

fuxamiy~apN * , like juhaniy~apN, (so in the JK, K, and TA, [in the CK and my MS. copy of the K fuxayomap, like juhayonap,]) Self-magnification, pride, or haughtiness, and assumption of superiority. (JK, K, TA.)

fayoxamaAnN *
A person of authority, (TA,) one held in honour, from whose judgment events are made to proceed, and without whom no affair is decided. (K, TA. [In the explanation of this word in the CK, yaSoduru is a mistranscription for yuSodaru.])

A^afoxamu *
i. q. A^aEoZamu [as meaning Most, or very, great in estimation, rank, or quality; applied to a man]. (TA.)

mufax~amN * , occurring in a trad., as an epithet applied to the Prophet, means Magnified, honoured, or regarded with respect or reverence or veneration, in the minds and the eyes [of others: and so it means when applied in a general manner]: not largeness in his bodily make: or, as some say, it means [characterized by] ↓ faxaAmap in his face, [i. e.] its nobleness, and fulness, with beauty, or comeliness, and a quality inspiring reverence or veneration. (TA.)

1 fad~a * , aor.
fadi3a , inf. n. fadiydN (As, T, S, M, L, K) and fad~N, (M, L,) He (a man, As, S) uttered his voice, called out, cried out, or vociferated: (As, S, M, A, L, K:) or did so vehemently: (T, M, L, K:) or raised his voice; (TA;) and so ↓ fadofada, said of a man, and of a camel: (L:) or they (a number of sheep or goats) made a sound by running: or made a sound by running with their pastors and those driving them with singing: (K:) or he, or it, made a sound like that termed HafiyfN; (Lth, T, M, K;) as also ↓ fadofada, inf. n. fadofadapN: (M, L, K: *) and he (a man) ran, making a sound by his running. (L.) ― -b2- fad~a, aor.
fadi3a , inf. n. fadiydN, It (a bird) moved, or flapped, (Hav~a,) its wings, expanding and contracting them. (M.) ― -b3- He ran, (K, TA,) fleeing. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1.] ― -b4- fad~ati AlA_ibilu The camels crushed the ground with their feet, by the vehemence of their tread. (M, L.) And fad~a, aor.
fadi3a , inf. n. fad~N and fadiydN; (L;) and ↓ fadofada; (M, L;) He (a man) trod vehemently upon the ground, by reason of exultation, and briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (M, L.) [See also 2.] -A2- huwa yafud~uniY wayaEud~uniY means He threatens me. (K, TA.)

2 fd~d * , inf. n. tafodiydN, He cried out, or vociferated, or did so vehemently, in buying or selling. (IAar, T, L, K.) ― -b2- And He (a man) walked upon the ground proudly and exultingly. (IAar, T, L, K. *)
R. Q. 1 fadofada * , inf. n. fadofadapN: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Also He (a man, TA) ran, fleeing from an enemy or a beast of prey. (T, L, K.) [See also 1, latter half.]
fudaAdN * : see fad~aAdN, last sentence.
fadiydN * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. -A2- Also Abundance of camels. (M, L.) ― -b2- And A_ibilN fadiydN Many camels. (M, L.)
fudaAdapN * and fadaAdapN: see the next paragraph, last two sentences, in three places.

fad~aAdN *
Having a strong, or loud, voice, (S, M, A, L, K,) and rude, coarse, or uncivil, in speech; (L, K;) as also ↓ fudofudN and ↓ fudafidN. (Lh, M, L,
K.) ― -b2- Having a vehement tread. (M, L, K.) Hence, in a trad., qado kunota tamo$iY fawoqiY fad~aAdFA i. e. [Thou usedst to walk upon me] treading vehemently, as said by the earth, (M, L,) to a dead man buried in it. (L.) ― -b3- Proud, (K, TA,) and exulting. (TA.) ― -b4- And Possessing camels in number from two hundred (in some copies of the K [and in a copy of the T] from hundreds, TA) to a thousand, (AO, T, Nh, L, K,) and therewithal rude, coarse, or uncivil, and proud. (AO, T.) ― -b5- Pl. fad~aAduwna. (L, K, &c.) ― -b6- The pl. occurs in a trad., in the saying, A_in~a AljafaA'a waAlqasowapa fiY Alfad~aAdiyna, (T, S, L,) meaning [Verily rudeness, or coarseness, and hardness, are in] the men whose voices are high, or loud, in their corn-fields and among their cattle: (El-Ahmar, As, T, S, L, K:) or (in the K “ and ”) the tenders of camels, and pastors, and tenders of oxen and of asses: (Th, T, K:) or (in the K “ and ”) the tillers of the ground; (M, A, Mgh, K, TA;) because they vociferate in their corn-fields: (A, Mgh:) or (in the K “ and ”) the people of the deserts; (M, K, TA;) the men who dwell in the fadaAfid [pl. of fadofadN, q. v.]; (MF;) because of the roughness of their voices, and their rudeness, or coarseness: (M:) or (in the K “ and ”) the possessors of many camels. (M, K, TA.) [See also art. fdn.] ― -b7- ↓ Alfad~aAdapu signifies The frog: (A, K:) so called because of its croaking. (A.) ― -b8- Also, ↓ fad~aAdapN, (IAar, Th, M, L, K,) and ↓ fudaAdapN, (IAar, L,) or ↓ fadaAdapN, (M, K,) A cowardly man. (IAar, Th, M, L, K.) ― -b9- Also, ↓ fad~aAdapN, (L,) or ↓ fudaAdapN, (M, K,) A certain bird: (M, L, K:) n. un. of fad~aAdF, (L,) or ↓ fudaAdu. (M.)
fad~aAdapN * : see the last three sentences of the next preceding paragraph.

fadofdN *
A desert, or waterless desert, (T, M, L, K,) wherein is nothing: (T, M, L:) or an even tract of land: (S, L, K:) or a spacious and pebbly tract of land: (A:) or a rugged and pebbly tract of land: or a hard place: (M, L:) or a hard and rugged place: (K:) or an elevated place (As, T, L, K) in which is hardness: (As, T, L:) pl. fadaAfidu. (L.)
fudfdN * : see fad~aAdN, first sentence.

fudafidN * : see fad~aAdN, first sentence. -A2- Also Thick milk: (IAar, T:) or i. q. hudabidN, (K,) which signifies very thick milk: (S and L and K in explanation of the latter:) or both signify sour and thick milk. (T and L in explanation of the latter.)

1 fadaHahu * , (S, A, K,) aor.
fadaHa , (K,) inf. n. fadoHN, (TA,) It (a debt, S, A, K, and an affair, and a load, TA) burdened him, burdened him heavily, oppressed him, or overburdened him: (S, A, K:) ↓ AfdHpu [in this sense], said of debt, has not been heard from any one in the correctness of whose Arabic speech confidence is placed. (S.)
4 A^afodaHa see the preceding paragraph: ― -b2- and that here following.

10 AstfdHpu *
He deemed it (i. e. an affair [&c.]) burdensome, heavily burdening, oppressive, or overburdening: (A, TA:) or he found it to be so; as also ↓ AfdHp. (K.)
AfdHhu * A debt, (A,) or an affair, (S, K,) [or a load, (see 1,)] burdening, burdening heavily, oppressing, or overburdening. (S, A, K.)

fAadiHapN *
A misfortune, an affliction, or a calamity: [pl. fawaAdiHu:] fawaAdiHu Ald~ahori signifies the afflictions, or calamities, of fortune. (K, * TA.)
mufodaHN * : see the following paragraph.
mafoduwHN * A man burdened, heavily burdened, oppressed, or overburdened, by debt, or by an affair, or by a load: (S, * L, TA:) ↓ mufodaHN in this sense is not allowable. (L.)

1 fadaxa raA^osahu * , aor.
fadaxa , (K, TA,) inf. n. fadoxN, (TA,) He broke his head with a stone: (K, TA:) and fadaxotu Al$~aYo'a I broke the thing: (TA:) [but] the verb is not used except in relation to a thing in which is moisture. (K, TA.)

1 fadara * , (Lth, IAar, T, S, M, O, K,) aor.
fadura , (M,) or
fadira , (O, K,) inf. n. fuduwrN (Lth, T, S, M, O, K) and fadorN; (K;) and ↓ fd~r, (IAar, T, O, K,) inf. n. tafodiyrN; (O;) and ↓ Afdr; (IAar, T, O, K;) said of a stallion, (IAar, T, S, &c.,) primarily of a stallion-camel, (IAar, T,) He desisted from covering; (IAar, T, S, O;) or he desisted from covering, being wearied by much indulging therein: (S, O:) or he flagged, or became remiss, or languid, in covering, (Lth, T, M, K,) and desisted therefrom: (M, K:) the w in fadara, thus used, may be a substitute for the t in fatara: (O:) accord. to IAth, it signifies he lacked power, or ability, to cover. (TA.) ― -b2- fadara, inf. n. fuduwrN, said of a mountain-goat, He became such as protected himself in the mountain from the hunter: or he became large, or big, and advanced in age, or full-grown; thus says IKtt. (TA.) ― -b3- And fadara said of cooked flesh-meant, (K, TA,) inf. n. fuduwrN, (TA,) It became cold. (K, TA.) -A2- fadira, aor.
fadara , inf. n. fadarN, He was, or became, foolish, stupid, or unsound in intellect or understanding. (TA.)
2 fad~ara see 1, first sentence. -A2- h`*ihi HijaArapN tufad~aru means These are stones that break into small and large pieces. (O, K.)
4 A^afodara see 1, first sentence.
5 tfd~r * , said of a stone, It, being struck, broke in pieces. (TA.)
fadarN * : see faAdirN, in two places.

fadirN *
Foolish, stupid, or unsound in intellect or understanding. (S, M, O, K.) ― -b2- And Wood that quickly [or easily] breaks. (O, K.)

fidorapN *
A piece of flesh-meat: (M, K:) or a compact piece thereof: (As, T, S, O:) or a piece of cold, cooked, flesh-meat: (T: [mentioned in the TA as from the M:]) and a piece of anything: (TA:) pl. fidarN. (T, TA.) ― -b2- A lump of dates [compacted together]: (M:) or a large lump of dates compacted together; as also finodiyrN and finodiyrapN, (TA in art. fndr.) ― -b3- A piece of a mountain: (T, K:) or an overtopping, or an overhanging, or a projecting, piece of a mountain. (M.) See also faAdirapN. ― -b4- And A portion of the night. (M, K.)
fudarapN * A man who goes away by himself; (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K;) like furadapN; formed by transposition. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) [See also faAdirN, last signification.]

fudur~N *
Silver. (O, K.) -A2- And also, (K,) or gulaAmN fudur~N, (O,) A boy, or youth, that has nearly attained to puberty: or fat, or plump. (O, K.)
faduwrN * : see the next paragraph.

faAdirN * , applied to a stallion, [primarily to a stallion-camel, (see 1, first sentence,)] Desisting from covering; or desisting from covering, being wearied by much indulging therein: (S, O:) or flagging, or becoming remiss, or languid, in covering, and desisting therefrom: (M, K:) [or lacking power, or ability, to cover: (see 1:)] pl. fawaAdiru, (S, O,) or fudorN. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ faduwrN, (S, M, O, K,) and ↓ fadarN, (M, K,) applied to a mountaingoat, Advanced in age, or full-grown: (S, M, O, K:) or youthful, and complete in make: (M, K:) or large, or big: (S, O:) or that protects himself in the mountain from the hunter: (M, K:) faAdirN applied to a mountain-goat as meaning advanced in age is like qaAriHN applied to a horse, and baAzilN to a camel, and SaAligN to an animal of the bovine kind and to a sheep or goat: (As, T:) accord. to IAth, it is from fadara said of a stallion as meaning “ he lacked power, or ability, to cover: ” (TA: [and the like is said in the O:]) the pl. (of faAdirN, M) is fudurN, (M, and so in some copies of the K,) or fudorN, (so in other copies of the K,) or both, (S, O, [see an ex. of the latter plural in a verse cited voce tadav~ara,]) and fawaAdiru and (of ↓ fadarN, M) fuduwrN, and (quasi-pl. n., M) ↓ mafodarapN, (M, K,) like ma$oyaxapN. (M.) -A2- And faAdirN, (O, K,) [thus] without p, (O,) signifies also A she-camel that goes away alone, apart from the others; (O, K, TA;) like faAridN. (TA.) [See also fudarapN.]

faAdirapN * (assumed tropical:) A great, (T, O, K,) hard and solid, (M, K,) mass of rock, (T, M, O, K,) which one sees (T, O) upon the head of a mountain; (T, M, O, K;) likened to the mountain-goat; (M, O;) as also ↓ fidorapN. (TA.) [See also what next follows.]

finodiyrN * (S, K) and finodiyrapN (S, M, K) A great mass of rock that projects, or juts out, (tanoduru,) from the head of a mountain: (S:) what is thus called is short of (duwna) what is termed fidorap [in relation to a mountain]; (M, K;) by which may
be meat dwn in respect of place and projection, not in respect of size. (TA.) [See also fidorapN and faAdirapN: and see more in art. fndr.]

TaEaAmN mufodirN * , like muHosinN [in measure, app. in some one or more of the copies of the K like muHoSanN, for, as is mentioned in the TA, El-Bedr El-Karáfee says that it is anomalous, like musohabN from A^sohaba, and muHoSanN from A^HoSana], Food that stops from copulation; (K;) as also ↓ mafodarapN. (Lh, K.)

mafodarapN * : see what next precedes: -A2- and see faAdirN. -A3- Also A place of the mountain-goats termed fudur. pl. of faAdirN: (S, O:) [or] makaAnN mafodarapN signifies a place in which are many of those mountain-goats. (M, K.)

1 fadiEa * , with kesr, [aor.
fadaEa , inf. n. fadaEN,] He was, or became, such as is termed A^fodaEu [q. v.]. (O.) And fadiEato qadamuhu, (O, K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] fadaEato,) [aor. and inf. n. as above,] occurring in a trad., His foot had the affection termed fadaEN [meaning as expl. below; and in like manner the verb may be used in relation to the hand]. (O, K, TA.) -A2- See also fadoEN.
2 fd~Epu * , (O, TA, from a trad.,) inf. n. tafodiyEN, (O, K,) He caused him (a man, O, TA) to be, or become, such as is termed A^fodaEu. (O, K, * TA.)
fadoEN * [app. an inf. n. of which the verb is ↓ fadaEa] A breaking, or crushing, syn. $adoxN [q. v.]: and a slight splitting or cleaving or slitting. (TA.)

fadaEN * [mentioned above as an inf. n.] Deflection, and distortion: this is [said to be] the primary signification. (TA.) [Generally] A distortion of the wrist or of the ankle-joint, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) so that the hand or the foot becomes turned towards the inner side: (S, O, Msb, K:) or the walking upon the back [i. e. the upper surface] of the foot [from an explanation of A^afodaEu by IAar, mentioned in the Mgh and O and Msb and TA; but it seems rather to mean a distortion of the foot that occasions the so walking]: (K: [see also rawaHN:]) or height of the hollow part of the sale of the foot, such that if the person trod upon a sparrow it would not hurt it [from an explanation of A^afodaEu by As, mentioned in the O]: (K, TA:) or a distortion (EiwajN, K, TA, [in the O EarajN,] and mayolN, TA) in the joints, as though they were dislocated, (Lth, O, K,) mostly in the wrists and ankle-joints, (Lth, * O, * K, * TA,) by nature (Lth, O, K, TA) or by disease, as though the person were unable to extend them: (Lth, O, TA:) or a deflection between the foot and the shank-bone, (O, K, TA,) and the like in the arm, being a state of dislocation of the joints: (TA:) or it is a colliding of the [inner] ankle-bones, and a wide separation of the feet, (Mgh, TA,) to the right and left. (TA. [See, again, rawaHN.]) In the camel, (K,) or in the fore legs of the camel, (ISh, O, TA,) it is The state in which one sees the animal to tread upon the part between the phalanges of his foot, so that the fore part of his foot becomes raised; (ISh, O, K, TA;) and it is nought but a rigidity in the pastern [that occasions this]. (ISh, O, TA.)
fadaEapN * The place of what is termed fadaEN, (S, O, Msb,) in the wrist or ankle-joint. (S, Msb.)

A^afodaEu *
Having a deflection; and distorted. (TA [in which it is implied that this is the primary signification].) [Generally] Having the affection termed fadaEN [q.v.]; applied to a man; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) and to a he-camel: (O, K:) fem. fadoEaA='u; (O, Msb, K;) applied to a woman; (Msb;) and to a she-camel; (O, K;) and to a female slave as meaning whose hand is distorted in consequence of work. (IDrd, O.) And the masc. is applied to a male ostrich, as meaning Having a distortion of the extremities of the fore parts of his feet; in like manner as when it is applied to a he-camel. (Lth, * O, TA.) And hence, AlA^fodaEu, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, signifies The male ostrich. (TA.) And A^fodaE is applied by Ru-beh to fish (samak) as meaning Bending, crooked, or curving. (O.) And AlfadoEaA='u is a name of (assumed tropical:) The well-known asterism called Al*iraAEu [q. v., the Seventh Mansion of the Moon; also called fadoEaA='u Aln~avorapi, because Alnvrp is the Eighth Mansion]: a poet says,
yawomN mina Aln~avorapi A^awo fadoEaAy^ihaA
yuxoriju nafosa AlEanozi mina wajoEaAy^ihaA
[A day of the auroral setting of Alnvrp or of its fdEA=' that causes the soul of the she-goat to pass forth from her anus]; meaning, by reason of the intenseness of the cold. (TA.) ― -b2- The dim. of A^afodaEu is ↓ A^ufayodiEu. (TA.)
A^ufayodiEu * : see what next precedes.

1 fadagahu * , aor.
fadaga , inf. n. fadogN, He broke it, (S, O, Msb, K,) or crushed it; (S, O, K;) or (K) it is said when the object is a hollow thing, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) or a moist, or soft, thing, (TA,) a person's head, (S, O, TA,) and a grape, and the like: (O, TA:) and he bruised, brayed, or pounded, it coarsely: and he clave, split, or rent, it slightly. (TA.) ― -b2- And fadaga AlT~aEaAma He put much clarified butter into the food. (O, * K, * TA.) ― -b3- And one says also, fadaga AlkamoA^apa fiY Als~amoni [app. meaning He preserved the truffles in clarified butter]. (O.)

7 Anfdg *
It (anything dry, or rigid,) became soft, or supple. (O, K. *)

fadagN *
Distortion in the foot: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) like fadaEN, which is more common. (O.) [See fadaEN.]

mifodagN *
An instrument for breaking, or crushing. (K, TA.) And applied to a man; like midaq~N [q. v.]. (TA.)

1 fadamotu EalaY fiyih biAlgidaAmi * , [aor.
fadima ,] inf. n. fadomN, I covered his, or its, mouth with the fidaAm [q. v.]: (S:) or fadama faAhu, and EalaY fiyhi, aor.
fadima , and ↓ fd~m, (M, K, TA,) inf. n. tafodiymN; (TA;) he put the fidaAm upon his, or its, mouth: (M, K:) [app. used in relation to a man and also to an A_iboriyq or other vessel: but the latter verb, and as trans. without a particle, seems to be more commonly used in relation to both:] one says of Persians or other foreigners, and of Magians, on the occasion of their giving to drink, A^afowaAhahumo ↓ fad~amuwA They bound the fad~aAm upon their mouths: (T:) and ↓ fd~m AlA_iboriyqa, (M, K,) inf. n. tafodiymN, (K,) He put the fidaAm upon the mouth of the Abryq. (M, K. *) -A2- faduma, (T, M, K,) inf. n. fadaAmapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and fuduwmapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He was or became, such as is termed fadom [q. v.]; or he was or became, heavy, sluggish, or dull; and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (TA.)
2 fad~ama see the preceding paragraph, in three places. One says also, fd~m AlbaEiyra, meaning He bound upon the camel's mouth the fidaAmap, (M,) which means the gimaAmap [q. v.]. (TA.)

fadomN *
Impotent (T, S, M, K) in speech, (T, M, K,) and in adducing an argument; (T, M;) [as though his mouth were covered with a fidaAm, for it is said in the S to be from fadamotu EalaY fiyhi biAlfidaAmi;] heavy, sluggish, or dull; (S;) or with heaviness, sluggishness, or dulness, and softness, and paucity of understanding: (M, K:) or unintelligent: (Msb:) and thick; (M, K;) fat; (M;) foolish, or stupid; rough, rude, or uncivil: (M, K:) accord. to IAar, the heavy, sluggish, or dull; as being likened to blood, which is thus called: (T:) and vadomN is a dial. var. thereof, or, accord. to Yaakoob, the v is a substitute for the f: (M:) the fem. is with p: (M, Msb, K:) and the pl. is fidaAmN [agreeably with analogy]. (M, K: in a copy of the T fudum [which I think a mistranscription].) ― -b2- Also Heavy [and app. thick] blood: and, accord. to IAar, blood [itself]. (T.) ― -b3- And A garment, or piece of cloth, (T, TA,) saturated with dye, (T,) or saturated with red dye by its being put again into the safflower time after time. (TA.) And Red that is saturated (M, K) with redness: (K:) or of which the redness is not intense. (Thus also in some copies of the K.) [See also mufodamN.]
fadaAmN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

fidaAmN * and ↓ fadaAmN and ↓ fad~aAmu and ↓ fad~uwmN, (K,) or ↓ fad~aAmN [only], (S, T, M,) A thing which the Persians or other foreigners, (T, K,) and the Magians, (K,) bind upon their mouths on the occasion of their giving to drink; (T, K;) or a
piece of cloth with which the Magian binds his mouth; (S;) or a sort of thing with which the Persians or other foreigners wipe [app. the mouth] when they give to drink; one of which is termed ↓ fad~aAmapN. (M. [In the S it seems to be implied that this last word is syn. with fad~aAmN as expl. above.]) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the first, (T, S, M,) and also ↓ fad~aAmN, (S,) or and also ↓ fadaAmN, (M,) A strainer, or clarifier, (T, S, M, K,) for a mug and an A_iboriyq and the like; (T;) a thing that is put in, or upon, the mouth of the Abryq, for the straining, or clarifying, of what is in it: (S, M: *) also called vidaAmN. (M.) ― -b3- And fidaAmN signifies also the same as EimaAmapN: thus in copies of the K [and in a copy of the M]: but the former word is correctly ↓ fidaAmapN [as is implied in one place in the M]; and the word by which it is explained is correctly gimaAmahN, [as in some copies of the K,] meaning A thing that is put upon the mouth of the camel. (TA. [See 2: and see also the first paragraph of art. gm.])
fidaAmapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
fad~aAmN * : see fidaAmN, in three places.
fad~uwmN * : see fidaAmN.
mufodamN * : n. un. of fad~aAmN: see fidaAmN, former half.

mufodamu * : see mufad~amu. ― -b2- Also A garment, or piece of cloth, saturated with red dye: (Sh, T, S, M, and some copies of the K:) or of which the redness is not intense. (M, and some copies of the K.) It is said in a trad. that he [the Prophet] disliked the mufodamo for the muHoram, but saw no harm in the muDar~aj [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Dye thick and saturated. (S.) ― -b4- And *ul~u mufoduwmN (tropical:) Deeplystained, intense, vileness or ignominy. (TA.)

mufad~amN * (T, M, K) and ↓ mafoduwmN (T) and ↓ mufodamN (M, K) An A_iboriyq [a vessel for wine] having a strainer, called fidaAm, (T, M, K,) in, or upon, its mouth: (M, K: *) and so muvad~amN. (M.) It is said in a trad., A_in~akumo madoEuw~uwna yawoma AlqiyaAmapi mufad~amapF A^afowaAhukumo biAlfidaAmi [Verily ye will be summoned on the day of resurrection having your mouths closed with the fdAm]; meaning, ye will be withheld from speaking with your mouths, so that your skins will speak. (M.)
mufad~amaAtN * [Vessels of the kinds called] A^abaAriyq and dinaAn [pls. of A_iboriyqN and dan~u]. (S.)
mafoduwmN * : see mufad~am.

2 tafodiynN * signifies The making a building tall. (K. [See fadanN.]) ― -b2- And (tropical:) The fattening of camels. (K, TA.) One says, fd~nhu, meaning (tropical:) He (the pastor) fattened him [i. e. a camel]; made him like the fadan, i. e. the qaSor. (TA.)

fadanN *
A [pavilion, or building of the kind termed] qaSor, (S, M, A, K,) raised high, or made lofty: (M, K:) pl. A^afodaAnN; (M, A;) to which fat camels are likened. (A. [See 2.]) -A2- And A certain red dye. (M, K.)
fadaAnN * : see the next paragraph, in five places.

fad~aAnN * The bull; (M, K;) and so ↓ fadaAnN: (K:) the bull with which one ploughs: (IAar, TA:) or, (AA, AHn, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) as also ↓ fadaAnN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) the oxen, (AA, S,) or the two bulls (AHn, M, Mgh, Msb, K) which are coupled together (AHn, M, K) in [or by means of] the [cord called] qiraAn (Mgh) [and] which plough, (S,) or with which one ploughs; (AHn, M, Mgh, Msb, K; *) and one thereof is not called fad~aAnN: (AHn, M, K:) or fad~aAnN signifies, (Mgh, K,) and so ↓ fadaAnN, (Mgh,) or the former, (S,) or each, (M, Msb,) signifies also, (S, M, Msb,) [the plough; or the apparatus, or gear, thereof; i. e.] the implement, or the apparatus, or gear, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the two bulls, (S, Mgh, K,) for ploughing; (S, Mgh, Msb;) or the whole apparatus, or gear, of the two bulls [which are coupled together] in [or by means of] the [cord called] qiraAn: (M:) but accord. to Abu-l-Hasan Es- Sikillee, ↓ fadaAnN, without teshdeed, signifies the implement, or apparatus, with which one ploughs: and fad~aAnN, with teshdeed, has a different meaning, expl. in what follows, relating to land: and IAar says the like: (TA:) [see also EiyaAnN:] the pl. of fad~aAnN is fadaAdiynu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) meaning oxen with which one ploughs: (M, TA:) the pl. of ↓ fadaAnN is A^afodinapN [a pl. of pauc.] and fudunN, (M, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and the vulgar say fidon, with kesr. (TA.) ― -b2- fad~aAnN, with teshdeed, also signifies A certain commonly-known quantity [of land]; (IAar, TA;) said by Abu-l-Hasan Es- Sikillee to signify a limited portion of land, subdivided into four and twenty keerats; (TA;) [loosely reckoned as the quantity of land which a yoke of oxen will plough in one day; thus corresponding to the Latin term jugerum, and our acre; and commonly defined as consisting of 333 kasabehs (or rods) and one third; (the kasabeh being 24 kabdahs; and the kabdah being the measure of a man's fist with the thumb erect, or about 6 inches and a quarter;) but different in different times and in different parts of the same country: hence, perhaps,] it is also expl. as signifying a place of seed-produce. (M, TA.)

Alfad~aAduwna * is said to signify A^aSoHaAbu AlfadaAdiyna [The possessors of ploughing oxen]; like as jam~aAluwna signifies “ possessors of camels: ” but it has been otherwise expl. in [its proper place, as pl. of fad~aAdN, in] art. fd. (K.)

binaA='N mufad~anN *
A building that is [made] tall, or lofty. (M.) -A2- And vawobN mufad~anN A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with fadan. (TA.)

1 fadaAhu * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yafodiyhi, (Msb, K,) inf. n. fidaA='N (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) [omitted in my copy of the Msb, probably by inadvertence,]) and fadFY, (Mgh,) or fidFY, (so in the M, accord. to the TT,) or also both of these, (Fr, T, S, Msb, K,) the latter of them said by Fr, on one occasion, to be the more common, (T, TA,) [which is the case when it is a subst., like fidoyapN,] but 'Alee Ibn-Suleymán El-Akhfash [i. e. El-Akhfash El-Asghar] is related to have said that this is not allowable except by poetic license, and El-Kálee says that AlfidaY was used by the Arabs in conjunction with AlHimaY, [see HimaA='u, in art. HmY,] but other forms were used in other cases [among which he seems to mention fadaA=', with fet-h and the lengthened alif, but the words in which I find this expressed are somewhat ambiguous, and are also rendered doubtful by an erasure and an alteration]; (TA;) and ↓ AftdAhu, (M,) [whence an ex. in a verse which will be found in what follows,] or bihi ↓ AftdY (K, TA) and minohu, (TA,) [but I do not know AftdY in either of these phrases as having any other than the well-known meaning of fadaY nafosahu, which is strangely omitted in the K;] and know ↓ fAdiAhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. mufaAdaApN and fidaA='N; (Msb, TA;) but some explain this differently [as will be shown in what follows]; (T, Mgh, Msb, TA;) He gave his ransom; (S;) he gave a thing, (K, TA, [AaEoTAhu in the CK being a mistake for A^aEoTaY, without the affixed pronoun,]) or a captive, for him, (TA,) and so liberated him; (K, TA;) [i. e. he ransomed him;] or he liberated him, or ransomed him, mina AlA^asori [from captivity]: (Mgh, Msb:) or ↓ fAdAhu signifies he loosed him, or set him free, and took his ransom: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) or mufaAdaApN signifies the giving a man and taking a man [in exchange]: and fidaA='N, [as inf. n. of fadaAhu,] the purchasing him [from captivity or the like]: (Mbr, T, Mgh, Msb, TA:) or the preserving a man from misfortune by what one gives by way of compensation for him; as also fadFY: (Er-Rághib, TA:) you say, fadayotuhu bimaAliY I purchased [i. e. ransomed] him with my property, and binafosiY with myself: (T:) or, accord. to Nuseyr Er-Rázee, the Arabs say, AlA^asiyra ↓ faAdayotu [I ransomed the captive], and fadayotuhu biA^abiY wa A^umiY [I ransomed him in a tropical sense with my father and my mother], and bimaAlK [with property], as though thou purchasedst him and freedst him therewith, when he was not a captive; and you may say, fadayotu AlA^asyra meaning I freed the captive from the state in which he was, though ↓ faAdayotu is better in this sense: as to the reading tafoduwhumo [in the Kur ii. 79], Aboo-Mo'ádh says, it means Ye purchase them from the enemy and liberate them; but the reading ↓ tufaAduwhumo, he says, means ye contend with them who are in your hands respecting the price and they so contend with you: (T, TA:) [that ↓ AftdAhu is syn. with fadaAhu is shown by what here follows:] a poet says,
yufotadaY lafadayotuhu falawo kaAna maytN
bimaA lamo takuno Eanohu Aln~ufuwsu taTiybu
[And if a person dead were to be ransomed, assuredly I would ransom him with what minds would not be willing to relinquish]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [The inf. ns. of the first of these verbs are much used in precative phrases:] they said, fadFY laka [for fadaAka fadFY, and therefore virtually meaning fudiyta Mayest thou be ransomed; the l being lilt~aboyiyni i. e. “ for the purpose of notifying ” the person addressed]: (TA:) and biY A^a fadFY laka [for fadaAka A^abiY binafosihi fadFY, and therefore virtually meaning simply fadaAka A^abiY binafosihi May my father ransom thee with himself; so that it may be well rendered may my father be a ransom for thee]: (S:) and fidaA=', with tenween, some of the Arabs pronounce with kesr [to the ', i. e. they pronounce fidaA=' with the tenween of kesr], peculiarly when it is next to [meaning immediately followed by] the preposition l, saying fidaA='K laka, because it is indeterminate; they intending thereby the meaning of a prayer; and As has cited [as an ex. thereof] the saying of En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee],
maholFA fidaA='K laka AlA^aqowaAmu kul~uhumu
wamaA A^uvamiru mino maAlK wamino waladi
[Act gently: may the peoples, all of them, and what I make to be abundant of wealth and of offspring, give themselves as a ransom, or be a ransom, for thee: fidaA='K being app. assimilated to an indeterminate imperative verbal noun such as SahK in the phrase SahK yaA rajulu, which is as though one said Ausokuto sukuwtFA yaA rajulu; thus meaning here liyafodika: but De Sacy mentions, in his “ Chrest. Arabe, ” see. ed., vol. ii., p. 460, three allowable readings (not the foregoing reading) in this verse, namely, fdA='N and fdA='F and fdA='K; and adds that what here follows is said by a commentator to be, of several explanations, that which is the right: wAlqwl AlA=xr whw AlSHyH An fdA='i bmEnY lyufdika fbnAh kmA bnY AlAmr wk*lk tarAki w darAki lAnh bmEnY Atrk w Adrk: this, it will be observed, is similar to the explanation which I have offered of fidaA='K lk; for lyufdik is app. a typographical mistake for lyafdik: and I incline to think that fdA='i, though supposed to be correct and therefore likened to tarAki and darAki, is a mistake of a copyist for fdA='K; and the more so because I find in Ahlwardt's “ Divans of the Six Ancient Arabic Poets ” the three readings fidA'N and fidA'F and fidA'K, but not fidA'i]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- wafadayonaAhu bi*iboHK [in the Kur xxxvii. 107] means And we made an animal prepared for sacrifice to be a ransom for him, and freed him from slaughter. (T, TA.) ― -b4- fadato nafosahaA mino zawojihaA and ↓ Aftdt [alone] mean She gave property to her husband so that she became free from him by divorce. (Msb, TA.) ― -b5- See also what next follows.

2 fd~Ahu * , (S, * K,) or fd~Ahu binafosihi, (S, * TA,) [or both, for both are correct,] inf. n. tafodiyapN; (S, K;) and bnfsh ↓ fadaAhu, (S, TA, *) aor. yafodiyhi, inf. n. fidaA='N; (TA;) He said to him ↓ fidaAka juEilotu [May I be made thy ransom, i. e. a ransom for thee]. (S, K, TA.)

3 faAodaYa see 1, former half, in five places. ― -b2- In the saying respecting bloodwits, waA_ino A^aHab~uwA faAdawoA, the meaning is, [And if they like,] they free the slayer, or his next of kin who is answerable for him, and accept the bloodwit; because this is a substitute for the blood, like as the ransom is a substitute for the captive. (Mgh.)

4 AfdAhu AlA^asiyra * [in the CK (erroneously) AlAsyru] He accepted from him the ransom of the captive. (M, K.) Hence the saying of the Prophet to Kureysh, when 'Othmán Ibn-'Abd-Allah and El- Hakam Ibn-Keysán had been made captives, laA nufodiykumuw humaA Ht~aY yaqodama SaAHibaAnaA [We will not accept from you the ransom of them two until our two companions shall come], meaning [by the two companions] Saad Ibn-Abee-Wakkás and 'Otbeh Ibn-Ghazwán. (M.) ― -b2- AfdY fulaAnN Such a one danced, or dandled, his child: (K, TA:) because of his [often] saying, fadiY laka A^abiY wa A^umiY [May my father and my mother be ransoms for thee]. (TA.) -A2- AfdY also signifies He made for his dried dates a store-chamber. (K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) He became large in his body; (IAar, T, K, TA;) as though it became like the fadaA=' [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And He sold dates. (IAar, T, K.)

6 tfAdwA *
They ransomed one another. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) They guarded themselves, one by another; as though every one of them made his fellow to be his ransom. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And tfAdY minohu (tropical:) He guarded against it, or was cautious of it, and kept aloof from it. (S, K, * TA.)

8 A_ifotadaYa see 1, first quarter, in two places; and again, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- As intrans., AftdY signifies [He ransomed himself;] he gave a ransom for himself. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, AftdY minohu bika*aA [He ransomed himself from him with such a thing]. (S.) Hence the usage of the verb in the Kur ii. 229. (TA.) See 1, last sentence but one.

fadFY * and ↓ fidFY and ↓ fidaA='N and ↓ fidoyapN all signify the same, (S, K,) i. e. [A ransom;] a thing, (K, TA,) or a captive, (TA,) that is given for a man, who is therewith liberated: (K, TA:) [the first three are also inf. ns. (and have been mentioned as such in the first paragraph); therefore when you say fadFY laka A^abiY and fidFY lk AbY, the words fadFY and fidFY may be either inf. ns. or substs.: as substs., the second and third are more common than the first:] fidoyapF [is also sometimes expl. as an inf. n., but accord. to general usage] signifies as above; (K, TA;) or property given as a substitute [or a ransom] for a captive: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) and property by the giving of which one preserves himself from evil in the case of a religious act in which he has fallen short of what was incumbent, like the expiation for the breaking of an oath and of a fast; and thus it is used in the Kur ii. 180 and 192: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and its pl. is fidFY and fidayaAtN. (Mgh, Msb, TA.)
fidFY * : see the next preceding paragraph. [Hence the phrase] juEilotu fidaAka: see 2. It is also a pl. of its syn. fidoyapF. (Mgh, Msb, TA.)

fidoyapN * : see fadFY. -A2- xu*o EalaY hidoyatika wa fidoyatika, accord. to the K, but in the S, xu*o fiY hidoyatika waqidoyatika, mentioned in art. qdY, is a saying meaning [Take thou to] that [course] in which thou wast: the author of the K seems to have followed Sgh, who has mentioned it here: (TA in the present art.:) fidoyahN and qidoyahN are dial. vars. (TA in art. qdY.)

fadaA='N *
An A^anobaAr, (K, TA,) i. e. (TA) a collection, of wheat: (M, K, * TA:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (M,) a collection of food, consisting of barley and dates and the like: (M, K:) or an A^anobaAr, i. e. a collection, of food, consisting of wheat and dates and barley: (S:) and it is said to signify a place in which dates are spread and dried, in the dial. of 'Abd-El-Keys. (M.) ― -b2- And The Hajom [or protuberant, or prominent, part, or perhaps the bulk,] of a thing (M, K) of any kind. (M.)
fidaA=y^N * : see fadFY.

AlfidaAwiy~apu * is the appellation of A class, or rect, of the xawaArij of the duroziy~ap [or duruwz, whom we call the Druses; it is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is fidaAwiY~u; the w being a substitute for ': it is used to signify those who undertake perilous adventures, more particularly for the destruction of enemies of their party; as though they offered themselves as ransoms or victims; and hence it is applied to the sect called in our histories of the Crusades “ The Assassins ”]. (TA.)

[
mafodiY~N * , originally mafoduwYN. In the saying binafosiY fulaAnN mufodiY~N With my soul, or myself, may such a one be ransomed, mafodiY~N is often suppressed; being meant to be understood.]

1 fa*~a Eano A^aSoHaAbihi * , [aor.
fa*i3a , inf. n. fa*~N,] He was, or became, apart from his companions, and remained alone. (L.) -A2- And fa*~, (TA,) [aor.
fa*u3a ,] inf. n. fa*~u, (K, TA.) He drove away (Tarada) vehemently. (K, TA.)

4 Af*~hu *
He made him, or it, to be single; sole; or one, and no more; syn. A^awotarahu; (S in art. wtr;) and jaEalahu fa*~FA, i. e. witorAF. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- And A^afa*~ato She (a ewe or goat) brought forth one only, (El-Ahmar, T, S, M, O, L, Msb,) at a breeding; (Msb;) inf. n. A_ifo*aA*N. (El-Ahmar, T, M, L.) [See mufi*~N.]
5 tafa*~a3a see next following paragraph.

10 Astf*~bihi *
He was, or became, alone; inde
pendent of others; without any to share, or participate, with him; in it: (K, TA:) you say, Astf*~ EalaY~a biAAlA^amori He was, or became, alone, or independent, exclusively of me, in the affair: (O:) and bihi ↓ tf*~* also has the former meaning: (K, TA:) or this latter signifies He was, or became, alone with him. (O.)

R. Q. 1 fa*ofa*a *
He contracted himself (taqaASara), to leap, deceiving, or circumventing, (IAar, T, O, K,) or in order to deceive, or circumvent, when leaping; (IAar, T in art. *f;) said of a man. (IAar, T, O.) ― -b2- [And accord. to the K, in art. *f, i. q. tabaxotara; like *afo*afa: but] accord. to IAar, *afo*afa has this latter meaning, and fa*ofa*a signifies as expl. above on his authority. (T in art. *f.)

fa*~N *
Single; sole; only; one, and no more; [and alone, or apart from others; (see 1;)] syn. farodN; (S, M, Mgh, O, L, K;) and waAHidN: (L, Msb:) pl. [of mult.] fu*uw*N (M, L, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] A^afo*aA*FA. (M, L, K.) One says, *ahabaA fa*~ayoni They two went away singly. (S, O, L.) And jaA=' Alqawoma A^afo*aA*FA: see fu*aA*aY. ― -b2- And tamorN fa*~N Dates that are separate, each one from others; (IAar, S, M, O, L, K;) not sticking together; (IAar, M, L;) as also faD~N; (M;) and fav~N. (T in art. fv.) ― -b3- And Alfa*~u is [a name of] The first of the arrows used in the game called Almayosir: (S, M, O, L, K:) it has one notch; and for it is gained one share [of the slaughtered camel] when it is successful, and one share is exacted when it is unsuccessful: (Lh, M, O, L:) the arrows are ten: the 2nd is called Alt~awoA^amu; the 3rd, Alr~aqiybu; the 4th, AlHilosu; the 5th, Aln~aAfisu; the 6th, Almusobilu; the 7th, AlmuEal~aY; and there are three for which there is no share, namely, Als~afiyHu and AlmaniyHu and Alwagodu. (S, O, L.) [See Alrqyb.] ― -b4- kalimapo fa*~apN: see faA*~apN.
fu*~aA*FA * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

jaA='a Alqawomu fu*aA*a * , (O,) or ↓ fu*aA*FA, (Msb,) and ↓ fu*~aA*FA, and ↓ A^afo*aA*FA, The people, or party, came one by one; singly. (O, Msb.) And A^akalonaA fu*aA*aY, (K, TA,) and fa*aA*aY, (CK,) and ↓ fu*aA*FA, and ↓ fu*~aA*FA, We ate separately. (K.)
fu*~aA*FA * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

kalimapN faA*~apN * , and ↓ fa*~apN, i. q. $aA*~apN [i. e. A word, phrase, proposition, or sentence, extraordinary, or exceptional, in respect of rule, or of usage]. (M, L.) And A=yapN faA*~apN A verse of the Kur-án that is alone in meaning. (L.)
A^afa*~u * An arrow having no feathers upon it; (T, O, K;) opposed to mariy$F: so says Aboo-Málik: others say A^aqa*~N [q. v.], with q: but he allowed only the former. (T, O.)

mufi*~N * A ewe or she-goat bringing forth one only, (El-Ahmar, T, S, M, O, L, Msb, K,) at a breeding: (Msb:) [like muforidN and muwHidN:] one does not apply this epithet to a she-camel, because she never brings forth more than one. (S, M, O, L, Msb.)
mifo*aA*F * A ewe or she-goat that usually brings forth one only. (T, S, O, L, K.)

1 far~a * , aor.
fari3a , inf. n. firaArF (T, S, M, K, &c.) and farN (M, K) and mafarN (S, M, K) and mafirN, (K,) or the last is a n. of place [and of time], (S, M,) He (a man, T) fled: (T, S:) or he turned away or aside, to elude, and fled, (M, K, TA,) from a thing that he feared. (TA.) A^ayona A@lomafar~u [in the Kur lxxv. 10] means Whither is the [fleeing or] turning away &c.? (M, TA:) or it may mean when is the time thereof? (TA:) and Ayn Almafir~u, another reading, where is the place of fleeing &c.? (I'Ab, Zj, S, M, TA,) as also Almifar~u, (Zj, K, TA,) which is an instrumental noun used as a noun of place: (K, TA:) but the first is the common reading. (TA.) ― -b2- far~a mino Eaduwihi, aor. as above, inf. n. far~N, He wheeled about widely from his enemy, to turn again. (Msb.) ― -b3- And far~a A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i He went, or betook himself, to the thing. (Msb.) ― -b4- And [hence] far~ato yaduhu His arm, or hand, fell off; like Tar~ato and tar~ato. (O.) -A2- far~a Alfarasa, (S, O,) or Ald~aAb~apa, (M, K,) aor.
faru3a , (S, M, O,) i. e. with damm, (O,) [in copies of the K
fari3a , but afterwards in those copies
faru3a , which is the regular and correct form,] inf. n. far~N (S, M, O, K) and furaArN and firaArN and faraArN, (K,) or furaArN is a simple subst., and firaArN is an inf. n., (Meyd, in explanation of the prov. which here follows,) He looked at, or examined, the teeth of the horse, (S, O,) or he exposed to view the teeth of the beast that he might see what was its age. (M, K.) Hence, (TA,)
A_in~a AljawaAda Eayonuhu furaAruhu
(S, M, * Meyd, K, *) and firaAruhu, (M, Meyd, K,) and faraAruhu, (S, K,) sometimes thus pronounced with fet-h, (S,) (tropical:) [Verily the fleet and excellent horse, his aspect (see EayonN) is (equivalent to) the examination of his teeth, i. e. he is known by his aspect], is a prov., applied to him whose external state indicates his internal qualities; (Meyd, O, K;) meaning that one knows his excellence from his Eayon [i. e. aspect] like as one knows the age of a beast by examining his teeth; (TA;) his external appearance rendering it needless for thee to test him, (S, Meyd, O, K,) and to examine (A^ano tafur~a) his teeth: (S, O, K:) and [with the same meaning] one says, far~u AljawaAdi Eayonuhu: (A, TA:) and [in like manner] Alxabiyvu Eaynuhu furiAaruhu [The bad, his aspect &c.]; (Meyd, O, TA;) i. e. thou knowest his badness by his Eayon when thou seest him. (TA.) And one says also, fararotu fama Alfarasi I opened the mouth of the horse that I might know his age. (Har p. 28.) And far~a Eano A^asonaAni Ald~aAb~api, aor.
fari3a , He examined the teeth of the beast. (Har p. 233.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying of El-Hajjáj, furirotu Eano *akaA='K, expl. in art. *kw.] And [hence also] one says, far~ahu Eano A^a$oyaA='i (tropical:) He examined him respecting things (O, * TA.) And far~a AlA^amora, (M, TA,) and far~a Eani AlA^amori, (S, M, O, K, TA,) (tropical:) He examined, looked into, scrutinized, or investigated, the affair; searched into it; inquired, or sought information, respecting it. (S, M, O, K, TA.) And far~a fulaAnN Eam~aA fiY nafosiY (tropical:) Such a one interrogated me in order that he might know, from what I should say, what was in my mind. (TA.) ― -b3- And fur~a AlA^amoru ja*aEFA (assumed tropical:) The thing returned to its first state; it recommenced. (M, O, K.) And fur~a AlA^amora ja*aEFA (assumed tropical:) Commence thou the affair from the first thereof. (M, in the TT. [But the MS. has in this case, as in that here immediately preceding, AlAmru: the right reading is evidently AlAmra; as in a similar phrase voce ja*aEN, q. v.]) -A3- far~a, aor. yafir~u or yafar~u, (accord. to different copies of the T,) He became intelligent after being weak [in mind]. (IAar, T, TA.)
3 faArarotuhu * , inf. n. mufaAr~apN, (tropical:) I investigated his state, or condition, he investigating mine. (TA.)

4 Afr~hu *
He, or it, made him to flee; (S, O;) or made him to turn away or aside, for the purpose of eluding, and to flee: (M, K:) or (O) he did to him a deed that made him to flee; (Fr, AO, T, M, O, K;) as also Afr~bihi. (TA.) It is related in a trad. that the Prophet said to 'Adee the son of Hátim, maA yufir~uka Eani AlA_isolaAmi A_il~A A^ano yuqaAla laA A_il`ha A_il~aA A@ll~`hu (T, M, O, TA) i. e. Nothing induces thee to flee from El-Islám except the saying “ There is no deity but God: ” many of the relaters say yafur~uka; but Az says that the former is the right. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, Afr~A@ll~`hu yadahu God made, or may God make, his arm, or hand, to fall off; like A^aTar~ahaA and A^atar~ahaA. (O.) ― -b3- And A^aforarotu raA^osahu I split, or clave, his head, with a sword; like A^aforayotuhu. (Yz, T, O, K.) -A2- A^afar~ato liloA_ivonaA='i, said of camels, (S, M, O, K,) and of horses, (M, K,) They shed their milk-teeth and had others come forth. (S, M, O, K.)

5 tafar~ara biY *
i. q. DaHika [He laughed at me, derided me, or ridiculed me]; (K, TA;) mentioned by Sgh. (TA.)

6 tfAr~wA *
They fled, one from another. (S, O, K.)

8 Aftr~ *
He laughed in a beautiful manner, (M, K,) beyond what is termed AinokilaAl [inf. n. of Ainokal~a, q. v.]. (M.) One says, Aftr~a DaAHikFA He showed his teeth laughing; (S;) as also Aftr Eano vagorihi. (T.) It is said of the Prophet, AlgamaAmi wa yafotar~u Eano mivoli Hab~i meaning And he used to smile so as to show teeth the like of hail-stones, without a reiterated, or a loud, laughing. (T.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) Aftr~ Albaroqu
(assumed tropical:) The lightning glistened. (M, K.) And hence the saying, AlS~arofahu naAbu Ald~ahori A@l~a*iY yafotar~u Eanohu [Es- Sarfeh is the dog-tooth of time, or fortune, which it shows smiling]: for when Es-Sarfeh [which is the Twelfth Mansion of the Moon] rises, [but it should be, when it sets, aurorally, for it so set, in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 9th of March, O. S.,] the blossoms come forth and the herbage attains its full height. (M, L. [See more in art. Srf.]) ― -b3- See also fur~N. -A2- Also He snuffed up a thing into his nose. (M, K.)

R. Q. 1 farofarahu * , (S, M, K, &c.,) inf. n. farofaArN, (M,) or firofaArN, (TA,) He put in a state of motion, commotion, or agitation; shook; or shook about; (S, M, K;) it, (S, K,) or him. (M.) One says of a horse, yufarofiru All~ijaAma fiY fiyhi He puts in a state of motion, &c., the bit in his mouth. (M. [See also an explanation of the verb as intrans., in what follows.]) ― -b2- He broke it, i. e. a thing. (M, K.) ― -b3- He cut it. (K.) ― -b4- He clave, split, slit, rent, or tore, it. (TA.) [Thus] farofara signifies He rent, or tore, [skins such as are termed] ziqaAq [pl. of ziq~N], and other things; (O, K, TA;) and slit, or rent, them much. (TA. [In two copies of the T, instead of Alz~iqaAqa wagayorahaA, the reading in the O and K and TA, I find AlruqAqa wgyrh.]) ― -b5- [He mangled it.] One says, Al*~iy^obu yufarofiru Al$~aApa The wolf mangles the sheep, or goat. (O, * TA.) ― -b6- And, (O, K, TA,) hence, (O,) inf. n. farofarapN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He defamed him, and mangled his reputation. (O, K, TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) He discommended it, [as though] mangling it with discommendation: the verb occurs in this sense in a trad., having for its object Ald~unoyaA [meaning the enjoyments, or good, of the present world]. (TA.) ― -b8- Also, (inf. n. farofarapN, TA,) He called or cried, or called out or cried out, to him. (M, K.) -A2- farofara as intrans., He (a camel) put his body in a state of commotion, or agitation. (M, K.) ― -b2- He (a horse) struck his teeth with the fA^os [q. v.] of his bit, and moved about his head. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- He hastened, or sped, and went with short steps. (M, O, K.) ― -b4- He was light, and unsteady, (S, * M, * O, * K, TA,) in mind; (TA;) inf. n. farofarapN. (S, M, O, TA.) ― -b5- He hastened, or was hasty, with foolishness, or stupidity. (IAar, T, TA.) ― -b6- And He confounded, or confused, and was profuse, fiY kalaAmihi [in his speaking, or talking, or his speech, or talk]. (M, K.) ― -b7- And [app. He talked; for] AlfarofarapN signifies AlkalaAmu [which is often used as a quasi-inf. n. of kl~m]. (M.) -A3- farofara also signifies He made the kind of vehicle called farofaAr. (T, K.) ― -b2- And He kindled [a fire] with [wood of] the species of tree called farfaAr. (T, K.)
far~N * : see faAr~N, in two places.

fur~N * [The best, or choice, of men &c.]. One says, huwa fur~N qawomihi, (O,) or fur~N Alqawomi, (K,) and ↓ fur~atuhumo, (O, K,) He is of the best, or choice, of his people, or of the people, (O, K,) and of the chief persons thereof, (O, K, *) who show him smiling (Aal~a*iyna Eanohu ↓ yafotar~uwna, perhaps better rendered who withdraw from him so as to render him conspicuous): (O, K:) or qawomihi ↓ huwafur~apN he is the best, or choice, of his people: (T:) and maAliY ↓ h`*aA fur~apN, (T,) or maAlihi, (O,) this is the best, or choice, of my, or his, property, or camels &c. (T, O.)

fur~apN * and ↓ A^ufur~apN and ↓ A^afur~apN The beginning, or first part, of the heat: (T, S, M, O, K:) or they signify, (T, S, M,) or signify also, (O, K,) the vehemence thereof: (S, M, O, K:) but [Az says,] the second and third are in my opinion from A^afara, the A^ being the first radical letter: and Ks states that some change the A^ into E, saying Eufur~ap and Eafur~ap. (T.) $ar~Kmino fulaAnK ↓ maA zaAla fulaAnN fiY A^ufur~apK is a saying mentioned by Lth, (T, TA,) meaning [Such a one ceased not to be] in a vehement state of evil or mischief [proceeding from such a one]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Confusion and difficulty. (M, K.) One says, waqaEa Alqawomu fiY fur~apK and ↓ A^ufur~apK and ↓ A^afur~apK The people, or party, fell into confusion and difficulty. (M.) ― -b3- See also the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

fir~apN *
A smiling: [or rather a manner of smiling:] one says, A_n~ahA laHasanapu Alfir~api [Verily she is beautiful in respect of the manner of smiling]. (TA.)
fururN * : see furaArN.
furarapN * : see faAr~N.

furaArN * and ↓ faryrN The young one of the ewe, and of the she-goat, (M, K,) and of the cow, (M,) or of the wild cow, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, O, K,) as also, in this last sense, (O, K,) and in the first and second senses, (K,) ↓ furofurN and ↓ furofuwrN (O, K) and ↓ faruwrN and ↓ furaAfirN: (K:) or they [app. referring to all the foregoing words] signify lambs: (K: [but see what follows:]) the female is termed furaArapN: (M:) and furaArN is pl. also; (T, M, K;) i. e. it is applied to a pl. number as well as to one; (TA;) it is said to be pl. of ↓ fariyrN; (T, S, M, O;) and is of a rare form of pl.; (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K; *) and it signifies the small in body of the young ones of the goat-kind; (M;) or ↓ fariyrN, as some say, signifies thus: (TA: [but this I think doubtful:]) this last word is said by IAar to signify the young one of the wild animal, of the gazelle and of the bovine kind and the like; and in one instance he says that it signifies lambs: (M:) and, (T, A,) as Aboo-l-'Abbás [i. e. Th] states on the authority of IAar, (T,) furaArN (T, M) and furaArapN (T) and ↓ fariyrN (M) and ↓ fururN and ↓ furofuwrN and ↓ furaAfirN (T, M) signify the lamb when it is weaned, (T, M,) and has become what is termed jaforN [q. v.], and obtained plenty of herbage, (M,) and has become fat: (T, M:) accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, (O,) the last two signify a lamb (Hamal, O, TA, in the K jamal, a mistranscription, TA) when it eats, and chews the cud: (O, K: [see also furofuwrN below:]) and [it is also said that] furaArN signifies great bahom [app. as meaning lambs or kids], and one thereof is termed ↓ furofuwrN. (TA.) It is said in a prov.
nazowu AlfuraAri A@sotajohala AlfuraAraA
[The leaping of the wild calf, or with equal propriety AlfrAr may be here rendered the kid, excited to lightness the other wild calf, or kid]: (T, S, O, K:) A 'Obeyd says, on the authority of El-Mu- ärrij, [and so says Meyd, and the same is implied in the S and O,] that AlfrAr here means the young one of the wild cow: (T:) i. e., when the frAr attains to youthful vigour it takes to leaping, and when another sees it [do so] it leaps in like manner: (T, S, K:) the prov. is used in relation to him of whose companionship one should be cautious; meaning, if thou become his companion thou wilt do as he does: (T, O, K:) some relate it otherwise, saying nazowa, meaning nazaA nazowa AlfuraAri. (O.) [See also a similar prov. in art. sfh, conj. 5.]
farurN * : see faAr~N. It is applied to a woman as meaning Wont to flee from that which induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion. (S.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

fariyrN * : see furaArN, in four places. -A2- Also The place of the mHas~ap [thus in a copy of the M (app. miHas~ap i. e. currycomb, as though meaning the part that is currycombed), in the K of the mjas~ap (i. e. majas~ap, q. v.), and in the O of the mjm~, which last I think to be a mistranscription,] of the maEorafap [or part, or flesh, upon which grows the mane] of the horse: (M, O, K:) or the base (A^aSol) of the maEorafap of the horse. (T; and accord. to the TA, mentioned by Sgh, and there said to be tropical.) ― -b2- And The mouth: (O, K, TA:) mentioned by Z in a manner indicating that it is of the horse or the like. (TA.)
faruwrapN * : see faArN.
katiybapN fur~aY * [A military force, or troop, &c.,] defeated: (T, O, K:) as also ful~aY. (T.)
far~aA='u * , applied to a woman, i. q. gar~aA='u, (O, K, TA,) meaning Beautiful in the front teeth. (TA.)
far~aArN * : see faAr~N. ― -b2- [Hence,] Quicksilver; so called because flowing quickly, and not remaining in a place: thus says Esh-Shereeshee. (Har p. 139.)
fur~ayorapN * , in the dim. form, with tesh-deed, [A spinning-top;] a thing with which children play. (TA.)

faAr~N * (S, M) and ↓ far~N (T, S, O, K) and ↓ faruwrN (M, O, K) and ↓ faruwrapN (M, K) and ↓ far~aArN (M, O, K) and ↓ furarapN (K) are epithets from far~a signifying as expl. in the first sentence of this art.: (S, T, M, O, K:) [the first and second meaning Fleeing; or turning away or aside, to elude, and fleeing: the third, fifth, and sixth, fleeing, &c., much: and the fourth, fleeing, &c., very much:] but ↓ far~N is applied to one and to two and to more, and to a female; (S, O;) it has no dual nor pl. [nor fem. form]; (T;) the sing. [and dual] and pl. [and mase. and fem.] are alike; (M;) as it is an inf. n. used as an epithet; (M, O;) and it may be a
pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of faAr~N, (S, M, O,) like as rakobN is of raAkibN, (S, O,) and SaHobN of SaAHibN, (S, O, K, *) or $arobN of $aAribN: (M:) it is related in the trad. respecting the Flight that Surákah Ibn-Málik, when he saw the Prophet and Aboo-Bekr fleeing to El-Medeeneh, and they passed by him, said, h`*aAni far~N quray$K A^afalaA A^arud~u EalaY qurayo$K far~ahaA, (T, * S, * O, * TA,) meaning [These two are] the two fugitives [of Kureysh: shall I not turn back to Kureysh their fugitives?]. (A 'Obeyd, T, TA.)
furofurN * : see farofaArN: ― -b2- and furaArN: ― -b3- and furofuwrN, in three places.
firofirN * : see furofuwrN, in two places.
furafirN * : see the next paragraph.

farofaArN *
A breaker [or mangler] of everything; as also ↓ furaAfirN. (M, K.) ― -b2- And The lion; because he mangles his antagonist: (Z, TA:) or the lion that mangles his antagonist (O, K *) and everything; (O;) as also ↓ firfaArN and ↓ furofurN, (K,) or ↓ furafirN, (O,) and ↓ furaAfirN and ↓ furaAfirapN. (O, K.) ― -b3- And Light and unsteady in mind: (Lth, T, M, O, K:) fem. with p. (Lth, T, M, O.) ― -b4- And Loquacious; talkative; a great talker; (M, K;) like varovaArN: (M:) fem. with p. (K.) -A2- Also A species of tree, (T, M, O, K,) hard, having much endurance of fire, (T, O,) of which are made [bowls such as are termed] qiSaAE (M, O, K) and EisaAs: (M, O:) AHn says, it is a great kind of tree; (O;) it becomes tall like the dulob [q. v.]; its leaves are like those of the almondtree; it has blossoms like the red rose; (O, TA;) and it becomes thick so that great [bowls such as are termed] EisaAs, and A^aqodaAH, are turned from it: (O:) when its tree becomes old, its wood becomes black like ebony: (O, TA:) it is a hard wood, that blunts iron; and the bowls thereof are thin and light, and of pleasant odour: small saddles, called maxaASir, pl. of mixoSarapN, for excellent she-camels, were also made of it, and the curved pieces of wood (A^aHonaA=') thereof amounted [in price] to two hundred dirhems. (O.) -A3- And A sort of vehicle, or saddle, for women (T, O, K) and for pastors, resembling the Hawiy~ap and sawiy~ap [described in arts. HwY and swY]. (T.)
firofaArN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

furofuwrN * : see furaArN, in three places. [It is said that] it signifies A fat jamal (Thus in copies of the K [an evident mistranscription for Hamal, i. e. lamb, as is indicated in the TA by the addition such as has become what is termed jaforN].) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A youth, or young man; (O, K, TA;) as being likened to the lamb (Hamal) that has obtained plenty of herbage and has become fat; (TA; [see furaArN;]) and so ↓ furaAfirN. (O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And A certain bird; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ furofurN (O, K) and ↓ firofirN: (K:) a small EuSfuwr [i. e. sparrow, or passerine bird]: (ISh, T, M:) so it is said: (M:) and ↓ furofurN signifies the EuSofuwrN [in an absolute sense]; (M, K;) as also furofuwrN: (K:) accord. to AHát, Et-Táïfee says that ↓ Alfurofuru, of which the pl. is AlfaraAfiru, signifies the naqaAqiyr; thus he says, [using the pl.,] not the nuq~aAr [or naq~aAr? (see EuSofuwrN)]; and he adds that sometimes it is said that the furofuwr is the Sir~ [q. v.]; and some say ↓ Alfirofiru, with kesr, but he says, I am not confident of its chasteness: (O:) [accord. to Ed-Demeeree, as stated by Freytag, furofurN is the name of a small aquatic bird like the dove or pigeon: SM says, app. relying upon the correctness of a modern application of the word,] I have seen the furofuwr in Egypt, and it is smaller than the A_wa*~ [which is applied to the goose and sometimes to the duck]. (TA.) -A2- Also, and ↓ furaAfirN, Parched meal (sawiyq) prepared from the yanbuwt [a tree described in art. nbt, which see, and see also gaAfN], (M, O, K,) i. e. from the fruit thereof; (O, K;) as some say, from the ynbwt of 'Omán. (TA.)

firofiyrN * [Purple;] a certain sort of colour. (K.) ― -b2- And The violet: or violet-colour: syn. in Pers. bnf$h [i. e. banafo$ah, which is said to have both of these significations]. (KL.) ― -b3- [And Purslane, or purslain. (Golius, on the authority of Ibn-Beytár.)]
firofiyriY~N * [Of a purple colour]. (TA: there applied as an epithet to the flower of the faAwaAniyaA [or peony].)

furaAfirN * A horse that moves about, or agitates, the bit in his mouth, (M, O, K, TA,) to which Z adds, in order that he may disengage it [therefrom, or] from his head. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. A^axoraqu [Rough, ungentle, &c.]; (M, O, K;) applied to a man. (O, K.) ― -b3- See also farofaArN, in two places: ― -b4- and furaArN, likewise in two places: ― -b5- and furofuwrN, also in two places.
furaAfirapN * : see farofaArN, second sentence.
A^ufur~apN * and A^afur~apN: see fur~apN, in five places.

mafar~N * an inf. n. of far~a. (S, M, K. [See the first and second sentences of this art.]) ― -b2- Also A time [and a place] of fleeing: (TA:) and ↓ mafir~u signifies a place of fleeing: (I'Ab, Zj, S, M, TA:) and so does ↓ mifar~u; (Zj, K, TA,) an instrumental noun used as a noun of place. (K, TA.) [See 1, second sentence.]
mafir~u * : see the next preceding paragraph.

mufir~u * [Making to flee: &c. See its verb, 4]. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] AlA^ay~aAmu Almufir~aAtu (assumed tropical:) The days that reveal, or make manifest, [or cause to fly abroad,] news, or tidings. (O, K.)

mifar~u * [originally an instrumental noun: and hence,] A horse fit for one's fleeing upon him: (S, O, K:) or excellent in fleeing. (K.) One says farasN mikar~N mifar~N A horse well trained, willing, and active, ready to return to the fight and to flee. (TA in art. kr.) ― -b2- See also mafar~u.
mufar~aru * : see what follows.
maforuwrN * and ↓ mufar~arN Examined, looked into, searched into, inquired respecting, or interrogated. (TA. [See 1.])

faraA^o * (T, S, M, O, K) and ↓ faraA='N, (K,) both of these forms authorized by the Koofees, (TA,) A wild ass: (ISk, T, S, M, O, K:) or a youthful wild ass: (M, K:) but the absolute [i. e. the former] meaning is that which is commonly known: (TA:) pl. (of mult., TA) firaA='N (T, S, M, O, K) and (of pauc., TA) A^aforaA='N. (M, K.) Hence the saying, kul~u AlS~aydi fiY jawofi AlfaraA [Every kind of game is in the belly (or might enter into the belly) of the wild ass]; (T, S, M, O, K;) meaning that every kind of game is inferior to the wild ass: (T, O, K:) a prov., (T, S, M, K,) and therefore [the last word is] without hemz, on account of the final pause; (K;) but some write it with hemz: (TA:) it is said to have originated from the fact that three men went forth to hunt; and one caught a hare; and another, a gazelle; and the third, a wild ass; and the first and second boasted against the third, who thereupon said as above: it is applied to him who excels his fellows: (Meyd:) or to a man who is, with respect to other men, as the wild ass with respect to other kinds of game: or to the case of a man who, having several wants, one of which is a great one, accomplishes that great want, and cares not for the others' being unaccomplished. (T, TA. [See also Har pp. 468-9.]) And A^anokaHonaA AlfaraA fasanaraY [We have married our daughter to the wild ass, and we shall see,] (T, S, M, O) is another prov.; (T, Meyd;) in which alif is substituted for the hemzeh, (S, M, * O,) for the purpose of the agreement [of AlfaraA in rhyme] with sanaraY: (M:) said by a man to his wife when a man demanded in marriage his daughter and he refused, but his wife consented, and overcame the father so that he gave her in marriage to him against his wish; then the husband made the intercourse [with her] to be evil, and divorced her: it is applied in cautioning against an evil consequence: (Meyd:) or it is applied to a man when his affair has been endangered and he has seen what he does not like; and it means we have wasted our precaution, and the affair has brought us to an evil result; (As, T;) or we have considered the affair, and we shall see what it will disclose; (T;) or we have sought after high things, and we shall see what our case will be afterwards. (Th, M.)
faraA='N * : see above, first sentence.

$aYo'N fariYo'N *
i. q. fariY~N [q. v.] (O, K. * See art. frY.)

Q. 3 Aiforanobaja * , said of a lamb, (Lth, O,) or of the skin of a lamb, (S, K, [some of the copies of
the latter of which have Aljamal in the place of AlHamal,]) and of the skin of a kid, (O,) It was roasted so that the upper parts of it became dried up. (Lth, S, O, K.)

muforanobijN * [part. n. of the verb above]. A man said, describing a roasted female kid,
faA^akalotu mino muforanobijK mino jilodihaA
[And I ate of such as was roasted so that the upper parts were dried up, of its skin]. (O.)

farobayuwnN * , (K, TA, [in several copies of the K farofayuwn,]) also called ↓ A^afarobayuwnN, (TA,) [Euphorbium; an inspissated sap of a certain African plant;] i. q. lubaAnapN magoribiy~apN; the best of which is that which dissolves quickly in water; (TA;) an attenuant medicine, beneficial as a remedy for sciatica, and for cold of the kidneys, and for colic, and for the sting, or bite, of venomous or noxious reptiles or the like, and for the bite of the mad dog, and it causes abortion, and attenuates viscous phlegm. (K.)
A^afar obayuwnN * : see the preceding paragraph.

1 faruta * , aor.
faruta , inf. n. furuwtapN [said in the M to be a subst.], It (water, T, Msb) was, or became, sweet [or very sweet or most sweet (see furaAtN)]. (T, O, Msb, K.) -A2- farata, (M, K,) aor.
farita , (M,) or
faruta , (K,) inf. n farotN, (M,) He acted vitiously, or unrighteously; or committed adultery, or fornication; syn. fajara. (M, K.) -A3- farita, [aor.
farata ,] He became weak in his intellect, after having possessed ample intelligence. (IAar, T, O, K.)

firotN *
i. q. fitorN [The space measured by the extension of the thumb and fore finger]; (IJ, M, K;) a dial. var. of the latter word; as though formed by transposition. (M.)

furaAtN * , applied to water, (T, S, M, &c.,) and furaAhN, both chaste forms, and well known, like taAbuwtN and taAbuwhN, (Towsheeh, MF, TA,) Sweet: (S, O:) or very sweet: (K:) or of the sweetest kind: (T, M, L:) or that subdues thirst by its excessive sweetness: (Bd in xxv. 55:) so called, accord. to Z, because it breaks the vehemence of thirst, and allays it; as though from rafata, and formed by transposition: (TA:) you say maA='N furaAtN, (S, M, O, K,) and in a copy of the K firaAtN also, (TA,) and miyaAhN furaAtN, (S, M, O, K,) and firotaAnN, (M, Msb, in copies of the K furotaAnN, and in the CK farotaAnN,) like girobaAnN [pl. of guraAbN], when furaAtN is pluralized, but this is rarely the case. (Msb.) ― -b2- AlfuraAtu signifies also [The Euphrates;] the river of ElKoofeh; (S, Mgh, O, * K; *) a great, celebrated river, which issues from the limits of Er-Room, then passes by the borders of Syria &c., and, after meeting with the Tigris, forms therewith one river, and pours forth into the Sea [or Gulf] of Persia. (Msb, TA.) And AlfuraAtaAni is an appellation applied to [The Euphrates and Tigris; i. e.] AlfuraAtu and dijolapu: or, accord. to the S [and O] AlfuraAtu and dujayolN [The Euphrates and Dujeyl, which latter is a branch of the Tigris]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The sea: (M, K:) so in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb describing pearls as found therein. (M.)

farotanaA * , (M, K,) accord. to Ibn-Habeeb from farata [q. v.], but accord. to Sb the n is radical, (M,) or AlgarotanaA accord. to IB, (TA in art. frtn,) The fornicatress, or adultress. (M and K in this art. * and in art. frtn.) And The female slave: (Th, and S and K in art. frtn:) or so AlfarotanaA: and Aibonu AlfarotanaA The son of the female slave that is a fornicatress. (IAar, TA in that art.) And Aibonu farotanaA The low, ignoble, mean, or sordid. (El-Ah wal, IB, TA.) ― -b2- Also, farotanaA, the name of A certain woman. (M and K in art. frtn.) ― -b3- And AlfarotanaA The young one of the hyena. (K in art. frtn.)

Q. 1 farotana * , (T, K, TA,) inf. n. farotanapN, (T, TA,) signifies $aq~aqa kalaAmahu waA@hotama$a fiyhi [app. meaning He uttered, or endeavoured with repeated efforts to utter, his speech in the best manner, and proceeded slowly therein]: (T, K, * TA:) in the copies of the K, Ahtms, with the unpointed s, is put for Ahtm$, which is the right reading. (TA.) ― -b2- And He went along with short steps. (K.) -A2- And He (a man) became angry, and in a state of excitement: from what here follows [and therefore, app., post-classical]. (TA.)
furotunapN * , with damm, [meaning with two dammehs,] A state of commotion of the sea arising from the violence of the winds: app. post-classical. (TA.)
farotanaA * , in which the n is held by some to be radical, and by others to be augmentative, see in art. frt.

1 faravotu Alkari$a * : see 4. ― -b2- farava Aljul~apa, (ISk, T, S, M, O, K,) aor.
faruva , (T, O,) or
fariva , (M,) or both, (ISk, S, K,) inf. n. farovN, (T, M,) He scattered, or dispersed, [the contents of] the jul~ap [or receptacle made of palm-leaves, for dates]: (T, * K:) or ripped the jul~ap, and then scattered, or dispersed, its contents, (ISk, S, M, O,) entirely, (M,) liloqawmi [for the people, or party]. (ISk, S, O.) ― -b3- And in like manner, (M,) farava kabidahu, (ISk, T, S, M, O, K,) aor.
faruva , (ISk, S, and so in some copies of the K,) or
fariva , (O, and so in other copies of the K,) inf. n. farovN; (S, O;) and ↓ far~avahaA, (ISk, S, M, O, K,) inf. n. taforiyvN; (ISk, S, O, K;) He struck, or smote, him, (ISk, T, S, O,) or his liver, (K,) he being alive, (ISk, S, O, K,) so that his liver became scattered. (ISk, T, S, O, K.) And [hence] one says, farava AlHub~u kabidahu, and ↓ far~avahaA, and ↓ AfrvhA, meaning (assumed tropical:) Love crumbled [or crushed] his liver: [like as we say “ it broke his heart: ”] (M, TA:) and farotN is used in like manner of men, as meaning the crumbling of the liver by grief and molestation. (TA.) -A2- See also 7. ― -b2- fariva, aor.
farava , (K,) inf. n. faravN, (M, O,) He was, or became, satiated. (M, * O, * K.) You say, $ariba EalaY faravK He drank on an occasion, or in a state, of satiety. (M, TA.) ― -b3- fariva Alqawomu The people, or party, became scattered, or dispersed. (O, K.)
2 far~ava see the next following paragraph: ― -b2- and see also the preceding paragraph, in two places.

4 Afrv Alkari$a *
He scattered the contents of the kr$ [or stomach of a ruminant animal]: (T:) or he ripped the kr$, and threw away what was in it: (ISk, S, O:) or Alkari$a Eani ↓ faravotu Alfarovi, aor.
faruva , inf. n. farovN; and A^aforavotuhaA, and ↓ faravotuhaA; I ripped the kr$, and scattered what was in it. (M, TA.) Accord. to the K, one says, Afrv Alkabida, meaning He ripped the kbd [or liver], and threw away the furaAvap, i. e., what was in it: but this is taken from two passages in the M and T, which the author of the K has confounded.
