(TA.) ― -b2- And [hence, app.,] Afrv A^aSoHaAbahu (assumed tropical:) He exposed his companions (T, S, M, O, K) to the ruling power, (T,) or to the censure of men: (T, S, M, O, K:) or he pronounced them to be liars, in the presence of a people, or party, in order to lessen them in their estimation: or he exposed to reproach their secret: (M:) or he calumniated, or slandered, them. (IF, O.) And Afrv Alr~ajula (assumed tropical:) He reviled, vilified, or vituperated, the man; charged him with a vice, fault, or the like; defamed him; or detracted from his reputation. (M, O.) ― -b3- See also 1.
5 tafar~ava see the paragraph here following.

7 Anfrvt kari$uhu *
His (a ruminant animal's) stomach became ripped and its contents became scattered, or dispersed. (M.) ― -b2- And Anfrvt kabiduhu His liver became scattered by a blow, (ISk, T, S, O, K,) he being alive. (ISk, S, O, K.) ― -b3- Ainofaravato said of a pregnant woman; as also ↓ tafar~avato; (O, K, but only the inf. ns. are mentioned in the K;) and ↓ farivato; (T, A, O, K, but only the inf. n. is mentioned; in a copy of the T written farav; in the K, farov, and so in a copy of the A; [accord. to the TK, the pret. is faravato, and the aor. taforuvu; but is probably only inferred from the form of the inf. n. in the K;]) She had a heaving of the soul [or stomach], or a tendency to vomit. (T, A, O, K. *) [And] Aunofuriva bihaA She (a woman, in the beginning of her pregnancy,) was affected with a spitting, and with a heaving of the soul [or stomach], or a tendency to vomit. (M.) [See also the last of the following paragraphs.]

farovN * The sirojiyn [here meaning feces] (S, A, O, K) while remaining (S, O) in the kari$ [or stomach of a ruminant animal]; (S, A, O, K;) the dregs in the kr$: (Jel in xvi. 68:) or i. q. siroqiyn [a dial. var. of srjyn]: and the srqyn of the kr$; as also ↓ furaAvapN, (M,) [i. e.] AlfuraAvapu signifies what is extracted from the kr$ [like
Alfarovu: it is erroneously expl. in the K: see 4]: (O:) the pl. of farovN is furuwvN. (S, O.) ― -b2- And Anything that is scattered from a bag or other receptacle for travelling-provisions &c. (M.) -A2- Also A small [leathern vessel for water, of the kind called] rakowap [q. v.]; (T, K;) a dial. var. of qarovu: (K:) or the small rakowap is called Alqarovu [only], with q. (O.) -A3- See also the last of the following paragraphs.
furaAvapu * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mafaArivu * [a pl. of which the sing. is app. maforavu or maforivN] The places in which [slaughtered] sheep and other animals are ripped [and eviscerated] and skinned. (O.)
mutafar~ivapN * : see the following paragraph, in two places.

A_in~ahaA lamunofaravN bihaA * , said of a pregnant woman, Verily she is affected with a heaving of the soul [or stomach], or a tendency to vomit, (O, K, * TA, *) by reason of the heaviness of pregnancy: (O:) [or] one says of a woman in the beginning of her pregnancy, ↓ A_n~ahaA lamutafar~ivapN, meaning [Verily] she is affected with a heaving of the soul [or stomach], or a tendency to vomit, and the phlegm at the head of her stomach is much in quantity: so says ISk, on the authority of AA: but [Az, after citing this, adds,] I know not whether it be munofarivapN or ↓ mutafar~ivapN: (T, TA: *) and ↓ AimoraA^apN farovN, (M, TA, [in the former, as given in the TT, the latter word is written frovN, without any vowel-sign to the f,]) it is said, (TA,) means A woman who spits, [or expectorates phlegm,] and has a heaving of the soul [or stomach], or a tendency to vomit, in the beginning of her pregnancy. (M, TA.)

1 faraja bayona Al$~ayoy^ayoni * , aor.
farija , inf. n. farojN, He made an opening, or intervening space, [or a gap, or beach,] between the two things; or he opened the interstice, or interval, between the two things: (Msb:) [and faraja Al$~Yo'a He opened the thing; and particularly by diduction, or so as to form an intervening space, or a gap, or breach; he unclosed it: and in like manner ↓ fr~ij, inf. n. taforiyjN; for ex.,] you say, Haluwbatihi far~aja maA bayona rijolaYo [He made an opening, or intervening space, between the hind legs of his milch camel; i. e. he parted her hind legs]; (S and O and K in art. fHj, &c.;) and fr~j bayona A^aSaAbiEihi He made openings, or intervening spaces, between his fingers. (MA.) ― -b2- The saying in the Kur lxxvii. 9 waA_i*aA A@ls~amaA='u furijato means [And when the sky] shall be opened so that it shall become portals: (Ksh:) or shall become cloven, or split, or rent. (Bd and Jel.) ― -b3- And you say, faraja AlbaAba He opened the door. (A, TA.) And faraja faAhu He opened his mouth to die. (TA.) ― -b4- And faraja Alqawomu lilr~ajuli, aor.
farija , inf. n. farojN, [and faraja lahu, aor.
faruja , inf. n. farojN and furojapN, seems from the context to be mentioned in this sense in the L,] The people, or party, made room, or ample space, for the man, in the place of standing or of sitting. (Msb.) ― -b5- And faraja, aor.
farija , (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. farojN; (O, Msb;) and ↓ fr~j, (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. taforiyjN; (S, O;) signify also He (God) removed, cleared away, or dispelled, grief, or sorrow; syn. ka$afahu. (Msb, K.) You say, ↓ far~aja A@ll~`hu gam~aka and faraja A@ll~`hu Eanoka gam~aka [May God remove, or clear away, from thee thy grief, or sorrow; and in like manner, suppressing the objective complement but meaning it to be understood, Eanoka ↓ far~aja and faraja Eanoka]. (S.) -A2- See also 7, in two places. -A3- farija, [aor.
faraja ,] inf. n. farajN, He had his pudendum (faroj) constantly uncovered (S, TA) when he sat. (TA.) ― -b2- [And, app., He had buttocks which did not meet, or which scarcely met, by reason of their bigness. (See farijN and A^aforaju.)] ― -b3- farijato said of a she-camel: see 4. ― -b4- [Freytag adds, as from the S, another signification of farija, “ Liberatus fuit curis, tristitia, laetatus fuit: ” but for this I do not find any authority.]

2 fr~j * : see the preceding paragraph, first sentence: ― -b2- and again, in the latter half, in three places. -A2- Also, (O, K,) inf. n. taforiyjN, (K,) He was, or became, extremely aged, or old and weak. (O, K.) [From fr~j laHoyayohi, which see expl. voce fak~a.]

4 Afrj Aln~aAsu Eano Tariyqihi *
The people cleared themselves away from his road, or path; removed out of his way. (S, O, K. *) And AfrjwA Eani Alqatiyli [as also ↓ AnfrjwA (occurring thus in the S and Msb and TA in art. jlw)] They cleared themselves away, or removed, from the slain person: (Mgh, O, Msb, K:) implying that it was not known who had killed him. (Msb.) And AfrjwA Eani AlmakaAni They left, abandoned, or quitted, the place. (O, K.) ― -b2- Afrj AlgubaAru The dust became dispersed. (TA.) ― -b3- And Afrj signifies also His shooting, or casting, became altered [for the worse], having been good. (TA.) -A2- Afrj Alwaladu Aln~aAqapa The young one caused the she-camel to be in the state in which one says of her ↓ farijato, i. e. ↓ Ainofarajato fiY AlwilaAdapi [app. meaning She became unknit, or loosened, in the joints of the hips in parturition (see explanations of fariyjN as applied to a ewe and to a woman)], when bringing forth for the first time; whereby she was caused to suffer extreme distress: whence ↓ faArijN signifies Distressed. (Mgh.)

5 tfr~j * : see 7, in two places. ― -b2- [It also signifies He diverted, amused, or cheered, himself; or became diverted, &c.; often followed by EalaY $aYo'K, meaning by viewing a thing, i. e., some rare, or pleasing, object: but thus used, it is app. postclassical. (See also the next paragraph.)]

7 Anfrj *
It opened; [and particularly by diduction, or so as to form an intervening space, or a gap, or breach; it gaped; it became unclosed; and so ↓ tafar~aja; (see exs. in art. fyD, voce A^afaASa, in three places;) and it became unknit, or loosened, said of a bone, and of a limb or member, and of a joint; (see fariyjN, in two places; and see also fakikota, and Ainofak~a in three places, and fakakN;)] syn. AnftH. (Msb in art. ftH; &c. [See also furojapN.]) ― -b2- Ainofarajato siyataAhaA is said of a bow such as is termed ↓ faruwjN, (O, K, TA,) as also Ainofaj~ato [i. e. Anfj~t hiYa, which shows that the meaning is, Its two curved extremities were such as to have an open space between them and between the intermediate portion and the string]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 4, second sentence: ― -b4- and the same, last sentence; and fariyjN, in two places; and faArijN. ― -b5- [Ainofarajotu Eani AlkalaAmi occurs in the L, in art. fS, app. meaning I broke off from, or intermitted, speaking.] ― -b6- Anfrj said of grief, or sorrow, or anxiety, [and the like,] signifies It was, or became, removed, cleared away, or dispelled; (A, O, TA;) as also ↓ tfr~j; (S, * O, * TA;) and so ↓ faraja, aor.
faruja , inf. n. furuwjN. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
↓ walil$~ar~i baEoda AlqaAriEaAti furuwju
meaning [And to evil, after striking and agitating calamities, there is, or shall be,] a removing, clearing away, or dispelling: (S, O, TA:) the last word being the inf. n. of the last of the verbs above mentioned; or it may be a pl. of ↓ farojapN, like as SuxuwrN is of SaxorapN. (TA.) ― -b7- Also He was, or became, happy, or cheerful. (KL. [See also 5.])

farojN * : see furojapN. ― -b2- The space between the hind legs of a horse or mare: (S, O, K:) so in the saying of Imra-el-Keys,
lahaA *anabN mivolu *ayoli AlEaruwsi
tasud~u bihi farojahaA mino duburN
[She has a tail like the skirt of the bride, with which she fills up the space between her hind legs, from behind]. (S, O.) And The space between the fore and hind legs of a horse or the like. (L.) [Hence, app.,] one says, malaA^a farojahu and furuwjahu, and sd~a furuwjahu [in which phrase mad~a is erroneously put for sad~a in one place in the TA], and jaraY milo'a furuwjihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He (a horse) ran swiftly. (TA.) And malaA^a furuwja farasihi (assumed tropical:) He made his horse to run at the utmost rate of the pace termed HuDor. (TA in art. mlA^.) ― -b3- The pudendum, or pudenda; the part, or parts, of the person, which it is indecent to expose; (S, O, Msb, K, &c.;) applied to the pudenda of men and of women and of youths, with what is around them; and so of horses and the like: (TA:) or the anterior pudendum [i. e. the external portion of the organs of generation] of a man and of a woman, by common consent of the lexicologists; and applied to this and the posterior pudendum [in the conventional language of the
law] because both belong to the same [legal] predicament [in certain cases]; (Mgh, Msb;) or because each of them is a place of opening; (Msb;) or because between the legs: (TA:) but in common parlance it is mostly applied to the anterior pudendum: (Msb:) or peculiarly, accord. to some, the anterior pudendum of a woman [i. e. the vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation of a woman: and the vagina]: (MF, TA:) pl. furuwjN. (Msb.) fulaAnN A@bonu farojihi means (assumed tropical:) Such a one is solicitous for his faroj. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. bnY.) ― -b4- And i. q. fatoqN [app. as meaning An open, wide, place]: pl. furuwjN: (Msb:) which latter also signifies The sides, or lateral parts, quarters, or tracts, of a land. (TA.) And The part between the two sides, i. e. the baTon, of a valley: and hence used in relation to a road, as meaning its entrance: and a faj~ [or wide, or depressed, road,] of a mountain. (ISh, TA.) And A frontier-way of acces to a country; and [particularly such as is] a place of fear; (S, O, K, TA;) so called because not obstructed; (TA;) and so ↓ furojapN, (Msb,) [pl. furajN, whence] one says, fulaAnN tusad~u bihi Alfuraju, (A,) or AlfuruwjN, which is the pl. of farojN, (TA,) meaning [Such a one, by him are obstructed] the frontier-ways of access [to the enemy's country]. (A, TA.)
furojN * : see furujN; the latter in two places.
firojN * : see furujN; the latter in two places.

farajN * inf. n. of farija [q. v.]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And [app. as such also, or] as a simple subst., The having the pudendum (Alfaroj) constantly uncovered, (K, TA,) when sitting. (TA.) ― -b3- Also a subst. [or quasi-inf. n.] from faraja Algam~a; (Msb;) [as such signifying] The removal, or clearing away, of grief, or sorrow: or freedom from grief, or sorrow: (S, * O, * KL:) or i. q. raAHapN [i. e. rest, repose, or ease; or cessation of trouble, or inconvenience, and of toil, or fatigue; or freedom therefrom]: (MA:) and ↓ farojapN and ↓ furojapN accord. to ISk, and ↓ firojapN: also accord. to Az, signify the same as farajN: (Msb:) one says, maA lih`*aA Algam~i mino ↓ farojapK and ↓ furojapK and ↓ firojapK [There is not for this grief any removal, or clearing away]: (T, TA:) and ↓ likul~i gam~i furojapN i. e. ka$ofapN [For every grief there is a removal, clearing away, or dispel-ling]: (A:) or ↓ farojapN, of which furuwjN may be a pl., (see 7, in two places,) signifies rest from grief, or mourning, or from disease: (TA:) or freedom from difficulty, distress, or straitness; as also ↓ furojapN: (Msb:) or freedom from anxiety; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ furojapN and ↓ firojapN: (O, K:) or ↓ farojapN, with fet-h, is an inf. n. [app. of unity]; and ↓ furojapN, with damm, is a simple subst.: (IAar, Msb:) or ↓ farojapN relates to an affair or event; and ↓ furojapN, [which see expl. below,] to a wall, and a door; but the two [primary] significations are nearly the same: the authority for the three [syn.] forms of the word is taken by the author of the K from the statement in the T, cited above, that one says, maA lih`*aA Algam~i mino farojapK and furjapK and firojapK. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] A^um~u Alfaraji is a name of The juw*aAbap [n. un. of juw*aAbN: see art. j*b]. (Har p. 227.)

farijN * (S, O, TA) and ↓ A^aforaju (K, TA) A man whose pudendum (faroj) is constantly uncovered (S, O, K, TA) when he sits. (TA.) ― -b2- makaAnN farijN A place in which is tafar~uj [app. as meaning diversion, amusement, or cheering pastime; such a place as is termed in Pers. tafar~uj GaAho]. (A, TA.)

furujN * (S, O, K) and ↓ firojN, with kesr, (O,) or ↓ furojN, (K,) and ↓ faArijN and ↓ fariyjN, (S, O, K,) [like faruwjN (see 7) and faj~aA='u,] A bow wide apart from the string; (S, O, K;) or of which the string is distant from its kabid [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And the first, A woman wearing a single garment; (O, L, K;) of the dial. of El-Yemen; (O, L;) like fuDulN in the dial. of Nejd; (L;) as also ↓ furojN. (K.) ― -b3- And, as also ↓ firojN, One who will not conceal a secret: (O, K:) and ↓ furajapN a man wont to reveal his secrets. (Ham p. 49.)

farojapN * : see farajN, in five places. ― -b2- It is said in the T, that A^adorakuwA Alqawoma EalaY farojatihimo or ↓ furojatihimo occurs in a trad. as meaning ElY hziymatihimo [i. e. They overtook the people, or party, in their state of defeat]: but it is also related as with qAf and HA=' [app. qaroHatihimo]. (TA.)

furojapN *
An opening, or intervening space, [or a gap, or breach,] between two things; (Msb, TA;) as also ↓ farojN, (A,) of which the pl. is furuwjN only; (TA;) [and so ↓ maforajN, lit. a place of opening, occurring in the K in art. wdY, &c.;] and ↓ munofarajN: (JK and K voce xalalN, &c.:) the pl. of the first is furajN (Msb, TA) and furujaAtN: (TA:) and it is also in a wall, (S, Msb, K,) and the like: (S, Msb:) and signifies also an opening, or a space, or room, made by persons for a man entering among them, in a place of standing or of sitting. (Msb.) One says, bayonahumaA furojapN, meaning AnofiraAjN [i. e. Between them two is an opening, or intervening space, &c.]. (S.) furaju Al$~ayoTaAni [The Devil's gaps], occurring in a trad., means the gaps, or unoccupied spaces, in the ranks of men praying [in the mosque]. (L.) ― -b2- See also farojN, last sentence: ― -b3- and see farajN, in seven places: ― -b4- and farojapN.
firojapN * : see farajN, in three places.
furajapN * : see furujN, last sentence.
faruwjN * , applied to a bow [like furujN &c.]: see 7.

fariyjN * : see furujN. ― -b2- Also A ewe whose hips are unknit, or loosened, [in the joints], (warikaAhaA ↓ Ainofaraja [see 4],) when she brings forth. (TA.) And A woman whose bones are unknit, or loosened, (EiZaAmuhaA ↓ Ainofarajato) in consequence of parturition: and hence, as likened thereto, (tropical:) a camel that is fatigued, and drags his feet, or stands still: (Skr, O:) or a woman fatigued in consequence of parturition: and hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) a she-camel that is fatigued. (Kr, TA.) And A she-camel that has brought forth her first offspring. (O, K.) [See also faArijN.] ― -b3- Also, accord. to the K, [and the O as on the authority of Ibn- 'Abbád,] i. q. baAridN: but [SM says that] this is a mistake for baArizN, meaning Uncovered, appearing, or apparent; in which sense it is applied also to a fem. noun: (TA:) it is applied, in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, to a pearl (dur~ap), as meaning uncovered, and exposed to view, for sale. (O, TA.)
far~aAjN * One who often removes, clears away, or dispels, grief, or anxiety, from those affected therewith; or who does so much. (O.)

far~uwjN * The young of the domestic hen; [the chicken, and chickens;] (S, Mgh, O, K; [but the explanation is omitted in one of my copies of the S;]) as also fur~uwjN, (S, O, K,) like sub~uwHN [q. v.], (K,) a dial. var., (S, O, TA,) mentioned by Lh: (TA:) n. un. with p: (S:) pl. faraAriyju. (S, Mgh, O.) ― -b2- And hence, app., by a metaphorical application, (Mgh,) it signifies also A [garment of the kind called] qabaA='i, (S, Mgh, O, K, [but omitted in one of my copies of the S,]) having a slit in its hinder part: (Mgh, O, K:) or the shirt of a child: (O, K:) [but] the Prophet is related to have prayed in a fr~wj (Mgh, TA) of xaz~ (Mgh) or of silk; (TA;) or he pulled off one that he had put on. (O.)

faArijN * : see furujN. ― -b2- Also A she-came that has become unknit, or loosened, [app. in the joints of the hips,] (↓ Ainofarajato [see 4],) in consequence of parturition, and therefore hates the stallion, (O, K,) and dislikes his being near. (O.) [See also fariyjN.] And see 4, last sentence.

A^aforaju * , in the phrase A^aforaju Alv~anaAyaA, i. q. A^afolaju [q. v.]. ― -b2- And A man whose buttocks do not meet, (S, O, K,) or scarcely meet, (TA,) by reason of their bigness: (S, O, K:) fem. farojaA='u: it is mostly the case among the Abyssinians. (S, O.) ― -b3- See also farijN.
tiforijN * , accord. to Akh, A beater and washer and whitener of clothes; syn. qaS~aArN. (O.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

tiforijapN * and ↓ tiforaAjN are sings. of tafaAriyjN, (O,) which signifies, (IAar, O, K,) as pl. of the first, (K,) or of the second, (IAar, O,) The openings [or interstices] of the fingers: (IAar, O, K:) and the apertures, (IAar, O,) or clefts, (K,) of a railing: (IAar, O, K:) and also, (O, K,) accord. to IDrd, as pl. of tiforijapN, (O,) the slits of the [kind of garment called] qabaA=' [and far~uwjo]. (O, K.) -A2-
tiforijapN as an epithet, applied to a man, signifies Cowardly and weak; as also ↓ tiforaAjapN; (O, K;) and niforaAjaA='u, with n, (O, * K,) mentioned by IAmb, as imperfectly decl., and as signifying cowardly; (O;) or so, accord. to the T and L, ↓ tiforijN and tiforijapN, and niforijN and niforijapN: and the last two, and niforaAjN and niforijaA='N, all with n, signify one who becomes defeated, or put to flight, (yanoka$ifu,) on the occasion of war, or battle. (TA.)
tiforaAjN * and tiforaAjapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
maforajN * : see furojapN. [Hence] maforaju Algami [The place of opening of the mouth]. (TA in art. $jr.) mafaAriju [is its pl.; and] signifies Places of exit, or egress. (TA.)

muforajN * , occurring in the saying, in a trad., laA yutoraku fiY AlA_solaAmi muforajN, [meaning that he who is thus termed shall not be left unbefriended among the Muslims,] is variously explained: As used to say that it is with H; and disapproved of the saying mfrj, with j: A'Obeyd says, I heard Mohammad Ibn-El-Hasan say, it is related with H and with j; and he who says mfrj, with j, means A slain person found in a desert tract, not by a town or village, [which signification is mentioned in the K,] the fine for whose blood is to be paid from the government-treasury: AO says that it means one who becomes a Muslim and has no alliance of friendship with any one [among the Muslims]; wherefore, if he commits a crime, [such as maiming another, &c.,] the governmenttreasury must make amends for it, because he has no relations or others bound to aid him by paying a bloodwit [or the like]: (S, O: and the like is also said in the Mgh and in the K:) or, accord. to Jábir El-Joafee, it means a man who is among a people to whom he does not belong; wherefore they are bound to pay for him a bloodwit [or the like]: (O, TA:) or it means one who has no kinsfolk, or near relations: so accord. to IAar: (Mgh, TA:) or one who has no offspring: or one who has no wealth, or property: and it is also said to mean one burdened by the obligation to pay a bloodwit, or a ransom, or a debt that must be discharged: and [in like manner] ↓ maforuwjN is said to mean one who is burdened with a debt: but it is correctly with H [unpointed]; (TA;) [i. e.] such is termed muforaHo, with H: (As, Mgh:) and muforajN means one burdened by his family, although he be not in debt. (Az, TA voce muforaHN [q. v.].)
muforijN * One whose shooting, or casting, has become altered [for the worse], having been good. (AA, O, * K.) -A2- And thus, without p, A hen having chickens. (S, O, K.)

mufar~ajN * A camel (O) whose elbow is distant from his armpit: (O, K:) or wide in step: (O:) or, with p, a she-camel whose elbows are far from her chest, and whose armpits are [therefore] wide. (Ham p. 783.) ― -b2- And A comb. (O, K.)
maforuwjN * An opened door. (TA.) ― -b2- See also muforajN, near the end.
munofarajN * : see furojapN.

Q. 1 Ald~aAb~apa farojana *
He curried the beast; removed the dust from it with the firojawon. (S, K.) But the etymologists assert that the n is augmentative. (TA.)

firojawonN *
A currycomb; syn. miHas~apN [q. v.]. (S, K.)

1 fariHa * , (S, A, L, Msb, K, &c.,) [aor.
faraHa ,] inf. n. faraHN, (S, * L, * Msb, &c.,) He rejoiced; was joyful, or glad; or was happy; (S, A, L, Msb, K, &c.;) syn. sur~a: (S, A, Msb, * &c.:) or he experienced a sensation of lightness in his heart: (Th, TA:) or his bosom became dilated with delight, or pleasure, of short continuance, transitory, or fleeting, not lasting, as is the case in bodily and worldly pleasures; faraHN differing from suruwrN in the manner expl. below, though each is sometimes used as syn. with the other. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, fariHa bihi He rejoiced, was joyful, or glad, or was happy, by reason of him, or it; syn. sur~a. (S, A, Msb. *) ― -b2- And He was, or became, well pleased, or content. ― -b3- And He exulted, or rejoiced above measure; or he exulted greatly, and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (S, Msb, K.) The verb is used in this sense in the Kur xxviii. 76. (TA.)
2 far~aHa see the paragraph here following.

4 AfrHhu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iforaAHN; (S;) and ↓ fr~Hhu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. taforiyHN; (S;) He, or it, rejoiced him; gladdened him; made him joyful, or glad; or made him happy: (S, A, Msb, K:) [or occasioned him a sensation of lightness of heart: or made his bosom to become dilated with delight, or pleasure, of short continuance, transitory, or fleeting, not lasting, as is the case in bodily and worldly pleasures. See faraHN.] ― -b2- And He, or it, made him to be well pleased, or content. (Msb.) ― -b3- And He, or it, made him to exult, or rejoice above measure; or to exult greatly, and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (Msb, K.) -A2- Also He, or it, grieved him; or made him unhappy; lit. deprived him of joy; or of happiness: like as A^a$okaAhu signifies “ he made his complaint to cease. ” (L.) [Thus it has two contr. meanings.] ― -b2- And It (a debt, AA, S, TA, or a thing, TA) burdened him, burdened him heavily, or overburdened him. (AA, S, K, TA.)

faraHN * [inf. n. of fariHa, q. v.: as a simple subst.,] Joy, mirth, or gladness; or happiness; (S, L, Msb, K;) syn. suruwrN; (Msb, K;) contr. of HuzonN, (L,) and of taraHN: (S and A in art trH:) or a sensation of lightness of the heart: (Th, TA:) or dilatation of the bosom with delight, or pleasure, of short continuance, transitory, or fleeting, not lasting, as is the case in bodily and worldly pleasures; whereas suruwrN is dilatation of the bosom with delight, or pleasure, wherein is quiet or tranquillity or rest of mind, of short or of long continuance; but each is sometimes used as syn. with the other. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- And A state of being well pleased, or content, with a thing. (Msb.) ― -b3- And Exultation, or a rejoicing above measure; or a state of exulting greatly, and behaving insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b4- [Also A festivity, or merry-making; particularly, as used in the present day, on the occasion of a marriage. ― -b5- Pl. A^aforaAHN.] ― -b6- In the saying of Muteea Ibn-Iyás,
qado Zafira AlHuzonu biAls~uruwri waqado
A^udiyla makoruwhunaA mina AlfaraHi
[Sorrow, or sadness, has overcome happiness, and the object of our dislike, or hatred, has been given a turn to prevail over the object of our love], by mina AlfaraHi he means mina AlmaforuwHi bihi, i. e. AlmaHobuwbi. (Ham p. 391.)
faruHN * : see the paragraph here following.

fariHN * and ↓ faroHaAnu (Msb, K) and ↓ faruHN, as in some copies of the K and in the L and other lexicons, or ↓ faruwHN, as in other copies and mentioned by IJ, (TA,) and ↓ faAriHN and ↓ maforuwHN, (K,) the last mentioned by IJ; (TA;) fem. [of the first] fariHapN and [of the second] faroHaY (Msb, K) and faroHaAnapN, (K,) but of the correctness of this last ISd was not certain: (TA:) pl. [of the first] fariHuwna (S, Msb) and [of the second] faraAHaY and faroHaY: (K, TA:) Rejoicing, joyful, or glad; or happy: (Msb, K:) [or experiencing a sensation of lightness in the heart: or having the bosom dilated with delight, or pleasure, of short continuance, transitory, or fleeting, not lasting, as is the case in bodily and worldly pleasures. See faraHN.] Hence, in the Kur [iii. 164], fariHiyna bimaA A=taAhumu A@ll~`hu mino faDolihi [Rejoicing by reason of that which God has given them of his bounty]. (Msb.) ― -b2- And Well pleased, or content: whence, in the Kur [xxiii. 55 and xxx. 31], kul~u HizobK bimaA ladayohimo fariHuwna [Every sect is well pleased, or content, with that religion which it has]. (Msb.) ― -b3- And Exulting, or rejoicing above measure; or exulting greatly, and behaving insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (S, Msb, K:) whence, in the Kur [xxviii. 76], A_in~a A@ll~`ha laA yuHib~u AlfariHiyna [Verily God does not love those who exult, or rejoice above measure; &c.]. (S, Msb.)
faroHapN * [A joy, or gladness; or a happiness]: see an ex. voce taroHapN. ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

furoHapN *
A cause of joy or gladness, or of happiness; a thing whereby one is made joyful or glad, or happy; as also ↓ faroHapN; syn. masar~apN. (K.) ― -b2-
And A thing that thou givest to him that rejoices thee; (L, K;) a recompense that thou givest him; (L;) [as also ↓ faroHapN; for] you say, laka EinodiY faroHapN A_ino ba$~arotaniY, (S, A, [in one of my copies of the S A^aYo ba$~arotaniY, as though this were an explanation, but the former is the right reading,]) and furoHapN, (S,) meaning bu$oraY [i. e. There is for thee, with me, a gift for announcing a joyful event, if thou announce to me such an event]. (A.)
faroHaAnu * ; fem. faroHaY, and accord. to the K faroHaAnapN also: see fariHN.

faroHaAnapN *
White kamoA^ap [or truffles]: (K:) from Kr: but ISd states the word transmitted to him to be with q [i. e. quroHaAnN, of which quroHaAnapN is mentioned as a n. un.]. (L, TA.)
faruwHN * : see fariHN.
faAriHN * : see fariHN.

muforaHN * A man burdened, or burdened heavily, or overburdened, by debt, (A'Obeyd, S, TA,) or by a fine, or the like, and unable to pay it: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or needy, or in want; overcome; and poor: (K:) or poor, possessing no property: (TA:) one who is not known to have any kinsfolk or near relations; (K, TA;) but in a trad. in which it occurs in this sense as related by some, it is, as others relate the trad., with j; and so in the sense next following: (TA:) and a slain person found between two towns or villages. (K.) In the trad. in which it is said lAa yutoraku fiY AlA_isolaAmi muforaHN it has the first of the significations mentioned above accord. to A'Obeyd [i. e. the saying means One who is burdened, or burdened heavily, or overburdened, by debt, &c., shall not be left unbefriended among the Muslims]. (TA.) And in the writing that the Apostle of God wrote [as a covenant] between the Muhájirs and the Ansár were the words, lAayatorukuwA muforaHAF Hat~aY yuEiynuwhu EalaY maA kaAna mino EaqolK A^awo fidaA='K, in which muforaHAF means mafoduwHAF, (Ez-Zuhree, As, S,) i. e. [They shall not leave] one who is burdened, or burdened heavily, or overburdened, by debt, [until they aid him to acquit himself of what has become incumbent on him, of a bloodwit or a ransom,] meaning that his debt shall be paid for him from the treasury of the state: so says As; and he disallowed the saying [in this case] muforajN, [q. v.,] with j. (S.)

muforiHN * A thing that makes joyful or glad, or that makes happy: (T, L:) [and bihi ↓ maforuwHN a thing by which one is made joyful or glad, or by which one is made happy:] one says, maA yasur~uniY bihi muforiHN, (As, T, S, L,) and bihi ↓ maforuwHN, for which one should not say maforuwHN [alone], (As, S,) [i. e. Nothing that makes joyful &c., and by which one is made joyful &c., renders me happy by means of it,] relating to an affair, or event. (S.) [See also furoHapN.]

mufar~iHN *
A certain well-known [exhilarating] medicine; (S, K;) a certain medicine which is given to drink to him who is in grief, and in consequence of which he becomes happy; thus called by the physicians, and by others called sulowaAnN. (S in art. slw.)
miforaAHN * One who rejoices much, or often: (K:) or one who rejoices [app. much] whenever fortune renders him happy. (S.)
maforuwHN * : see muforiHN, in two places: -A2- and see fariHN.

1 farixa * , aor.
faraxa , (K,) inf. n. faraxN, (TK,) He (a man, TA) became free from fright, or fear, and at ease, or calm. (K.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- And farixa A_ilaY AlA^aroDi He clave to the ground; (K, TA;) as also ↓ fr~x. (TA.)

2 far~axato * , and ↓ A^aforaxato, said of a bird, (S, A, Msb, K, but in the S and Msb the verbs are in the masc. forms,) [inf. n. of the former taforiyxN,] She had [or she produced by hatching] a young one, (Msb, K,) or young ones. (A.) [In the L, in one place, and so, accord. to the TA, in other lexicons, for SaAra in the explanatory phrase SaAra lahaA faroxN, is put TaAra; as though the verbs signified She had a young one that flew.] ― -b2- And both verbs, said of an egg (bayoDapN), It had [or produced] a young one: (L, K:) or Afrxt said of an egg, it had in it a young bird: (ISh, TA in art. byD:) or it broke open from over the young bird, which thereupon came forth from it. (AHeyth, TA in art. rwE; and Msb.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph, in two places. ― -b4- fr~x Alz~aroEu, (S, A, L, K,) inf. n. taforiyxN, (S, L,) (tropical:) The seed-produce, or corn, was ready to cleave open, when it had come up: (S:) or produced many shoots: (A:) or put forth its shoots: (K:) or shot forth into leaf from the grain, when the latter had cloven asunder; as also ↓ Afrx. (L.) [See also qaS~aba.] And fr~x $ajaruhumo firaAxAF kaviyrapF (tropical:) Their trees produced many offsets, or shoots from their roots or stems. (A.) ― -b5- See also 1. ― -b6- [Hence,] wafar~axa abaADa fiyhimu Al$~ayoTaAnu, occurring in a trad., means (tropical:) The devil made his fixed abode among them; like as a bird keeps to the place of its eggs and young ones. (L.) And [in like manner] one says, fr~x Al$yTAn fiY raA^osihi (tropical:) The devil took up an abode in his head. (TA in art. fHS.) ― -b7- fr~x Alqawomu means (assumed tropical:) The people, or party, became weak; i. e., became like young birds. (K.) And fr~x said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, base, vile, or abject. (T, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was frightened; or he feared, or was afraid. (K.) And fur~ixa, in the pass. form, said of a coward, and of a weak old man, inf. n. taforiyxN, (assumed tropical:) He was frightened, and made to tremble. (L.)

4 A^aforaxato * said of a bird: ― -b2- and of an egg: see 2. ― -b3- [Hence,] one says, A^aforaxa bayoDapu Alqawomi, meaning (assumed tropical:) What was hidden, of the affair, or case, of the people, or company of men, became apparent. (ISh, TA in art. byD. [See also a similar phrase in what follows.]) And Afrx fuw^aAduhu (tropical:) His heart became free from fear: fear in the heart being likened to a young bird in the egg. (L.) And Afrx Alr~awoEu (tropical:) Fright, or fear, departed; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓ fr~x, inf. n. taforiyxN: (K, TA:) and one says, liyuforiHo rawoEuka (tropical:) Let thy fright, or fear, depart; like as the young bird goes forth from the egg. (S, TA. [But see rawoEN: and see also a phrase similar to this in what follows.]) And A^aforaxa AlA^amoru The affair, or case, became manifest, or plain, (S, A, L, K,) as to its issue, or result, (L,) after having been confused, or dubious; (S, A, L, K;) as also ↓ fr~x. (L.) ― -b4- Afrx Alqawomu bayoDahumo, (S, L, K,) or bayoDatahumo, (as in some copies of the K,) meaning (tropical:) The people, or party, disclosed their secret, (S, L, K, TA,) is said of those whose case has become apparent. (L.) [Hence it seems that Afrx AlbayoDapa properly signifies It (a bird) hatched the egg, and produced the young bird.] A^aforixo rawoEaka (tropical:) Calm thy mind, (S, L, K, TA,) is a prov., mentioned by Az, from A'Obeyd, as said, on occasions of fear, to him who is cowardly. (L, TA.) And A^aforaxa rawoEahu means (assumed tropical:) He prayed for him that his fright, or fear, might become calmed, and depart. (AO, TA.) ― -b5- See also 2, latter half.

10 Astfrx AlHamaAma *
He took for himself the pigeons (S, K) for their young ones, (S,) or for [the purpose of their producing] young ones. (K.)

faroxN * The young one of a bird: (S, A, Mgh, L, K:) this is the primary signification: (L:) or, of any creature that lays eggs: (Msb:) fem. with p: (S, A:) and, (L, K,) sometimes, (L,) the young one of any animal: (L, K:) pl. (of pauc., S, L) A^aforuxN and A^aforaAxN (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and A^aforixapN, (L, K,) the last of which is extr. [with respect to rule], (IAar,) and (of mult., S, L) firaAxN (S, L, Msb, K) and firoxaAnN (L, Msb, K) and furuwxN (Msb, K) and furuxN. (L.) [See an ex. (from a poet) in which firaAx is treated grammatically as a sing. in the first paragraph of art. xlf.] ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A base, a vile, or an abject, man, who is driven away. (K.) And one says, fulAanN faroxN mina AlfiraAxi, (TA,) or mn Alfuruwxi, (so in two copies of the A,) meaning (tropical:) Such a one is a bastard: (A, TA:) said by El-Khafájee to be a phrase of the people of El-Medeeneh, peculiarly; but accord. to MF, it is a post-classical phrase common in El-Hijáz. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A sucker, an offset, or a sprout, of any plant (L, K) or tree &c.: (L:) or a branch of a tree: or, as some say, a branch that is in the middle of a tree: (Ham p. 347:) or [its pl.] firaAxN signifies offsets, or shoots, from the roots or stems of trees: (A:) and this is also said to signify worms that are in herbs. (Ham p. 491.) And (tropical:) Seed-produce, or corn, shooting forth into leaf from the grain, when the latter has cloven
asunder: (Lth, TA:) or, ready to cleave open, (S, K,) when it has come up: (S:) or, when it has shoots. (L.) ― -b4- And Alfaroxu signifies (tropical:) The fore part of the brain; (K, TA;) thus called by way of comparison [to the young one of a bird], in like manner as it is called AlEuSofuwru; (TA;) or the ESfwr is beneath the farox: (TA in art. ESfr:) the pl. is firaAxN: and Alfaroxu signifies [also, particularly,] the fore part of the brain of the horse. (TA in the present art.) In the saying of ElFarezdak,
wayawoma jaEalonaA AlbiyDa fiyohi liEaAmirK
muSam~imapF tafoA^aY firaAxa AljamaAjimi
he means [And a day in which we made the swords, penetrating into that which they smote, cleave] the brains [lit. brain (Ald~maAg) of the tribe of 'Ámir]. (S, TA.)
farixN * , like katifN, (assumed tropical:) A man whose grounds of pretension to respect, or honour, are suspected. (TA.)
faroxapN * fem. of faroxN [q. v.]. (S, A.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A broad sinaAn [or spear-head]. (K.) ― -b3- faroxapu Ald~ayolami: see *ur~aAHN.

furayoxN * a dim. [of faroxN]: hence the saying, fulaAnN furayoxu qurayo$K (tropical:) [Such a one is the honoured and cherished of Kureysh]: fryx being here a dim. (S, K) denoting magnification (K) [i. e.] denoting commendation: (S:) and fulAanN furayoxu qawomihi (tropical:) Such a one is the honoured [and cherished] of his people; like a little young bird in the house of a people who rear it and treat it with kindness. (A.)

furayoxiy~apN * [or, probably, furaxiy~apN, agreeably with analogy,] an epithet applied to niSaAl [meaning “ arrow-heads, ” &c., but app. a mistranscription for nibaAl i. e. “ arrows ”], which were so called in relation to Alfurayox, a certain blacksmith in the Time of Ignorance: (TA:) or Alfurayox was a man who used, in the Time of Ignorance, to pare, or shape, arrows: (S:) mentioned by a poet in the saying,
wamaqo*uw*ayoni mino baroYi Alfurayxi
[And two feathered arrows of the paring, or shaping of El-Fureykh]. (S, TA.) [Freytag mentions fur~axiY~N, as applied to an arrow, meaning “ ad virum fr~yx appellatum referendus: ” but he names no authority: and it has been shown above that the name of the man is without teshdeed; and so, therefore, is its rel. n.]

far~uwxN *
Ears of wheat of which the final condition has become apparent, and of which the grain has become organized and compact: occurring in a trad., in which the selling of such for measured wheat is forbidden. (IAth, TA.)
muforaxN * : see mafaArixu.
muforixN * A hen-bird having [or producing by hatching] a young one [or young ones (see 2)]; (L, K;) as also ↓ mufar~ixN. (L.)
mufar~axN * : see mafaArixu.
mufar~xN * : see muforixN.

mafaArixu * , a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned, (TA,) Places where birds have [or produce by hatching] young ones. (K.) [Such a place may be called, accord. to analogy, ↓ muforaxN (which may be the sing. of mafaArixui) and ↓ mufar~axu.]

1 farada * , aor
faruda , [inf. n. furuwdN,] He, or it, was, or became, single; sole; or one, and no more. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 7, (with which two other forms of the unaugmented verb, namely, farida and faruda, are also mentioned,) in four places.

2 fr~d * , inf. n. taforiydN, He applied himself to the study of practical religion, or the law, and withdrew from [the rest of] mankind, and attended only to the observance of the commands and prohibitions [of religion]. (IAar, T, L, K.) [See also the part. n., below.]

4 Afrd * as intrans.: see 7. ― -b2- A^aforadato She (a female, S, L, a pregnant female, A, or a woman, K) brought forth one only: (S, A, L, K:) opposed to A^atoA^amato: (A:) not said of a she-camel, because she never brings forth more than one. (S, L, K.) ― -b3- Afrdhu He made him, or it, to be single; sole; or one, and no more. (Lth, T, M, * L, Msb. *) ― -b4- And He put, or set, him, or it, apart, aside, or away; he separated him, or it. (S, K.) You say, Afrdhu minohu [He separated him from him, and rendered him solitary; or he left him solitary]. (A and Mgh in art. wtr.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce EaA*ibN.] ― -b5- [Hence,] Afrd fulAanFA bi$aYo'K He made such a one to have a thing to himself alone, with none to share, or participate, with him in it. (A in art. frz.) ― -b6- And Afrd AlHaj~a Eani AlEumorapi He performed the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage separately from those of the Eumorapi [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b7- And Afrd A_ilayohi rasuwlAF (S, K) He sent [away] a messenger to him. (K.)
5 tafar~ada see the next paragraph, in two places.

7 Anfrd * and ↓ farada signify the same: (S:) the latter, aor.
faruda , [inf. n. furuwdN,] is expl. by Lth as signifying He was, or became, alone, by himself, apart from others, or solitary: (T, L:) and thus Anfrd binafosihi signifies. (Msb.) And Anfrd Eanohu He, or it, was, or became, apart, or separate, from him, or it, and alone. (L.) And Anfrd bifulAani and ↓ Astfrdhu are syn. [as meaning He was, or became, alone with such a one]. (M, A, K.) And Anfrd baAlA^amori, (AZ, T, M, L, K,) and bika*aA, (S,) and biraA^oyihi; (L;) and ↓ farada, (AZ, T, M, L, K,) aor.
faruda , (AZ, T, M, L,) inf. n. furuwdN; (AZ, L;) and ↓ farida, and ↓ faruda, (M, L, K,) mentioned by Lh; (M, L;) and ↓ Afrd, (L, K,) and ↓ tfr~d, and ↓ Astfrd; (S, M, L, K;) signify alike; (AZ, T, S, M, L, K;) i. e. He was, or became, alone; independent of others; without any to share, or participate, with him; in the affair, and in such a thing, and in his opinion: (the lexicons passim: [see Aisotabad~a:]) and [in like manner] biAlmaAli ↓ tfr~d [he was without any to share, or participate, with him in the property]. (Msb.) ― -b2- laA^uqaAtilan~ahumo Ht~aY tanofaridu saAlifatiY, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) I will assuredly fight with them until I die; lit., until the side of my neck shall become separate from my body; because its separation can be only by death. (L.)

10 Astfrd * as intrans.: see 7. -A2- Astfrdhu: see 7. ― -b2- Also He found him alone, having no second person with him. (A.) [Hence, one says,] AisotaTorada fajad~alahu lahumo falam~aA A@sotaforada minohumo rajulAF kar~a Ealayohi [He fled, or wheeled about widely, from them, to turn again, by way of stratagem; and when he found a man of them alone, he returned against him, and threw him down upon the ground]. (A, L.) And Astfrd Ald~ur~apa He (the diver) found the pearl alone, having no other with it. (A.) ― -b3- And He took it alone; by itself; without any other, or any like it. (T, L.) He took it forth from among the things that were with it. (M, K.)

faroda *
Single; sole; only; one, and no more; syn. witora; (S, A, L, Msb;) i. e. waAHidN: (Msb:) [and, used as a subst., a single, or an individual, person or thing:] fem. farodapN and ↓ farodaYo [which latter is anomalous, as though fem. of farodaAnu]: (Msb:) pl. A^aforaAdN and ↓ furaAdaY which latter is anomalous, as though pl. of furodaAnu (S, L, Msb) and of farodaYo, like as sukaAraY is pl. of sukoraAnu and of sakoraY. (Msb. See also furaAdN, below.) You say, Eadadotu Ald~araAhima A^aforaAdAF I counted the dirhems one by one. (T, A.) ― -b2- And Such as has no equal, or like: (Lth, M, L, K:) pl. A^aforaAdN (M, K) and furaAdaY [respecting which latter see above]. (K.) Alfarodu as an epithet applied to God means The Single; the Sole; the One; (T;) He who has no equal, or like; the Unequalled: (Lth, T, L:) but Az says, I have not found it so applied in the Sunneh; and no epithet should be applied to God except such as He has applied to Himself, or such as the Prophet has applied to Him. (L.) And one says sayofN farodN, (K,) and ↓ faradN, (T, L, K,) and ↓ furudN, (L, K,) and ↓ faridN, (K,) and ↓ farudN, (T, K,) and ↓ fariydN and ↓ farodadN, (K, but the third and fifth not in the text of the K as given in the TA,) A sword having diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain; (*uw firinodK, K, [in the TA wafirinodN, as though one said also sayofN firinodN, which is evidently a mistake,]) unequalled (T, L, K) in excellence. (T, L.) ― -b3- And The half [meaning one] of a pair or couple. (M, L, K.) ― -b4- And Such as is alone, by himself or by itself, or apart from others; unconnected with, or unattended by, others; solitary, or separate; syn. mut~aHidN, (M, L, K,) or maA kaAna waHodahu; (Lth, L;) unmixed with others; [in which sense it is] a word of more common application than
witorN, and more special than waAHidN: (Kull p. 278:) pl. firaAdN (M, L, K) [and A^aforaAdN and furuwdN also, as will be shown below]: an ex. of the first of these pls. occurs in the saying, (cited by IAar, L,)
taxal~ufa Als~aqori firaAda Als~irobi
[As the hawk's seizing, or carrying off by force, those that are apart from the others of the flock of birds]. (M, L. See, again, furaAdN.) [Hence,] one says vaworN farodN, (S,) and $aYo'N farodN, (M, K,) and ↓ faridN, (S, M, K,) and ↓ faradN, and ↓ farudN, (M, K,) and ↓ furudN, (K,) and ↓ faAridN, (S, M, K,) and ↓ fariydN, (S, K,) and ↓ faruwdN, (M, K,) and ↓ farodaAnu, (K,) [and ↓ muforadN (see an ex. voce $aApN, in art. $wh),] A bull, (S,) and a thing, (M, K,) that is alone, by itself, or apart from others; solitary, or separate from others. (S, M, K.) And ↓ sidorapN faAridapN A lote-tree apart from others. (S.) And $ajarapN ↓ faAridN, (M, K,) and faAridapN, (M, TA,) A tree apart from others. (M, K, * TA.) And ↓ ZaboyapN faAridN A gazelle apart, or separate, from the herd. (S, M, K.) And ↓ naAqapN faAridN, and ↓ miforaAdN, and ↓ faruwdN, A she-camel that goes away alone, apart from others, in the pasture, (M, L, K, *) and at the water; (M in explanation of the last, and L;) the epithet applied to the male being ↓ faAridN, only. (M, L.) And bih`*aA AlA^amori ↓ huwa faAridN He is alone in this affair. (A.) And it is said in a trad., ↓ lAa tuEad~u faAridatukumo, meaning Your ewe, or she-goat, that ye have set apart from the flock, or herd, that ye may milk her in the tent, or house, shall not be reckoned [among those for which ye are to pay the poorrate]: (A:) or the meaning is, what is over and above the fariyDap [or fixed number of camels, &c., to be given in payment of the poor-rate] shall not be added to the latter and reckoned therewith. (L.) And in another it is said, ↓ lAa yagul~u faAridatukumo, expl. by Th as meaning Such of you as shall segregate himself, as, for instance, one or two, and gain spoil, shall resign it to the collective body, and not act unfaithfully by taking it for himself. (M, L.) And in another, faminokumu Almuzodalifu SaAHibu AlEimaAmapi Alfarodapi And of you is El-Muzdelif, he of the solitary turban: this was said of him because, when he rode, no one with him wore a turban, to show honour to him. (L.) ― -b5- laqiyotuhu farodayoni means I met him, we two being alone. (S, L, K.) ― -b6- A^aforaAdu Aln~ujuwmi, (S, M, L, K,) as also furuwduhaA, (K,) signifies The brightly-shining stars (Ald~araAriYo'u) in the horizon [when other stars, there, are invisible]: so called because they are apart from the other [visible] stars. (M, L.) And Alfuruwdu, (T, M, L, and so in some copies of the K,) in some copies of the K ↓ Alfuroduwdu, [and thus in the CK,] but the former is the right, (TA,) Certain stars, disposed in a row, behind the Pleiades; (K;) in some copies of the K, around the Pleiades: (TA:) certain bright stars around the Pleiades. (T, L.) And (L) Certain stars around HaDaAri [q. v.], which is one of the two stars called AlmuHolifaAni, (M, L, TA,) the other whereof is called Alwazonu; (TA;) certain small stars with HaDaAri; so called because situate apart from the latter, by its side. (Kitáb Anwá el- 'Arab, TA.) And Alfarodu is a name of The star (a) in the hinder part of the neck of Al$~ujaAE [the constellation Hydra; which star is also called Eunuqu Al$~ujaAEi]. (Kzw in his description of Al$jAE.) ― -b7- farodN signifies also One side of a jaw: (M, L, K:) pl. A^aforaAdN. (M, L.) ― -b8- And A sandal such as is termed simoTN, not patched, nor having a second sole added to it; (K;) a sandal having a single sole; not having a sole composed of two pieces of leather sewed together, one beneath the other; thus in the saying,
yaA xayora mano yamo$iY binaElK farodi
[O best of such as walk with a single-soled sandal], meaning O best of the great men of the Arabs; for sandals were worn by the Arabs, exclusively of the foreigners; and thin sandals, only by the kings and chief persons of the former. (L.) ― -b9- Also, and ↓ faAridN, A bull [app. a wild bull]. (Lth, T, L. [See also muforadN.]) ― -b10- [The pl.] AlA^aforaAdu as a conventional term in lexicology signifies What have been transmitted by only one of the lexicologists; what is thus transmitted, if the transmitter is a person of exactness (as Aboo-Zeyd and ElKhaleel and others), is admitted. (Mz, 5th nwE. [See also AlA=HaAdu, voce A^aHadN; a similar, but less restricted, term: and see AlmafaAriydu.])
faradN * and faridN and farudN and furudN: see the next preceding paragraph, first quarter: and again, in the second quarter: and for the first and second and third, see also furaAdN.
farodapN * fem. of farodN [used as an epithet] in the first of the senses assigned to the latter above. (Msb.)
furadapN * One who goes away alone, (K, TA,) having left his companions. (TA.)
furodaAtN * [Hills, or the like, such as are termed] A=kaAm [pl. of A^akamapN, q. v.]. (K.)
farodaY * : see farodN, first sentence: ― -b2- and see furaAdN.
farodaAnu * : see farodN, second quarter: ― -b2- and see furaAdN.
faraAda * ; see the paragraph here following.

furaAdN * [is most properly regarded as a quasi-pl. n., rather than as a pl., of farodN; and furaAdu is similar to it in meaning]. One says, jaAw^uwA furaAdAF, and ↓ furaAdaY, (S, M, K,) with tenween and without it, (S,) and furaAda, (K,) like vulaAva and rubaAEa, (TA,) and ↓ faraAda, and firaAdAF [a pl. of ↓ farodN,] and ↓ farodaY, (K,) [and ↓ fur~aAdAF, perhaps thus by poetic license, see an ex. in a verse cited voce murosimN,] They came one by one; one at a time; (S;) one after another: (M, K:) AZ relates that the Kilábees said, jiy^otumuwnaA furaAdAF [Ye came to us one by one; or one after another]: and humo furaAdN waA^azowaAjN [They are separate persons and pairs], with tenween: and the Arabs said qawomN furaAdu, imperfectly decl., likened to vulAavu and rubaAEu, [A party composed of separate persons, disposed by ones, or one after another,] and ↓ furaAdaY, which latter is said by Fr to be a pl.: (T, L:) and the sing. [he adds] is ↓ faradN and ↓ faridN and ↓ fariydN and ↓ farodaAnu: (T, K:) but ↓ farudN, (so accord. to a copy of the T,) or ↓ farodN, (so in the K accord. to the TA, [in the CK furodN,]) in this sense, [i. e. in the pl. sense] is not allowable. (T, K.)
faruwdN * : see farodN, second quarter, in two places.

fariydN * : see farodN, former half, in two places: and see furaAdN. ― -b2- Also i. q. $a*orN [app. as meaning The beads that divide the other beads of a string]; (T, A;) in the language of the 'Ajam [app. meaning Persians] called jaAwarosaq [a word I do not find in any dictionary]: accord. to Ibráheem El-Harbee, $a*or of silver, like pearls: (T:) or $a*or that divide the pearls and gold: (M, L, K:) and pearls that are strung, and divided by other things interposed: (S, L, K:) or pearls that divide the pieces of gold in a necklace: (A:) one thereof is termed ↓ fariydapN: (T, M, A, L:) pl. faraAy^idu. (T, M, K.) And A precious, or highly-esteemed, gem; (M, L, K;) as also ↓ fariydapN; (K;) as though it were the only one of its kind; (M, L;) or so called because unequalled; or because [it is a pearl] found alone in its shell: (MF:) and as some say, (S,) ↓ faraAy^idu Ald~ur~i signifies the large pearls. (S, L.) ― -b3- Also The intermediate vertebræ between the last of the six vertebræ that are next to the daA^oY [q. v.] of the neck and the six that are between these fariyd and the [rump-bone called the] Eajob; as also ↓ faraAy^idu: (M, L, K:) or ↓ fariydapN [the sing.] signifies the vertebra that projects from the part, of the back of a horse, that is next to the lumbar vertebrœ; intervening between the dorsal vertebræ and the lumbar: it projects in some horses. (M, L.)
fariydapN * , and the pl. faraAy^idu: see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.
furaAdaY * : see farodN, first sentence: and see also furaAdN, in two places.
far~aAdN * One who sells, (T, A, L, K,) and one who makes, (M, L, K,) what are termed fariyd, (A, L, K,) i. e. (A) $a*or. (T, A.)
fur~aAdFA * : see furaAdN.
farodadN * : see farodN, first quarter.
Alfuroduwd * : see farodN, latter half.

faAridN * , and its fem. (with p): see farodN, near the middle, in nine places: ― -b2- and again, near the end. ― -b3- suk~arN faAridN Sugar of the best kind, and white. (K.) ― -b4- And A_ibilN fawaAridu [She-camels] which stallions do not resemble (lAa tu$obihuhaA). (So in the O and K. [But the right reading is evidently I think, lA ta$otahiyhaA, which the Turkish translator
of the K appears to have found in a copy of that work; and the meaning, therefore, which stallions do not desire. fawaAridu is pl. of faAridapN.])

muforadN * : see farodN, second quarter. ― -b2- [Hence, as a conventional term, A single, simple, word or vocable;] an expression of which a portion does not denote a portion of its meaning: (KT:) [pl. muforadaAtN. ― -b3- And Singular, as distinguished from dual and plural. ― -b4- And muforaAdaAtu AlT~ib~i The simples of medicine; medicinal simples.] ― -b5- And muforadN signifies also A wild bull. (L. [See, again, farodN, near the end.])

muforidN * A female, (S, L,) a pregnant female, (A,) or a ewe or she-goat, (M,) or a woman, (K,) bringing forth one only: (S, M, A, L, K:) like muwHidN and mufi*~N: (S, L:) opposed to mutoy^imN. (A.) [See its verb, 4.]

*ahaba mufar~adN *
Pieces of gold (in a necklace, A) divided, one from another, by fariyd [q. v.], (M, A, L, K,) i. e., by pearls. (A.)

mufar~idN * A rider having no other with him: (A:) or a rider having only his camel with him. (K.) ― -b2- TuwbaY lilomufar~idiyna, occurring in a trad., (L,) means Good betide those who apply themselves to the study of practical religion, or the law, and withdraw from [the rest of] mankind, and attend only to the observance of the commands and prohibitions [of religion]: (IAar, T, * L, K, TA:) and (K, TA) it is also said to mean (TA) those who are devoted to the commemoration of the praises of God: (K, TA:) or, as expl. by the Prophet himself, those men and women who commemorate the praises of God much, or frequently: (TA:) also, (K,) or, as Kt says in explaining the trad., (TA,) [and as his words are cited in the T,] those whose contemporaries in birth, (K, TA,) and the generation among which they were, (TA,) have perished, or died, while they themselves have remained, (K, TA,) commemorating the praises of God: but Az holds the explanation of IAar to be more correct than this of Kt. (TA.)
miforaAdN * : see farodN, near the middle of the paragraph.

AlmafaAriydN * as a conventional term in lexicology signifies What have been uttered by only one of the Arabs: differing from AlA^aforaAdu, which signifies what have been transmitted from the Arabs by only one of the leading lexicologists. (Mz, 15th nwE.)

Q. 1 farodasahu * , (O, K,) inf. n. farodasapN, (Kr, M, O,) He threw him down, prostrate, on the ground, (Kr, M, O, K,) in an evil, or abominable, manner: (Kr, M, O:) and flung him upon the ground; lit., smote with him the ground. (O, K.) ― -b2- And farodasa Aljul~apa He filled, or stuffed, compactly, the [receptacle for dates, termed] jul~ap. (AA, O, * K.)

farodasapN *
Width; amplitude: (M, O, Msb, K:) whence is derived the word firodawosN, (Msb, K,) accord. to Fr. (Msb.)

firodawosN *
A garden: (S, Msb:) so in the Greek language [ παράδεισος]: (M:) or a garden comprising everything that is in gardens: (Zj, M, A, O, K:) such is the proper signification; (Zj, M, O;) and so with the people of every language: (Zj, M:) and containing grape-vines: (Fr, O, K:) or a garden in which are grape-vines: (IAmb, M, Msb:) or a place in which are grape-vines: (TA:) or an ample, beautiful garden: (A:) or a garden comprising grape-vines and palm-trees: (Bd in xviii. 107:) or with the Arabs it signifies a valley abounding with herbage, like a garden: (M:) or a valley, (Zj, Msb,) or valleys, (O, K,) producing various sorts of plants or herbage: (Zj, O, Msb, K:) in the K, for AlA^awodiyapu Al~atiY tunobitu, we should read mina AlA^awodiyapi Al~atiY tunobitu; (TK;) [or rather, mina AlA^awodiyapi maA yunobitu, as in the Msb:] or a meadow; syn. rawoDapN: (Seer, M:) and the greenness of grapes (A^aEonaAb), (so in a copy of the M,) or of herbs (A^aEo$aAb): (so in the TA:) masc. and fem.: (Msb:) sometimes the latter; (K;) as in the Kur xxiii. 11, because, by Alfirodawosa is there meant Aljan~apa: (O, TA:) it is an Arabic word, (S, O, Msb, K,) accord. to Fr, (S, O, Msb,) occurring in a verse cited voce vawaAbN, which is by Hassán Ibn-Thábit, (O,) derived from farodasapN, meaning “ width ” or “ amplitude, ” (Msb, K, *) accord. to Fr: (Msb:) or it is Greek, (Zj, O, Msb, K,) transferred to the Arabic language; (Zj, O, Msb;) [i. e., arabicised: but as it occurs in the Kur (xviii. 107 and xxiii. 11), this is contr. to the opinion of Esh-Sháfi'ee and others, who deny that any arabicized word occurs therein: (see sunodusN:)] or it is Syriac: (Zj, O, K:) the pl. is faraAdiysu; (A, TA;) which is applied by the people of Syria to gardens and grape-vines. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (Bd in xviii. 107,) Alfirodawosu [Paradise: or] a garden of trees, or walled garden, (HadiyqapN,) in Aljan~ap [or Paradise]: (S:) or the highest of the stages of Aljan~ap: (Bd, ubi suprà:) or the middle and highest part of Aljan~ap. (Jel, ibid.)

furoduwsN *
Increase (nazal, in the CK nuzul,) that is in TaEaAm [i. e. wheat]: (O, K:) mentioned by IDrd, as heard from some persons of ElBahreyn. (O.)
furaAdisN * A man big in the bones. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

mufarodasN * A trellised grape-vine; syn. muEar~a$N. (Lth, S, M.) ― -b2- A wide breast. (O, K.) ― -b3- Widebreasted; having a wide breast. (M.) ― -b4- And [A thing] filled, or stuffed, compactly. (O.)

1 farazahu * , (S, A, O, Msb, K,) aor.
fariza , inf. n. farozN, (S, O, Msb, K,) He put it, or set it, apart, away, or aside; removed it; or separated it; from another thing, or from other things; (S, A, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Afrzhu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. A_iforaAzN: (K:) he divided it therefrom; (A, TA;) [and so ↓ Afrzhu:] he divided it into parts, or shares; as also ↓ Afrzhu: (Az, Msb, TA:) he distributed it, or dispersed it. (AO, AZ, TA.) You say, faraza lahu naSiybahu, aor. and inf. n. as above; and ↓ Afrzhu; He set apart, or separated, for him his portion, or share. (Mgh.) And faraza lahu mino maAlihi naSiybFA [He set apart, or divided, for him a portion, or share, of his property]; as also ↓ Afrzhu. (A.) And ↓ Afrz lahu naSiybFA mina Ald~aAri [He divided for him a share of the house]. (A.) ― -b2- See also 2. -A2- [Also, app., He made fringes, or similar decorations, to it; namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, or the like: see the pass. part. n.] Aboo-Firás [El-Farezdak] says,
busuTN mina AldiybaAji qado furizato
xuDori ↓ A^aTraAfuhaA bifaraAwizK
[app. meaning, Carpets of silk brocade, the extremities of which had been fringed with green fringes]. (TA.)

2 fr~z EalaY~a biraA^oyihi * , (K,) or ↓ faraza, (thus, without teshdeed, in the O,) inf. n. taforizapN, [which may be of either of the verbs,] (K,) He decided (qaTaEa) against me by his opinion. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K. [See also 8.])

3 fArz $ariykahu *
He separated himself from his partner, with the latter's concurrence; syn. faASalahu, (S, O, K,) and qaATaEahu, (S, A, O, K,) and faAraqahu. (A.)

4 Afrzhu * : see 1, in six places. ― -b2- A^aforazotu fulAanFA bi$aYo'K I made such a one to have a thing to himself alone, with none to share, or participate, with him in it. (A.) -A2- Also It (an object of the chase) offered him an opportunity (S, O, K) so that he shot it, or shot at it, (S, O,) from within a short distance. (S, O, K.)

6 tfArz Al$~urakaA='u *
The partners separated themselves, one from another. (A.)

7 Anfrz baEoDuhumo Eano baEoDK *
They went apart, away, or aside; removed; or separated; one from another, or one party from another. (TA in art. Ezl.)
8 Aftrz A^amorahu duwna A^aholi bayotihi * means qaTaEahu [i. e. He decided his affair exclusively of the people of his house or tent, or of his wife and family]. (O, K. [See also 2.])

Q. Q. 1 farowaza *
He died; (IDrd, O, K;) said of a man: (IDrd, O:) like harowaza. (TA.)

farozN *
A depressed tract of land (S, O, K, TA) between two hills: (TA:) or an intervening space between two mountains: (TA:) [or] ↓ furozapN has the latter meaning; mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád. (O.)
firozN * : see firozapN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also furozapN. ― -b3- Accord. to Lth, Alfirozu is syn. with Alfarodu; but this is disallowed by Az. (TA.)

farozapN *
A cleft in rugged ground. (TA.)

furozapN *
A road in, or upon, an [eminence such as is termed] A^akamap; as also ↓ firozN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- See also farozN. -A2- Also i. q. furoSapN, i. e. nawobapN [meaning A turn; or time at which, or during which, a thing is, or is to be, done, or had, in succession]. (O, K. *)

firozapN *
A piece, or detached portion, (S, O, Msb, K,) of a thing that is put, or set, apart, away, or aside, or that is removed, or separated; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ firozN: pl. [of pauc.] A^aforaAzN and [of mult.] furuwzN: and ↓ firozN signifies also a portion, or share, that is put aside for the party to whom it pertains, whether one [person] or two. (TA.)
furuz~N * A slave sound, or healthy, or without defect or blemish: or a free man sound, or healthy, or without defect or blemish. and plump. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

farowaAzN * [an arabicized word, from the Pers. ParowaAz, app. as meaning A fringe, or the like; as the latter word does in Turkish, and probably, sometimes, in Persian]: accord. to some, it is of the measure faEolaAlN from faraza in the first of the senses expl. in this art.; therefore, if so, it is an Arabic word: the pl. is faraAwizu. (TA.) See 1, last sentence.

faArizN * A tongue distinct [in utterance]: (O, K, TA:) and discriminating language. (A, * O, K, * TA.) -A2- Also A species of ant, round and black, found in dates: so says Ibráheem El-Harbee: (O and TA in art. Eqf:) or the progenitor (jad~) of the black ants: that of the red is termed EuqofaAn: (K:) but it has been before said by the author of the K, in art. fzr, that faAzirN signifies “ black ants in which is a redness: ” and it may be a mistranscription. (TA.)

faArizapN *
A road taking its course in a tract of sand amid sands that are compact and cleaving to the ground, and soft, (O, K,) appearing like an extended natural cleft in the ground: but this is mentioned in the book of Lth in art. fzr [as written faAzirap]. (O.)

A^aforazu *
Humpbacked; as also A^aforasu and A^aforaSu: so says Fr. (TA voce A^aEojaru.) [The same meaning is also assigned to A^afozaru, q. v.]

A_iforiyzN * , of a wall, an arabicized word, (S, Mgh, O, K,) [of unknown origin, like our word “ frieze, ” and the French “ frise, ” &c., said in the TA to be from the Pers. ParowaAz, mentioned above, voce farowaAzN,] A projecting appertenance or roof or covering (janaAHN) thereof; (Mgh;) the Tunuf [q. v., app. meaning a projecting coping, or ledge, or cornice,] thereof; (O and K in the present art., and the same and S in art. Tnf;) surrounding the upper part: (Kr, TA voce zayofN:) [it is also expl. as meaning] a hole, or an aperture, in a wall. (KL. [But this is app. a mistake, caused by a misunderstanding of the word TaAqN, which is expl. as having this meaning and also as syn. with A_iforiyzN; and the author of the KL evidently doubted its correctness, for he adds, “ so we have heard. ”])
muforazN * : see what next follows.

maforuwzN * and ↓ muforazN Put, or set, apart, away, or aside; removed; or separated: (Mgh:) divided into parts, or shares. (Msb.) -A2- And the former, Having the back broken; like maforuwsN. (TA in art. frs.) -A3- vawobN maforuwzN, (S, O, K,) by some written mufarowazN, (TA,) is from A_iforiyzN, the Afryz of a wall, (S, TA,) and signifies [A garment, or piece of cloth,] having taTaAriyf [app. meaning a fringe, or fringes; likened to fingers, or the ends of fingers]. (O, K.) [See 1, last sentence.]
Q. 2 tafarozana * , said of a bayo*aq [or pawn] in the game of $iToranoj [or chess], It became a firozaAn. (TA.) [See an ex. voce dasotN.]

firozaAnu Al$iToranoji * (K, TA) [The queen of the game of chess; or, as some say,] what occupies the place of the wezeer to the sultán [in that game]: (TA:) the former of these words is arabicized, from [the Pers.] faroziyn. (O and K in art. frz, and K in the present art.)

1 farasahu * , aor.
farisa , inf. n. farosN, (S, M, O, Msb, K, &c.,) He (a lion) broke, or crushed so as to break, its neck; (S, A, * Mgh, * O, K;) i. e., the neck of his fariysap; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ Aftrshu: (S:) this is the primary signification: (S, Mgh, TA:) or he (a beast of prey) seized it, (a thing,) and broke, or crushed so as to break, its neck; as also ↓ Aftrshu: (M:) or he (a lion) broke it; i. e., his fariysap: (Msb:) and he bruised, or crushed, and broke, it; namely, a thing. (M.) Accord. to ISk, (S,) you say, faras Al*iy^obu Al$~aApa, (S, TA,) meaning The wolf seized the sheep, or goat, and broke, or crushed so as to break, its neck: (TA:) accord. to En-Nadr (i. e. ISh), you say, A^akala Al*~iy^obu Al$~aApa [The wolf ate, or devoured, the sheep, or goat], but not ↓ AftrshA. (S, O, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) He killed it, in any manner; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Aftrshu: (TA:) or ↓ the latter, he (a lion, O, or a wolf, TA) captured it; or made it his prey. (O, K, TA. See also 2 [where a similar but tropical usage of the former verb is mentioned.]) You say, farasahu AlA^asadu The lion killed him or it. (Mgh.) ― -b3- farasa Al*~abiyHapa, (M, Msb,) aor.
farisa , (M,) inf. n. as above, (S, M, Mgh,) He (the slaughterer) broke the bone of the neck of the slaughtered animal before it became cold: (S, Mgh, O:) or broke its neck before its death: (Msb:) or cut, or severed, its nuxaAE [or spinal cord]: or divided its neck: (M, TA:) or slaughtered it so as to reach to the nxAE: (AO, TA:) the action thus [variously] expl. is forbidden. (S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b4- qabiyHapF ↓ farasahu firosapF He struck him [in an abominable manner, app. in the back,] so that the part between his hips became depressed and his navel protruded. (M.) -A2- farusa, aor.
farusa , (S, A, O, K,) inf. n. furuwsapN (S, A, O, K *) and faraAsapN (S, K, * in the O firaAsapN) and furuwsiy~apN, (S, * A, O, * K, *) all of which ns. are mentioned as syn. by As, (TA,) [as they are also in the S and K,] and the first and last, in like manner, by IAar, (TA,) [but the first is expressly said to be an inf. n. of farusa in the S and A only, and the second in the S only, and the third (which seems to be rather a simple subst.) in the A only,] He was, or became, skilled in horsemanship, or in the management of horses, (S, A, O, K, TA,) and in riding them, (O, * K, TA,) and in urging them to run, and in remaining firm upon them: (TA:) or faraAsapN and furuwsapN are inf. ns. having no verb: Lh only [says ISd] mentions farasa and farusa as signifying he became a horseman; and this is extr.: (M, TA:) but [beside what has been cited above, from the S and A and K,] IKtt also says that farasa Alxayola, inf. n. furuwsapN and furuwsiy~apN, signifies he rode horses well; and in like manner farusa [but not followed by Alxyl]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, skilled in anything that he endeavoured to do. (TA.) -A3- farasa biAln~aZari, [and binaZarihi, and biEayonihi, and farasa fiY Aln~aAsi, (see faArisN,)] aor.
farisa , (Msb,) inf. n. firaAsapN and faraAsapN, (As, IAar, Msb, TA,) accord. to the citation of the words of As and IAar in the L, but this is at variance with the opinion generally held, [which is, that faraAsapN is an inf. n. only of farusa, signifying as expl. above, and that firaAsapN is a subst. from tafar~usN, having no proper verb of which it is an inf. n.,] (TA,) is said of a man [in the same sense as tafar~asa, (q. v.,) as will be seen from the explanations of firaAsapN and faArisN, below]. (Msb.) See 5, latter part, in two places. -A4- farisa He kept continually, or constantly, to the eating of the dates called faraAs. (O, K.) ― -b2- And He pastured upon, or depastured, the plants called firos. (O, K.)

2 fr~s Alganama * , (inf. n. taforiysN, TA,) He (a wild beast) seized often the sheep or goats, or seized many of them, and broke, or crushed so as to break, their necks. (M, TA.) -A2- fr~sh Al$~aYo'a, (inf. n. as above, TA,) He exposed to him (namely a wild beast) the thing, [meaning the animal,] that he might seize it, and break, or crush so as to break, its neck: and A_ay~aAhu ↓ A^aforasahu the threw, or cast, it to him, that he might do so to it: (M:) and Alr~ajulu AlA^asada HimaArahu ↓ A^aforasa the man left his ass to the lion, that he might break his neck, or kill him, or make him his prey, while he himself should escape. (S, K.) El-'Ajjáj uses the former verb in relation to the kind of flies called nuEar, saying,
DarobFA A_i*aA SaAba AlyaA=fiyxa A@Hotafaro
fiY AlhaAmi duHolaAnFA yufar~isona Aln~uEaro
[A beating which, when it falls upon the tops of heads, digs, in the pates, hollows that afford prey to the blue stinging flies]; meaning, that these wounds are wide, and enable the nEr to obtain
thence what they desire. (M.) And one of the poets uses it in relation to human beings, in the following verses, [which exhibit an instance of the license termed A_iqowaA=',] cited by IAar:
qado A^arosaluwniY qiY AlkawaAEibi raAEiyFA
↓ faqado waA^abiY raAEiY AlkawaAEibi A^uforasu
A^atatohu *iy^aAbN laA yubaAliyna raAEiyFA
wakun~u sawaAmFA ta$otahiY A^ano tufar~asaA
[They had sent me among the girls with swelling breasts, as a guardian; and, by my father, while guardian of the girls with swelling breasts, or by the father of the guardian of the girls with swelling breasts, I was (lit. I am) made a prey: there came thither wolves not caring for a guardian, and those females were (as) pasturing camels eagerly desiring to be given as prey]: he likens these women to pasturing camels, although differing from them inasmuch as the latter do not eagerly desire to be given as prey, since this would be a cause of their death, whereas women do eagerly desire it, since farosu Alr~ijaAli liln~isaA='i [lit. men's making women their prey] is in this case (assumed tropical:) men's holding commerce of love with women: A^uforasu is for furisotu; for, as Sb says, they sometimes put A^afoEalu in the place of faEalotu: A^abiY is in the gen. case as governed by wa denoting swearing; and rAEY AlkwAEb may be a denotative of state relating to the t [the pronoun of the first person] understood [in A^uforasu for furisotu]; or wA^bY may be prefixed to rAEY AlkwAEb, governing it in the gen. case, and by the latter expression he may mean himself: by wolves not caring for a guardian, he means wicked men not caring for him who guarded these women: and he uses the word t$thY to denote intense desire; for if he did not mean intenseness, he would have said turiydu. (M.)

3 fArshu * , inf. n. mufaArasapN and firaAsN, (M, TA,) [app., He vied, or contended, with him in horsemanship: this signification seems to be indicated by what immediately precedes in the M, which is, farasa and farusa “ he became a horseman: ” but perhaps it may signify he vied, or contended, with him in firaAsap, meaning insight, &c.: or it may have both these significations.]

4 Afrs *
He (a pastor) had the neck of one of his sheep, or goats, broken, or had one of them killed, (S, O,) or taken, (K,) by the wolf, (S, O, K,) he being inadvertent. (K.) ― -b2- See also 2, in two places. ― -b3- Afrs Eano baqiy~api maAlK He left a remainder of property [as a prey], having taken all beside thereof. (AA, O, K.)

5 tfr~s *
He pretended to others that he was a horseman, or one skilled in horsemanship. (As, O, K.) -A2- He acted deliberately, (S, O, K, TA,) and considered, or examined, a thing, or did so repeatedly, in order to know it, or to obtain a clear knowledge of it. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- tfr~s fiyhi Al$~aYo'i [He perceived in him the thing intuitively; or by a kind of thaumaturgic faculty, and by right opinion and conjecture: or by means of indications, or evidences, and experiments, and the make and dispositions: (see firaAsapN, below:) or] he perceived in him the thing by forming a correct opinion from its outward signs; syn. tawas~amahu. (M.) You say, tafar~asotu fiyhi xayorFA, (S, O,) or Alxayora, (Msb,) [I perceived in him good, or goodness, intuitively; &c.: or] I discovered (taEar~afotu) in him good, or goodness, by right opinion. (Msb.) [↓ farasa biAln~aZari, and binaZarihi, and biEayonihi, inf. n. firaAsapN and faraAsapN, (respecting which, however, see 1, last quarter,) signifies the same as tfr~s; i. e., He perceived, or discerned, the internal, inward, or intrinsic, state, condition, character, or circumstances, by examination of outward indications, &c., and by his eye. And so fiY Aln~aAsi ↓ farasa He saw into the internal, inward, or intrinsic, states, &c., of men. See firaAsapN, below.]
8 A_ifotarasa see farasahu, in five places.

Q. Q. 1 faronasapN * [an inf. n. of which the verb is faronasato, as is shown by the mention of the part. n. mufaronisapN,] A woman's good managing of the affairs of her house, or tent: (Lth, K, TA:) the n is augmentative. (TA.)
Alfurosu * : see faArisN.

firosN *
A species of plant: (Yaakoob, S, M, O, K:) the qaSoqaAS, (O, and so in copies of the K,) or qaDoqaAD, (so in the CK,) [each said to be a name of the A^u$onaAn (or kali) of Syria, or of a species of HamoD, q. v.,] accord. to Abu-l-Meká- rim: (O:) or the Habon [q. v.]: or the barowaq [q. v.]: (O, K:) or the [small kind of thorny trees called] $iros. (TA.)

farasN * [A horse; and a mare;] one of what are called xayolN; (M;) the name frs is given to it because it crushes and breaks the ground with its hoofs; (A, O; *) and is applied to the male and the female; (S, M, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) but mostly applied to the latter; (M;) the female not being called ↓ farasapN; (S, O;) or the female is [sometimes] thus called: (Yoo, IJ, M, Msb, K:) it is applied also to the Arabian, (Mgh, Msb,) and to the Turkish, (Msb,) or that which is not Arabian: (Mgh:) or, accord. to Mohammad [the Hanafee Imám], to the Arabian only; but for this [says Mtr] I find no authority of a lexicologist, except that ISk, speaking of a solid-hoofed animal, says, “ whether it be a birozawon or a faras or a bagol or a HimaAr: ” (Mgh:) the pl. is A^aforaAsN, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) [a pl. of pauc. but used as a pl. of mult. also,] and A^aforusN, [a pl. of pauc. only,] (O,) and furuwsN: (K:) and as farasN is originally fem., you say valaAvu A^aforaAsK when you mean males [as well as when you mean females]: (M:) or you say valaAvapu A^aforaAsK, with p, when you mean males; and valaAvu A^aforaAsK, without p, when you mean females: (Msb:) the dim. is furayosN, (S, O, Msb,) when applied to the male; (Msb;) and ↓ furayosapN, when applied to the female; (S, O, Msb;) agreeably with rule; (Msb;) accord. to Aboo-Bekr Ibn-Es-Sarráj: (S, O:) or ↓ furayosN when applied to the female [also], which is extr. (Sb, M. [See HarobN.]) ― -b2- humaA kafarasaYo rihaAnK [They two are like two horses running for a wager] is a saying applied to two persons running a race to a goal, and being equal: (A, O, K:) the comparison relating to the beginning [of a contest], for the termination necessarily shows which outstrips; (O, K:) and to two who are equal, and two who are nearly equal, in excellence &c. (Har p. 640.) It was said by a man who swore that he would abstain from his wife for four months, and then divorced her: for the period during which a woman may be taken back after a [first or second] divorce is that of three menstruations or three periods of purity from menstruation; and if it ended in this case before the end of the four months during which he swore to abstain from her, she became separated from him by that divorcement: so he likened the two periods to two horses running for a wager. (O, * TA.) ― -b3- farasu AlbaHori (assumed tropical:) [The horse of the great river; i. e., of the Nile;] the hippopotamus. (Dmr. [See also EaSobN.]) ― -b4- Alfarasu (assumed tropical:) A well-known constellation; so called because of its resemblance in form to a horse; (M;) [i. e.] Alfarasu AlA^aEoZamu (assumed tropical:) [The Greater, or Greatest, Horse;] the constellation Pegasus. (Kzw.) ― -b5- qiToEapu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) [The Piece of the Horse;] the constellation Equuleus. (Kzw.) ― -b6- Alfarasu Alt~aAm~u (assumed tropical:) [The Complete horse;] a certain constellation composed of thirty-one stars, in which a portion of the constellation called Alfarasu AlA^aEoZamu is included. (Kzw. [It is further described by him; but in a manner that does not enable me to identify it with any of the constellations named by our astronomers.])

Alfarosapu * , (IAar, S, M, O, K, TA,) or ↓ Alfirosapu, (M, TA,) the former accord. to A'Obeyd, (M, TA,) or, accord. to A'Obeyd, it is with S, and the vulgar, he says, pronounce it with s, (O,) Gibbosity [of the back]; syn. AlHadabu: (IAar, O, TA:) or, (M, O, K, TA,) as also AlfaroSapu, (M, O,) which latter is the more approved in this sense, (M,) the riyH [or flatus] of gibbosity; (M, O, K, TA;) [i. e.] the ryH that renders gibbous; (M;) as though it were breaking, or crushing so as to break, the back (kaA^an~ahaA taforisu AlZ~ahora A^aYo taduq~uhu), and cleaving it (taforiSuhu A^aYo ta$uq~uhu): (O:) [or Alfarosapu signifies the displacement of one of the vertebræ; for,] accord. to As, one says A^aSaAbatohu farosapN when one of the vertebræ of one's back has become displaced; but the flatus (Alr~iyHu) from which gibbosity results is termed AlfaroSapu, with S: (TA:) or Alfarosapu signifies a flatus that attacks in the neck, and breaks it: (S:) or, as some say, an imposthume, or ulcer, (qaroHap,) that is in the neck, breaking it: (M:) or a breach (furojap) in the neck; thus says AZ: or a breach (frjp) that is in [the case of] gibbosity: the pl. is farasaAtN, not
A^aforisapN, which latter is said to be a pl. of farosapN, but is anomalous. (TA.)

furosapN * and furoSapN; the latter of which is the more approved in both of the following senses; i. q. nawobapN [meaning A turn; or time at which, or during which, a thing is, or is to be, done, or had, in succession; as also furozapN: pl. furasN]: furasu Alwirodi [the turns, or times, for coming to water in succession] means [the occasions of] persons' being left free to come to water. (M. [See furoSapN.]) ― -b2- And i. q. nuhozapN [meaning An opportunity; a time at which, or during which, a thing may be done, or had]. (IAar, M, O.) So in the phrase A^aSaAba furosatahu [He got, or obtained, his opportunity]. (M.)
firosapN * [an inf. n. of modality]: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. -A2- Alfirosapu: see Alfarosapu.
farasapN * : see farasN, near the beginning.

Alfirosinu * , of the camel, is What corresponds to the HaAfir [or hoof] of the horse (S, O, Msb, K) and the like: (S, O, Msb:) or what corresponds to the qadam [or foot] of the man: (El-Bári', Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) of the bovine animal in like manner: (IAmb, Msb:) and sometimes (tropical:) of the sheep or goat, (S, O, TA,) for AlZ~ilofu: (TA:) or it is only of the camel: (El-Bári', Msb:) or the extremity of the xuf~ [or foot] of the camel: (M:) of the fem. gender: (IAmb, M, O, Msb, K:) pl. faraAsinu, (M, Msb,) not firosinaAtN: (M:) it is of the measure fiEolinN; (S, O;) the n being augmentative; (Aboo-Bekr Ibn-Es-Sarráj, S, O, Msb, K;) because it is from farasotu. (Aboo-Bekr Ibn-EsSarráj, S.) See also art. frsn.

faraAsN *
A sort of black dates; (IAar, O, K;) not the same as the sihoriyz (O) or $ihoriyz. (K.)
A^abuw firaAsK * : see AlfaArisu.
Alfaruwsu * : see AlfaArisu.
