fariysN * [originally Having the neck broken, or crushed so as to be broken. ― -b2- And hence,] Killed [in any manner: see 1]: pl. farosaY. (K.) It is applied in this sense to a bull, and in like manner [without p] to a cow. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence] ↓ fariysapN signifies The prey of a lion [or other beast]: (TA:) an animal that is seized, (M,) and that has its neck broken, (S, M, Msb, *) by a lion [or other beast]; (S, Msb;) as also fariysN: (M:) [pl. of the former faraAy^isu.] ― -b4- See also maforuwsN. -A2- Also A ring, or hoop, of wood, (S, M, O, K,) bent [into that form], and tied, (M, O,) at the end of a rope; (M, O, K;) called in Pers. janobar [correctly Janobar]. (S, O, K.) -A3- See also fariySu AlEunuqi, in art. frS.
furayosN * , and with p; dim. ns.: see farasN, near the middle; the former in two places.
faraAsapN * : see what next follows.

firaAsapN * a subst. (S, M, O, K) from Alt~afar~usu, (O, K, TA,) signifying Alt~awas~umu, (TA,) or from tafar~asotu fiyhi xayorFA [q. v.], (S,) or from tafar~asa fiyhi Al$~aYo'a [q. v.]: (M:) or, as also ↓ faraAsapN, [said to be] an inf. n. of farasa biAln~aZari: [but see this verb:] (Msb:) firaAsapN biAlEayoni [or biAln~aZari (see 1, last quarter,)] signifies Insight; or intuitive perception; or the perception,. or discernment, of the internal, inward, or intrinsic, state, condition, character, or circumstances, by the eye [or by the examination of outward indications &c.]: (IKtt:) or firaAsapN signifies a faculty which God puts into the minds of his favourites, in consequence whereof they know the states, conditions, or circumstances, of certain men, by a kind of what are termed karaAmaAt [or thaumaturgic operations], and by the right direction of opinion and conjecture: and also a kind of art [such as physiognomy, which is especially thus termed in the present day,] learned by indications, or evidences, and by experiments, and by the make and dispositions, whereby one knows the state, conditions, or circumstances, of men: (IAth:) or the discovery of an internal quality in a man by right opinion. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., Ait~aquwA firaAsapa Almuw^omini [Beware ye of the insight, &c. of the believer]: (S, M, IKtt, IAth, Msb:) and the reason is added, faA_in~ahu yanoZuru binuwri A@ll~`h [for he looks with the light of God]. (TA. [See also quraAbapN.])
fariysapN * : see fariysN. [It is a subst. formed from the latter by the affix p.]
far~aAsN * , and Alfar~aAsu, and A^abuw far~aAsK: see AlfaArisu, in four places.

AlfironaAsu * : see AlfaArisu, in two places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The strong and courageous, (En-Nadr, O, K,) of men, as being likened to the lion. (En-Nadr, O, TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The headman, or chief, of the dahaAqiyn [pl. of dihoqaAnN, q. v.], (IKh, O, K,) and of the villages, or towns: (IKh, O:) pl. faraAnisapN. (IKh, O, K.)
Alfironawosu * : see AlfaArisu.
AlfuraAnisu * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

faArisN * act. part. n. of farasa [q. v.]. ― -b2- AlfaArisu The lion; [so called because he breaks the neck of his prey;] as also ↓ Alfaruwsu, [which has an intensive signification,] and ↓ Alfar~aAsu, (O, K,) which last [also] has an intensive signification, (TA,) and ↓ A^abuw firaAsK, (S, A, K,) and ↓ A^abuw far~aAsK, (O,) and ↓ Almufotarisu, (TA,) and ↓ AlfironaAsu, (S, M, K,) and ↓ Alfironawosu, a word of a measure not mentioned by Sb, (IJ, M,) and ↓ AlfuraAnisu; (K;) or ↓ AlfironaAsu, which is said by IKh to be applied to the lion because he is the chief of the beasts of prey, signifies, (O,) or signifies also, (S,) used as an epithet applied to the lion, (S, * M, * O,) and so ↓ AlfuraAnisu, (S, * M, O,) the thick-necked, (S, O,) that is wont to break the neck of his prey; or the former of these two, the rapacious lion; (O;) and the n in these words is augmentative: (Sb, S, M, O:) and you also say ↓ saboEN far~aAsN, (M,) or ↓ A^asadN far~aAsN, (TA,) meaning a rapacious beast, (M,) or lion, (TA,) that often seizes others and breaks their necks. (M, TA.) -A2- Also The master, or owner, of a horse; (S, M, K;) a possessive epithet; (M;) like laAbinN (S, O, K) and taAmirN: (S, O:) and a horseman; a rider upon a horse; (ISk, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) and upon a mule; (ISk, A, Mgh, Msb;) and upon an ass: (ISk, Mgh, Msb:) or a rider upon a mule is called faArisN EalaY bagolK; (ISk, S, O, Msb, K;) or faArisu bagolK; (A, O;) and a rider upon an ass, faArisN EalaY HimaArK; (ISk, S, Mgh, O, Msb;) and a rider upon any solid-hoofed beast, faArisN EalaY *iY HaAfirK: (K:) or these phrases are not used: (K:) 'Omárah Ibn- 'Akeel Ibn-Bilál Ibn-Jereer says, (S,) or AZ, (Msb,) I do not call the owner of the mule, nor the owner of the ass, faArisN, but I call them bag~aAlN and Ham~aArN: (S, O, Msb:) [faArisN is often best rendered a cavalier:] the pl. is furosaAnN (S, M, Msb) and fawaArisu, which latter is [more usual, but] anomalous, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) for fawaAEilu is [regularly] the measure of the pl. of a sing. of the measure faAEilapN, as DawaAribu, pl. of DaAribapN, or of an epithet of the measure faAEilN applying to a female, as HawaAy^iDu, pl. of HaAy^iDN, or of a sing. of the measure faAEilN applying to a thing that is not a human being or not a rational being, as bawaAzilu, pl. of baAzilN, and HawaAy^iTN, pl. of HaAy^iTN; and there are no instances like fawaArisu except those of hawaAliku and nawaAkisu [and xawaAlifu and some other words enumerated in the Msb and TA]; (S, Msb;) and as fwArs is not applied to females, no ambiguity is feared from its usage: (S, O:) [ISd says,] we have not heard AimoraA^apN faArisapN. (M.) ― -b2- Also, (As,) or faArisN EalaY Alxayoli, (S,) A man skilful in horsemanship, or in the management of horses. (As, * S.) ― -b3- And hence, the former, (fArs,) (assumed tropical:) A man skilful in anything that he endeavours to do. (TA.) ― -b4- AlfawaArisu is the name of (assumed tropical:) Four stars of the constellation Cygnus. (Kzw. See dajaAjN.) -A3- rajulN faArisu Aln~aZari, (S, O, TA,) and binaZarihi, and biEayonihi, (As,) A man who acts deliberately, and examines: (S, and so in Hr p. 356:) who possesses firaAsap [i. e. insight, or intuitive perception, &c.]: (O:) or knowing by means of examination. (TA.) And faArisN fiY Aln~aAsi [Seeing into the internal, inward, or intrinsic, states, &c., of men]. (IAar.) -A4- faArisu, (S, M, Mgh, K,) or faArisN, (so in some copies of the K,) [the former if fem., as it is a proper name, the latter if masc.,] A certain nation; (Mgh, Msb;) [namely, the Persians;] i. q. ↓ Alfurosu: (S, O, K:) generally fem.: (Msb:) furosN is pl. of ↓ faArisiY~N, which is a rel. n. from faArisu in the sense next following: (M:) [or, rather, furosN is a coll. gen. n., and faArisiY~N is its n. un.] ― -b2- Also, (S, O, but in the K “ or ”) The country of the furos; (S, O, K;) [i. e., Persia;] a country of a certain nation. (M.)
faArisiY~N * [Persian: a Persian]: see faArisu. Hence, Alt~amoru AlfaArisiY~u A certain sort of dates, (Mgh, Msb,) of good quality. (Msb.)

A^aforasu * : see maforuwsN. -A2- It is also a noun of excess, or a comparative and superlative epithet, from firaAsapN, used by Zj, in the phrase A^aforasu Aln~aAsi, meaning, The best, (M,) or best and most true, (TA,) in firaAsap, [i. e., insight, or intuitive perception, &c.,] of mankind. (M, TA.) One says also, A^anaA A^aforasu minoka I am more endowed with mental perception, [or insight, or intuitive perception,] and more knowing, than thou. (TA.)

maforuwsN *
Having the back broken: (M, TA:) and so maforuwzN. (TA.) ― -b2- And Humpbacked; as also ↓ fariyosN, (M, TA,) and ↓ A^aforasu (Fr in TA voce A^aEojaru) [and A^aforaSu and A^aforazu].
Almufotarisu * : see AlfaArisu.
mufaronisapN * A woman who manages well the affairs of her house, or tent. (Lth, TA.)

farosaxN * , mentioned, but not explained, by J [in the S], (K,) [A parasang, or league;] three Háshimee miles (A^amoyaAl haA$imiy~ap [see miylN]): or twelve thousand cubits: or ten thousand cubits: (K:) three miles of the Háshimee measure, i. e., accord. to the Bári' and the T [&c.], twenty-five bow-shots; twenty-five times the measure termed galowapN [q. v.]: (Msb:) or three miles, i. e. thirty bow-shots reckoning the bow-shot as four hundred cubits, or sixty bow-shots reckoning the bow-shot as two hundred cubits: (Msb voce maylN:) the ancient Greeks said that it is three miles, reckoning these [together] as about sixty bow-shots [of the shorter measure mentioned above]: (Msb in the present art.:) or, accord. to some, six miles: (L: [but this is app. a mistake occasioned by finding it expl. as consisting of sixty bow-shots and supposing these to be bow-shots of four hundred cubits each:]) it is [said to be] from the same word as signifying “ rest, ” or “ ease; ” (K, TA;) because, when a man walks the distance thus called, he sits down, and rests: or, accord. to the Msb, from farosaxapN signifying “ width; ” the word having this meaning, however, is faro$axapN, with $: (TA:) [the truth is, that] it is a Pers. word [farosanoG], arabicized: (S, A:) the pl. is faraAsixu. (S, A, Msb.) The other meanings of this word, not mentioned by J, may have been regarded by him as not of established authority. (TA.) ― -b2- It signifies also An opening, or intervening space, between two things. (K.) ― -b3- And A thing in which is no opening, or intervening space: as though having two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b4- Also A thing that is lasting and abundant, that does not cease, or come to an end. (ISh, K.) ― -b5- And A long time (K, TA) of the night or of the day: thus in the saying, AinotaZarotuka farosaxFA [I looked, or waited, for thee, or I have looked, &c., a long time &c.]. (TA.) ― -b6- And A saAEap [meaning hour or time] (K, TA) of the day: or a time of the night and of the day: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b7- And The time, (K, TA,) or interval, (TA,) between stillness and motion. (K, TA.) ― -b8- And Stillness, or quiet: (K, TA:) a meaning mentioned by more than one of the authorities respecting strange words. (TA.) ― -b9- And Rest, or ease. (K.)
firosiqN * : see the art. here following.

firosikN * (S, O, K) [and firosiqN (K in art. frsq) The peach: or the sort thereof called the nectarine: from the Greek persikh\ or persiko\n; the malum Persicum, which is generally applied to the former fruit; or amydalus Persica of Linn., (so in Forskål's Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. cxiii.,) which is applied to both of the fruits above mentioned: i. e.] the [fruit called] xawox; (K, TA;) of the dial. of El-Yemen: (TA:) or a sort thereof, (K,) i. q. firosiqN, which is like the xawox in size, (Lth, O,) A^ajoradu [which here means without down, and for which Golius and Freytag appear to have read A^ajowadu], smooth, red [accord. to the CK “ or red ”], (Lth, O, K, TA,) and yellow, the flavour of which is like that of the xawox: (Lth, O, TA:) or [a cling-stone peach or nectarine; i. e.] a sort of xawox that does not cleave asunder from its stone: (S, O:) or [a free-stone peach or nectarine; i. e.] such as cleaves asunder from its stone. (K.)

Alfirosinu * , of the camel, is What corresponds to the HaAfir [or hoof] of the horse or a similar beast: (S, K:) or the part which is below the rusog [or pastern] and in which are the bones called sulaAmaY [q. v.]: and sometimes it is (tropical:) of the sheep or goat: it is of the fem. gender: and the pl. is faraAsinu: (TA:) accord. to Ibn-Es-Sarráj, the n is augmentative, because it is from farasotu, (S, TA,) and [therefore] it has been mentioned before [in art. frs, in which see more]. (S.)
AlfirosaAnu * : see what next follows.

AlfuraAsinu *
The lion; (K, TA;) as also ↓ AlfirosaAnu: and so [AlfuraAnisu and] AlfironaAsu. (TA.) See also the last paragraph below.

AlfuraAsiyuwnu * , (K, TA,) with damm, (TA,) The kur~aAv jabaliY~ [lit. mountain-leek]: (K, TA:) so it is said to be: it is a four-sided A^aSol [app. meaning stem], from which rise many white, foursided, branches, whereon sometimes grow rough leaves like the thumb; and it has a blossom inclining to blueness and yellowness: (TA:) it has the property of clearing the complexion, dissolves thick humours, is diuretic, opens obstructions, and is beneficial as a remedy for the bite of the dog, (K, TA,) i. e. of the mad dog: (TA:) [it is now applied in Cairo to euphrasia: (Forskål, Descr. Anim. &c., p. 145:) and marrubium plicatum. (Idem, Flora Aegypt. Arab., pp. lxviii. and 213.)]
mufarosanu Alwajohi * , with fet-h to the s, Having much flesh in the face. (K.) Perhaps the lion is hence called ↓ furaAsinu. (TA.)

1 fara$ahu * , (S, A, O, K,) aor.
faru$a , (S, O,) inf. n. faro$N (O, K) and firaA$N, (S, O, K,) He spread it; expanded it. (S, A, O, K.) You say, fara$tu lahu firaA$FA and fara$otuhu firaA$FA (A, TA) and ↓ A^afora$otuhu (TA) ↓ and Aifotara$otuhu (A) [I spread for him a bed: or the last signifies I spread it (namely a bed) for myself]. And fara$otu fulaAnFA I spread for such a one. (Lth.) And fara$a fulaAnFA bisaATFA, inf. n. faro$N; and bsATA ↓ A^afora$ahu; and bsATA ↓ far~a$ahu, inf. n. taforiy$N; He spread for such a one a carpet (IAar, K) in his entertainment. (IAar.) And ↓ far~a$a Alv~awoba, inf. n. taforiy$N; and ↓ Aftr$hu; [He spread the garment, or piece of cloth: or the latter signifies he spread it for himself.] (TA.) And taHotahu turaAbFA ↓ Aftr$ or vawobFA [He spread, or spread for himself, beneath him, dust, or a garment, or piece of cloth]. (A.) And Alr~amola ↓ kunotu A^afotari$u waA^atawas~adu AlHajara [I used to spread the sand for my bed, and make the stone my pillow]. (A, TA.) And *iraAEayohi ↓ Aftr$, (A, TA,) and yadayohi, (TA,) He (a lion, and a wolf, and a dog, TA, or a beast of prey, A, TA) spread his fore legs upon the ground: (TA:) and the former phrase, he (a man, Msb, TA) spread his fore arms upon the ground, (S, K, TA,) in the same manner, not raising them from the ground; the doing of which in prostrating oneself in prayer, is forbidden: (TA:) or laid his fore arms upon the ground (Mgh, Msb) like a bed for himself. (Msb.) faro$N [as an inf. n. of which the verb is furi$at, as is shown by an explanation of A_aqoEaAdN in the S and L, and by the phrase maforuw$apu Alr~ijoli mentioned in the S and O and TA,] in the hind leg of a camel [and of a horse as is shown by the explanation above mentioned of AqEAd] signifies The being a little expanded; which is approved: (S, O, K:) when the width [between the shanks] is immoderate, so that the hock-joints knock together, which state is termed EaqalN [inf. n. of Eaqila], it is disapproved: or, as some say, it signifies its not being erect nor much expanded. (S, O.) And fara$a A@ll~`hu Alfaro$a, (Fr, S,) inf. n. faro$N, (Fr, S, K,) means God spread abroad the young camels; syn. bav~a. (Fr, S, K. *) ― -b2- [Hence,] fara$ahu A^amorahu, (S,) or A^amorFA, (K,) (tropical:) He made, or rendered, his states, or case, or affair, (S,) or a state, &c., (K,) ample, or free from straitness, to him; and laid it open to him, altogether; [as though he expanded it to him;] syn. A^awosaEahu A_iy~aAhu, (S, K,) and basaTahu lahu kul~ahu. (TA.) And in like manner the saying of 'Alee,
fara$otukumu AlmaEoruwfa, is expl. by Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed as signifying A^awosaEotukumo A_iy~aAhu [meaning (tropical:) I largely conferred upon you favour, or kindness]: but MF deems this strange. (TA.) You say also, fara$otuhu A^amoriY (tropical:) I displayed, or laid open, to him my state, or case, or affair; [and so A^amoriY ↓ A^afora$otuhu; (see an ex. voce baATinN;)] syn. basaTotuhu lahu. (A.) [And agreeably with this explanation, probably, the saying of 'Alee mentioned above should be rendered in the opinion of MF.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] fulaAnN yaforu$u nafosahu liln~aAsi (tropical:) [Such a one lays himself out for the service of men]; (A;) and nafosahu ↓ yafotari$u lahumo: (TA:) [or perhaps, makes himself like a victim for them: (see mutafar~i$N, below:) for you say, fara$ahu lil*~aboHi, or ↓ A^afora$ahu, (which latter form is mentioned by Freytag in his Lexicon, but without any indication of the authority,) meaning, (assumed tropical:) he threw him down (namely a beast) for slaughter: (see faro$N, below:)] and ↓ Aftr$hu (tropical:) he prostrated him, and got upon him: (A:) or (tropical:) he overcame him, (meaning another man,) and prostrated him, (O, K, TA,) and got upon him. (TA.) ― -b4- fara$a AlmakaAna, aor.
faru$a and
fari$a , inf. n. faro$N, means He spread the place [with carpets or the like]; as also ↓ Afr$hu, and ↓ fr~$hu. (Msb.) And Ald~aAra ↓ fr~$, inf. n. taforiy$N, He paved the house; (Lth, S, K;) he spread in the house baked bricks, or broad and thin stones. (Az, TA.) ― -b5- h`*aA firaA$N yaforu$uka [This is a bed sufficiently large for thee] is like the saying h`*ihi $amolapN ta$omaluka i. e. tasaEuka. (TA in art. $ml.) -A2- fr$ Eanohu [app. fara$a] He desired, and prepared himself for, it, or him. (TA.) -A3- And fara$a, aor.
faru$a , (O, TA,) inf. n. faro$N, (O, K, TA,) He lied: (O, K, * TA:) one says, kamo taforu$u i. e. [How long] wilt thou lie? (O, TA.)

2 far~a$a see 1, in four places; two near the beginning and two near the end. -A2- fr~$ Alz~aroEu, inf. n. taforiy$N, (tropical:) The seed-produce spread itself (S, A, TA) upon the surface of the earth. (TA.) You say, far~axa Alz~aroEu wafar~a$a (tropical:) [The seed-produce put forth its shoots, and spread itself upon the surface of the earth]. (A.) And the latter of these two verbs is also like the former [in signification]. (TA.) ― -b2- fr~$ AlT~aAy^iru, (A, K,) inf. n. as above; (K;) and ↓ tfr~$; (S, A, K;) (tropical:) The bird expanded and flapped its wings, (S, A, K, * TA,) EalaY $aYo'K over a thing, (A, K, TA,) without alighting: (A, TA:) and ↓ the latter verb, it (a young locust) spread its wings. (Mgh.)

4 A^afora$a see 1, in five places. -A2- Afr$hu also signifies (tropical:) He spoke evil of him; or did so in his absence: (IAar, A, * O, K, TA:) and they say, A^afora$ota fiY EiroDiY (tropical:) [Thou spakest evil of me; &c.]. (TA.) [See Aftr$ EiroDahu.] -A3- And (assumed tropical:) He made it thin; or thin, and fine in the edge; namely, a sword. (O, K.) -A4- Afr$ Al$~ajaru (tropical:) The trees put forth branches; syn. A^agoSana. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Afr$ Eanohu (tropical:) He, or it, left him, or quitted him. (S, A, K.) You say, Darabahu famaA A^afora$a Eanohu Hat~aY qatalahu (tropical:) He beat him, or smote him, and left him not until he slew him. (A, * TA.) And Afr$ Eanohumu Almawotu (tropical:) Death quitted them; became withdrawn from them. (IAar, O.) -A5- Afr$t said of a mare, (assumed tropical:) She desired to be covered. (O.) -A6- Afr$hu [from faro$N signifying “ young camels ”] He gave him young camels, (O, K,) small or large. (O.) ― -b2- And Afr$ [app. A^afora$a, or perhaps A^u$orifa,] He (a man) became a possessor of fr$ [app. faro$, and meaning young camels]. (IKtt, TA.) -A7- And Afr$ said of a place, It abounded with faraA$, (O, K, TA,) i. e., [app., moths, or butterflies, and, as being the cause thereof,] seed-produce. (TA.) -A8- A^aqofala faA^afora$a [He locked, and made fast by means of the catch, or catches, (faraA$ap, or faraA$, which see below,) of the lock]. (S, TA.)
5 tafar~a$a see 2, last sentence, in two places.
7 A_inofara$a see 8, last signification.

8 A_ifotara$a see 1, first quarter, in five places; and latter half, in two places. ― -b2- Aftr$ lisaAnahu [lit.] He expanded his tongue: (S:) i. e. (tropical:) he spoke in whatsoever manner he desired. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- Aftr$hu (tropical:) He trod upon him or it: (S, K, TA:) [as though he made him or it a carpet or a bed:] from Alfaro$u and AlfiraA$u. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] Aftr$ AlT~ariyqa (tropical:) He went, or travelled, along the road. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] Aftr$ A@moraA^apF (assumed tropical:) He compressed a woman. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) He took to wife a woman. (O.) One says, Aftr$ kariymapF (assumed tropical:) He took to wife a female of high birth. (TA.) ― -b7- [Hence also,] Aftr$ EiroDahu lit. He made his honour as a bed for himself to tread upon; (O, TA;) i. e., (tropical:) he treated his honour as a thing which it was allowable to attack, by speaking evil of him. (O, K, TA.) [See also 4, second sentence.] ― -b8- And Aifotara$atonaA Als~amA='N biAlmaTari (tropical:) The sky assailed us with rain. (A, * O.) ― -b9- And Aftr$ AlmaAla (tropical:) He took the mAl [i. e. property, or cattle, &c.,] wrongfully, or by force. (K, TA.) ― -b10- And Aftr$ A^avarahu (tropical:) He followed his footsteps; he tracked him. (A, O, K.) -A2- Aifotara$a [in one of my copies of the S, Aufoturi$a, which is also allowable, as the verb in the act. form is trans. as well as intrans.,] It became spread, or expanded; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓ Anfr$; said of a garment or the like. (TA.)

faro$N * [an inf. n. of 1, q. v. passim. ― -b2- Also, used in the sense of a pass. part. n. in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] What is spread, of household furniture, (S, K,) [such as carpets and mattresses and the like. See also firaA$N.] ― -b3- (tropical:) Seed-produce when it spreads itself (S, K, TA) upon the ground: (TA:) in [some of] the copies of the K, instead of A_i*aA far~a$a, which is the right reading, we find A*A furi$a: accord. to some, the word signifies seed-produce when it has become three-leaved, or four-leaved. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A place abounding with plants or herbage. (O, K.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A wide, or spacious, plain, or tract of land, or place: (S, K, TA:) or land that is plain, or even, and soft, and unobstructed by mountains: (TA:) or a depressed tract of land in which are trees of the kinds called EurofuT and salam, (IAar, O,) which cause the mouths of the camels that eat them to become relaxed. (O.) [Hence, app., the saying,] mina AlEaro$i A_ilaY Alfaro$i, meaning, [From the highest sphere, or the empyrean, to] the earth. (A in art. Er$.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A collection of trees of the kind called EiDaAh: and a round plot of trees of the kind called TaloH. (TA.) ― -b7- (tropical:) Shrubs, or small trees: (Lth, A, K:) and small fire-wood. (Lth, K.) ― -b8- (tropical:) Young camels; or the young of camels; (Fr, S, A, * K;) and ↓ fariy$N is said to have this meaning; but accord. to Aboo-Bekr, erroneously: (TA:) so the former signifies in the Kur vi. 143: (S, K:) Fr says, I have heard no pl. of it: and he adds, that it may here be an inf. n. used as a subst., from the saying, fara$ahaA A@ll~`hu faro$FA, meaning, bav~ahaA bav~FA: [see 1:] (S, TA:) but it is said in the K that in all of the above-mentioned senses that are assigned to it in that work, it has no sing.; meaning that it is used alike as sing. and pl.: (TA:) and bulls or cows: and sheep or goats: (K:) so accord. to some of the expositors of the Kur: (TA:) and such as are fit for nothing but slaughter, (K, TA,) of camels, and of bulls or cows, and of sheep or goats; as some say: (TA:) or such as is thrown down (yufora$u, i. e., yuloqaY,) for slaughter, of the young of camels, and bulls or cows, and sheep or goats; used alike as sing. and pl.: (Mgh:) and faro$u AlA_ibili also signifies old camels. (Th, TA.)

faro$apN *
A track, somewhat depressed, extending to the distance [of the journey] of a day and a night, and the like thereof, and only in land that is wide and level and like the [desert termed] SaHoraA=': pl. furuw$N. (AHn, TA.)

firo$apN *
Form; appearance; garb; or the like; syn. hayoy^apN: so in the saying, huwa Hasanu Alfiro$api [He is goodly in form, &c.]. (O, K.)

faro$iY~N *
A seller of faro$ [meaning household furniture such as carpets and mattresses and the like]. (TA.)

faraA$N * [Moths, and the like, that fly into the flame of a lamp &c.;] the flying things (S, TA) that fall one after another into the lamp, or lighted wick, (S, K, TA,) to burn themselves: (TA:) [and accord. to modern usage, butterflies also:] a pl., [or rather a coll. gen. n.,] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is ↓ with p: (S, K:) the former mentioned in the Kur ci. 3: (TA:) or the former signifies what one sees, resembling small gnats, falling, one after another, into the fire: (Zj:) or young locusts, when their wings grow, (Fr, Mgh, Jel,) and they spread them forth, (Mgh,) and mount, one upon another: (Fr, Mgh:) and silk-worms; app. so called because they become like these when they come forth from the cocoon. (Mgh.) It is said in a prov., ↓ A^aToya$u mino faraA$apK [More light, or unsteady, or light-witted, than a moth that flies into the flame of the lamp]. (S.) And ↓ faraA$apN is used
to signify (tropical:) A man who is light (A, K) in head; (A, TA;) light-witted, or unsteady; (TA;) such being likened to the frA$p of the lamp, in respect of lightness, or unsteadiness, and contemptibleness. (A, * TA.) -A2- Also Thin pieces of bone, such as fly off from any bone when it is struck: or any crusts, or coverings, that are upon bone, exclusive of the flesh: or the bone of the eyebrow: or what is thin, of the bone of the head: or the bones that come forth from the head of a man when it is broken: (TA:) or faraA$u Alr~aA^osi signifies certain thin bones that are next to the bone that covers the brain: (S, TA:) and ↓ faraA$apN, any thin bone: (S, K:) and Alr~aA^osi ↓ faraA$apu, the thin bones, or pieces of bone, of the head, such as fly off in consequence of a blow. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, faraA$u AlZ~ahori The place where the upper parts of the ribs are infixed in [the spine of] the back. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlfaraA$aAni The two extremities of the haunches, in [or at] the nuqorap, q. v. (TA.) ― -b4- And The parts of the upper portions (furuwE) of the two shoulder-blades that rise towards the base of the neck and the even part of the back. (AO, O.) ― -b5- And Two veins, green, or of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, (A^axoDaraAni,) beneath the tongue. (En-Nadr, O, K. * [In the last of these, this signification and the next are erroneously assigned to the sing. word. See also AlfiraA$u.]) ― -b6- Also, (TA,) or faraA$aA All~ijaAmi (En-Nadr, O,) or ↓ faraA$ataAhu, (IDrd in his Book on the Saddle and Bridle,) The two iron things with which are made fast the check-straps of the headstall. (En-Nadr, O, K.) ― -b7- And faraA$N and ↓ faraA$apN also signify The edge of anything. (Aboo-Sa'eed, in TA, art. nsr.) -A3- And The former, Mud that has dried, after the water, upon the ground. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And it is said to signify A little water in pools left by torrents: n. un. ↓ faraA$apN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And [Little] bubbles (Habab) upon the surface of [the beverage called] nabiy*: (S, O, K:) and likewise of the water of sweat: (S, * L:) or a little sweat: so says IAar. (L.) -A4- faraA$u qufolK signifies The manaA$ib [or catches] of a lock; [app. meaning the little pins which fall into corresponding holes in the bolt of the Arabian wooden lock of a door, (which see figured and described in the Introduction to my work on the Modern Egyptians,) when it is pushed into the hole or staple of the door-post, preventing its being drawn back until they are raised by the key, which has small pins, made to correspond with the holes, so that, being introduced into these, they push up the catching pins:] n. un. ↓ with p: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or qufolK ↓ faraA$apu signifies what catches, or sticks fast, in a lock; (S, K;) [or, as expl. in the Arabic Dictionary of Farhát, what enters into a lock and makes it fast;] meaning its teeth; (TK;) [which are the little pins described above:] the word is thought by IDrd to be not Arabic: or, thus applied, it is from the same word as signifying “ a thin bone, ” because of the thinness of the frA$p of the lock. (TA.)

firaA$N *
A thing that is spread (Mgh, K) upon the ground: (Mgh:) a thing that is spread for one to sit or lie upon; in which sense it is used in the Kur ii. 20: (TA:) and particularly, a bed, upon which one sleeps: (AA, Mgh:) pl. [of pauc.] A^afori$apN (TA) and [of mult.] furu$N, (S, K,) for which one may say, in the dial. of the Benoo-Temeem, furo$N. (Sb.) [See also faro$N: and see what is quoted below from a trad.] ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) (tropical:) A man's wife; (AA, S, O, K;) as also A_izaArN and liHaAfN: (O, TA:) pl. furu$N; so used, accord. to some, in the Kur lvi. 33. (K.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) A woman's husband: (AA, Er-Rághib:) and a female slave's master, or owner. (TA.) So, accord. to some, in the words of a trad., Alwaladu lilofiraA$i walilEaAhiri AlHajaru, meaning The child is for the husband; (Er-Rághib, TA;) or for the master of the bed, who is the husband, or the owner of the woman; (Mgh, TA;) or for the bed, so that there is no ellipsis; (TA;) and for the adulterer, or fornicator, shall be stones, like as you say he shall have dust, meaning, nothing; i. e., he shall have no right of relationship; or, accord. to some, stoning. (Mgh.) [See also EaAhirN.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The nest of a bird. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A house, or tent. (AA.) ― -b6- And AlfiraA$u signifies The place against which the tongue goes in the furthest, or innermost, part of the mouth; (AA, O, K, TA;) or, as some say, in the lower part of the Hanak [which word app. here, as it often does, means the palate]: or firaA$u All~isaAni signifies the portion of skin (Aljilodapu [to which is here added Al$~an~aA=', app. a mistranscription which I am unable to rectify,] that covers the bases of the upper teeth. (TA. [In the TA voce maHaArapu, in art. Hwr, q. v., q. v., it is written AlfiraA$apu.])

fariy$N * A plant, or herbage, that becomes spread upon the ground, not standing up upon a stem. (TA.) [See also mufar~i$N.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A girl, or young woman, compressed by a man; (O, K; *) an instance of faEiylN from AifotaEala; (O;) [being from Aifotara$a;] but not heard by Az on any other authority than that of Lth. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) An Arabian Bull [or perhaps it is properly an epithet applied to that animal as meaning] having no hump: (TA:) [see also mufar~a$N as applied to a camel:] or firaA$N, which is pl. of fariy$N, signifies a sort of oxen, between the diraAb and EiraAb having small humps, and their AEyAb [a mistranscription for A^agobaAb, i. e. dewlaps, pl. of gababN,] are flaccid, or pendulous. (TA voce darabaAniy~apN.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) A mare, (As, O, K,) or any solid-hoofed animal, (S,) seven days, (As, S, K,) or seven nights, (O,) after her having foaled; (As, S, O, K, TA;) which is the best of times for putting a burden upon her: (O, K:) and that has recently brought forth; (O, K, TA;) so says Kt; like the nufasaA= of women; or like the muEowi* of she-camels: (TA:) pl. faraAy^i$u. (S, O, K.) ― -b5- See also faro$N, latter half.

faraA$apN * : see faraA$N, in ten places. -A2- Also (tropical:) A small quantity of water: (A, O, K, TA:) one says, lamo yaboqa fiY AlA_inaA='i A_il~aA faraA$apN [There remained not in the vessel save a small quantity of water]. (O, TA.) And A small quantity of water remaining in pools left by torrents, the ground beneath which is seen, by reason of its clearness: and some say, a place where water collects and remains in a smooth, or hard and smooth, rock. (TA.) -A3- And Great stones, like mill-stones, which are laid first [as a foundation] and upon which is then built a tarokiyb, i. e. an enclosure for palm-trees. (TA.) -A4- And AlfaraA$ataAni signifies Two cartilages near, or by, the lahaAp [which generally means the uvula; but also, the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate; or the furthest part of the mouth]. (TA.)

far~aA$N *
One who spreads the carpets and similar furniture [such as beds, or mattresses, and the like, and keeps them in order: app. a post-classical word: fem. with p]. (KL.)

mifora$N *
A thing resembling the $aA*akuwnap [a kind of thick quilted stuff made in El-Yemen]; (O, K;) i. e. a thing that is put upon the Suf~ap [or covering next the saddle] to sit upon; (TA;) as also ↓ mifora$apN: (A, TA:) or the latter is smaller than the former, (O, K,) and is put upon the Suf~ap of the camel's saddle, (A,) or upon the camel's saddle [itself], to sit upon: (O, K:) [pl. mafaAri$u.] ― -b2- [Hence,] mafaAri$u is applied to signify (tropical:) Women, or wives. (A, TA.) One says, fulaAnN kariymu AlmafaAri$i (tropical:) Such a one is a person who has highborn wives or women; (A;) or who takes as his wives high-born women. (S, O, K.) One says also of a man who has never married, A_in~ahu lahaAliku Almifora$i, meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily his life has passed away lost. (TA.) And huloku AlmafaAri$i is said to mean (assumed tropical:) Persons who will not die upon their beds, and will not die otherwise than by slaughter. (TA.)
mifora$apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

jamalN mufar~a$N * , (O, K,) [and] ↓ jamalN mufotari$u AlA^aroDi, (T, TA,) or AlZ~ahori ↓ mufotara$u, (A, TA,) (tropical:) A camel having no hump. (T, A, O, K, TA.) [See also fariy$N.] And AlZ~ahori ↓ A^akamapN mufotari$apu, (S, TA,) or AlZhr ↓ mufotara$apu, (as in one of my copies of the S and in a copy of the A,) (tropical:) A flat-topped [hill, or eminence, of the kind termed] Akmp. (S, A, TA.)

mufar~i$N * Seed-produce spreading itself (S, K, TA) upon the ground. (TA.) [See also fariy$N.] ― -b2- $aj~apN mufar~i$apN A wound of the head that reaches to the faraA$ [q. v.]; as also ↓ mufotari$apN: (L:) or that cracks the bone but does not crush. (S, O, K.)

maforuw$apu Alr~ijoli * (S, O, TA) applied to a she-camel, (TA,) Having what is termed faro$N in the kind leg; (thus, by implication, in the S and O; [see 1;]) or having a [certain] bending in the kind leg. (TA.)
mufotara$N * ; and its fem., with p: see mufar~a$N.
mufotari$N * ; and its fem., with p: see mufar~a$N: ― -b2- and for the latter, see also mufar~i$N.

fulaAnN mutafar~i$N liln~aAsi * (tropical:) Such a one is a person who lays himself out for the service of men, or makes himself like a victim for them, (yaforu$u lahumo nafosahu,) in kindness for them. (A.) And fulaAnN kariymN mutafar~i$N liA^aSoHaAbihi (tropical:) Such a one is a generous person, who lays himself out for the service of his companions, &c.; expl. by the words yafotari$u nafosahu lahumo. (TA.)

Q. 1 faro$aHa * , inf. n. faro$aHapN (S, K) and faro$aHaY, (K,) He (a man, S) parted his legs; (K:) or he parted his legs in sitting; and so faro$aTa: (Lh, S:) or he spread his legs wide apart: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) and he stood with his legs wide apart in prayer; (Ks, S;) and so fr$H rijolayohi: (S:) or he sat in a relaxed state, with his thighs cleaving to the ground; (K;) and so faro$aTa: (TA:) or he leaped, or jumped; (K;) or made short leaps or jumps. (TA.) And faro$aHato, (S, L, and so in some copies of the K,) or ↓ tafaro$aHato, (thus in other copies of the K, and thus in the CK,) She (a camel) parted her kind legs to be milked (S, L, K) and to stale. (L.)
Q. 2 tafaro$aHato * : see what immediately precedes.

firo$aAHN * A broad, or wide, land: (K, TA:) accord. to the K, syn. with firosaAHN; but Sh says that the latter is a mistranscription; the former being the correct word, from faro$aHa fiY jilosatihi: and Az mentions the latter as from the Jm, but not found by him as on trustworthy authority. (TA in art. frsH.) ― -b2- And A spreading, or wide, solid hoof. (S, K.) ― -b3- And Clouds (saHaAb) in which is no rain. (K.) ― -b4- And An unseemly, or ugly, and old, woman, and she-camel. (K.)
Alfiro$iyHu * (tropical:) The penis: (K, TA:) a tropical term. (TA.)

1 faraSahu * , (M, K,) aor.
faruSa , (TA,) or
fariSa , (O in art. frs,) inf. n. faroSN, (S, M,) He cut it; (S, M, K;) namely, skin, or a skin, (M,) [and metal; (see miforaSN;)] or it signifies, (TA,) or signifies also, (S, K,) sometimes, (S,) he slit it, or cut or divided it lengthwise: and he made a hole in it: (S, K, TA:) namely, skin, or a skin: (TA:) or he slit it, namely, a skin, with an iron instrument having a wide end, like as the maker of sandals slits the two ears of the sandal at the heel, to put into them the $iraAk [or the two arms of the $rAk]: (Lth, TA:) or faraSotu Aln~aEola signifies I made a hole in each of the two ears of the sandal, for the $rAk [or for the two arms of the $rAk]. (S.) -A2- Also, (S, M, K,) aor.
fariSa , [so in a copy of the M, but accord. to a rule of the K it should rather be
faruSa ,] inf. n. as above, (M,) He hit, or hurt, his fariySap [q. v.]; (M, K; and so in a copy of the S;) or, accord. to [other copies of] the S, his fariyS [q. v.]; (TA;) which is a place where a wound causes death. (S.) ― -b2- And fariSa, [aor.
faraSa ,] inf. n. faraSN; and furiSa, inf. n. faroSN; He had a complaint of his fariySap. (M.) -A3- faraSa AlfuroSapa: see 8.

2 taforiySu naEoli AlqiraAbi * , (L,) or tforiySu A^asofali Aln~aEoli (O, K, TA) [i. e.] naEoli AlqiraAbi, (TA, [in the O baEoda AlqiraAbi, which is an evident mistranscription,]) signifies The ornamenting, or engraving, (tanoqiy$, O, L, K, TA,) of the nEl [i. e. shoe of iron or silver, at the bottom of the scabbard of a sword] (L,) or of the lower part of the nEl (O, K, TA) of the scabbard, (O, * TA,) with the extremity of the [instrument of] iron. (O, L, K, TA.)

3 faAraSaniY fiY AlmaA='i * , (A,) inf. n. mafaAraSapN, (K,) He took of the water with me, each of us taking his turn. (A.) The inf. n. signifies The doing, or taking, with another, each in his turn. (K.)

4 A^aforaSatohu AlfuroSapu *
The opportunity gave him power or ability [to do a thing]. (M, A, K.)
5 tfr~S AlfuroSapa * : see 8.

6 tfArSwA AlmaA='a *
They shared the water among themselves by turns. (M, A, * Msb.) And tfArSwA biy^orahumo They took, or drew, of the water of their well by turns. (S, K.)

8 AftrS AlfuroSapa *
He took, or seized, the opportunity; or he arose and hastened to be before another, or others, in taking, or seizing, the opportunity; syn. AinotahazahaA; (O, K;) or AigotanamahaA: (TA:) or he got, or took, the opportunity; as also ↓ tfr~ShA; and ↓ faraSahaA, (M, TA,) aor.
fariSa , (so in a copy of the M,) inf. n. faroSN. (TA.) You say also, AftrS AlA^umuwra [He took, or seized, opportunities to do things]. (A.) And fulaAnN laA yufotaraSu A_aHosaAnuhu wabir~uhu [Such a one's beneficence and kindness are not caught at]; because there is no fear that his beneficence and kindness will become beyond one's reach. (A, TA. [See also 8 in art. frT.]) ― -b2- mani A@fotaraSa musolimFA, occurring in a trad., is an instance of the verb derived from faroSN signifying the “ act of cutting, ” or from furoSapN signifying “ an opportunity; ” and the meaning is [Such as] detracts, or, literally, cuts off, somewhat [from the honour of a Muslim wrongfully]: or assumes authority over the honour of a Muslim wrongfully, by speaking evil of him behind his back, or otherwise, or defaming him. (IAth, L, TA. *) -A2- AftrSt Alwaraqapu [from AlfariySapu, “ the quivering muscle ” so called,] The leaf was caused to quiver. (M, TA.)
faroSN * The stones of the muqol [or fruit of the Theban palm]: n. un. with p. (AA, O, K.)

faroSapN * : see firoSapN. -A2- Also, AlfaroSapu, The riyH [or flatus] from which results gibbosity [of the back] (AlHadabu): (S, M, O, K:) and Alfarosapu is a dial. var. thereof: (M, TA:) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, the latter [q. v.] is vulgar. (TA.)

furoSapN *
A turn; a time at which, or during which, a thing is, or is to be, done, or had, in succession: (S, A, K:) or a turn, or time, for persons' coming to water in succession, (Yaakoob, S, * M, A, * Msb, K, *) in the cases of the periodical drinkings of their camels, such as the ximos and the riboE and the sidos &c., (Yaakoob, M,) when the water is little; (Msb;) as also ↓ firoSapN (M) and ↓ fariySapN: (Yaakoob, M:) a dial. var. of the same is with s; (IAar, M;) and rufoSapN is another: (TA:) pl. furaSN. (M, Msb.) You say, jaA='ato furoSatuka mina Albiy^ori Thy turn, or time, for watering from the well has come. (As, S, * Msb. *) ― -b2- A portion, or share, of what falls to one's lot, of water; syn. $irobN. (S, K.) ― -b3- An opportunity; a time at which, or during which, a thing may be done, or had; syn. nuhozapN; (S, M, TA;) and furosapN is a dial. var. of the same. (M.) You say, Ainotahaza AlfuroSapa, i. e. AigotanamahaA [expl. above: see 8]. (S.) And A^ay~aAmuka furaSN [Thy days are opportunities]. (A, TA.) -A2- See also firoSapN. -A3- Also The temper (sajiy~ap), and outstripping, and strength, of a horse. (M.)

firoSapN *
A piece of wool, (As, M,) or of cotton, (As, S, M, O, Msb, K,) or of rag, (S, O, Msb, K,) with which a woman wipes herself, to purify herself from the catamenia; (S, M, * O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ faroSapN and ↓ furoSapN: (Kr, M:) from faraSa meaning “ he cut ” a thing: (As, TA:) pl. firaASN: (K:) or they say firaASN, as though pl. of firoSapN. (IDrd, O.) ― -b2- And, accord. to AAF, A piece, or bit, of mush. (M.) -A2- See also furoSapN.
faroSaA='u * A she-camel that remains aside, and when the trough for watering is vacant, comes and drinks: (O, K, * TA:) from furoSapN signifying nuhozapN. (Az, TA.)

firaASN *
Strong; (O, K;) as expl. by El-Umawee: (O:) and thick and red; (O, K;) as expl. by Ez-Ziyádee. (O.) -A2- maA Ealayohi firaASN, (O,) or mino firaASK, (K,) means There is not upon him a garment: (O, K:) so says El-Umawee. (O.)

fariySN *
One who shares in water with another, each taking of it in turn. (S, K.) You say, huwa fariySiY [He is my sharer in water, each of us taking thereof in turn]; and in like manner, ↓ mufaAriSiY. (TA.) -A2- fariySN is also, like faraAy^iSu, pl. of fariySapN; (S;) [or, rather, fariySN is a coll. gen. n., whereof the n. un. is ↓ fariySapN;] which signifies The portion of flesh [or muscle] between the side and the shoulder-blade which incessantly trembles, or quakes, (As, S, K,) in a beast: (As, S:) or the portion of flesh which is in the part extending from the marojiE [or lower part, next the armpit,] of the shoulder-blade to the arm, on either side, and which trembles, or quakes, when the man, or beast, is frightened: (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) or the portion of flesh which is by the nagoD of the katif, [which may app. be here rendered with sufficient exactness the cartilage of
the shoulder-blade; or the part of it where it moves to and fro;] in the middle of the side, by the place where the heart beats: there are two such portions, each of them thus called, which tremble, or quake, on an occasion of fright: and the piece of flesh that is between the breast (vadoY) and the marojiE [expl. above] of the shoulder-blade, of a man and of a beast: or, as some say, the lower part (A^aSol) of the marojiEu Almirofaqayoni [or place to which either elbow returns, in a beast, when, having been removed from the usual place, it is brought back thereto]: (M:) or a small piece of flesh which is in the heart, and which trembles, or quakes, by reason of a calamity, when one is frightened: (A 'Obeyd:) or a piece of flesh [or muscle] in the side, which trembles, or quakes, when one is frightened. (A.) [Hence the saying,] ↓ huwa Daxomu AlfariySapi (tropical:) He is bold and strong. (A, TA.) ― -b2- fariySu AlEunuqi The external jugular veins (A^awodaAj) of the neck: n. un. with p: (A 'Obeyd, S, K:) or the tendons, or sinews, (EaSab,) and veins, of the neck: so, app., says A 'Obeyd, in the following words of a trad.: A_in~iY laA^akorahu A^ano A^araY Alr~ajulu vaAy^irFA fariySu raqabatihi qaAy^imFA EalaY murayoy^atihi yaDoribuhaA [Verily I hate to see the man having the tendons, or sinews, and veins, of his neck swelling with anger, rising against his little wife, beating her]: for these are what swell out in anger: (S:) or, accord. to IAar, the meaning is, the hair of the fryS, which term is metaphorically used in relation to the neck, though it [really] has no faraAy^iS, because anger causes its veins to swell out [like as fright causes the fariyS properly so called to tremble or quake]: (Az, TA:) fariysN is a dial. var. of the same. (TA.) [See faraSahu, last signification.]
fariySapN * : see fariySN, in two places. ― -b2- AlfariySapu i. q. A^um~u suwayodi, (IDrd, O, K,) i. e., AlAisotu. (TA.) -A2- See also furoSapN.

A^aforaSu *
Humpbacked; as also A^aforazu and A^aforasu. (Fr in TA voce A^aEojaru.)
miforaSN * : see what next follows.

miforaASN * (IDrd, S, M, A, O, K) and ↓ maforaSN (IDrd, S, O, K) A thing with which silver is cut, (S, A,) and gold: (A:) or a broad iron instrument with which one cuts: (M:) or the iron with which iron is cut, or silver: (K:) or a broad iron instrument with which iron is cut: (IDrd, O:) or the iron with which silver is cut: (O:) [see also miqoraADN:] or, as some say, i. q. A_i$ofFY [q. v.] with a broad head, with which sandals are sewed. (IDrd, O.) El-Aashà says,
waA^adofaEu Eano A^aEoraADikumo waA^uEiyrukumo
lisaAnFA kamiforaASi AlxafaAjiY~i miloHabaA
[And I defend your honours, and lend to you a tongue like the mfrAS of the Khafájee, sharp]. (S.) And you say, bayona janobayohi miforaASu AlxafaAjiY~i (tropical:) [Between his two sides is an intellect sharp as the mfrAS of the Khafájee]. (A.) [Hence it seems that among the tribe of Khafájeh were expert workers with the instrument thus called.]
huwa mufaAriSiY * : see fariySN, second sentence.
firoSidN * and ↓ firoSiyodN The stones of raisins and of grapes; (M, O, L, K;) as also ↓ firoSaAdN. (M, L, K.)

firoSaAdN * The [mulberry called] tuwt [q. v.]: (AO, AHn, O, Msb:) or the [tree called] tuwt: or its fruit: (M, K:) or the red twt: (S, Msb:) [or, accord. to Zeyn el-'Attár, the sweet and white mulberry: so says Golius: see tuwtN:] Lth says that it is a well-known tree; that the people of ElBasrah call the tree thus, and call its fruit tuwtN: (T, O, * Msb:) and by firoSaAdN the lawyers mean the tree that bears the [fruit called] tuwt. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A red dye; (K:) or redness. (M, L.) ― -b3- See also firoSidN.
firoSiydN * : see firoSidN.

1 faraDahu * , (S, A, O, Msb, &c.,) aor.
fariDa , (Msb, TA, &c.,) inf. n. faroDN, (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) He made a mark in it, or upon it, by notching, or otherwise: (O:) he notched it: made a notch, or an incision, in it; (S, O, Msb, K;) namely, a piece of wood, (Msb,) a zanod, [or rather faraDahaA said of a zanodap, from which fire is produced,] and a siwaAk [or toothstick], (S, O,) and in like manner a bow; (A;) as also [↓ AftrDhu; (see this verb below;) and] ↓ fr~Dhu, inf. n. taforiyDN: (K:) or this last signifies he notched it much; or made notches in it; (S, O, TA;) or you say, faraDa qawosahu and far~aDa qisiy~ahu: (A:) and faraDahu signifies he notched it with his teeth; namely, a tooth-stick: (As:) and he cut it; namely, a thing; or a hard thing; which is said by some to be the primary signification: (TA:) and he (a tailor) cut it out; namely a garment: (Kull p. 275:) and he cut it out and made it round; namely a shield: (TA:) and faroDN also signifies the cutting, or dividing, lengthwise; cleaving; or the like; applied in a general manner; or the making a trench, or an oblong excavation, in the middle of a grave; faraDotu lilomay~iti signifying I made a trench, or an oblong excavation, in the middle of a grave, for the corpse. (TA.) -A2- faraDa lahu, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (K, &c.,) He apportioned to him [a thing]: he appointed to him [a thing]: (Bd in xxxiii. 38, and TA: *) because that which is apportioned, or appointed, [to a person] is cut off from the thing from which it is apportioned, or appointed: (TA:) he made [a thing] lawful, or allowable, to him; (Jel in xxxiii. 38, and Kull in p. 275, and TA; *) relating to a case into which a man has brought himself: (Kull:) this is said to be the meaning when the phrase faraDa A@ll~`hu lahu occurs in the Kur: (TA:) he appointed, or assigned, to him a definite portion; (K;) as also lh ↓ AfrD. (O, L, K.) You say faraDa lahu fiY AlEaTaA='i [He appointed, or assigned, to him a definite portion in the gift]. (As, S.) And faraDa lahu fiY Ald~iywaAni (As, S, A) [He appointed, or assigned, to him a definite portion in the register of soldiers or pensioners; or] he registered his stipend therein. (As, A, TA.) And faraDahu, (S,) and ↓ AfrDhu, (S, K,) He gave to him. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- faraDa, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Msb, TA,) also signifies He (God, S, A, Mgh, Msb) made a thing, (S, TA,) or prayer, (A, Mgh,) or statutes or ordinances, (Msb,) obligatory, or binding, syn. A^awojaba, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) by a known decree, (TA,) [or He imposed a thing &c.,] EalaY A_inosaAnK on a man, (TA,) or EalayonaA on us; (S;) and so ↓ AifotaraDa: (S, A, Mgh, O, K:) or faroDN is like A_iyjaAbN; but the latter is so termed in consideration of its befalling; and the former is so called in consideration of the sentence, or decree, respecting it: (B:) [this is said in books on the law, in explanation of the opinion of Aboo-Haneefeh, as opposed to that of Esh-Sháfi'ee: for] accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee, these two terms are alike; (L, TA;) but accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh, the difference between AlwaAjibu and AlfaroDu is like the difference between heaven and earth: (TA:) this distinction, however, is founded upon contested derivations of the two terms: (Kull p. 276:) and it is said that wherever the phrase faraDa A@ll~`hu Ealayohi occurs, it means A_iyjaAbN. (TA.) Also He (the apostle of God) instituted, or prescribed, [a thing as a statute, or an ordinance, or a command or prohibition;] syn. san~a; (O, K;) on the authority of IAar alone: (O, TA:) but accord. to others, he made necessarily obligatory or binding; and this, says Az, is the obvious meaning. (TA.) Also He (a judge) decreed, or adjudged, [TA.) Also He (a judge) decreed, or adjudged, [a thing, as, for instance,] expenses [&c.]. (Msb.) Also He assigned, or appointed, a particular time for doing a thing; or he determined, defined, or limited, a thing as to time, or otherwise; the inf. n., faroDN, being syn. with tawoqiytN: (Ibn-'Arafeh, A, O, K:) as in the phrase famano faraDa fiyhin~a AlHaj~a [And whoso determineth the performance of the pilgrimage therein]; (Ibn-'Arafeh, O, K;) occurring in the Kur [ii. 193]; and in like manner it is expl. by Ibn- 'Arafeh as occurring in xxxiii. 38 of the Kur (O, TA:) but the phrase quoted above is also expl. as meaning and whoso maketh it obligatory, or binding, on himself to perform the pilgrimage therein, by his entering upon the state of A_iHoraAm. (TA.) ― -b3- suwrapN A^anozalonaAhaA wafaraDonaAhaA, (K,) in the Kur, [commencing chap. xxiv.,] (TA,) means [This is a chapter which we have revealed and] in which we have set down the obligatory statutes: (O, K:) or in which we have bound you to do according to what is made obligatory therein: (Az, O:) or, as some read, ↓ wafar~aDonaAhaA, (S, O, K, *) meaning and in which we have set down obligatory statutes, (O, L, K,) one after another: (O, K:) or which we have distinctly explained: (Az, S, O, K:) or we
have distinctly explained what is in it, of lawful and unlawful [things]. (T, TA.) ― -b4- faroDN also signifies The act of reading, or reciting. (IAar, O, K.) You say, faraDotu juzoy^iY I read, or recited, my portion. (O, TA.) -A3- faruDa, inf. n. faraADapN, He was, or became, skilled in the faraAy^iD; (A, O, K, TA;) i. e. in the science of the division of inheritances. (TA.) MF says that, accord. to IKtt, the verb is also written faraDa, like kataba: but [says SM] what I find in his “ Kitáb el-Abniyeh ” is the mention of the two modes of writing in the instance of frDt said of a cow; and the verb applied to a man he has not mentioned. (TA.) -A4- faraDato, aor.
fariDa , inf. n. furuwDN; and faruDato, inf. n. faraADapN; She (a cow) became old, aged, far advanced in age, (S, O, K,) or extremely old. (TA.) ― -b2- And faraDa, inf. n. furuwDN, signifies It (a thing) became wide; it widened, or dilated. (TA.)
2 far~aDa see 1, first sentence: and again, in the last quarter of the paragraph. -A2- fr~D, inf. n. taforiyDN, said of a man, He had a fariyDap [to give from] among his camels. (O, K.)

4 AfrD lahu * : and AfrDhu: see 1, latter part of the first half of the paragraph. -A2- A^aforaDati AlmaA$iyapu The beasts amounted to the number which rendered it obligatory on the owner to give from among them a fariyDap. (S, O, K. *)

8 AftrDhu * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- lamo yafotariDohaA waladN, occurring in a trad., means [A child had not been brought forth by her; lit.] lamo yaHuz~ahaA, and lamo yuw'at~irohaA [a mistake for lm yuw'a$~irohaA]. (TA.) -A2- See also 1, latter part of the first half of the paragraph. -A3- AftrD AljunodN The soldiers received their stipends. (A, K.) -A4- AftrD Alqawomu The people, or company of men, perished, none of them remaining; syn. AnqrD. (K.)

faroDN *
A mark [made by notching, or otherwise; as is shown by the first explanation of 1]: (TA:) a notch, or an incision, in a thing: (O, TA:) of a bow, (S, A, K,) the place of the string; (K;) the notch (S, A, O) in the curved extremity thereof, (A,) into which the string falls; (S, O;) as also ↓ furoDapN; (A, TA;) or this is the place of the notch for the string thereof: (Msb:) pl. of the former firaADN (S, O, K) and furuwDN; (TA;) and of the latter furaDN (Msb, TA) and firaADN: (Msb:) also, of a zanod, (S, K,) or [rather] of a zanodap, (A,) the notch; (K;) or the place, or part, whence the fire is produced; (S, K;) the hole, or perforation, that is made in the head thereof, into which the zanod is put, and then twisted round, in producing fire; also called wakorN; (A;) and ↓ furoDapN signifies the same: (TA:) and furaDN also signifies notches in an unfeathered and headless arrow [such as is used in the game called Almayosir]. (TA.) -A2- I. q. ↓ maforuwDN (A, Msb, K) [Apportioned: appointed; made lawful, or allowable: and] a thing made obligatory, or binding, by God; (S, A, O, K;) for neglecting which one will be punished; like waAjibN; accord. to EshSháfi'ee; (TA in art. wjb;) because it has marks and limits; (S, O, TA;) said to be from the same word signifying “ a mark, ” because it inseparably pertains to a man, like a mark; (TA;) or, as some say, because it necessarily pertains to a man like as does the faroD, i. e. notch, to the arrow; (O, TA;) as also ↓ mufotaraDN: (TA:) pl. furuwDN. (Msb.) As a law-term, it is of two sorts, faroDu EayonK and faroDu kifaAyapK: the former is That whereof the observance is obligatory on every one, and does not become of no force in respect of some in consequence of the observance [thereof] by some [others]; as religious belief, and the like: the latter is That whereof the observance is obligatory on the collective body of the Muslims, and, in consequence of the observance [thereof] by some, becomes of no force in respect of the rest; as warring against unbelievers, and the prayer over the dead in the bier. (KT.) You say, h`*aA A^amorN faroDN Ealayohimo, and ↓ maforuwDN, and ↓ mufotaraDN, This is [a thing] made obligatory, or binding, on them by God. (TA.) And Haq~uka faroDN, and ↓ maforuwDN, and ↓ mufotaraDN, Thy right, or due, is [a thing] made obligatory, or binding, by God. (A.) ↓ naSiybFA maforuwDFA, in the Kur [iv. 8 and 118], means A share, or portion, determined, defined, or limited, as to time, or otherwise: (Zj, Ibn-'Arafeh:) or, in iv. 118, a share, or portion, cut off and limited. (S, O.) [See also fariyDapN.] ― -b2- A statute, an ordinance, a command or prohibition, of the Apostle of God; syn. sun~apN. (IAar, O, K.) [But faroDN is generally distinguished from sun~apN: the former, for instance, being applied to prayer appointed in the Kur-án; and the latter, to prayer appointed by Mohammad without allegation of a divine order.] ― -b3- A gift, or a soldier's stipend or pay, syn. EaTaA='N, (A,) or EaTiy~apN, (S, O, K,) assigned, or appointed. (S, O, K. *) In the copies of the K, mawosuwmap is put by mistake for marosuwmap. (TA.) You say, maA A^aSabotu minohu faroDFA walaA qaroDFA I did not obtain from him an assigned, or appointed, gift, or soldier's stipend, (S, O, TA,) nor a gift to be requited, or a loan. (O, TA.) And faroDN also signifies A thing which one makes obligatory, or binding, on himself, and freely gives: or a thing which one gives liberally, not for a recompense. (IDrd, O, K.) -A3- Also Soldiers who receive stipends; (K:) so accord. to Lth, as related by Az; but [Sgh says] I have not found it in the book of Lth: (O:) or soldiers having definite portions assigned to them: (A:) pl. furuwDN. (A, TA.) You say, Einodahu miAy^apN mina AlfaroDi He has with him a hundred soldiers &c. (A.) -A4- A shield. (S, O, K.) Sakhr-el-Gheí says, describing lightning, (O, TA,) likening it to a light shield which an announcer of tidings was turning over and over with his hands that a party might see it and be gladdened [by the signal], (TA,)
A^ariqotu lahu mivola lamoEi Alba$iyri
yuqal~ibu biAlkaf~i faroDFA xafiyfFA
[I was sleepless by reason of it, it being (in its flickering) like the signalling of the announcer of tidings turning over and over with the hand a light shield]: one should not say quroSFA xfyfA. (S, O, TA: but my copies of the S have qal~aba instead of yuqal~ibu.) [See also what follows.] ― -b2- And A stick, or piece of wood; syn. EuwdN; thus [it means] in the verse (fiY Albayoti) accord. to El-Jumahee, (O, TA,) i. e. in the verse above-cited: (TA:) he says, AlfaroDu fiY Albayoti EuwdN: (O, TA:) whence the author of the K has been misled to explain AlfaroDu as meaning EuwdN mino A^aEowaAdi Albayoti. (TA.) ― -b3- And An arrow before it has been furnished with feathers and a head: (Akh, S, O, TA:) a meaning also heard by El-Jumahee: (O, TA:) and to this, in the hand of the player, 'Abeed ElAbras has likened lightning, accord. to the S; but Sgh says, in the TS, that he did not find the verse cited by J in the poetry of 'Abeed. (TA.) ― -b4- And A piece of rag: another explanation heard by El-Jumahee. (O.) ― -b5- And A garment, or piece of cloth: (O, K:) a meaning mentioned by As on the authority of some one or more of the Arabs of the desert, of Hudheyl. (O.) [See also firaADN.] ― -b6- And it is said that in the verse cited above it means the notch in the zanod [or rather zanodap, mentioned in the first sentence of this paragraph]. (O, TA.) -A5- A sort of dates (S, O, Msb, K) of 'Omán: (Msb:) As says that the best dates of 'Omán are these and the baloEaq: (S, O:) and AHn says, Certain of the desertArabs of 'Omán informed me that when the tree thereof has its fruit ripened, and the gathering is delayed, the fruit falls from its stones, and the raceme remains with nothing upon it but stones hanging to the vafaAriyq [by which they are attached to the ends of the stalks]. (TA.)
firoDN * The fruit of the dawom [or Theban palm] while continuing red. (AA, O, * K.)

furoDapN * : see faroDN, first sentence, in two places, ― -b2- A gap, or an opening, in a wall and the like: pl. furaDN. (Msb.) ― -b3- A gap, or breach, in the bank of a river, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) whence one draws water, (S, O, K,) or by which one descends to the water, (Mgh, Msb,) and by which the ships, or boats, ascend; (Msb;) i. e. (Mgh) its ma$oraEap: (As, A, Mgh:) pl., in this and the following senses, furaDN (TA) and firaADN. (A, TA.) Hence the saying, in a trad., faA@joEaluwA Als~uyuwfa lilomanaAyaA furaDFA (assumed tropical:) Therefore make ye the swords to be ma$aAriE [here used in the sense of means of access] to death; (O, TA;) and offer, or expose, yourselves to martyrdom. (TA.) Hence also, firaADN is used in the sense of vuguwrN [pl. of vagorN, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b4- Of a sea, or great river, The place where ships unload; syn. maHaT~u Als~ufuni: (S, O, K:) or where they are stationed, near the bank of a river, or near the land. (Mgh.) ― -b5- Of a receptacle for ink, The place of the ink. (S, O, K.) ― -b6- Of a door, The najoraAn [or piece of wood in which is the foot; i. e. upon which turns the foot]. (S, O, K.) ― -b7- Of a mountain, A part sloping down
from the middle and side. (TA.) -A2- furoDataAni i. q. fariyDataAni, q. v., accord. to ISk. (IB.)

faraDiY~N * and ↓ faAriDN (S, A, Mgh, O, K) and ↓ far~aADN (A, Mgh, B) and ↓ fariyDN (A, O, L, K) A man skilled in the science of the faraAy^iD; (S, * A, Mgh, O, K, * B;) i. e. in the science of questions relating to inheritance; (Mgh;) or in the science of the division of inheritances. (TA.)

firaADN * The mouth of a river or rivulet. (S, O, K. *) ― -b2- And Roads, or ways. (Lth, O, K.) [In this latter sense, app., (as well as in others shown above,) pl. of furoDapN, q. v.] -A2- Also The fire that is elicited from the zanodap. (AHn, TA.) [See also faroDN (of which it is a pl.), first sentence.] -A3- And Clothing: (S, O, K:) one says, maA Ealayohi firaADN There is not upon him any clothing; (S, O;) or, accord. to AHeyth, covering. (TA.) [See also faroDN, near the end.]

fariyDN * An arrow having its notch cut; (S, A, O, K;) as also ↓ maforuwDN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also faraDiY~N: -A2- and see faAriDN. -A3- Also The cud of the camel; accord. to Kr: but accord. to others this is called, qariyD [q. v.], with q. (TA.)

fariyDapN * , of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: pl. faraAy^iDu: said by some to be derived from faroDN signifying the act of “ apportioning, ” or “ appointing; ” because frAy^D are apportioned, or appointed: by others said to be from faroDN in relation to a bow. (Msb.) [These remarks apply to the word in all the senses here following.] ― -b2- A subst. signifying A thing made obligatory, or binding, on a person or persons, (S, Mgh, TA) by God; (S, TA;) an obligatory statute or ordinance of God, in a general sense: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b3- A portion, or share, made obligatory, or binding, (K, * TA,) on a man: (TA:) or anything apportioned, or appointed: [and particularly a primarily-apportioned inheritance: (see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. Ewl:)] and hence, faraAy^iDu is applied to the portions, or shares, of inheritances; [i. e. the fixed primary portions of inheritances assigned by the Kur-án; which are a half, third, fourth, sixth, and eighth;] because they are apportioned, or appointed, to their several owners. (Mgh.) And hence, (Mgh,) Eilomu AlfaraAy^iDi, and elliptically AlfaraAy^iDu, (S, * Mgh, O, * Msb,) The science of the division of inheritances; (S, O, TA;) or the science of questions relating to inheritance. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., (Mgh,) taEal~amuwA AlfaraAy^iDa waEal~imuwhaA Aln~aAsa faA_in~ahaA niSofu AlEilomi, accord. to the relation commonly followed, with the pron. fem., referring to AlfrAy^D; and waEal~imuwhu faA_in~ahu, with the pron. masc., referring to Eilom understood as prefixed to AlfrAy^D; [i. e. Learn ye the science of the division of inheritances, &c., and teach ye it to (other) men, for it is the half of science:] it is said to be called the half of science in consideration of the division of statutes into those which pertain to the living and those which pertain to the dead; or by way of amplification. (Mgh, * Msb.) The phrase AlfariyDapu AlEaAdilapu [The equitable portion of inheritance], in a trad. of Ibn-'Omár, is that respecting which the Muslims have agreed: or that for which the authority is elicited from the Kur-án and the Sunneh without there being in these any express statute respecting it: or that is equitably divided, agreeably with the portions and shares mentioned in the Kur-án and the Sunneh. (TA.) ― -b4- What is made obligatory, or binding, [on the owner, to give,] of pasturing beasts, [i. e. camels,] in payment of the poor-rate; (S, O, K;) the camel that is taken in payment of the poor-rate: so termed because it is made obligatory to be given, of a certain number of camels: the p is added because the word is made a subst., not an epithet: pl. faraAy^iDu: (TA:) faraAy^iDu AlA_ibili signifying the dues of the poor-rate, of camels: (A, Mgh: *) the fryDp of twenty-five camels is a binot maxaAD, (Mgh,) or she-camel one year old; (AHeyth;) that of thirty-six, a binot labuwn, (AHeyth, Mgh,) or she-camel two years old; (AHeyth;) that of forty-six, a Hiq~ap, or she-camel three years old; and that of sixty-one, a ja*aEap, or she-camel four years old. (AHeyth.) AlfariyDataAni signifies The ja*aEap of sheep, or goats, with the Hiq~ap of camels; (ISk, S, O, K;) and ↓ AlfuroDataAni signifies the same, accord. to ISk. (IB.) And fariyDapN, by an extension of its meaning, is applied to A camel, in other cases than those of the poor-rate. (TA.) ― -b5- See also faAriDN.

firoyaADN *
Wide, or broad. (O, K.)
far~aADN * : see faraDiY~N.

faAriDN * : see faraDiY~N. -A2- Old, aged, or advanced in age; applied to a cow; (S, A, O;) in the Kur ii. 63; (S, O;) and to a ram: (TA:) or extremely aged; or old and weak; applied to a cow; (Fr, Katádeh;) as also faAriDapN and ↓ fariyDN (TA) and ↓ fariyDapN: (K, TA: [but to what these are applied is not shown further than by their being mentioned as fem. epithets:]) or large and fat; applied to a cow: pl. fawaAriDu: (AZ:) and the pl. also signifies sound, or healthy, and large; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TS, K;) not small, nor diseased: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TS:) and, contr., diseased. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, TS, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Old, aged, or advanced in age, and large, big, or bulky; applied to a man: (TA:) or large, big, or bulky; applied to a man; (S, A, O, K;) and to a full-grown unripe date (busorap); (A, TA;) and to the bursa faucium of a camel ($iqo$iqap); and to a uvula (lahaAp); (O, K;) and to a skin for water or milk (siqaA='); (IB;) and to a beard (liHoyap); (A, O, K;) or, applied to this last, it is with p; (Akh, S;) or with and without p: (L:) and without p, applied in the same sense to anything; (S, O, K;) being masc. and fem.: (As, O:) pl. fur~aDN, (IAar, S, A, O, K,) applied to men; (IAar, S, A, O;) or this, so applied, signifies goodly, or handsome: (TA:) and fawaAriDu is applied to dates [&c.]. (A, TA.) Also (assumed tropical:) Old, or ancient; (K;) applied to a thing. (TA.) You say DigonN faAriDN (tropical:) Great rancour, or malevolence, or malice; (L;) as also DagiynapN faAriDN: (A, L:) or old rancour, &c. (O.) And Dab~N faAriDN (tropical:) Great enmity. (IAar.)

A^aforaDu * The most [and more] skilled, of men, in the science of the faraAy^iD; (S, Mgh, O, K; *) i. e. in the science of the division of inheritances; (S, O, TA;) or in the science of questions relating to inheritance. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., A^aforaDukumo zayodN The most skilled, of you, &c., is Zeyd. (S, Mgh.)

miforaDN *
An iron instrument with which notches, or incisions, are made. (S, O, K.)

mufar~aDN *
Notched much, or in many places; serrated; or jagged. (El-Báhilee.) ― -b2- And hence, The [kind of beetle called] juEal: (El-Báhilee:) or the male of the [beetles called] xanaAfis. (IAar.)
maforuwDN * : see fariyDN: -A2- and see also faroDN, as syn. with maforuwDN, in four places.
mufotaraDN * : see faroDN, as syn. with maforuwDN, in three places.

1 faraTa * , (O, K,) aor.
faruTa , (TA,) inf. n. furuwTN, (K,) He (a man, TA) preceded; went before; was, or became, before, beforehand, first, or foremost; had, or got, priority, or precedence; (O, K, TA;) as also fariTa, aor.
faraTa , [inf. n. faraTN; which is therefore used as an epithet applied to one and to more;] (O, TA;) and so ↓ AftrT, in the phrase AftrT A_ilayohi fiY h`*aA AlA^amori [He was foremost in attaining to him in this affair]. (TA.) [See mufotariTN.] ― -b2- faraTa Alqawoma, (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
faruTa , (S, Msb,) or
fariTa , (K,) inf. n. faroTN, (S,) or furuwTN, (Msb,) or both, (O,) or the former and faraATapN, (M, K,) He preceded, or went before, the people, or company of men, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) to the water, (S, O,) or in search of water, (Msb,) or to come to water, (M, K,) for the purpose of preparing the buckets and ropes, (Msb,) or for the purpose of putting into a right state the watering-trough (M, K) and ropes (M, O) and buckets, (M, O, K,) i. e. to prepare these for them. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b3- An Arab of the desert said to El-Hasan, Eal~imoniY diynFA wasuwTFA laA *aAhibFA furuwTFA walaA saAqiTFA suquwTFA, meaning Teach thou me a religion of the middle sort, not passing beyond the due mean, nor falling short of it. (TA.) ― -b4- faraTa minohu It proceeded from him hastily, before reflection, or without premeditation; [as thought it preceded his judgment;] syn. badara, and sabaqa, and taqad~ama. (TA.) [See 3.] You say, faraTa minohu kalaAmN, aor.
faruTa , Speech proceeded from him hastily, before reflection, or without premeditation; syn. sabaqa, and taqad~ama. (Msb.) And faraTa A_ilayohi min~iY qawolN A saying proceeded to him from me hastily, before reflection, or without premeditation; syn. sabaqa. (S.) And in like manner you say of an evil action. (TA.) ― -b5- faraTa Ealayohi He hasted to do him an evil action: (O, TA:) he acted hastily and unjustly towards him. (S, O,
TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xx. 47], A_in~aA naxaAfu A^ano yaforuTa EalayonaA Verily we fear that he may act hastily and unjustly towards us: (S:) or that he may hastily do to us an evil action: (Ibn-'Arafeh, O:) or that he may hasten to punish us. (Fr, Bd, O, Jel.) [See also 4.] faraTa Ealayohi also signifies He did to him what was disagreeable, or hateful, or evil; he annoyed him. (TA.) And faraTa, inf. n. furuwTN, He reviled. (IKtt.) You say also faraTa Ealayohi fiY Alqawoli: see 4, latter half. ― -b6- faraTa fiyhi: see 2, near the middle. ― -b7- faraTa fiY HawoDihi: see 4, last sentence but one. ― -b8- faraTati Aln~axolapu The palm-tree was left without being fecundated until its spadix became dry and hard (EasaA, in the CK Ea$A, and in the O yaEosuw). (O, K, * TA.) ― -b9- And faraTati Albiy^oru The well was left until its water had collected again. (Sh, TA.) -A2- faraTa A_ilayohi rasuwlahu: see 2. ― -b2- faraTa wulodFA, or waladFA, and faraTa waladahu: see 4.

2 fr~Thu * , inf. n. taforiyTN, He, or it, made him to precede; to be, or become, before, beforehand, first, or foremost; to have, or get, priority, or precedence; (TA;) as also ↓ AfrThu. (O, TA.) ― -b2- He emboldened him, in contention, or altercation; as also ↓ AfrThu. (TA.) fr~T A_ilayohi rasuwlFA, (IDrd, O, K,) inf. n. as above, (IDrd,) He sent to him a messenger (IDrd, O, K) among his particular, or special, friends; sent him forward, or in advance, to him: (IDrd, O:) or he made him his deputy in a litigation: (O:) and rasuwlFA ↓ AfrT he sent a messenger specially and expressly respecting his needful affairs: (IAar, O, L, K: *) and A_ilayohi rasuwlahu ↓ faraTa he sent forward, or in advance, his messenger to him, and hastened him: (K, TA: [in the CK, instead of waA^aEojalahu, we find wAarosalahu:]) but [SM says,] I do not find this last form mentioned by any of the leading authorities. (TA.) ― -b3- fr~Thu also signifies He sent it before, remaining behind it: or he quitted it, and sent it before: (TA:) he left it, and quitted it: (S:) he left him; (AA;) as also ↓ AfrThu: (Ks, S:) he left him, and became behind him; as also ↓ AfrThu: (TA:) he left him, and went before him: (S, O, K:) and ↓ AfrThu [has a similar meaning,] he left him behind, and forgot him: (Fr:) and he forgot it, namely a thing, or an affair: (K:) firaATN, also, [inf. n. of ↓ fArT,] signifies the act of leaving: (TA:) and fr~T Eanohu he left, forsook, or relinquished, him, or it; or he abstained, or desisted, from it: (TA:) and fr~T fiyhi he neglected it; and preferred backwardness (qad~ama AlEajozi) in it, or with respect to it; and failed, or fell short, of doing what he ought, or flagged, or was remiss, with respect to it; as also fr~Thu; (K; [but accord. to the TA, only the former of these two phrases signifies “ he failed of doing what he ought, ” &c.;]) or simply he neglected it; (ISd, TA;) or he failed of doing what he ought, or flagged, or was remiss, with respect to it, and neglected it, (S, O, Msb,) so that it escaped him; (S, O;) as also fyh ↓ faraTa, (S, O, K, * [in the K, the words rendered “ so that it escaped him ” are omitted,]) aor.
faruTa , (S, O,) inf. n. faroTN: (S, O, K:) and fr~T alone, he flagged, or was remiss; was lazy, or indolent: (TA:) its second pers. sing. is used in cautioning a man against a thing before him, or in commanding him to go forward, or to advance; and is intransitive. (Sb, TA.) Sakhr-el-Gheí says,
*`lika baz~iY falano A^ufar~iTahu
A^axaAfu A^ano yunojizuwA Al~a*iY waEaduwA
That is my weapon, and I will not send it before, remaining behind it: [I fear lest they perform that which they have threatened:] or I will not quit it, nor send it before: or I will not be behind it: (TA:) or I will not neglect it. (ISd, TA.) And Sá'ideh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh says,
maEahu siqaA='N laA yufar~iTu Hamolahu
With him is a skin, the carrying of which he will not leave, nor quit. (S.) You say also, far~aTotuka fiY ka*aA wa ka*aA I left thee in such and such [a state, &c.]: (AA, O:) and mina Alqawomi A^aHadFA ↓ A^aforaTotu I did not leave, of the people, or company of men, any one. (Ks, S, O.) And fr~T fiY janobi A@ll~`hi He neglected the things of God, and did them not: (TA:) or the command of God. (O, TA.) [See also art. jnb.] And it is said in a trad., layosa fiY Aln~awomi taforiyTN A_in~amaA Alt~aforiyTu A^ano laA yaSoHaY Hat~aY yadoxula waqotu AlA^uxoraY [There is no falling short of one's duty in sleeping: the falling short of one's duty is only the not awaking until the time of the other (prayer) commences]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also He let him alone, or left him, for a while; or granted him a delay, or respite; [and so ↓ fArThu; for] A^aTalotu firaATahumo means I long let them alone, or left them, or granted them delay or respite. (TA.) ― -b5- You say also, fr~T A@ll~`h Eanohu maA yakorahu God put away, or removed, or averted, from him what he dislikes, or hates: (Kh, S, O, K:) but this expression is seldom used except in poetry. (S, O.) -A2- fr~Thu, (O, K,) inf. n. taforiyTN, (TA,) also signifies He praised him immoderately; (O, K, TA;) like qr~Zhu: (O, TA:) Sgh has expressed, in the TS, his fear that the former may be a mistranscription for the latter; but seems to have afterwards conceded the correctness of the former, from his mention of it in the O. (TA.)

3 faAraTahumo * , (S, O, * K, * in the O and K fArThu,) inf. n. mufaAraTapN and firaATN, (S,) He vied, or strove, with them, to precede them; to outgo, or outstrip, them; to get before them. (S, O, * K. *) ― -b2- takal~ama firaATFA, (S, O, Msb, K,) the latter word being an inf. n. of fArT, (TA,) He spoke hastily; without premeditation; expl. by sabaqato minohu kalimapN; (S, O, K;) he let fall hasty, or unpremeditated, sayings or expressions; expl. by saqaTa minohu bawaAdiru. (Msb.) ― -b3- See also 2, in two places: ― -b4- and see 6. ― -b5- fArThu also signifies He found him; syn. A^alofaAhu and SaAdafahu: (O, K, TA:) and so fAlThu and lAfThu. (TA.)

4 A^aforaTa see 2, in seven places. ― -b2- A^aforaTato A^awolaAdFA, (S, O,) or AwlAdA ↓ AftrTt, (TA,) said of a woman, She sent children before her [to Paradise, by their dying in infancy]; syn. qad~amatohumo: (S, O, TA:) and AwlAdA ↓ AftrT, said of a man, in like manner signifies qad~amahumo. (TA.) And you say also, ↓ faraTa waladahu He was preceded by his child to Paradise. (IKtt.) And wulodFA ↓ faraTa, (K, TA,) or waladFA, (CK,) He lost children by their dying young: (K, TA;) as though they preceded him to Paradise; (TA;) and so faraTFA ↓ AftrT; (Msb;) and waladFA ↓ AftrT; which also signifies he lost a young child by death: (TA:) or the last of these phrases, (K,) or the last but one, (S, O,) signifies he lost his child, or children, (K,) or a young child, (S, O,) by death before attaining to puberty. (S, O, K.) [See AiHotasaba.] And Alwaladu ↓ AufoturiTa The child's death was hastened; or was made to happen early. (Th.) ― -b3- AfrThu He hastened him; or made him to hasten. (S, O.) And you say also, Als~aHaAbapF tuforiTu AlmaA='a (assumed tropical:) The cloud hastens and forwards the water in the beginning of the [autumnal rain called] wasomiY~. (TA.) And AfrTt Als~aHaAbapu biAlwasomiy~i (tropical:) The cloud hastened with the [rain called] wasomiY~. (S, O, and the like is said in the K.) And AfrT biyadihi A_ilaY sayofihi liyasotal~ahu He put his hand hastily to his sword to draw it forth. (IAar, O, K.) And AfrT [alone] He hastened with an affair. (K, * TA.) And He advanced, or went forward, before tarrying, or waiting, or pausing, fiY AlA^amori in the affair. (TA.) ― -b4- AfrT also [very frequently] signifies He exceeded the due bounds, or just limits; or acted extravagantly, or immoderately; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) fiY AlA^amori in the affair; (S, O, TA;) and fY Hub~ihi in loving him; and fY bugoDihi in hating him; (O, TA;) and fY madoHihi in praising him: (K:) it is likewise said of anything exceeding the due bounds; [meaning it was, or became, excessive, or immoderate:] and also signifies he did more than he was commanded. (TA.) You say also, Ealayohi fiY Alqawoli ↓ faraTa He exceeded the due bounds, or just limits, towards him in speech. (K, TA.) And AfrT fiY Alqawoli He talked [excessively, exceedingly, immoderately, or] much. (TA.) [And, AfrT Ealayohi He acted insolently, or presumptuously, towards him.] ― -b5- Also AfrT Ealayohi He loaded him (namely a camel, IKtt) with that which he was unable to bear. (IKtt, K.) And AfrT He filled (S, O, K) a mazaAdap (S) or a qirobap (O) so that he made the water to flow: (O, K:) or a watering-trough or vessel (TA) so that it overflowed: (K, TA:) and fiY HawoDihi ↓ faraTa, (O, TA,) aor.
faruTa , (O,) inf. n. faroTN, (TA,) he filled his watering-trough: (O, TA:) or poured much water into it. (TA.) ― -b6- And AfrT Aln~axolapa He left the palm-tree without fecundation until its spadix became dry and hard. (O, L, K. [See 1, near the end.])

5 tfr~T *
He (a horse) outwent, or got before, other horses. (S, TA.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

6 tfArTwA *
They vied, or strove, one with another, to precede, outgo, outstrip, or get before. (S, O. *) Bishr says, [using the verb transitively,]
yunaAziEona AlA^aEin~apa muSoEabaAtK
kamaA yatafaAraTu Alv~amada AlHamaAmu
[They contend with the reins, being unbroken and refractory, like as the pigeons vie, one with another, in striving to get first to the scanty remains of rainwater]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tfArT fulaAnN Such a one preceded, or got before, and made haste. (O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) tafaAraTatohu Alhumuwmu, (O, K, TA,) and AlA^umuwru, (O, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Anxieties, and affairs, or events, came to him [as though] vying, one with another, to be first: (K, TA:) or befell him at an indefinite time, (O, * K, * TA,) but only at such a time. (O, TA.) You say also, ↓ faAraTatohu Alhumuwmu (assumed tropical:) Anxieties ceased not to come to him at one indefinite time after another. (TA.) ― -b4- tfArT Al$~aYo'u The time of the thing past; as also ↓ tfr~T, which occurs in a trad., relating to a time of prayer, and meaning its time passed before its being performed: (TA:) and both of these verbs are used in the sense next following in relation to a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition. (O.) The time of the thing became postponed, or delayed, so that he who desired it did not attain it. (K.) You say, tafaAraTati AlS~alaApu Eano waqotihaA The prayer became delayed after its time. (TA.)

8 A_ifotaraTa see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and see 4, in five places. ― -b3- fulaAnN laA yufotaraTu A_iHosaAnuhu wabir~uhu (S, K *) Such a one's beneficence and kindness are not caught at, (laA yufotaraSu, as in a copy of the S and in the TA,) or do not pass away, (laA yanoqariDu, as in another copy of the S,) and (S, TA) their passing away, so that one cannot avail himself of them, is not to be feared: (S, K, TA:) a saying of one of the Arabs of the desert. (TA.)

faroTN *
Excess; extravagance; exorbitance; an exceeding degree; an exceeding of the due bounds, or just limits. (S, O, K, * TA.) You say, A_iy~aAka waAlfaroTa fiY AlA^amori [Avoid thou, or beware thou of, excess in the affair].
