(S, O.) ― -b2- Mastery, ascendency, prevalence, or predominance: (K, TA:) as, for instance, of eager desire, and of grief. (TA.) -A2- A time, whether long or short; an indefinite time; syn. HiynN. (S, O, K.) You say, laqiytuhu fiY AlfaroTi baEoda AlfaroTi I met him time after time. (S, O.) And A^anaA A=tiyhi AlfaroTa I come to him, or will come to him, at some time. (TA.) ― -b2- It also denotes one's meeting a man, (TA,) or coming to him, (K,) after some days, (K, TA,) accord. to A 'Obeyd; (TA;) not more than fifteen days, (K,) or than fifteen nights, accord. to the same, (S, O,) nor less than three. (K.) You say, A^anaA A^aloqaAhu fiY AlfaroTi [I meet him, or will meet him, or shall meet him, after some days]. (TA.) [But the above-mentioned restriction does not apply when it is prefixed to a noun signifying a period of time: for] you say also, A^atayotuhu faroTa yawomK A^awo yawomayoni [app. meaning I came to him after a day or two days]. (S, O.) [It is said in the TA that, accord. to ISk, it is used in the saying A=tiyka faroTa yawomK A^awo yawomayoni, and that it is a day between two days; but this seems to me to be a mistake for between a day and two days: it is afterwards said in the TA that faroTa yawomK A^awo yawomayoni means after two days; but the complete explanation should doubtless be after a day or two days.] Lebeed says,
hali Aln~afosu A_il~aA mutoEapN musotaEaArapN
tuEaAru fataA^otiY rab~ahaA faroTa A^a$ohuri
[Is the soul aught but a borrowed thing to be enjoyed, which is lent, and goes to its Lord after some months?]. (S.) And an Arab said, maDayotu faroTa saAEapK walamo A^uwmino A^ano A^anofalita; and being asked “ What is frT sAEp? ” he answered, “ Like since thou begannest to speak: ” he meant [I went away after a little while, or a little while ago, and] by lm and what follows it, I did not feel sure of my escaping. (TA.) -A3- Also A small mountain; (K;) pl., accord. to Kr, furuTN [q. v.]: (TA:) or the head of an [eminence such as is termed] A^akamap. (K.) ― -b2- And the same, (K,) or ↓ faraTN, (thus as written in the O,) An erect way-mark, or thing set up for guidance to the right way: (O, K:) pl. A^aforuTN and A^aforaATN: (K:) [but] it is said in the A that badato lanaA A^aforaATu AlmafaAzapi is a tropical saying, signifying maA A@sotaqodama mino A^aEolaAmihaA [as though meaning (tropical:) The foremost of the way-marks of the desert, or waterless desert, appeared to us]. (TA.)
furoTN * : see furuTN, near the end.

faraTN *
A person who goes before, or in advance of, others, to the water, (S, Mgh, K,) or who is sent before, or in advance, to seek water, (Msb,) and who prepares for them the ropes and buckets, (S, O, Msb,) and plasters with mud [in one copy of the S and fills] the watering-troughs, and draws water for them; (S, TA;) as also ↓ faAriTN; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA;) being of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, (S, Msb, TA,) like tabaEN in the sense of taAbiEN: (S, TA:) and a number of persons who perform that office; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ fur~aATN, (S, Msb, K, TA,) pl. of faAriTN: (Msb, TA:) you say rajulN faraTN and qawomN faraTN. (S, Msb.) It is said in a trad., A^anaA faraTukumo EalaY AlHawoDi [I shall be your preceder to the pool of Paradise]. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also faAriTN. ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) A child [that dies] not having attained to puberty: (K, TA:) [whence the phrase AifotaraTa faraTFA: see 4:] pl. A^aforaATN: or faraTN is both sing. and pl. [in this sense]. (TA.) ― -b4- Hence also, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) A reward, or recompense, prepared in advance, or beforehand: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and a work, or an action, of the same kind. (K.) You say, of an infant that has died, (S, Msb,) Aall~`hum~a A@joEalohu lanaA faraTFA O God, make him to be a [cause of] reward, or recompense, prepared in advance, or beforehand, for us. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] (tropical:) Water [at which one arrives] in advance of other waters. (K, TA.) ― -b6- [Hence also,] A^aforaATu AlS~uboHi, (S, O,) or AlS~abaAHi, (K,) (tropical:) The annunciations, or foretokens, (K,) or the beginnings of the annunciations or foretokens, (S, O,) of the daybreak: (S, O, K:) sing. faraTN. (Lth, TA.) ― -b7- See also faroTN, last sentence. -A2- Also Haste. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

furuTN * A swift horse; (S, O, K;) one that precedes, outgoes, outstrips, or gets before, others: (S, A, O:) pl. A^aforaATN. (L, TA.) ― -b2- A case, or an affair, in which the due bounds, or just limits, are exceeded: (S, O, K:) or neglected; (S, * TA;) as also ↓ faraTN: (TA:) or despised and neglected. (AHeyth, O, TA.) You say, kul~u A^amori fulaAnK furuTN The whole of the case of such a person is one in which the due bounds, or just limits, are exceeded. (A, TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xviii. 27], wakaAna A^amoruhu furuTFA, meaning, And whose case is one in which the due bounds, or just limits, are exceeded: (S, O:) or in which obedience is neglected and unheeded: (TA:) or [one of] preference of backwardness (taqodiymu AlEajozi): (Zj:) or [one of] repentance: or, accord. to some, the meaning is that which here next follows: (O, TA:) wrongdoing; injustice; transgression: (O, K, TA:) some say also, that it means hastening, or acceleration. (TA.) -A2- furuTN (S, O) and ↓ furoTN (O) An [eminence such as is termed] A^akamap, resembling a mountain: (S, O:) or the second, accord. to Zbd, the base (safoH) of a mountain: (TA:) pl. A^aforaATN (Zbd, S, O) and A^aforuTN. (O.) [See also faroTN, last sentence but one.]

faroTapN *
A single act of going forth; (S, O, K;) and of preceding, or going before. (S, O.) ― -b2- [A hasty, or an unpremeditated, saying, or action: pl. faraTaAtN. (See 1 and 3.)] You say, Aall~`hum~a A@gofiro liY faraTaAtiY, i. e. maA faraTa min~iY [meaning, O God, forgive me my hasty, or unpremeditated, sayings, or actions]: (TA:) [or my acts of hastiness, or forwardness, and transgression: for] AlfaroTapu fiY Ald~iyni [unless we should in this instance read AlfuroTap, as the Turkish translator of the K has done,] signifies hastiness, or forwardness, and transgression, in religion. (TA.)

furoTapN * The act of going forth; (S, O, K; *) and of preceding, or going before. (S, O.) Hence the saying of Umm-Selemeh, to 'Áïsheh, nahaAki Eani AlfuroTapi fiY AlbilaAdi [He (referring to Mohammad) forbade thee from going forth into the country, or provinces]. (S, O.) And fulaAnN *uw furoTapK fiY AlbilaAdi Such a one is a person who makes many journeys. (TA.)

faraTiY~N * and furaTiY~N, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) but the latter is said in the Moheet to be with damm, [which most probably means that it is furoTiY~N, and it is thus written in the O,] (TA,) applied to a camel and to a man, Untractable, refractory, or stubborn; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) not rendered manageable or submissive. (TA.)

firaATN * (S, O) and ↓ furaATapN, like vumaAmapN, or ↓ firaATapN, (so in the O,) Water that is for him, of the tribes, who first arrives at it; (S, O;) water that is common property among a number of tribes, and is for him who first arrives at it: (O, K:) and in like manner the latter word applied to a well. (TA.) You say, bayona baniY fulaAnK ↓ h`*aA mA='N furaATapN wabaniY fulaAnK, meaning, [This is water between the sons of such a one and the sons of such a one, so that] whichever of them arrives at it first waters [his beasts] and the others do not throng him. (TA.)
fuiraATapN * : see firaATN, in three places.

faAriTN *
Preceding; going before; being, or becoming, before, beforehand, first, or foremost; having, or getting, priority, or precedence: pl. fur~aATN. (TA.) ― -b2- See the sing. and pl. voce faraTN, first sentence. ― -b3- fur~aATu AlqaTaA The foremost of the [birds called] qTA [meaning sand-grouse], who precede the others to the valley and the water. (S, TA.) ― -b4- faAriTN also signifies One who goes before to dig the grave: pl. as above, and also fawaAriTu, which latter is extr., like fawaArisu, pl. of faArisN, as is said in the O. (TA.) ― -b5- And hence, (Lth, TA,) AlfaAriTaAni, (Lth, S, O, K,) in the A ↓ AlfaraTaAni, (TA,) (tropical:) Two stars, (Lth, S, O, K,) separate, each from the other, (Lth, S, O,) before [the stars in the tail of the Bear, app. meaning the Greater Bear, called] banaAt naEo$, (K,) or before the bier (sariyr) of bnAt nE$: [each] being likened to the fArT who goes before a company of men to dig the grave. (Lth, O, TA.)

muforaTN *
Sent before, or first, or foremost. (TA.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xvi. 64], (TA,) waA^an~ahumo muforaTuwna And that they shall be sent before, or first, or foremost, to the fire [of Hell], and hastened thither; (Az, O, K, TA;) this being the primary signification: (Az, O, TA:) or forgotten (Mujáhid, Fr, O) in the fire [of Hell]: (Fr:) or neglected, or left: (TA:) or forgotten, and neglected or left, in the fire: and another reading is ↓ muforiTuwna, meaning [they are] exceeding the limits assigned to them: (O, K:) and another is ↓ mufar~iTuwna, meaning [falling short of their duty] to themselves, in respect of sins. (TA.) ― -b2- [Filled, or] full; applied to a pool of water left by a torrent. (S, TA.)

muforiTN *
Exceeding the due bounds, or just limits; acting extravagantly; applied to a man: excessive; applied to anything; as, for instance, tallness, and shortness. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Alee, ↓ laA taraY AljaAhila A_al~aA muforiTFA A^awo mufar~iTFA Thou wilt not see the ignorant otherwise than exceeding the due bounds in what he doth or falling short of what he ought therein. (TA.) See also muforaTN.
mufar~iTN * : see muforaTN and muforiTN.
mafaAriTN * The extremities of a country or the like. (TA.)

fulaAnN mufotariTu Als~ijaAli A_ilaY AlEulaY * [Such a one's emulation is foremost in attaining to eminence]; i. e. he has precedence therein: [see 1, first sentence:] (TA:) said in praise of a man. (TA in art. rnq.)

Q. 1 faroTaHa *
He made broad, or wide, (K,) or he spread out, or expanded, anything: and so faloTaHa. (L.) Hence, furoTiHa said of a round cake of bread, It was made broad, or wide: (S, L:) said by IB to be correctly fuloTiHa, and to be thus in a verse as related by El-Ámidee. (TA. [But see the pass. part. n., below.])
firoTaAHN * : see what follows.

raA^osN mufaroTaHN *
A broad, or wide, head; (S, K;) as also ↓ firoTaAHN: the former is thus accord. to J; but it is [said to be] correctly mufaloTaHN, with l: (K:) [or] both are correct; r being a letter which replaces l. (MF.)

1 faraEa * [He, or it, overtopped, or surpassed in height or tallness: this seems to be the primary signification]. It is said in a trad., yakaAdu yaforaEu Aln~aAsa TuwlFA (O, TA) He is, or was, near to overtopping the people, or surpassing them in tallness. (TA.) And one says, faraEa fiY qawomihi i. e. TaAla [app. meaning He surpassed in tallness among his people or party]; as also ↓ AfrE. (TA.) And faraEa Alqawoma, (K,) or faraEotu qawomiY, (S, O,) inf. n. faroEN and furuwEN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, superior to the people or party, (K,) or I was, or became, superior to my people or party, (S, O,) in eminence, or nobility, or in beauty, or goodliness. (S, O, K.) And faraEa SaAHibahu (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, superior to his companion; he excelled him. (IAar, TA in art. brE.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- And faraEa, (O, K,) aor.
faraEa , (K,) inf. n. faroEN (TK [as is indicated in the K, and, in the former of the two senses here following, furuwEN also, said in the TA to be syn. with SuEuwdN]), (tropical:) He (a man, O) ascended: and also he descended: thus having two contr. significations: (O, K, TA:) or, accord. to IAar, it has the former meaning, and ↓ AfrE has the latter meaning: (TA: [but see what follows:]) you say, faraEotu Aljabala (S, TA) and fiY Aljabali, (TA,) I ascended the mountain; (S, TA;) as also ↓ far~aEotuhu, (S, O, * K, *) inf. n. taforiyEN: (S, O, K:) and fiY Aljabali ↓ far~aEotu I descended the mountain; as also fiyhi ↓ A^aforaEotu: (S, O, K:) or, as IB says, on the authority of A 'Obeyd, fiY Aljabali ↓ AfrE means he ascended the mountain: and minohu ↓ AfrE he descended it. (TA.) ― -b3- And faraEotu raA^osahu biAlEaSaA, (S, O, K, * TA, *) inf. n. faroEN; (O, TA;) as also qaraEotuhu, (S, O,) inf. n. qaroEN; (O;) (tropical:) I smote his head, [or assailed it, smiting,] syn. Ealawotuhu (S, O, K, * TA) bihaA (K, TA) DarobFA, (TA,) [with the staff, or stick], and biAls~ayofi [with the sword]. (TA.) ― -b4- faraEotu farasiY biAll~ijaAmi, (S, O, K, *) aor.
faraEa , inf. n. faroEN, (S, O,) (assumed tropical:) I pulled in my horse by the bridle and bit, to stop him. (S, O, K.) ― -b5- faraEotu bayonahumaA, (S, O,) or bayonahumo, (K, TA,) aor.
faraEa , inf. n. faroEN, (TA,) (tropical:) I interposed, or intervened as a barrier, (S, O, K, TA,) between them two, (S, O, TA,) or between them, (K, TA,) and restrained (S, O, K, TA) them two, (S, O, TA,) or them, and made peace, or effected a reconciliation, between them: (K, TA:) and ↓ fr~E bayona Alqawomi, inf. n. taforiyEN, (assumed tropical:) He made a separation, and interposed, or intervened as a barrier, between the people, or party: and hence the saying in a trad., bayona Alganami ↓ kaAna yufar~iEu i. e. He was making a separation between the sheep, or goats: IAth says that Hr has mentioned it as with q; but, he adds, Aboo-Moosà says, it is one of his mistakes. (TA.) -A2- h`*aA A^aw~alu SayodK faraEahu means This is the first object of the chase of which he shed, or has shed, the blood. (TA. [See also 4.]) ― -b2- See also 8. -A3- faraEa AlA^aroDa: see 4. -A4- fariEa, [aor.
faraEa ,] (TA,) inf. n. faraEN, (S, O, K, TA,) He (a man) was, or became, abundant, (TA,) or free from deficiency, (S, O, K,) in respect of the hair [of the head]. (S, O, K, TA.) [See A^aforaEu.]

2 far~aEa see 1, near the middle, in two places. -A2- far~aEotu mino h`*aA AlA^aSoli masaAy^ila, (Msb, K, but in the latter far~aEa,) inf. n. taforiyEN, (TA,) (tropical:) I derived, or deduced, questions, or problems, or propositions, from this fundamental axiom or principle; (Msb;) or made questions to be the furuwE [i. e. the branches, meaning derivatives,] of this fundamental axiom or principle: (K, TA:) a tropical phrase. (TA.) -A3- See again 1, latter half, in two places. -A4- And see also 4, former half, in three places.

3 fArE Alr~ajula *
He sufficed the man; and bore, or took upon himself, a responsibility for him. (TA.)

4 A^aforaEa see 1, in five places. ― -b2- You say AfrE bihim meaning He alighted at their abode [as a guest]; syn. nazala. (K.) And A^aforaEonaA bifulaAnK famaA A^aHomadonaAhu i. e. nazalonaA bihi [We alighted as guests at the abode of such a one, and we did not find him to be such as should be commended]. (S, O.) ― -b3- And AfrE fY lwmh [app. fiY luw^omihi] i. e. AinoHadara [as though meaning (tropical:) He lowered himself in his meanness, or sordidness; but I suspect it to be a mistranscription]; a tropical phrase. (TA.) -A2- AfrE AlA^aroDa He went round, or about, or round about, (S, O, K, TA,) or did so much, (S, O, TA,) in the land, (S, O, K, TA,) as also ↓ faraEahaA, and ↓ fr~EhA, (TA,) and consequently knew its state, or case, or circumstances. (S, O, K, TA.) -A3- AfrEt AlA_ibilu The camels brought forth the [firstlings, or] first offspring (AlfaraEa). (O, K.) ― -b2- And A^aforaEuwA, (O,) or Alqawomu AfrE, (K,) They, (O,) or the people, or
party, (K,) were, or became, persons whose camels had brought forth the first offspring. (O, K.) ― -b3- And AfrE Alqawomu The people, or party, sacrificed the faraE [or firstling of a camel, or of a sheep or goat]: (S, Msb:) or AfrE AlfaraEapa he sacrificed the faraEap, (O, K,) which signifies the same as the faraE; (Mgh, Msb;) and so AlfaraEapa ↓ AstfrE; (O;) or [simply] ↓ AstfrE; (K;) and AfrE [alone]; (O;) and ↓ fr~E, (O, K,) inf. n. taforiyEN; (K;) he sacrificed the faraEa; (O, K;) whence the trad., ↓ far~iEuwA A_ino $ay^otumo wal`kino laA ta*obaHuwA garaApF Hat~aY yakobara i. e. Slaughter ye the firstling [of a camel, or of a sheep or goat], but slaughter not one that is little, whose flesh is like glue, [until it be full-grown.] (O, TA. *) ― -b4- And [hence, perhaps,] A^aforaEotuhu I made him to bleed. (Msb.) And A^aforaEati AlD~abuEu Alganama, (O, K, TA,) so says Ibn-'Abbád, (O, TA,) or fiY Alganami, so in the L, (TA,) The hyena, or female hyena, injured, and made to bleed, (O, K, TA,) or killed, and injured, (L, TA,) the sheep or goats. (O, L, K, TA.) And AfrE All~ijaAmu Alfarasa The bit made the mouth of the horse to bleed. (O, K. [See also 1, near the end.]) And AfrE AlmaroA^apa, said of menstruating, It made the woman to bleed. (TA.) And [hence, app.,] AfrE AlEaruwsa He accomplished his want in respect of the compressing of the bride. (AA, O, K. * [See also 8.]) ― -b5- And AfrEt She (a woman) saw blood on the occasion of childbirth: (O, K:) or, as some say, before childbirth: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or at the first of her menstruating: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or she menstruated: (A'Obeyd, L, TA:) or she (a woman, or a beast,) first saw blood when taken with the pains of parturition, or near to bringing forth: and AfrE lahaA Ald~amu the blood appeared to her. (L, TA.) -A4- And AfrE He began, or commenced, discourse, or a narration; (K;) and so ↓ AstfrE; (Sh, O, K, TA;) and ↓ AftrE: (Sh, TA:) and likewise, as also ↓ AstfrE, a thing. (K.) One says, biy^osa maA A^aforaEota bihi Very evil is that with which thou hast begun, or commenced: (S, O:) and niEoma maA A^aforaEota [or A^aforaEota bihi] Very good is that which [or with which] thou hast begun. (Msb.) And AfrE safarahu, and HaAjatahu, He began, commenced, or entered upon, his journey, and his needful affair. (TA.) And AfrEwA mino safarihimo They came, or arrived, from their journey when it was not the proper time for their coming. (TA.) ― -b2- And AfrEwA They sought after herbage in its place (AinotajaEuwA) among the first, or foremost, of the people. (S, O, K.) -A5- AfrE A^aholahu, thus in all the copies of the K, expl. as meaning kafalahumo, and likewise in the O, is a mistranscription by Sgh, whom the author of the K has here followed: it is correctly, AfrE AlawAdiY A^aholahu i. e. The valley sufficed its people; syn. kafaAhumo. (TA.) -A6- A^uforiEa bisay~idi baniY fulaAnK, (O, K,) with damm, (K,) means The chief of the sons of such a one was taken (O, K, TA) and slain. (TA.)

5 tfr~Et A^agoSaAnu Al$~ajari *
The branches of the trees became abundant. (S, O, K. *) ― -b2- And [hence,] tfr~E AlwaAdiY (assumed tropical:) [The valley branched forth]. (TA.) ― -b3- [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce faZiyEN.] ― -b4- tafar~aEato mino h`*aA AlA^aSoli masaAy^ilu (O, Msb, K, TA) (tropical:) Questions, or problems, or propositions, were derived, or deduced, from this fundamental axiom or principle; (Msb;) or were made to be the furuwE [i. e. the branches, meaning derivatives,] thereof; (K, TA;) [they ramified therefrom;] is a tropical phrase. (TA.) -A2- tafar~aEahumo (tropical:) He set upon them (O, K, TA) with reviling and the like; as in the A and L: (TA:) and he was, or became, superior to them, (O, K, TA,) in eminence, or nobility; and excelled them: (TA: [see also 1:]) or it signifies, (S, K, TA,) or signifies also, (O,) (tropical:) he married, or took to wife, the chief of their women, (S, O, K, TA,) and the highest of them: (TA:) and tafar~aEotu bibaniY fulaAnK (tropical:) I married among the noble and high of the sons of such a one; like ta*ar~ayotuhumo and tanaS~ayotuhumo. (TA.)

8 AftrE * : see 4, latter half. ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) He devirginated a maid; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) as also ↓ faraEahaA. (K.) ― -b3- And hence, AftrE qaSiydapa ka*aA (tropical:) [He broached such an ode], and maEaAniYa ka*aA [such meanings]: (Har p. 61:) and yafotariEu A^abokaAra AlmaEaAniY (tropical:) [He broaches virgin meanings]. (TA, and Har ubi suprà.)
10 A_isotaforaEa see 4, former half, in two places: -A2- and the same again, latter half, in two places.

faroEN * The upper, or uppermost, part of anything; (S, O, Msb, K;) the faroE being what branches forth (yatafar~aEu) from the lower, or lowest, part thereof: (Msb:) pl. furuwEN only. (TA.) It is said in a trad. A^aY~u Al$~ajari A^aboEadu mina AlxaArifi qaAluwA faroEuhaA qaAla waka*`lika AlS~af~u AlA^aw~alu [What part of trees is furthest from the plucker of the fruit? they said, The uppermost part thereof; he said, And such like is the first row of the persons worshipping in the mosque]. (TA.) Thus faroEu AlA^u*uni signifies The upper, or uppermost, part of the ear; (K, * MF, TA;) pl. as above. (TA.) And furuwEu Almuqolatayoni The upper, or uppermost, parts of the two eyeballs. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A branch of a tree or plant: (KL, TA:) or the head of a branch: or a great branch: and a branch of anything. (MA.) ― -b3- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) A branch, or subdivision, or derivative, of anything that is regarded as a fundamental or a whole;] a thing that is built, or founded, upon another thing; opposed to A^aSolN: (K, TA:) [the pl. furuwEN, as opposed to A^uSuwlN meaning “ fundamentals, ” signifies, in the conventional language of the lawyers and the men of science in general, the derivative institutes of the law, &c.: see 2:] Eilomu AlfuruwEi [the science of the derivative institutes of the law] is what is commonly known by the appellation of Eilomu Alfiqohi [the science of jurisprudence; because it is mainly concerned with institutes derived from fundamentals]. (Hájjee Khaleefeh.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) The hair of a woman: pl. as above [app. used in a collective sense like the French “ cheveux ”]: (K, TA:) one says AimoraA^apN Tawiylapu AlfuruwEi [meaning (tropical:) A long-haired woman]. (TA.) And (K) (tropical:) Full [or abundant] hair. (S, O, K, TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) The noble, or man of eminence, of a people or party: (S, O, K, TA:) pl. as above: (TA:) one says, huwa faroEu qawomihi (tropical:) He is the noble, or man of eminence, of his people or party, (S, O, TA, *) and mino furuwEihim of their nobles, &c. (TA.) ― -b6- And [app. from the same word as signifying “ a branch of a tree, ”] (assumed tropical:) A valley branching off. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A channel in which water runs to the $iEob (K, TA) i. e. the waAdiY [here meaning the water-course in a low tract or between the two acclivities of two mountains]: (TA:) [but] in this sense its pl. is firaAEN. (K, TA.) -A2- Also [or qawosN faroEN] A bow that is made from the extreme portion of a branch, (As, S, O, K, TA,) from the head thereof: (As, TA:) and (K) a bow that is not [made from a branch] divided lengthwise (S, O, K, TA) is called qawosN faroEN; (S, O, TA;) such as is [made from a branch] divided lengthwise being called qawosN filoqN: (S, O:) or the faroE is [one] of the best of bows: (AHn, K, TA:) and [this word is used as an epithet, i. e.] one says qawosN faroEN and faroEapN. (K.) -A3- Also, i. e. faroEN, Property that is beneficial, or serviceable, and made ready, or prepared: (O, K, TA:) or, accord. to the S, it is ↓ faraEN which has this signification; but this is said by Sgh [app. in the TS], and after him by the author of the K, to be a mistake; and a verse in which it occurs with the r quiescent is cited in the O and K as an ex. of it in this sense: it may be, however, that the poet has made the r quiescent of necessity [by poetic license, for the sake of the metre]; or it may here [properly] signify “ a branch, ” and be metonymically used as meaning recent property. (TA.) -A4- See also the next paragraph, latter half.

faraEN * The firstling of the camel, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) or of the sheep or goat, (L, K,) which they used to sacrifice to their gods, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) looking for a blessing thereby; (S, O, Msb;) and ↓ faraEapN signifies the same: (Mgh, Msb:) hence, (Mgh, O, K,) it is said in a trad., [implying the prohibition of this custom,] laA faraEa walaA EatiyrapN, (S, O, K, *) or walaA Eatiyrapa ↓ laA faraEapa: (Mgh: [see EatiyrapN:]) or when the camels amounted to the number for which their owner wished, they sacrificed [a firstling]: (TA:) or when one's camels amounted to a complete hundred, (K, TA,) he sacrificed a he-camel thereof every year, and gave it to the people to eat, neither he nor his family tasting it, or rather, it is said, (TA,) he sacrificed a young, or youthful, he-camel to his idol: and
the Muslims used to do it in the first part of ElIslám: then it was abrogated: (K, TA:) accord. to the Bári' and the Mj, the firstling of camels and also that of sheep or goats are thus called: (Msb:) the pl. [of faraEN] is furuEN, with two dammehs. (K.) It is said in a prov., A^aw~alu AlS~ayodi faraEN [The first of what are taken by the chase or the like is a frE] as being likened to a firstling: so says Yezeed Ibn-Murrah. (TA. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 35.]) ― -b2- The poet Ows Ibn- Hajar, (S, O,) or Bishr Ibn-Abee-Kházim, has used it as meaning The skin of a faraE; (S, O; *) suppressing the prefix jilod: (S:) for they used to clothe with its skin another young one of a camel, in order that the mother of the one sacrificed might incline to it [and yield her milk]. (O; and the like is said in the TA.) -A2- Also, and ↓ faroEN, Lice: (S, K:) or, as some say, small lice: (TA:) and one thereof is termed ↓ faraEapN and ↓ faroEapN: (S, K:) or, accord. to some, frEp signifies a large louse. (TA.) -A3- And the former (faraEN), Food that is prepared [app. for persons invited to partake of it] on the occasion of camels' bringing forth; like as xurosN signifies such as is on the occasion of a woman's bringing forth. (TA.) ― -b2- And A portion, or share; syn. qisomN: (O, K, TA:) accord. to some, peculiarly of water. (TA.) ― -b3- See also faroEN, last quarter. -A4- It is also the inf. n. of fariEa. (TA. [See 1, last sentence.])

faroEapN *
A high, or an elevated, place of a mountain: pl. firaAEN: so in the saying, Aiyoti faroEapF mino firaAEi Aljabali faA@nozilohaA [Come thou to one of the high places of the mountain and descend it]: (S, TA:) or, as some say, it signifies particularly the head of a mountain. (TA. [See also faAriEapN.]) ― -b2- And faroEapu Aljul~api The highest, or uppermost, of the dates of the [receptacle called] jul~ap [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And frEp AlTryq [i. e. faroEapu AlT~ariyqi] and frEth [sic, app. ↓ faraEatuhu,] and ↓ faroEaAw^uhu and ↓ faAriEatuhu all signify The highest part of the road, and the place where it ends: or the conspicuous and elevated part thereof: or ↓ faAriEatuhu signifies the sides, or borders, thereof. (TA. [See also qaAriEapu AlT~ariyqi.]) ― -b4- And one says, A^atayotuhu fiY faroEapK mina Aln~ahaAri (tropical:) I came to him in a first part of the day. (TA.) -A2- See also faraEN, latter half.
furoEapN * The blood of the virgin on the occasion of devirgination.

faraEapN * : see faroEapN. -A2- [Also] A piece of skin that is added in the qirobap [or water-skin] when the latter is not full-sized, or complete. (O, K.) -A3- See also faraEN, first quarter, in two places: -A4- and the same again, latter half, in one place. -A5- It is also a pl. of faAriEN [q. v.]. (O, K.)

furuwEu AljawozaA='i * means The most intense degree of heat: (S, O, TA:) [or rather AlfuruwEu is a name of a certain asterism of AljawozaA='u (which is an appel-lation of Orion and of Gemini, either whereof may be here appropriately meant,) at the season of the auroral rising of which the heat becomes most intense:] Aboo-Khirásh says,
waZal~a lahaA yawomN kaA^an~a A^uwaArahu
*akaA Aln~aAri mino najomi AlfuruwEi Tawiylu
[And a day continued to them, the heat whereof was as though it were the blazing of fire, from the asterism of the furuwEi; a long day]: (S, * O, TA:) in the S, waZal~a lanaA; but correctly lahaA, meaning to the she-asses: (TA:) and Aboo-Sa'eed related it as above with the unpointed E in AlfrwE: (S, * TA:) in the same manner, also, it is expl. by him as used in the phrase fayoHu najomi AlfuruwEi [which I would render the vehement raging of the heat of the asterism of the frwE] in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee-'Áïdh: El-Jumahee related it differently, with g; but the furuwg [or rather the farogaAni] are of the stars of Aquarius; and the season thereof [i. e. of their auroral rising] is cold; there is then no fyH. (TA.)

furayoEN * , occurring [with tenween, perfectly decl.,] in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi-s-Salt, (O, K,) i. q. ↓ firoEawonu, (O,) which is a proper name of such as was King of the Amalekites [or rather of the ancient Egyptians, in general], like as qayoSar was of the Room [or Greeks of the Lower Empire], and kisoraY of the Persians, (Ksh in ii. 46,) [and also] a foreign word, (Msb,) [wherefore it is imperfectly decl., in Hebr. פַּרְעֹה, i. e. Pharaoh,] a dial. var. of firoEawonu, or used by poetic license: (K:) the pl. of the latter is faraAEinapN. (Msb.)
firoEawonu * : see the next preceding paragraph.

faAriEN * [Overtopping, or surpassing in height or tallness: this seems to be the primary signification]. You say jabalN faAriEN A mountain higher, or taller, than what is next to it. (S, O.) ― -b2- And High, or tall; applied to a man, and to an extended gibbous piece of sand. (TA.) ― -b3- And High, or elevated; goodly in form or aspect or appearance; beautiful: (Aboo-'Adnán, O, K:) or [simply] high [app. in rank or dignity]: (IAar, O:) and also low, ignoble, or mean: (IAar, O, K:) thus having two contr. significations. (O, K.) ― -b4- And a man of the Arabs said, ↓ laqiytu fulaAnFA faAriEFA muforiEFA, meaning [I met such a one] one of us ascending and the other descending. (S, O, TA.) -A2- Also sing. of faraEapN, which signifies The armed attendants, or guards, of the Sultán, or sovereign: (O, K, TA:) it is like waAziEN. (TA.)

faAriEapN * The higher, or highest, part of a mountain [and of a valley]: one says, Ainozilo bifaAriEapi AlwaAdiY waA@Ho*aro A^asofalahu [Alight thou in the higher, or highest, part of the valley, and beware of its lower, or lowest, part]. (S, O.) See also faroEapN, in two places. ― -b2- AlfaAriEapu mina AlganaAy^imi means The surplus that is deducted [so I render AlmurotafiEapu AlS~aAEidapu, app. such things as cannot be divided and are therefore removed,] from the main stock of the spoils before they are divided into fifths. (TA.) ― -b3- And fawaAriEN, (pl. of faAriEapN, TA,) applied to tilaAE, [a word variously explained, here, I think, used as signifying either high, or low, grounds, (see its sing. taloEapN,)] (S, O, * K, *) means Of which the channels wherein the torrents flow are in high, or elevated, parts. (S, O, K.)
fayofaroEN * (K, TA) and fayofaraEN (TA) A species of trees. (K, TA.)

A^aforaEu *
Free from deficiency in the hair [of the head]; (S, O, K;) contr. of A^aSolaEu; (IDrd, S, O, K;) used only in this sense; not applied to a man who is large in the beard or in the whole head of hair: (IDrd, S, O:) the Prophet was A^aforaE, (S, O,) and so was Aboo-Bekr, (O, K,) and 'Omar was A^aSolaE: (O:) fem. faroEaA='u; (S, O, K;) accord. to IDrd, applied to a woman as meaning having much hair: (S, O:) pl. furoEaAnN, (O, K,) like its contr. SuloEaAnN; (O;) and also furoEN. (K.) 'Omar, being asked, “ Are the SuloEaAn better or the furoEaAn, ” said “ The frEAn are better, ” meaning to assert the superior excellence of Aboo-Bekr over himself. (O.) ― -b2- faroEaA='u AlT~ariyqi: see faroEapN. -A2- Also i. q. muwasowisu [app. as meaning Such as is subject to diabolical promptings or suggestions]: so in the trad., laA yaw^um~an~akumu AlA^aforaEu [The AfrE shall by no means act as your Imám]. (Nh, K, TA.)

muforaEN * Anything tall. (TA.) ― -b2- muforaEu Alkatifi A man broad in the shoulder-blade: (S, O, TA:) or high therein. (TA.) And katifN muforaEapN A shoulder-blade high, projecting, and broad. (TA.)
muforiEN * : see faAriEN, last sentence but one.

miforaEN *
One who interposes as a restrainer between persons [at variance], (O, K, TA,) and makes peace, or effects a reconciliation, between them: (TA:) pl. mafaAriEu. (S, O, K.)

Q. 2 tafaroEana *
He (a man, TA) affected the nature, or disposition, of the faraAEinap [pl. of firoEawonu, and here meaning such as are inordinately proud or corrupt or unbelieving, &c., as were the Pharaohs]. (S, * K, TA.)

faroEanapN *
Cunning; i. e. intelligence, or sagacity; or intelligence mixed with craft and forecast; (S, K, TA;) and pride, haughtiness, or insolence. (TA.)

firoEawonu * [Pharaoh;] the surname of El-Weleed Ibn-Mus'ab, king of Egypt: (S:) or the surname of every king of Egypt: (K:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S,) [app. used as a proper name,] anyone inordinately proud or corrupt or
unbelieving; (S, K;) insolent and audacious in acts of rebellion or disobedience, or extravagant therein and in wrongdoing: as also furoEuwnu and furoEawonu; (K;) the last mentioned by IKh, from Fr, and anomalous: (TA:) pl. faraAEinipN. (Msb, K, TA.) It is said in a trad., A^aHadunaA firoEawonu h`*ihi AlA^um~api [app. meaning One of us is the Pharaoh of this people, or nation]. (S: in one of my copies of the S, A^axa*onaA and firoEawona.) ― -b2- And [it is said that] AlfiroEawonu signifies The crocodile, (K, TA,) in the language of the Copts. (TA.)

Ald~uruwEu AlfiroEawoniy~ipu *
Certain coats of mail so called in relation to the firoEawon [or Pharaoh] of Moses. (Sh, TA.)

1 faraga * , [aor.
faruga ; and app. fariga, aor.
faraga and
faruga , as below; inf. n. furuwgN and faraAgN; or, accord. to some, the latter is a simple subst., but it is more commonly used than the former;] said of a thing, It was, or became, empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; syn. xalaA. (Msb.) [You say, faraga mino ka*aA It was, or became, empty, vacant, void, devoid, or destitute, of such a thing; or unoccupied thereby.] And faraga laka Al$~aYo'u [The thing was, or became, vacant, or unoccupied, for thee; as though it were a place, or a vessel: and hence, the thing was, or became, exclusively for thee]. (TA voce xalaA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] faraga (O, * K, * TA) said of a man, (TA,) [and app. fariga also, as below,] inf. n. furuwgN, (tropical:) He died; (O, K, TA;) because his body became devoid of his soul, or spirit. (TA.) ― -b3- And faraga mina Al$~ugoli, (S, O, Msb, K, *) aor.
faruga , inf. n. furuwgN (S, O, Msb, K) and [more commonly] faraAgN, (S, O, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and farag, aor.
faraga , (O, K,) mentioned by Yoo; (O;) and fariga, aor.
faraga , (O, Msb, K,) of the dial. of Temeem; (Msb;) and fariga, aor.
faruga , a compound of two dial. vars.; (O, Msb;) He was, or became, vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure. (K, * TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b4- [And hence, faraga mina AlA^amori He ceased from, ended, or finished, the affair.] ― -b5- And faraga lahu and A_ilayohi, (O, Msb, K, TA,) aor.
faruga and
faraga ; (TA;) and fariga, (O, * Msb, K, * TA,) aor.
faraga ; inf. n. furuwgN and [more commonly] faraAgN; (TA;) He made him, or it, his object, or the object to which he directed himself; syn. qaSada: (O, Msb, K, TA:) [or he made him, or it, his exclusive object; agreeably with an explanation of the phrase here following]: whence, in the Kur [lv. 31], lakumo sanaforugu We will make you our object; expl. by IAar as meaning sanaEomidu [which is syn. with sanaqoSidu]; (TA;) and some read sanaforagu; (O, TA;) and some, saniforagu; (O;) and some, saniforigu, asserting that Temeem say niEolimu; (O, TA;) and some, sanaforagu A_ilayokumo, meaning sanaqoSidu A_ilayokumo; or sanaforugu lakumo means We will apply ourself exclusively (sanatajar~adu) to the reckoning with, and the requiting of, you; and it is said to be a threat; (Bd;) a metaphorical phrase, from a man's saying to him whom he threatens, saA^aforugu laka, (Ksh, Bd,) meaning I will apply myself exclusively to the making an assault upon thee: (Ksh:) one says [also] in threatening, laA^aforugan~a laka [meaning in like manner I will assuredly apply myself &c.]. (TA.) [See, again, 5.] ― -b6- fariga AlmaA='u, (S, O, K,) aor.
faraga , (S, K,) inf. n. faraAgN, (S, TA,) The water poured out or forth, or became poured out or forth. (S, O, K.) -A2- faruga, [aor.
faruga ,] inf. n. faraAgapN, (tropical:) He (a horse) was easy, or good, and quick, in pace, and wide in step. (TA.) ― -b2- farugati AlD~arobapu (tropical:) The [wound made by a] stroke, or blow, was wide; (O, K, TA;) likened to the farog of the leathern bucket. (TA.) ― -b3- And faraAgapN (as an inf. n. of which the verb is faruga, TK) signifies The being impatient, and disquieted or disturbed or agitated. (O, K.) -A3- faraga as trans.: see 4.

2 far~agotuhu *
I made it empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; as also ↓ A^aforagotuhu. (Msb.) taforiygu AlZ~uruwfi signifies The making the receptacles empty. (S, O, K.) And some read [in the Kur xxxiv. 22], Hat~aY A_i*aA fur~iga Eano quluwbihimo, (O, TA,) expl. as meaning Until, when their hearts shall be made void of fear, or fright: or, accord. to IJ, fur~iga and fuz~iEa and A@foranoqaEa [which are all mentioned as readings in the same passage] have one meaning. (TA. [See 2 in art. fzE.]) ― -b2- [Hence one says, fr~ghu lika*aA He made him to be, or become, or he left him, vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; or made him to be unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure; so that he might apply himself exclusively to such a thing.] ― -b3- See also the next paragraph.

4 A^aforaga see 2, first sentence. ― -b2- Afrghu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. A_iforaAgN and muforagN, (O,) signifies [also] He poured it out, or forth; (S, O, K;) namely, water [&c.]; (S;) as also ↓ fr~ghu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. taforiygN; (S, O;) and Afrg likewise signifies he poured forth blood; (S, O, K;) and Ealayohi ↓ faraga AlmaA='a, meaning he poured out, or forth, upon him, the water, is mentioned by Th, who has cited as an ex.,
faragona AlhawaY fiY Alqalobi vum~a saqayonahu
SubaAbaAti maA='i AlHuzoni biAlA^aEoyuni Aln~ujoli
[They (referring to women) poured desirous love into the heart; then they gave him to drink the remains of the water of grief, by looking with the wide eyes: but perhaps faragona is here used for far~agona, by poetic license, for the sake of the metre]: (TA:) A_iforaAgapN signifies A single act of A_iforaAg; and hence the trad. kaAna yuforigu EalaY raA^osihi valaAva A_iforaAgaAtK [He used to pour upon his head three pourings]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] rab~anaA A^aforigo EalayonaA SaborFA, in the Kur [ii. 251 and vii. 123], means (tropical:) O our Lord, pour forth upon us patience, like as [the water of] the leathern bucket is poured forth: (O, TA:) or send down upon us patience (Msb, * TA) that shall envelop us: (TA:) or A^aforaga A@ll~`hu Ealayohi AlS~abora means (assumed tropical:) God inspired him with patience. (Msb in art. rbT.) ― -b4- [Hence, also,] A^aforaga Ealayohi *anuwbFA [lit. He poured forth upon him a bucketful of water] means (tropical:) he talked with him of that in consequence of which he was confounded, or perplexed, by shame. (TA.) ― -b5- Afrg also signifies He poured metal, such as gold and silver &c., in a molten state, into a mould. (TA.) And He cast a thing, i. e. formed it by pouring molten metal into a mould. (Msb. [See its pass. part. n., muforagN.]) ― -b6- And Afrg Einoda AljimaAEi He poured forth his maA=' [or sperma] on the occasion of jmAE. (TA.)

5 tfr~g *
He was, or became, or he made himself to be, vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure; syn. taxal~aY mina Al$~ugoli. (O, K.) [See also faraga mina Al$~ugoli.] Hence the trad. of the Prophet, tafar~aguwA mino humuwmi Ald~unoyaA maA A@sotaTaEotumo [Be ye, or make yourselves to be, vacant, or free, from the anxieties of the present state of existence as much as ye are able]. (O.) ― -b2- And tafar~agotu lika*aA [I was, or became, or I made myself to be, vacant, or free, from business, occupation, or employment; or unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure; for such a thing: and I applied myself exclusively to such a thing]: (S: [these meanings are there indicated, but not expressed; and are well known:]) one says, tfr~g liloEibaAdapi [He applied himself exclusively to religious service]: (Msb in art. btl:) and tafar~agotu liloA^amori means [also, simply,] taSad~ayotu lahu [i. e. I addressed, or applied, or directed, myself, or my regard, or attention, or mind, to the affair]. (Msb in art. Sd.) [See also faraga lahu and A_ilayohi.] ― -b3- And tfr~g bihi signifies taxal~aY bihi [meaning He confined himself exclusively to it; or contented himself with it exclusively of other things]. (K and TA in art. xlw.)

8 Aifotaragotu *
I poured forth upon myself (S, O) water: (S:) [and so Aftrgt EalaY nafosiY; for one says,] raA^ayotuhu yagotarifu AlmaA='a vum~a yafotariguhu EalaY nafosihi [I saw him taking, or lading out, the water; then pouring it forth upon himself]. (A, TA.) And Aifotaragotu linafosiY maA='F I poured out for myself water. (O, K.)

10 Astfrgi * [He drew forth water &c.]. One says, Astfrg maA fiY Alr~aAwiyapi mina AlmaA='i [He drew forth what was in the leathern water-bag, or pair of leathern water-bags, of water]. (TA in art. Ezl.) El-Akhtal said respecting Esh-Shaabee, meaning to denote the largeness of the latter's retentive faculty, A^anaA A^asotaforigu mino A_inaA='K waAHidK wahuwa yasotaforigu mino A^awaAniYa $at~aY (tropical:) [I draw from one vessel, and he
draws from divers vessels]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He vomited intentionally; or constrained himself to vomit: (O, K:) thus it signifies in the conventional language of the physicians. (O.) ― -b3- Aisotaforaga fulaAnN maA fiY SaHofatihi is a prov., meaning Such a one [exhausted, or] chose for himself, as his share, [the whole of] what was in his SHfp [or large bowl]. (TA in art. SHf.) ― -b4- And one says, Astfrg fulaAnN majohuwdahu (tropical:) Such a one exhausted his power, or ability; or exerted it unsparingly, or to the utmost; (S, * O, Msb, * K, * TA;) fiY ka*aA [in such a thing]. (S, TA.)

farogN *
Width, breadth, or ampleness. (S, O, TA.) ― -b2- And The place whence the water pours forth, between the cross-pieces of wood (AlEaraAqiY), of the leathern-bucket; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ firaAgN: (K: [expl. in the O as signifying the side of the leathern bucket from which the water pours forth:]) pl. of the former furuwgN (TA) and mafaArigu, [which is anomalous, like ma$aAbihu and maHaAsinu &c.,] (A, TA,) or this is pl. of ↓ maforagN. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence AlfarogaAni, (S, O,) farogu Ald~alowi Almuqad~amu and farogu Ald~alowi Almuw^ax~aru, (S, O, K,) or Alfarogu AlA^aw~alu and Alfarogu Alv~aAniY, (Kzw,) Two of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, O, K,) the Twenty-sixth Mansion and the Twentyseventh; four stars, wide apart, forming the corners of a square, or four-sided figure; (Kzw;) each consisting of two stars, (S, O, K, and Kzw,) of two bright stars, (S,) the apparent distance between each two stars being the measure of five cubits, (S, O, L,) or the measure of a spear; (K;) [see *iraAEN and rumoHN; the former pair consists of the stars a and b of Pegasus; and the latter, of g in Pegasus together with the bright star in the head of Andromeda; as is shown by what here follows:] the Arabs name Ald~alowu the four bright stars in Pegasus which form a square, or four-sided figure; i. e., that at the extremity of the neck, which is called matonu Alfarasi, and that which is called manokibu Alfarasi, and that which is called janaAHu Alfarasi, and the star that belongs to both Pegasus and Andromeda: (Kzw, descr. of Pegasus:) [these two pairs of stars are what are commonly known as the farogaAni; and are plainly indicated by the periods assigned to the auroral settings thereof: but the periods assigned to their auroral risings would lead us to apply the appel-lation of the frgAn to some other stars, not easily determinable, in Aquarius: see nawo'N: and see also manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] The pl. Alfuruwgu is said to be applied to The farogaAni with the stars around them: (O, TA:) and (accord. to El-Jumahee, O, TA) Alfuruwgu [in the CK erroneously written Alfaruwgu] signifies [The constellation called] AljawozaA='u. (O, K, TA. [But see furuwEu AljawozaA='i, in art. frE.]) ― -b4- farogN also signifies A vessel in which is [the exuded, or expressed, juice termed] dibos, (O, K,) and Saqor. (O.) ― -b5- Also Land affected with drought, or barrenness. (IB, TA.) ― -b6- See also the next paragraph.

firogN * : see faArigN. ― -b2- *ahaba damuhu firogFA and ↓ farogFA mean His blood went for nothing, as a thing of no account, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct, (S, O, K,) and retaliation for it was not sought: (S, O:) and in like manner one says, *ahabato dimaAw^uhumo firgFA [Their bloods went for nothing, &c.]. (Z, TA.) Hence, in the Kur xxviii. 9, accord. to one reading, waA^aSobaHa fuw^aAdu A^um~i muwsaY firogFA (Ksh and Bd) i. e. And the heart, or mind, of the mother of Moses became [as though it were] a thing that was lost, or that had gone away. (Ksh. [See faArigN.])
farigN * : see faArigN, first quarter.

furugN *
i. q. mufar~agN [Made empty, vacant, void, &c.]: (O, TA:) so in the phrase A_inaA='N furugN [An emptied vessel]: (TA:) and so in the saying [in the Kur xxviii. 9], accord. to the reading of Kh, waA^aSobaHa fuw^aAdu A^um~i muwsaY furugFA [And the heart of the mother of Moses became rendered void of patience, or of anxiety, &c.: see faArigN]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a bow, as also ↓ firaAgN, it means Without a string: or, as some say, without an arrow. (TA.)
farogaAn * [whether with or without tenween is not shown] A wide, or capacious, vessel. (TA.)

faraAgN * [generally mentioned as an inf. n., and much used as such; but accord. to the Msb, a simple subst.: as a simple subst., it means Emptiness, vacancy, or vacuity, &c.: ― -b2- and vacancy, or freedom, from business, &c.; or contr. of $ugolN, as is said in the K, in art. $gl: and cessation from an affair: ― -b3- &c.: see 1]. ― -b4- [bayotu AlfaraAgi means The privy.]

firaAgN *
A great bowl, that cannot be carried: pl. A^aforigapN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- A wide, or capacious, large, watering-trough, of hides. (As, O, K.) ― -b3- A vessel (IAar, T, O, K) of any kind. (IAar, T, O.) ― -b4- An udder. (O.) ― -b5- The half of a load, such as is on either of the two sides of a camel: (AA, O, K:) so in the dial. of Teiyi. (AA, O.) ― -b6- See also farogN, second sentence. -A2- [As a pl.,] Valleys, or torrent-beds: from IAar, who has not mentioned a sing. thereof, nor the derivation. (TA.) ― -b2- And [probably as pl. of ↓ fariygN, agreeably with analogy,] Broad niSaAl [or arrow-heads; the word nSAl being app. understood]. (O, K.) -A3- [As a sing. epithet,] A she-camel having no brand, or mark made with a hot iron. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A she-camel having much milk, ample in the integument of the udder. (AZ, O, L, K.) ― -b3- And A bow of which the arrowhead makes a wide wound: or of which the arrow goes far. (O, K.) ― -b4- See also furugN. ― -b5- And see the next paragraph, in two places.

fariygN *
Broad, or wide. (TA.) See firaAgN. [Hence,] DarobapN fariygN (S) or fariygapN (O, K) (tropical:) A wide [wound made by a] stroke, or blow; (S, O, K, TA;) likened to the farog of the leathern bucket: (TA:) and ↓ TaEonapN farogaA='u, likewise, signifies (tropical:) a wide [wound made by a] piercing [with a spear &c.], (S, O, K, TA,) of which the blood flows. (TA.) ― -b2- And fariygapN (tropical:) A mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] that takes in much water; (O, K, TA;) as though having farog, i. e. width. (TA.) ― -b3- And friygN signifies also (tropical:) Land, or ground, that is even, or flat, as though it were a road, (O, K, TA,) and wide: (TA:) or that is marked by much treading: to such Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee likens the whiteness of the A^avor, i. e. firinod, of a sword. (O, TA.) -A2- And (tropical:) A horse wide in step, (S, O, K, TA,) easy, or good, and quick, in pace; as also ↓ firaAgN: (O, K, TA:) or swift and excellent, wide in step: or quick in pace, wide in step, applied to a horse or the like; and so ↓ firaAgN, applied to an ass, and likewise to a man: and, accord. to Z, fariygN applied to an ass signifies wide in step. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Sharp, applied to an arrow, and likewise to a knife. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Sharp-tongued, applied to a man. (TA.)
furaAgapN * The sperma of a man. (S, ISd, K.)

faArigN *
Empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; syn. xaAlK; as in the phrase A_inaA='N fArigN [an empty vessel]: (O, TA:) and likewise applied to a man, (O, TA, *) meaning vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business, occupation, or employment; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ farigN: (O, K, TA:) [and often, used elliptically, meaning vacant from, devoid of, or free from, business &c., and care or anxiety or disquietude; unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure:] and ↓ A^aforagu is syn. with faArigN; (O, K;) as in the phrase, of Ru-beh, maA Alma$oguwlu mivolu AlA^aforagi [The busied is not like the free from business]: (O, TA:) [fur~aAgN is pl. of faArigN: and] ↓ firogN is syn. with fur~aAgN; (O, K; [in the former, as is often the case, the sign of tesh-deed in this word has been carelessly omitted; and in the CK, Alfragu is put for Alfur~aAgu, and has been erroneously supposed to be for AlfaraAgu;]) for ex., Tuleyhah Ibn-Khuweylid El-Asadee says, in relation to the slaying of his brother's son, Hibál Ibn-Selemeh Ibn-Khuweylid,
famaA Zan~ukumo biAlqawomi A_i*o taqotuluwnahumo
A^alayosuwA waA_ino lamo yusolimuwA birijaAli
faA_ino taku A^a*owaAdN A^uSibona wanisowapN
falano ta*ohabuwA firogFA biqatoli HibaAli
[And what is your opinion of the party when ye slay them? Are they not (though they have not become Muslims) men? And if some small numbers of camels have been smitten (and carried off). and some women, ye will not go away free from care by reason of the slaying of Hibál]. (O, TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxviii. 9], waA^aSobaHa fw^aAdu A^um~i muwsaY faArigFA, meaning And the heart, or mind, of the mother of Moses became devoid of patience: or devoid of everything except remembering of Moses: or devoid of anxiety; because of God's having promised to restore him to her, (O, TA,)
by words in the next but one of the preceding verses. (O.) [See also another reading voce firogN; and another, voce furugN.] And it is said in a form of prayer, Aall~`hum~a A_in~iY A^asoA^aluka AlEayo$i Alr~aAfigi waAlmaAla AlfaAriga [O God, I ask of Thee ample, or abundant, and pleasant, or good, means of subsistence, and cattle free from labour]. (TA.) And one says, fulaAnN faArigN ma$oguwlN, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is devoted to that which is unprofitable. (TA in art. $gl.) And h`*aA kalaAmN faArigN (tropical:) [This is empty talk or language]. (TA.)

A^aforagu * [More, and most, empty &c.: and more, and most, free from business &c.]. A^aforagu mino fuw^aAdi A^um~i muwsaY [More void than the heart, or mind, of the mother of Moses] is a prov. (Meyd. [See faArigN, latter half.]) See also another prov., voce Haj~aAmN. -A2- Also i. q. faArigN, q. v.: (O, K:) fem. farogaA='u: see fariygN.

maforagN *
A place of pouring out or forth: (O, TA:) and [particularly] the part of the leathern bucket that is next to the fore part of the wateringtrough. (TA.) See farogN, second sentence. -A2- Also i. q. sylAn [app. sayalaAnN i. e. The flowing of water &c.; as an inf. n. of fariga said of water]. (TA.)

dirohamN muforagN *
A dirhem [cast, i. e.] poured into a mould; not maDoruwb [coined or minted]. (TA.) And HaloqapN muforagapN A ring that is solid (S, O, K, TA) in the sides [that compose the round], (S, O,) and [continuous,] not cut. (TA.) One says, humo kaA@loHaloqapi Almuforagapi laA yudoraY A^ayona TarafaAhaA [They are like the solid and continuous ring, of which it is not known where are the two ends]: (A, TA:) a prov., applied to a company of men united in words and action. (TA in art. Hlq.) -A2- muforagN is also an inf. n. of A^aforagahu [q. v.]. (O.)

musotaforigapN * A she-camel having much milk. (O, K. [See also firaAgN.]) ― -b2- And musotaforigN (tropical:) A horse that does not reserve aught of his run [i. e. of his power of running, for the time of need; that exhausts his power thereof]. (O, K, TA.)

farofaxN * (S, A, L, K) and ↓ farofaxapN, (L,) [the former app. a coll. gen. n., and the latter the n. un., Purslane, or garden purslane;] the herb called Albaqolapu AlHamoqaA='u, (S, A, L,) which does not grow in Nejd, (L,) also called farofiynN, (S, A,) i. q. rijolapN: (S, L, K:) an arabicized word, from the Pers. ParoPahon, which signifies “ broad-winged. ” (AHn, L, K.) ― -b2- Also, the former, The kaEaAbir [which are things that are taken forth, or picked out, and thrown away, in the clearing] of wheat. (K.)
farofaxapN * : see the preceding paragraph.

1 faraqa bayona Al$~ayoy^ayoni * , (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, *) aor.
faruqa , (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) and in one dial.
fariqa , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. farogN and furoqaAnN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the latter of which has a more intensive signification, (TA,) He made a separation, or a distinction, or difference, (Msb, K, TA,) between the two things, (K, * TA,) or between the parts of the two things: (Msb:) relating alike to objects of sight and to objects of mental perception: (TA:) IAar, by exs. that he mentions, makes it to relate particularly to objects of the mind, such as sayings; and ↓ fr~q, to persons, or material things: (Msb: [and it is stated in the Mgh that the same distinction is mentioned by Az:]) others, however, state that the two verbs are syn.; but that the latter has an intensive signification. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [v. 28], faA@foruqo bayonanaA wabayona A@loqawomi AlfaAsiqiyna [Therefore decide Thou, or make Thou a distinction, between us and the unrighteous people]: accord. to one reading, faA@foriqo. (Msb, TA.) fiyhaA yuforaqu kul~u A^amorK HakiymK, in the Kur [xliv. 3], means [Wherein] is made distinct [every firm decree]: (Lth, TA:) or is decided; (O, K, TA;) thus expl. by Katádeh. (O, TA.) And in the phrase waqurA=nFA faraqonaAhu, (S, O, K, TA,) in the same [xvii. 107], (S, O, TA,) by faraqonaAhu is meant We have made it distinct, (S, O, K, TA,) and rendered it free from defect, (O, K, TA,) and explained the ordinances therein: (TA:) but some read ↓ far~aqonaAhu, meaning We have sent it down in sundry portions, in a number of days. (S, TA.) waA_i*o faraqonaA bikumu A@lobaHora, (O, K, TA,) in the Kur [ii. 47], (O, TA,) means And when we clave because of you the sea; i. q. falaqonaAhu: (O, K, TA:) another reading, ↓ far~aqonaA, meaning we divided into several portions, is mentioned by IJ; but this is unusual. (TA.) It is also said that Alfaroqu is for rectification; and ↓ Alt~aforiyqu, for vitiation: and IJ says that diyonahumo ↓ A_in~a A@l~a*iyna far~aquwA, in the Kur [vi. 160, and the like occurs in xxx. 31], means Verily those who have divided their religion into sundry parts, and dismembered it, and have disagreed respecting it among themselves: but that some read faraquwA diyonahumo, without teshdeed, meaning, have severed their religion from the other religions [app. by taking it in part, or parts, therefrom]; or this, he says, may mean the same as the former reading, for sometimes faEala has the same meaning as faE~ala. (TA.) IJ also says that faraqa lahu Eani Al$~aYo'i signifies He made the thing distinct, or plain, to him. (TA.) ― -b2- faraqa Al$~aEora biAlmu$oTi, aor.
faruqa and
fariqa , inf. n. faroqN, He separated his hair with the comb: and raA^osahu biAlmu$oTi ↓ far~aqa, inf. n. taforiyqN, He separated the hair of his head with the comb. (TA.) [And it is implied in a trad. cited in the O and TA that faraqahu signifies the same as the latter of the two phrases in the next preceding sentence.] -A2- faraqa lahu AlT~ariyqu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. furuwqN, (K,) The road presented itself to him divided into two roads: (S, O, K, TA:) or [it means] an affair presented itself, or occurred, to him, and he knew the mode, or manner, thereof: (TA, as from the K: [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K:]) and hence, in a trad. of I'Ab, faraqa liY raA^oYN An idea, or opinion, appeared [or occurred] to me: (TA:) [or] one says, faraqa liY h`*aA AlA^amoru, inf. n. furuwqN, This affair became, or has become, distinct, apparent, or manifest, to me: and hence the saying, faA_ino lamo yuforuqo liloA_imaAmi raA^oYN [And if an idea, or an opinion, appear not, or occur not, to the Imám]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- faraqato said of a she-camel, and of a she-ass, (S, O, K,) aor.
faruqa , (S, O,) inf. n. furuwqN, She, being taken with the pains of parturition, went away at random in the land. (S, O, K.) -A3- faraqa, (O, K,) aor.
faruqa , (K,) He voided dung; syn. *araqa [which is said of a bird, and sometimes of a man]. (O, K. [See also A^aforaqa.]) -A4- And He possessed a firoq [q. v.] (O, K, TA) of sheep or goats: (O, TA:) accord. to the K, of date-stones with which to feed camels: but the former explanation is the right. (TA.) -A5- faraqahaA, (K,) inf. n. faroqN, (TA,) He fed her (i. e. a woman) with fariyqap [q. v.]; as also ↓ AfrqhA, (K,) inf. n. A_iforaAqN. (TA.) -A6- fafaraqotuhu ↓ faAraqaniY, aor.
faruqa , [He vied with me in fear and] I exceeded him in fear. (Lh, L, TA.) ― -b2- See also 2, last sentence. -A7- fariqa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faraqa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. faraqN, (S, O, Msb,) He feared; or was, or became, in fear, afraid, or frightened. (S, O, Msb, K.) You say, fariqotu minoka [I feared thee, or was in fear of thee]: (S, O, Msb: *) but you should not say, fariqotuka: (S, O:) Sb [however] mentions fariqahu, suppressing mino. (TA.) And you say also, fariqa Ealayohi [He feared for him]. (TA.) -A8- And fariqa, aor.
faraqa , He entered into a wave, [which is termed firoqN,] and dived therein. (K.) -A9- And the same verb accord. to the K, but accord. to Sgh [in the O] it seems, from the context to be faraqa, (TA,) He drank (O, K) the measure called faraq, (O,) or with the faraq. (K, TA.)

2 fr~qhu * , inf. n. taforiyqN and taforiqapN, (S, O, K,) He separated it [into several, or many, portions]; disunited it [i. e. a thing, or a collection of things]; or dispersed, or dissipated, it; or did so much [or greatly or widely]; syn. bad~adahu. (K.) And fr~q bayona AlA^a$oyaA='i [He made, or caused, a separation &c., or much, or a wide, separation, &c., between the things]. (Mgh.) [And fiyhimo fr~qhu and Ealayohimo He scattered, or distributed, it among them, and to them.] See 1, former half, in five places. It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, far~iquwA Eani Almaniy~api waA@joEaluwA Alr~aA^osa raA^osayoni, (Mgh, O, *) meaning Separate ye your cattle by way of preservation from death, [and make the one head two head,] by buying two animals with the price of one, that, when one dies, the second may remain. (Mgh, O.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the poor-rate, laA yufar~aqu bayona mujotamiEK walaA yujomaEu bayona mufotariqK There shall be no separating what is put together, nor shall
there be a putting together what is separate. (TA. [The reason is, that by either of these acts, in the case of cattle, the amount of the poor-rate may be diminished.]) yufar~iquwna bihi bayona A@lomaro'i wazawojihi [in the Kur ii. 96, meaning Whereby they might dissolve, break up, discompose, derange, disorganize, disorder, or unsettle, the state of union subsisting between the man and his wife, in respect of affairs and of the expression of opinion, or, briefly, whereby they might cause division and dissension between the man and his wife,] is from Altaforiyqu as meaning ta$otiytu Al$~amoli waAlkalimapi. (El-Isbahánee, TA.) One says also, fr~q AlA^amora, meaning $at~atahu [i. e. He discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, the state of affairs]. (S in art. $t.) And fr~q EalayonaA AlkalaAma [lit. He scattered speech (app. meaning he jabbered) at us, or against us]. (K in art. bq: see R. Q. 1 in that art.) In the saying in the Kur [ii. 130 and iii. 78], laA nufar~iqu bayona A^aHadK minohumo [We will not make a distinction between any of them], the verb is allowably made to relate to AHd because this word [in negative phrases] imports a pl. meaning. (TA. [See p. 27, 3rd col.]) See, again, 1, near the middle. -A2- fr~qhu, (O, TA,) inf. n. taforiyqN, (O, K, TA,) also signifies He made him to fear, or be afraid; put him in fear; or frightened him: (O, K, * TA:) and minohu ↓ A^aforaqotuhu I made him to fear, or be afraid of, him, or it: (Msb:) and Lh mentions AlSabiY~a ↓ faraqotu as meaning I frightened the boy, or child; but ISd says, I think it to be far~aqotu. (TA.)

3 fArqhu * , inf. n. mufaAriqapN and firaAqN, (S, Msb, TA,) He separated himself from him, or it; or left, forsook, or abandoned, him, or it: or he forsook, or abandoned, him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him: syn. baAyanahu; (TA;) and qaATaEahu, and faArazahu; (A in art. frz;) and tarakahu. (Msb in art. trk.) And fArq A@moraA^atahu He separated himself from his wife. (TA.) ― -b2- faAraqotu fulaAnFA mino HisaAbiY EalaY ka*aA waka*aA I released such a one from my reckoning with him on such and such terms agreed upon by both: and so SaAdarotuhu EalaY ka*aA waka*aA. (TA.) And fuwriqa EalaY maAlK yuw^ad~iyhi He (an agent) was released from being reckoned with on the condition of his paying certain property for which he became responsible. (TA in art. Sdr.) -A2- faAraqaniY fafaraqotuhu: see 1, last quarter.

4 AfrqwA A_ibilahumo *
They left their camels in the place of pasture, and did not assist them in bringing forth, nor have them got with young. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b2- And Afrq ganamahu He made, or caused, his sheep, or goats, to stray; and neglected them, or caused them to become lost, or to perish. (TA.) ― -b3- And Afrq He lost a portion of his sheep or goats. (IKh, TA.) ― -b4- And His sheep, or goats, became a fariyqap [q. v.]. (IKh, TA.) -A2- Afrq He recovered; (Lth, As, Az, S, O, K;) or recovered, but not completely; (As, O, K;) to which IKh adds, quickly; (TA;) i. e., a sick person from (mino) his sickness; (As, Az, S, O, K;) and one fevered from his fever; (As, S;) and one smitten with the plague: (Lth, TA:) or (K) it is not said except in the case of a disease that does not attack one more than once, as the small-pox, (O, K,) and the measles. (O.) ― -b2- Afrqt She (a camel) had a return of some of her milk. (O, K.) -A3- Afrq said of a man, and of a bird, and of a beast of prey, and of a fox, He voided dung, or thin dung. (Lh, TA. [See also 1, last quarter.]) ― -b2- And Afrqhu He, or it, caused him to void dung; syn. A^a*oraqahu. (K. [But I do not find A*rq mentioned except as an intrans. v.]) See also firoqapN, last sentence. -A4- AfrqhA: see 1, last quarter. -A5- A^aforaqotuhu minohu: see 2, last sentence.

5 tfr~q * , inf. n. tafar~aqN (O, K) and tifir~aAqN, (K, TA,) with two kesrehs, but accord. to the “ Nawádir ” of Lh taforiyqN, (TA,) [and in the CK taforAq,] It was, or became, separated, or disunited: or separated much, or greatly, or widely, or into several, or many, portions; or dispersed, or dissipated: contr. of tajam~aEa: and ↓ Aftrq signifies the same: (K, TA:) and so does ↓ Anfrq: (TA:) all are quasi-pass. of far~aqotuhu: (S, * TA:) [or rather the second and third have the former of the meanings mentioned above: and tfr~q has the latter of those meanings:] or ↓ AifotaraqaA is said of two sayings, as quasi-pass. of faraqotu bayonahumaA: and tafar~aqaA, of two men, as quasi-pass. of far~aqotu bayonahamaA: (Mgh, * Msb, TA:) so says IAar: (Msb:) [but] one says also, Aftrq Alqawomu [The party, or company of men, became separated; or they separated themselves:] (Msb:) and Esh-Sháfi'ee has used ↓ AifotaraqaA as relating to two persons buying and selling; (Msb, TA;) and so have Ahmad [Ibn-Hambal] and Aboo-Haneefeh and Málik and others. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Albay~aEaAni biAlxiyaAri maA yatafar~aqaA i. e. [The buyer and seller have the option to annul their contract] as long as they have not become separated bodily; (Mgh, Msb;) originally, maA lamo yatafar~aqo A^abodaAnuhumaA; for this is the proper meaning. (Msb.) tafar~aqato bihimu AlT~uruqu [properly The roads became separate with them,] means every one of them went one [separate] way. (TA.) [And one says, tfr~qt AlA^agoSaAnu (S in art. $*b, &c.,) The branches were, or became, or grew out, apart, one from another; divaricated; diverged; forked; straggled; or spread widely and dispersedly. And tfr~q A^amoruhu His affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, so that he considered what might be its issues, or results, saying at one time, I will do thus, and at another time, I will do thus: see A^ajomaEa; and $at~a: and ↓ Aftrq signifies the same: see an ex. voce fa$aA, in art. f$w. And tfr~qt kalimatuhumo (K voce $aAla, in art. $wl,) Their expression of opinion was, or became, discordant: and tfr~qt A=raAw^uhumo Their opinions were, or became, so.]

6 tfArqwA *
They separated themselves, one from another; or left, forsook, or abandoned, one another. (TA.)

7 Anfrq * , of which munofaraqN may be an inf. n. [like AinofiraAqN], as well as a n. of place, It was, or became, separated, or divided. (O, K.) See also 5. [Hence,] Anfrq Alfajoru i. q. Ainofalaqa [The dawn broke]. (TA.)
8 Aftrq * : see 5, first sentence, in three places: and also in the last sentence but one.

faroqN * [is originally an inf. n.: but is often used as a simple subst. meaning A distinction, or difference, between two things. ― -b2- Hence,] The line [or division] in the hair of the head: (K: [see also maforaqN:]) or, as some say, the part, of the head, extending from the side of the forehead to the spiral curl upon the crown: an ex. occurs in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb cited voce maTorabN. (TA.) ― -b3- [And app. A blaze on a horse's forehead. (See an ex. voce muEotadilN.)] ― -b4- And [hence, perhaps,] one says, baAnato fiY qa*aAlihi furuwqN mina Al$~ayobi i. e. A^awoDaAHN [app. meaning There appeared in the back of his head portions of white, or hoary, hair, distinct from the rest]. (TA.) ― -b5- One says also of the female comber and dresser of the hair, tamo$uiTu ka*aA waka*aA faroqFA i. e. [She combs and dresses the hair] with such and such a mode or manner [app. of combing and dressing or of dividing]. (L. [But the last word, which seems to be in this case an inf. n., is there written without any vowel-sign.]) -A2- Also A certain bird or flying thing; (TaAy^irN O, K;) not mentioned by AHát in “ the Book of Birds. ” (O, TA.) -A3- And Flax. (K.) -A4- See also faraqN, in nine places.

Alfuroqu * : see AlfuroqaAnu. ― -b2- It also signifies A certain vessel with which one measures. (TA. [See also faraqN.]) ― -b3- And [it is said that] AlfuroqaAni signifies qdHAn mftrqAn [app. meaning Two separate bowls, or milking-vessels, supposing the former word to be qadaHaAni; the latter word being mufotariqaAni]. (TA. [This is app. said in explanation of furoqaAni ending a verse in which it means “ milkingvessels: ” but it is said in the S, and in one place in the TA, that it is in that instance pl. of faroqN or faraqN, q. v.])

firoqN *
A piece, or portion, that is split from a thing, or cleft therefrom; (S, O, K;) whence its usage in the Kur xxvi. 63: (S, O:) and a portion of anything (K, TA) when it is separated; and the pl. is firaqN: (TA:) or a portion that is separated, or dispersed, of a thing; and thus it is said to mean in the Kur ubi suprá; and the pl. is A^aforaAqN, like A^aHomaAlN as pl. of HimolN. (Msb.) See also firoqapN. ― -b2- Also A great flock or herd, of sheep or goats: (S, O, K:) and (as some say, TA) of the bovine kind: or of gazelles: or of sheep, or goats, only: or of straying sheep or goats; as also ↓ fariyqN, (K, TA,) and ↓ fariyqapN: (TA:) or less than a hundred, (K, TA,) of sheep or goats. (TA.) firoqaAni mino TayorK SawaAf~a, occurring in a trad., in which the second and third chapters of the Kur-án are likened thereto, (L,) means Two flocks [of birds expanding their wings without moving them in flight]. (L, TA: but the first word, in both, is without any vowel-sign.) See, again, firoqapN. ― -b3- And A set of boys. (O, K.) An
Arab of the desert said of some boys whom he saw, h`w^ulaA='i firoqu sawo'K [These are a bad set of boys]. (O.) ― -b4- And A distinct quantity of date-stones with which the camel is fed. (K.) ― -b5- [And app. Any feed for one's beast: see an ex. in art. jl, conj. 4.] -A2- Also A mountain. (IAar, O, K.) And A [hill, or mountain, or the like, such as is termed] haDobap. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b2- And A wave, billow, or surge. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b3- And Alfiroqu is the name applied by the Arabs to The star [a] upon the right shoulder of Cepheus. (Kzw.)

faraqN *
Wideness of the space between the two central incisors, (IKh, S, O, K, TA,) of a man: (TA:) and likewise between the two toe-nails of the camel. (Yaakoob, S, O, K, TA.) And A division in the Eurof [or comb] of the cock: and likewise in the forelock, and in the beard, of a man: (S, O, K:) pl. A^aforaAqN. (S, O.) And sparseness, or a scattered state, of the plants, or herbage, of a land. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- In a horse, The state of the hips when one of them is more prominent than the other; which is disapproved: (S, O, K, TA:) or a deficiency in one of the thighs, in comparison with the other: or a deficiency in one of the hips. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The dawn: or Alfaraqu signifies falaqu AlS~uboHi: (K:) or what has broken of the bright gleam of dawn; of the dawn that rises and spreads, filling the horizon with its whiteness; (maA A@nofalaqa mino Eamuwdi AlS~uboHi [which is one of the explanations of Alfalaqu in the K];) because it has become separated from the blackness of the night: (TA:) one says, A^aboyanu mino faraqi AlS~uboHi a dial. var. of falaqi AlS~uboHi [i. e. More distinct than what has broken of the bright gleam of dawn]. (S, O, Msb, * TA.) -A2- It is also the inf. n. of fariqa [q. v.: when used as a simple subst., signifying Fear, or fright]. (S, O, Msb.) -A3- Also, and ↓ faroqN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the latte accord. to the usage of the relaters of traditions, (Az, Mgh, O, Msb, TA,) but the former accord. to the usage of the Arabs, (Az, Mgh, O, * TA,) or the former is the more chaste (K, TA) accord. to Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà and Khálid Ibn-Yezeed, (TA,) A certain vessel, (T, Mgh, O, Msb,) a measure of capacity, (S, O, K, TA,) of large size, (TA,) well known, (S,) in El-Medeeneh, (S, Msb, K,) holding three A=SuE [a pl. of SaAEN], (Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA,) or, (K, [app. referring to ↓ faroqN only,]) which is the same quantity, sixteen pints, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, * TA,) i. e. twelve times the quantity termed mud~ by the people of El-Hijáz: (TA:) or, accord. to El-Kutabee, the ↓ faroq is sixteen pints, and the SAE is one third of the faroq; but the faraq is eighty pints: or the ↓ faroq, he adds, is, as some say, four pints: (Mgh:) or it is four A^arobaAE [pl. of ruboEN, q. v.]; (K, TA;) thus accord. to AHát: and IAth says, the faraq is said to be five A^aqosaAT; [or six; (see qisoTN;)] the qisoT being the half of a SAE: but the ↓ faroq is a hundred and twenty pints: (TA:) in the “ Nawádir ” of Hishám, on the authority of [the Imám] Mohammad, the ↓ faroq is said to be thirty-six pints; but [Mtr says] this I have not found in any of the lexicons in my possession; and so what is said in the Moheet, that it is sixty pints: (Mgh:) the pl. is furoqaAnN, (S, Mgh, O, K, TA,) which is of ↓ faroqN and of faraqN; (S, Mgh, O, TA;) and A^aforuqN occurs in a trad. as a pl. [of pauc.] of faraqN meaning the measure thus called. (TA.) 'Áïsheh is related to have said that she and the Prophet used to wash themselves from a vessel called the ↓ faroq. (O, Msb.) [In a verse of which a hemistich is cited in the S and TA, the pl. furoqaAn is used as meaning Milking-vessels. (See also Alfuroqu.) Respecting a modern signification of ↓ faroq (A bale, or sack, of merchandise), see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., iii., 378-9 and 382.]
faruqN * : see faruwqapN, in two places.

fariqN * is applied to plants, or herbage, (nabotN,) as meaning [In a sparse, or scattered, state; or] small, not covering the ground: (AHn, K, TA:) or (K) fariqapN is applied to land, (A^aroDN,) meaning of which the plants, or herbage, are in a sparse, or scattered, state; (S, O, K, TA;) not contiguous: (S, O, TA:) thus used, it is a possessive epithet, having no verb. (TA.) -A2- See also faruwqapN, in two places.

furoqapN * the subst. from faAraqahu; (S, MA, * TA;) or from Aifotaraqa, (Msb,) [i. e.] a quasi-inf. n. used in the sense of AifotiraAqN; (TA;) signifying Separation, disunion, or abandonment; (MA, KL, PS;) and ↓ faraAqN is syn. therewith, whence the reading [in the Kur xviii. 77], h`*aA faraAqu bayoniY wabayonika [This shall be the separation of my and thy union]; and so is ↓ firaAqN, (O, * K, TA,) which [is an inf. n. of fArqh, and], in the Kur lxxv. 28, means the time of the quitting of the present world by death. (TA.)

firoqapN *
A TaAy^ifap [or party, portion, division, sect, or distinct body or class,] of men, (S, O, Msb, K,) and of other things; as also ↓ firoqN; (Msb;) and so, accord. to IB, ↓ fariyqN: (TA: [but see this last word:]) [and a separate herd or the like of cattle:] pl. firaqN (O, Msb, K) and A^aforaAqN (S, O, K) is pl. of firaqN (O, K) and A^afaAriyqu is pl. of A^aforaAqN, (S, O, K,) and A^afaAriqapN occurs in poetry; (O, K;) or A^afaAriyqu may be of the class of A^abaATiylu, a pl. without a sing. (O, TA.) ― -b2- Also A portion of a thing in a state of dispersion; and so ↓ firoqN and ↓ fariyqN. (L, TA.) -A2- And A skin that is full [of milk], that cannot be agitated to make butter Hat~aY A^aYo yu*oraqa ↓ yuforaqa [app. a tropical phrase meaning until it is made to void some of its contents]. (K.)

furoqaAnN * , originally an inf. n. (Msb. [See 1, first sentence.]) Anything that makes a separation, or distinction, between truth and falsity. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) AlfuroqaAnu signifies The Kur-án; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Alfuroqu. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And The Book of the Law revealed to Moses, (Az, O, K,) in which a distinction is made between that which is allowable and that which is forbidden. (O.) ― -b4- And Proof, evidence, or demonstration. (O, K.) ― -b5- And The time a little before daybreak: (AA, O, K:) or the dawn. (O, K.) One says, TalaEa AlfuroqaAnu [The dawn rose]. (O.) ― -b6- And Aid, or victory: (IDrd, O, K:) so, accord. to IDrd, in the phrase yawoma AlfuroqaAni in the Kur [viii. 42]: (O:) or by this phrase is meant The day of Bedr, (O, K,) in which a distinction was made between right and wrong. (O.) ― -b7- And The cleaving of the sea: so it means [accord. to some] in the Kur ii. 50. (O, K.) ― -b8- And Boys: (O, K:) such the people of the olden time used to make witnesses [in law-suits or the like]. (O.) -A2- It is also pl. of faroqN (S, M, O, K) and of faraqN. (S, Mgh, O.)
faraAqN * and firaAqN: see furoqapN.
faruwqN * : see faruwqapN, in two places: -A2- and A^aforaqu, last sentence but two.

fariyqN *
A TaAy^ifap [or party, &c.,] (S, Msb, K) more in number, (S, K, *) or larger, (Msb,) than a firoqap: (S, Msb, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aforiqapN and [of mult.] A^aforiqaA='u and furuwqN (K, TA) and furuqN: (CK:) see also firoqapN, in two places; and see firoqN: AHei says that it is itself a quasi-pl. n., applied to few and to many: 'Abd-el-Hakeem, that it occurs in the sense of a TaAy^ifap [or party, &c.], and in the sense of a single man: and El-Isbahánee, that it signifies a company of men apart from others [i. e. a party of men]: (MF, TA:) or [simply] a company [of men]. (O.) ― -b2- And A separator of himself. (IB, TA.) Hence the saying, huwa A^asoraEu mino fariyqi Alxayoli i. e. [He is swifter] than the outgoer, or outrunner, of the horses. (TA.) ― -b3- niy~apN farayqN means mufar~iqN [i. e. A place to which one purposes journeying that separates widely]: a poet says,
A^aHaq~N A^an~a jiyoratanaA A@sotaqal~uwA
faniy~atunaA waniy~atuhumo fariyqu
[Is it true that our neighbours have gone away, so that the place to which we purpose journeying and the place to which they purpose journeying are such as separate widely]: he says fariyq in like manner as one applies [the epithet] SadiyqN to a company of men. (Sb, TA.) -A2- Also A palm-tree (naxolapN) in which is [app. meaning out of which grows] another. (AA, AHn, O, TA.)

faruwqapN * , applied to a man and to a woman, (IDrd, S, O, K,) and having no pl., (S, O,) and ↓ far~uwqapN, applied to a man (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) and to a woman, (K,) and ↓ faAruwqapN, applied to a man (O, K,) and to a woman, or, as epithets applied to a man, faruwqapN, (K,) and ↓ far~uwqapN, (CK,) and ↓ faAruwqapN, and ↓ faruwqN, (K,) but this last is also applied to a woman, (IB, TA,) and ↓ far~uwqN, and ↓ faAruwqN, One who fears much, or vehemently; [or rather the epithets with the affix p are doubly intensive, meaning one who fears very much;]
(S, * O, * K, TA;) and ↓ fariqN and ↓ faruqN signify the same as the other epithets above; or ↓ faruqN signifies fearing, or fearful, by nature; and ↓ fariqN, [simply,] fearing a thing. (K.) It is said in a prov., rub~a EajalapK tahabu rayovFA warub~a faruwqapK yudoEaY layovFA warub~a gayovK lamo yakuno gayovFA [Many an act of haste causes (lit. gives) slowness, and many a very fearful man is called a lion, and many a collection of clouds has not been productive of rain]: (S, * O:) said by Málik Ibn-'Amr Ibn-Mohallam, when Leyth, his brother, looked hopefully at the clouds from afar, and desired to avail himself of the benefit thereof; whereupon Málik said to him, “ Do not, for I fear for thee some of the troops of the Arabs: ” but he disobeyed him, and journeyed with his family; and he had not stayed [away] a little while when he came [back], and his family had been taken. (O. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 535.]) -A2- And Alfaruwqapu signifies AlHuromapu [meaning Honour, or reputation; or that which one is under an obligation to respect and defend]: (O, K, TA: [in the CK AlHuzomapu:]) so Sh was told: and [so, app., ↓ Alfaruwqu, for] he cites as an ex.,
maA zaAla Eanohu Humoquhu wamuwquhu
waAll~uw^omu Hat~aY A@notuhikato faruwqahu
[His foolishness and his stupidity quitted him not, and meanness, so that his honour, &c., was violated]. (O, TA.) -A3- And The fat of the kidneys: (O, K:) so says A'Obeyd, on the authority of El-Umawee; but Sh disallowed this meaning, and knew it not. (O, TA.)

fariyqapN * : see firoqN. ― -b2- Also Some (S, O, K) one or two or three (S, O) of a flock or herd, of sheep or goats, becoming separate therefrom, (S, O, K,) being shut out from the rest by the like of a mountain or a space of sand or some other thing, as is said in the “ Kitáb Leysa, ” (TA,) and going away, (S, O, K,) in the “ Kitáb Leysa ” straying, (TA,) in the night, from the main aggregate. (S, O, K,) -A2- And Dates cooked with fenugreek (Hulobap), for the woman in the state following childbirth: (S, O, K:) or fenugreek (Hulobap) cooked with grains (Hubuwb) [or kernels?], (O, K, TA,) such as maHolabo [q. v.], and byr [app. a mistranscription], and other things, (TA,) for her: (K, TA:) or, accord. to IKh, a soup that is made for him who is affected with a chronic disease, or emaciated by disease so as to be at the point of death. (TA.) [See also faliyqapN.]
far~uwqN * : see faruwqapN, first sentence.
far~uwqapN * : see faruwqapN, first sentence, in two places.

faAriqN * [act. part. n. of faraqa, q. v.]. AlfaAriqaAtu, mentioned in the Kur lxxvii. 4, means Those angels that descend with what makes a distinction between truth and falsity: (Fr, O, K:) or that distinguish between that which is allowable and that which is forbidden: (Th, TA:) or that make a distinction between things according as God has commanded them.
