(Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- Also, faAriqN, A she-camel, and a she-ass, in consequence of her being taken with the pains of parturition, going away at random in the land; (S, O, K;) and so faAriqapN, as in the “ Mufradát: ” or a she-camel that separates herself from her mate, and brings forth alone: or a she-camel that runs (ta$otad~u), and then casts her young one by reason of the pain that befalls her; thus expl. by IAar: (TA:) pl. fawaAriqu and fur~aqN (S, O, K) and furuqN (K) and fur~aAqN, which is thus used by El-Aashà, applied to she-camels, and ↓ mafaAriyqu is [an irreg. pl.] likewise applied to she-camels as syn. with fawaAriqu. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, as being likened to such a she-camel, applied to a cloud (saHaAbapN) as meaning (tropical:) Apart from the other clouds; (S, O, K;) cut off from the main aggregate of the clouds: (ISd, TA:) or an isolated cloud, that will not break its promise [of giving rain], and sometimes preceded by thunder and lighting: (TA:) thus applied, also, having for pl. fawaAriqu and fur~aqN [&c.]. (O.)

faAruwqN * A thing that makes a distinction between two things: and a man who makes a distinction between truth and falsity: (TA:) or one who makes a distinction between affairs, or cases. (Msb.) AlfaAruwqu is an appellation that was given to 'Omar Ibn-El-Khattáb, (S, O, K, TA,) the second of the Khaleefehs; (TA;) because a distinction was made by him between truth and falsity. (Ibráheem El-Harbee, O, K, * TA.) ― -b2- tiroyaAqN faAruwqN, (O,) or Alt~iroyaAqu AlfaAruwqu, (K,) The most approved sort of theriac, (O, K,) and the most esteemed of compounds; because it makes a distinction between disease and health: (K:) called by the vulgar tiroyaAqa faAruwqiY~. (TA.) -A2- See also faruwqapN, first sentence.
faAruwqapN * : see faruwqapN, first sentence, in two places.

A^aforaqu * , applied to a man, Having a wide space between the two central incisors: (IKh, TA:) [or] i. q. A^afolaju [app. as meaning the same, or having a similar meaning]: (K, TA: [but the CK has AlA^afolaHu instead of AlA^afolaju:]) or, accord. to Lth, the A^aforaq is like the A^afolaj, except that the Aflj is such as has been rendered so, and the Afrq is such naturally. (O, TA.) And A camel having a wide space between the two toe-nails. (Yaakoob, TA.) And Having a wide space between the buttocks. (TA.) And A he-goat having a wide space between his horns. (IKh, TA.) And A ram, or he-goat, having a wide space between his testicles: and [the fem.] faroqaA='u a ewe, or she-goat, having a wide space between the two teats. (Lth, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- A camel having two humps. (TA.) ― -b3- A man whose forelock is as though it were divided; and in like manner, whose beard is so. (S, O, K. *) A cock whose Eurof [or comb] is divided: (S, O, K:) and (accord. to Lth, O) a white cock: (O, K:) or, as some say, having two combs (*uw Eurofayoni). (O.) ― -b4- A horse having one of the hips more prominent than the other; which is disapproved: (S, K, TA:) or having a deficiency in one of his thighs, in comparison with the other: or having a deficiency in one of the hips: or, accord. to the T, a beast having one of his elbows prominent, and the other depressed. (TA.) And A horse having one testicle. (Lth, O, K, TA.) The pl. is furoqN. (TA, in which it is here mentioned: also mentioned in the K after A^aforaqu as applied to a ram or he-goat: in the CK [erroneously] furuqN) And ↓ faruwqN applied to a horse signifies the same as A^aforaqu. (O, TA.) ― -b5- TariyqN A^aforaqu A road that is distinct, apparent, or manifest. (TA.) And sayolN A^aforaqu A torrent that is as though it were the firoq [app. as meaning wave, billow, or surge]. (TA.)

tafaAriyqu * [Sundry, or separate, or scattered, portions or things: and sundry times]. You say, A^axa*otu Haq~iY minohu biAlt~afaAriyqi (S, O, K, * TA) i. e. [I took my right, or due, from him in sundry portions: or] at sundry times. (TA.) And Dam~a tafaAriyqa mataAEihi i. e. [He put together] what were scattered [of his household goods, or furniture and utensils]. (TA.)
A_in~aka xayorN mino tafaAriyqi AlEaSaA
[Verily thou art better than the several portions of the staff], (S, O, K,) which is a prov., (O,) was said by a poet, (S,) or by Ghaneeyeh, (O,) or Ghuneiyeh, (K,) El-Aarábeeyeh, to her son; for he was evil in disposition, [EAzimFA in the CK is a mistake for EaArimFA,] very mischievous, notwithstanding his weakness, (O, K,) and slenderness of bone; (O;) and he assaulted one day a young man, who thereupon cut off his nose, and his mother took the mulct for it; so her condition became good after abasing poverty; then he assaulted another, who cut off his ear; and another, who cut off his lip; and his mother took the mulct for each; and when she saw the goodness of her condition, (O, K,) the camels and the sheep or goats and the household goods that she had acquired, (O,) she said thus: (O, K:) for from the staff (S, O, K) when it is broken (S) is made a saAjuwr [q. v.], and from this are made tent-pegs, and from the tent-peg is made an EiraAn [q. v.], and from this are made tawaAdK [pl. of tawodiyapN, q. v.]. (S, O, K.)

maforaqN * (S, O, K) and maforiqN (S, O, Msb, K) The middle of the head; (S, O, K;) the place where the hair of the head is separated: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. mafaAriqu; which is used also in the sense of the sing., as though the sing. applied to every part thereof: (S, O:) one says, $aAbato mafaAriqu raA^osihi [meaning The place (lit. places) of the separation of the hair of his head became white, or hoary]. (Mgh voce *akarN.) [See also faroqN.] ― -b2- Also The place, of a road, where another road branches off: (S, O, Msb, K:) both words are used in this sense likewise: (S, O, K: *) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b3- And [hence] one says, waqafotuhu EalaY mafaAriqi AlHadiyvi (tropical:) [I made him to know] the modes, or manners, [of the narrative, or discourse,] or the manifest, plain, or obvious, modes or manners [thereof]. (TA.)

muforiqN * A she-camel whose young one has become separated from her, (S, O, K, TA,) as some say, (TA,) by death: (S, O, K, TA:) pl. ↓ mafaAriyqN. (TA. [Thus in my original, not mafaAriqu.]) ― -b2- And A she-camel that tarries two years, or three, without conceiving. (TA.) ― -b3- And A she-camel having a return of some of her milk. (TA.) ― -b4- And Anyone recovering from his disease. (Lh, TA.) ― -b5- And Deviating from the right way or course, or from that which is right. (TA.) ― -b6- And muforiqu Aljisomi, (thus accord. to the K, there said to be like muHosinN,) or Aljisomi ↓ mufar~aqu, (thus in the O,) A man (O) having little flesh: or fat, or plump: (O, K:) two contr. meanings. (K.)
mufar~aqu * : see what next precedes.

mufar~iqu * [The disperser of the camels or cattle;] the [small, stinking beast called] ZaribaAni; because when it emits a noiseless wind from the anus among the cattle, they disperse themselves. (S, O, K.)
mafaAriyqu * : see muforiqN: ― -b2- and faAriqN, latter half.
munofaraqN * is a n. of place, as well as an inf. n. [of Ainofaraqa]: (O, K:) and is used by Ru-beh as meaning A place where a road divides. (O.)

faroqadN *
A calf: (S:) accord. to Aboo-Kheyreh, after he has become about two months old: (TA voce EijolN:) or the calf of a wild cow; as also ↓ furoquwdN: (IAar, O, L, K:) fem. faroqadapN. (L.) ― -b2- And Alfaroqadu (O, L, K) and ↓ Alfuroquwdu (O, K) (assumed tropical:) The asterism (najom) by which one directs his course (O, K) by sea and by land; (O;) two stars [b and y of Ursa Minor]; (L, K;) also called (in poetry, O, K, [and generally in prose,]) AlfaroqadaAni; (O, L, K;) thus in a verse cited voce A_il~aA; (O;) they are two stars near the quTob [or pole-star]; (S, L;) two stars that never set, revolving round the jadoY [or pole-star], both in Ursa Minor; (L;) the two bright stars of the four that form the angles of a quadrilateral figure in Ursa Minor; (Kzw;) also called by the Arabs AlfaraAqidu [which is the pl. of Alfaroqadu]. (L.) -A2- And faroqadu signifies also A level, or an even, land. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)
furoquwdN * : see above, first and second sentences.

Q. 1 faroqaEa AlA^aSaAbiEa *
i. q. naq~aDahaA, (S, * O, * K, [in copies of the K written naqaDahaA, but correctly with teshdeed, as is shown by what here follows,]) inf. n. faroqaEapN i. q. tanoqiyDN (S, O) and tafoqiyEN, (TA,) [He cracked the joints of his fingers;] i. e. he pressed his fingers so that a sound was heard to proceed from their joints: (TA:) the doing of which is forbidden, (O, TA,) in prayer. (TA. [See also 2 in art. fqE.]) And one says, samiEotu faroqaEapF lirajulK and SaroqaEapF [I heard a cracking of the joints of the fingers of a man]: both signify the same. (TA.) ― -b2- And faroqaEapu He twisted his (a man's, K) neck. (O, K.) -A2- faroqaEa [as an intrans. v.], (O, K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He ran vehemently, (O, K, TA,) going back, or retreating: so in the Tekmileh. (TA.) ― -b2- And firoqaAEN (as an inf. n. of which the verb is faroqaEa, TK) signifies The emitting of wind from the anus with a sound: (O, K:) mentioned by IDrd as from some one or more of the Arabs. (O.) ― -b3- See also faroqaEapN in what next follows.

Q. 2 tafaroqaEato AlA^aSaAbiEu *
The fingers produced a sound or sounds [by their joints' being cracked]; (O;) quasi-pass. of 1 in the first of the senses expl. above; (S, K;) as also ↓ AiforanoqaEat, (K, TA,) inf. n. AiforinoqaAEu and [quasi-inf. n., being app. the inf. n. in this case of furoqiEat,] ↓ faroqaEapN, (TA,) [and this is app. what is meant by its being said that] ↓ AlAiforinoqaAEu is [syn. with] AlfaroqaEapu. (K.) ― -b2- Accord. to IDrd, tafaroquEN signifies The sounding of two things striking against each other. (O.) ― -b3- And tfrqE Alr~ajulu The man drew himself together, or shrank; like taqaroEafa [which is mentioned in the K in the same sense, as also taqarofaEa]. (L, TA.)

Q. 3 A_iforanoqaEa see Q. 2, in two places. ― -b2- AlAiforinoqaAEu also signifies The withdrawing, or removing, and going away, from a thing (Eano $aYo'K); (K;) and the dispersing of itself, or becoming dispersed. (IAth, TA.) AiforanoqiEuwA Ean~iY, a phrase used by 'Eesà Ibn- 'Omar, (S, O,) to people who had congregated about him on an occasion of his having fallen from his ass, (O,) means Withdraw ye, or remove, (S,) or disperse yourselves, (O,) from me, (S,) and go away. (S, O.) And 'Eesà Ibn-'Omar is related to have read, [in the Kur xxxiv. 22,] Hat~aY A_i*aA A@foranoqaEa Eano quluwbihimo; meaning, ku$ifa; [AlfazaEu, or the like, being understood;] but the common reading is fuz~iEa, q. v. (TA.)

AlfuroqaEapa *
The Aisot [here app. meaning anus (see 1)]; (Lth, IAar, K;) of the dial. of ElYemen: (O:) also called AlqurofuEapu. (TA.)

1 farokN * , as expl. by Lth, signifies (O, TA) primarily (TA) One's rubbing, or rubbing and pressing, a thing [with the hand] so that its integument becomes stripped off (O, TA) from its kernel; as, for instance, a [shelled] walnut. (TA.) One says, faraka Als~unobula, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faruka , inf. n. farokN, (S, Msb,) He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the ears of corn (K, TA) with his hand [so that the kernels became divested of their husks]. (S, O, Msb, TA.) And faraka Alv~awoba (S, O, Msb, K) He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the garment (K, TA) with his hand [to remove a soil]. (S, O, Msb, TA.) And faraka AlmaniY~a mina Alv~awobi (Mgh, O, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) He rubbed, (Msb,) or rubbed and pressed, (Mgh,) with his hand, the [dry soil of] sperma, so that it crumbled, and came off from the garment; (Mgh, Msb;) like Hat~ahu: and in like manner AlT~iyna [i. e. the dry mud]. (Msb.) [And faraka Alqamolapa He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the louse, between his finger and thumb, or otherwise, to kill it. (See the pass. part. n., below.)] -A2- farikato zawojahaA, and farikahaA zawojuhaA, aor.
faraka ; (S, O, K;) and farakatohu, and farakahaA, aor.
faruka , but this form of the verb is extr.; (K;) inf. n. firokN (S, O, K) and farokN and furuwkN; (K;) She hated her husband, and her husband hated her; (S, O;) or she hated her husband vehemently, and her husband hated her vehemently: (K:) the verb has not been heard otherwise than as relating to the husband and wife: (S, O:) Lh has mentioned farakatohu, aor. taforukuhu; but it is not well known: (TA:) all of the nouns mentioned above as inf. ns. signify [hatred, or] vehement hatred, in a general sense, as also ↓ furuk~aAnN, (K, TA,) which is [app. a simple subst.] mentioned on the authority of Seer, and also mentioned as with two kesrehs and the teshdeed [i. e. ↓ firik~aAnN]: (TA:) or all relate peculiarly to the hatred of the husband and wife; (K, TA;) i. e., to the man's hating his wife; or to her hating him, which is the better known: it is said in a trad. of Ibn-Mes'ood, A_in~a AlHub~a mina A@ll~`hi waAlfiroka mina Al$~ayoTaAni [Verily love of the husband is from God, and hatred of the husband is from the Devil]: A'Obeyd says that Alfiroku signifies the woman's hating her husband; that it relates peculiarly to the wife and the husband, and that it had not been heard by him as used in relation to any but them two: and IAar says that the sons of a man by a wife who hates him, which sons are termed A^awolaAdu Alfiroki, possess generosity, because the sons thus called are most like to their fathers, and do not resemble her: and when the husband hates the wife, one says SlfhA [i. e. SalafahaA or SalifahaA] and Slft Endh [i. e. Salifato Einodahu]. (TA.) -A3- farikati AlA^u*uni, aor.
faraka , (K,) inf. n. farakN, (S, O, K,) The ear had a flaccidity in its A^aSol [or base, meaning the part surrounding the entrance of the meatus auditorius]. (S, * O, * K.)
2 taforiykN * [inf. n. of fr~k] The causing to be hated, or much hated. (O.)

3 fArkhu * , (AZ, O, K, TA,) inf. n. mufaArakapN, (TA,) i. q. taArakahu [i. e. He left, forsook, or abandoned, him; or he did so being left &c. by him]; (AZ, O, K, TA;) namely, his companion; (AZ, O;) said by IF to be formed by substitution [of f for t]: (O, TA:) expl. in the A as meaning faAraqahu [which is syn. with tArkh]. (TA.)

4 Afrk Als~unobulu *
The ears of corn became ↓ fariyk, i. e. in the state in which they were fit to be rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, with the hand [so as to divest the kernels of their husks], and then to be eaten: (S, O:) and Afrk Alz~aroEu, (TA,) and AlHab~u, (K,) The seed-produce, and the grain, attained to the state in which it was fit to be rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, (K, TA,) with the
hand: or the grain became hard, or firm, and attained to its utmost state of growth; before which it is forbidden to sell it. (TA.)

5 tfr~k *
He (an effeminate man, O) affected languor, or languidness, (takas~ara) in his speech, (O, K,) and in his walk: (K:) so says IDrd. (O.)

7 Anfrk Als~unobulu *
The ears of corn were rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, (K, TA,) with the hand [so that the kernels became divested of their husks]. (TA.) And Anfrk Alv~awobu The garment became rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, (K, TA,) with the hand [to remove a soil]. (TA.) [See 1.] ― -b2- And Anfrk Almanokibu The shoulder-joint became lax, or slack: (S, * TA:) or Anfrk manokibuhu, (Lth, O, K, *) as also Anfrkt waAbilatuhu, (Lth, O,) signifies the waAbilap [or head] of his humerus became dislocated (Lth, O, K) from the Sadafap [or socket] of the scapula, so that the shoulder-joint became lax, or slack: but when the like thereof happens in the wAblp of the femur, one does not say Anfrk, but Huriqa, and the epithet maHoruwqN is applied to it [i. e. to the hip-joint]. (Lth, O.) ― -b3- And Anfrk Eano Eahodihi He became released from his compact, engagement, or promise; syn. Ainofak~a. (TA.)

10 Astfrk AlHab~u fiY Als~unobulapi *
The grain became full (samina [q. v.]), and hard, or firm, [as though demanding to be rubbed with the hand so as to be divested of the husks, and eaten,] in the ear of corn. (K, * TA.)
farokN * : see what next follows.

farikN * , (O, K,) like katifN, (K,) or correctly, as written in the L and A. ↓ farokN, (TA, [but this I think doubtful,]) [A fruit or the like] of which the integument becomes rubbed off [with the hand]: (O, K: [I read Almunofariku qi$oruhu, as in the CK, for Almutafar~iku qi$oruhu in other copies of the K and in the O:]) thus applied to an almond, and likewise to a peach. (TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

A^u*unN faroqaA='u *
An ear having a flaccidity in its A^aSol [or base]; as also ↓ farikapN. (S, O, K. [See 1, last sentence.])
furuk~aAnN * and firik~aAnN: see 1, latter half.
firaAkN * a term for HayoDN [or Menstruation]: mentioned by MF. (TA.)
faruwkN * : see faArikN, first sentence.

fariykN * , applied to grain (Hab~), i. q. ↓ maforuwkN [i. e. Rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, with the hand, so that the integument becomes stripped off from the kernel]: (K:) or wheat (bur~) that is rubbed, &c., and picked, or cleared. (O.) See also 4. ― -b2- And Wheat rubbed, &c., and moistened with clarified butter &c.; (K, TA;) also termed ↓ maforuwkapN. (TA.) -A2- The fariykaAni, or, as in some copies of the K, ↓ fariykataAni, (TA,) Two bones [app. the two greater cornua of the os hyoides] in, or at, (fiY,) the root of the tongue. (K, TA.)
fariykataAni * : see what next precedes.

faArikN * A woman hating, or who hates, her husband; [app. accord. to the K, vehemently;] as also ↓ faruwkN [but app. in an intensive sense]: (S, O, K:) pl. of the former fawaArikN. (O, * TA.) Dhur-Rummeh says, (O, TA,) describing camels, (TA,)
A_i*aA All~ayolu Eano na$ozK tajal~aY ramayonahu
biA^amovaAli A^aboSaAri Aln~isaA='i AlfawaAriki
[When the night clears away from an elevated piece of ground, they cast at it the like of the eyes of the women that hate their husbands]: (O, TA:) he likens them to the women that hate their husbands because these raise their eyes towards men, not confining the look to the husbands: he says, these camels enter upon the time of dawn, having journeyed all their night; and whenever an elevated piece of ground becomes within their view, they cast their eyes at it by reason of sprightliness and strength for the journeying. (TA.)

mufar~akN * [Caused to be hated, or to be much hated: see its verb. And] A man hated by women: (S, O, K:) such was Imra-el-Keys: (S, O:) [and accord. to Freytag, ↓ maforuwkN occurs in this sense in the Deewán of Jereer.] And mufar~akapN A woman hated by men. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- Also Left, forsaken, or abandoned, and hated. (Fr, TA.)

maforuwkN * : see fariykN. One says also qamolapN maforuwkapN [A louse rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, between the finger and thumb, or otherwise, to be killed]. (S, O.) ― -b2- Applied to a camel, (En-Nadr, O, K,) it means Such as is termed A^afak~u [q. v.]; (En-Nadr, O;) whose shoulder is slit [so I render Ainoxarama, but I incline to think that it here means is splayed, or dislocated, as though rent without being separated (see taxar~ama)], and the EaSabap [which I suppose to signify in this case either tendon or ligament] that is in the interior of the A^axorama [q. v., app. here meaning the glenoid cavity of the scapula] detached. (En-Nadr, O, K. [See also Anfrk manokibuhu.]) ― -b3- And A garment, or piece of cloth, (TA,) strongly dyed (K, TA) with saffron &c. (TA.) -A2- See also mufar~akN.
maforuwkapN * , as a subst.: see fariykN.

2 taforiymN * [as an inf. n. of which the verb is far~amat] signifies A woman's contracting her faloham (or qubul, TA) [i. e. vulva or vagina] with the stones of raisins [which were supposed to have an astringent property, or with some other medicament: see faromN: and see also 10]: and so taforiybN. (IAar, T.)

3 firaAmN * [app. as an inf. n. of which the verb is faAramat] signifies A woman's menstruating, and stuffing her vulva with a piece of rag: and one says of her who has done this, ↓ Aifotaramat [and app. also faAaramat]. (T, K.) [See also firaAmapN.] ― -b2- It occurs in a trad. [as an inf. n.] used in the sense of mujaAmaEap [meaning (tropical:) The act of compressing]. (IAth, TA.)

4 Afrm *
He filled (T, S, K) a watering-trough (T, K) or a vessel: (S:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (T, S.)
8 Aifotaramat * , said of a woman: see 3.

10 Aisotaforamat *
She (a woman) applied a medicament to her vulva, or vagina, to contract it: (S, K: *) or she stuffed her vulva, or vagina, (T, TA,) with the stones of raisins, and the like: (TA:) the women of [the tribe of] Thakeef, having a wideness in that part, made this use of the stones of raisins, desiring thereby to contract it: (M, TA: *) [see also 2: and see faromN:] the epithet ↓ faromaA='u is applied to her who does thus; as also ↓ musotaforimapN. (M, K.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says of a mare, Aisotaforamato biAlHaSaY, meaning (assumed tropical:) She caused the pebbles to enter her vulva by her vehement running. (TA. [And the same is implied in the S by an ex. and explanation of the part. n.])

faromN * , (T, S, M, K,) and ↓ faromapN, (S, K,) and ↓ firaAmN, (M, K,) A medicament, or remedial application, (T, S, M, K,) such as the stones of raisins, (T, M,) used by a woman for the purpose of contracting her vulva, or vagina. (T, S, M, K.)

faramN * The rag that is used on the occasion of menstruation: (IAth, TA:) and ↓ mafaArimu signifies the rags used on the occasion thereof; and [may be an irreg. pl. of faramN, like as ma$aAbihu is held to be of $abahN, but it is said that it] is a pl. having no sing.: (M, TA:) [in the K, in art. H$w, the ↓ mafaArimu (there in the CK erroneously written maqaArim) are said to be used by the musotaHaADap: see 8 in that art.]
faromapN * : see faromN.
faromaA='u * : see 10.
firaAmN * : see faromN: -A2- and see also the next following paragraph.

firaAmapN * The piece of rag which a woman bears [stuffed] in her vulva, or vagina: (AZ, T, K:) or her menstruating, and stuffing her vulva with a piece of rag; like ↓ firaAmN [as expl. above: see 3]. (K.)
A^aforamu * A man (TA) whose teeth become much broken. (K, TA.)

muforamN *
Filled with water (T, M) &c.: (M:) mentioned by A'Obeyd, as applied to a wateringtrough: (T:) and applied also to a $iEob [or road in a mountain, &c.,] as meaning filled with men, or people: (M:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (T, M.)
mafaArimu * : see faramN, in two places.
musotaforimapN * : see 10.

furonN * [app. from, or cognate with, the Latin
“ furnus ”] An oven, (IDrd, * S, * M, K,) syn. maxobazN, (M, K,) [or one] in which one bakes bread such as is termed furoniY~; (S, K;) differing from the tan~uwr [q. v.]: (S:) a word of the dial. of Syria: (M:) thought by IDrd to be not Arabic [in origin]: (TA:) pl. A^aforaAnN. (M.)

furoniY~N *
Thick, (S, K,) round, or circular, (K,) bread; (S, K;) so called in relation to its place [in which it is baked, i. e. the furon]: (S:) or (K) a sort of bread having a raised and pointed, or hollowed, head, the lateral portions thereof being drawn together to, or towards, the middle, (M, K,) and being intermingled, one part thereof in another, (M,) roasted, or fried, (K,) then well moistened with milk and clarified butter and sugar: (M, K:) n. un. ↓ furoniy~apN: which signifies also a round, or circular, great cake of bread: (M:) [whence, app.,] faA_i*aA hiYa mivolu Alfaroniy~api AlHamoraA='i [And lo, she, or it, was like the red frny~p; but to what this refers I know not]: a saying of some of the Arabs. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And (as being likened thereto, TA) (tropical:) A thick, bulky, man: (M, K, TA:) and (K) a bulky dog. (IB, K, TA.) ― -b3- Also A baker; as a rel. n. of furonN: (Msb:) and so ↓ far~aAnN, in the dial. of the vulgar. (TA.)
furoniy~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
far~aAnN * : see furoniY~N, last sentence. [It is applied in the present day to A baker of bread and of meat &c.]

?? *
A female baker (T, K) of the bread termed furoniY~. (T.)

fironibN *
A rat, or mouse; syn. faA^orapN: (IAar, O, K:) or the young one generated between it and a jerboa: (K:) or [as a coll. gen. n.] the rat, or mouse; syn. faA^orN. (T.) [See also qaronabN.]
Alfiranoju * , n. un. firanojiY~N: see what follows.

AlA_iforanojapu * (O, K) [and AlA_iforanoju, which is the more common,] and ↓ Alfiranoju, (MF, TA, [but in the Commentary of MF written without any of the syll. signs,]) in which last manner it is correctly written accord. to the sheykhs of El-Andalus, who are the nearest to, and the best acquainted with, the country of the people thus called, and so written by Suh, (MF,) A certain people; [the Franks; an appellation given originally, by the Arabs, to the French; and afterwards to all Europeans except those of the Turkish Empire:] an arabicized word from A_iforanok, (K,) or AfrnG, (O,) or from frnk [or firanoG]: (Suh, MF:) accord. to general analogy, it should be AlA_iforinojapu, with kesr to the r: (O, K:) so called because the seat of their dominion is [named] frnjp or frAnsp [i. e. France]; and their king is called AlfrnsPs, [more properly AlfaranosiyosiY~u,] which is likewise an arabicized word. (Suh, as cited by MF.) [The n. un., or appellation given to a single person of this people, is A_iforanojiY~N and firanojiY~N.]

firinodN *
A sort of cloth, or garment, (Lth, T, O, K,) well known: (K:) an adventitious word, (Lth, T, O,) [from the Pers. Paranod,] arabicized. (O, K.) ― -b2- And [hence, app.,] firinodu Als~ayofi, (T, S, M, O, K,) and ↓ A_iforinoduhu, (S, O, K,) The diversified wavy marks, streaks, grain, or water, of the sword; syn. wa$oyuhu, (T, S, M, O, K,) and jawoharuhu, (T, O, K,) and rubaduhu [q. v.], (S, O,) and maAw^uhu Al~a*iY yajoriY fiyhi, (T, O, *) and TaraAy^iquhu, (T, O,) i. e. safaAsiquhu. (T.) ― -b3- And Alfirinodu signifies The sword itself. (M, L, K.) ― -b4- And The Hawojam; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) the red rose. (M, TA.) ― -b5- And The grains of the pomegranate. (AA, O, K.)

fironidN *
i. q. A^abozaArN [Seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; &c.]: pl. faraAnidu. (IAar, O, K.)

firinodaApN *
A qaTaAp [or sand-grouse]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
A_iforinodu Als~ayofi * : see firinodN, second sentence.

div1.div2: frns For words mentioned in some of the lexicons under this head, see art. frs.

div2.entryFree:
Q. 2 tafaronaqa *
He was, or became, bad; (K, TA;) said of a camel: (TA:) and so tafaronaqat said of a sheep or goat ($aAp). (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.) -A2- And A^u*unuhu tafaronaqato His ear became raised. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

furonuqN *
Bad; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) applied to the Eariyf [or chief, superintendent, or manager of the affairs,] of a people or party: and so ↓ mutafaroniqu applied to a camel. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

furaAniqN * The bariyd, i. e., (IDrd, S, O,) the warner before the lion; (S, O, K;) a certain beast of prey, [sometimes called by us the lion's provider,] that cries out before the lion, as though warning men of his presence; said to resemble the jackal (Aibonu A=waY); (IDrd, TA;) and said to be the jackal [itself]; but some say otherwise: (TA voce bariydN:) a Pers. word, (IDrd, S, O,) arabicized, (IDrd, S, O, K,) originally farowaAnahu [or ParowaAnah], (IDrd, TA,) or originally ParowaAnak: (S, O, K:) said by AHát to be [also] called the waEowaE. (TA.) ― -b2- And (hence, TA) The guide of the messenger on a beast of the post. (O, K, TA.) And sometimes The guide of an army was thus called. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And, (O, K,) accord. to some, (O,) it signifies The lion [himself]. (O, K.)
mutafaroniqN * : see furonuqN.

1 faruha * , aor.
faruha , (S, K,) inf. n. faraAhapN and faraAhiyapN (K) [and app. also furuwhapN, expl. below as a simple subst.], He was, or became, skilled, or skilful. (S, K.) ― -b2- And faruha and faraha, aor. of each
faruha , [inf. n. app. furuwhapN and faraAhapN and faraAhiyapN, expl. below as simple substs.,] said of a horse or similar beast, &c., He was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or light. (Msb.) ― -b3- [And faruha, inf. n. faraAhapN, (of which see an explanation below,) probably signifies He was, or became, beautiful, comely, pretty, or elegant; like SabuHa, inf. n. SabaAHapN.] ― -b4- And fariha, (S, K,) aor.
faraha , (K,) inf. n. farahN, (TK,) He exulted, or rejoiced above measure; or he exulted greatly, and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (S, K:) the h in this verb, accord. to Fr, is substituted for the H in fariHa, which has this meaning. (TA.)
2 far~aha see what next follows.

4 A^aforahat *
She (a camel) brought forth [young ones such as are termed] furohN (S) or fur~ahN (K) [i. e. such as were brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or light]; as also ↓ fr~ht, inf. n. taforiyhN. (K.) ― -b2- And She (a woman) brought forth beautiful children. (TA.) ― -b3- And Afrh He (a man) took for himself a gulaAm [i. e. youth, young man, or male slave,] such as is termed faArihN (IAar, K) meaning beautiful, or comely, of countenance. (IAar, TA.)

10 huwa yasotaforihu AlA^aforaAsa * means yasotakorimuhaA [i. e. He seeks the horses, or mares, that are of generous race]: (aK, TA:) and the like is said in the A, but with Ald~awaAb~a in the place of AlAfrAs. (TA.)

farihN * [part. n. of fariha, meaning Exulting, or rejoicing above measure; &c.]. In the Kur xxvi. 149, some read farihiyna, from fariha, signifying as expl. above: others reading faArihiyna, which is from faruha: (S, TA:) ― -b2- but farihN is also syn. with faArihN, as an epithet applied to a youth, or young man, or male slave; and thus the reading of farihiyna in the Kur has been expl. as meaning Possessing skill. (TA.)

furaAhN *
i. q. furaAtN, as an epithet applied to water, signifying Sweet, &c.: both are chaste forms, and well known, like taAbuwhN and taAbuwtN: so in the Towsheeh. (MF and TA in art. frt.)
faraAhapN * [mentioned in the first paragraph as an inf. n. is also expl. as a simple subst.]: see furuwhapN. ― -b2- Also Beauty, or comeliness. (Msb, TA.)

furuwhapN * [app. an inf. n., but mentioned as a simple subst., meaning] Skilfulness. (K.) ― -b2- And furuwhahN and ↓ faraAhapN and ↓ faraAhiyapN denote a
quality of a hackney and of a mule and of an ass, (S,) or of a horse, or similar beast, &c., (Msb,) all signifying Briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, activity, agility, or lightness. (Msb, TA. *)
faraAhiyapN * [mentioned in the first paragraph as an inf. n.]: see what next precedes.

faArihN *
Skilful, or possessing skill; (S, Msb, K;) part. n. of faruha, irregularly formed, for by rule it should be fariyhN: (S:) accord. to Z, it is applied to a man; and also, without p, to a qayonap [i. e. female slave, or slave-songstress]. (Msb.) ― -b2- And it is applied as an epithet to a hackney, (Az, S, Msb,) and a mule, (S,) and an ass, (Az, S, Msb,) or to a horse, or similar beast, (Az,) meaning Brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or light; (Az, * Msb;) sharp; strong; that goes, or journeys, much; a great goer: (Az, TA:) it is not applied to a faras, (Az, S,) i. e. to an Arabian horse; (Az, Msb;) such being termed jawaAdN, (Az, S, Msb,) and raAy^iEN: (S:) 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd has applied it to the latter; but As has charged him with error in so doing; saying that he possessed not knowledge of horses: (S:) the pl. is furohN, (S, Msb,) like buzolN and HuwlN pls. of baAzilN and HaAy^ilN, (S,) or furuhN, like kutubN, (K,) and farahapN, with two fet-hahs, (Msb,) or furohapN, (S, K,) but this is held by Sb to be a quasi-pl. n., (ISd, TA,) and fur~ahN, like ruk~aEN, and fur~ahapN, like suk~arapN, (K,) as in the A, but MF says that no pl. of this measure is known. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a gulaAm [i. e. youth, young man, or male slave], Beautiful, or comely, of countenance. (IAar, TA.) And [the fem.] faArihapN signifies A beautiful, or comely, girl, or young woman: (K:) [and] so ↓ farohaA='u, [of which the masc. is A^aforahu, and] of which the pl. is furohN; but Az says, I do not think that they use this word in relation to girls, or young women, though they may apply it peculiarly to female slaves like as they apply faArihN and faArihapN peculiarly to hackneys and mules and jades, exclusively of Arabian horses. (Msb.) ― -b4- And faArihapN is also syn. with fatiy~apN [i. e. A youthful females, or one in the prime of life]: (thus accord. to several copies of the K and accord. to the TA:) or qayonapN [i. e. a female slave, or a slave-songstress: see the first sentence of this paragraph]. (Thus in the CK.) ― -b5- And it signifies also [A woman] who eats vehemently: (K:) and faArihN applied to man, A vehement eater. (IAar, TA.)
A^aforahu * : see its fem., farohaA='u, in the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- fulaAnN A^aforahu mino fulaAnK means Such a one is more beautiful, or comely, than such a one. (Msb.)
muforihN * and muforihapN (S, K) and mufar~ihapN (S) are epithets applied to a she-camel, meaning Bringing forth [young ones such as are termed] furohN (S) or fur~ahN. (K.) [See 4.]
Q. 2 tafarohada * , said of a boy, or youth, not of a man, He became fat. (TA. [See also furohudN, and mufarohadN.])
farohadN * : see the next paragraph, in three places.

furohadN * (S, M, O, L, K) and ↓ furohuwdN (M, L, K) A boy, or youth, (L,) fat, or compact in make, (HaAdirN,) and thick; (S, M, O, L, K;) as also ↓ farohadN: (O:) and soft, thin-skinned, and plump: (M, O, * K:) some assign this meaning to qurohadN, but others say that this is a corruption, and it is correctly with f: and one says also gulaAmN fulohudN, meaning a plump boy or youth: (L:) also, (K,) or furohudN [only], (TA,) or ↓ furohuwdN, (IDrd, O,) a boy, or youth, (IDrd, O, K, TA) not a man, (IDrd, O,) plump (IDrd, O, K, TA) in body, (TA,) and beautiful (IDrd, O, K, TA) in face; (TA;) as also ↓ farohadN: (K:) and furohudN and ↓ farohadN signify a boy, or youth, that has nearly attained to puberty. (O. [See also falohadN and fawohadN.]) ― -b2- Also, i. e. the first and second, (L, K,) or ↓ furohuwdN, which is of the dial. of Azd, (O,) The whelp of a lion; (O, L, K;) of the dial. of 'Omán: the pl. [of ↓ furohuwdN, or] of furohudN, accord. to Kr, is faraAhiydN; but ISd distrusts his authority on a matter of this kind. (L.)
furohuwdN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in four places. ― -b2- Also A young mountain-kid. (L, K.) ― -b3- And [the pl.] faraAhiydu signifies Young lambs or kids. (O, K.)
mufarohadN * A fat boy or youth. (TA.)
2 fr~Y Aljub~apa * , inf. n. taforiyapN, He furred, or lined with fur, the garment called jub~ap: see the pass. part. n., below.]

4 AfrY *
He was, or became, abundant in cattle, or other property: like A^avoraY. (M in art. vrw. [See farowapN, last sentence.])

8 AftrY farowFA *
He wore farow [i. e. fur]: (S, M, K:) [and so, app., AftrY alone: see mufotarK, below.]

farowN * signifies A certain thing that is worn; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ farowapN: (Msb:) each of these is a word of well-known meaning: (M:) [but the former is properly a coll. gen. n., and ↓ farowapN is its n. un.; agreeably with what here follows:] Alfarowu is well known [as being fur]; and ↓ farowapN is the appellation applied when it is [a furred garment] like the jub~ip: (Lth, T:) and signifies also a skin, but not unless having upon it wabar [i. e. fur, or soft hair,] or wool: (T:) [in general,] this latter word signifies, (K, TA,) and some say the former also, (TA,) a kind of garment, well known, (K, TA,) lined with the skins of various species of animals, the most highly esteemed whereof is the sam~awr [or sable], tanned, and sewed together; this garment being worn for preservation from the cold: (TA:) firaA='N is the pl. (S, M, Msb, TA) of mult., and the pl. of pauc. is A^aforK: so says Aboo- 'Alee El-Kálee. (TA.)

farowapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- Also The scalp, or skin of the head: (S, Msb, K:) or farowapu Alr~aA^osi signifies the scalp, or skin of the head, with the hair thereof, (Lth, T, M, Mgh,) of a man, and of other than man: (M:) or the upper part of the head: (M, TA:) and one says, Darabahu EalaY A^um~i farowatihi meaning [He struck him upon] his haAmap [crown, &c.]. (TA.) [Hence,] it is metaphorically applied, in a trad., to (tropical:) The skin of the face. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A woman's [head-covering such as is called] ximaAr, (Mgh, K, TA,) or [such as is called] qinaAE; occurring in a trad.; (Mgh, TA;) metaphorically applied thereto. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A crown, such as is worn by a king: (Z, K, * TA:) [said to be] so called because made of skins. (TA.) ― -b5- And A [garment of the kind called] jub~ap of which the two sleeves have been tucked up. (K.) ― -b6- And The half of a [garment such as is called] kisaA=' made of the soft hair of camels; (K, TA;) now known by the appellation of jbp [evidently a mistranscription, app. for xib~ap, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b7- And A [bag such as is termed] wafoDap [q. v.], (K, TA,) [i. e.] like the xariyTap, made of skin, (TA,) in which the beggar puts his alms. (K, TA.) And hence, (TA,) *uw Alfarowap means The beggar. (K, TA.) ― -b8- And A portion of herbage collected together and dry. (S, K.) ― -b9- And Waste, or uncultivated, land, having in it no herbage (T, K) and no bara$ [or maculæ, or spots differing in colour from the rest]. (T.) ― -b10- A^abuw farowapK signifies The bal~uwT [here meaning chestnut, which is called in Egypt Abw frwp in the present day]; of the dial. of Egypt: it is thus called because within its husk is what resembles the soft hair of camels. (TA.) -A2- Also i. q. varowapN, (Fr, As, ISk, T, S, M, Msb, K,) and ginFY; (S, K;) [i. e. Abundance, and richness &c.;] accord. to Yaakoob [i. e. ISk], (M,) formed from varowapN by substitution (S, M) of f for v: (M:) one says, A_in~ahu la*uw varowapK mina AlmaAli and farowapK, both meaning the same [i. e. Verily he is a possessor of abundance of property]; (T, S; [in some copies of the latter, fiY AlmaAli;]) so says ISk, (T,) or Fr; (S;) and As says the like: (S:) the latter says, fulaAnN *uw farowapK and varowapK, meaning Such a one is a possessor of abundant property. (T.)

far~aA='N *
A manufacturer of firaA=' [i. e. furs, or furred garments]: ― -b2- and A seller thereof. (TA.)
jub~apN mufar~aApN * [A furred jb~p;] a [garment of the kind called] jb~p upon which is a farowap [or fur, i. e., that is lined therewith].
mufotarK * [act. part. n. of 8]. AlmufotariY laA yajida Albaroda [The wearer of fur will not feel the cold] is a saying of the Arabs. (TA.)

div2.head: Quasi frwz
div2.entryFree: Q. Q. 1 farowaza * see in art. frz.

1 faraAhu * , (M, K,) aor. yaforiyhi, (K,) inf. n. faroYN, (K,) He slit it, or cut it lengthwise, ill, or improperly; or well, or properly; as also ↓ fr~Ahu and ↓ AfrAhu [both relating to both of the foregoing explanations]: (K:) or he slit it, or cut it lengthwise, and made it bad, or improper; as also ↓ fr~Ahu: or, accord. to the sound lexicologists, the former has this meaning: but ↓ AfrY signifies he slit, or cut lengthwise, and made good, or proper: (M:) or ↓ AfrAhu (M, K) signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (K,) he made it good, or proper: or he ordered [another] to make it so: (M, K:) as though he removed from it unsoundness, or imperfection: but some say that this signifies he slit it, or cut it lengthwise, and made it bad, or improper: and when you mean he measured it, and cut it, to make it good, or proper, you say faraAhu, inf. n. faroYN: (M:) [thus, accord. to J,] faraY, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he cut a thing in order to make it good, or proper: (S:) or he cut a skin, or hide, in a good, or proper, manner: (Ks, S, Msb:) and ↓ AfrY he cut it in a bad, or an improper, manner: (Ks, S:) or this signifies he slit much, in a bad, or an improper, manner: and AfrY Aljiloda, accord. to As, he rent, tore, or slit, the skin, and made holes in it, and spoiled it: and AfrY signifies also he slit a thing (S, M, Msb) of any kind; (as also ↓ fr~Ahu:]) thus you say, AfrY AlA^awdaAja he slit the AwdAj [or external jugular veins], (T, M, Mgh, Msb,) and made what was in them, of the blood, to come forth; (T, Mgh, Msb;) and in like manner one says of a garment, or piece of cloth, and of a jul~ap [or receptacle for dates, made of palm-leaves woven together]; (T;) or he cut the AwdAj: (S:) IAar alone mentions faraY A^awodaAjahu and ↓ AfrAhA: (M:) [but it is also said that faraY signifies he cut a niTaE [or the like]: (K in art. xlq: [see an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of that art.; also cited in the T after the first of the explanations here following, and in the M after the second thereof:]) or faraY, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he measured, and worked, or manufactured, and made good, or proper, a thing, such as a sandal, or a niTaE [q. v.], or a water-skin, and the like: (T:) or he measured it, and cut it, to make it good, or proper: (M:) and he measured and manufactured a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag]: (S, K:) or he sewed, and made well, or properly, a mzAdp: (T:) [it is said that] the difference between ↓ AlA_iforaA@'u an AlfaroYu is this, that the former signifies the cutting so as to render bad, or improper, and the slitting like as the slaughterer and the wild beast slit [their victims]; and the latter, the cutting so as to make good, or proper, like the act of cutting of the sewer of the hide, or of leather: but faraY sometimes occurs in the sense of AfrY: (Mgh:) one says, raA^osahu ↓ A^aforayotu, meaning I split, or clave, his head with a sword; like A^aforarotuhu: (Yz, T &c. in art. fr:) and AfrY AljuroHa he slit the wound: (T:) and AfrY Al*~iy^obu baTona Al$~aApi [the wolf slit, or rent, the belly of the sheep, or goat]: (S:) and one says, qado A^aforayota wamaA farayota i. e. thou hast done ill, or improperly, and hast not done well, or properly. (A, TA.) ― -b2- faraAhu, aor. as above, [and so the inf. n.,] is sometimes metonymically used [as meaning (tropical:) He slaughtered him, or butchered him; i. e.] as denoting vehemence, or excess, in slaying. (TA.) ― -b3- And it means also (assumed tropical:) He cut him with censure, or satire: (TA:) and ↓ AfrY means he blamed, or censured, a man. (M, K.) ― -b4- And you say, farayotu AlA^aroDa (tropical:) I traversed, or crossed, (lit. travelled and cut,) the land, or country; (T, S, K, TA;) inf. n. as above. (TA.) ― -b5- huwa yaforiY ↓ AlfariY~a means (assumed tropical:) He effects what is wonderful in his deed. (S, K.) A^aHadN ↓ maA yaforiY fariy~ahu, thus, with teshdeed [to the Y in fryh] as related by A'Obeyd, is said of a courageous man [as meaning No one does his deed, or the like]: but it is said [by Kh] to be correctly faroyahu, [as an inf. n.,] without tesh-deed. (M. [See, however, what follows.]) They say, ↓ tarakotuhu yaforiY AlfariY~a, meaning [I left him] doing well, or excellently, in a deed, or in watering: [an explanation relating to what here follows:] the Prophet said, respecting 'Omar, whom he saw in a dream drawing water at a well with a great bucket, ↓ falamo A^ara Eaboqariy~FA yaforiY fariy~ahu [And I have not seen a chief of a people do his deed, &c.]: (T:) or, as some relate it, he said faroyahu: (TA:) [but] A'Obeyd says, this is like thy saying yaEomalu Eamalahu and yaquwlu qawolahu; and Fr cited to us [as an ex.]
↓ qado kunoti taforiyna bihi Alfariy~aA
meaning [Verily] thou didst multiply and magnify thy words respecting it: (T: and in like manner this hemistich [which shows, by the measure, that Alfariy~aA cannot be here a mistake for AlfaroyaA,] is expl. in the S:) it is said that ↓ fariY~ thus used is of the measure faEylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, from faraY signifying “ he cut ” [or “ cut lengthwise ” or “ slit ”] a hide, or leather; (Har p. 257; [where see more;]) [and this assertion is corroborated by the fact that] one says of a man strenuous, or vigorous, in an affair, and strong, wayaqud~u ↓ tarakotuhu yaforiY AlfariY~a [lit. I left him slitting, or cutting, the slit, or cut, thing, and shaping]. (T.) ― -b6- faraY is also synonymous with AftrY: see the latter, in two places. ― -b7- faraY Albaroqu, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies The lightning shone, or glistened, or shone with flickering light, and continued, in the sky. (T, TA.) -A2- fariYa, (T, S, M, K,) aor. yaforaY, (T, S,) inf. n. farFY, (T, S, K, but omitted in the CK,) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; syn. bahita, (T,) and dahi$a, (T, S, M, K,) and taHay~ara, (S, K,) and baTira: (Skr, on the verse here following:) El-Aalam El-Hudhalee says,
wafariytu mino fazaEK falaA
A^aromiY walaA wad~aEotu SaAHibo
[And I became confounded, &c., by reason of fright, so that I did not shoot an arrow, nor bade I farewell to a friend]: (T, M:) or, accord. to As, fariYa, aor. yaforaY, signifies he looked, and knew not what he should do: (T:) and fariytu signifies also I wondered; from ↓ AlfariY~u meaning “ that which is wonderful. ” (Skr, on the verse above-cited.)
2 far~aYa see 1, first quarter, in three places.
4 A^aforaYa see 1, former half, in seven places: ― -b2- and also in the latter half, near the middle of the paragraph.

5 tfr~Y *
It became slit, or cut lengthwise; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AnfrY; (S, M, Msb;) both said of a skin, (M,) or of a thing: (S:) or it became much slit, or rent; said of the sewing of a leathern water-skin. (T.) And tfr~Y Eanohu vawobuhu His garment became much slit, or rent, from him. (T.) And tfr~t AlEayonu (tropical:) The spring of water burst forth: (K, TA:) or tfr~t AlA^aroDu biAlEuyuwni (tropical:) The earth, or ground, burst with the springs. (S, M, A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] the saying of Kabeesah Ibn-Jábir,
tafar~aY bayoDuhaA Ean~aA fakun~aA
baniY AlA^ajolaAdi minohaA waAlr~imaAli
i. e. (assumed tropical:) Its eggs (the pronoun in byDhA denoting the earth) burst from us [so as to disclose us], so that we were the sons of the hard tracts thereof and of the soft tracts, or plains, [or of the sands,] means only their numerousness, and the wide extent of their districts. (Ham p. 341.) ― -b3- And tfr~Y All~ayolu Eano SuboHihi (tropical:) [The night became distinct, as though cleft, from its dawn]. (TA.)
7 A_inofaraYa see the next preceding paragraph.

8 A_ifotaraYa
AftrYka*ibFA He forged, or fabricated, a lie, or falsehood; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) you say, AftrY Ealayohi ka*ibFA [he forged against him a lie]; (Mgh, Msb;) and ka*ibFA ↓ faraY signifies the same, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yaforiY, (Msb,) inf. n. faroYN; (M;) and this verb likewise is followed by Ealayohi: (Msb:) ↓ faraY in this sense is mentioned as said by Lth; others saying AftrY. (T.) AftrY is used in the Kur in relation also to the attributing a copartner to God: thus in the saying [in iv. 51], wamano yu$oriko biA@ll~`hi faqadi A@fotariYA_ivmFA EaZiymFA [And whoso attributeth a copartner to God, hath devised an enormous sin]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

faroyapN *
Clamour; or a confusion, or mixture, of cries or shouts or noises. (M, K, TA. [AlHalobapu in the CK is a mistake for Aljalabapu.]) firoyapN A lie, or falsehood; (S, * M, Mgh, * Msb, * K, TA;) a subst. from AifotaraY: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and meaning [also] a defamation: (Mgh:) pl. firFY. (TA.) ― -b2- And An affair, or a case, of great magnitude or moment or gravity. (M, TA.)

friY~N *
Slit, or cut lengthwise; applied to a skin (jilodN): and so fariy~apN [app. as applied to a qirobap or
the like, as being fem. of fariY~N]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And A wide dalow [or leathern bucket]; (M, K;) as though it were slit; (M;) as also fariy~apN. (K.) ― -b3- And A thing forged, or fabricated; (S, K, TA;) thus [or rather as hence meaning unknown, or unheard of,] in the saying, laqadojiy^oti $ayoy^FA fariy~FA, in the Kur [xix. 28], (S, TA,) i. e. [Thou hast done] a thing hitherto unknown; a thing deemed strange: (Bd:) or a thing of great magnitude or moment or gravity; (S, K, TA;) and thus it is said to mean in the phrase above cited: (S, TA:) or wonderful; (T, TA;) thus as expl. by Er-Rághib; (TA;) and thus it is also said to mean in that phrase. (T, TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, latter half, in eight places. -A2- Also, applied to a man, A forger, or fabricator, of lies; and so ↓ miforFY. (Lh, M, TA.) -A3- And Milk of the time when it is milked. (K.) -A4- And they say, AlfariY~a AlfariY~a, meaning AlEajalapa AlEajalapa [i. e. Haste: haste: used in an imperative sense; as inf. ns. are often thus used; but they are] both like ganiY~ [in measure]: mentioned by Sgh. (TA.)
A^aforaY AlfiraY * occurs in a trad. as meaning The most lying of lies: AlfiraY is the pl. of firoyapN. (TA.)
mifor~aY * : see fariY~N.
maforiy~apN * A mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] made in a good, or proper, manner; well made. (T, TA.)

1 faz~a * , (A, O, K,) aor.
fazi3a , inf. n. faz~N, (TA,) He (a gazelle) was, or became, frightened, or afraid. (A, O, K.) ― -b2- faz~a qalobuhu His heart heaved by reason of fear. (O.) ― -b3- faz~a Eanohu He (a man, O) turned away from him. (A, O, K.) And He separated himself from him, and became alone. (A, O, K.) -A2- faz~a, aor.
fazi3a , inf. n. fazaAzapN and fuzuwzapN, He (a man, O) became excited with ardour, or eagerness. (O, K.) -A3- faz~a fulaAnFA Eano mawoDiEihi, (A, O, * K,) inf. n. faz~N, (O,) He disturbed, removed, or unsettled, such a one from his place: (A, O, * K:) or he frightened, and disturbed, or removed, or unsettled, such a one from his place, and made his courage (lit. his heart) to fly away: (IDrd, TA:) and [in like manner] ↓ A^afaz~ahu he frightened him; (K;) or, as in some copies of the K, he disturbed or disquieted him; (TA;) or he frightened him, and disturbed or disquieted or unsettled him, and made his courage (lit. his heart) to fly away. (S, O. *) [See also 10.] -A4- faz~a, aor.
fazi3a , inf. n. faziyzN (S, O, K, TA) and faz~N, (TA,) said of a wound, It became moist, and flowed, (S, O, K, TA,) discharging its contents; and so faS~a: and in like manner it is said of water [app. as meaning it oozed forth]: (TA:) and of sweat, meaning It exuded; and so faS~a. (TA in art. fS.)

2 fz~zhu *
He (a man) rendered him powerful, or strong, and made him to overcome. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
4 A^afoza3a see 1, latter half.

8 Aftz~ *
He (a man, O) overcame; (K;) or was, or became, powerful, or strong, and overcame: (O:) and Abtz~ and Abt*~ signify the same: so in the Nawádir. (O, TA.)

10 Astfz~hu *
It (fear, S, A, O) excited him to lightness and unsteadiness; unsettled him. (S, A, O, K.) waA@sotafozizo mani A@sotaTaEta minohumo biSawotika, in the Kur [xvii. 66], is expl. by Fr as meaning And excite thou to lightness and unsteadiness, or unsettle thou, when thou canst, with thy voice. (O, TA.) And in like manner, waA_ino kaAduwA layasotafiz~uwnaka mina AlA^aroDi, in the same [xvii. 78], is expl. by him (O, TA) as meaning, And verily they were near to unsettling thee from the land: (TA:) but some say the meaning is, they were near to frightening thee so as to excite thee to promptness of flight from the land. (O, TA.) And Astfz~hu Eano raA^oyihi He incited him, or excited him, to ignorance, foolishness, or wrong conduct, and levity, or unsteadiness, so as to make him swerve from his right sentiment, opinion, or judgment; like Aisotaxaf~ahu En rA^yh. (Az and TA in art. xf.) ― -b2- He incited him, or excited him, to be promptly obedient and submissive to him and to that which he desired of him; like Astxf~hu. (Ksh in xliii. 54.) ― -b3- He expelled him (Jel in xvii. 105, and K) from the land, (Jel,) or from his abode, and disturbed, or disquieted, or unsettled, him, (K,) so as to excite him to lightness and unsteadiness. (TA.) [See also 1, latter half.] ― -b4- He, or it, deceived him, or beguiled him, so as to cast him into destruction. (TA.) ― -b5- He slew him: so the verb is expl. by some in the Kur xvii. 78, quoted above. (TA.)
faz~N * A light, or an active, man. (S, A, O, K.) ― -b2- And The offspring of the cow; (S;) [meaning,] of the wild cow: (O, K:) because of its restlessness: (TA:) pl. A^afozaAzN. (S, O, K.)

faz~apN *
A leap with disquietude [or fright]. (TA.)

qaEada musotafaz~FA * [so in a copy of the S, but without the vowel-signs: in two other copies of the same, musotawofizFA, which belongs to art. wfz:] He sat in an uneasy posture. (S.) ― -b2- farasN musotafiz~N lilowavobi waAlEadowi [so in two copies of the S, in art. Tmr; in the O, in that art., musotafiz~u Alwavobi waAlEadowi; probably a mistake for musotafaz~; app. meaning, A horse in a state of excitement to leap and run.]

1 fazara * , (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
fazura , (M, O, TA,) or
fazira , (Msb,) inf. n. fazorN, (S, * O, * Msb,) He rent, or slit, a garment, or piece of cloth: (K:) he dissundered (S, * O, * Msb) the same. (S, O.) ― -b2- He split, slit, or cracked, a thing. (S, O, TA.) ― -b3- He struck a man's nose with a thing so as to split it. (O, * TA.) ― -b4- He struck one with a stick, or staff: (TA:) or he struck him with a stick, or staff, on his back, (K, TA,) so as to break it. (TA.) ― -b5- He separated, disunited, sundered, or dispersed, a thing. (TA.) ― -b6- He separated, or divided, a thing from another thing. (TA.) ― -b7- He broke [a thing]. (Sh, O, Msb.) Sh says, I was in the desert, and, seeing some small round tents (qibaAb) pitched, I said to an Arab of the desert, “ To whom belong these qbAb ? ” and he answered, libaniY fazaArapa fazara A@ll~`hu Zuhuwrahumo: whereupon I said to him, “ What meanest thou by it? ” and he answered, “ [To Benoo-Fezárah:] may God break [their backs]. ” (TA.) ― -b8- He crumbled, or broke into small pieces, a jul~ap [or round piece of camel's or similar dung]; as also ↓ fz~r, (TA,) and ↓ Afzr. (O, K, TA. [In the CK, AlHul~ap is put for Aljul~ap.]) -A2- See also 5. -A3- Also, as implied in the K, but correctly fazira, aor.
fazara , inf. n. fazarN [q. v.], He was, or became, such as is termed A^afozar [expl. below]. (TA.)
2 faz~ara and 4: see 1, last signification but one.

5 tfz~r *
It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became rent, or slit; (K;) as also ↓ Anfzr; (O, * K;) and ↓ fazara, inf. n. fuzuwrN; (Msb; [but see fazarN, below;]) and so the like thereof; (Msb;) and the same is said of a wall: (TA:) and it (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became dissundered, ragged, tattered, or shabby, and old and worn out; (S, TA;) as also ↓ Anfzr. (TA.)
7 A_inofazara see 5, in two places.

fazorN * inf. n. of the trans. v. fazara. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And app. used as a simple subst., having for its pl. fuzuwrN: see fizarN.] -A2- [Also] A man possessing little, or no, good, or goodness; or little, or no, wealth; like nazorN. (AZ, TA in art. nzr.)

fizorN *
A flock of sheep, or herd of goats: (S, O:) or a flock of sheep from ten to forty: (AZ, A'Obeyd, S, O, K:) or from three to ten; thus in the copies of the K; but in the L, to twenty: (TA:) and two, and more: (S, O, K:) and hence, (S, O,) Alfizoru was a surname of Saad Ibn-ZeydMenáh: he came to the mawosim [or fair, and place of meeting, app. of the pilgrims,] with some goats, and allowed them to be taken as spoil, saying, “ Whoso takes of them one, it shall be his, but a fizor [i. e. a pair or more] of them shall not be taken; ” fizorN here meaning two and more: whence the prov., laA A=tiyka miEozaY Alfizori, meaning [I will not come to thee] until the goats of El-Fizr shall become gathered together; and [that means never, for] those goats will never become gathered together: (S, O, K:) or, accord. to ISd, this surname was given to him because he said to his sons, one after another, “ Pasture ye these goats, ” and they were incompliant to him; so he called to the people, “ Collect yourselves together; ” and they did so; and he said, “ Take ye them as spoil; but I do not allow to any one more than one; ” therefore they separated them at once, and they became scattered in the country: this was the origin of the prov.: and one of their provs. relating to leaving a thing undone is the saying, laA A^afoEalu *alika miEozaYAlfizori [I will not do that until the goats of El-Fizr shall become gathered together. (TA.) Accord. to AO, (S, O, TA,) fizorN means The kid (S, O, K, TA) itself: (S, O, TA:)
and one says, laAA^afoEaluhu maA nazaA fizorN [I will not do it as long as a kid leaps]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The male young one of the namir [or leopard]: (TA:) or the male young one of the [beast of prey called] babor [q. v.], (O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, bayor,]) as is said in the T, and likewise in the Tekmileh: (TA:) and fizorapN signifies the female young one thereof; (O, K, TA;) or, as some say, the sister thereof: (TA:) and ↓ fazaArapN signifies the female of the babor; (O, Msb, TA;) thus says IAar, (O,) [and] thus is said in the T: (TA:) or the mother of the babor is called fzArp; and also the female of the namir; (K, TA;) thus says IAar. (TA.) -A2- Also The A^Sol [or origin, &c.,] (O, K) of a thing. (O.) -A3- And A small thing, (O, K,) like a naboxap [or blister], in the root of the thigh, (O,) below the extremity of the pubes, resembling a gud~ap [or ganglion], from an ulcer that comes forth in a man, (O, K,) or from a wound. (O.)

fazarN * an inf. n. [of which the verb, accord. to a general rule, is fazira], A garment's being old and worn out; and rent, or slit. (KL. [See also 5, with which the verb fazara, inf. n. fuzuwrN, is mentioned in a similar sense.]) ― -b2- And [app. The being open, or wide, or broad,] meaning in Pers. frAx $dn. (KL.) -A2- Also The being such as is termed A^afozar [expl. below]. (S. [See 1, last sentence.])

fizarN *
Slits, rents, or fissures: (K:) but this word perhaps occurred to the author of the K mistranscribed; for it is said in the L that fuzuwrN [a pl. of which the sing. is app. fazorN, originally an inf. n.,] signifies slits, rents, or fissures, and clefts, or cracks. (TA.)
fuzorapN * : see faAzirN. -A2- Also A great protuberance upon the back, or upon the chest. (K.)
fazaArapN * : see fizorN, last quarter of the paragraph.

faAzirN * A wide road; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ fuzorapN: (O, K:) or a wide and conspicuous road: or, accord. to ISh, a road that passes over the [eminences termed] nijaAf [pl. of najafN] and the [hills, or small mountains termed] quwr [pl. of qaArapN], and cleaves them as though it made furrows upon their heads: you say, A^axa*onaAAlfaAzira and A^axa*onaATariyqa AlfaAziri, meaning [We took] the road that made a track upon the heads and the base of the mountains. (TA.) And ↓ faAzirapN [or TariyqN faAzirapN] signifies A road taking its course in a tract of sand amid sands that are compact and cleaving to the ground, (K, TA,) and soft; appearing like an extended, long, natural cleft in the ground: (TA:) the same meaning is also assigned to faArizapN. (K * and TA in art. frz.) -A2- Also A species of ants, (O,) black ants, (K,) in which is a redness: (O, K:) mentioned also among words of which the final radical is z [as being called faArizN]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The round black thing [app. a species of animalcule] found in [dried] dates. (O.)
faAzirapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^afozaru * and ↓ mafozuwrN A man humpbacked; (S, O;) having a great protuberance upon his back; (S, O, K:) or having such a protuberance upon his chest: (K:) or, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, the former signifies the same as A^aqoEasu [having a protuberant breast, or chest, and a hollow, or receding, back]. (O. [See also A^aforazu.]) ― -b2- And [the fem. of the former] fazoraA='u A female, (K,) or girl, or young woman, (TA,) full of fat and flesh: or that has nearly attained to puberty. (K, TA.)
mafozuwru AlA^anofi * A man having his nose struck with a thing so as to be split. (TA.) -A2- See also A^afozaru.

1 faziEa * , (S, O, Msb, K,) and fazaEa, (K,) aor.
fazaEa , of the former verb, (Msb, K,) and of the latter also, (K,) inf. n. fazaEN, (S, O, Msb, K,) which is of the former verb, (S, * O, Msb, TA,) and [of the latter verb] fazoEN [fazaEFA in the CK being a mistake for fazoEFA] and ?? (K, TA,) He feared; or was, or became, in fear, afraid, frightened, or terrified; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) and so ↓ tfz~E: (TA in art. rwE:) you say, faziEa minohu he feared him, or it; or was, or became, in fear, &c., of him, or it: (MA, Msb, TA:) accord. to Er-Rághib, fazaEN signifies a shrinking, and an aversion, that comes upon a man, from a thing causing fear or fright; and is a kind of jazaE [q. v.]; and one should not say faziEotu mina A@ll~`hi like as one says xifotu minohu: or, as Mbr says, in the “ Kámil, ” its primary signification is the fearing, or being in fear or afraid or frightened or terrified: then, by a metonymical application, it signifies a people's going forth quickly to repel an enemy, or the like, that has come upon them suddenly; and this meaning has become [conventionally regarded as] proper. (TA.) ― -b2- fazaEN signifies also The seeking, or demanding, aid, or succour: (Az, K, TA:) and the aiding, or succouring; (Az, S, O, K, TA;) this latter being likewise a signification of ↓ A_ifozaAEN: (S, O:) an ex. of the former word (S, O, TA) in the latter sense (O, TA) occurs in the saying of the Prophet to the Ansár, A_in~akumo latakovuruwna Einoda AlfazaEi wa taqil~uwna Einoda AlT~amaEi [Verily ye are many on the occasion of aiding, or succouring, and ye are few on the occasion of coveting, or greed]; (S, O, TA;) or in this saying the implied meaning may be, on the occasion of men's betaking themselves to you in fear (Einoda fazaEi Aln~aAsi A_ilayokumo) in order that ye may aid or succour them [which is virtually the same as their seeking your aid or succour]: (TA:) thus [it is said] fazaEN has two contr. significations: (K:) and both of these significations are expressed by the verb faziEa: (O:) you say faziEa A_ilayohi and faziEa minohu; (K in continuation of what has been last cited therefrom above, and TA; [app. meant to indicate that both of these phrases signify he sought, or demanded, aid, or succour, of him; and he aided, or succoured, him; or that the former phrase has the former signification; and the latter phrase, the latter signification; though accord. to the TK, both phrases have the former signification, and the former phrase has also the latter signification;]) but you should not say fazaEahu, (K, TA,) i. e. like manaEahu: (TA:) [or] from AlfazaEu as signifying “ fear, ” or “ fright, ” you say faziEotu A_ilayoka and faziEotu minoka; [app. meant to indicate that the former phrase signifies I betook myself to thee in fear, which is a meaning thereof well known, and nearly agreeing with an explanation of the verb followed by A_ilayohi which will be found below in this paragraph; and that the latter phrase signifies I feared thee, or I was, or became, in fear, &c., of thee, the only meaning, of this phrase, for which I find any explicit authority, and one for which I have given three authorities in the first sentence of this art.;] but you should not say faziEotuka: (S: [thus in my copies, faziEotuka, not fazaEotuka:]) or faziEa A_ilayohimo signifies he sought, or demanded, of them, aid, or succour; and fazaEahumo and faziEahumo signify he aided, or succoured, them, syn. A^agaAvahumo [in the CK AaEAnahumo] and naSarahumo, like ↓ A^afozaEahumo: (K, TA:) accord. to IB, faziEotuhu meaning A^agavotuhu is originally faziEotu lh [primarily signifying I feared, or became in fear &c., for him]; then the l was dropped; for one says faziEotuhu and faziEotu lahu: (TA:) or faziEa, like fariHa, signifies AinotaSara: (K: [thus in the copies of the K, and hence in the TA, app. a mistranscription for AisotanoSara, he sought, or demanded, aid, or aid against an enemy:]) and faziEa A_ilayohi he betook himself, or had recourse, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, or preservation, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) by reason of fear, or fright, (S,) and sought, or demanded, aid, or succour, by him, or it; whence, in a trad. respecting the eclipse of the sun, faA@fozaEuwAA_ilaY AlS~alaAp i. e. Then betake yourselves, &c., to prayer, and seek, or demand, aid, or succour, by it. (TA.) ― -b3- faziEa mino nawomihi means He became roused from his sleep; (O, K;) because he who is roused is not free from some fear, or fright: occurring in a trad. in this sense. (O.) And one says, faziEotu bimajiYo'i fulaAnK, meaning I prepared [or roused] myself by reason of the coming of such a one, by a change of state, or condition, like as the sleeper passes from the state of sleeping to that of waking. (TA.) -A2- fazaEahu in the phrase fafazaEahu ↓ faAzaEahu means He exceeded him in fear, or fright. (TA.) -A3- fuziEa Eano quluwbihimo: see the next paragraph.

2 fz~Ehu * : see 4. ― -b2- [It also app. signifies He made a fearful event, or fearful events, to befall him: see its pass. part. n. below.] ― -b3- faz~aEa Eanohu He removed from him fear, or fright: (O, in two places:) it is implied by the context in the K that Enh ↓ AfzE has this meaning; but in the O and other lexicons it is faz~aEa. (TA.) And fuz~iEa Eanohu, (S, K,) inf. n. tafoziyEN, (K,) Fear, or fright, was removed from him. (S, K.) It is said in the
Kur [xxxiv. 22], Hat~aY A_i*aAfuz~iEa Eano quluwbihimo, meaning Until, when fear, or fright, shall be removed from their hearts: (S, O:) this is the common reading: another reading is faz~aEa, i. e. faz~aEa A@ll~`hu: and El-Hasan reads ↓ fuziEa: and he says that in this reading and the first, the prep. with its noun are [regarded as supplying the place of the agent and therefore virtually] in the nom. case, as in the phrase siyra Eani Albaladi: (TA:) some read fur~iga [q. v.]: (O and TA in art. frg:) and 'Eesà Ibn- 'Omar is related to have read A_i*aA A@foranoqaEa. (TA in art. frqE.)
3 fAzEhu fafazaEahu * [He vied with him in fear, or fright,] and he exceeded him therein. (TA. See 1, last sentence but one.)

4 AfzEhu * , (Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ifozaAEN, (S, O,) He made him to fear, or to be afraid; frightened him; or terrified him; (S, * O, * Msb, K;) as also ↓ fz~Ehu, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafoziyEN. (S, O.) And you say, yufozaEu minohu [One is made to fear, or be afraid of, or is frightened, or terrified, at, it, or him], (S, O, K,) and mino A^ajolihi [on account of him, or for the sake of him], (O, K,) and bihi [by him, or by means of him]. (O.) ― -b2- [Hence,] He housed him from his sleep. (K, TA. [See 1, last quarter.]) ― -b3- Also He aided, or succoured, him. (S, K.) See 1, former half; and again, in the latter half. ― -b4- See also 2.
5 tafaz~aEa see 1, first sentence.

fazaEN *
Fear, or fright: (S, O, K:) originally (S) an inf. n.; but notwithstanding this, (S, * O, K,) sometimes, (S, O,) having a pl., which is A^afozaAEN. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- [And, as seems to be indicated by an explanation of mufaz~aEN (q. v.), A fearful event: pl. as above.]

faziEN *
Fearing; being afraid or frightened or terrified; (Er-Rághib, MA, Msb, TA;) thus in a verse cited voce ZunobuwbN; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and ↓ mufaAziEN is syn. therewith: (O, K:) and one says also ↓ rajulN faAziEN, pl. fazaEapN; and ↓ mafozuwEN; meaning a man put in fear; made afraid; frightened, or terrified. (TA.) And In a state of disquiet, disturbance, or agitation: whence an extraordinary reading, of four readers, in the Kur xxviii. 9, [i. e. faziEFA] for faArigFA, relating to the heart of the mother of Moses, meaning in a state of disquiet, &c., almost quitting its pericardium. (TA.) It has no broken pl.; its only pl. being faziEuwna. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Seeking, or demanding, aid, or succour; and Sgh thus explains it [in the O] as used in the verse above mentioned; but Er-Rághib says that this is an explanation of the intended meaning, not of the literal signification: (TA:) and it has also the contr. meaning, aiding, or succouring; thus being trans., though of the measure faEilN; but it may be altered from ↓ faAziEN, like as Ha*irN is [said to be] altered from HaA*irN. (IB, TA,)
fazoEapN * : see fazaEapN.

fuzoEapN * A man whom one is made to fear, of whom one is made afraid, or at whom one is frightened: (O, K:) [like mafozaEapN as expl. by Lth and others:] and by whom, or by means of whom, one is made afraid, or frightened. (O.)

fazaEapN * sing. of fazaEaAt in the phrase fazaEaAtu Alr~uwEi [app. meaning The fears, or frights, of the heart]. (TA. [The sing., as well as the pl., is there said to be thus, biAlt~aHoriyk; but if the former be, as I think it is, an inf. n. un., it should by rule be ↓ fazoEapN.])
fuzaEapN * One who fears men, or is frightened at them: (K:) or one who fears, or is frightened, much, or often; (O;) [and] so ↓ faz~aAEapN. (TA. [But see what next follows.])

faz~aAEapN *
One who makes men to fear, or frightens them, much, or often. (O, K.) See also fuzaEapN.
faAzigN * : see faziEN, in two places.

mafozaEN *
i. q. malojaA^o [as meaning A refuge, i. e. a place to which, or a person to whom, one betakes himself, or has recourse, for refuge, protection, or preservation,] (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) on the occasion of the befalling of an affliction or a calamity; (TA;) applied to a sing. and a pl. (S, O, K) and a dual (S, O) and a masc. and a fem.; (S, O, K;) one says, fulaAnN mafozaEN liln~aAsi Such a one is a refuge to men when an event comes upon them suddenly, and humaAmafozaEN liln~aAsi, and humo mafozaEN, &c.; (S, O;) and ↓ mafozaEapN is the same in signification and in its applications; (K;) expl. by IF as signifying a place to which one who is in fear, or frightened, betakes himself, or has recourse, for refuge, protection, or preservation: (TA:) or mafozaEN signifies one of whom aid, or succour, is sought, or demanded: (K:) and ↓ mafozaEapN, [a cause of fear or fright; being a word of the class of maboxalapN and majobanapN; i. e.] a thing that one is made to fear, or at which one is frightened; (S;) or a person whom one is made to fear, or at whom one is frightened; [like fuzoEapN;] or on account of whom, or for the sake of whom, one is made to fear, or is frightened: (Lth, O, K:) you say, fulaAnN lanaA mafozaEapN [Such a one is to us a person whom we are made to fear, &c.], and in like manner you say of a female, and of a pl. number. (O.)
mafozaEapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

mufaz~aEN *
Cowardly; (Fr, O, K;) as being made to fear, or to be frightened at, everything: (Fr, O:) and courageous; (Fr, O, K;) as being one the like of whom fearful events are made to befall (bimivolihi tunozalu AlA^afozaAEu). (Fr, O. [But what here follows suggests another reason, and I think a better, for the latter meaning.]) mufaz~aEapN applied by 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib as an epithet to his Aisot, in replying to a threat of El-Ash-'ath, who had said to him, lawo danawota laA^uDar~iTan~aka, means Secure from being overcome by fear, or fright, and [therefore] not lax so as to break wind [in consequence of fear]; being from faz~aEa Eanohu meaning “ he removed fear, or fright, from him; ” or it may be for the same reason as that for which mufaz~aEN is applied to a courageous man. (O.)
mafozuwEN * : see faziEN, first sentence.
mufaAziEN * : see faziEN, first sentence.

fisofisapN *
i. q. fiSofiSapN, i. e. raTobapN: (K:) the second of these is more known than the first; both of which are arabicized, from the Persian A_isoPisot [or A_isofisot]. (TA.)

1 fasaA^ahu * : see 2. ― -b2- Also, (M, K,) or fasaA^ahu biAlEaSaA, (AZ, O,) aor.
fasaAa , inf. n. faso'N, (M,) He struck, or beat, (AZ, M, O, K,) him, (O,) or his back, (AZ, M, K,) with the staff, or stick; (AZ, M, O, K;) as also ↓ tfs~A^hu, (K,) or tfs~A^hu bAlESA. (O.) ― -b3- And fasaA^a fulaAnFA Eanohu He restrained, withheld, or debarred, such a one from him. (O, * K.) -A2- fasiy^a, aor.
fasaAa , [inf. n., app., fasaA^N, q. v. infrà,] He was, or became, such as is termed A^afosaA^u [q. v.]. (K.)

2 fs~A^hu * , namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, M, O, K,) inf. n. tafosiy^apN (S, O) and tafosiYo'N, (S,) He stretched it so that it rent, or became ragged, or dissundered: (S, O:) or he rent it; as also ↓ fasaA^ahu, aor.
fasaAa , (M, K,) inf. n. faso'N (M.)

5 tfs~A^ * , said of a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, M, O, K,) It became ragged, or dissundered, (S, O,) and worn out: (S:) like tqD~A^, or tfS~A^: (accord. to different copies of the S: the latter in the L:) or it became rent. (M, O.) ― -b2- tfs~A^ fiyhimo, (K,) or bihimo, (O,) said of a disease, It spread among them, (O, K,) and became common among them: (TA:) like tf$~A^. (O, K.) -A2- tfs~A^: see 1.
6 tfAsA^ * , and tfAsY, (M, O, TA,) He (a man) protruded (M, O, TA) his posteriors, (M,) or his back, (O,) or both. (TA.)
fasaA^N * a subst. signifying The state of such as is termed A^afosaA^u [q. v.]: (M, TA:) or a hollowness, or incurvity, of the spine. (TA in art. fqA^.) [See also 1, last sentence.]

A^afosaA^u *
i. q. A^abozaxu [i. e. Having a protuberant breast, or chest, and hollow back; &c.]: or having a protuberant breast, or chest, and the lower part of the belly prominent: (M, K:) fem. fasaA='u: (M:) and (M, in the K “ or ”) he who, when he walks, is as though his posteriors were in pain (in the M tawojaEu; in some copies of the K tawaj~aEu [as though for tatawaj~aEu], and in some yrjE); as also ↓ mafosuwo'N: (M, K:) or he who, when he sits, cannot rise but with an effort: (O, K:) or whose spine enters into [or turns inwards between] his haunches. (K.)
mafosuwo'N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

div2.head: fst and fstT
div2.entryFree: fusotaAtN * , also written fisotaAtN: see fusoTaATN.

fusotaATN * , also written fisotaATN: see fusoTaATN, in art. fsT, to which it belongs; for the t is a substitute for the [former] T in fsTAT, or for the [latter] s in fis~aATN. (M and TA in art. fsT.)

fusotuqN * and fusotaqN, (O, Msb, K,) the latter the more agreeable with the original, (O,) which is Pisotah, (O, K,) a Pers. word, (O,) for from this each is arabicized; (O, Msb, * K;) [The pistachio-nut, pistacia vera of Linn.;] a certain fruit; (O;) [in the Msb bql; perhaps a mistranscription for nql, i. e. naqolN, a certain fruit that is eaten with wine;] well known: (K:) said in a verse of Aboo-Nukheyleh to be mina Albuquwli: thus, and thus only, with b, the phrase is related: if it were mn Aln~uquwli, the mistake would be removed: (O:) Az says that the fstqp [which is the n. un.] is a fruit of a well-known tree: and AHn says, “ It has not come to my knowledge that it grows in the land of the Arabs: ” (TA:) it is good for the liver, and the mouth of the stomach, and the colic, and the odour of the mouth. (K. [In the CK, Aln~ahakapi is put for Aln~akohapi.]) The vulgar pronounce the word with fet-h [to the f, saying fasotuq: and many of them say fisotuq]. (Msb.)
vawobN fusotuqiY~N * [meaning A garment of the colour of the fusotuq] is [thus] with damm [to the f and t]. (Msb.)

1 fasuHa * , (MA, Msb, K, [in the CK fasaHa, a misprint,]) with damm, (Msb,) like karuma, (K,) [aor.
fasuHa ,] inf. n. fusaAHapN, (L,) or fasaAHapN [for which the former is app. a mistranscription] and fusoHapN, (MA,) It (a place) was, or became, spacious, roomy, wide, or ample; (MA, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AfsH, (Msb, K,) and ↓ tfs~H, and ↓ AnfsH. (K.) -A2- fasaHa lahu, (S, MA, Msb, K,) aor.
fasaHa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. fasoHN (MA, Msb, TA) and fusuwHN; (TA;) as also ↓ tfs~H, (A, K,) and ↓ AfsH; (A;) He made room, or ample room, for him, (S, MA, Msb, K,) fiY Almajolisi (S, MA, Msb) in the sitting-place, or in the assembly. (MA.) You say, fiY Almajolisi ↓ tafas~aHuwA, (S, Msb, *) and ↓ tafaA saHuwA, (S, K,) Make ye room, or ample space, [in the sitting-place, or in the assembly,] syn. tawas~aEuwA: (S, K:) both of these verbs have nearly the same signification: [each may be rendered, but the latter more properly, make ye room, or ample space, one for another:] the latter occurs, accord. to the reading of El-Hasan, and the former accord. to that of others, in the Kur lviii. 12. (Fr, TA.) ― -b2- And AifosaHo Ean~iY Remove thou, withdraw, or retire to a distance, from me. (Ksh and Bd in lviii. 12.) ― -b3- fasoHN [as inf. n. of fasaHa] also signifies The making wide steps; and so fayosaHaY. (K.) [Hence,] AifosaHi AlxuTaY, said by an Arab of the Desert, of the Benoo-'Okeyl, to one who was sewing for him a water-skin, and mentioned in the T, as heard by its author, meaning (assumed tropical:) Make wide the spaces between each two punctures of the needle, lest the punctures should rend. (L.) ― -b4- And fasaHa lahu AlA^amiyru fiY Als~afari means The commander, or governor, wrote for him a fasoH [q. v.]. (K.)

2 fs~H *
He made a place spacious, roomy, wide, or ample. (Msb.)
4 A^afosaHa see 1, first and second sentences.
5 tafas~aHa see 1, in three places. ― -b2- [tfs~H also signifies He expatiated, or ranged at large: and he had ample room or scope: see mutafas~aHN.]
6 tafaAosaHa see 1, third sentence.

7 A_inofasaHa see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] AnfsH muraAHuhumo [lit. The nightly resting-place of their camels was, or became, spacious,] means (assumed tropical:) their camels became numerous. (TA.) ― -b3- And AnfsH Sadoruhu (assumed tropical:) His bosom became dilated [with joy]. (S, A.) ― -b4- And AnfsH Tarofuhu (assumed tropical:) His eye had an unobstructed view, nothing hindering its seeing far. (L.)
Q. Q. 2 tafayosaHa * : see tafayoHasa, in art. fHs.

fasoHN *
A writing like a jawaAz [or traveller's pass]. (K.) [See 1, last sentence.]
fusuHN * : see fasiyHN, in three places.

fusoHapN *
Spaciousness, roominess, width, or ampleness; (S, A, L, K;) [particularly, or generally,] with respect to the ground. (L.) [In the MA it is mentioned as an inf. n. of fasuHa.] ― -b2- And [Ample scope for action &c.] in an affair. (Msb in art. rxw.) [And A state in which is ample scope for acting &c.: see nafasN.] ― -b3- AlfusoHataAni signifies The two spaces without hair on the two sides of the hair that grows immediately beneath the middle of the lower lip. (L.)

fusoHumN * : see fasiyHN, in two places. ― -b2- fulaAnN A@bonu fusoHumK is a phrase mentioned by Lh, thought by him to be from AlfusoHapu and AlAinofisaAHu, but the meaning is unknown. (L.) -A2- Also The glans of the penis. (K in art. fsHm; where the word is mentioned again in the S likewise.)
fusaAHN * : see the paragraph here following.

fasiyHN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ fusaAHN, (K,) like TawiylN and TuwaAlN, (TA,) Spacious, roomy, wide, or ample; applied to a place; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ fusuHN and ↓ fusoHumN: (K:) or ↓ fusuHN signifies thus applied to a sitting-place: (S:) and ↓ fusoHumN, (S, K,) in which the m is augmentative, (S,) signifies (S, K) also (K) waAsiEu AlS~adori [meaning free from distress of mind or from narrowness of mind], (S, K,) as does also ↓ fusuHN [in the CK in this sense written fusoHN]; both being applied in this sense to a man. (K.) ― -b2- sayorN fasiyHN [means A pace in which the steps are wide: see 1, latter half].

jamalN mafosuwHu AlD~uluwEi *
i. q. masofuwH [i. e. A camel wide in the ribs]. (TA.)
maA laka fiY h`*aA mutafas~aHN * [There is not for thee ample scope (lit. a place in which one has ample scope) in this]. (A.)
munofasaHN waAdK * [The place of expanding of a valley]. (JK and K in art. xrq, &c.)
muraAHN munofasiHN * (assumed tropical:) A nightly resting-place of camels, or of camels and other cattle, in which they are numerous. (As, K.)

1 fasaxa * , (S, A, L, K,) aor.
fasaxa , (S, L, K,) inf. n. fasoxN; (S, L;) and ↓ fs~x; (L; [but this has an intensive signification;]) He dislocated, luxated, or disjointed, (A, L, K,) one's arm, or hand, (S, A, L, K,) or a limb, without breaking: (L:) [and] fasaxotu AlmafoSila Eano mawoDiEihi I removed the joint from its place. (Msb.) ― -b2- And the former v., aor. and inf. n. as above, He removed a stick, or twig, or branch, from its place with his hand. (Msb.) ― -b3- And the same v., (S, Msb,) aor. as above, (A,) and so the inf. n., (K,) He cast, or cast off, (S, Msb, K,) a garment, (S, Msb,) or his garments. (A.) You say, fasaxotu Ean~iY vawobiY I cast, or cast off, from me my garment. (S.) ― -b4- And the same v., (L, Msb,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (K,) He separated, disunited, sundered, dissundered, or dispersed, (L, Msb, K,) a thing.
