(L, Msb.) ― -b5- Also, the same verb, (S, A, L, Msb,) aor. as above, (L,) and so the inf. n., (L, Msb, K,) (tropical:) He undid, dissolved, or annulled, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) a sale, (S, A, L, Msb,) and a determination, resolution, or decision, (S,) and a marriage, (S, A, L,) and a contract, compact, or covenant, and an affair. (Msb.) ― -b6- And the same v., (L, Msb,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (L, K,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, Msb) corrupted, or disordered, the judgment, or opinion. (L, Msb, K.) -A2- fasixa, aor.
fasaxa , (L, K,) inf. n. fasaxN; (L;) or fasaxa, this v. being intrans. as well as trans.; (Msb;) (assumed tropical:) It (the judgment, or opinion,) was, or became, corrupt, or disordered. (L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [And, accord. to the TK, fasixa, (but this I think to be a mistake for fasaxa,) inf. n. fasoxN, signifies DaEufa ((assumed tropical:) He was, or became, weak, app. in intellect and in body; see fasoxN below); said of a man: and jahila (app. intrans., meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, ignorant; but accord. to the TK trans., meaning he knew not a thing).] ― -b3- In the conventional language of the philosophers, Alfasoxu [as an inf. n.] signifies (assumed tropical:) The transmigration of the rational soul of a human being from his body to [some one of] the inanimate,
not increasing, bodies, such as the minerals, or metals, and the simple elements: (Dict. of Technical Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans:) or, to a plant: the former meaning being that of Alr~asoxu. (So in a marginal note in a copy of the TK.)
2 fas~axa see the preceding paragraph, first sentence.
3 fAsxhu AlbayoEa * (tropical:) [He agreed with him in undoing, dissolving, or annulling, the sale]. (A. [See 6.])
4 Afsx AlquroA=na * (assumed tropical:) He forgot the Kur-án. (Fr, S.)

5 tafas~axa see 7, in two places. ― -b2- tfs~x Al$~aEaru Eani Aljilodi The hair fell off and became scattered from the skin, peculiarly of a dead body: (L, K:) and in like manner, All~aHomu Eani AlEaZomi the flesh from the bone. (A, L.) And tafas~axati AlfaA^arapu fiY AlmaA='i The rat, or mouse, became dissundered, [or fell in pieces, through putrefaction,] in the water. (S.) ― -b3- tfs~x taHota AlHimoli Alv~aqiyli, said of a [young camel such as is termed] rubaE, (S, K, *) He was, or became, weak beneath the heavy load, (K,) and unable to bear it: (S, K:) and [in like manner] one says of a man, tfs~x taHota AlEibo'i Alv~aqiyli. (A.)

6 tfAsxwA AlEaqoda * (assumed tropical:) They agreed together in undoing, dissolving, or annulling, the contract, compact, or covenant. (Msb.) And tfAsxA AlbayoEa (tropical:) [They two agreed in dissolving, or annulling, the sale]. (A.) ― -b2- And tfAsxt AlA^aqaAwiylu (tropical:) The sayings annulled, or contradicted, one another. (TA.)

7 Anfsx *
It (a limb, L, such as an arm, or a hand, A, L) became dislocated, luxated, or disjointed; (A, L;) as also ↓ tfs~x. (L.) One says, waqaEa fulaAnN faA@nofasaxato qadamuhu Such a one fell, and his foot became dislocated. (L. [And the like is said in the A.]) ― -b2- It (a stick, or twig, or branch,) became removed from its place by the hand. (Msb.) ― -b3- It (flesh) became dissundered by putrefaction; as also ↓ tfs~x. (L.) ― -b4- And, said of a sale, (S, A, K,) and a determination, resolution, or decision, (S, K,) and a marriage, (S, A, K,) [and a contract, compact, or covenant, (see 1,)] and an affair, (L,) (tropical:) It became undone, dissolved, or annulled. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b5- Also said of a weak man, [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) He became unnerved,] on an occasion of difficulty. (L: see fasiyxN.)

fasoxN * [mentioned above as the inf. n. of 1 in most of its senses] (assumed tropical:) Weakness (L, K) in intellect and in body; as also ↓ fasoxapN. (L.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Ignorance: (K:) which is referrible to weakness of intellect. (TA.) -A2- And (assumed tropical:) Weak in intellect and in body; as also ↓ fasoxapN. (K.) ― -b2- See also fasiyxN.
fasixN * (assumed tropical:) A corrupt, or disordered, judgment, or opinion. (L.)
fasoxapN * : see fasoxN, in two places.

fasiyxN * [applied to flesh-meat, Parting in pieces, and easily resolvable, by reason of much cooking. (Golius, from Meyd.) ― -b2- And] (assumed tropical:) A weak man, who becomes unnerved (↓ yanofasixu) on an accasion of difficulty: (L:) a man who does not attain that which he wants, (S, L, K,) and is not fit for his affair, or business; as also ↓ fasoxN [q. v.]. (K.)

vawobN faAsixN * [(assumed tropical:) A faded garment: so in the language of the present day: perhaps post-classical]. (A in art. rmd.) -A2- [AlfaAsixu is a name given by the Jews to their festival of The Passover: see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 291, and p. 97 of the Ar. text: and see also AlfiSoHu.]

1 fasada * , aor.
fasuda , (S, M, A, O, L, Msb, K, &c.,) which is the aor. commonly known, (TA,) and
fasida , (IDrd, M, O, L, K,) which is of weak authority; (IDrd, O, TA;) and fasuda, aor.
fasuda ; (S, M, O, L, K;) inf. n. fasaAdN (S. M, A, O, L, K) and fusuwdN, (M, O, L, K,) the former being inf. n. of fasada, aor.
fasuda , (S, A, O,) and so the latter, and the former being also inf. n. of fasuda, (O,) or the former is of fasuda and the latter is of fasada, (TA,) or the former is a simple subst., and the latter is the inf. n.; (Msb;) It (a thing, S, A, O) [and he (a man)] was, or became, bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; devoid of virtue, or efficacy; in a corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, injured, impaired, deteriorated, tainted, or infected, state; in a state of disorder or disturbance, destruction, annihilation, consumption, waste, or ruin; (MA, KL, PS, &c.;) and so ↓ Astfsd: (KL:) contr. of SalaHa: (M, * L, K:) it became altered in its state [for the worse]: and it became null, void, of no force, or of no account; or it came to nought, or perished; accord. to the explanation by most of the expositors of the ex. in the Kur xxi. 22. (MF.)
2 fas~ada see 4, first sentence.

3 fAsdhu *
He became at variance with him; he cut, severed, or broke, the tie of friendship [or kindred] with him. (L in art. k$H.) And fulaAnN yufaAsidu rahoTahu [Such a one cuts the ties of friendship, or kindred, with his people, tribe, or near kinsfolk]. (A.)

4 Afsd * , (S, M, O, L, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. A_fosaAdN and [quasi-inf.n.] fasaAdN; (L;) and ↓ fs~d, (O, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafosiydN; (O, K;) He, or it, made, or rendered, bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; deprived of virtue, or efficacy; corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, injured, impaired, deteriorated, tainted, or infected; [constituted, disposed, arranged, or qualified, ill, wrongly, or improperly;] disordered, or disturbed, [disorganized,] destroyed, annihilated, consumed, wasted, or ruined; (MA, KL, &c.;) contr. of A^SolaHa. (M, L, K.) One says, Afsd AlmaAla [He rendered the property in a bad state; marred, impaired, consumed, or wasted, it]. (L.) [And Afsd Ealayohimo He corrupted, perverted, or marred, their state, case, affair, scheme, plot, or the like; A^amorahumo, or the like, being understood. And Afsdhu EalaY~a He corrupted him and rendered him disaffected towards me.] A_ifosaAdu SabiY~K, occurring in a trad., means The injuring a child by rendering its mother pregnant while she is suckling it and so vitiating her milk: which act is also termed Algiylahu. (L.) [And Afsd as contr. of A^aSolaHa signifies also He acted in a bad, an evil, or a corrupt, manner; acted ill, corruptly, wrongly, wrongfully, improperly, unrighteously, wickedly, vitiously, or dishonestly; or did evil, or mischief; A_ilayohi to him: and he created, or excited, disorder, disturbance, disagreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrel-ling; or made, or did, mischief; bayona Alqawomi between, or among, the people, or party. (See also 10.)]

6 tfAsdwA *
They became at variance, one with another; (M, L;) they cut, severed, or broke, the tie of kindred, (M, L, K,) and of friendship, (L,) one with another. (M, L, K.)
7 Anfsd * [as quasi-pass. of A^afosadahu] is not allowable, (S, L,) or has not been heard. (K.)

10 Astfsd *
contr. of AisotaSolaHa. (S, O, L, K.) [Hence, He regarded, or esteemed, a thing, or man, as bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; &c.: see 1. ― -b2- And] He wished, or desired, [a thing, or man,] to be bad, evil, corrupt, &c. (KL.) ― -b3- [And He sought to render bad, evil, corrupt, &c. ― -b4- And hence, He treated in such a manner as to render disaffected, or rebellious.] One says, AlA^amiyru yasotafosidu raEiy~atahu [The prince, or governor, treats his subjects in such a manner as to render them disaffected, or rebel-lious]. (A.) And AstfsdAls~uloTaAnu qaAy^idahu The Sultán provoked the leader of his forces to rebel-lion by his evil conduct to him. (L.) ― -b5- [And He sought to act in a bad, an evil, or a corrupt, manner; to act ill, corruptly, wrongly, wrongfully, improperly, unrighteously, or dishonestly.] One says, Astfsd fulaAnN A_ilaY fulaAnK [Such a one sought to act in a bad, an evil, or a corrupt, manner, or to act ill, &c., to such a one]. (M.) ― -b6- [And He sought discord, or dissension. ― -b7- And It (an event) happened in a bad, or an evil, manner.] ― -b8- See also 1.

fasaAdN * an inf. n. of 1: (S, M, A, &c.:) or a simple subst.: (Msb:) [as a subst. signifying] Badness, evilness, corruptness, unsoundness, wrongness, wrongfulness, impropriety, unrighteousness, wickedness, vitiousness, depravity, or dishonesty; the state of being devoid of virtue or efficacy; a corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, deteriorated, or tainted, state; a state of disorder or disturbance, or of destruction, annihilation, consumption, waste, or ruin: (MA, KL, PS, &c.:) contr. of SalaAHN. (Lth, M, Msb.) And it is also [frequently used as a quasi-inf. n.] syn. with A_ifosaAdN
[signifying The making, or rendering, bad, evil, corrupt, &c.: (see 4:) and, oftener, the acting ill, corruptly, wrong, wrongfully, improperly, unrighteously, wickedly, vitiously, or dishonestly; doing evil, or mischief; and creating, or exciting, disorder, disturbance, disagreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrelling]: (L:) and [particularly] the taking property wrongfully. (O, K.) [Hence,] Harobu AlfasaAdi [The war of evildoing]: thus was termed a war that happened between [the two sub-tribes] banuw$k [in which the latter word is app. a mistranscription for $ibokK] and gawov, of the tribe of TaY~i': it was so termed because one party patched their sandals with the cars of the other, and one party drank wine out of the skulls of the other. (MF.) ― -b2- Also Drought, barrenness, dearth, or scarcity of good: (M, L, K:) so in the Kur [xxx. 40], Zahara A@lofasaAdu fiY Albar~i wa A@lobaHori i. e. Drought, &c., hath appeared in the land, and in the cities that are upon the rivers; (M, L, TA;) accord. to Zj; (M;) or accord. to Ez-Zejjájee. (L, TA.)
fasiydN * : see the next paragraph.

faAsidN * , (S, M, A, O, L, Msb, K, &c.,) part. n. of fasada; (S, M, A, &c.;) and ↓ fasiydN, (S, M, O, L, K,) part. n. of fasuda; (S, O;) Bad, evil, corrupt, unsound, wrong, wrongful, improper, unrighteous, wicked, vitious, depraved, or dishonest; devoid of virtue, or efficacy; in a corrupted, vitiated, perverted, marred, spoiled, injured, impaired, deteriorated, tainted, or infected, state; in a state of disorder or disturbance, destruction, annihilation, consumption, waste, or ruin: (MA, KL, PS, &c.: [contr. of SaAliHN and SaliyHN, as is indicated in the S and M &c.:]) pl. (of the former, S, O, Msb, [dev. from general analogy, and of the latter agreeably therewith,]) fasodaY, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) applied to a people, (S, M, O,) like as they said saAqiTN and saqoTaY; (S, O;) the pl. being made of the same form as halokaY because these two words are nearly the same in meaning. (Sb, M.)

A^afosadu * is [a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees] from AlfasaAdu; as in the prov., A^afosadu mino bayoDapi Albaladi i. e. [More corrupt, or unsound, &c.,] than the egg that the ostrich leaves in the desert, not returning to it, in consequence of which it becomes corrupt, or unsound, &c.: and, anomalously, from AlA_ifosaAdu; as in the prov., A^afosada mina AljaraAdi [i. e. More corrupting, or marring, &c., than the locust], because it strips the trees and the herbage; and as in other provs. (Meyd.)

mafosadapN *
A cause, or means, or an occasion, of fasaAd [i. e. badness, evilness, corruptness, unsoundness, &c.; or making, or rendering, bad, evil, corrupt, &c.]; (M, A;) contr. of maSolaHapN: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. mafaAsidu. (A, Msb.) One says, h`*aA AlA^amori mafosadapN lika*aA [This affair, or event, is cause of evil, &c., to such a thing]. (M.) And humo mino A^aholi AlmafaAsidi laA AlmaSaAliHi [They are of the people who do actions that are causes of evil, not actions that are causes of good]. (A.)

1 fasara * , aor.
fasira (S, M, O, Msb, K) and
fasura , (M, K,) inf. n. fasorN; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) and ↓ fs~r, (S, M, K,) inf. n. tafosiyrN; (S, K;) which latter is the more common; (IKtt;) or the latter has an intensive signification; (Msb;) He discovered, detected, revealed, developed, or disclosed, a thing that was concealed or obscured; (IAar, O, K;) or a meaning perceived by the intellect: (B:) he rendered a thing apparent, plain, or clear; explained, expounded, or interpreted, it: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) accord. to Th (O, K, TA) and IAar, (TA,) ↓ tafosiyrN and taA^owiylN signify the same; (O, K, TA;) and so these and maEonFY: (O, TA:) or ↓ tfsyr signifies the discovering, detecting, revealing, developing, or disclosing, what is meant by a dubious expression; and tA^wyl signifies the “ reducing one of two senses, or interpretations, which an expression bears, or admits, to that which suits the apparent meaning: ” (O, L, K, TA:) or the latter, the “ turning a verse of the Kur-án from its apparent meaning to a meaning which it bears, or admits, when the latter is agreeable with the Kur-án and the Sunneh: ” for instance, in the phrase in the Kur [vi. 95, &c.], yuxoriju A@loHaY~a mina A@lomay~iti, if the meaning be [thus explained], “ He produceth the bird from the egg, ” this is ↓ tfsyr: and if the meaning be [thus explained], “ He produceth the believer from the unbeliever, ” or “ the knowing from the ignorant, ” this is tA^wyl: (KT:) or ↓ tfsyr signifies the expounding, explaining, or interpreting, the narratives that occur collected without discrimination in the Kur-án, and making known the significations of the strange words or expressions, and explaining the occasions on which the verses were revealed; and tA^wyl, the “ explaining the meaning of that which is muta$aAbih, [or what is equivocal, or ambiguous,] i. e., what is not understood without repeated consideration. ” (TA.) ― -b2- Also fasara, inf. n. fasorN; and ↓ fs~r, inf. n. tafosirapN, (S, O, K,) like ta*okirapN; (TA;) or tafosirapN has the last of the significations assigned to it below as a subst.; (O, K, TA;) or it is postclassical; (S, O, K;) He (a physician) examined, or inspected, urine, (S, O, K, [but the inf. ns. only are mentioned,]) that he might judge, by its colour, of the disease of the person from whom it came. (TA.)
2 fas~ara see the preceding paragraph, in six places.
5 tafas~ara see the next following paragraph.

10 Astfsrhu ka*aA *
He asked him to explain, expound, or interpret, such a thing to him: (S, Msb, TA:) and ↓ tafas~urN is like AisotifosaArN. (TA.)

tafosirapN *
Anything by which is known the explanation and meaning of a thing: (O, TA:) or anything which interprets, or explains, the state, or condition, of a thing. (B, TA.) ― -b2- Urine by means of which, (M, O, K,) or by means of the colour of which, (TA,) one seeks to obtain an indication of the disease (M, O, K, TA) of a patient: (O, TA:) or it is an inf. n., as mentioned above. (O, K.) [See 1, last sentence.]
A^aworada kalaAmahu gayora mufas~arK * : see EaAhinN.

fusoTaATN * and fisoTaATN (S, M, Msb, K) and fus~aATN and fis~aATN and fusotaATN and fisotaATN, (S, M, K,) the t in the last two, as it is not found in the pl., being a substitute for the [former] T in fsTAT, or rather for the [latter] s in fs~AT, because it is more regular to change the latter of two identical letters than to change the former, and because the two identical letters in fs~AT are together, whereas the two identical letters in fsTAT are separated, (M,) and fusotaAtN and fisotaAtN, (K,) altogether eight different forms, but MF observes that Esh-Shiháb El-Kastalánee gives twelve, [which, however, he does not transcribe, the remaining four being probably with fet-h to the f,] (TA,) A tent of hair [-cloth]: (S, Msb:) or a great tent: (Mgh:) or a kind of structure (M, Z) used in travelling, less than the suraAdiq: (Z:) or the kind of structure called suraAdiq: (K:) pl. fasaATiyTu; (M, Msb, TA;) for which they did not say fasaAtiyTu. (M, TA:) ― -b2- Hence fusoTaATN is applied to A city: (Z, TA:) any city: and particularly a city in which is the general place of assemblage of people: (TA:) a populous, or comprehensive, city; accord. to some: (Msb:) the place of assemblage of the people of a kuwrap [which means a city, and a district, or region], (Lth, Az, K,) around their general mosque: (Az, TA:) or you say, fusoTaATu AlmiSori, meaning the place of assemblage of the people of the mSr [or city], around their congregational mosque. (M.) fusoTaATu [so in two copies of the S] is [a name of] The city of miSor [the metropolis of Egypt]: (S:) or AlfusoTaATu is also the proper name of miSoruAlEatiyqapu, (K, TA,) the city so called, (TA,) which was built by 'Amr Ibn-El- 'Ás; (K, TA;) the city of mSr in old times; as also AlfisoTaATu: (Msb:) and AlbaSorapu. (TA.)

1 fasaqa * is said to signify primarily It (a thing) went forth, from another thing, in a bad, or corrupt, manner. (Msb.) One says, fasaqati Alr~uTabapu, (S, O, Msb,) or fasaqati Alr~uTabapu Eano qi$orihaA, (K,) The fresh ripe date came forth from its skin; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Anfsqt: (IDrd, O, K:) and in like manner fasaqa is said of anything as meaning it came forth from its integument: so says EsSarakustee. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence] fasaqa, aor.
fasuqa and
fasiqa , (S, O, Msb, K) the latter aor. mentioned by Akh, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. fusuwqN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and fisoqN, (S, O, K,) or this latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and likewise fasuqa, like karuma, (K, TA,) mentioned by Lh, but not known by Ks; (TA;) He went forth from, departed from, or quitted, (Mgh, Msb, K,) the right way, (Mgh, K,) or the way of truth, (K,) and the limits of the law, (Mgh,) [or the bounds of] obedience; (Msb;) he forsook, relinquished, or neglected, the command of God; he disobeyed; (K;) or i. q. fajara [meaning
as above; or he transgressed; or acted unrighteously, sinfully, wickedly, vitiously, or immorally]. (S, O, K. [See also fisoqN below.]) fasaqa Eano A^amorirab~ihi (in the Kur [xviii. 48], O, TA) means He departed (xaraja) from the command of his Lord: (Th, S, O, K:) or from the obeying [of the command] of his Lord: (Fr, O, TA:) and Akh says that this phrase is like Ait~axama En AlT~aEAmi, (S, O,) meaning Eano maA^okalihi, (S,) or Eano A^akolihi AlT~aEaAma; but Th says that there is no need of this [explanation]: or, accord. to AO, it means he declined, or deviated, from obeying the command of his Lord: (O:) for fasaqa signifies also he declined, or deviated: (K:) and hence the saying, fasaqati Alr~ikaAbu Eano qaSodi Als~abiyli i. e. [The ridden camels] declined [from the right direction of the way]. (TA.) Sometimes fusuwqN may mean The believing in a plurality of gods: and it may mean the committing sin. (A Heyth, O.) And it is said to mean The calling one another by names of reproach: (Zj, * Mgh, TA:) or the saying “ O Jew, ” and “ O Christian, ” after one has become a believer: thus in the Kur xlix. 11. (TA.) ― -b3- One says also, fasaqa fiY Ald~unoyaA, inf. n. fisoqN, meaning He had a wide, or an ample, range in respect of worldly things, and made them light and easy to himself, being without restraint in his management of them, not making them strait to him. (Ktr, Sh, TA.) ― -b4- And fasaqa maAlahu He made away with his property; and disposed of it, or spent it. (TA.)

2 tafosiyqN * is the contr. of taEodiylN: (O, K, TA:) one says fs~qhu, (O, TA,) inf. n. tafosiyqN, (TA,) He (the judge) pronounced him to be characterized by fisoq [q. v.]: (O, TA:) he attributed to him fisoq. (TA.)
7 A_inofasaqa see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] Anfsq mina Alxayori, said of the faAsiq, He divested himself, or became divested, of good. IDrd, O.)

fisoqN * is an inf. n., (S, O, K,) or a simple subst., (Msb,) from fasaqa [q. v]: (S, O, Msb, K:) unless as signifying [simply] A going forth, or a departure, it is said to be a word unknown before ElIslám, and to have become so much used in its legal acceptation as to be, when so used, conventionally regarded as proper (MF, TA:) [thus used,] it signifies a going forth, or departure, from the right way, (K, TA,) which is said to be the primary meaning, (TA,) or from the way of truth; (K, TA;) or from the truth, or that which is right, as in the phrase waA_in~ahu lafisoqN, (O, K, [in the CK lafasiqN, a strange mistake,]) in the Kur [vi. 121]; (O;) or a relinquishment, or neglect, of the command of God; (Lth, O, K;) and an inclining to disobedience; (Lth, O;) or also disobedience [itself]; (K;) or i. q. fujuwrN [meaning as above; or transgression; or unrighteous, sinful, wicked, vitious, or immoral, conduct]: (O, K:) it is said by El-Isbahánee to be a more general term than kuforN; applying to few sins, misdeeds, transgressions, or acts of disobedience, or to little thereof; and also, to many, or much thereof; but is commonly known as applying to the latter: and it is related on the authority of Málik that in the Kur vi. 146 it means such as is slaughtered: (TA:) [being used as a subst.,] it sometimes has a pl., which is fusuwqN. (TA.)

fusaqN * (Lth, O, K) and ↓ fis~iyqN, (Lth, S, O, K,) applied to a man, Always characterized by fisoq. (Lth, S, O, K.) ― -b2- yaAfusaqu means yaA A^ay~uhaA AlfaAsiqu [O thou faAsiq]; (S, O, K;) like yaA xubavu, meaning yaA A^ay~uhaA Anxabiyvu; fusaqu being determinate, as is shown by their saying yaA fusaqu Alxabiyvu, thus prefixing Al to xbyv: (S, O:) and to a woman they say ↓ yaA fasaAqi, like qaTaAmi, (S, O, K,) meaning yaA faAsiqapu (K) [or rather yaA A^ay~uhaA AlfaAsiqapu].

fasoqiy~apN * , with fet-h, [often pronounced fisoqiy~ap,] a post-classical word, [arabicized, from the Lat. “ piscina, ”] i. q. mutawaD~aA^N [properly A place, here meaning a tank, or basin, in which the ablution termed wuDuwo' is performed: now commonly applied to a basin, or shallow pool, of water, in the court of a house, or in a room, generally having in the centre a fountain that throws up water:] pl. fasaAqiy~u. (TA.)
fasaAqi * : see fusaqN
fis~iyqN * : see fusaqN

faAsiqN *
Going forth, or departing, or one who goes forth, or departs, [from the right way, or the way of truth, and the limits of the law, or] from [the bounds of] obedience; (Msb;) disobedient [to God]; (Mgh, TA;) [transgressing, or a transgressor; unrighteous, sinful, wicked, vitious, or immoral;] mostly applied to one who has taken upon himself to observe what the law ordains, and has acknowledged its authority, and then fallen short of observance in respect of all, or of some, of its ordinances: and when the person fundamentally, or utterly, an unbeliever is thus termed, it is because he falls short of observing the ordinance that the intellect renders obligatory on him and that the natural constitution with which he was created in his mother's womb requires to be conceded; hence the believer is contrasted with him in the Kur xxxii. 18; so faAsiqN is a more general term than kaAfirN; and ZaAlimN is a more general term than faAsiqN: (El-Isbahánee, TA:) accord. to IDrd, (O,) the faAsiq is thus called because of his divesting himself, or becoming divested, of good: (O, K:) the word has not been heard in the speech of the people of the Time of Ignorance, (IAar, S, O, Msb, K,) nor in their poetry, (IAar, S, O, K,) though it is an Arabic word, (IAar, S, O, Msb, K,) and a chaste one, and the Kur-án has used it: (IAar, Msb:) the pl. is fasaqapN and fus~aAqN: (Msb:) fawaAsiqu, [pl. of faAsiqapN,] applied to women, signifies fawaAjiru [generally meaning adulteresses, or fornicatresses]. (TA.) ― -b2- The five animals, or living things, (AlHayawaAnaAtu Alxamosu, [specified voce HayawaAnN,]) are metaphorically termed fawaAsiqu [as though meaning (tropical:) Transgressors] (Mgh, Msb) because of their noxiousness, (Mgh,) or because of their much, or frequent, noxiousness and harmfulness, so that they may be killed in the case of freedom from A_iHoraAm and in the state of A_iHoraAm, and in prayer, which is not rendered ineffectual thereby: (Msb:) or because of their being out of the pale of inviolability: or, as some [unreasonably] say, because the eating of them is forbidden. (Mgh.)

faAsiqiy~apN *
A certain mode of attiring oneself with the turban. (Z, O, K.) One says, taEam~ama fulaAnN AlfaAsiqy~apa [Such a one attired himself with the turban in the mode termed AlfAsqy~p]. (TA.)

Alfuwayosiqapu *
The rat, or mouse; syn. AlfaA^orapu: (S, O, K:) so called because it comes forth from its hole upon people: (O, K:) or, accord. to Z, because it does mischief in houses: and it is said in a trad. that it is to be killed: the word is the dim. of faAsiqapN. (TA.)

A^afosaqu * [More, or most, characterized by fisoq]. The Arabs say, laEana A@ll~`hu A^afosaqiY wA^afosaqaka, meaning, AlA^afosaqa min~aA [i. e. May God curse the more characterized by fisoq, of us, or of me and thee]. (Fr, O.)

Q. 1 fasokalahu *
He postponed him; i. e., made him, or asserted him, to be behind, or posterior, or last, (Sh, O, K,) in rank, or estimation. (O.) ― -b2- And fasokala He was, or became, behind, &c.: the verb being intrans. as well as trans. [unless fasokala be a mistake for fusokila, the pass. form, of which an ex. occurs in the O and TA]. (K.) ― -b3- Accord. to IAar, a foreign word (Eajamiy~ap), arabicized. (O.)
fusokulN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

fisokilN * The last, in coming in, of the horses in a race; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ fusokulN and ↓ fusokuwlN and ↓ fasokawolN: (K:) also called the suk~ayot [q. v.] and the qaA$uwr. (S, O. [In a copy of the S, in art. skt, Alfisokil~u is put for Alfisokilu.]) ― -b2- And hence, (S, O,) applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Low, base, ignoble, vile, or mean: (S, O, K:) the vulgar say ↓ fusokulN. (S, O.)

fusokuwlN * and fisokawolN: see fisokilN. ― -b2- Both also signify (assumed tropical:) Occupying the hinder, or latter, or last, place [in rank, or estimation: see Q. 1, above]; (K, TA;) as epithets applied to a man. (TA.)

1 fasula * , (S, M, O, K,) with damm, (S, O,) like karuma; (K;) and fasila, (M, K,) like Ealima; (K;) and fusila, (M, K,) of the form of that whereof the agent is not named, (M,) like EuniYa; (K;) inf. n. fasaAlapN and fusuwlapN (S, M, O, K) and fusuwlN; (M, TA;) He (a man, S, O) was, or became, low, base, ignoble, vile, or mean; (S, M, O, K;) such as had no manliness, or manly virtue, (M, K,) and no hardiness. (TA.) -A2- And fasala AlS~abiY~a He weaned the boy; (AA, O, K;) as though a dial. var. of faSala. (TA.)
2 fas~ala see the paragraph here following.

4 Afsl Ealayohi mataAEahu *
He pronounced against him (i. e. against another man, Lth, O) that his goods
were bad; syn. Ar*lh: (Lth, O, K:) and Afsl Ealayohi daraAhimahu he pronounced against him that his dirhems, or pieces of money, were bad, or were such as are termed zuyuwf; (Lth, O, K; *) syn. zay~afahaA, (Lth, O, K, TA,) and A^aro*alahaA: (TA:) and [in like manner] ↓ fs~lhu, inf. n. tafosiylN, signifies A^aro*alahu and zay~afahu. (TA.) -A2- See also what next follows.

8 Aftsl Alfasiylapa * , (M,) inf. n. AifotisaAlN; (O, TA;) or ↓ A^afosalahaA; (K; [app. a mistranscription for AifotasalahaA, as it is outweighed by the latter in authority;]) He plucked the young palm-tree from its mother, and planted it (M, O, K) in another place. (O.)

fasolN * and ↓ mafosuwlN, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) as epithets applied to a man, (S, O, Msb,) Low, base, ignoble, vile, or mean; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) such as has no manliness, or manly virtue, (M, K,) and no hardiness: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^afosaAlN, (S, O,) or A^afosulN, (M, K,) or both, (TA,) and [of mult.] fisaAlN and fusuwlN (S, M, O, K) and fusuwlapN (Kr, M, K) and fusolN (M, K) and fusalA='u, (S, M, O, K,) which last is anomalous, as though they imagined it to have as its sing. fasiylN. (M.) ― -b2- Also, the former, Anything bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved. (TA.) [The pl.] fusuwlN, applied to dirhems, or pieces of money, means Bad; or such as are termed zuyuwf. (TA.) -A2- And fasolN signifies also Cuttings from grape-vines, for planting. (AHn, M, K. *)

fisolN *
Foolish, stupid, or unsound in intellect or understanding. (AA, O, K.)

fasiylN * The young ones, or small ones, of palmtrees, like wadiY~N; (S, O, Msb;) as also ↓ fasiylapN: (S, O:) [or] the former signifies such as are cut from the mother-tree, or plucked from the ground, (Mgh, * Msb,) of the young ones, or small ones, of palm-trees, (Mgh,) and then planted; (Mgh, Msb;) and ↓ fsylp signifies one thereof: (Msb:) [i. e.] ↓ fasiylapN signifies [a sucker, or an offset, of a palm-tree: or] a small palm-tree: and fasiylN is its pl., as also fasaAy^ilu, (M, K,) and fusolaAnN, (S, O, K,) or this last is a pl. pl., (M,) or [rather] it is pl. of fasiylN [which is properly speaking a coll. gen. n.], like as rugofaAnN is pl. of zagiyfN. (Msb.)
fusaAlapN * The filings (suHaAlap) of iron: (S, O:) or the portions that become scattered about, on the occasion of beating [or hammering], in the manufacturing, of iron and the like thereof. (M, K.)
fasiylapN * : see fasiylN, in three places.

mufas~ilapN * A woman who, when her husband is desirous of compressing her, (S, M, O, K,) urges an excuse to him, (S, O,) or says to him A^anaAHaAy^iDN, (M, K, *) and the like thereof, (M,) in order to repel him (M, K) thereby: (M:) such, and the musaw~ifap [which belongs to the same category] the Prophet cursed. (O.)
mafosuwlN * : see fasolN.

1 fasaA * , (aor. yafosuw, Msb,) inf. n. fasowN (S, M, Msb, K) and fusaA='N, (M, K,) or this latter is a simple subst., (S, Msb,) He emitted a noiseless wind [or a puff of wind] (Msb, K, TA) from his anus. (K, * TA.) [Hence the saying, fasaAbayonanaA AlZ~aribaAnu, or bayonahum, expl. in art. Zrb.]

6 tfAsY * , said of a man, He protruded his posteriors: (M, TA:) and tafaAsato, said of the [beetle called] xunofasaA=', It protruded its podex for the purpose of emitting a noiseless wind: (S, TA:) but As says that it is with hemz. (TA. See 6 in art. fsA^.)
AlfasaA * is a dial. var. of AlfasaA^u [i. e. fasFA is a dial. var. of fasaA^N, expl. in art. fsA^]. (K.)
AlfusaApu * : see the paragraph here following.

fasowapN * [is the inf. n. of unity of fasaA, as such signifying A single noiseless emission of wind from the anus: and] has for its pl. [fasawaAtN, agreeably with rule, and also] fusFY, which is [anomalous,] like $uhFY pl. of $ahowapN, which see. (TA.) ― -b2- layosa lahu A_il~aA fasowapu AlD~abuEi [the lit. signification of which is sufficiently plain] occurs in a trad. as meaning (assumed tropical:) There is not any benefit, or profit, or utility, attributable to it; [or rather, it is worse than useless;] the DbE [or hyena] being particularized because of its stupidity and its evil nature: or, some say, it [i. e. fswp AlDbE, and app. ↓ AlfusaApu also (mentioned among the addenda to this art. in the TA),] is a plant ($ajarapN) like the xa$xaA$ [or poppy], from the fruit of which no great utility is derived: so says IAth. (TA.) [See also xamoTN, in two places.] ― -b3- fasawaAtu AlD~ibaAEi is an appellation of Certain truffles (kamoA^apN); (K;) a species of kamoA^ap; (M;) said by AHn to be the species thereof called AlqaEobalu; (M, TA;) and the like is said in the Minháj; and further, that it is a plant of disagreeable odour, having a head which is cooked, and eaten with milk; and when it dries, there comes forth from it what resembles waros [q. v.]. (TA.)
fasaA='N * an inf. n. of 1; (M, K;) or a subst. therefrom [signifying A noiseless wind from the anus]. (S, Msb.)
fasuw~N * A man who often emits a noiseless wind from the anus; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ fas~aA='N. (M, K.)
fusay~apN * [originally fusayowapN] dim. of fasowapN. (TA.)
fas~aA='N * : see fasuw~N. ― -b2- And Alfas~aA='apu: see what here follows.

AlfaAsiyapu * (S, M, K) and ↓ AlfaAsiyaA='u (M, K) and ↓ Alfas~aA='apu (TA) The [beetle called] xunofasaA='; (S, M, K;) which emits a noiseless wind, and makes the party to stink by its foul odour: (M:) the pl. of the first is AlfawaAsiY. (TA.) Hence the prov., A^afoHa$u mino faAsiyapK i. e. [More foul than] a xnfsA'. (S, M.)

AlfaAsiyaA='u * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- [Aibonu AlfaAsiyaA='i is an appellation of The insect called qaranobaY, resembling the beetle called xunofasaA=', or somewhat larger than the latter, with long hind legs, and with a speckled back: for AlqaranobaY, as the explanation of A, the TA, in art. bnY, has AlqrynY; and the TT, in that art., as from the T,. AlfuranaY: what I have here substituted for these is evidently, in my opinion, right.]
A^afosaY mina AlZ~aribaAni * [More wont to emit noiseless wind from the anus than the ZrbAn, a small stinking beast, described in art. Zrb,] is a saying of the Arabs. (TA.)

AlmafosaY *
The anus [as being the place of emission of the fusaA=']. (TA.) maA A^aqoraba maHosaAhu mino mafosaAhu [How near is his mouth to his anus!] is a prov. [expressive of wonder at a man's shortness: see maHosFY, in art. Hsw]. (S.)

1 fa$~a AlwaToba * , (S, A, K,) aor.
fa$u3a , inf. n. fa$~N, (S, TA,) He made the wind, (S, A, K,) and the butter, (TA,) to come forth from the milk-skin, or butterskin, (S, A, K, TA,) by loosing the tie round its mouth. (TA.) And fa$~a Als~iqaA='a He loosed the tie of the skin, and opened its mouth, after blowing into it, so that the wind came forth from it. (Mgh.) [Hence the prov.,] lA^afu$~an~aka fa$~a AlwaTobi (assumed tropical:) I will assuredly make thine anger to come forth from thy head, as one makes the wind to come forth from the milk-skin, or butter-skin: said to a man who is angry: (T, S:) or I will assuredly remove thy boastfulness, &c.: (TA:) or I will assuredly take away thy pride, and thy vanity, or vain glory, or conceit, &c.: (Th:) or the meaning is laA^aHoluban~aka [I will assuredly mulet thee, &c.; lit., milk thee]. (Kr.) See also fa$aA$i. ― -b2- [Hence,] fa$~a Aln~aAqapa, (S, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, TA,) He milked the she-camel quickly. (S, K.) And fa$~a AlD~aroEa He exhausted all the milk of the udder. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also, fa$~a Alwarama It (a medicament) caused the swelling, or tumour, to subside.] (See also 7.) ― -b4- And fa$~a Alqufola, (IKtt, L,) or AlbaAba, (Mgh, Msb,) [aor.
fa$u3a ,] inf. n. fa$~N, (IKtt, L,) He opened the lock, (IKtt, L,) or the lock of the door, by artifice, (Mgh, Msb,) without a key, (IKtt, L,) or without its key: (Msb:) from fa$~a Als~iqaA='a. (Mgh.) ― -b5- And accord to Lth, (O,) Alfa$~u signifies tatab~uEu Als~ariqapi Ald~uwni [app. meaning The seeking repeatedly, or in a leisurely manner, after pilfering, or petty theft]: (O, Msb, K:) it is the inf. n. of fa$~ahu, aor.
fa$u3a : (O, Msb:) and Lth, (O,) or Az, (Msb,) cites as an ex.,
naHonu waliynaAhu falaA nafu$~uhu
[which seems to mean We have had charge of it, and we will not seek repeatedly, or in a leisurely manner, bit by bit, after pilfering from it]. (O, Msb.) ― -b6- And fa$~a, aor.
fa$u3a , inf. n. fa$~N, He compressed a woman. (IKtt, TA.) ― -b7- And He ate; as a trans. verb. (TA.) ― -b8- And fa$~a Alr~ajulu, (S, O, K,) aor.
fa$u3a , (O,) [inf. n. fa$~N,] The man eructed, or belched. (S, O, K. [A meaning assigned by Freytag to 4 also, as on the authority of the S,
in which I find it assigned to fa$~a only.]) ― -b9- And Alfa$~u also signifies The blowing gently, or softly. (TA.) ― -b10- And The breaking wind gently, or softly. (IAar, TA.) ― -b11- And The uttering calumny; (O, K;) thus accord. to IAar, with f, (O,) bayona Aln~aAsi [among the people]. (TK.) ― -b12- And fa$~a Alqawomu, inf. n. fu$uw$N, The people, or party, became in good condition, or fat, after leanness: mentioned here, and also in art. q$, in the L. (TA.) ― -b13- And fa$~a is syn. with faA$a as meaning He gloried, or boasted, and magnified himself, imagining [in himself] what he did not possess. (TA in art. fy$.)

4 Af$~ Alqawomu *
The people, or party, went away, and fled quickly: and so with q. (TA.)

7 Anf$~ti Alr~iyaAHu *
The blasts of wind came forth from the skin, (S, Mgh, *) on its being felt, (Mgh,) and from the like thereof. (S.) ― -b2- Anf$~ All~abanu The milk flowed forth by reason of the wideness of the orifice of the teat. (TA.) ― -b3- Anf$~ AljuroHu [and Alwaramu, and likewise ↓ fa$~a accord. to modern usage,] The wound [and the swelling or tumour] ceased to swell, or be inflated. (ISk, S) ― -b4- Anf`$~ Eani AlA^amori He (a man) became remiss and indolent in the affair: (S:) he turned back from it through weakness and impotence; like tfy~$. (TA in art. fy$.) ― -b5- And Anf$~ He was, or became, cowardly; weak-hearted. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 fa$ofa$a * , (K,) inf. n. fa$ofa$apN, (Fr, O,) He was, or became, weak in judgment. (Fr, O, K.) ― -b2- And He was, or became, extravagant, immoderate, or excessive, in lying: (IDrd, O, K:) or so f$f$ fiY qawolihi. (TA.) ― -b3- And f$f$ bibawolihi He sprinkled his urine; (IDrd, O, K;) as also $afo$afa. (IDrd, O.)

fa$~N * The fruit of the yanobuwt [q. v., a kind of trees, of which one species is said to be also called xar~uwb; but see the next sentence]; (S, O, K;) not mentioned by AHn in the Book of Plants: (O, TA:) n. un. fa$~apN: and pl. fi$aA$N. (TA.) ― -b2- And The [species of trees called] xar~uwb [which name is now commonly applied to the carob, or locust-tree; ceratonia siliqua]; as also ↓ fa$uw$N, (O, K,) and ↓ fa$ofa$apN, (TA as from the K, but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K,) or this last signifies a xar~uwbap [n. un. of xar~uwbN], accord. to AA. (O.) -A2- Also Foolish, or stupid. (IAar, O, K.) -A3- And Places in which water collects and remains: and a depressed piece of ground into which water pours and where it remains: (O, K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád: [but] ISh says that hajolN fa$~N means [a wide, depressed, piece of ground,] such as is not very deep. (O.) -A4- Also, and ↓ fa$uw$N, and ↓ fa$ofaA$N, [this last said in the TA to be written by Sgh with kesr, but it is not so in the O,] A [garment of the kind called] kisaA=' such as is thick (IAar, O, K, TA) in texture, (TA,) fine in the yarn; (IAar, O, K, TA;) called by the vulgar ↓ fa$~aA$N; (O; in the TA fi$~A$;) or, as some say, ↓ fa$~aA$N signifies a thick ksA='; and ↓ fa$uw$N, a thin, or flimsy, ksA=', such as is scanty in the yarn. (TA.)

fa$aA$i * , like qaTaAmi, [indecl.,] means ↓ AlfaA$~apu [i. e. She who makes the wind to come forth from a skin, by loosing the tie round its mouth: in the TA expl. only as signifying AlD~aruwTu EinodaAljimaAEi, which may be a secondary meaning, but is not the meaning in what here follows]. (O, K.) fa$aA$i mini A@sotihi A_ilaY fiyhi ↓ fu$~iyhi [lit. O woman discharging the confined wind of the skin, discharge thou its confined wind, from its anus to its mouth, i. e., from end to end], (Meyd, O, K,) which is a prov., (Meyd, O,) means (assumed tropical:) [O woman] do thou with it, or him, what thou wilt, for it, or he, has no means of self-defence (Meyd, O, L, K) nor of becoming altered; and it is said in relation to an angry man who is not able to become altered: (L:) Alfa$~u is the making the wind to come forth from a waTob. (Meyd.)
fi$aA$N * : see the next paragraph.

fa$uw$N * A female slave who emits noiseless wind from the anus; as also faA$~A' [an evident mistranscription for ↓ faA$~apN]: (IAar, in TA:) [or] a woman from whom wind issues on the occasion of AljimaAE: (IDrd, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to the K, applied to a woman, sonum submissum genitalibus edens in congressu: and also, applied to a man, who glories, or boasts, vainly: but these two explanations are there wrongly assigned: (TA:) the former of them applies to naj~aAxap; and the latter, to fayuw$; two epithets occurring, with fa$uw$, in a verse of Ru-beh. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And, applied to a woman, i. q. xal~aAbapN [i. e. Very deceitful]: (O, CK, TA:) thus correctly, with x: in some copies of the K with H; and in others, with j. (TA.) ― -b3- And A woman who sits upon the jurodaAn. (TA.) -A2- Also, (O, K,) applied to a she-camel, (S, O, TA,) and to a ewe, or she-goat, (O, TA,) it signifies munota$irapu Al$~uxobi, (S, O, K, TA,) meaning Whose milk flows forth without its being drawn, by reason of the wideness of the orifice of the teat: or whose milk flows forth in separate jets, like the rays of the rising sun, into the vessel, so as not to make froth: and ↓ fi$aA$N signifies the quality, or state, that is denoted by this epithet thus applied. (TA.) ― -b2- And A skin, such as is used for water or milk, that sweats, or exudes moisture. (O, K.) -A3- See also fa$~N, in three places.
fa$iy$N * The sound of a gentle emission of wind from the anus. (TA.) ― -b2- And The sound of the skin of a viper when it moves along upon a dry, or rigid, substance. (TA.)
fa$~aA$N * One who opens locks by artifice, (Mgh, Msb,) without their keys. (Msb.) -A2- See also fa$~N, last sentence, in two places.
faA$~apN * : see fa$aA$i and fa$uw$N.
fa$ofa$apN * : see fa$~N, second sentence.
fa$ofaA$N * A man who inflates himself with lying, and arrogates to himself that which belongs to another. (TA.) -A2- See also fa$~N, last sentence.
munofa$~u Almanoxirayoni * A man inflated in the nostrils, with shortness and expansion of the cartilaginous portion of the nose, which are characteristics of the noses of the Zenj. (TA.)

1 fa$aA^a * , (O, K,) aor.
fa$aAa , (K,) [inf. n. fa$o'N;] as also ↓ Af$A^; He magnified himself; or behaved proudly, or haughtily: (O, K:) [or he gloried, or boasted: for] Alfa$o'u is from Alfaxoru, (Ibn-Buzurj, O,) [or] syn. with Alfaxoru. (K.)
4 A^afo$aAa see what here precedes.

5 tf$~A^ *
It (a thing) spread. (S, O.) One says of a disease, tf$~A^bihimo, (AZ, S, O,) or fiyhimo, (K,) [and tf$~Y, and tfs~A^,] It spread among them: (AZ, S, O, K:) and tf$~A^hm it became common, or general, or universal, among them. (O.) -A2- tf$~A^ bihi He mocked at him, or derided him. (O, K.)

1 fa$aja * , aor.
fa$ija , (S, O, K,) inf. n. fa$ojN, (A'Obeyd, TA,) He parted his legs, or made an opening between them, (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K,) but less than is denoted by tafaAj~a, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) previously to making water; as also ↓ f$~j, (S, O, K,) inf. n. tafo$iyjN; (S, O;) or the latter signifies he did so [much, i. e.,] in a greater degree than is denoted by the former verb: (TA:) [and fa$aHa and f$~H signify the same:] and ↓ tf$~j [likewise] is syn. with nafaH~aja [signifying the same as fa$aja]; (Lth, S, K;) or he did so at the fire. (Lth, L.) And fa$ajato (T, TA) and ↓ tf$~jt and ↓ Anf$jt, (T, O, TA,) as also Anf$Ht, with H, (IAar, O,) are said of a she-camel, (T, O, TA,) meaning She parted her [hind] legs widely, to be milked or to stale. (T, TA.) ― -b2- And fa$aja Eanohu, and ↓ f$~j He declined, deviated, or turned aside or away, from him, or it; like fa$aHa and f$~H. (TA in art. f$H.)
2 fa$~aja see the foregoing paragraph, in two places.
5 tafa$~aja see the same paragraph, in two places.
7 A_inofa$aja see the same paragraph.

1 fa$aHa * , aor.
fa$aHa , (K,) inf. n. fa$oHN, (TK,) He (a man, TK) parted his legs, or made an opening between them; (K;) like fa$aja; both mentioned by Th, on the authority of IAar; (TA;) as also ↓ f$~H, (K,) inf. n. tafo$iyHN; and likewise with j, as mentioned by Th. (TA.) ― -b2- And fa$aHa Eanohu, and ↓ f$~H, He declined, deviated, or turned aside or away, from him, or it; (K;) and so fa$aja and f$~j. (TA.)
2 fa$~aHa see above, in two places: ― -b2- and see also what here follows.

5 tf$~Ht *
She (a camel) parted her [hind] legs widely; syn. tafaAj~ato; (K, TA;) [to be milked, or] to stale; as also ↓ f$~Ht; (TA;) and so ↓ Anf$Ht. (K.) -A2- And tf$~H jaAriyatahu He compressed his young woman. (K.)
7 A_inofa$aHa see the next preceding paragraph.
fa$aAHi * , [indecl.,] like qaTaAmi, The DabuE [or hyena, or female hyena]. (K.)

1 fa$agahu * , (S, O, K,) aor.
fa$aga , (K,) inf. n. fa$ogN, (TA,) It overspread it and covered it; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ f$~ghu, (K,) inf. n. tafo$iygN. (TA.) And fa$agato said of the naASiyap [or forelock (of a horse)], and of the quS~ap [which has the same, or a similar, meaning], It covered the eye. (TA.) And fa$aga It (a thing) was, or became, wide and spreading; as also ↓ Anf$g: and ↓ tafa$~agato said of the gur~ap [or blaze on a horse's forehead] is like fa$agato [signifying it was wide and spreading]. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- fa$agahu biAls~awoTi, (S, O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He set upon him, or assailed him, or struck him, with the whip, syn. EalaAhu bihi, (S, O, TA,) and Darabahu bihi; (TA;) and biAls~awoTi ↓ Af$ghu signifies in like manner he struck him with the whip; (S;) or so Als~awoTa ↓ Af$ghu. (O, K.)
2 fa$~aga see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] f$~ghu Aln~awomu, inf. n. tafo$iygN, Sleep came upon him and overpowered him; (As, O, K, * TA;) and rendered him heavy, lazy, or torpid. (O, TA.)
4 A^afo$aga see 1, last sentence.

5 tf$~ghA * , said of the he-camel, He overcame her, and mounted upon her; namely, the she-camel. (O.) ― -b2- And in like manner, tf$~ghu, said of debt, (O,) It overcame him, and lay as a burden upon him. (O, K.) ― -b3- And, said of hoariness, i. q. t$y~Ehu and t$y~mhu and tsn~mhu [i. e. It became abundant upon him, and spread]: (IAar, TA:) or tf$~E fiyhi said of hoariness, or of the blood, it spread in him, and became abundant: (K:) or this, said of hoariness, it became abundant in him, and spread: and, said of the blood, it overcame him, and pervaded his body. (S, O.) See also 1. tf$~E Alwaladu, occurring in a trad., means Children were, or became, numerous. (O.) And in another trad. occur the words, maA h`*ihi AlfutoyaA Al~atiY qado tafa$~agato, meaning [What is this judicial decision] that has spread abroad? (O: [and the like is said in the Mgh, in which the verb thus used is said to be from fa$aAgN signifying a certain plant:]) but this is differently related; some saying thus; and some, t$g~ft [q. v.]; and some t$E~ft [app. a mistranscription, perhaps for $aEabota, q. v.]. (TA.) One says also, tf$~g AlxayorufiY baniY fulaAnK i. e. [Good, or prosperity,] became abundant, and arose, or betided, among the sons of such a one. (TA.) ― -b4- And tf$~g Albuyuwta He (a man, S, O) entered among the houses, or tents; (S, O, K;) and disappeared among them. (K, * TA.) ― -b5- And tf~$g AlmaroA^apa He devirginated the woman. (S, O, K: more fully expl. in all of these by the words daxala bayona rijolayohaA waA@fotaraEahaA.)

7 Anf$g *
It (a thing, TA) appeared, and became abundant. (O, K, TA.) See also 1.

fa$ogapN *
A [substance like] cotton (quTonapN [in the L qaSabapN]) in the interior of the reed, or cane: and also a substance that flies about from the interior of the SwSlAp [in the O SawoSal~aAp, and in the K without the teshdeed], i. e. the plant, or herb, thus called, (Lth, O, K,) which is the SaASul~aY; (O;) and this is that whereof the children of El-' Irák eat the interior. (TA.) ― -b2- And The [species of convolvulus called] labolaAb [q. v.], (K, TA,) which mounts upon trees, and twines upon them. (TA.)

fa$aAgN * , (S, [thus written in my copies and others also,] and so in the Mgh,) or ↓ fu$aAgN and ↓ fu$~aAgN, (O, K, said in the former to be like SuraAxN and muk~aA='N, and in the K to be like guraAbN and also with teshdeed,) thus accord. to IB on the authority of Az, and thus also accord. to Hr, but mentioned by Z as with the unpointed E, (TA,) A certain plant, (S, Mgh, O, K,) [said by Golius to be the rough smilax,] that spreads, (S, K,) or mounts, (Mgh, O,) and twines, upon trees, (S, Mgh, O, K,) and mars them, (O, K, [in some copies of the latter of which it is mentioned in two places,]) and has no leaves [?]. (Mgh.)
fu$aAgN * : see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- Also A piece of hide, or leather, with which a skin for water or milk is patched. (O, K.)
fu$~aAgN * : see fa$aAgN.
naASiyapN faA$igapN * : see the following paragraph.

A^afo$agu * A ram (K) whose horns go this way and that [app. meaning widely, or dissimilarly]. (O, K.) ― -b2- And naASiyapN fa$ogaA=' A spreading forelock [of a horse]; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ faA$igapN. (O, K.) ― -b3- And rajulN A^afo$agu Alv~aniy~api A man having the fore tooth projecting. (Lth, O, K.) And A^afo$agu AlA^asonaAni Having the teeth disparted; (Lth, O, K;) having wide interstices between the teeth. (Lth, O.)

1 fa$ila * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor
fa$ala , (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. fa$alN; (S, O, Msb;) a verb of which exs. occur in the Kur iii. 118 and viii. 48; and fa$ala, aor.
fa$ula ; and fa$ala, aor.
fa$ila ; two dial. vars., the former of these agreeable with a reading of the latter verse of the Kur-án, and the latter agreeable with a reading of the same verse by El- Hasan El-Basree; (O;) He was, or became, cowardly, (S, O, Msb, K,) and weak, (O, K,) or weak-hearted, (Msb,) and flagging, remiss, or languid, (K,) and timorous. (TA.) -A2- fa$alato, and fa$alato mifo$alahaA, (O,) or fa$alato fi$olahaA, (K, * TA, [in the CK ↓ fa$~alatohu, the pronoun relating to Alfi$ol,]) inf. n. fa$olN; (TA;) and ↓ Aifota$alatohu, (O, K, * TA,) thus accord. to the M as well as the O, (TA,) i. e. mifo$alahaA, (O,) or fi$olahaA; (TA;) [in the K Aifota$alato alone, i. e. without any complement, as though it were intrans.; or ↓ Af$lt, which is said in the TA to be the reading in the copies of the K, but which I have not found in any;] and ↓ tf$~lt [mentioned without any complement, as though intrans.]; (K, TA;) said of a woman, (O, K, TA,) in relation to the fi$ol, (K,) which is also called mifo$al, (IAar, O,) meaning She hung a vawob [or piece of cloth] (thus in the O, in the TA her vwb,) upon the [camel-vehicle called] hawodaj, then put it [or drew it, or the main part thereof,] within it, and bound its extremities to the qawaAEid [or four pieces of wood that form a square frame upon which it is fixed (see its sing. qaAEidapN)]; this being [beneath her (see fi$olN) so as to be to her] a preservative from the heads of the [curved pieces of wood called] A^aHonaA=' [pl. of HinowN q. v.] and the [apparatus called] A^aqotaAb [pl. of qitobN q. v.] and the knots of the cord called EuSom [pl. of EiSaAmN q. v.]: (O, TA:) so says ISh. (TA.)
2 fa$~ala and 4: see the preceding paragraph.

5 tf$~l * , said of water, It flowed. (S, O, K.) -A2- And He took a wife (ISh, O, K) minohumo [from among them, probably meaning persons not of his own kindred: see mifo$alN]. (ISh, O.) -A3- See also 1.
8 A_ifota$ala see 1, latter sentence.

fa$olN *
Weak; (S, O, K;) or weak-hearted; (Msb;) cowardly; (S, Msb, K;) flagging, remiss, or languid; (K;) and accord. to the K, ↓ fa$ilN signifies the same, and one says, rajulN xa$olN fa$olN and ↓ xa$ilN fa$ilN; but [SM says that] this is a mistake, and [incorrectly] taken from a passage of the M, in which it is stated that one says rajulN xa$olN fa$olN and xasol fasolN; i. e., with $ in both and with s in both; not that it is with fet-h in both and like katifN: (TA:) [I find, however, ↓ xa$ilN fa$ilN mentioned in art. x$l in the K, and also, as from Ibn-'Abbád, in the same art. in the O; and as ↓ fa$ilN is agreeable with a general rule as part. n. of fa$ila, I think it probably correct;] the pl. is A^afo$aAlN, (S,) or fu$olN, (K,) or both. (TA.) In the following verse, occurring in a trad. respecting the prayer for rain, (O, TA,) uttered to the Prophet by an Arab of the desert, (O,)
walaA $aYo'a mim~aA yaA^okulu Aln~aAsu EinodanaA
siwaY AlHanoZali AlEaAmiY~i waAlEilohizi Alfa$oli
by AlEilohizi Alfa$oli is meant AlEilohizi Alfa$oli A=kiluhu wamud~axiruhu, i. e. AlD~aEiyfi; (O, TA; *) the phrase being like Al$~ajarapa AlmaloEuwnapa in the Kur [xvii. 62], i. e., A=kiluwhaA: [so that the verse means, And there
is nothing, of what men eat, in our possession, save the colocynth that is a year old, and therefore dry, or that has been laid up for the year of drought or barrenness, and the food made of blood and the fur of camels, the eater, and the storer, whereof is weak]: (O, TA:) but it is also related with s, [i. e. Alfasoli,] and thus does not need any paraphrastic interpretation. (TA.) -A2- See also what next follows.

fi$olN * (O, K,) or ↓ fa$olN, (S,) [but said to be] with kesr, (O, K,) A certain thing (S, K) of the apparatus of the [women's camel-vehicle called] hawodaj, (S,) which the woman puts beneath her in the hwdj: (K:) or the curtain (sitor) of the hwdj; as also ↓ mifo$alN. (IAar, O, K.) [See a description thereof in the latter sentence of the first paragraph.]
fa$ilN * : see fa$olN, in four places.
fayo$ilN * : see the paragraph here following.

Alfayo$alapu *
The Ha$afap; (K;) [i. e.] the head [or glans] of the penis: (S, O:) and the head of any muHaw~aq [or penis having a large glans]: (CK: in the text of the K as given in the TA, mujaw~af: [and thus in my MS. copy of the K; but it has been there altered, app. to agree with the TA, as have many other words in that copy; and the former reading is evidently, I think, the right:] some say that its l is augmentative, like the l in EabodalN and in [the proper name] zayodalN: but it may be from some other word than fayo$apN, though this has nearly the same meaning, [or, as is said in the TA in art. fy$, both have the same meaning,] and, if so, the Y may be augmentative, which is more agreeable with analogy: (TA:) the pl. is fayaA$ilu, (K,) and ↓ fayo$alN is another pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] thereof, used as such in a verse of Jereer. (TA.) ― -b2- [The pl.] fayaA$ilu signifies also a name of Certain trees. (K.) ― -b3- [Freytag adds as other meanings what belong to a description of the proper name of a certain water and of hills surrounding it, called AlfayaA$ilu.]

tafo$iylN *
Milk remaining in the udder: (Fr, O, K:) and so tamo$iylN. (Fr, O.)
mifo$alN * : see fi$olN. -A2- Also One who takes a wife from among persons not of his own kindred, lest the offspring should come forth spare in body, or weak. (IAar, O, K, TA.)

mifo$alapN * The kyArjp [i. e. kayaArijap], (ISh, TA,) which is an arabicized word from the Pers. krAjh, in Turkish qwrsq [also written quwroSaq, i. e. the gizzard, or the crop, of a bird]. (TK voce mi$ofalapN [which is said in the K to signify thus, and also the stomach of a ruminant animal: one of the two words thus expl. may be a mistranscription for the other].)

1 fa$aA * , (aor. yafo$uw, S,) inf. n. fu$uw~N (S, MA, Msb, K) and fu$iY~N (K) and fa$owN, (Msb, K,) It (a thing, Msb, or a secret, MA, or information, news, or tidings, S, K, and a man's beneficence, or bounty, K) became revealed, disclosed, or divulged, (S, MA, Msb, K, *) and spread. (S, * Msb, K.) ― -b2- [It (a saying or the like) became common; or obtained extensively.] ― -b3- fa$ati AlmaA$iyapu The cattle pastured [at large], where they pleased. (Msb.) ― -b4- fa$ato DayoEatuhu, (TA in art. DyE,) or fa$ato Ealayohi DayoEatuhu, (TA in the present art.,) or fa$ato Ealayohi AlD~ayoEapu, (Ham p. 33,) said to mean His property was, or became, large, or abundant, [or widespread,] so that he was unable to collect it together: and [hence] his means of attaining his object, or his affairs, became disordered so that he knew not with which of them to begin: (TA in art. DyE and in the present art.;) or he took to doing an affair that did not concern him. (TA in art. DyE, and Ham p. 33.) ― -b5- And fa$ato A^umuwru Aln~aAsi The affairs of the people became discomposed, or disordered; syn. Aifotaraqato. (Msb.)

4 Af$Ahu *
He revealed, disclosed, or divulged, it, (S, MA, Msb, K,) and spread it; (S, * Msb, K;) namely, a thing, (Msb,) or a secret, (MA,) or information, news, or tidings, (S, K,) and a man's beneficence, or bounty. (K.) ― -b2- Af$Y A@ll~`hu DayoEatahu, occurring in a trad., means God made, or may God make, his means of subsistence to be abundant. (TA in art. DyE.) -A2- And Af$Y, said of a man, He had numerous cattle, (T, K, TA,) such as sheep or goats, and camels, &c., pasturing at large, (K, TA.)

5 tf$~Y *
It (a thing) became wide. (S.) And tf$~t AlqaroHapu The ulcer, or sore, became wide, (K, TA,) and blistered, and corrupt, by reason of third purulent matter. (TA.) ― -b2- tafa$~aAhumo, and tf$~Y bihimo, said of a disease, It became much among them, (K, TA,) and spread: or, as in the T, became common, or general, or universal, among them: AZ mentions the verb as with hemz. (TA. [See 5 in art. f$A^.]) ― -b3- And tf$~Y AlHiborufiY AlkaAgadi The ink infiltrated into the paper upon which one had written, it (the paper) being thin. (TA.)
fa$oyaAnN * , accord. to the K, but in the book of Az [i. e. the T] fa$ayaAnN, (TA,) A swoon (ga$oyapN) that betides a man; termed in Pers. taAsaA. (K, TA:) mentioned by Lth. (TA.)
fa$aA='N * The multiplication by propagation, and the numerousness, of cattle. (K.)

faA$iyapN * sing. of fawaA$K, (TA,) which signifies Such as spread themselves, of cattle pasturing at large, of sheep or goats, and of camels, &c. (S, K, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad., Dum~uwA fawaA$iyakumo Hat~aY ta*ohaba faHomapu AlEi$aA='i [Draw ye together your cattle pasturing at large, until the darkness, or intense blackness, of, or after, nightfall pass away]. (S, TA.) -A2- Also A sleep which a person takes during a portion of the night, after which he rises. (TA.)

1 faS~ahu * , [aor., accord. to rule,
faSu3a , and inf. n., accord. to Golius, faS~N,] (tropical:) He separated it from (mino) another thing; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ AftS~hu: (S, K:) and he pulled it out, or up, or off; or removed it; or displaced it; from another thing; (S, K;) as also ↓ the latter. (S.) -A2- faS~a, inf. n. faSaSN: see 7. -A3- faS~a AljuroHu, aor.
faSi3a , inf. n. faSiySN, (S, M, O, K,) like faz~a; (S, O;) The wound became moist, and flowed: (S, O, K:) or flowed: or flowed with somewhat, not much. (M.) And faS~a AlEaraqu The sweat exuded; (M, TA;) and so fiz~a. (TA.) ― -b2- faS~a said of the [locust, or cricket, called] junodab, (Sh, O, K,) inf. n. faSiySN (M, O) and faS~N, (M,) It uttered a sound. (Sh, M, O, K.) And, said of a child, (AA, O, K,) inf. n. faSiySN, (AA, O,) He uttered a weak weeping, (AA, O, K, TA,) like whistling. (TA.) ― -b3- And faSiySN signifies also The being in a state of commotion; and twisting, or winding. (M.) -A4- And one says, maA faS~a fiY yadi Y $aYo'N, (IAar, M, O, K,) aor.
faSi3a , inf. n. faS~N, (M,) Nothing remained, or became permanent, (IAar, O, K,) or accrued, (M,) [in my hand,] minohu, [thereof, or therefrom]. (M.)

2 fS~S AlxaAtama * [He set a faS~ (q. v.) in the ring, or signet]. (A.) -A2- fS~S biEayonihi, (A,) inf. n. tafoSiySN, (O, K,) (tropical:) He looked intently, or hardly: (A:) or he opened his eyes and looked intently, or hardly. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

4 A^afoSa3a
AfS~ A_ilayohi mino Haq~ihi $ayoA^F (assumed tropical:) He produced, or gave forth, (Fr, S, K,) or gave, (M,) to him somewhat of his right, or due. (Fr, S, M, K.)

7 AnfS~ * (tropical:) It became separated from (mino) another thing: (S, M, K, TA:) it became parted asunder, severed, disjoined, or disunited: (TA:) and i. q. Ainofaraja [app. as meaning it opened, so as to form an interval, an interstice, or a gap]; (L;) [and so, app., ↓ faS~a, aor.
faSa3a , inf. n. faSaSN; for] faSaSN is syn, with AinofiraAjN. (TA.) And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) He got out of or from (mn) a thing, and severed himself therefrom. (Mtr, in De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., tome iii., p. 232.) And AnofaSaSotu Eani AlkalaAmi means Ainofarajotu [i. e., app., I broke off from, or intermitted, speaking]. (L.)
8 A_ifotaSa3a see 1, in two places.
10 maA AstfS~ minohu $ayoA^F * (assumed tropical:) He did not extract, get out, or elicit, from him, or it, anything. (S, K.)

R. Q. 1 faSofaSa *
He told a narrative, or story, truly; (IAar, K, TA;) as though from its faS~, [q. v.,] and kunoh. (TA.) ― -b2- And [the inf. n.] signifies The being hasty in speech, (Ibn-'Abbád, 'O, K,) and quick therein. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) -A2- Also He fed a beast, or horse or the like, with fiSofiSap [q. v.]. (M.)

R. Q. 2 tafaSofaSuwA Eanohu * , (K, TA,) mino HawaAlayohi, (O, TA,) They dispersed themselves, and took themselves away, from him, (K, TA,) from around him; and took fright, and ran away at random. (O, TA.)

faS~N * , of a ring, or signet, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) signifies [The stone, or gem, or] what is set therein, (Lth, M, L, Msb,) of a different substance therefrom; (Msb;) and is also written ↓ fiS~N, (M, A, K,) thus pronounced by the vulgar, (Lth, S,) but J's saying this does not necessarily mean that it is incorrect, which, as in opposition to what is said by J, it is asserted not to be in the K [and A], (TA,) or the latter form is bad, accord. to ISk and El-Fárábee; (Msb;) and ↓ fuS~N; (A, K;) all of which three forms are mentioned by Ibn-Málik and others; but they assert that the first is the most correct and the most commonly known: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^afuS~N (Lth, M) and [of mult.] fuSuwSN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and fiSaASN. (Lth, M.) ― -b2- [Also, Any gem, or similar stone, rare or common, and natural or factitious: and any hard stone cut for inlaying or for construction. ― -b3- A die, such as is used in the game of tables, or backgammon: and an ossicle that is used in like manner: see kaEobN.] ― -b4- (tropical:) A clove (sin~N) of garlic; (Lth, A, O, K;) [and] so ↓ faS~apN. (S and L in art. sn.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The yolk of an egg. (M, voce muH~N.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) The bubbles of water. (M.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) What leaps, or leap, up, [i. e., the particles that leap up, in effervescence,] of wine. (M.) ― -b8- (tropical:) The black (Hadaqap) of the eye: (M, K:) [or the pupil: for] you say, Earafotu AlbagoDaA='a fiY faS~i Hadaqatihi (tropical:) [I knew vehement hatred in the pupil of the black of his eye]: and ramawohu bifuSuwSi A^aEoyunihimo (tropical:) [they cast piercing glances at him with their eyeballs]. (A, TA.) ― -b9- (tropical:) A joint, or place of separation between two parts of an animal: (M, A:) or any joint, (AZ, M,) or any place of meeting of two bones, (ISk, S, Msb, K,) except (of) the fingers, (AZ, M,) for the joints thereof are not so called: (M:) pl., in this and all the other senses which we have mentioned, [of pauc.] A^afuS~N (M) and [of mult.] fuSuwSN: (S, M, A, Msb:) or, as some say, contradicting AZ, the fSwS are the baraAjim and the sulaAmayaAt: [see these two words:] (Sh, TA:) and ISh says, in the “ Book of Horses, ” that the fSwS of the horse are the joints of the knee and pasterns, in which latter are the sulaAmayaAt, these being the bones of the pasterns. (TA.) One says of a horse, A_in~a fuSuwSahu laZimaA='N (tropical:) Verily his joints are hard; not flabby nor fleshy. (S, A.) [And hence, app., from the place in which it is mentioned by Z in this art., the saying,] fulaAnN Haz~aAzu AlfuSuwSi [in a copy of the A, Haz~aAru; and in the TA, DrAr; but I have no doubt that the right reading is that which I have given; lit., Such a one is the great cutter of joints;] meaning, (tropical:) Such a one is often right in his judgment, or opinion, and in his answer. (A, TA.) ― -b10- Hence, [immediately,] accord. to Abu-l-'Abbás; or [originally] from faS~N in the first of the senses expl. above, accord. to IDrd; (Mtr, cited in De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, see. ed. iii. 232;) faS~u A^amorK (tropical:) The point upon which a thing, or an affair, turns, or hinges; or the point in which it is distinguished, or discriminated, from other things; syn. mafoSiluhu; (Abu-l- 'Abbás ubi suprà, S, Msb, K;) or maHaz~uhN: (Mtr ubi suprá:) [or its utmost point, or particular; syn. munotahaAhu: (Msb in art. fSl, in explanation of mafoSilu A^morK:)] or its origin, or source; syn. A^aSoluh; (M; and Mtr ubi suprà, and L;) and maxorajuhu Al~a*Y qado xaraja minohu: (L, TA:) and its essence, or very essence; its substance; its most essential, or elementary, part; its pith; the ultimate element to which it can be reduced or resolved; syn. Haqiyqatuhu, (M, L, TA,) and kunohuhu, i. e. jawoharuhu, and nihaAyatuhu: (L, TA:) or its real, as opposed to its apparent, state; syn. maxobaruhu. (A, TA.) Hence the saying, (S, Msb, TA,) of a poet, (S, TA,) or of Ez-Zubeyr Ibn-El-'Owwám, (TA,) or of 'AbdAllah Ibn-Jaafar Ibn-Abee-Tálib, (Mtr ubi suprà, and TA,)
wayaA^otiyka biAlA^amori mino faS~ihi
(tropical:) [And he will tell thee the thing, or affair, tracing it from the point on which it turns, or hinges; &c.: but it appears to be originally without wa; forming an incomplete hemistich: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 918]: (S, M, * A, * Mtr, TA:) or he will tell thee the thing, or affair, distinctly. (Msb, TA. *) You say also, qaraA^otu fiY faS~i AlkitaAbi ka*aA (tropical:) [I read, in the most essential part of the book or writing, such a thing]. (A, TA.) And hence, fuSuwSu AlA^axobaAri (tropical:) [The most essential parts or particulars of narrations]. (A.)
fuS~N * : see faS~N, first signification.
fiS~N * : see faS~N, first signification.
faS~apN * : see faS~N, former half.
faSiySN * [as an inf. n.: see 1. -A2- Also] Datestones (nawFY) clean, as though oiled. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
faS~aASN * [A cutter, or an engraver, or a seller, of fuSuwS, or stones, or gems, for rings or signets]. (TA.)
faSofiSN * : see what next follows.

fSofiSapN * (S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ fiSofiSN (M) A certain plant; (K;) i. q. raTobapN [a species of trefoil, or clover], (S, M, Msb,) a food for beasts, or horses and the like, (TA,) before it dries up; after which it is called qat~: (Msb:) or i. q. qat~N: or qat~ in its fresh state: (M:) also written with s: (TA:) originally, (S, M,) in Pers., (S, M, K,) A_isofisoto, (so in copies of the S,) or A_isobisoto, (so in a copy of the S and one of the M) or A_isobisoto, (K, and so, accord. to the TA, in the hand writing of Az,) or A_isoPisoto: (CK:) pl. faSaAfiSu. (S, M, Msb.)

fuSaAfiSN *
Hardy; strong; (O, K, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.)

AlfuSaAfSapu *
The lion. (O, K.)
xaAtamN mufaS~aSN * [A ring, or signet, having a faS~ set in it]. (A.)

1 faSuHa * , (S, A, Mz in the 9th nwE, and so in some copies of the K as stated in the TA,) [aor.
faSuHa ,] inf. n. faSaAHapN, (KL,) or faSoHN; (Mz ubi suprà, on the authority of Er-Rághib;) or ↓ fS~H; (so in other copies of the K;) or the latter also; (A;) and ↓ AfSH; (A, K, Mz;) said of milk, It became divested of the froth, (S, A, K, Mz,) which is the primary signification accord. to Er-Rághib; (Mz;) and clear of its biestings: (A:) or ↓ AfSH has this latter signification. (S, L, K.) And faSoHN, accord. to Er-Rághib, signifies [also] A thing's becoming clear of what was mixed with it. (Mz ubi suprà.) ― -b2- And [hence] faSuHa, (S, Msb, K, and Mz ubi suprà,) [aor.
faSuHa ,] inf. n. faSaAHapN (S, K) and faSoHN, (K,) (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, good in his language, or dialect; a metaphorical signification from the same verb as said of milk; so accord. to Er-Rághib: (Mz: see also 4: [and see faSaAHahN below:]) or he (a foreigner) was, or became, good and correct in his language, or dialect: (S, Msb:) or he [a man] was, or became, clear, perspicuous, or distinct, in speech, or language: and he (a foreigner) spoke Arabic intelligibly: but this signification seems to belong more properly to A^afoSaHa, q. v.:] or he [a man] was an Arab [by birth, and therefore in speech], and he increased in faSaAHap [q. v.]; like ↓ tfS~H: (K:) and he was, or became, eloquent; (L;) thus used as syn. with baluga [from which it is properly distinct]. (MF.) -A2- qado faSaHaka AlS~uboHu [is said to mean] (assumed tropical:) Daybreak has become apparent to thee, and its light has overcome thee: (K, * TA:) and some say, faDaHaka: [or,] accord. to Lh, faSaHahu AlS~uboHu means daybreak came upon him suddenly. (TA.)
2 fS~H * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) He (a foreigner) made his tongue to speak Arabic. (A.)

4 AfSH * : see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- It is also said of urine, (K, TA,) as mentioned by IAar, but not expl. by him, (TA,) meaning It became clear, or free from turbidness. (K.) ― -b3- And AfSHt is said of a ewe, or she-goat, (S, A, K,) and of a she-camel, (TA,) meaning Her milk became free from admixture; (K;) or free from froth, and clear of its biestings: (A:) or her biestings ceased, and the milk came after: (Lh, TA:) or her biestings ceased, and her milk became free from admixture. (S.) ― -b4- And [hence] AfSH signifies also (tropical:) He spoke with faSaAHap; (K, TA;) [i. e. clearness, perspicuousness, or distinctness; accord. to the explanation of fSAHp in the K, and the usage of this verb in numerous exs.; or with chasteness, or correctness;] as also AfSH AlkalaAma and AfSH bihi, and AfSH Alqawola; but when the verb became in frequent use, and commonly known, the objective complement became dropped, as in the case of A^aHosana, &c.: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) he spoke clearly, or plainly, (A, * K, *
TA,) to another; (A, TA;) without indistinctness, or without concealment: (TA:) [and] (tropical:) he (a foreigner) spoke Arabic: (S, A, Msb:) or (assumed tropical:) spoke Arabic correctly: (ISk, Msb:) [and] (assumed tropical:) he (a man of barbarous or vitious or indistinct speech) spoke intelligibly. (L.) And one says, AfSH fiY manoTiqihi (tropical:) He (a child) began to speak intelligibly. (A, L.) And ↓ AfSH fulaAnN vum~a faSuHa (tropical:) [He spoke Arabic, and then became good in his language, or dialect: so accord. to Er-Rághib, as cited in the Mz, 9th nwE; in which it is said that some, but not so correctly, use these two verbs in the converse manner: or he spoke clearly, or intelligibly, and then became chaste, or good and correct, or eloquent, in his speech, or language]. (A.) And AfSH is also used in poetry as signifying (assumed tropical:) He (an animal not endowed with speech) uttered a sound, or cry, clearly. (L.) And one says, AfSH Eano $aYo'K, inf. n. A_ifoSaAHN [in this and the preceding senses], meaning (tropical:) He explained a thing. (A, * TA.) And AfSH Eano muraAdihi (assumed tropical:) He showed or revealed [his desire or his meaning]. (Msb.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) became clearly apparent, manifest, or evident. (K.) One says, AfSH AlS~uboHu (tropical:) The daybreak became clearly apparent; (A, * K;) the light of daybreak appeared. (S.) ― -b6- And AfSH Alr~ajulu mino ka*aA (assumed tropical:) The man got clear out of such a thing; or escaped from it. (S, TA.) You say, nufoSiHu mino $itaAy^inaA (tropical:) We shall get clear out of our winter. (A.) ― -b7- And A^afoSaHuwA (tropical:) They (the Christians, S, A, K) entered upon, (S, K,) or celebrated, (A,) the festival called AlfiSoH [or Easter], (S, A, K,) and broke their fast, eating flesh-meat. (TA.) [And said also of Jews, meaning They celebrated the Passover: see AlfiSoHu.]

5 tfS~H * (tropical:) He affected (takal~afa) the faculty, or quality, of faSaAHap [q. v.] (S, A, TA) fiY kalaAmihi [in his speech]; as also ↓ tfASH: (S:) or he made use of the faculty of faSaAHap: or, as some say, [but accord. to general analogy, this signification seems to belong more properly to ↓ tfASH,] he affected a resemblance to those endowed with that faculty; [or made a show of fSAHp;] like taHal~ama as meaning “ he made a show of AlHilom ” [i. e. “ forbearance, ” &c.; in which sense taHaAlama is more commonly used]. (TA.) See also 1, latter part.
6 tafaAoSaHa see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

10 A_isotafoSaHa [AstfSHhu (assumed tropical:) He deemed it faSiyH as meaning chaste, or free from barbarousness, &c.; namely, a word, or phrase: and probably used in a similar sense in relation to a man: but perhaps post-classical: its pass. part. n. occurs in the Mgh, in art. bnY.] ― -b2- AisotafoSaHotuhu Eano ka*aA (assumed tropical:) [I asked him, or desired him, to explain such a thing: see 4, latter half]. (O and K in art. snH.)
faSoHN * : see faSiyHN.

fiSoHN * : see faSiyHN, first sentence. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A day cloudless by reason of cold; (ISh, T, TA,) or a day without clouds and without cold; as also ↓ mufoSiHN. (K.) ― -b3- And AlfiSoHu [or Eiydu AlfiSoHi] (vulgarly pronounced AlfaSoH, ISk, Msb) (tropical:) The festival of the Christians, (S, A, Msb, K,) [namely, Easter,] when they break their fast, and eat flesh-meat, (S, Msb,) after haring fasted eight and forty days, the Sunday after these days being their festival: (TA:) [and the Passover of the Jews; also called AlfaAsixa; thus with s and x; more properly called Eiydu AlfaTiyri:] pl. fuSuwHN. (Msb, TA.)

faSiyHN * Milk divested of the froth, (S, A,) and clear of its biestings; (A:) or milk that has come after the ceasing of the biestings; as also ↓ fiSoHN. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (tropical:) Chaste, as meaning free from barbarousness: applied in this sense to a word, or an expression, and to language in general, and to a speaker, or writer: i. e.,] as applied to a word, or an expression, it means [free from an incongruous combination of letters and from strangeness and from contrariety to analogy not sanctioned by frequency of usage among the Arabs of pure speech; (see faSaAHapN, below:) or] of which the beauty is perceived by hearing: (K:) and as applied to language in general, [free from weakness of construction and from incongruity of works, with faSaAHap (which see again) in the words themselves:] as used by the vulgar, it means in which the rules of desinential syntax are observed: syn. muEorabN: (L;) [and sometimes it means] eloquent; syn. baliygN. [from which it is properly distinct]: (S:) and as applied to a man, [possessing a faculty whereby he is enabled to express what he desires, with faSaAHap (which see again) in languages or] clear, perspicuous, or distinct, in speech, or language; as also ↓ faSoHN; (K;) but this latter is an intensive epithet, [being originally an inf. n.,] like EadolN: (TA:) [and sometimes it signifies] eloquent; syn. balaygN [respecting which see what precedes]: (S, A:) or munoTaliqu All~isaAni [i. e. free from impediment of the tongue, or eloquent, or chaste,] in speech, who knows how to distinguish what is good in language from what is bad: (TA;) the pl. as applied to men is fuSaHaA='i and fiSaAHN and fuSuHN, (K, TA,) the last formed in the manner of the broken pl. of a subst., like quDubN pl. of qaDiybN: (Sb, TA:) the fem. is faSiyHapN; of which the pl. is fiSaAHN and faSaAy^iHu. (K, TA.) And you say rajulN faSiyHu All~isaAni (assumed tropical:) A man whose tongue speaks Arabic correctly. (Msb.) And lisaAnN faSiyHN i. q. TaloqN (assumed tropical:) [A tongue free from impediment, or eloquent, or chaste in speech]: (S:) or (tropical:) an eloquent tongue. (A.) And faSiyHN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Any one having the faculty of speech; (S;) [i. e.] a human being; (TA:) A^aEojamu meaning that which is “ destitute of the faculty of speech; ” (S;) [i. e.] “ a beast; ” as also SaAmtN: whence the saying, lahu maAlN faSiyHN waSaAmitN (tropical:) [as though meaning He has property consisting of human beings and of beasts: but see SaAmitN]. (TA.) And it also occurs in poetry as meaning (assumed tropical:) Clear, applied to the cry of an ass. (L.)

faSaAHapN * , [an inf. n. of faSuHa, q. v.: as denoting a quality of a word, and of language in general, and of a speaker or writer, from the same word as relating to milk, it signifies (tropical:) Chasteness, as meaning freedom from barbarousness: i. e.,] in a word, freedom from an incongruous combination of letters and from strangeness and from contrariety to analogy [not sanctioned by frequency of usage among the Arabs of pure speech; (KT, and Mz in the 9th nwE;) [for] the point upon which it turns is the frequency of the use of a word by the Arabs [of pure speech]; (Mz ibid.;) a word being known to have this quality by its being frequently used by the Arabs in whose Arabic confidence is placed, or by its being used by them more frequently than one synonymous therewith: (El-Kazweenee in the “ Eedáh, ” cited in the same nwE of the Mz:) and in language [in general], freedom from weakness of construction (ZaEofu Alt~aA^oliyfi q. v.) and from incongruity of words, combined with faSaAHap in the words themselves: (KT:) and in a speaker [or writer] a faculty whereby one is enabled to express what he desires, with faSaAHap in language: (KT:) or goodness and correctness in language, or dialect: (S:) or clearness, perspicuousness, or distinctness, in speech, or language: (K:) and [agreeably with an explanation of faSiyHN in the S and A &c.] it is sometimes used as meaning eloquence; syn. balaAgapN [from which it is properly distinct]. (MF.)
A^afoSaHu * [More, and most, chaste, as meaning fra from barbarousness; &c.]: in the Kur xxviii. 34, it means more clear or perspicuous or distinct [in tongue] (Jel.)

[
A^afoSaHiy~apN * The quality of being more, and most, chaste, as meaning free from barbarousness: &c.]

mufoSaHN * [or as a n. of place from A^afoSaHuwA (see 4, last two sentences)] A place where the Christians celebrate the festival called AlfiSoHu [or Easter (A.) [And app. also A place where the Jews celebrate the festival so called by them, i. e. the Passover.]
mufoSiHN * : see fiSoHN. ― -b2- Also Anything clearly apparent, manifest, or evident. (S.)

1 faSada * , (S, O, K,) aor
faSida , (K,) inf. n. faSodN (S, O, K) and fiSaAdN, (O, K,) [or the latter is a simple subst.,] He cut, (S, O,) or slit, (K,) [or opened,] a vein; (S, O, K,) as also ↓ AftSd. (S, * K.) ― -b2- And faSadahu, aor.
faSida , inf. n. faSodN (M, L, Msb) and fiSaAdN, (M, L,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) He cut, or slit, [or opened,] it, namely, a vein, (M, L.) [And app., accord. to
the Msb, He bled him by opening a vein; agreeably with what here follows.] And one says also, faSada Aln~aAqapa He slit [or opened] a vein of the she-camel to draw forth the blood therefrom and to drink it [or to put it in a gut and broil it: see faSiydN]. (M L.) ― -b3- lamo yuHoramo mano fuSoda lahu He has not been denied the entertainment of a guest for whom a camel has been bled by the slitting [or opening] of a vein and who has had the blood so obtained, (M, A, * K,) is a prov.; (S, M, A, O;) fuSoda being for fuSida, (S, M, O, K,) like Duroba for Duriba, and qutola for qutila; (M;) and some, also, say fuzoda; (S, M, O, K;) for every quiescent S before d may be changed into z; and every movent S before d may have somewhat of the sound of z given to it, (S, M, O,) but may not in this case be altogether changed into z; so that for Sadara and Sadafa you may not say zadara and zadafa: (M:) some, also, say mano quSida lahu, with q, meaning mano A^uEoTiYa qaSodFA i. e.
