[who has been given] a little: (S, O, K:) the origin of the saying was this: two men passed the night at the abode of an Arab of the desert, and, meeting in the morning, one of them asked his companion respecting the entertainment given by the host, and the latter answered, “ I was not entertained as a guest, but only a vein [of a camel] was slit [or opened] to draw blood for me; ” whereupon the other replied in the words above: (O, K:) or a man used to entertain another as his guest in a time of scarcity, and, having no food to offer him, and being unwilling to slaughter his camel, bled it by slitting [or opening] a vein, and heated the blood that came forth, for his guest, until it became thick, and gave it to him to eat; and hence this prov.: (M, L:) it is applied to him who has obtained a part of that which he wanted. (Yaakoob, M, O, L, K.) [See faSiydN.] ― -b4- One says also, faSada lahu EaTaA='F, (O, L, K,) aor.
faSida , inf. n. faSodN, (L,) meaning He apportioned to him a gift, or stipend, and caused it to be transmitted to him. (O, L, K.)

entryFree.key: raA^ayotu fiY AlA^aroDi tafoSiydFA mina Als~ayoli

div2.entryFree: 2 raA^ayotu fiY AlA^aroDi tafoSiydFA mina Als~ayoli * means I saw, in the ground, a cleft, or furrowed, state, resulting from the torrent. (ISh, O, L, K. * [Here tafoSiydFA is a pass. inf. n., used as a subst.]) ― -b2- And tafoSiydN, also, signifies The macerating [a thing] with a little water. (ADk, O, K.)
4 AfSd Al$~ajaru * , and ↓ AnfSd, The trees opened their gems, (M, K,) and disclosed the extremities of their leaves. (M.)

5 tafaS~ada see 7. [Hence,] tfS~d jabiynuhu EaraqFA His jbyn [i. e. forehead, or side of the forehead,] flowed with sweat: (M, O:) the last word is here put in the accus. case as a specificative; and has the force of an agent; the meaning being, the sweat of his jbyn flowed. (M.)
7 A_inofaSada see 4. ― -b2- Also, and ↓ tfS~d, It flowed: (S, O:) or both signify it flowed in small quantity; said of blood. (A.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

8 A_ifotaSada
He (a man) had his vein cut [or opened; i. e. he had blood taken from him by the opening of a vein; and so ↓ AnfSd as used in the present day]. (Lth, L, Msb. *) ― -b2- See also 1, first sentence.
fuSodapN * : see faSiydapN.
fiSaAdN * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]: (M, O, L, K:) or a simple subst. [signifying The act of bleeding by opening a vein]. (Msb.)

faSiydN * and ↓ mafoSuwdN A vein slit [or opened]. (M, K.) ― -b2- And both signify also A man bled by the opening of a vein. (TK.) ― -b3- Also, the former, Blood (S, M, O, L, K) obtained by the cutting [or opening] of a vein (S, O, L) of a camel, (L,) and put into a gut, (S, M, O, K,) in the Time of Ignorance, (M,) and broiled: (S, M, K:) the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance used to eat it, (M, A, * L,) and to give it to the guest to eat, in a season of dearth. (S, O, * L.)

faSiydapN *
Dates kneaded and mixed with blood; (Ibn-Kuthweh, O, L, K;) as also ↓ fuSodapN; (O, K;) thus termed by Ibn-'Abbád: (O:) a medicine given to children. (Ibn-Kuthweh, O, L.)

faS~aAdN *
A phlebotomist, or bleeder. (MA. [See also what next follows.])
faASidN * [Bleeding, or (like faS~aAdN) one who bleeds, by opening a vein]. (Msb.) ― -b2- And AlfaASidaAni signifies The place [or the two places] of the running of the tears upon the cheek. (O.)
AiEoSibo mafoSidahu * [Bind thou his place of bloodletting]. (A.)
mifoSadN * [A lancet;] the instrument with which a vein is slit [or opened]. (O, Msb, K.)
mafoSuwdN * : see faSiydN.
mutafaS~idN * : see what follows.
munofaSidN * and ↓ mutafaS~idN Flowing; (M, K;) running: (K:) [or flowing in small quantity: see 7.]

1 faSaEa * , aor.
faSaEa , (Lth, O, K,) inf. n. faSoEN, (Lth, S, O,) He squeezed, or pressed, a fresh ripe date, (Lth, S, O, K,) with his two fingers [or his thumb and a finger], (Lth, O,) so that it should become divested of its skin; (Lth, S, O;) and in like manner, a fig: (Lth, O:) or he made it (i. e. a fresh ripe date) to come forth from its skin, (A'Obeyd, O,) [to which SM adds, as from A' Obeyd,] in order that it might ripen quickly. (TA.) The act thus explained is forbidden in a trad.; [but I have not found for what reason.] (S, O.) ― -b2- And He rubbed a thing with his two fingers, (in the K, erroneously, with his finger, TA,) in order that it might become soft, and open so as to disclose what was in it. (IDrd, O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And He pulled or stripped, or put off, [a garment or the like]. (O, TA.) You say, faSaEa EimaAmatahu (O, K,) Eano raA^osihi (K) He removed, or took off, his turban from his head. (O, K.) ― -b4- Said of a boy [not yet circumcised], He withdrew his prepuce from his glans; and so ↓ AftSE. (S, O, K.) ― -b5- faSaEato said of a mare; She disclosed and concealed alternately her vulva on the occasion of staling. (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.) ― -b6- faSaEa liY bika*aA, (K,) inf. n. faSoEN, (TA,) He gave to me such a thing: (K:) [or] liY biHaq~iY ↓ fS~E, inf. n. tafoSiyEN, he gave to me my right, or due: (Ibn-' Abbád, O:) and faSaEa lahu biA@lomaAli he gave to him the property; as also ↓ fS~E. (K.)

2 faS~aEotuhu mino ka*aA * , inf. n. tafoSiyEN, I made it to go, or come, forth from such a thing. (IAar, S, L, TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence, in two places. ― -b3- Accord. to Lth, fS~E, inf. n. as above, is also used in relation to a stink, and the ordure of a child, and a noiseless emission of wind from the anus: (O:) [or] it means He emitted wind from the anus with a sound: or without a sound. (K.)

7 AnfSE *
It went, or came, forth from a thing; or was made to do so; quasi-pass. of faS~aEotuhu mino ka*aA (S.)

8 AifotaSaEotu minohu Haq~iY *
I took from him my right, or due, (O, K, *) all of it, (K,) by force, (O, K,) not leaving of it anything: (O:) or I took from him my right, or due, all of it, on the spot. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also 1, latter half.

fuSoEapN * The prepuce of a boy, (IDrd, T, O, K, TA,) when it is wide, so that the glans protrudes from it, (IDrd, O, K, TA,) or when he withdraws it from over the glans, before he is circumcised. (T, TA.)

faSoEaAnu *
Having the head always uncovered, by reason of heat and inflammation. (IAar, O, K.)

A^afoSaEu * A boy having the prepuce appearing (S, O, K) withdrawn from the glans. (S, O.) -A2- And AlfaSoEaA='u [fem. of AlA^afoSaEu] signifies AlfaA^orapu [app. as n. un., or fem., of AlfaA^oru q. v.; but it may here have some other of the meanings expl. in art. fA^r]. (IAar, K.)

1 faSala * , (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faSila , inf. n. faSolN, (M, Msb, K,) He separated, or divided, (S, O, Msb, K,) and put apart, (Msb,) a thing, (S, O, Msb, *) Eano gayorihi [from another thing], (Msb,) and baEoDahu mino baEoDK [or Eano baEoDK i. e. part thereof from part]. (M and TA in art. myz.) And (K,) He made a separation, or partition, (M, K, TA,) bayonahumaA (M, TA *) i. e. between them two, meaning, two things, making it known that the former had come to an end: so says Er-Rághib: (TA:) and faSala AlHad~u bayona AlA^aroDayoni, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, The limit, or boundary, made, or formed, a separation between the two lands: (Msb:) and faSalotu bayona Alqawomi I made a division, or separation, between, or among, the people, or party. (O.) ― -b2- [Hence,] faSala Alr~DiyEa Eano A^um~ihi, (S, Mgh, O,) or Almawoluwda (M, K) Eani Alr~aDaAEi, (M,) aor. as above,
(M, K,) inf. n. fiSaAlN, (S, O,) or faSolN, and the former is a simple subst., (M, K,) or both, (Mgh,) He weaned [the suckling from his mother, or the young infant from sucking the breast]; (S, M, Mgh, O, K;) as also ↓ AftSlhu: (S, M, O:) or faSalati AlmaroA^apu raDiyEahaA, inf. n. faSolN, and fiSaAlN is the subst., the woman weaned her suckling. (Msb.) ― -b3- Hence also, i. e. from faSala as first expl. above, faSolu AlxuSuwmaAti The deciding of litigations, altercations, or disputes: like faSolu AlxiTaAbi: (Msb:) or this latter means distinct, or plain speech; which he to whom it is addressed distinctly, or plainly, understands; which is not confused, or dubious, to him: (Ksh in explanation of it in the Kur xxxviii. 19, and Mgh:) or such as decides, or distinguishes, between what is true and what is false, (Ksh ibid., Mgh, O, K,) and what is sound and what is corrupt, (Ksh, Mgh,) and what is correct and what is erroneous: (Ksh:) or such as decides the judgment, or judicial sentence: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the evidence, or proof, that is obligatory [as a condition of his justification] upon the claimant, or plaintiff, and the oath that is obligatory [in like manner] upon him against whom the claim, or plaint, is urged; (Ksh, O, K; [an explanation of which a part is dropped in the CK;]) thus accord. to 'Alee: (Ksh:) or the [using of the] phrase A^am~aA baEodu. (Ksh, O, K. [Respecting this phrase, and for other explanations, see 3 in art xTb.]) kalimapu AlfaSoli in the Kur xlii. 20 means The sentence of God's deciding between mankind on the day of resurrection, (O,) which is called yawomu AlfaSoli. (TA.) And AlfaSolu [alone] means The deciding judicially between what is true and what is false; (M, O, K;) and, (O, K,) sometimes, (O,) so ↓ AlfayoSalu; (S, O, K;) or this latter is [a simple subst, i. e.,] a name for such decision; (TA;) and is also an epithet [expl. below]. (M, O, K.) h`*aA yawomu A@ld~iyni h`*aA yawomu A@lofaSoli, in the Kur xxxvii. 20 and 21, means [This is the day of requital:] this is the day wherein a decision, or a distinction, shall be made (yufoSalu fiyhi) between the doer of good and the doer of evil, and every one shall be requited for his work and with that wherewith God will favour his servant the Muslim. (M.) And A_in~a rab~aka huwa yafoSilu bayonahumo yawoma A@loqiyaAmapi fiymaA kaAnuwA fiyhi yaxotalifuwna, in the Kur xxxii. 25, means [Verily thy Lord] He shall decide [between them], and distinguish what is true from what is false, [on the day of resurrection,] by distinguishing the speaker of what is true from the speaker of what is false, in respect of that wherein they used to disagree, of what concerned religion. (Bd.) And one says also faSala AlHukoma [He decided the judgment, or judicial sentence]. (M.) faSala Aln~aZoma, in the K, is a mistake: see 2. (TA.) -A2- faSala mina Aln~aAHiyapi, (S, O,) or mino Albaladi (K,) or Eano baladika*aA, aor.
faSula , (M,) inf. n. fuSuwlN, (M, K,) He went forth [from the part of the country, or from the town or country, or from such a town or country]. (S, O, K.) And faSala AlEasokaru Eani Albaladi [The army went forth from the town or country]: whence the saying of the Prophet respecting Ibn-Rawáhah, kaAna A^aw~alanaA fuSuwlFA waA=xirunaAqufuwlFA i. e. He was the first of us in going away (↓ AinofiSaAlFA) from his house and his family and the last of us in returning to [it and] them. (Mgh.) And faSala fulaAnN mino EinodiY, inf. n. fuSuwlN, Such a one went forth [from my presence or vicinage, or from me]. (TA.) And faSala min~iY kitaAbu A_ilayohi [A letter] passed from me to him. (TA.) Thus the verb is intrans, as well as trans.; its inf. n. when it is trans, being faSolN; when intrans., fuSuwlN. (TA.) ― -b2- And faSala Alkaromu The vine put forth small grapes, resembling lentils or a grain similar thereto. (M, K.)

2 fS~l Aln~aZoma * , (M, TA,) thus correctly, with teshdeed, bat in the K faSala, like naSara, (TA,) [inf. n. tafoSiylN,] He put between every two of the strung beads [or pearls] a bead such as is termed faASilapN [q. v., or what is described voce mufaS~lN as an epithet applied to a necklace]. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- And fS~ltu Al$~Yo'a inf. n. tafoSiylN, I made the thing to consist of distinct portions or sections. (Msb.) ― -b3- And fS~l Al$~Apa, (inf. n. as above, TA.) He (a butcher) divided the sheep, or goal, into limbs, or members. (S, O, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence fS~l means also He cut a piece of cloth for a garment: and he cut out a garment: ― -b5- whence tafoSiylN means The cut of a garment (See also De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., see. ed., i. 86-7.)] ― -b6- And [hence, likewise,] tafoSiylN also signifies [The dissecting, or analyzing, of speech, or language: the explaining distinctly, or in detail: and] the making distinct, clear, plain, manifest, or perspicuous; i. q. taboyiynN. (S, O, K.) faS~alonaAhu in the Kur vii. 50 [referring to the book of the Kur an] means by~n~aAhu [Which we have made distinct, &c.]: or, as some say, whereof we have divided the verses by means of the fawaASil [pl. of faASilpN, q. v.]. (TA.)

3 faAoSala
fASl $ariykahu, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. mufaASalapN, (TA,) He separated himself from his partner, with the latter's concurrence; syn. baAyanahu, (K, TA,) and faArazahu. (S and O and K in art. frz.)

7 AnfSl *
It became separated, or divided, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) and put apart (Msb.) ― -b2- [And He went forth, or away; like the intrans. faSala.] See 1, near the end.

8 A_ifotaSala see 1, former half. ― -b2- AftSl Aln~axolapa Eano mawoDiEihaA He transplanted the palm-tree. (AHn, M, K.) A man of Hejer [which is famous for its dates] said that the best of palm-trees is that of which the young one has been removed from its place of growth, which young one is called ↓ faSolapN. (TA.)

faSolN * inf. n. of the trans. v. faSala [q. v. passim]. (M, Msb, K, TA.) [As a simple subst., it has various significations here following: and is] sing. of fuSuwlN. (S, O.) ― -b2- A separation, division, or partition, between two things. (M, K.) ― -b3- The place of the mafoSil [i. e. joint, or articulation, and therefore of the division, of two bones] of the body: between every one such and another [that is the next to it] is a wiSol [or limb, in the CK, erroneously, waSol]. (Lth, O, K.) See also mafoSilN. ― -b4- As used by the Basrees, [in grammar,] it is [A disconnective] like EimaAdN as used by the Koofees: (O, K:) thus in the saying in the Kur [viii. 32], A_no kaAna h`*aA huwa A@loHaq~a mino Einodika [lit. If this, it, be the truth from Thee], hw is termed fSl and EmAd, [more commonly the former,] and AlHq~ is in the accus. case as being the predicate of kAn. (O.) ― -b5- Also sing. of fuSuwl in the phrase fuSuwlu Als~anapi [The four divisions of the year: namely autumn, winter, spring, and summer], expl. in art. zmn. (Msb: see zamanN.) ― -b6- And A division, or section, of a bAb [or chapter]; as being divided from others, or as forming a division between itself and others, so that it has the meaning of the measure mafoEuwlN or that of the measure faAEilN. (MF, TA.) ― -b7- And The contr. of A^aSolN [as denoting relationship]: there are A^uSuwl of relationship and fuSuwl thereof; [the former meaning the stocks and] the latter meaning the branches. (Msb. [See also other explanations of faSolN as opposed to A^SolN under the latter of these words ;) -A2- [It is also used as an epithet;] One say (??) faSolN A true say or saying: (M, K;) not false: thus in the Kur [lxxxvi. 15]: (M.) or (??) there means distinguishing between what is true and what is false: and relates to the Kur án [itself]. (Ksh, Bd, Jel.) And it is said of the speech of the Prophet that it was faSalN laAnazorN walaA ha*arN, (O, TA, but in the latter ha*orN [to assimilate it in form to nazorN],) meaning Distinct, (O, TA,) clear, or plain, distinguishing between what is true and what is false; (TA;) not little are much. (O.) -A3- And A general TaAEuwn [i. e. plague or pestilence] (TA.)

faSolapN *
A transplanted palm-tree; (AHn, M, K;) a young palm-tree removed from its place of growth [meaning from its mother-tree]: pl. faSalaAtN. (TA.) See 8.

fiSaAlN * an inf. n., (S, Mgh, O,) or a simple subst., (M, Msb, K,) The weaning of a sucking infant. (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur [xlvi. 14], waHamoluhu wafiSaAluhu valaAvuwna $ahorFA, (O, TA,) meaning And the period of the bearing of him in the womb and thenceforward to the end of the time of the weaning of him is thirty months. (TA.) And one says, h`*aA zamanu fiSaAlihi This is the time of the weaning of him. (Msb.)

fSiylN *
A young camel when weaned from his mother: (S, M, Mgh, * O, K, TA:) and some times such a young one of the bovine kind: (TA:) [and by a proleptic application,] a young camel [in a general sense], because he is, or will be, weaned from his mother: (Msb:) [in the T, voce HuwaArN,
and in other lexicons &c., it is applied to a young, newly-born, camel: and in the L, voce suxodN, to a fœtus in a she-camel's belly: see an ex. of its meaning a young sucking camel (one of many such exs.) in the first paragraph of art. rjl; and a strange similar usage of the first of the following pls. in a verse cited voce xasofN:] the pl. is fuSolaAnN, (Sb, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) agreeably with rule, (Sb, M,) and fiSolaAnN, (Sb, Fr, M, Msb, K,) formed by likening the sing. to guraAbN, of which girobaAnN is a pl., (Sb, M,) and fiSaAlN, (Sb, S, M, Msb, K,) as though it were an epithet, (Sb, M, Msb,) like kariymN, of which kiraAmN, is a pl.: (Msb:) and the female is termed faSiylapN. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also A HaAy^iT [or wall of enclosure], (M, O, K,) having little height, (O, K,) before, or in front of, a fortress; (M, K;) or (K) before, or in front of, the [main] wall of a city or town. (O, K.) One says, wav~aquwA suwra Almadiynapi bikibaA$K wafaSiylK [They strengthened the wall of the city by means of buttresses and a low wall in front of it]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A piece of stone; of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.)

faSiylapN *
A piece of the flesh of the faxi* [or thigh]: (Hr, IAth, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to Th, (O, in the K “ and ”) a piece of the limbs, or members, of the body. (O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And A man's nearer, or nearest, rahoT (S, M, O, K) and Ea$iyrap (M, K) [i. e. kinsfolk, or sub-tribe, &c.]: or [some] of the nearest of the Ea$iyrap of a man: from the first of the significations mentioned in this paragraph: (IAth, TA:) it signifies less than the faxi*: (Mgh, Msb:) or less than the qabiylap: (TA:) [see $aEobN in two places:] or the nearest to him of the A=baA=' [meaning male ancestors and including paternal uncles] of a man: (Th, M, K, TA:) [or any one of such persons; for] El-'Abbás [one of Mohammad's paternal uncles] was called faSiylapu Aln~abiy~i: the term is like the mafoSil in relation to the human foot. (TA.) jaAw^uwA bifaSiylatihimo means They came, all of them, or all together. (S, O.)
faS~aAlN * and epithet applied to a man, (O,) Who praises men much in order that they may bestow upon him: an adventitious, not indigenous, word: (O, K:) [and] loquacious in every place. (MA.)

faASilN * [as an act. part. n.] Separating; dividing; or making a separation, or partition. (Msb.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., mano A^anofaqa nafaqapF faASilapF fiY sabiyl A@ll~`hi fahiYa bisaboEimiAy^ap DiEafK, (S, * O, K, *) meaning [Whoso expends expense] such as distinguishes between his belief and his unbelief [i. e. such as distinguishes him as a believer, it shall be rewarded with seven hundred fold]: (S, O, K, TA:) or, as some say, such as he cuts off from his property. (TA.) And one says kalaAmN faASilN (K and TA in art. frz) and ↓ fayoSalN (A ibid.) i. q. faArizN (O and K, and TA ibid.) i. e. Discriminating language. (TA ibid.) And HukomN faASilN and ↓ fayoSalN [A judgment, or judicial sentence, that is decisive, and therefore meaning,] that has effect; and in like manner, ↓ HukuwmapN fayoSalN: and ↓ TaEonapN fayoSalN [An act of piercing or thrusting with a spear or the like] that decides between the two antagonists. (M, K, TA.) As an epithet applied to God, AlfaASilu means The Decider between the xaloq [i. e. the human race, or these and other created beings,] on the day of resurrection. (Zj, TA.)

fayoSalN * : see 1, near the middle. It also signifies A cut, or severance, (O, TA,) such as is complete, (TA,) between two persons. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And it is also an epithet: see faASilN, in four places. ― -b3- And [hence] it signifies (assumed tropical:) A judge, one who decides judicially, an arbiter, or arbitrator; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ fayoSaliY~N: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) in the Expos. of the “ Miftáh ” [of Es-Sekkákee] by the seyyid [El-Jurjánee] it is implied that it is in this sense a tropical intensive appellation. (TA.)

faASilapN *
A bead [or a bead of gold or a gem] that forms a separation, or division, between the pair of [other] beads [i. e. between every two other beads] in a string thereof. (M, K. [See also mufaS~alN.]) ― -b2- And [hence] fawaASilu, of which it is the sing., (assumed tropical:) The final words of the verses of the Kur-án, (O, K,) and of the clauses of rhyming prose [in general], (Msb and K and TA in art. sjE,) that are like the rhymes of verses; (O and K in the present art., and Msb and TA in art. sjE;) and [the final words] of verses. (TA in art. sjE.)
fayoSaliY~N * : see fayoSalN.

mafoSilN *
Any place of meeting [or juncture, as being a place of separation,] of two bones of the body and limbs or members; as also ↓ faSolN: (M, K:) a single one of the mafaASil of the limbs or members: (S, O, Msb, K:) [a joint such as the elbow and knee and knuckle: and sometimes a joint as meaning a bone having an articulation at each end, or at one end, together with the flesh that is upon it:] in a trad. in which it is said that the mulct for any mafoSil of a human being is the third of the mulct for the [whole] finger, it means the mafoSil of any of the fingers or toes; i. e. the portion between any A^anomalataAni [here meaning two knuckles; but this is a loose and an imperfect explanation; for to it should be added, and also the ungual portion, or portion in which is the nail; for the word is here applied to denote any of the phalanges with the flesh that is upon it: in the T &c., in art. nml, one of the explanations of AlA^anomalapu is “ the mafoSil in which is the nail ”]. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says, yaA^otiyka biAlA^amori mino mafoSilihi (assumed tropical:) [He will tell thee the thing, or affair, tracing it from the point on which it turns, or hinges; (like as one says, mino faS~ihi, q. v.;) or], from its utmost point or particular, i. e., munotahaAhu. (Msb.) [This saying may be originally a hemistich, thus:
wayaA^otiyka biAlA^amori mino mafoSiliho
like the similar saying ending with faS~ihi.] ― -b3- In the following saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, [the former half of which I give from art. Tfl in the S, the latter half only being cited in the present art. in the S and M and O,]
waA_in~a HadiyvFA minoki lawo tabo*uliynahu
janaY Aln~aHoli fiY A^alobaAni Euw*K maTaAfili
maTaAfiyla A^abokaArK HadiyvK nitaAjuhaA
tu$aAbu bimaA='K mivoli maA='i AlmafaASili
[And verily discourse from thee, if thou wouldst bestow it, would be (like) gathered honey of bees in the milk (lit. milks) of camels such as have recently brought forth, having young ones with them, such as have young ones with them [and] that have brought forth but once, whose bringing forth has been recent, such milk being mixed with water like the water of the mfASl], AlmafaASil (which is pl. of mafoSilN, S, O) signifies (accord. to As, S, O) the place of separation (↓ munofaSal) of the mountain from the tract of sand, these two having between them crushed and small pebbles, so that the water thereof is clear, (S, M, O,) and glistens, (wayaboruqu, S, O,) or and is shallow; (wayariq~u;) the poet meaning to describe the clearness of the water because of its descending from the mountain and not passing by dust nor earth: (M:) or it signifies hard stones (M, K) compactly disposed, or heaped up: (M, K: in the former, mutaraASifap: in the latter, mutaraAkimap:) and (M, K) it is said to signify (M) what is between two mountains, (M, K,) consisting of sand and crushed pebbles, the water whereof is clear: (K:) or, accord. to AO, the water-courses of a valley: (O:) accord. to Abu-l-'Omeythil, the clefts in mountains, from which water flows; and only said of what are between two mountains: in the T, the mafoSil is said to be any place, in a mountain, upon which the sun does not rise: (TA:) and it is said that maA='u AlmafaASili means what flows from between the two joints (mino bayoni AlmafoSilayoni) when one of them is cut from the other; like clear water; and the sing. is mafoSilN: (M:) AA says that the mfASl in the verse are the mfASl of the bones; and that it likens that water to the mA=' of the flesh: (O, TA:) and IAar says the like thereof. (TA.)
AlmifoSalN * (assumed tropical:) The tongue; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) as being likened to an instrument. (Msb.)

EiqodN mufaS~alN *
A necklace between every two pearls [or other beads] of which is put a bead [of another kind], (S, O, TA,) or a $a*orap [or bead of gold, &c.], or a gem, to form a division between every two of the same colour, or sort. (TA.) ― -b2- A=yaAtK mufaS~alaAtK, in the Kur [vii. 130] means [Signs, or miracles,] between every two whereof was made a separation by a period of delay: or which were made distinct, plain, or manifest. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlmufaS~alu is an appellation of The portion of the Kur-án from [the chapter entitled] AlHujuraAt [i. e. ch. xlix.] to the end; accord. to the most correct opinion: or from AljaAviyap [ch. xlv.]: or from AlqitaAl [ch. xlvii.]:
or from qaAf [ch. l.]: or from AlS~aAf~aAt [ch. xxxvii.]: or from AlS~af~ [ch. lxi.]: or from tabaAraka [ch. lxvii.]: or from A_in~aA fataHonaA [ch. xlviii.]: or from sab~iHi A@soma rab~ika [ch. lxxxvii.]: or from AlD~uHaY [ch. xciii.]: (K:) this portion is thus called because of its many divisions between its chapters: (Msb, K:) or because of the few abrogations therein: (K:) accord. to the A, it is the portion next after that called AlmavaAniY. (TA.)
munofaSalN * : see mafoSilN, latter half.

1 faSamahu * , (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
faSima , (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. faSomN, (S, M, Msb,) He broke it (S, M, Msb, K) without separating: (S, M, Msb:) [i. e. he cracked it:] and ↓ fS~mhu [he cracked it much, or in several places], (M, TA,) inf. n. tafoSiymN. (TA.) And faSama Alxurozapa [He cracked, or tore without separating, the seam, or suture, of a skin] (K and TA in art. xrm: in the CK qaSama and Alxarazapa.) AlqaSomu, with q, signifies “ the breaking so as to separate. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- (??). said of a house, or tent, (K,) or of the side thereof, (M,) It became thrown down, or demolished. (M, K.) ― -b4- And waSomN signifies A thing's being cracked. (A'Obeyd, TA.)
2 faS~ama see the preceding paragraph.

4 AfSm AlmaTaru *
The rain passed away, or ceased. (S, M, K.) And AfSmt Eanohu AlHum~aY The fever quitted him: (S, K, * TA:) in the K, erroneously. AfSm AlHum~aY. (TA.) And one says, ↓ daA='N yafoSimu walaA yufoSamu A disease that breaks and does not pass away. (TA.) ― -b2- And AfSm is said of a stallion [camel], meaning He ceased, or abstained, from covering. (TA.)
5 tafaS~ama see the next paragraph.

7 AnfSm *
It broke (S, M, Msb, K) without becoming separated: (S. M, Msb:) [i. e. it be came cracked:] and ↓ tfS~m has a similar meaning [i. e. it became cracked much, or in several places]. (S, M, K.) You say, AnfSm Zahoruhu His back cracked. (TA.) And AnfSmt Ald~ur~apu The pearl cracked in one part thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- And It broke, or became severed, or cut off. (K.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 257], laA A@nofiSaAma lahaA (S, M, Msb, TA) meaning There shall be no breaking incident to it. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And It opened so as to form an interstice, or a gap. (TA in art. $ZY.)
fSm Als~iwaAki * [app. faSom, originally an inf. n., but probably, I think, a mistranscription for qaSom,] A fragment [of the stick with which the teeth are cleaned]. (TA.)

faSomapN *
A crack in a wall. (TA.)

faA^osN faSiymo *
A large [hoe, or adz, or the like]. (Fr, K.)
A^afoSamu * An anklet much cracked. (El-Hejeree, M, K. *)
dumolujN mafoSuwmN * [A cracked armlet of silver: to this, thrown down and neglected, Dhu-r-Rummeh likens a sleeping gazelle]. (S, TA.)

1 faSaYa Al$~aYo'a mina Al$~aYo'i * , (M, K,) or Eani Al$~aYo'i, (Msb, and so in the TA,) improperly written in the copies of the K fSA, (TA,) aor. yafoSiyhi, (Msb, K,) inf. n. faSoYN, (M, Msb,) He separated the thing from the thing; (M, K;) or removed it therefrom: (Msb:) whence fSY AllHm En AlEZm [evidently meaning faSaY Al~aHoma Eani AlEaZomi i. e. He separated, or removed, the flesh from the bone]: (TA:) [but in both of my copies of the S, I find faSaYa Al~aHomu Eani AlEaZomi, as though faSaY were used as syn. with tfS~Y and AnfSY, meaning The flesh became freed, or cleared, from the bone: perhaps a mistake of copyists; though it is immediately added,] and minohu ↓ faS~ayotuhu, inf. n. tafoSiypN, i. e. I freed it, or cleared it, from it; (S, K;) or, accord, to Fr, this signifies I separated it from it, i. e., anything from another thing. (Har p. 640.)
2 faS~aYa see the preceding paragraph.

3 fASAhu * , inf. n. mufaA SaApN, as is related on the authority of Er. Rázee, but accord, to analogy, not on the ground of received usage, means He separated himself from him; left, forsook, or abandoned, him: or forsook, or abandoned, him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him, syn. faAraqahu. (Har p. 640.)

4 A^afoSaYa see 5. ― -b2- AfSY Enoka AlHar~u means The heat departed, or has departed, from thee: but you do not say AfSY Enk Albarodu: (ISk, S, M: but in the M, Enk is omitted in both phrases:) or you say, AfSY En~aA Al$~itaA='u, and AlHar~u, the winter, and the heat, departed from as; or left, or quitted, us; (K, TA;) so says Az, on the authority of IAar: (TA:) or, accord, to IAar, AfSY Eanoka Al$~itaA='u [the winter departed, or has departed, from thee]; and sqaTa Eanoka AlHr~u. (M, TA.) And AfSY AlmaTaru The rain cleared away. (S, M, K.) ― -b3- AfSY said of a sportsman, He had no game caught in his snare. (K.)

5 tfS~Y * , said of flesh, or flesh-meat, It became separated, or detached, Eani AlEaZomi [from the bone]; as also ↓ AnfSY; (M;) which is said of anything that was sticking. (Lth, TA.) He became freed, free, or released, [and in like manner said of a thing of any kind,] minohu [from him, or it]; S, M, Msb, K;) i. e., from another man, (S,) from his adversary, or antagonist; (Msb;) from a thing; (M;) from debts; (S, Msb; *) from straitness, or difficulty, (S, Msb, TA,) or from trial, or affliction; (S, TA;) or from good, or evil; as also ↓ AfSY (K.) And He, or it, went forth, or departed, mina Al$~aYo'i [from the thing]; as also ↓ AnfSY, and ↓ AstfSY. (Msb.) A^a$ad~u tafaS~iyFA means A^a$ad~utafal~utFA: (Msb, TA:) thus in the trad. respecting the Kur-án, lahuwa A_a$ad~u tafaS~iyFA mino quluwbi Alr~ijaAli mina Aln~aEami [Verily it is more apt to escape from the breasts of men than are pasturing camels, or cattle, from their pastor]. (TA. [In my original, the last word in this saying is without any vowel-sign; but it is not doubtful, as the trad. is well known.])
7 A_inofaSaYa see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
10 A_isotafoSaYa see 5, last sentence but one.

faSFY * , (M, K, * TA,) incorrectly written in the copies of the K with A (TA,) The stones (Hab~) of raisins: (M, K:) also mentioned in the K [and M] as with D: (TA:) n. un. (??): (M, K:) of the dial. of El-Hijáz: and they also call the stones of dates fSyp [app. (??), pl. of faSY, like as fitoyapN is pl. of fatFY]. (TA.)

faSoyapN * the subst, from tafaS~aY as syn. with taxl~aSa; (S, M, Msb, K;) [thus signifying Freedom. or release, from a thing or state;] primarily denoting one's being in a thing and then coming, or going, forth, or departing, from it; (S;) as also ↓ fSy~pN. (K.) Hence the saying, qaDaY A@ll~`hu liY biAlfaSoyapi mino h`*aA AlA^amori [God decreed for me, or may God decree for me, freedom, or release, from this affair, or case]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- faSoypu maA bayona AlHar~i waAlbarodi means An intermission (sakotapN, lit, a quiescence,) between heat and cold: and one says layolapN faSoyapN and yawomN faSoyapN [A night that is, or that was, one of intermission, and a day &c.], and layolapu faSoyapK and yawomu faSoyapK [meaning the same], (M, K.)
faSiy~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 faD~ahu * , (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) aor. yafuD~u, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. faD~N, (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K.) He broke it; namely, the seal (A, Mgh, Msb, K) of a letter; (A, K;) and any other thing; (TA:) he broke it asunder, or into several pieces; he dissundered it; (S, Mgh, O, K;) for instance, the seal from a letter. (S, O.) faS~a AlxaAtama is also a metonymical phrase, meaning (tropical:) (??): (TA.) [or rather, i. a.] faD~ AlbakaArapa (tropical:) he destroyed the virginity: the virginity being likened to a seal, or this phrase is from faDaDotu All~uw^oluw^apa I bored, or perforated, the pearl. (Msb.) [See also 8.] You say also, faD~a A@ll~`hu faAhu, (Msb, TA,) and, accord. to IKtt, ↓ A^afaD~ahu, which J disallows, (TA,) God broke, or may God break, his teeth: (TA;) or God scattered, or may God scatter, his teeth. (Msb.) The phrase laA yafoDuDi A@ll~`hu faAka, (S, A.) meaning May God not break thy teeth, (TA,) occurs in a trad.: (S, A:) and J says. (TA,) you should not say ↓ yufoDiD; (S, TA; [but in
one copy of the S, I find yafoDiD;]) though some allow it: and some say that A_ifoDaA' [evidently a mistake for A_ifoDaAD] means the falling out of the teeth from above and below; but the former explanation is the more common. (TA.) ― -b2- He separated it; dispersed it; scattered it; broke it up; (S, A, Msb, TA;) namely, a thing; (Msb;) or a party of men; (S, O;) or a ring of men, (A, TA,) after they had collected together. (TA.) You say also, faD~a AlmaAla EalaY Alqawomi (Mgh, * TA) He distributed the property among the people, or party of men. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b3- faDaDotu maA bayonahumaA I cut [the tie, or bond, that was between them]. (TA.) ― -b4- faD~a AlmaA='a, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, He poured out, or forth, the water; (TA;) and so Ald~umuwEa the tears. (Har p. 57.) [See also 8.] -A2- faD~a AlmaA='u, [aor., accord. to rule, yafiD~u,] The water flowed: (TA:) and Ald~umuwEu ↓ AnfD~t The tears poured forth. (Har p. 57.)
2 faD~a3a [fD~D He silvered a thing: he ornamented a bit or bridle with silver: from fiD~apN: see the pass. part. n., below.]
4 A^afoDa3a see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AfD~ AlEaTaA='a He made the gift large. (TA.)

5 tafaD~a3a see 7. -A2- tafaD~ayotu from AlfiD~apu, for tafaD~aDotu, has been mentioned by Sb; but ISd says, I know not what he meant thereby; whether I took for myself, or acquired, fiD~ap, [i. e. silver], or I made use of it. (TA.)

7 AnfD~ *
It broke; or became broken; (S, Mgh;) said of a seal, (Mgh,) or thing. (S.) ― -b2- AnfD~ mim~aA SuniEa biA@boni Eaf~aAna, occurring in a trad., means His connections became cut, or sundered, [so that he became clear] from what was done to ['Othmán] Ibn-'Affán, through grief and regret: (O, TA:) but accord. to one relation, the verb is [AnqD~,] with q. (TA.) ― -b3- AnfD~ also signifies It became separated, dispersed, scattered, or broken up; or it separated, dispersed, or scattered, itself, or it broke up; (S, Mgh, O, Msb;) said of a thing, (Msb,) and of a party of men; (S, Mgh, O, Msb;) as also ↓ tfD~D, said of a thing, (S,) and of a party of men. (TA.) One says, AnfD~ Almajolisu [The assembly of persons sitting together broke up]. (Msb in art. jls.) ― -b4- See also 1 last sentence.

8 AftD~hA *
He devirginated her: (O, K:) and so AqtD~hA, with q. (O, TA.) [See also 1, second sentence.] ― -b2- AftD~ AlmaA='a He poured out, or forth, the water by little and little, successively: (O, K:) or he obtained the water at the time of its coming forth (S, O, K,) from the spring or from the clouds. (TA.) [See also 1, near the end.] ― -b3- AftD~ti said of a woman, She broke [i. e. ended] her Eid~ap, (O, K, TA,) meaning a widow's Ed~p [during which she may not marry again, nor use perfumes &c., and] which is a period of four months and ten nights, but was before the Prophet's time a year: (TA:) this she did by touching perfume, or by some other act, (K, TA,) such as paring the nail, or plucking out the hair from the face: (TA:) or she rubbed her body with [or against] a beast, (K, TA,) i. e. an ass, or a sheep or goat, (O in art. Hf$,) thereby to quit the state of the Ed~p: or it was customary with them for her to wipe her qubul with a bird, and to throw it away; in consequence of which it hardly ever, or never, lived: (K, TA:) she used to enter a Hifo$ [or small tent], and wear the worst of her clothing until a year passed, when a beast or bird was brought to her, and by means thereof she broke her Ed~p; then she went forth, and a baEorap [or piece of camel's or similar dung] was given to her, and she threw it: (TA: [see 1 in art. bEr:]) she used not to wash herself, nor to touch water, nor to pare a nail, nor to pluck out hair from her face; then she would go forth, after the year, with the foulest aspect, and break her Ed~p by means of a bird, wiping her qubul with it, and throwing it away. (O, TA.) The verb, thus used, occurs in a trad., but, as some relate it, with q and b [i. e. saying taqobiDu instead of tafotaD~u]; and Az mentions that EshSháfi'ee related this trad. [in like manner] pronouncing the word with q and D, from AlqbD. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 faDofaDa *
He made a garment, and a coat of mail, wide, or ample. (TA.) -A2- [Also, probably, It (a garment, and a diroE and (assumed tropical:) the means of subsistence,) was, or became, wide, or ample: see faDofaDapN, below.]

R. Q. 2 tafaDofaDa bawolu Aln~aAqapi *
The urine of the she-camel became sprinkled upon her thighs. (TA.)

faD~N * , (K,) or faD~N mina Aln~aAsi, (O, TA,) A small number of men (nafarN) in a state of dispersion. (O, K, TA.) And tamorN faD~N Dates in a separate state, not sticking together. (IAar. [See also fav~N.]) And HariyrN faD~N Silk scattered, strewn, or thrown dispersedly. (A, TA.) [See also faDaDN, and fuDaADN.]
faD~apN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

fiD~apN * [Silver;] a certain thing well known: (S, O, K:) or wrought silver: (IAar, T and K voce tiborN, q. v.:) pl. fiDaDN. (TA.) The phrase qawaAriyra mino fiD~apK, in the Kur [lxxvi. 16], means Such [flasks] as, notwithstanding their clearness, or transparency, will be secure from being broken, and capable of being restored to a sound state if broken, (Az, O, K,) like silver: (Az, O,) being, as Zj says, originally of silver, yet transparent, so that what will be within them will be seen from without; whereas the qwAryr of this world are originally from sand. (Az, O.) [See also art. qr.] -A2- Also An elevated [stony tract such as is termed] Har~ap; and so ↓ faD~apN: pl. fiDaDN and fiDaADN. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And fiDaADu AljibaAli signifies Rocks scattered (manovuwr, in the CK mano$uwr), one upon another: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) sing. ↓ faD~apN. (TA.)

faDaDN *
What is separated, dispersed, or scattered; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ faDiyDN; (O, K, TA;) of rain-water, and of hail, and of sweat: (TA:) and sprinkled: (K:) and particularly what is sprinkled, of water, when one performs ablution with it, (A, O, K,) and what flows upon the limbs on that occasion; (A;) as also ↓ faDiyDN. (K.) The saying of 'Áïsheh to Marwán, faA^anota faDaDN mino laEonapi A@ll~`hi, (A, O, K,) or ↓ faDiyDN, (A,) or ↓ fuDuDN, or ↓ fuDaADN, accord. to different relations, (K,) means So thou art a part [of the object] of the curse of God: (Sh, A, O, K:) for the Apostle of God had cursed the father of Marwán, the latter being at the time [essentially] in his father's loins: (A:) or it means that he came forth in sprinkled seed from his father's loins: (Th, S, * TA:) or, accord. to another relation, she said fuZaAZapN [see faZiyZN]. (TA.) [See also faD~N and fuDaADN.]
fuDuDN * : see faDaDN [and faDiyDN].

fuDaADN *
What is separated, dispersed, or scattered, of a thing, when it is broken; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ fiDaADN; (O, K;) and ↓ fuDaADapN. (TA.) You say, TaArato EiZaAmuhu fuDaADFA His bones became scattered in fragments on the occasion of the blow. (TA.) See also faDaDN.
fiDaADN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

faDiyDN * : see mafoDuwDN: ― -b2- and see faDaDN, in three places. ― -b3- Also What is cast forth from the mouth, of date-stones. (TA.) ― -b4- And Sweet water: (S, O, K:) or flowing water: (A'Obeyd, S, O, K:) or fresh water when it comes forth from the spring or from the clouds: (O:) or water such as is termed gariyDN: pl. fuDuDN. (TA in art. fZ.) And a place abounding with water. (TA.) ― -b5- naAqapN kaviyrapu faDiyDi All~abani A she-camel having much milk: and rajulN kaviyru faDiyDi AlkalaAmi a man of much speech or talk. (TA.) -A2- And accord. to El-Khattábee and others, [and among them the author of the K,] A TaloE [or spadix of a palmtree] when it first comes forth: but this is a mistranscription; correctly gaDiyDN, with g (O, TA.)
fuDaADapN * : see fuDaADN.

faAD~apN *
A calamity; a misfortune: (Fr, S, O, K:) as though breaking and demolishing that which it befalls: (O, TA:) pl. fawaAD~u. (O, K.)

faDofaDapN *
Wideness, or ampleness, of a garment, and of a diroE [see faDofaADN], and (assumed tropical:) of the means of subsistence. (S, O, K.) [See R. Q. 1.]

faDofaADN *
Wide, or ample: (S, O, K:) in this sense applied to a garment; (S, O;) and to a diroE; (O, K;) the drE [or shift] of a woman, and the drE [i. e. coat of mail] used in war; (O;) as also faDofaADapN, (S, A, O, K,) and ↓ fuDaAfiDapN; (TA;) and (assumed tropical:) to the means of subsistence: (S:) also
much, or abundant, and ample: (TA:) and [in this sense] applied to water. (TA.) faDofaADu Alr~idaA='i waAlbadani, in a trad. of Sateeh, means (tropical:) Liberal, or generous, in disposition: or a large giver: (TA:) and rajulN faDofaADN means (tropical:) a man who gives much; likened to water to which the same epithet is applied. (TA.) You say also, jaAriyapN faDofaADapN A fleshy, corpulent, tall, girl. (O, K.) And saHaAbapN faDofaADapN A cloud abounding with rain. (TA.) And A^aroDN faDofaADN Land overspread with water from abundance of rain. (O, TA.)
fulaAnN faDofaADapu waladi A^abiyhi * , accord. to Lth, means Such a one is the last of the children of his father; but Az says that the word known in this sense is naDonaADap, with n. (TA.)
fuDaAfiDapN * : see faDofaADN.

mifaD~apN *
A thing with which clods of earth are broken; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ mifoDaADN. (O, K.)
mufaD~aDN * A thing silvered: (TA:) a bridle (lijaAm) ornamented with silver. (S, TA.)
mifoDaADN * : see mifaD~apN.

mafoDuwDN *
Broken; as also ↓ faDiyDN. (TA.)

1 faDaHahu * , (S, A, &c.,) aor.
faDaHa , inf. n. faDoHN, (Msb,) He exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions; disgraced him; or put him to shame. (S, A, L, Msb, * K.) laA tafoDaHonaA bayona xaloqiki, occurring in a prayer, means Expose not Thou our vices, or faults, among thy creatures: or the meaning may be, protect Thou us, that we may not be disobedient, and so deserve to have our vices, or faults, exposed among thy creatures. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] faDaHa Alqamaru Aln~ujuwma (tropical:) [The moon put to shame the stars; i. e.] the light of the moon predominated over that of the stars, (A, TA,) so that they were not apparent, or distinct: (TA:) and in like manner, AlS~uboHu the dawn. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And faDaHaka AlS~uboHu, said to a person sleeping at daybreak, (TA,) (tropical:) Daybreak has shone forth, so as to discover thee to him who may see thee, and to expose thee to shame: (L, TA:) or i. q. faSaHaka [i. e. daybreak has become apparent to thee, and its light has overcome thee: or daybreak has come upon thee suddenly]. (K.) ― -b4- And faDaHa AlS~uboHu, (so in the S, and in some copies of the K,) or ↓ fD~H, (so in other copies of the K,) and ↓ AfDH, (S, K,) (assumed tropical:) The daybreak appeared, (S, K, TA,) and shone forth. (TA.) -A2- faDiHa, aor.
faDaHa , (K,) inf. n. faDaHN, (TK.) It was, or became, of the colour termed fuDoHapN [q. v.]. (K.)
2 faD~aHa see the last sentence but one above.
3 fADHhu * [He exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, the other doing the like to him: see also 6]. (A.)

4 A^afoDaHa see 1, last sentence but one. ― -b2- AfDH Albusoru (assumed tropical:) The full-grown unripe dates showed in them a redness. (S.) And AfDH Aln~axolu (assumed tropical:) The palm-trees became red and yellow [in their fruit]. (K.)

6 tfADH AlmurotajizaAni * [The two composers, or reciters, of verses of the metre termed rajaz exposed each other's vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions]. (A.) And A^araAduwA A^ano yatanaASaHuwA fatafaADaHuwA [They desired, or meant, to give sincere, or faithful, advice or counsel, one to another, and they exposed one another's vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions]. (A.)

8 AftDH *
His vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, became exposed; he became disgraced, or put to shame: (S, L, K:) he did evil, and became disgraced thereby. (L.) ― -b2- And [hence] AifotaDaHonaA fiyka We have been negligent, or have failed of our duty, in respect of visiting thee, and seeking for thee. (A, TA.)

AlS~uboHu AlfaDaHu *
The dawn that is overspread with redness: (K, TA:) because of its shining forth. (TA.) -A2- See also what next follows.

fuDoHapN * , a subst from faDiHa, (L, K, TA,) and ↓ faDaHN, (S, L, TA,) the inf. n. of faDiH, (TK,) Whiteness, but not in an intense degree: (K, TA: [and the same is implied in the S:]) or, as some say, dust-colour inclining to TuHolap [which is a hue between that of dust and whiteness, with a little blackness, or between that of dust and blackness, with a little whiteness], (S, L, TA,) intermixed with an ugly hue; one of the colours of camels and of pigeons: the epithet is ↓ A^afoDaHu; fem. faDoHaA='u: said by an Arab of the desert, in answer to a question of AA respecting it, to be the colour of cooked flesh-meat. (L, TA.) fuDoHapu AlS~uboHi means The whiteness of the dawn. (TA.)
fiDaAHN * : see faDiyHapN.

faDuwHN * One who exposes [much, or habitually, or often,] the vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, of others; who [so] disgraces them, or puts them to shame; as also ↓ faD~aAHN. (TA.) One says, Alxamoru faDuwHN li$aAribihaA [Wine is a thing that exposes much the vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, of the drinker thereof]. (A.) ― -b2- yaA faDuwHu means O thou who act rendered notorious by thy evil character or conduct. (K, * TA.)
fuDuwHN * : see faDiyHapN, in two places.

huwa faDiyHN fiY AlmaAli *
He is a bad manager of property, or cattle; (K, TA;) not taking good care thereof. (TA.)
faDaAHapN * : see the paragraph here following.
fuDuwHapN * : see the paragraph here following.

faDiyHapN * a subst. from faDaHahu, as also ↓ fuDuwHN, (S, A, L, K,) and ↓ fuDuwHapN, and ↓ faDaAHapN, (L, K,) and ↓ fiDaAHN; (K;) Disgrace, shame, or ignominy; (PS, TA;) a state of exposure of the vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, of a man: (Har p. 3:) any evil thing that exposes its author to disgrace or shame; any disgraceful, or shameful, thing: (L:) a vice, or fault, or the like; syn. EayobN: pl. faDaAy^iHu: (Msb:) [and] a disgracing; putting to shame; or rendering ignominious. (MA and KL; in both of which it is mentioned as an inf. n.) It is said in a trad., Ald~unoyaA A^ahowanu mino fuDuwHi ↓ fuDuwHu AlA=xirapi [The disgrace of the present world is easier to bear than the disgrace of the world to come]. (A, TA.)
faD~aAHN * : see faDuwHN.

faADH * [act. part. n. of 1]. It is said in a prov., AlZ~amaA^u AlfaAdiHu A^ahowanu mina Alr~iY~i AlfaADiHi [Oppressing thirst is easier to bear than the state of satisfaction with drinking that disgraces, or puts to shame] and you say, A_i*aA kaAna AlEu*oru waADiHFA kaAna AlEitaAbu faADiHFA [When the excuse is manifest, reproof is disgracing]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And AlfaADiHu signifies (assumed tropical:) The daybreak, or dawn: because it exposes and manifests everything. (Har. p. 556.)

A^afoDaHu *
White, but not intensely so: (S, L, K:) see also explanations of fuDoHapN, indicating other meanings: fem. faDoHaA='u. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, because of their colours, (S,) AlA^afoDaHu signifies The lion: and The camel. (S, K.)

1 faDaxa * , aor.
faDaxa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. faDoxN, (Mgh, Msb,) He broke a hollow thing [or the like], (Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) such as a head, and a melon; (A, TA,) syn. kasara: (Msb. K, TA;) as also ↓ AftDx: (K, TA:) he broke, or crushed, syn. $adaxa, (S, K, TA,) a person's head, (S, TA,) and a fresh ripe date, and the like; (TA,) as also ↓ AftDx: (K, TA:) or he struck a person's head [and wounded it] so that the brains came forth: (Msb:) and [particularly] he crushed ($adaxa) fullgrown unripe dates [to make the beverage called faDiyx]; and so ↓ AftDx: (S:) or Albusora ↓ AftDx he made, or made for himself, the beverage called nabiy* [or faDiyx] of the full-grown unripe dates. (A.) ― -b2- And He ruptured, or broke, or rent open, an eye, (AZ, K, TA,) and a belly, and any receptacle containing oil or beverage. (AZ, TA.) ― -b3- And faDoxu AlmaA='i signifies The pouring forth of water, (K, TA,) and of the seminal fluid; occurring in the latter sense in a trad. (TA.) ― -b4- And yafoDaxu $aAribahu, said of a beverage, (K, TA,) such as is termed faDiyH, (TA,) means (assumed tropical:) It subdues (yakosiru) and intoxicates its drinker. (K, TA.)

4 AfDx * , said of a raceme, or bunch, (Eunoquwd,) [of dates or the like,] It attained to the time, (L, K,) and became in a fit state, for the crushing of the fruit and (L) for the expressing of the juice. (L, K.)

7 AnfDx * [It (a hollow thing or the like, such as a head, and a melon,) became broken, or
crushed: (see 1:) or] it (a person's head) was struck [and wounded] so that the brains came forth: (Msb:) and it (a camel's hump) became broken, or crushed. (S, K.) ― -b2- AnfDxt It (an eye) became ruptured, broken, or rent open. (L.) And AnfDx It (a full skin) slit, or burst, and let flow its contents. (L.) And the former, It (a qaAruwrap [i. e. flask, or bottle,]) broke, and became empty. (L.) And It (a dalow [or leathern bucket]) poured forth the water that was in it: (L, K:) and so AnfDjt. (L.) And It (a qaroHap [i. e. purulent pustule, or the like,]) opened, (A, L, K,) and discharged its fluid, (L,) or and became wide. (K.) ― -b3- And AnfDx said of a man, He wept much, (K, TA,) and shed copious tears. (TA.) ― -b4- And It (anything) became wide. (L.)
8 A_ifotaDaxa see 1, in four places.
faDuwxN * Beverage that subdues (yakosiru) and intoxicates its drinker. (L, K.) See the next paragraph.

faDiyHN *
A beverage (S, A, Mgh, K) of the kind called nabiy* (A) prepared from full-grown unripe dates, (S, A, Mgh, K,) crushed, (K,) without its being touched [i. e. boiled or heated in any degree] by fire: (S:) or prepared by putting dried dates into a vessel, and then pouring upon them hot water, which extracts their sweetness, after which the preparation is boiled, and becomes strong: it is like baA*aq in respect of the legal predicament to which it belongs: but if cooked in the least degree, it is like muval~av. (KT.) A rájiz says,
baAla suhayolN fiY AlfaDiyxi fafasado
expl. in art. bwl. (L.) Ibn-'Omar, being asked respecting faDiyx, said, “ It is not faDiyx, but ↓ faDuwx; ” meaning that it subdues and intoxicates its drinker. (Mgh, * L.) ― -b2- Also Expressed juice of grapes. (L, K.) ― -b3- And Milk mixed with a greater quantity of water, (K, TA,) so that it has become thin, and is white, like DayoHN and xaDaArN &c. (TA.)

mifoDaxapN *
A stone with which full-grown unripe dates are crushed. (K.) ― -b2- And mafaADixu [of which it is app. the sing.] signifies Vessels for the beverage called faDiyxu, (L, K,) in which it is left to become [fermented and] strong. (L.) ― -b3- And the former signifies also A wide dalow [or leathern bucket]. (K.)

1 faDala * , aor.
faDula ; and faDila, aor.
faDila ; and faDila, aor.
faDula ; three syn. dial. vars.; (S, O, Msb, K;) the second mentioned by ISk; and the third [said to be] anomalous and unparalleled; (S, O;) [but] it is a compound of two thereof, (S, O, Msb, K,) accord. to the companions of Sb, (S, O,) i. e. a compound of the second and the third, (K,) like naEima having for its aor. yanoEumu, (Sb, S, O, Msb,) and nakila, aor. yanokulu, [but this I do not find in its proper art.,] and HaDira, aor. yaHoDuru, [but this is disallowed by some,] and fariga, aor. yaforugu, among perfect verbs, (Msb,) and mit~a, aor. tamuwtu, and dimota, aor. taduwmu, (Sb, S, O, Msb,) and kidota, aor. takuwdu; (Sb, S;) inf. n. faDolN: (S, * O, * Msb, K: *) all signify It exceeded; or was, or became, redundant, or superfluous; [syn. zaAda;] being used in relation to AlfaDolu (K, MF, TA) meaning Alz~iyaAdapu, as Ibn-Es-Seed says, (MF, TA,) [i. e.] as meaning the contr. of Aln~aqoSu: (K, TA:) or the first of the three, i. e. fDala, aor.
faDula , inf. n. faDolN, signifies thus, i. q. zaAda, (Msb,) and fuDolN and fuDulN are also inf. ns. [of the same, i. e.] signifying ziyaAdapN, as in the saying, in a trad., accord. to different relaters, A_in~a lil~`hi malaAy^ikapF say~aArapF fuDolFA EalaY AlmalaAy^ikapi Almurat~abiyna maEa AlxalaAy^iqi and fuDulFA [i. e. Verily to God belong angels who occupy themselves in ranging about, in addition to the angels who are stationed among the created, or human and other, beings]: (TA:) and all the three dial. vars. mentioned above signify it remained [of a greater quantity or number]; syn. baqiYa; (S, * O, * Msb;) you say, faDala minohu $aYo'N, aor.
faDula ; and faDila, aor.
faDala ; and faDila, aor.
faDula ; somewhat remained thereof: (S, O:) or from AlfaDolu as meaning Albaqiy~apu, you say faDala like naSara, [i. e. aor.
faDula ,] and faDila like Hasiba, [implying that the aor. is
faDala and
faDila ,] (K,) [accord. to the TK meaning it had somewhat remaining, but accord. to SM,] using these verbs [which are said by him to be like naSara and samiEa and Hasiba, the last as mentioned by Lh,] in the phrase faDala minohu $aYo'N [expl. above]. (TA.) ― -b2- [faDala is trans. as well as intrans.] One says, faDalahu and faDala Ealayohi, [aor.
faDula ,] inf. ns. faDolN and fuDuwlN, [but see a distinction made between these two words voce faDolN, below,] meaning He, or it, exceeded, or excelled, him, or it. (MA.) See also 4. [And see faDolN below, last signification.] AlfaDolu as meaning The overcoming, or surpassing, in highness, elevation, or eminence, of rank, condition, or estimation, has but one form of verb, faDala, aor.
faDula , like qaEada, aor. yaqoEudu: he who relates the saying of the poet,
wajadonaA naho$alFA faDalato fuqayomaA
[We found, or have found, that Nahshal (the tribe so called) overcame &c., or have overcome &c., Fukeym (another tribe)], pronouncing the D [in fDlt] with kesr, errs; not distinguishing between the two meanings: so says Ibn-Es-Seed, in the book entitled “ Kitáb el-Fark: ” and Es- Seymuree says, in his book entitled “ Kitáb etTebsireh, ” faDala, aor.
faDula , like naSara, aor. yanoSuru, is from AlfaDolu meaning the ruling [others] as a chief, lord, or master. (TA.) And faDalahu signifies also [simply] He overcame him; surpassed him; or gained ascendency, or the mastery, over him. (TA.) See also 3.

2 fD~lhu * (K, TA) EalaY gayorihi, (TA,) inf. n. tafoDiylN, i. q. maz~aAhu, (K, TA,) i. e. He attributed to him an excellence distinguishing him from [or above] another, or others: (TA:) or faD~alotuhu EalaY gayorihi, inf. n. as above, I judged him (S, O, Msb, * TA) to be more excellent than another, or others: (S, * O, * Msb, TA: *) or I made him (S, O, Msb, * TA) to be so. (S, * O, * Msb, TA.) wafaD~alonaAhumo EalaY kaviyrK mim~ano xalaqonaA, in the Kur [xvii. 72, i. e. And we have made them to excel many of those that we have created], has been expl. as meaning that the excellence of the son of Adam consists in his walking erect, whereas the beasts, the camels and the asses and the like, walk pronely; and the son of Adam takes food with his hands, whereas the other animals take it with the mouth. (TA.) And waA@ll~`hu faD~ala baEoDakumo EalaY baEoDK, in the Kur [xvi. 73, i. e. And God hath made some of you to excel some others], means, in ability, and wealth, and rank or station, and power; which are excellences that may be acquired. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And you say, fD~lhu bihi, meaning xaS~ahu [i. e. He distinguished him particularly, peculiarly, or specially, by it, namely, a thing]. (A and K in art. xS.) And fD~l fiY AlEaTaA='i He gave to some more than to others. (S in art. Afq.) ― -b2- [An explanation of fD~l given by Golius, as on the authority of the K, (“ i. q. wsx, Sordibus infecit, vel pro sordida habuit, quotidianam vestem, ”) is a strange mistake; app. caused by his finding in a copy of the K Alt~afoDiylu Alt~awosiyxu instead of Alt~afaD~ulu Alt~awa$~uHu: see 5. ― -b3- Aisomu Alt~afoDiyli The noun of the attribution of excess or excellence is a term applied to the comparative and superlative noun or epithet; also called A^afoEalu Alt~afoDiyli, because it is regularly of the measure A^afoEalu: see exs. voce xayorN.]

3 AlfiDaAlu * [and AlmufaADalapu inf. ns. of faADala] and ↓ Alt~afaADulu [inf. n. of 6 (of which see an ex. in art. swY, conj. 6,)] signify Alt~amaAziY fiY AlfaDoli [i. e. The contending for superiority in excellence]; (K, * TA;) Alt~amaAziY being of the measure tafaAEul from Almaziy~apu. (TA.) And you say, ↓ faADalotuhu fafaDalotuhu, (S, O, K, * in the last faADalaniY,) aor. of the latter
faDula , (TA,) inf. n. faDolN, (O, TA,) I contended with him for superiority, or vied with him, in excel-lence, (O, TA,) and I surpassed him, or outvied him, therein. (S, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And fADl bayona Al$~ayoy^ayoni [app. He made the relation between the two things to be unequal in respect of excellence; i. e. he made the two things to be unequal, or unlike each other, in excellence; contr. of saAwaY bayonahumaA: see also 6]. (TA.)

4 AfDl fiY tijaAratihi *
He gained; or made gain, or profit; in his traffic; syn. rabiHa. (Az and Msb in art. rbH.) ― -b2- Eanohu [and Eanohu ↓ faDala, aor.
faDula , inf. n. faDolN, (see faDolN below, last signification, and see also faADilN,)] It exceeded it. (K, TA. [See also 1, latter half.]) Ows says, describing a bow,
kaqawosK TilaAEi Alkaf~i laA duwna miloy^ihaA
walaA EajosuhaA Eano mawoDiEi Alkaf~i A^afoDalaA
[Like a bow of which the part that is grasped is sufficient in size for the filling of the hand, not less than suffices to fill it, nor does the part that is grasped thereof extend beyond the place of the hand: the pret. being here used for the aor. to suit the metre]. (TA. [But my original has kaqawomK, an evident mistranscription.]) ― -b3- AfDl Ealayohi: see 5, in two places. -A2- A^afoDalotu minohu Al$~aYo'a and ↓ AisotafoDalotu signify the same, (S, O, K, TA,) i. e. I left of it the thing remaining, or redundant. (O, TA.)

5 tfD~l Ealayohi * [in the CK (erroneously) faD~ala] i. q. tamaz~aY, (K, TA,) both of which signify He thought himself to be superior to him in excellence; (TA in art. mzw;) whence the saying in the Kur [xxiii. 24], yuriydu A^ano yatafaD~ala Ealayokumo, meaning He desireth that he may have superiority over you in rank and station: (TA in the present art.) or i. q. Elyh ↓ AfDl, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. A_ifoDaAlN, (Msb, TA,) i. e. he bestowed, or conferred, a benefit, or benefits, upon him, syn. A^aHosana, (S, TA,) or taTaw~ala, (K, TA,) and gave him of his bounty: (TA:) [and each, followed by bi$aYo'K, he presented him, or favoured him, with a thing:] or tfD~l signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S,) he laid claim to superiority of excellence over his equals, or fellows; (S, K;) whence [accord. to some] the saying in the Kur quoted above: (S:) and [you say] Ealayohi fiY AlHasabi ↓ AfDl, (K, TA,) meaning he became possessed of eminence. [or superiority, over him, in the grounds of pretension to respect or honour,] as in a verse of Dhu-l-Isba' cited voce Eano, [q. v., p. 2164,] ending with fataxozuwoniY for fataxozuwaniY, [which latter reading I have there given,] because the rhyme of the whole ode requires the former. (TA.) -A2- Alt~afaD~ulu also signifies Alt~awa$~uHu [generally meaning The throwing a portion of one's garment over his left shoulder, and drawing its extremity under his right arm, and tying the two extremities together in a knot upon his bosom]: and the putting, or disposing, the extremities of his two garments, or pieces of cloth, contrariwise, or in contrary directions, upon his EaAtiq [or part between the shoulder and the neck]. (K, TA: but in the former, EalaY EaAtiqayohi is erroneously put for ElY EaAtiqihi. TA.) ― -b2- And tafaD~alato said of a woman in her tent or chamber or house, She was in a single garment; (S, O, TA;) [she wore a single garment;] such as is termed mifoDalN [q. v.]: (S, TA:) or she (a woman) wore the garments of her service. (TA.)

6 tafaAoDala see 3. ― -b2- Alt~afaADulu bayona Alqawomi means The differing in superiority, or excellence, of some over others, among the people, or party. (TA.) And one says, AlA^a$oyaA='u tatafaADalu [meaning The things are unequal, or unlike, one to another, in respect of excellence; contr. of tatasaAwaY: see also 3]. (TA.)

10 AstfDl A^alofFA *
He took a thousand [dirhems] in excess of his right, or due. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4.

faDolN * [an inf. n.: (see 1, throughout:) and also a simple subst., signifying] An exceeding, a redundant, or a superfluous, quantum [of anything, good or evil]; an excess, a redundance, or a superfluity; syn. ziyaAdapN; (Mgh, Msb;) contr. of naqoSN: (S, O, K:) [and often meaning superabundance, or exuberance; and surpassingness, superiority, or excellence. EalaY gayorihi over another, or others, than him, or it: and preponderance:] the pl. is fuDuwlN (Mgh, Msb, K:) and this is sometimes used as a sing.; (Er-Rághib, Msb;) and [thus used] relates to a thing [or quality] in which is no good; (Er-Rághib, Mgh, Msb;) by a predominant application; whence the saying fuDuwlN bilaA faDolK [excess without excellence]; (Mgh;) and hence the rel. n. ↓ fuDuwliY~N is formed from it: (Er-Rághib, Msb, TA;) [see this last word, one of the explanations of which shows that a particular meaning of fuDuwlN is the quality of busying oneself with that which does not concern him:] accord. to Er-Rághib, faDolN signifies an excess [in respect of a property or quality, or of an acquisition,] above moderateness; and this is of two sorts; such as is commended, as the fDl of knowledge, or science ; and such as is discommended, as the fSl of anger at that whereat it is not necessary: but faDalN is more used in relation to that which is commended; and [the pl.] fuDuwlN, in relation to that which is discommended. when the former is used of an excess [in respect of some attribute, of our of two things above the other, it is of three sorts; fDl of kind, as of the animal kind above the vegetable kind; and of species, as of man above other animals; and of the individual, as of one man above another; the first and second of which three are essential attributes, such that he who is deficient in [either of] them cannot do away with his deficiency and acquire fDl, as, for instance, the horse, and the ass, which cannot acquire the excellence (faDiylap) of the human being; but the third may be accidental, such that the way may be found to acquire it, and of this sort are ability, wealth, rank or station, and power: and it signifies also any gift whereof the giving to the recipient thereof is not obligatory: [i. e. a free gift, or gratuity; and an act of bounty or grace; a favour; a benefit; and bounty as an abstract term;] as in the saying [in the Kur iv. 36], waA@soA^aluwA A@ll~`ha mino faDolihi [And ask ye God of his free gift, or of his bounty, or (as expl. in the Ksh and by Bd) of his exhaustless treasures]; and in the saying in the Kur [v. 59 and lvii. 21 and lxii. 4], *`lika faDolu A@ll~`hi yuw^otiyhi mano ya$aA='u [That is the free gift of God; He giveth it to whom He willeth]; which comprises the three sorts of excellences (faDaAy^il) [mentioned above]: thus says Er-Rághib: El-Muná- wee says, [explaining one of its meanings,] in the “ Towkeef, ” that it is the commencing, or originating, of an act of beneficence without an efficient cause [i. e., app., not by reason of any obligation]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A portion remaining, (K, TA,) of a thing, such as food &c., and of water in the leathern water-bag, and of wine or beverage in the vessel; (TA;) and ↓ faDolapN and ↓ fuDaAlapN signify the same, (K, TA,) or a redundant portion (S and O and Msb in explanation of these two words) of a thing: (S, O:) whence the saying of the vulgar, ↓ lilofaDiyli ↓ AlfaDolapu i. e. The remaining portion of the wine or beverage [is for the excel-lent]. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yumonaEu faDolu AlmaA='i liyumonaEa bihi AlkalaA^u [The redundance of water shall not be denied that the herbage be thereby denied]: (TA, in the present art.:) meaning that when there is a well in the desert, with herbage near it, and a person prevents others from drawing water, he thereby prevents the latter from availing themselves of the herbage; for when a man comes with his camels, and pastures them upon that herbage, and does not then water them, thirst kills them. (TA in art klA^,) And it is said in another trad., faDolu AlA_izaAri fiY Aln~aAri [The redundant portion of the waist-wrapper is in the fire of Hell]; meaning what one drags [thereof] upon the around, by reason of pride. (TA;) And one says, fiY yadihi faDolu Alz~imaAmi, meaning [In his hand is] the end of the zmAm [or nose-rein of the camel]. (TA.) *aAtu AlfuDuwli and ↓ AlfDuwli, with damm and with fet-h, [The thing having redundant portions] is the name of the coat of mail of the Prophet, which was thus called because having redundance and ampleness. (TA.) fuDuwlu AlganaAy^imi means The remains of the spoils when they are divided (TA;) such as a single horse, or a single camel (KL.) And by the fuDuwl of women are meant The remains of the menstrual discharge (Ham p. 107: see, there, explanations of a verse in which this occurs.) (??) [The confederacy, or covenant, of the fDwl, a word which is here of uncertain meaning,] is thus explained: Háshim and Zuhrah and Teym [accord. to the CK Teymà] went in to 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Jud'án, and united in a confederacy to repel wrongdoing, and to exact the due from the wrongdoer; and it was thus called because they bound themselves by their confederacy not to leave in the possession of any one aught remaining [of property] whereof he aught despond any one, without their taking it for him [i. e. the latter] from him [i. e. the former] (O, K, TA: [in the CK, yaZolimuhu A^aHadN is a mistake for yZlmh A^aHadFA:]) or it was thus called as being likened to a confederacy, or covenant, which was made of old, at Mekkeh, in the days of Jurhum, to act with mutual equity, and to take for the weak from the strong, and for the stranger from the resident, and in which three men, every one of whom was named El-Fadl, joined: and it was also called that of the maTay~abuwn. (TA. [See art. Tyb.]) ― -b3- The saying laA yamoliku dirohamFA faDolFA Eano diynaArK, and the like may be said of other sayings similar to it, means He does not possess a dirhem nor a deenár [or rather much less a deenár]: it is as though one said, he does not possess a dirhem: how then should he possess a deenár? for the negation of that which is much is a necessary consequence of the negation of that which is little: faDolFA is here in the accus case as an inf. n.; the implied meaning being faqada miloka dirohamK faqodFA
yafoDulu Eano faqodi miloki dynaArK [or rather yafoqidu &c., i. e. he lacks the possession of a dirhem with a lacking exceeding the lacking of the possession of a deenár]: (Msb:) Kutb-ed-Deen Esh-Sheerázee says, (Msb, TA,) in the Expos. of the “ Miftáh, ” (TA,) faDolFA is used in a case in which the inferior [of two things] is deemed a thing of which the existence is improbable, and the impossibility of the existence of a thing that is above it is meant thereby; wherefore it occurs between two phrases differing in meaning; and it is mostly used after a particle of negation: (Msb, TA:) AHei says that he had not found any authority for it in the [classical] language of the Arabs. (Msb. [See also baloha, which is used in a somewhat similar manner.])

fuDulN *
Wearing a single garment, such as is termed mifoDalN; an epithet applied to a woman; (S, Mgh, * O, K;) and also to a man; (S, O, K;) like ↓ mutafaD~ilN: (O, K:) it is of the dial. of Nejd; like furujN in the dial. of El-Yemen. (L in art. frj.) ― -b2- And A woman proud, or self-conceited, or so in her gait; who makes a portion of her skirt to be redundant [so that it drags upon the ground when she walks]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also mifoDalN, in three places.

faDolapN * : see faDolN, former half, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence, as used by grammarians,] A dispensable member of a proposition; such as the objective complement of a verb, when the suppression thereof is not detrimental [to the meaning]; contr. of EumodapN. (I'Ak, p. 143) [The pl. is faDalaAtN.] ― -b3- And The clothes that are used for sleeping [therein]: (K, TA:) [so called] because they are an addition over and above the clothes that are used on various [other] occasions. (TA.) ― -b4- And Wine; and so ↓ fiDaAlN [which see also in what here follows]: (O, K:) AlfaDolapu is mentioned by A'Obeyd as a name for wine: (O:) or it signifies, accord. to AHn, the wine that alters [or has become altered] in colour after oldness; and ISd says that it is so called because the choice, or best, or most excellent, part thereof [for lA^n~ HmymhA in my original (an obvious mistranscription) I read liA^an~a SamiymahaA ] is what remains: (TA:) the pl. is faDalaAtN and fiDaAlN [the latter word mentioned above as a syn. of faDolapN]. (K.)

fiDolapN * is a n. of the same kind as jilosapN and rikobapN: (AZ, S, O, TA:) one says, A_in~ahu laHasanu AlfiDolapi, meaning [Verily he is comely in respect of] the manner of wearing a single garment. (S, * O, * K, * TA.)
fiDaAlN * : see faDolapN: ― -b2- and see also mifoDalN.
faDuwlN * : see faDolN, latter half.
faDiylN * ; pl. fuDalaA='u: see faADilN; and see an ex. voce faDolN, former half.
fuDaAlapN * : see faDolN, former half.

faDiylapN *
An excellence, or excellent quality; contr. of naqiySapN; (S, O, Msb;) and contr. of ra*iylapN: (M and K in art. r*l:) or a high degree in [or of] excellence: (K:) [differing from faADilapN, q. v.:] pl. faDaAy^ilu. (MA.)
fuDaAlaY * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] i. q. ↓ mutafaD~iluwna, (O, K, TA,) i. e. [Men] who bestow, or confer, benefits. (TA.)

fuDuwliY~N * a rel. n. formed from fuDuwlN as pl. of faDolN but used as a sing.: (Er-Rághib, Msb, TA:) see faDolN, near the beginning: One who busies himself with that which does not concern him. (Er-Rághib, Mgh, O, Msb, TA.) In the conventional language of the lawyers, One who is not a commissioned agent, (Mgh, O, KT, TA,) nor a guardian (waliY~), (KT, TA,) nor a proprietor, (TA,) nor a person of firm judgment (A^aSiylN), in a contract. (KT.) The pronunciation with fet-h to the f is a mistake. (Mgh, O.) ― -b2- Also A tailor. (IAar, O, K.)
faD~aAlN * : see mifoDaAlN.

faADilN * [act. part. n. of faDala: as such signifying Exceeding; &c.]. One says, maAlu fulaAnK faADilN i. e. [The wealth, or property, of such a one is superfluous; or] abundant, or much in quantity, such as has exceeded the supply of food sufficient to sustain life (faDala Eani Alquwti). (TA.) ― -b2- And [Excelling; or excellent, as also ↓ faDiylN, of which the pl. is fuDalaA='u, but which is probably postclassical: or it is] applied to a man as [a possessive epithet] meaning possessing faDol [i. e. excel-lence]. (TA.) [And conventionally, Erudite; or excellent in learning.] ― -b3- See also mafoDuwlN.

faADilapN * is a subst. from faDiylapN [app. as a concrete term, signifying An excellent thing, or an excel-lent action; each as distinguished from an excel-lent quality]; (K, TA;) pl. fawaADilu: (TA:) [but generally] it signifies a gift, or thing that is given: (Ham p. 431, and Har p. 184:) or a benefit, or benefaction: or such as is continual, or uninterrupted: (MA:) pl. as above: (Ham and Har, ubi suprà; and MA:) [or] fawaADilu signifies benefits, or benefactions, that are goodly, or pleasing, (IDrd, O, K,) or such as are great, or large. (K.) And fawaADilu AlmaAli signifies What accrues to one of the proceeds and profits of property, (O, K, TA,) of the increase of lands and palm-trees and the like, and the gains of commercial transactions, and the milk and wool of cattle and sheep. (TA.) The Arabs say, A_i*aA Eazaba AlmaAlu qal~ato fawaADiluhu (O, K,) meaning When the estate is distant, the profits of its owner, accruing therefrom, are small in quantity. (O.)
A^afoDalu * [More, and most excellent, &c.]; fem. fuDolaY: (TA:) pl. masc. A^afaADilu; and pl. fem. fuDalN and fuDolayaAtN. (Msb in art. Axr.)

mifoDalN * : see mifoDaAlN. -A2- Also A single garment that is worn [without any other] by a woman (S, O, K, KL) in her tent or house or chamber, such as is called xayoEalN [a garment variously described], or the like of this, (S,) and by a man; (KL;) also called ↓ mifoDalapN, (K,) and ↓ fuDulN; (Fr, O, K;) or ↓ vawobN fuDulN signifies a single garment, a miloHafap [q. v.], or the like thereof, with which a woman wraps herself (tatawa$~aHu bihi); (Mgh;) and accord. to Lth, ↓ fiDaAlN signifies a single garment that is worn by a man in his tent or house or chamber: (TA:) and mifoDalN signifies [also] an every-daygarment: (MA:) ↓ fiY viyaAbK fuDulK occurring in a trad. of 'Áïsheh requires consideration [as being questionable]. (Mgh.)
mifoDalapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mufaD~alN * : see what next follows.

rajulN mifoDaAlN * and ↓ mifoDalN and ↓ mufaD~alN and ↓ faD~aAlN A man possessing much excellence, or superiority, (K, TA,) and beneficence, and goodness, and liberality, or bounty. (TA.) And (K) rajulN mifoDaAlN (S, O, K) EalaY qawomihi, (K,) and AimoraA^apN mifoDaAlapN EalaY qawomihaA, A man, and a woman, possessing excellence, or superiority, [or much thereof, agreeably with the former explanation, over his, and her, people,] and liberal or bountiful [or very liberal or bountiful]. (S, O, K.)

mafoDuwlN * [pass. part. n. of faDala: as such signifying Exceeded; &c.: and excelled: and overcome, or surpassed, in highness, elevation, or eminence, of rank, &c.: and simply] overcome, or surpassed: whence the saying, qado yuwjadu fiY AlmafoDuwli maA laA ↓ yuwjadufiY AlfaADili [Sometimes, or often, what is not found in the overcomer is found in the overcome]. (TA.)
mutafaD~ilN * One who lays claim to superiority of excellence over his equals, or fellows. (S.) [See also its verb: and] see fuDaAlaY. -A2- See also fuDulN.

div2.head: fDw and fDY
div2.entryFree: 1 faDaA * , (M, Msb, K,) aor. yafoDuw, (M, Msb,) inf. n. fuDuw~N (M, Msb, K) and faDaA='N, (M, K,) It (a place) was, or became, wide, or spacious; (M, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AfDY; (TA as from the K, in which I do not find it;) the latter occurring in a trad., and expl. in the Nh as signifying it became a faDaA=' [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [And It was, or became, empty, vacant, or void; (for it is said in the TA that AlfDw, by which AlfuDuw~u is evidently meant, signifies Alxuluw~u;) as also ↓ AfDY, as appears from an explanation of the part. n. mufoDK, q. v.] ― -b3- faDaA Al$~ajaru biAlmakaAni, inf. n. fDw [i. e. fuDuw~N], The trees became numerous, or abundant, [so as to occupy much space,] in the place. (IKtt, TA.) ― -b4- And faDaA daraAhimahu He did not put his dirhems, or money, into the purse [app. meaning that he left his money strewn]. (K.)

4 AfSY * : see the preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also He went forth, (S,) or came, (TA,) to the faDaA=' [q. v.]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence] AfDY fulaAnN A_ilaY fulaAnK Such a one came to, or reached, such a one: (M, Mgh, TA:) originally, became in the space, or the place, or quarter, of
such a one: (M:) or properly, became in the faDaA=' of such a one. (Mgh.) And in like manner, AfDY A_ilayohi AlA^amoru [The thing, or event, came to, or reached, him]. (M.) And A^afoDayotu A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i I came to, or reached, the thing. (Msb.) Accord. to IAar, (TA,) AlA_ifoDaA='u properly signifies AlAinotihaA='u [i. e. The coming at last, or ultimately, or the reaching, to a person or thing]. (IAar, T, Msb, TA.) Hence the saying [in the Kur iv. 25], waqado A^afoDaY baEoDukumo A_ilaY baEoDK i. e. When one of you hath come, and betaken himself, to the other; (TA;) in which the verb is made trans. by means of A_ilaY because having the meaning [of AinotahaY or] of waSala: (M:) or this means, when one of you hath become alone with the other, agreeably with the original derivation; or, accord. to some, it is an allusion to mutual contact, skin to skin: or to copulation. (Mgh.) You say, AfDY A_ilaY A@moraA^atihi [He went in to his wife: or] he became in contact with his wife, skin to skin: (S, Msb:) or it signifies, (M, K,) or signifies also, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) he compressed his wife: (S, M, Msb, K:) or he was, or became, with her alone in private, whether he compressed her or not. (M, K.) ― -b4- AfDY bihimo He reached with them, or brought them to, a wide, or spacious, place. (TA.) And AfDY bihi AlT~ariyqu A_ilaY waEorK mina AlA^aroDi [The road brought him to a rugged tract of land]. (K * and TA in art. wEr) ― -b5- AfDY biyadihi A_laY AlA^aroDi He touched the ground with the palm of his hand (IF, S, Msb, K) in his prostration [in prayer]. (S, K.) And A^afoDayotu A_ilayohi biyadiY mino gayori HaAy^ilK I put my hand to it without anything intervening; i. q. masasotuhu (Msb in art ms.) ― -b6- A^afoDayotu A_ilaY falaAnK bisiriY [I communicated, or made known, to such a one my secret]: (S;) or A^afoDayotu A_ilayohi biAls~ir~i I acquainted him with the secret. (Msb. TA.) ― -b7- AfDY also signifies (assumed tropical:) He became poor: so says IAar: as though he came to the ground. (TA.) -A2- laA yufoDiY A@ll~`hu faAka, occurring in a trad., is a phrase expressive of a prayer, meaning May God not make thy mouth wide and empty. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying of IAar, AlA_ifoDaA='u A^no tasoquTa Alv~anaAyaA mino taHotu wamino fawoqu [app. meaning that AifoDaA='N is the inf. n. of A^ufoDiYa signifying His central incisors, below and above, fell out: or he was caused to lose them]: and hence [the epithet] AlmufoDaApu [and therefore hence also what here follows]. (TA.) ― -b3- AfDY AlmaroA^apa He made the woman's masolakaAni (i. e. her vagina and rectum, Msb) to become one, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) in devirginating her, (Msb,) or in compressing her; (TA;) the intervening part becoming rent: (Mgh, TA:) and so A^afaADahaA: (M, in which it is mentioned in art. fDY:) the epithet applied to her is ↓ mufoDaApN, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is syn. with $ariymN. (S.)

5 tafaD~ayotu * for tafaD~aDotu see in art. fD (conj. 5). ― -b2- [AltfD~Y in a passage of the Fákihet el-Khulafà accord. to several copies thereof is an obvious mistake for Alt~afaS~iY, with the unpointed S: see Freytag's Critical Annotations and Corrections in his edition of that work, p. 6.]

faDFA * , (S, M, K,) also written faDFY, (TA,) A thing (S, K) mixed. (S, M, K.) You say TaEaAmN faDFA Mixed food: (S:) and tamorN faDFA dates mixed, (AA, * S, M,) as, for instance, (S, TA,) with raisins, (Lh, S, M, TA,) in one vessel, or bag; thus says El-Kálee; (TA;) or scattered, or strewn, and mixed; (M:) and tamoraAni faDayaAni [two sorts of dates mixed]: and tumuwrN A^afoDaA='N [several sorts of dates mixed]. (AA, TA.) And mataAEuhomN fawoDaY faDFA Their goods are mixed together: (M:) or are shared in common. (TA.) And A^amoruhumo faDFA bayonahumo [Their case is mixed, or promiscuous, &c., like A^amoruhumo fawoDaY bayonahumo (q. v. in art. fwD); or] their case among themselves is alike; (M, TA;) i. e. they have no commander over them. (S, TA.) And taraka AlA^amora faDFA i. e. [He left the affair] in an unsound [or a disordered] state. (TA.) And A^aloqaY vawobahu faDFA [He threw down his garment in a disorderly, or cureless, manner;] he did not commit his garment to any one's care.
