(M, TA.) ― -b2- [Also One; a single thing or person: and alone; by itself or himself; not having any other with it or him; apart from others: thus it has two contrmeanings.] You say sahomN faDFA One, or a single, arrow. (K:) or an arrow that is alone, by itself, not having any other with it, in the quiver. (AA, TA.) And baqiyta faDFA I remained alone, (Az, K, TA,) of such as were fellows: (Az, TA:) or a part from my brethren and my family. (Akh, TA) -A2- Also, i. e. faDFA, (M, K,) or correctly with Y [i. e. (??)], as written by El-Kálee, (TA,) The stones (Hab~) of raisins; (M;) i. q. faDFA [or fSFY]. (K.) -A3- See also what next follows.

faDoyapN *
Water collecting and stagnating: pl. fiDaA'N, with medd, accord. to Kr: and also ↓ faDFY and fiSFY, with fet-h and with kesr, the former of these like HalaqN as pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of HaloqapN, and the latter like bidarN as a pl. of badorapN; occurring in different relations of a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Er-Rikáa. (M in art. fDY, and TA.)

faDaA='N * is an inf. n.: (M, K, TA:) and is expl. by Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee as signifying Width, or spaciousness. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is also used as an epithet:] see faADK. ― -b3- And [as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] it signifies A court, an open area, or a yard, of a house; syn. saAHapN: (S, K:) and a wide, or spacious, tract of land: (ISh, S, M, K:) or a plain and wide expanse of land: (Sh, TA:) the pl. is A^afoDiypN. (ISh, TA.)

fiDaA='N *
Water running upon the ground: (K:) or, accord. to Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee it is [in measure, but not exactly in meaning,] like HisaA='N [a pl. of HisoYN], signifying water running upon the surface of the earth; [or rather waters &c.; for he adds,] and its sing. is ↓ faDiy~apN: in the M, [in art. fDY,] it is said to be a pl. of faDoyapN, [q. v.,] on the authority of Kr. (TA.)
faDiy~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

faADK * (Msb, TA) and ↓ mufoDK (M, * TA) Wide, or spacious, (M, * Msb, TA,) as also ↓ faSaA='N, (Az, Er-Rághib, Mgh, Msb, TA,) open and plain, and vacant. (TA.) ― -b2- [The first of these words, in the present day, pronounced faADiY, is commonly used in the sense of faArigN as meaning Unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure.]

mafoDFY *
i. q. mut~asaEN [A place of width or spaciousness, &c.]. (TA.)
mufoDK * : see faADK. [And see also its verb, 4.]
mufoDaApN * : see 4, last sentence,

1 faTaA^ahu * is like HaTaA^apu in its [various] meanings. (K.) Like the latter it signifies He struck him on the back. (AZ, S, O.) ― -b2- And He broke it, or crushed it. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And faTaA^ahaA, (S, O, TA,) aor.
faTaAa , inf. n. faTo'N, (TA,) He compressed her; (S, O, TA;) namely, a woman. (TA.) ― -b4- And faTaA^a bihi AlA^aroDa He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground, (S, O.) ― -b5- And (??) He cast forth his excrement, or ordure; sometimes occurring with v; (S, O;) which is a dial. var.; or an instance of mispronunciation. (O) ― -b6- And faTaA^ati Alganamu biA^awolaAdihaA The sheep, or goats, brought forth their young ones. (S, O.) And laEana A@ll~`hu A^um~aA faTaAtN bihi May God curse a mother who cast him forth [from her womb]: like $aTaA^ato bh. (TA in art. $TA^.) ― -b7- And faTiA^abihaA He broke wind [app. with a sound; like HTaA^abhA]. (S, O.) ― -b8- faTaA^a Alqawoma He did to the people, or party, what they did not like. (O, K.) ― -b9- And faTaA^a Zahora baEiyrihi He loaded his camel with a heavy burden, so that his back became hollow, or depressed. (K.) -A2- faTiy^a, aor.
faTaAa , (K,) inf. n. faTaA^N, (TA,) [app., i. q. faTisa, i. e. He had the bone of his nose wide and depressed; or depressed and expanded; or he had his nose spreading upon his face: see faTaA^N below. ― -b2- And] He had a hollow back, and a protuberant breast, or chest. (K.) ― -b3- And faTiy^a AlbaEiyru The camel was, by nature, low, or depressed, in his back. (S, O.)

4 AfTA^ *
He copulated much, or often. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b2- And He became ample in his state, or circumstances. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b3- And His nature, or disposition, became evil, after having been good. (IAar, O, K.) -A2- AfTA^hu He fed him; gave him to eat; or gave him food. (O, K.)

6 tfATA^ * , (K, TA,) said of a man, (TA,) is syn. with taqaAEasa [q. v.; app. in a sense similar to the senses here following]: or it signifies more than tqAEs. (K, TA.) tfATA^ Eanohu means He held back, or receded, from him, or it (K, * TA.) And tfATA^ Eanohumo He was defeated, and retreated from them, (O, K,) after he had charged, or made an assault or attack, upon them. (O.)

faTaA^N * [mentioned above as inf. n. of faTiy^a, and in the O erroneously written fuTaA',] i. q. faTasN [i. e. A depression and expansion of the bone of the nose; or a spreading of the nose upon the face]; (S, * O, * K;) and ↓ faTaA^apN is syn. with faTasapN [which is a subst. signifying as above] (S, O: but in one of my copies of the S, the former of these words is written faToA^ap; and in the O, the latter is written faTosap.) ― -b2- And Hollowness of the back, (K, TA,) or, as some say, of the middle of the back, (TA,) and protuberance of the breast, or chest; as also ↓ faToA^apN. (K, TA.)
fuToA^apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
faTaA^apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^afoTaA^u *
i. q. A^afoTasu [i. e. Having the bone of his nose depressed and expanded; or having his nose spreading upon his face]. (S, * O, * TA.) It is said that Museylimeh the Liar was A^afoTaA^, (O,) or A^afoTaA^u AlA^anofi: so in a trad. (TA.) ― -b2- And Having a hollow back, and a protuberant breast, or chest. (K.) And A^afoTaA^u AlZ~ahori A camel low, or depressed, in the back, by nature. (TA.)

1 faTaHahu * , (S, K,) aor.
faTaHa , (K,) inf. n. faToHN; (S;) and ↓ fT~Hhu, (S, * K,) inf. n. tafoTiyHN; (S;) He made it broad, or wide. (S, K.) ― -b2- And faTaHa AlEuwda wagayorahu, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above; and ↓ fT~Hhu, inf. n. as above; (TA;) He pared, or fashioned by cutting, the stick, or piece of wood, &c., and made it broad, or wide. (K, TA.) And faTaHa AlHadiyodapa, and ↓ fT~HhA, He made the piece of iron broad, or wide, and even, or flat, for a misoHaAp, or a miEozaq, or some other thing. (L.) ― -b3- And faTaHa biAlEaSaAZahorahu, (K, * TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He struck his back with the staff, or stick. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- And faTaHato biAlwaladi, said of a woman, i. q. ramato bihi [She cast forth the child, or the fœtus]. (K, TA.) [Compare TafaHato.] -A2- faTiHa, aor.
faTaHa , inf. n. faTaHN, [app., He (a man) had a broad, or wide, head: (see A^afoTaHu:) or it signifies, or signifies likewise, and so app. ↓ fuT~iHa, inf. n. tfoTiyHN, (see faTaHN below, and A^afoTaHu,)] said of the head, and of the end of the nose, It was, or became, broad, or wide. (TK.) -A3- faTiHa Aln~axolu The palm-trees became fecundated. (Kr, K.)
2 faT~aHa see the preceding paragraph, in four places.

faTaHN * [inf. n. of faTiHa, q. v.: and, as a simple subst.,] Breadth, or width, of the head, (S, K, TA,) in the middle; as also tafoTiyHN: (TA:) and breadth, or width, of the end of the nose, (L, K,) so that it sticks close to the face; as in the bull, which is termed A^afoTaHu. (L.)
faTuwHN * A she-camel bulky in the belly, (K, TA,) broad, or wide, in the ribs. (TA.)

A^afoTaHu * A man having a broad, or wide, head. (S.) And A broad, or wide, head; (A, L;) as also ↓ mufaT~aHN (S, A, L) and ↓ mafoTuwHN. (A.) And A^aronabapN faToHaA='u A broad, or wide, end of a nose: (A, L:) and so qadamN [i. e. foot]. (A.) ― -b2- AlA^afoTaHu The bull: so called because of the breadth of the end of his nose: (L, K:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (L.) ― -b3- And The chameleon (K, TA) whose back and colour the sun makes to glisten so that it becomes white by reason of the heat thereof. (TA.) ― -b4- And AlfaToHaA='u The broad, or wide, part of a bow. (L.) -A2- Also i. q. A^afodaEu [q. v.]. (K.)
mufaT~aHN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mafoTuwHN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

AlfiTaHolu * , (S, O, K,) and accord. to the expositors of the Fs, AlfaTaHolu also, (TA,) [or zamanu AlfaTaHoli,] A [or the] time in which mankind had not as yet been created (lamo yuxolaqo fiyhi baEodu): (S, O, K:) or the time of Noah: (K:) or a [or the] time in which the stones were moist, or soft: (S, O, K:) thus said Ru-beh, when asked respecting it; (TA;) and thus the Arabs of the desert accord. to AO: (S, O, TA:) a poet said,
zamana AlfiTaHoli A_i*aAAls~ilaAmu riTaAbu
[In the time of the fTHl, when the stones were moist, or soft]: (TA:) and El-'Ajjáj is related to have said, (S,) or, correctly, Ru-beh, as in the O, or Ru-beh Ibn-El-'Ajjáj, in replying to a woman whom he desired to take to wife, and who had asked him what was his age, and what was his property, &c., (TA,)
faqulotu lawo Eum~irotu Eumora AlHisoli
A^awo Eumora nuwHK zamana AlfiTaHoli
waAlS~axoru mubotal~N kaTiyni AlwaHoli
Sirotu rahiyna jadavK A^awo qatoli
[And I said, If I were made to live the life of the new-born young one of the dabb (which is said to be seven hundred years), or the life of Noah in the time of the fitahl, when the rocks were moist like the clay of the mire, I should become the pledge of a grave or of slaughter]: (S, * O, TA: but the last has haramK in the place of jadavK:) and one says, kaAna *`lika zamana AlfiTaHoli [That was in the time of the fitahl]; a prov., in which the last word is said to have the first, or the third, of the meanings expl. in this art.; and which is said of a thing that happened long ago; (Meyd: [see also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 340:]) and A^atayotuka EaAma AlfiTaHoli, and Alhidamolapi, expl. by AHn as meaning [I came to thee] in the time [or year] of abundance of herbage, and of food and drink. (TA.) ― -b2- And fiTaHolN also signifies A torrent. (Sh, O, K.) ― -b3- And A camel large, big, or bulky. (Fr, Sh, K.) ― -b4- And Plump and big. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

1 faTarahu * , (S, M, K,) aor.
faTura , (M, K, TA,) and, accord. to the K,
faTira also, but this latter form requires consideration, for it is related by Sgh, from Fr, in another sense, that of milking a camel, and not unrestrictedly, (TA,) inf. n. faTorN; (S, M;) and ↓ fT~rhu, (M, TA,) inf. n. tafoTiyrN; (TA;) [but the latter is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects;] He clave, split, slit, rent, or cracked, it. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) faTara, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
faTura , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. faTorN (Msb, K) and fuTuwrN, (K,) It (the tooth called nAb, of a camel,) came forth; (S, K;) it clave the flesh and came forth. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 7. -A2- faTarahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
faTura , inf. n. faTorN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He (God, Msb, K) created it, (S, Msb, K,) namely, the creation: (Msb, K:) he caused it to exist, produced it, or brought it into existence, newly, for the first time, it not having existed before; originated it; commenced, or began it; (S, M, A, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ AftTrhu, relating to an affair. (TA.) I'Ab says, I did not know what is [the meaning of] Als~am`waAti ↓ faATiru [The Originater, or Creator, of the heavens] until two Arabs of the desert came to me, disputing together respecting a well, and one of them said A^anaA faTarotuhaA, meaning, I originated, or began, it. (S.) fuTira EalaY Al$~aYo'i: see TubiEa. [The explanation there given is confirmed by explanations of fiTorapN.] -A3- faTara AlEajiyna, (Lth, S, K,) aor.
faTura , inf. n. faTorN; (S;) and ↓ fTr~hu; (Ks, TA;) He made the dough into bread, or baked it, without leavening it, or leaving it until it should become good [or mature]; (K;) he kneaded the dough and made it into bread, or baked it, immediately; (Lth;) he hurried the dough, or prepared it hastily, so as to prevent its becoming mature. (S.) You say faTarat A@lomaroA^apu ↓ AlEajiyna Hat~aY A@sotabaAna fiyhi AlfaToru [The woman hurried the dough, or prepared it hastily, so that immaturity, or want of leaven, was manifest in it]. (S.) ― -b2- And in like manner, faTara AlT~iyna He prepared, or kneaded, the clay, or mud, [without leaving it until it should become mature,] and plastered with it immediately. (Lth, TA.) ― -b3- And faTara Aljiloda, (IAar, K,) inf. n. faTorN; (TA;) and ↓ AfTrhu; (K;) He did not saturate the skin with the tanning liquid: (IAar, K:) or he did not put it therein. (A.) -A4- And faTara, (Fr, O, K,) aor.
faTura and
faTira , (Fr, O, K, * TA,) inf. n. faTorN, (Fr, S, O, K,) He milked a she-camel, (Fr, S, O, K,) and a ewe or goat, (TA,) with the fore finger and the thumb: (Fr, S, O, K, TA:) or with the ends of the fingers: (K, TA:) or, as one does in indicating the number thirty, i. e., with the two thumbs and the two fore fingers: [but this is app. a mistake for what next follows:] (L, TA:) or, accord. to IAth, with two fingers [and] with the end of the thumb. (TA. See also Dab~a Aln~aAqapa.)
― -b2- And [hence, app.,] faTara A^aSaAbiEahu He pressed, or squeezed, his fingers. (TA.) And He struck his (another's) fingers so that they burst forth with blood (AinofaTarato damFA). (TA.) -A5- See also 2: ― -b2- and 4, first sentence.

2 fT~rhu * : see 1, first sentence. -A2- Also, (inf. n. tafoTiyrN, S,) He made him to break his fast; or to eat and drink; (S, * Mgh, * K;) as also ↓ AfTrhu, and ↓ faTarahu: (K:) he gave him breakfast: he, or it, (namely, the action termed A_isotimonaA='N, and a clyster, [&c.,] Msb,) broke, or vitiated, his fast. (Msb.) And you say also h`*aA kalaAmN yufoTiru AlS~awoma, [and, more commonly, yufaT~iruhu,] This is speech which breaks, or vitiates, the fast. (TA.) -A3- fT~r AlEajiyna: see 1.

4 AfTr *
He broke his fast; (S, * Mgh; *) he breakfasted; he ate and drank after fasting; (Msb, * K;) as also ↓ faTara, (K,) aor.
faTura , (TA,) inf. n. fuTuwrN: (Msb, TA:) his fast became vitiated. (Msb.) AfTr as quasi-pass. of faT~arotuhu is extr., (Sb,) like A^abo$ara as quasi-pass. of ba$~arotuhu. (Sb, Mgh.) You say AfTr EalaY tamorK [He breakfasted upon dates, or dried dates;] he made dates, or dried dates, his breakfast, after sunset [in Ramadán]. (Msb.) In the saying SuwmuwA liruw^oyatihi waA^afoTiruwA liruwoyatihi [Fast ye after the sight of it, namely, the new moon commencing Ramadán, and break ye your fast after the sight of it, namely, the new moon commencing Showwál], the l is in the sense of baEod, i. e., baEoda ruw^oyatihi. (Msb.) ― -b2- It was time for him to break his fast: (K:) he entered upon the time of breaking his fast; (Mgh, Msb, K;) like A^aSobaHa and A^amosaY as meaning “ he entered upon the time of morning ” and “ upon the time of evening: ” (Mgh, * Msb:) or he became in the predicament of those who break their fast, and so though he neither ate nor drank: whence the trad., A^afoTara AlHaAjimu waA@lomaHojuwmu The cupper and the cupped place themselves in the predicament of those who break their fast: or it is time for the cupper and the cupped to break their fast: or it is used after the manner of a harsh expression, and an imprecation against them. (IAth.) -A2- AfTrhu: see 2. -A3- AfTr Aljiloda: see 1.
5 tafaT~ara see the next paragraph, in six places.

7 AnfTr * , and ↓ tfT~r, (S, M, K,) and ↓ faTara, (M,) [but the second is with teshdeed as quasi-pass. of 2, to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, or application to many subjects of the action, as is indicated in the S by its being expl. by ta$aq~aqa,] It became cleft, split, slit, rent, or cracked. (S, M, K.) A_i*aA A@ls~amaA='u A@nofaTarato [in the Kur lxxxii. 1] means When the heaven shall become cleft. (Bd, TA.) And minohu ↓ takaAdu Als~am`waAtu yatafaT~arona [in the Kur xix. 92] The heavens are near to becoming repeatedly rent in consequence thereof. (Bd.) And qadamaAhu ↓ tafaT~arato His feet became cracked: [or much cracked.] (TA, from a trad.) And ↓ tafaT~arati AlA^aroDu biAln~abaAti The earth became cracked [in many places by the plants coming forth]. (TA.) And Al$~ajaru biwaraqK ↓ tafaT~ara [The trees broke forth with leaves; as also AnfTr, often occurring in this sense; see Har p. 58; and see fiTorN]. (S and K, voce raAHa; &c.) And qadamaAhu damFA ↓ tafaT~arato [and AnfTrt (see 1, last sentence but one,)] His feet [burst forth or] flowed with blood. (TA.) ― -b2- And AnfTr AlS~uboHu (assumed tropical:) The dawn broke. (TA in art. SdE.)
8 A_ifotaTara see 1. And see also 8 in art. $rE.

faTorN * [as an inf. n.: see 1: ― -b2- as a subst.,] A cleft, split, slit, rent, or crack: (K:) or, accord. to some, a first cleft &c.: (MF:) pl. fuTuwrN: (K:) occurring in the saying halo taraY mino fuTuwrK [Dost thou see any clefts?], in the Kur [lxvii. 3]. (TA.) -A2- 'Omar, being asked respecting [the discharge termed] Alma*oY, answered, It is AlfaToru: (O, K:) thus as related by A 'Obeyd: (TA:) it is said that he likened it, in respect of its paucity, to what is drawn from the udder by means of the milking termed AlfaToru: (O, K:) or, as some say, it is from tafaT~arato qadamaAhu damFA [expl. above]: (TA:) or he likened its coming forth from the orifice of the *akar to the coming forth of the naAb of the camel: or, as it is related by En-Nadr, he said ↓ AlfuToru, with damm: meaning the milk that appears upon the orifice of the teat of the udder. (O, K.)

fuTorN *
Such as has broken forth [with buds or leaves] (maA tafaT~ara), of plants. (TA.) See also fiTorN. ― -b2- And, (S, K,) as also ↓ fuTurN, (K,) the latter used in poetry, (TA,) [The toadstool;] a species of kamoA^ap [or fungus], (S, K,) white and large, (S,) and deadly: (K:) [so called] because the ground cleaves asunder from it: (TA:) n. un. fuTorapN. (S.) [Also applied in the present day to The common mushroom; agariens campestris. And Any fungus.] -A2- [Also, the former, Immaturity, or want of leaven, in dough:] see the explanation of faTarati AlmaroA^apu AlEajiyna. -A3- And fuTorN and ↓ fuTurN signify also Somewhat of that which remains of milk [in the udder], which is then milked: (L, K:) or a small quantity of milk when it is milked: (TA:) or milk at the time when it is milked. (AA, TA.) See also faTorN, last sentence.

fiTorN *
Grapes when the heads thereof appear; (K, TA;) [so called] because the [fruit-] stalks [then] break forth (tanofaTiru); (TA;) as also ↓ fuTorN. (K, TA.) -A2- Also a subst. from A^afoTara; (S;) [as such] it signifies The breaking of a fast; contr. of SawomN. (TA.) [Hence, Eiydu AlfiTori The festival of the breaking of the fast, immediately after Rama- dán; sometimes called AlfiToru alone.] ↓ AlfiTorapu means Sadaqapu AlfiTori [The alms of the breaking of the fast], (O, K, TA,) which is a SaAE [q. v.] of wheat: the prefixed noun (Sdqh) is rejected, and p is affixed to its complement (AlfTr) to indicate that such has been done: but it is a word used by the lawyers; not of the classical language. (TA.) -A3- See also mufoTirN.
fuTurN * : see fuTorN, in two places.

fiTorapN *
Creation: (Msb:) the causing a thing to exist, producing it, or bringing it into existence, newly, for the first time; originating it. (TA.) ― -b2- The natural constitution with which a child is created in his mother's womb; (AHeyth, K;) i. q. xiloqapN. (S, Mgh.) It is said to have this signification in the Kur xxx. 29. (TA.) And so in the saying of Mohammad, kul~u mawoluwdK yuwladu EalaY AlfiTorapi Every infant is born in a state of conformity to the natural constitution with which he is created in his mother's womb, either prosperous or unprosperous [in relation to the soul]; and if his parents are Jews, they make him a Jew, with respect to his worldly predicament; [i. e., with respect to inheritances &c.;] and if Christians, they make him a Christian, with respect to that predicament; and if Magians, they make him a Magian, with respect to that predicament; his predicament is the same as that of his parents until his tongue speaks for him: but if he die before his attaining to the age when virility begins to show itself, he dies in a state of conformity to his preceding natural constitution, with which he was created in his mother's womb. (AHeyth, TA.) [See another explanation of the word, as occurring in this trad., below.] ― -b3- Nature; constitution; or natural, native, innate, or original, disposition, or temper or other quality or property; idiosyncrasy. (Th, TA.) ― -b4- The faculty of knowing God, with which He has created mankind: (TA:) the natural constitution with which a child is created in his mother's womb, whereby he is capable of accepting the religion of truth: this is a secondary application: and this is [said to be] the signification meant in the trad. mentioned above. (Mgh.) ― -b5- Hence, The religion of el-Islám: (Mgh:) the profession whereby a man becomes a Muslim, which is the declaration that there is no deity but God, and that Mohammad is his servant and his apostle, who brought the truth from Him, and this is (AHeyth, TA) religion. (AHeyth, K, TA.) This is shown by a trad., in which it is related that Mohammad taught a man to repeat certain words when lying down to sleep, and said faA_in~aka A_ino mut~a mino layolatika mut~a EalaY AlfiTorapi [And then, if thou die that same night, thou diest in the profession of the true religion]. (AHeyth, TA.) Also by the saying, qaS~u AlA^aZofaAri mina AlfiTorapi The paring of the nails is [a point] of the religion of el-Islám. (Mgh.) ― -b6- Also i. q. sun~apN [app. meaning The way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like, pursued, and prescribed to be followed, by Mohammad]. (TA.) ― -b7- In the Kur xxx. 29, accord. to some, The covenant received, or accepted, from Adam and his posterity. (Bd.) ― -b8- The pl. is fiTaraAtN and fiToraAtN and fiTiraAtN. (TA.) -A2- See also fiTorN.
AlA_iymaAnu AlfiToriY~u * [The faith to which one is disposed by the natural constitution with which he is created]. (Msb.)
fuTaArN * A sword having in it cracks; (S, Z, O, K;) and (K) that will not cut: (IAar, O, K:) or recently made. (TA.)
faTuwrN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ faTuwriY~N, (S, K,) as though the latter were a rel. n. from the former, (S,) A breakfast; a thing [i. e. food or beverage] upon which one breaks his fast. (S, Msb, K.)

faTiyrN * Dough unleavened; or not left until it has become good [or mature]; contr. of xamiyrN: (S, TA:) and in like manner clay, or mud. (TA.) [Hence,] Eiydu AlfaTiyri [The feast of unleavened bread; also called, of the Passover;] a festival of the Jews, [commencing] on the fifteenth day of their month niysaAn, and lasting seven days. (Msb. [See also AlfiSoHu.]) ― -b2- Anything prepared, made, or done, hastily, or hurried, so as to prevent its becoming mature: (Lth, S, K:) fresh; recent; newly made: (S, TA:) pl. faToraY: (Sgh, IAth, TA:) for A^aToEamahu faToraY, in the K, expl. as meaning [He fed him] with faTiyr, is a gross mistake, a mistranscription of A^aToEimapN faToraY, as the phrase stands in the handwriting of Sgh himself, in wellformed letters, and with the syll. signs, meaning meats [newly prepared, &c.]. (TA.) You say EinodiY xubozN xamiyrN waHayosN faTiyrN [I have leavened bread, and] fresh, recent, or newly made, Hys [q. v.]. (S, TA.) You say also A_iy~aAka waAlr~aA^oYa AlfaTiyru (tropical:) Beware thou of a hastily formed, immature, opinion. (S.) And $ar~u Alr~aA^oYi AlfaTiyru (tropical:) [The worst opinion is the hastily formed, and immature]. (TA.) ― -b3- A skin not saturated with the tanning liquid: or not put therein: (TA:) a whip not tanned: not softly tanned: (TA:) or not newly tanned. (L.) -A2- Also A calamity; syn. daAhiyapN. (O, K, TA.)
faTuwrapN * : see what next follows.
faTiyrapN * and ↓ faTuwrapN A sheep, or goat, that is slaughtered on the day of [the festival of] the fiTor: (K, TA:) mentioned by Sgh, and in the B. (TA.)

fuTaAriY~N * A man possessing neither good nor evil; (IAar, O, K, * TA;) such as is termed fadom [impotent in speech or actions, heavy, or dull; &c.]: (TA:) from fuTaArN applied to a sword, meaning that will not cut. (IAar, O, TA. *)
faTuwriY~N * : see faTuwrN.

faATirN * A camel whose naAb [or tush] is coming forth, (S,) or cleaving the flesh and coming forth. (TA.) -A2- faATiru A@ls~am`waAti waA@lA^aroDi [in the Kur xlii. 9, &c.,] means The Originater [or Creator] of the heavens and of the earth. (I'Ab, S, * TA.) See 1.
fuwTiyrN * a subst. for AljimaAE, in Syriac. (TA.)
A^ufoTuwrN * , and the pl. A^afaATiyru: see the next paragraph.

tafaATiyru * , a word similar to taEaA$iybu and taEaAjiybu and tabaA$iyru [q. v.], none of which four words has a sing., Pimples that come forth in the face of a boy or young man, and of a girl or young woman; as also ↓ nafaATiyru: thus correctly, with t and n: the author of the K, following Sgh [in the O], says that ↓ A^afaATiyru is the pl. of ↓ A^ufoTuwrN, and signifies a cracking, or chapping, in the nose of a young man, and in his face. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, thus correctly, with t, The first of [the herbage of the rain called] the wasomiY~ [q. v.]; and in this sense also it has no sing.: but it is said in the K that ↓ nafaATiyru is pl. of ↓ nufoTuwrapN, with n; [in the O, that it is pl. of ↓ nufoTuwrN;] and [in both] that it signifies scattered herbage; (TA;) and Lh says, as is stated by AHn, that mino Eu$obK ↓ nafaATiyru means small quantities of herbage in land: (O, TA:) it is also added in the K, in explanation of ↓ nafaATiyru, or it signifies the first herbage of [the rain called] the wasomiY~: (TA:) [and it is said that] tafaATiyru nabaAtK signifies what break forth of, or from, plants, or herbage. (TA voce tabaA$iyru.)

mufoTirN * A man breaking his fast; eating and drinking after fasting: (S, * Msb, * K, TA:) pl. mafaATiyru, (Sb, S, Msb, K,) like as mayaAsiyru is pl. of muwsirN, (S,) and mafaAliysu of mufolisN: (Msb:) and ↓ fiTorN signifies the same, as sing. and pl., (S, Msb, K,) being originally an inf. n. (S, Msb.)

munofaTirN * is used in the Kur [lxxiii. 18], in the phrase A@ls~amaA='u munofaTirN bihi [The heaven shall be with rents by reason of it], in the manner of a possessive noun, [not as an act. part. n.,] like muEoDilN in the phrase dajaAjapN muEoDilN. (TA.)
nufoTuwrN * and nufoTuwrapN, and the pl. nafaATiyru: see tfATyr, in six places.

1 faTasa * , (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
faTisa (S, Msb, K) and
faTusa , (Msb,) inf. n. fuTuwsN, (S, M, &c.,) He died; (S, M, &c.;) as also Tafasa: (TA:) or he died without disease: (M:) or without any apparent disease. (TA.) -A2- faTasa AlHadiyda, (A, O, K, TA,) aor.
faTisa , (K, * TA,) inf. n. faTosN, (TA,) He made the iron broad (A, O, K) with the great hammer called fiT~iys: (A:) or he beat the iron. (TA.) ― -b2- And AlfaTosu signifies The treading vehemently, or the compressing vehemently. (M, TA: the word thus doubly rendered is AlwaTo'u.) ― -b3- And you say, faTasotuhu Eano ka*aA meaning I repelled him in a most evil manner from such a thing: and likewise I beat him [app. away from such a thing]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b4- And faTasahu biAlkalimapi, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) and biAlxabari, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O,) aor.
faTisa , (K,) He uttered in his face [the word, or sentence, and the tidings, or information]; as also ↓ fT~shu, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) inf. n. tafoTiysN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) -A3- fiTisa, aor.
faTasa , inf. n. faTasN, (S, M, A, K,) He had the bone of his nose wide and depressed; (M;) or depressed and expanded: (S, A, K:) he had his nose spreading upon his face. (A, K.) [And faTiy^a app. signifies the same.]

2 fT~shu *
He killed him. (Msb.) -A2- See also 1.
faTosN * (with fet-h, O, in a copy of the M written fuTos,) The berries of the myrtle: n. un. with p. (Lth, M, O, K.)
faTasN * : see faTasapN.

faTosapN * The skin of an animal that has not been slaughtered in the manner prescribed by the law. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- [See also faTosN.] ― -b3- Also A certain bead used for fascinating and restraining [men]; (Lh, S, M, K;) one of the beads of the Arabs of the desert, with which women are asserted by the Arabs to fascinate and restrain men. (O.) They (i. e. women, O, K) say,
baAlv~uw^abaA waAEaTosapi
A^ax~a*otuhu biAlfaTosapi
[I captivated and restrained him by means of the fatseh, by means of yawning and of sneezing]: (S, O, K: [in some copies of the S and K biAlv~uw^abA='i:]) they shorten AlvwbA=' on account of the metre, which is rajaz with the third foot of each hemistich suppressed. (O.)

faTasapN * a subst. from faTisa [as such signifying A state of depression and expansion of the bone of the nose; or a spreading of the nose upon the face]: (S, O, K:) or the same word, (M, L,) or ↓ faTasN, (TA, [but this is the inf. n. of faTisa, and seems to be here a mistranscription,]) the place of a width and depression of the bone of the nose. (M, L, TA.)

fiT~iysN *
A great hammer, (S, M, A, O, K,) such as is used by a blacksmith: (A, TA:) or, (K,) accord. to IDrd, (O,) it is either Greek or Syriac, (O, K,) not genuine Arabic. (O.) ― -b2- And A great faA^os [i. e. hoe or adz or axe]. (M, TA.)

fiT~iysapN * The snout of the swine; as also ↓ finoTiysapN: (S, M, * K:) or its nose with what is next thereto: (IDrd, O, K:) and, (K,) accord. to Th, (O,) it [app. meaning the lip] is [called] the $afap of man, and of camels the mi$ofar, and of beasts of prey the xaTom and the xuroTuwm, and of the swine the ↓ finoTiysip, (O, K, * [in the latter of which it is plainly stated that fiT~iysapN is used in relation to man and to camels and to beasts of prey, whereas Th seems evidently to mean that what is called the $afap of man, and of camels the ma$ofar, &c., is called the fanoTiysap of the swine,]) which word fnTysp he [thus] mentions, with n, as of the measure finoEiylapN, the n being augmentative. (O.)

faATisN *
Dying, or dead. (IAar, M.)
finoTiysapN * : see fiT~iysipN, in two places: and see also art. fnTs, in two places.

A^afoTasu * A man (S) having the bone of his nose wide and depressed; (M;) or depressed and ex-
panded: (S, K:) having his nose spreading upon his face: (K:) fem. fTosaA='u. (M, K.) And it is also applied as an epithet to the nose itself [as meaning Having its bone wide and expanded; &c.]. (A in art. nfs.) ― -b2- tamorapN faTosaA='u means A date small in the drupe, having the base cleaving [to it]. (TA.)

1 faTamahu * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
faTima , (Msb, K,) inf. n. faTomN, (Msb, * TA,) He cut it, or severed it; (S, Msb, K, TA;) namely, a rope, (S, Msb, TA,) or a stick, or piece of wood, and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- And faTamahu, (K,) or faTamatohu (S, Msb) said of a mother (S) or of a suckling woman, (Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) He, (K,) or she, (S, Msb,) weaned, or ablactated, him, (S, Msb, K,) namely, a child, (S, K,) or suckling. (Msb.) And fuTimati Als~axolapu The lamb, or kid, was weaned, or ablactated. (K.) [And in like manner one says of other animals.] ― -b3- And [hence, or] from the first of the significations expl. above, (Msb,) one says, faTamotuhu Eano EaAdatihi (tropical:) I [weaned him, or] disengaged him, (TA,) or withheld him, (Msb,) namely, a man, (S, Msb, TA,) [from his custom, or habit.] And laA^afoTiman~aka Eam~aA A^anota Ealayohi (tropical:) [I will assuredly wean thee from the state in which thou art, or from that which thou art pursuing: or] I will assuredly cut short thy eager desire. (TA.)

4 AfTm *
He (a child) entered upon the time for his being weaned, or ablactated. (Msb, TA.) And in like manner one says of a lamb, or kid. (IAar, K, TA.)

6 tfATmwA *
Their lambs, or kids, (bahomuhumo, [in the CK, erroneously, buhomuhumo,]) kept to their mothers after the weaning, or ablactation; (K, TA;) therefore this [person] gave, or delivered, his lambs, or kids, to this; and this [person], his lambs, or kids, to this. (TA.)

7 A_inofaTama [AnfTm He (a child, or young one,) was, or became, weaned, or ablactated: commonly used in this sense in the present day. ― -b2- And] AnfTm Eanohu (tropical:) He desisted from, or left, or relinquished, him, or it. (K, TA.)

fiTaAmN * The act of weaning, or ablactation, of a child or young one: (S, Msb, * K:) a subst. in this sense. (K.) -A2- And [it is also, app., an epithet:] you say nAqp fTAm [app. naAqapN fiTaAmN, like as you say naAqapN faATimN, q. v.], meaning A she-camel whose young one has been weaned from her: thus in the A. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence it seems to be used as a proper name of a woman; like faATimapu; for it is said,] and the woman is named fiTaAmN, like kitaAbN, [in form]. (TA.)

faTiymN * A child weaned, or ablactated; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ mafoTuwmN: (K:) pl. of the former fuTumN, (S, Msb, K,) which is of a rare form as pl. of an epithet of the measure faEiylN, and more particularly of such as is used in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (IAth, TA.) And saxolapN faTiymN [in the CK faTiymapN] and ↓ faATimN and ↓ mafoTuwmapN A lamb, or kid, weaned, or ablactated, (K, TA,) which is the case two months from its birth, and it ceases not to be thus termed until it becomes a jafor [q. v.]. (TA.)
faTiymapN * [a subst., rendered so by the affix p,] A sheep, or goat, weaned, or ablactated. (TA.)

faATimN * [act. part. n. of 1, q. v.] ― -b2- [Hence,] faATimapN A suckling woman weaning, or ablactating, a suckling. (Msb.) And faATimN A she-camel whose young one has become a year old and been weaned, or ablactated. (S, TA.) And A she-camel that weans, or is weaning, from her, her young one. (TA.) [See also fiTaAmN.] ― -b3- [Hence,] in a trad. cited voce muroDiEN [q. v.], AlfaATimapu signifies (assumed tropical:) Death. (TA in art. rDE.) -A2- See also faTiymN.
mafoTuwmN * ; and its fem., with p: see faTiymN.

1 faTina * , [aor.
faTana ,] inf. n. fiTonapN and faTaAnapN and faTaAniyapN [&c. as in the next sentence, He was, or became, intelligent, understanding, knowing, sagacious, or skilful: see the explanations of fiTonapN below]; (S;) and faTuna signifies [the same, i. e.] he became such as is termed faTin. (Lth, TA.) You say, faTina lahu, (Msb, K,) and A_ilayohi, and bihi, (K,) aor.
faTana ; (Msb, K;) and faTana, aor.
faTuna ; (Msb, K;) and faTuna, aor.
faTuna ; (K;) inf. n. faTonN (Msb, K) and faTonN and fuTonN and faTanN and fuTunN (K) and fiTonapN and fiTaAnN (Msb) and fuTuwnapN and faTaAnapN and faTaAniyapN; (K;) He was, or became, [intelligent, understanding, knowing, or sagacious, respecting it; (agreeably with explanations above;) or] skilled of it, i. e. skilful in it; (K;) namely, an affair: (Msb:) [and he understood, or knew, it; often used in this sense:] and sometimes they said faTanahu, making the verb trans. by itself, because it implies the meaning of fahima; (TA;) or faTanotu Al$~aYo'i, with fet-h, signifies I understood, or knew, the thing: (S:) and some say that faTaAnapN [as inf. n., agreeably with analogy, of faTuna, which see in what follows,] signifies [the possessing] excellence in respect of readiness of intelligence for the perception of what comes to one from another. (TA.) [faTana lahu also signifies He took notice of, or paid attention to, him, or it: see Har p. 626, and Ham p. 695.] And faTuna signifies [also] He became one of whom fiTonap [i. e. intelligence, &c., as expl. below,] was a sajiy~ap [meaning faculty, or quality, firmly rooted in the mind]. (Msb.)

2 fT~nhu llA^amori * , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. tafoTiynN, (K, TA,) He made him to understand, or know, the affair: (K, * TA:) or he made him knowing in the various modes of the affair, and skilful therein. (Msb.) Hence the prov., laA yufaT~inu AlqaArapa A_il~aA AlHijaArap i. e. [Nothing will make] the she-bear [to understand, except stones]. (TA.) And fT~nhu AlmuEal~imu means The teacher rendered him faTin [i. e. intelligent, &c.,] by the disciplining of his mind and the correcting him. (TA.)

3 mufaATanapN * is of the measure mufaAEalapN from faTina: (S:) [as such it signifies The contending, or vying, one with another, in intelligence, understanding, knowledge, sagacity, or skill; whence faATanotuhu is used in the K (in art. Hjw) as a syn. of HaAjayotuhu, q. v.: or] it signifies [sometimes] the showing intelligence, understanding, knowledge, sagacity, or skill, one with another. (PS.) [Agreeably with the former explanation,] one says, faATanahu fiY AlkalaAmi i. e. He held a dialogue or colloquy, or a disputation or debate, with him [with the view of trying which of them would prove superior in intelligence, &c.]; syn. raAjaEahu. (K) [See also 3 in art. lHn.]

5 tfT~n lahu *
He understood it, or knew it, [quickly, or] with quickness of intelligence; namely, what was said. (TA.)
faTonN * : see what next follows.
faTunN * : see what next follows.

faTinN * (S, Msb, K, KL) and ↓ faTunN (S, K, KL) and ↓ faTonN and ↓ faTiynN and ↓ faTuwnN and ↓ faATinN (K) are epithets (S, K, TA) applied to a man, (S, TA,) signifying Intelligent, understanding, knowing, sagacious, or skilful; (S, * K, * KL;) the first expl. by Lth as signifying possessing fiTonap respecting things: (TA:) and it signifies one of whom fiTonap has become a sajiy~ap [meaning faculty, or quality, firmly rooted in the mind]: (Msb:) the pl. [of this] is fuTonN, (K,) or fuzunN, with two dammehs, (Msb,) or both: (TA:) and the fem. is faTinapN. (K.) faTinN bixuSuwmatihi means A man knowing in the various modes of his disputation, or litigation, and skilful therein. (Msb.)

fiTonapN * [mentioned above as an inf. n. seems to be regarded by some as a simple subst., and] signifies Intelligence, understanding, knowledge, sagacity, (S, * KL, PS,) or skill; (K, KL, PS;) contr. of gabaAwapN: (TA:) or, accord. to some, such [intelligence, &c.,] as is instinctive [or natural; infused into the mind by God]; not acquired. (TA.) [See also *ihonN.]
faTuwnN * : see faTinN.
faTiynN * : see faTinN.
faATinN * : see faTinN.

1 faZ~a * , (Msb,) sec. pers. faZiZota, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. faZaAZapN (S, M, Msb, K) and faZaZN, (M, K,) but the former is the more common because of the difficulty of pronouncing the doubled letter in the latter, (M,) and ↓ fiZaAZN is syn. with these, (M, K,) and so is ↓ faZaAZN, but these two are simple substs., (M,) He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed faZ~N [i. e. rough, coarse, rude, &c., as expl. below]; (S, M, Msb, K; *) or rough, &c., so as to be unduly feared. (Msb.) -A2- faZ~apu, (M, K,)
aor.
faZu3a , inf. n. faZ~N; (TK;) and ↓ AftZ~hu; (M, K;) He let it out, namely the water termed faZ~N, by cutting open the stomach [of a camel]: (M, TA:) or he pressed it, or squeezed it, out, namely the water so termed, (M, K,) from the stomach, (M, TA,) and drank it: (TK:) and kari$a baEiyrK ↓ AftZ~ he slaughtered a camel, and pressed out, or squeezed out, the water of its stomach, and strained it: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, T:) or ↓ AftZ~ signifies he gave his camel to drink, then bound his mouth in order that he might not ruminate, and, when attacked by thirst, cut open his belly, and pressed out, or squeezed out, the fluid of the feces of his stomach, and drank it: (S:) and Alkari$a ↓ A^afoZaZotu I pressed out, or squeezed out, the water of the stomach. (Z, TA.)

4 A^afoZa3a see faZ~ahu. ― -b2- AfZ~hu, inf. n. A_ifoZaAZN, also signifies He turned him back, or away, from the object of his desire. (TA.) ― -b3- And AfZ~hu is also said of a man when he has inserted the thread into the eye of the needle: [if the affixed pronoun refer to the eye of the needle, the meaning is, He inserted the thread into it: if to the thread, he inserted it into the eye of the needle:] mentioned by AA. (TA.)
8 A_ifotaZa3a see faZ~ahu, in three places.

faZ~N * , applied to a man, (T, S, M, &c.,) Rough; coarse; rude; unkind; hard; churlish; uncivil; surly; hard to deal with; incompliant; unobsequious; (S, M, O, K, and Bd in iii. 153;) evil in disposition; illnatured; (O, K, and Bd and Jel ubi suprà;) hard-hearted; hard, or severe; rough, coarse, or the like, so as to be unduly feared; (Msb;) rough, or coarse, in speech; (Lth, T, M, K;) sour, or austere, therein: (Lth:) [said in the T to be from the same word in the sense next following; but accord. to the M, the reverse seems to be the case:] pl. A^afoZaAZN. (M.) You say, A_in~ahu lafaZ~N baZ~N [Verily he is rough, coarse, or the like]; the latter word being an imitative sequent; (M, K;) as such we regard it because Th, who mentions it, does not explan it; (M;) and ↓ faZiyZN baZiyZN [app. signifies the same]. (TA in art. bZ.) -A2- Also The water of the stomach [of a camel], (T, S, K,) which is pressed, or squeezed, out, and drunk, (T, K,) on an occasion of want of water, (T,) in the waterless deserts; (T, K;) the water that comes forth from the stomach [of a camel]; because it is a coarse, or bitter, beverage: (M:) it may not be used for the purpose of religious purification: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, T:) also, the urine of horses which is drunk on an occasion of thirst: pl. fuZuwZN: thus used by Mutemmem Ibn-Nuweyreh. (M, L.)
faZaAZN * and fiZaAZN: see 1, first sentence.

faZiyZN * The seminal fluid of a woman: or of a stallion: (M, K:) so they assert: but it is not of established authority: (M:) and so say IDrd and Fr: (TA:) accord. to Kr, the seminal fluid of a stallion, in a she-camel's womb: (M, * TA:) or this is the explanation given by Fr: (T:) and ↓ fuZaAZapN is of the measure fuEaAlapN from this word; (K;) as signifying the seminal fluid of a stallion, or the water of the stomach; but El-Khattábee disallows the latter meaning; or from faZ~N: (TA:) and hence the saying of 'Áïsheh to Marwán, wal`kin~a A@ll~`ha laEana A^abaAka waA^anota fiY Sulobihi faA^anota fuZaAZapN mino laEonapi A@ll~`hi [But God cursed thy father when thou wast essentially in his loins; so thou art seed of the object of the curse of God]; (K;) i. e., nuTofapN minohaA; (TA;) or EuSaArapN minohaA [produce thereof, as though expressed therefrom]: (Z:) or, accord. to one relation, fuDuDN; (K;) pl. of faDiyDN, which means water such as is termed gariyD: or, accord. to another relation, faDaDN, meaning nuTofapN: and accord. to another, faDiyDN. (TA.) -A2- See also faZ~N.
fuZaAZapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

huwa A^afoZ~u mino fulaAnK *
He is [more rough, coarse, rude, or the like, (see faZ~N,) or] more difficult in disposition, evil in disposition, illnatured, or perverse, than such a one. (TA.)

1 faZuEa AlA^moru * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faZuEa , (O,) inf. n. faZaAEapN, (S, O, Msb,) and perhaps faZaEN [respecting which see faZiEa]; (Mbr, TA;) as also ↓ AfZE; (S, O, Msb, K;) The affair, or event, was, or became, hard, difficult, or distressing; bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; excessive, or exorbitant: (S:) or excessively bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (O, Msb, K.) -A2- And faZiEa AlA^amora, (K, TA,) thus in the copies of the K, and in like manner in the O, [where I find, AZ says, faZiEotu AlA^amora, aor. A^afoZaEuhu,] but [SM says] in the “ Nawádir ” of AZ, faZiEa biAlA^amori, inf. n. faZaAEapN, (TA,) He reckoned the affair, or event, or judged it to be, great, hard, difficult, or distressing, syn. AisotaEoZamahu, (K,) or was made to fear, or be frightened, and was overcome, by it, (AZ, O, TA,) and trusted not that he had power to accomplish it, or to bear it: (AZ, O, K, TA:) it is said in a trad., A^uriytu A^an~ahu wuDiEa fiY yadaY~a sawaAraAni mino *ahabK fafaZiEotuhumaA [I was made to see, meaning I imagined, or dreamt, that two bracelets of gold were put upon my arms, and I regarded them with fear]; in which instance, as IAth says, the verb is thus made trans. in accordance with its meaning, which is A^akobarotuhumaA, and xifotuhumaA: but the phrase commonly known is faZiEotu bihi and minohu: (TA:) you say, faZiEonu bika*aA I was unable to do, or accomplish such a thing: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K: *) and faZiEotu biA^amoriY occurs in a trad. as meaning [I found that] my affair, or case, was hard, difficult, or distressing, to me, and I regarded it with fear, or dread: faZiEa biAlA^amori, inf. n. faZaAEapN and faZaEN, means He saw the affair, or event, or case, to be faZiyE [q. v.]: Mbr says, faZaEN is an inf. n. of faZiEa bihi: or it may be an inf. n. of faZuEa, like as karamN is of karuma: but I have not heard it save in the saying of the poet,
qdo Ei$otu fiY Aln~aAsi A^aTowaArFA EalaY xuluqK
$at~aY waqaAsayotu fiyhi All~iyna waAlfaZaEaA
[I have lived among men during several periods, conforming to disposition differing in kind, (EalaY xuluqK $at~aY being like the phrase A_in~a saEoyakumo la$at~aY, in the Kur xcii. 4, meaning An~ masaAEiykumo laA^a$otaAtN, as is said in the Ksh and by Bd,) and I have endured therein softness and hardness]. (TA.) -A3- faZiEa, (O, K,) aor.
faZaEa , inf. n. faZaEN, (O,) said of a vessel, (K,) It became full. (O, K.)

2 fZ~E * , inf. n. tafoZiyEN, accord. to Freytag, signifies He described a thing as great: but for this he names no authority: by “ great ” is here meant hard, difficult, or distressing; &c.: see 1, first sentence.]

4 AfZE * as intrans.: see 1, first sentence. -A2- A^afoZaEaniY AlA^amoru The affair, or event, made me to fear, or frightened me: made me to fall into a hard, difficult, or distressing, case: (TA:) made me to be without power, or strength, or ability; disabled, or incapacitated, me. (Ham p. 32.) ― -b2- And A^ufoZiEa He (a man, S, O, Msb) suffered the befalling of a hard, difficult, or distressing, event. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b3- See also 10.
5 tafaZ~aEa see what next follows.
10 AstfZEhu * (S, O, K) and ↓ AfZEhu (S, K) and ↓ tfZ~Ehu (O, K) He found it (a thing, S) to be faZiyE [i. e. hard, difficult, or distressing; &c.]. (S, O, K.)
faZiEN * : see faZiyEN. -A2- Also Full; applied to a vessel. (O, TA.)

faZiyEN * (S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ mufoZiEN (S, Msb, TA) and ↓ faZiEN, which last is a possessive epithet, (TA,) applied to an affair, or event, Hard, difficult, or distressing; bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; excessive, or exorbitant: (S, TA:) or excessively bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (O, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- And the first, Much, or abundant: so in the saying of 'Amr Ibn-MaadeeKerib,
waqado Eajabato A^umaAmapu A^ano raAtaniY
tafar~aEa lim~atiY $ayobN faZiyEu
[And Umámeh wondered that she saw me such that much, or abundant, hoariness had spread in, or overspread, my hair descending below the ears, or upon the shoulders: fiY is app. understood before lim~atiY]. (O, TA.) -A2- faZiyEN applied to water signifies Sweet: (Lth, O, K:) or clear; limpid; or cool, sweet, and clear or limpid. (IAar, O, K, TA.)
mufoZiEN * : see faZiyEN.

1 faEalahu * , (S, O, Msb, K, *) aor.
faEala , (S, O, K,) inf. n. faEolN (S, O, Msb, K) and faEaAlN, (S, O, Msb,) and ↓ fiEolN is the subst. therefrom, (S, O, Msb, K, *) but, accord. to Ibn-Kemál, it has become commonly used as the inf. n.; MF, however, says that its being thus used requires consideration; and it is said that there is no instance like faEalahu, aor. yafoEaluhu, inf. n. fiEolN, except saHarahu, aor. yasoHaruhu, inf. n. siHorN; or, to these may be added as sometimes occurring, xadaEa, aor. yaxodaEu, inf. n. xadoEN and xidoEN, and SaraEa, aor. yaSoraEu, inf. n. SaroEN and SiroEN; (TA;) [He did it]; namely, a thing (S, O. [For further explanation see fiEolN below.]) [In the Kur. xxi. 73,] some read waA^awoHayonaA A_ilayohimo faEola A@loxayoraAti [And we suggested to them the doing of good works]; (Lth, S, O;) others reading ↓ fiEola AlxyrAt. (Lth, O.) ― -b2- And one says also faEala bihi [He did to him something]. (TA.) [faEala A@ll~`hu bihi is a form of imprecation, meaning May God do to him what He will do; i. e. may God punish him: see an ex. voce A^aZolamu. ― -b3- And faEala biAlmaroA^api often occurs in trads. &c. as meaning He compressed the woman.]

2 tafoEiylN * [inf. n. of fE~l] is used by IJ as metonymically signifying The scanning of a verse; because the names of the measures of its feet, all of them, have the letters f and E and l for constituents, as when you say faEuwluno and mafaAEiylno and faAEilaAtuno and faAEiluno &c. (TA.)
3 faAoEala [faAEalaA, inf. n. fiEaAlN, if used, app. signifies They two did a thing together.] See fiEaAlN below.

7 AnfEl * quasi-pass. of 1: you say, faEalotuhu faA@nofaEala [I did it, and it was done]; (S, Msb;) like your saying kasarotuhu faA@nokasara. (S.) [AlAinofiEaAlu signifies The suffering, or receiving, the effect of an act, whether the effect is intended by the agent or not: or, accord. to some, particularly when the effect is not intended: for it is implied in a passage in the TA, that it is held by some to be used particularly in cases in which the effects are such as the blushing in consequence of confusion, or shame, affecting one from the seeing a person, and the emotion, or excitement, ensuing from the hearing of singing, and the agitation of the passionate lover at his seeing the object of his love : as a term of logic, it is one of the ten predicaments, i. e. passion, or suffering.] It is said that to every fiEol there is an AinofiEaAl, except to the act of creation, which proceeds from God; for this is the bringing into existence from a state of nonexistence, not from matter [already existing to receive the effect of the act]. (TA.)

8 AftEl Ealayohi ka*ibFA * (Mgh, * O, Msb, * K) and zuwrFA (O) He forged against him a lie. (Mgh, * O, Msb, * K.) ― -b2- Hence the phrase AlxuTuwTu tufotaEalu i. e. [Handwritings] are forged, or falsified. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And [hence] it used to be said, A^aEo*abu AlA^agaAniY maA A@fotuEila i. e. [The sweetest of songs is] such as has been composed with originality, not in imitation of any model: and A^aZorafu Al$~iEori maAA@fotuEila [The most eloquent of poetry is such as has been so composed]. (TA.)
faEolN * an inf. n. of 1. (S, O, Msb, K.) -A2- And The vulva of the she-camel, and of any female. (K.)

fiEolN * : see 1, in two places: [as a subst. from faEalahu] it signifies [A deed, or an action: or] a motion (HarakapN) of a human being: (K:) or, as Sgh says, the origination of anything, whether it be what is termed EamalN [which means work or labour or service as well as a deed or an action] or other than it; so that it is more general in application than EamialN: (TA:) or it is a metonymical term for any Eamal [meaning deed or action] that is transitive (M, K, TA) or intransitive (M, TA:) or a mode that is accidental to the producer of an effect upon another [person or thing] by reason of the producing of the effect at the first; as the mode that ensues to the cutter by reason of his being cutting: or, as Er-Rághib says, the production of an effect considered with reference to an agent thereof; and it is common to that which is by his, or its, origination or otherwise, and to that which is with knowledge or otherwise, and to that which is by intention or otherwise, and to what proceeds from the human being or the animal [of any kind] or the inanimate thing; and EamalN and SunoEN are more particular in application: El-Harállee says that the fiEol is what has become apparent in consequence of a motive of the efficient, whether from knowledge or otherwise, by reason of premeditation [for litaday~un (an obvious mistranscription in my original) I read litadab~urK] or otherwise: and El-Juweynee says that it is what is within the limits of a small space of time, without repetition, or reiteration, whereas the Eamal is what has been repeated, or reiterated, and whereof the time has been long; but this is repugned by the trad. [in which occurs the saying], maA faEala Aln~uigayor [expl. in art. ngr]; (TA:) the pl. is fiEaAlN (S, O, Msb, K) and A^afoEaAlN [a pl. of pauc.], (O, TA,) [and A^afaAEiylu is app. a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of A^afoEaAlN, like A^qaAwiylu pl. of A^aqowaAlN which is pl. of qawolN, and many other instances]: you say, A_in~a Alr~i$aA tafotalu AlA^afaAEiyla watunosiY A_iboraAhiyma waA_isomaAEiyla [Verily bribes do great deeds, and cause the receivers to forget the principles of Ibráheem and Ismá'eel, who are esteemed models of true religion]. (TA. [This saying is written in my original without any vowel-signs, perhaps because well known: and it is there added that AlAfAEyl may be pl. of AfEwl (which has been altered by the copyist and is probably a mistranscription for A^afoEuwlapN) or of AfEAl; with other remarks equally doubtful and unimportant.]) [Hence, biAlfiEoli meaning Actually; as opposed to biAlquw~api i. e. potentially, or virtually.] ― -b2- As used by the grammarians, it means [A verb; i. e.] what denotes a meaning in itself together with any one of the three times [past and present and future: but it should be observed that it includes the maSodar, or infinitive noun; and also that there is what is termed fiEolN nAqiSN an incomplete, i. e. non-attributive, verb (as kaAna coordinate to SaAra, &c.); as well as what is termed fiEolN taAm~N a complete, i. e. attributive, verb]. (TA.)

faEolapN *
A single fiEol [i. e. deed or action], (Msb, TA,) with fet-h. (Msb.) Thus in the saying in the Kur [xxvi. 18], wafaEalota faEolataka A@A~atiY faEalota [lit. And thou hast done thy one deed that thou hast done]; as though the speaker said, fatalota Aln~afosa qatollataka: in which Esh-Shaabee read ↓ fiEolataka [thy kind of deed], with kesr, as meaning fatalota Alqitolapa Al~atiY qado EarafotahaA: so says Zj; but he adds that the former reading is better. (TA.) And [hence also] one says, kaAnato minohu faEolapN HasanapN or qabiyHapN [A good single deed proceeded from him or a bad one]. (S, O, TA.)
fiEolapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

faEilapN *
A custom, manner, habit, or wont. (K.)

[
fiEoliY~N *
Of, or relating to, a verb.]

[
fiEoliy~apN * The quality of a verb.]
faEaAlN * , like nazaAli, has sometimes occurred as meaning AifoEalo [Do thou]. (O, K. *)

faEaAlN * , (O, K,) accord. to Lth, (O,) is a name for A good doing, such as liberality, or bounty, (O,) and generosity, (O, K, [the only meaning assigned to it in the S,]) and the like of these: (O:) or, (O, K,) accord. to IAar, (O,) the doing of a single person, peculiarly, [as distinguished from fiEaAlN, q. v.,] (O,) relating to good and to evil; (O, K;) one says, fulaAnN kariymu AlfaEaAli [Such a one is generous in respect of doing or doings], and fulaAnN lay^iymu AlfaEaAli [Such a one is mean in respect of doing or doings]; (O: [and the like is said in the T and in the Msb;]) and Az says that this is the correct explanation: not that of Lth; and Mbr [likewise] says, it is used in commendation and in discommendation: (O:) and it is used only of a single agent. (O, K.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. (S, O, Msb. [See 1, first sentence.])

fiEaAlN * , as distinguished from faEaAlN, signifies A doing that is between two [agents]; (IAar, O, K, TA;) and therefore it is an inf. n. of ↓ faAEala [a verb of which I have not found any ex.]. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also a pl. of fiEolN. (S, O, Msb, K. -A2- Also The handle, (K,) or piece of wood that is inserted into the hole, (IAar, IB, O,) of the axe, or adz, or hoe: (IAar, IB, O, K:) pl. fuEulN. (K.)
fuEaAlapu * (with damm, O, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, faEAlapu,]) A metonymical appellation substituted for xuzaAEapu, (O, K, TA,) the well-known tribe [thus named]. (TA.)
faE~aAlN * [Wont to do]. (Kur xi. 109 and lxxxv. 16. [Thus in the phrase faE~aAlN limaA yuriydu Wont to do what He willeth: relating to God.])

faAEilN * [act. part. n. of 1, Doing: and, used as a subst., a doer: and hence] a carpenter is thus
called; accord. to IAar: but it is now peculiarly applied to such as works with clay, [and builds, and plasters,] and digs foundations: (TA:) and [the pl.] faEalapN, (Mgh, K, TA,) as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, is applied to workers in clay and digging and the like; (K, TA;) or such as work with their hands in clay or building or digging; like EamalapN [pl. of EaAmilN]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- wakun~aA faAEiliyna, in the Kur [xxi. 79], means And we were able to do what we willed. (O, TA.) And waA@l~a*iyna humo lilz~ak`wpi faAEiluwna, in the same [xxiii. 4], means And who give the *kwp [or poor-rate]: (Zj, O, TA:) or, as some say, who do that which is good, or righteous. (O, TA.)

mufotaEalN * A writing forged, or falsified. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And Poetry composed with originality, not in imitation of any model. (TA.) ― -b3- jaA='a biA@lomufotaEali, meaning It produced a grievous, or distressing, effect, (K, TA,) is a phrase mentioned by IAar, as used by Ed-Dubeyree when asked respecting a wound that he had received and that rendered him sleepless, and as used by him in respect of anything [unprecedented]: thus one says, Ea*~abaniY wajaEN A^asoharaniY fajaA='a biA@lomufotaEali i. e. [A malady that rendered me sleepless, tormented me,] and produced pain that had not been known before. (TA.)

1 faEuma * , aor.
faEuma , inf. n. faEaAmapN and fuEuwmapN, It was, or became, full; said of the saAEid [or fore arm]; (S, K;) and of a vessel. (K.) ― -b2- And faEumato, said of a woman, She was, or became, full-formed, and thick in her shank. (K.) -A2- See also 4, in three places.
2 faE~ama see what next follows.

4 AfEm * ; [like A^afoA^ama;] (S, K;) and so Afgm; (K in art. fgm;) as also ↓ fE~m; (thus in some of the copies of the K;) or ↓ faEama, (thus accord. to other copies of the K and accord. to the TA,) aor.
faEama , inf. n. faEomN; (TA;) He filled a vessel; (S, K, TA;) and exceeded the usual degree, or strove, or laboured, or did not fall short of what was requisite, in filling it. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^afoEamotu Albayota biriyHi AlEuwdi [I filled the house, or chamber, or tent, with the odour of aloes-wood]. (S.) It is said in a trad., lawo A^ano A@moraA^apF mina AlHuwri AlEiyna A^a$orafato laA^afoEamato maA abyona Als~amaA='i waAlA^aroDi riyHa Almisoki i. e. [If a woman (or Paradise) of those having eyes like the eyes of gazelles rose into view,] she would fill [the space between the heaven and the earth with the odour of musk]: thus related: and also laA^afogamato, and lafagamato: but Az says that the right relation is lAfEmt, with E. (TA in this art. and in art. fgm.) And one says, AfEm Almisoku Albayota The musk filled with its odour, (S,) or perfumed, (K,) [the house, or chamber, or tent.] ― -b3- And AfEm Alr~ajula He filled the man with anger; (S, TA;) mentioned by Az on the authority of Aboo-Turáb: (TA:) or he angered him: or he filled his nose with odour, (K, TA,) i. e. with sweet odour: (TA:) as also ↓ faEimahu and ↓ faEamahu, aor. of both
faEama , (K, TA,) inf. n. faEomN; but better known with the pointed g. (TA.) ― -b4- And AfEmhu and Afgmhu He filled him with joy, or happiness. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.)

12 AifoEawoEama *
It became full, and overflowed. (K.) ― -b2- And AfEwEm TiybFA It (a house, or chamber, or tent,) became filled with perfume. (TA.)

faEomN *
Full; applied in this sense to a saAEid [or fore arm]; (S, K;) and to a vessel; as also ↓ faEomalN, in which the l is augmentative: (K:) and full of flesh; applied to the place of the anklet. (TA.) It is said of the Prophet, in a trad., kaAna faEoma AlA^awoSaAl i. e. He was full in respect of the limbs. (TA.) And one says AimoraA^apN faEomapN A woman full-formed, and thick in her shank. (K.) And HaADirN faEomN A [great] tribe filled with its people. (TA.) [See also mufoEamN: and see A^afoEamu.] -A2- And A species of tree: or the rose. (K.)
faEomalN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^afoEamu *
Full [like faEomN]: or overflowing by reason of fulness. (TA.)

mufoEamN *
Filled; applied in this sense to a skin for water or milk; as also mufoA^amN: but as to ↓ mafoEuwmN, IAar asserts that he had not heard it except in a verse of Kutheiyir: Az, however, mentions it as signifying full [like faEomN], applied to a river, or rivulet: and Aboo-Sahl cites an ex. of it from the verses of the Fs as signifying full of flesh. (TA.) ― -b2- The phrase sayolN mufoEamN may be of the same category as ham~N naASibN [for ham~N *uw naSabK], the meaning being A torrent having the quality of filling; though the possessive epithet in most instances has the form of the act. part. n., such as TaAliqN [for *aAta TalaAqK] and muroDiEN [for *aAtu raDiyEK]: or it may be that mafoEamN in this case is expressive of muchness, or abundance, like the latter word in the phrase $iEorN $aAEirN and in mawotN maAy^itN. (Ham p. 106.)
mafoEuwmN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

div2.head: fEw or fEY
div2.entryFree:
1 faEaA $ayoy^FA *
i. q. ftth [so in my original, app., if not a mistranscription, fat~atahu i. e. He crumbled a thing much]; said of a man. (TA.)
2 fE~Y * , inf. n. tafoEiyapN, He branded a camel with a mark in the form of the viper (AlA^afoEaY). (TA.)

4 AfEY *
He (a man) became possessed of [or characterized by] evil after good or goodness. (TA.)

5 tfE~Y *
He (a man, S) became like the viper (AlA^afoEaY, S, K) in evil: (S, TA:) or, as in the A, he made himself to resemble the viper (ta$~abaha biAlA^afoEaY) in the evilness of his disposition. (TA.)

faAEK *
Angry and foaming [with anger]. (IAar, M, K.) ― -b2- And [the fem.] faAEiyapN A woman (TA) wont to calumniate; syn. nam~aAmapN. (K, TA: in the CK Alv~umAmapu is put for Aln~am~aAmapu.)
faAEiyapN * [as a subst.] The flower of the Hin~aA=' [i. e. Lawsonia inermis, or Egyptian privet]: (K:) [said to be] a dial. var. of faAgiyapN [q. v.]. (TA.)

A^afoEFY * , (S, Msb, K) of the fem. gender, but with tenween, (S, Msb,) because it is a subst., not an epithet; (Msb;) [said in the S and Msb to be like A^arowFY; but this is a mistake, for ArwY is without tenween;] or it is an epithet and a subst.; (K, TA;) but mostly a subst.; (TA;) [if used as an epithet, it is without tenween, written A^afoEaY, being also of the measure of a verb;] A certain serpent, (S, Msb, K,) of a malignant kind; [i. e. the viper;] also called ↓ A^ufoEuw~N, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AufoEuwAn, which see in what follows,]) occurring in a trad., in which it is said that there is no harm in the killing of the A^ufoEuw~ and the Huduw~ by the muHorim, the [final] alif being changed into w in both of these words in the dial. of El-Hijáz: (TA:) it is spotted, black and white; slender in the neck; broad in the head; it is said that it will not quit its place; (TA;) always coiling itself round; and neither antidote nor charm is of any avail against it: (Msb, TA:) sometimes it has two horns [i. e. it sometimes signifies the cerastes, or horned viper]: (TA:) ↓ A^ufofuwaAnN signifies the male: (S, Msb, TA:) [see also xi$aA$N:] the pl. is A^afaAEK. (S, Msb, K. * [In the K, the pl. is written A^afaAEiY, which, when indeterminate, is wrong.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] by way of comparison [to vipers], (TA,) AlA^afaAEiY signifies (tropical:) Certain veins (Euruwq) that branch off from the HaAlibaAni [q. v.]. (K.)
A^afoEA='N * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Sweet, or pleasant, odours. (IAar, M, K.)
A^ufoEuw~N * , and A^ufoEuwAnN: see A^afoEFY.

A^aroDN mafoEaApN *
A land in which are vipers (A^afaAEK): or, abounding therewith. (K.)
mufaE~FY * A camel branded with a mark in the form of the viper (AlA^afoEaY): (K:) and [the fem.] mufaE~aApN camels (A_ibilN) branded therewith. (TA.)
mufaE~aApN * [as a subst.] A brand in the form of the viper (AlA^afoEaY). (S, K.)

1 fagara * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
fagara (Msb, K) and
fagura , (AZ, K,) inf. n. fagorN (Msb, TA) and fuguwrN, (TA,) He opened his mouth; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Afgr. (Zj, Sgh, K.) ― -b2- [Also, both verbs, fagara and ↓ Afgr, He, or it, made, or caused, to open the mouth. And hence,] fagara Aln~ajomu, (T, TA,) or Aln~ajomu ↓ A^afogara, (S, O,) i. e., Al~uray~aA, (T, S, O,) The
asterism, meaning the Pleiades, became overhead: [lit., made one to open his mouth:] (T:) this is in the winter: (S, O:) for when the Pleiades are in the midst of the sky, he who looks at them opens his mouth: (T, S, O:) or the Pleiades began to rise [after sunset, so as to be overhead in the middle of the night], in the winter. (TA.) -A2- fagara also signifies It (the mouth) opened; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Anfgr: (K:) and the latter is said of a blossom, or flower, in the same sense. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And fagarati Als~in~u (assumed tropical:) The tooth showed its point; as though it broke forth to grow: but some say that its f is substituted for v, and Az inclines to think so [though vagara differs much in meaning from fagara]. (TA.)
4 A^afogara and 7: see 1; the former in three places.

huwa waAsiEu fagori Alfami *
He is wide in the opening of the mouth. (Lth, O, K.) ― -b2- And accord. to Lth, (O,) fagarN signifies also A rose when it opens: (O, K:) but it is thought by Az to be, in this sense, a mistake for fagowN, with w. (O.)

wulida biA@lofagorapi *
He was born at the commencement of the rising of the Pleiades [after sunset]; (O, K;) which is in the winter. (TA.) See 1.
fugorapN * The mouth of a valley: pl. fugarN. (O, K.)
TaEonapN fagaAri * , the latter word like qaTaAmi, [A spearwound, or the like,] that passes through. (O, K.)

faAgirN * , an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, (TA,) A [certain] duwayob~ap [i. e. small animal, or small creeping thing, or insect], (O, K, TA,) always opening its mouth: (O, TA:) and another, black and white in the A^anof [or snout], that stings men. (TA.)

faAgirapN *
A sort of perfume: (S, K, TA:) or (K, TA) the roots of the [lotus called] nayoluwfar [q. v.] (S, K, TA) of India: (S, TA:) or the kabaAbap [or cubeb] (K, TA) of China; because, when a man eats it, he opens his mouth. (TA.)
mafogarapN * A wide tract of land. (S, K.) ― -b2- And An opening, or a hollow, in a mountain, smaller than a kahof. (K.)
fagofuwriY~N * [China-ware, or porcelain,] the [sort of] xazaf that is brought from China; so called from fagofuwr, [the title of] the king of China: vulgarly farofuwriY. (TA in art. fr.)

1 fagamahu AlTiybu * , (S, K,) aor.
fagama , inf. n. fagomN and fuguwmN, (K,) The perfume stopped the air-passages of his nose. (S, K.) ― -b2- And fagamati Alr~aAy^iHapu Als~ud~apa The odour opened the obstruction of the nose: thus the verb has two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b3- See also a trad. cited in art. fEm, conj. 4. -A2- fagama said of a rose, or flower, (S, TA,) aor.
fagama , inf. n. fuguwmN, (TA,) It opened; as also ↓ tfg~m. (S, TA.) -A3- fagama, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. fagomN; (TA;) and ↓ fAgm, (S, * K, TA,) inf. n. figaAmN (S, TA) and mufaAgamapN; (S;) He kissed (S, K, TA) him, or it, (S,) or a woman. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And fagama said of a kid, (K, TA,) inf. n. fagomN, (TA,) He sucked (K, TA) the dug of his mother. (TA.) -A4- fagima bihi, (S, K,) aor.
fagama , (K,) inf. n. fagamN, (S,) He was, or became, attached to it, fond of it, or eagerly desirous of it. (S, K.) And fagamN Alkalobi signifies The dog's being attached, or accustomed, or habituated, to the chase. (TA.) ― -b2- And fagima biAlmakaAni, (K, TA,) inf. n. fagamN, (TA,) He resided, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place; and kept, or clave, to it; (K, TA;) not quitting it. (TA.)
3 faAogama see the preceding paragraph.

4 Afgm *
He filled a vessel: (K:) and so AfEm. (TA.) ― -b2- And It filled its place with its odour; (K;) as also AfEm [q. v.]. (TA.)
5 tafag~ama see 1.
7 Anfgm * , said of a zukaAm [or defluxion from the head], It was, or became, removed, cleared away, or dispelled; syn. Ainofaraja; (K;) as also ↓ Aftgm. (TA.)
8 A_ifotagama see what next precedes.

fagomN *
What one extracts from the interstices of his teeth, (K, TA,) of what has clung thereto. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kuluwA Alwagoma waA@ToraHuwA Alfagoma [Eat ye the wgm and throw ye away the fgm]; in which, accord. to IAth, by the fgm is meant what is expl. above; and by the wgm, what falls, portion after portion, of the food: but some, he adds, say that the converse is the case. (TA.)

fugomN * and ↓ fugumN The mouth, altogether: or the chin with the two lateral portions of its jaw; (K, TA; [i. e. bilaHoyayohi; for which the CK has bliHoyatihi;]) and so fuqomN: (TA:) or, accord. to Sh, fugomN signifies the nose: but accord. to Kr, it is ↓ fagomN that has this meaning. (TA.) A^axa*a bifugomihi, a phrase mentioned by AZ, is expl. as meaning He took hold of his chin together with the two lateral portions of its jaw: or, accord. to Sh, it means he took hold of his nose: (TA:) or it means (assumed tropical:) he distressed, afflicted, troubled, or molested, him. (K, TA.)
fagamN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

huwa fagimN bihi * (S, TA) and bihi ↓ mufogamN (K, TA) He is attached to it, fond of it, or eagerly desirous of it. (S, K, TA.) And kalobN fagimN EalaY AlS~ayodi [A dog attached, &c., or accustomed, or habituated, (see 1,) to the chase]: (S:) or kalobN fagimN [alone] a dog eagerly desirous of the chase. (TA.)
fugumN * : see fugomN.

fagomapu AlT~iybi *
The odour of perfume: (S, TA:) and so fagowatuhu. (TA.) And fagomapu riyHi Alxamori The fragrance of the odour of wine]. (Z, TA voce EaSofapN.)
mufoguwmN * : see fagimN.
mafoguwmN * A thing perfumed with aromatics. (TA.) -A2- And [A man] affected with a zukaAm [or defluxion from the head]. (TA.)

div2.head: fgw and fgY
div2.entryFree: 1 fagaA * , (K, TA,) inf. n. fagowN, (TA,) It (a thing) became revealed, disclosed, or divulged; syn. fa$aA. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And Its odour became perceptible, or perceived: occurring in a trad. in this sense, said of saffron: or, as some relate it, the verb in that instance is ↓ AfgY, which means it flowered, or blossomed. (TA.) ― -b3- And, said of seed-produce (zaroE), It dried, became dry, or dried up. (K.) -A2- fagiYa, aor. yafogaY, inf. n. fagFA, said of dates (tamor), i. q. H$f, [app. a mistranscription, unless there be such as Ha$ifa, which seems to be not improbable, as one says tamorN Ha$ifa, and Ha$afN also; but it can hardly be doubted that the meaning is, They became bad, such as are termed Ha$ifN or Ha$afN, or, which is nearly the same, such as are termed fagFA]: so says Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee. (TA.)

4 AfgY *
It (a plant, S, [app., accord. to the K, the plant Hin~aA=',]) put forth its faAgayp [i. e. flower, or blossom]. (S, K.) See also 1. ― -b2- Afgt Aln~axolapu The palm-tree became in a bad, or corrupt, state [with respect to its fruit, as is implied in the S: i. e. bore dates such as are termed gafFA]. (S, K.) ― -b3- And [hence, app.,] AfgY (said of a man, TA) He became poor after being rich: and He became ugly after being handsome: and He rebelled after being obedient: (K, TA:) all from IAar: as though his state became bad, or corrupt, like as do unripe dates. (TA.) ― -b4- And, said of a man, He kept constantly to the eating of fagFA, (K, TA.) i. e. unripe dates in an altered state. (TA.) -A2- And AfgY fulaAnFA He angered such a one. (K, TA.) One says, maAAl~a*iY A^afogaAka [What is it that angered thee? or, hath angered thee?]. (TA.)
fagowN * : see faAgiyapN.

fagFA * [or fagFY] i. q. gafFA [or gafFY] in its several meanings (K, TA) that have been mentioned [in art. gfw and gfY]: and among these it has that of The bad of anything. (TA.) And The [refuse termed] HuvaAlap [q. v.] of wheat. (TA.) And A dust that comes upon unripe dates, spoiling them, and rendering them [in the skin] like the wings of the [locusts, or the like, called] janaAdib [pl. of junodab]. (TA.) And Unripe dates [themselves] (S, TA) such as are bad and mugobar~ [i. e. of a hue like dust]; (S;) or such as are mutagay~ir [i. e. altered for the worse]. (TA.) ― -b2- And fagaA AlA_ibili The small, or young, of camels. (TA.) -A2- And accord. to the K, AlfagaA signifies AlElbp wAljfnpwamayalN fiy Alfami; but this is a mistake; correctly it signifies mayalN fiY Alfami waAlEulobapi waAljafonapi, meaning fiY AlEulobapi waAljafonapi [i. e. A distortion in the mouth, and in the kinds of bowl called Eulobap and jafonap], as expl.
by ISd: Kr says that it signifies a certain malady, which ISd thinks to be a distortion in the mouth, an explanation given by IAar. (TA.)

fagowapu AlT~iybi *
The odour of perfume; like fagomatuhu: (TA in art. fgm:) or the state of spreading of the odour of perfume. (TA in the present art.)

faAgiyapN * and ↓ fagowN The flower of the Hin~aA=' [i. e. Lawsonia inermis, or Egyptian privet]; (Fr, S, K;) as also faAEiyapN: (K in art. fEw or fEY:) or both signify the flower, or blossom, of anything [i. e. of any plant, or, app., of any fragrant plant: see Ham p. 713]: or, as is said in a trad., the fAgyp is the prince, or chief, of the sweet-smelling plants of Paradise: Sh says that ↓ Alfagowu signifies nawor wraAy^iHap Tay~ibap [a flower, or blossom; and a sweet odour: but I think that we should read naworN *uw raAy^iHapK Tay~ibapK a sort of flower, or blossom, having a sweet odour]: and IAar says that the fAgyp is the best and the most fragrant of sweetsmelling plants: (TA:) or it is the flower produced by a branch of the Hin~aA=' that has been planted inverted, and which is sweeter than [that of] the [common] Hin~aA='. (K.)

1 faqA^a AlEayona * , (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faqaAa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. faqo'N, (S, Mgh, O,) He put out the eye; or blinded it; or made it to sink in its socket; syn. baxaqahaA; (Lh, S, O, K;) as also ↓ fq~A^hA, (S, O, K,) inf. n. tafoqiy^apN: (S, O:) or, accord. to the Msb, baxaSahaA; which is said by Es-Sarakustee to mean he put his finger into the eye and pulled it out; and by IKtt to mean he extinguished its light; and by some to mean he slit it, or rent it: (TA:) or he slit, or rent, the portion of the eye that is surrounded by the white thereof: (Mgh:) or i. q. qalahaA; (K, TA;) i. e. [he pulled out the eye; or], as some say, he pulled out the portion of the eye which is surrounded by the white, and with which one sees: (TA: [and the like is said in the Mgh in explanation of AlqaloEu, but this is there said to differ from Alfaqo'u:]) or, as some say, he put his finger into the eye and so slit, or rent, it: (TA:) or he broke, or ruptured, the eye; syn. kasarahaA; and so Albavorapa [the pimple, or the small, or purulent, pustule]; and the like of these: (K: [and to all of these the two other explanations mentioned above as from the K are likewise there, improperly, made to relate:]) this last explanation, in the K, is said by MF to be unknown; but it is mentioned in the A and L, and by more than one of the leading lexicologists: (TA:) [accord. to Mtr,] faqaA^otu Albavorapa means I slit the pimple, &c., or rent it [open]. (Mgh, Msb.) Among the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance, when a man's camels amounted to a thousand, he put out (faqaA^a) an eye of one of them (a baEiyr), and set it free to pasture where it would, and made no use of it. (TA.) ― -b2- faqaA^a A@ll~`hu Eanoka Eayona AlkamaAli is a tropical saying [app. meaning May God prevent from seeing thee the fatal eye: the term Eyn AlkmAl being applied to an eye believed to have the power of killing by its glance]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And faqaA^a naAZirayohi, (O, K,) likewise said to be a tropical phrase, (TA,) means (tropical:) He dispelled his anger. (O, K.) ― -b4- And faqaA^Eayonahu also means [sometimes] (tropical:) He struck him; or struck him vehemently with a broad thing, or with anything; or slapped him with his hand: or he was rough, rude, or ungentle, to him in speech. (TA in art. Eyn.) ― -b5- And faqaA^ati AlbuhomaY, inf. n. fuquwo'N, (O, K, TA,) or, accord. to the L, faqo'N, (TA,) The [barleygrass termed] bhmY was rendered dusty by rain, or by a torrent, so that the cattle would not eat it until it became clean: (O, K, TA:) and in like manner one says of any plant. (O, TA.) [See also 1 in art. fqA^.] ― -b6- And, as some say, (TA,) or ↓ tfq~A^t, (S, O, TA,) (tropical:) The envelopes [or glumes] of the buhomaY burst open so as to disclose (S, O, TA) its fruit [or seeds], (S, O,) or its flower. (TA.)

2 faq~aAa see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- laA yufaq~iy^u AlbayoDa, (IJ, TA,) or AlbayoDa ↓ laA yatafaq~aA^u, (A, TA,) (assumed tropical:) [He will not break, or burst, eggs, or the eggs,] is said of a weak and quiet man, (IJ, TA,) or of an impotent man. (A, TA.)

4 AfqA^ *
His breast, or chest, became depressed (Ainoxasafa), in consequence of a malady, or an accident; (IAar, O, TA;) said of a man. (IAar, O.) [But see faqaA^N and A^afoqaA^u.]

5 tafaq~aAa see 7, in two places. ― -b2- It is also said of the corpse that has lain long upon the field of battle, meaning It rent, or burst. (Mgh.) And one says, tafaq~aA^otu $aHomFA (assumed tropical:) [I almost burst with fat]: (S:) [and] tafaq~aA^ati Al$~aApu $aHomFA [the sheep, or goat, almost burst with fat]: (O:) $HmA being in the accus. case as a specificative. (S, O.) And A^akala Hat~aY kaAdabaTonuhu yatafaq~aA^u (assumed tropical:) He ate until his belly almost burst. (A, TA.) And ↓ A^akala Hat~aY kaAda yanofaqiy^u (assumed tropical:) [He ate until he almost burst]. (O: in the TA with bakaY [he wept] in the place of Akl, and with baTonuhu after ynfqy^.) ― -b3- And tafaq~aA^ati Als~aHaAbapu Eano maAy^ihaA (tropical:) The cloud burst with its water. (S, * O, * TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, last sentence. -A2- And see 2.

7 AnfiqA^t AlEayonu * and ↓ tfq~A^t, quasi-pass. vs., [the former] of faqaA^a AlEayona and [the latter] of faq~aA^ahaA as expl. in the first sentence of this art.; (K, TA;) [thus signifying The eye became put out; or blinded; or made to sink in its socket: &c.: or it broke; or became broken, or ruptured:] and so Albavorapu [the pimple, or the small, or purulent, pustule]: and the like of these: (K, TA:) the former, (Mgh,) or each, (Msb,) said of a bavorap, means it [broke, or] rent, or burst: (Mgh, Msb:) and thus ↓ tfq~A^ said of [a pustule such as is termed] a dum~al, (S, Mgh, O,) and of [such as is termed] a qaroH. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also 5.

8 AftqA^ Alxaroza * is expl. in the K as meaning A^aEaAda Ealayohi wajaEala bayona Alkulobatayoni kulobapF A^uxoraY; [and in like manner in the O, except that the latte has Alkuloyatayoni and kuloyapF; and so have several copies of the K;] but this meaning is assigned by Lh to AqtfA^, which see for a fuller explanation. (TA.)

faqo'N * (S, O, K) and (O, K) accord. to Ks and Fr (O) ↓ fuqoA^apN [in the CK fuqaA^p] and ↓ faqaA^apN (O, K) and in some copies of the K ↓ fuq~aA='ap (TA) and ↓ faAqiyaA='u, (K,) originally faAqiy^aA='u, (TA,) The [membrane called] saAbiyaA=' (S, O, K) which comes forth EalaY raA^osi Alwaladi [upon the head of the young one, meaning at the time of bringing forth,] (S, O,) or which rends open from off the head of the young one [at the time of bringing forth]: (K:) pl. [of the first] fuquw'N: (TA:) or a small, thin, piece of skin, which is upon the nose of the young one, and which, if not removed from it, (O, K,) at the birth, (O,) causes its death, (O, K,) is thus termed, (K,) or is termed ↓ fuqoA^apN, by IAar: (O:) or, accord. to As, the water [or fluid] that is EalaY raA^osi Alwaladi [app. meaning that is discharged at the time of the birth (see 2 in the arts. rbq and rmd)]: and accord. to IAar, the water [or fluid] that is in the ma$iymap [or membrane enclosing the fœtus in the womb] is termed faqo'N and suxodN and suxotN and nuxoTN: (TA:) it is also said that faqowN signifies a certain white thing that comes forth from the woman or the she-camel in parturition, and which is an envelope wherein is much water or fluid; mentioned by A 'Obeyd as with hemz [i. e. written faqo'N], and said by him to be the saAbiyaA=' [q. v.]. (TA in art. fqw.) ― -b2- And faqo'N signifies also A small hollow, or cavity, in stone, or a rugged place, that collects water: (K:) or it is [a hollow, or cavity,] like a xuforap or juforap, in the midst of a [stony place such as is termed] Har~p, (Sh, O, TA,) or in the midst of a mountain: (TA:) and ↓ faqiYo'N signifies the same: (K:) the pl. (of the former, O, or of the latter, TA) is fuqoA=nN. (O. TA.)

faqaA^N *
A protuberance, or swelling out, (O, TA,) of the back, (O,) or of the breast, or chest. (TA.) [But see 4, and see also A^afoqaA^u.]

fuqoA^apN * : see faqo'N, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A cloud in which is neither thunder nor lightning, and the rain of which is mutaqaArib [app. meaning drawing near: as though likened to the membrane thus called]. (O, * TA. [In the former written, in this instance, faqoA^apN, which I think to be a mistranscription by the copyist.])
faqaA^apN * : see faqo'N.
faqoA^aY * : see the next paragraph.
