faqiYo'N * A he-camel affected with a disease termed Haqowap [q. v.], in consequence of which he voids not his urine nor his dung; (O, K; *) and sometimes, or often, his veins and his flesh become choked with blood, and swollen; and if slaughtered and cooked, the cooking-pot becomes full of blood; and sometimes, or often, his stomach becomes so much inflated, or swollen, that it rends, or bursts: and it is likewise applied to a she-camel: (O:) and ↓ faqoA^aY signifies the same applied to a she-camel. (K.) ― -b2- Also (i. e. faqiYo'N) The disease above-
mentioned, itself. (O, K.) -A2- See also faqo'N, latter sentence.
fuq~aA='apN * : see faqo'N.
faAqiyA='u * : see faqo'N.

A^afoqaA^u *
Having a protuberant breast, or chest. (IAar, TA in art. fsA^.) [But see 4, and see also faqaA^N.]
mufaq~y^apN * Valleys, or water-courses, or torrent-beds, (A^awodiyapN,) that cleave the earth. (O, K.)

1 faqaHa * : see 2. ― -b2- Said of a plant, It became tall, or full-grown, and blossomed. (K.) -A2- faqaHa fulaAnFA He, or it, hit, or struck, such a one in his faqoHap [q. v.]. (K.) -A3- And faqaHa Al$~aYo'a, (K,) aor.
faqaHa , inf. n. faqoHN, (TA,) i. q. saf~ahu [i. e. He took the thing into his mouth, not moistened,] like as one does medicine: (K, TA:) of the dial. of ElYemen. (TA.)

2 fq~H * , (S, K,) inf. n. tafoqiyHN, (S,) He (a whelp) opened his eyes for the first time; (S, K;) as also ↓ faqaHa, aor.
faqaHa , (K,) inf. n. faqoHN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., faq~aHonaA waSaA^oSaA^otumo (S, TA) (tropical:) We have opened our eyes for the first time, and ye have kept your eyes closed; (TA;) meaning the truth has become manifest to us, and ye have been blind to it; (AO, A, * TA;) or we have seen our right course, and ye have not seen [yours]. (IB, TA.) And fq~H Al$~ajaru The trees burst their buds, and made the extremities of their leaves to appear. (L.)

5 tfq~H *
It opened; syn. tafat~aHa: (K:) it is said in this sense of a rose, (S, A, TA,) and of any flower, or blossom: (TA:) some say that it signifies tft~H absolutely: others, peculiarly fY AlklAm. (Az, as quoted in the L. [See tafat~aHa fiY AlkalaAmi (a well-known phrase) in art. ftH: but fY klAm in the present case appears, from what precedes, to be evidently a mistranscription for fiY AlkimaAmi, i. e., in relation to calyxes.])

6 tfAqHwA *
They put [or turned] their backs one towards another; (S, K;) [from faqoHapN, q. v.;] like as you say taZaAharuwA [and tadaAbaruwA] and [in the contr. sense] taqaAbaluwA. (S, TA.)

faqoHapN * : see fuq~aAHN. ― -b2- Also The anus: (S, K:) because it opens in the case of need: (Ham p. 677:) or a wide, or an ample, anus: (K, MF:) or a wide dubur: or a dubur with what it comprises: and afterwards, by reason of frequency of usage, applied to signify any dubur: (L:) pl. fiqaAHN. (S, K.) ― -b3- And The palm of the hand; as also ↓ faqaAHapN: (K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen: so called because of its width. (TA.) ― -b4- And The napkin (minodiyl) of AlA_iHoraAm [i. e., which is used by one performing the rites of the Haj~ or of the Eumorap]: (K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)
faqaAHapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

fuq~aAHN *
A certain herb, (K, TA,) resembling the A^uqoHuwaAn [or chamomile] in its growth and its place of growth; n. un. with p: it is one of the plants growing in the sands; and it is said that its flower is more contracted than that of the chamomile, and that the dust, or earth, sticks to it as it does to the [herb called] HamaSiyS: (TA:) or the flower of the A_i*oxir [or juncus odoratus]; (S, K, TA;) said by Az to be a sort of perfume, sometimes put into medicine, called fuq~aAHu AlA_i*oxiri; and it is the flower of the A_i*oxir when its calyx opens: (TA:) or the flower, or blossom, of any plant, (K, TA,) when it opens, whatever be its lawon [i. e. colour, or kind]; (TA;) as also ↓ faqoHapN, (K, TA,) thus with fet-h and sukoon. (TA. [Written by Golius fuqoHapN.]) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A woman of goodly, or beautiful, make, or form. (Kr, K, TA.)

EalaY fulaAnK Hul~apN fuq~aAHiy~apN *
Upon such a one is a Hul~apN [q. v.] of the colour of the rose when it is about to open. (S.)
huwa mutafaq~iHN lil$~ar~i * (assumed tropical:) He is in a state of preparation for evil, or mischief.

1 faqadahu * , (S, A, MA, Mgh, O, L, Msb, K,) aor.
faqida , (S, A, O, &c.,) inf. n. faqodN and fiqodaAnN (S, MA, O, L, Msb, K) and fuqodaAnN (S, O, F) and fuquwdN; (IDrd, O, L, K;) and ↓ Aftqdhu; (S, A, MA, Mgh, O;) He found it not, (L, TA,) lost it, (MA, PS, &c.,) saw it not, (JK in explanation of the latter verb,) [missed, or failed of finding or seeing, it,] it was, or became, absent from him, (Mgh,) or he had it not, was destitute of it, was without it, lacked it, or wanted it, syn. Eadimahu; (Msb, L, K;) but accord. to Er-Rághib, Alfaqodu has a more special signification than AlEadamu, this latter being the contr. of Alwujuwdu; (TA;) [whereas] Alfaqodu [as inf. n. of fuqida, though often used as meaning the being non-existent, properly] signifies the thing's being absent from the range of perception by sense so that its place is not known. (Bd in xii. 71.) [fuqida signifies It was not found, was lost, was not seen, &c.] It is related of Abu-dDardà that he said, yafoqido ↓ mano yatafaq~ado, [lit. He who seeks will not find,] meaning he who seeks after good in mankind will not find it; for he saw good to be rare in mankind: or he who seeks to acquaint himself with the circumstances of men will not find what will please him. (L.)

4 A^afoqadahu A@ll~`hu A_iy~aAhu *
God caused him to lose, or fail of finding, him, or it. (L, K.) One says, A^afoqadaka A@ll~`hu kul~a jamiymK [May God cause thee to lose every relation, or loved and loving relation]. (A.) [Or] AlA_ifoqaAdu is not of established authority: as to the saying Aljunuwnu yufoqidu $ahowapa AljimaAEi [meaning Insanity causes to lose, or annuls, the desire of coïtus], the correct word is yuEodimu or yuziylu. (Mgh.)

5 tfq~dhu *
He sought it, or sought for it or after it; or did so leisurely or repeatedly; (A, * Mgh, L;) as also ↓ Aftqdhu: (Mgh, L:) or he sought it, or sought for it or after it, it being absent from him; (S, O, L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Aftqdhu: (K:) or he sought, or sought leisurely or repeatedly, to obtain knowledge of it, having lost it: so accord. to Er-Rághib and many others; but this expression and tEah~adahu are used, by some, each in the place of the other, and the latter, accord. to Er-Rághib and many others, [properly] signifies he sought, or sought leisurely or repeatedly, to obtain knowledge of it, having known it before. (MF.) You say, ↓ maA tafaq~adotuhu muno*u A@fotaqadotuhu, meaning mn* faqadotuhu [i. e. I have not sought for, or after, him, or it, since I lost him, or it. (B, TA.) See also 1, last sentence. ― -b2- [Also He investigated it.]
6 tfAqdwA * means faqada baEoDuhumo baEoDFA [i. e. They lost one another]. (S, O, K.)
8 A_ifotaqada see 1: ― -b2- and see also 5, in three places.

Alfaqodu * , (O, K,) by Az, (K,) or in a number of the copies of the work of Az, (O,) erroneously written Alfaqadu, (O, K,) A certain plant, (K,) resembling the [species of cuscuta, or dodder, called] ka$uwv: (TA:) and a beverage prepared from raisins or honey or [the plant] k$wv, as also ↓ Alfuqodudu: (K:) or, as AHn says, a certain plant which is thrown into the beverage of honey, which beverage consequently becomes strong, and is then called Alfaqodu: he says, the faqod is what is called in Pers. fanojanoku$ot: IAar says, ↓ Alfiqodapu [or Alfaqodapuk$wv ? then. un.] is the k$wv: and a beverage prepared from raisins and honey; and it is said that a beverage (nabiy*) is made of honey, and then the faqod is thrown into it, and causes it to become strong: so says Lth: and he says that the faqod is a plant resembling the k$wv: and ↓ Alfuqodudu is the nabiy* of the k$wv. (O.)
Alfiaqodapu * : see the next preceding paragraph.
Alfuqodudu * : see Alfaqodu, in two places.

faqiydN * and ↓ mafoquwdN signify the same, (O, Msb, K,) [Not found, lost, not seen, missed, non-existent,] absent from one, (Mgh in explanation of the latter,) not had, lacking or lacked, wanting or wanted. (Msb, K.) One says, maAta gayora faqiydK walaA HamiydK, (A, K,) and walaA maHomuwdK ↓ gayora mafoquwdK, (A,) [He died unmissed and unpraised; or,] without his loss being cared for [and without being praised]. (A, K.)

faAqidN * [as act. part. n. of 1 signifies Not finding a thing, losing it, not seeing it, missing it, not having it, being destitute of it, lacking it, or wanting it; or having failed to find it, having lost it, or having failed to see it. ― -b2- And hence,] A woman who is bereft of her child [by death]: (A 'Obeyd:) or who loses (tafoqidu) her husband or child: (S, O:) or whose husband, or child, (L, K, TA,) or relation, or loved and loving relation, (TA,) has died: (L, K, TA:) or who marries after the death of her husband. (Lth, L, K.) The Arabs say, laA tatazaw~ajan~a faAqidFA watazaw~ajo muTal~aqapF [Do
not thou marry a woman whose husband has died, but [rather] marry thou a divorced woman]. (Lh, L.) ― -b3- And in like manner, (O,) it is applied also to a she-gazelle, (S, O, L,) and to a cow [app. a wild cow], (O, L, K,) as also faAqidapN, (O,) meaning Whose young one has been devoured by a beast, or bird, of prey; (O, L, K;) and to a pigeon (HamaAmap) likewise. (L.)
mafoquwdN * : see faqiydN, in two places.

1 faqara * , (TA,) [aor., app.,
faqura and
faqira ,] inf. n. faqorN, (O, K, TA,) He dug the ground; (O, * K, * TA;) as also ↓ fq~r, (TA,) inf. n. tafoqiyrN. (K, TA.) And He dug a well to draw forth the water. (TA.) ― -b2- And faqorN signifies The boring, or perforating, of beads for the purpose of stringing; (K;) [as also tafoqiyrN; for one says] ↓ faq~arotu [as well as faqarotu], meaning I bored, or perforated, beads. (S.) ― -b3- And The act of cleaving, slitting, or rending. (O.) [See also 8.] ― -b4- And faqara A^anofa AlbaEiyri, (S, O, K, *) [and faqara AlbaEiyra also, as is indicated in the TA,] aor.
faqura and
faqira , inf. n. faqorN, (K,) He made an incision in the nose [or muzzle] of the camel, (S, O, K, TA,) the beast being refractory, (TA,) with an iron instrument, (S, O, TA,) so as to reach to the bone, (K, TA,) or nearly so, (TA,) then put upon the place of the incision the [cord called] jariyr, (S, O, TA, *) with a [string such as is termed] watar wound upon it, (S, O,) to render him tractable, or to train him, thereby: (S, O, K, TA:) sometimes the refractory camel has three incisions made in his muzzle; and when his owner desires to render him tractable, and to prevent him from being brisk above measure, he puts the jryr upon the incision that is next to his lip, and in consequence he governs him as he will; and if he be between the refractory and the tractable, he puts the jryr upon the intermediate incision, and in consequence he exceeds in his pace; and if he desire that he should stretch forth and go without inconvenience to his owner, he puts the jryr upon the uppermost incision. (Aboo-Ziyád, L.) [The incision above mentioned is termed ↓ fuqorapN. ― -b5- Hence, app., by a tropical usage, faqara signifies (assumed tropical:) He stigmatized a man: Freytag has mentioned it as occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, and meaning “ satyra perstrinxit eius vitia commemorans aliquem. ”] -A2- [faqarahu, aor.
faqura , inf. n. faqorN, He, or it, broke the faqaAr (or vertebræ) of his back. ― -b2- Hence the phrase,] faqaratohu AlfaAfqirapu, (S, O,) or Ald~aAhiyapu, aor.
faqura , inf. n. faqorN, (Msb,) [lit.] The calamity broke the vertebræ of his back: (S, O:) [meaning] the calamity befell him. (Msb.) -A3- faqura, with damm, [aor.
faqura ,] He had a complaint of his vertebræ: and faqira, aor.
faqara , inf. n. faqarN, He had a complaint of his vertebræ arising from fracture or disease. (Msb.) ― -b2- faqura or faqira in the sense of Aifotaqara: see 8.

2 faq~ara see 1, first and third sentences. ― -b2- fq~r lilowadiy~api, (S, TA, *) or lilofasiylapi, (K, TA,) inf. n. tafoqiyrN; [and accord. to Golius, ↓ tfq~r, but for this I have not found any authority;] He dug a hollow such as is termed faqiyr [q. v.] for the shoot, or offset, of a palm-tree. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- And fuq~ira, said of anything, It was incised, or notched; and impressed, or marked. (TA.) ― -b4- Lth has erroneously assigned to tafoqiyrN, a meaning belonging to taqofiyzN, q. v. (TA.)

4 Afqr *
He (a colt) became fit for riding upon his faqaAr [or vertebræ]; like A^arokaba: (O:) or he (a colt, Msb), or it (the back of a colt, L), became [strong in the vertebræ and] fit for being ridden. (L, Msb.) -A2- Afqrhu naAqatahu, (S, O,) or baEiyrahu, (ISk, K,) or Zahora baEiyrihi, (TA,) or baEiyrFA, (Mgh,) or daAb~atahu, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) or Almuhora, (Msb,) He lent him the vertebræ [meaning the back] of his she-camel, that he might ride thereon: (S, O:) and he lent him the back of his camel (ISk, K, TA) during a journey, (ISk, TA) for carrying a burden, and for riding, (ISk, K, TA,) to be returned afterwards: (ISk, TA:) and he lent him a camel, that he might ride thereon; from faqaAr signifying the “ vertebræ ” of the back: (Mgh:) and he lent him his beast to ride as long as he pleased during a journey and then to return it to him: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) and he lent him the colt to ride upon its vertebræ [or back]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, Afqrhu A^aroDahu (tropical:) He lent him his land for sowing. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- A^afoqaraka AlS~ayodu means The object of the chase has enabled thee to have its vertebræ within thy power; therefore shoot it, or shoot at it: (O, TA:) or has enabled thee to have its side [which is sometimes termed fuqor] within thy power: (K:) or has become near to thee. (TA.) [The Khaleefeh] El-Weleed the son of Yezeed the son of 'AbdEl-Melik is related to have said, A^afoqara baEoda masolamapa AlS~ayodu limano ramaY i. e. The object of the chase has enabled the shooter at it to have its vertebræ within his power after Meslemeh; meaning that, since the death of his paternal uncle Meslemeh, the territory of the Muslims had become assailable to him who might attempt it. (TA.) -A3- Afqrhu also signifies He (i. e. God, S, O, K, or a man, Msb) rendered him faqiyr [meaning poor, or needy, &c.]. (S, O, Msb, K.) -A4- maA A^afoqarahu [i. e. How poor, or needy, &c., is he!] and maA A^agonaAhu [which has the contr. meaning] are [said to be] anomalous; for their [respective primitive] verbs are Aifotaqara and AisotagonaY, from either of which the verb of wonder is not properly [or regularly] formed. (S, O. [But see 8.])

5 Zahara qabolanaA naAsN yatafaq~aruwna AlEiloma * , occurring in a trad., as some relate it, means [There appeared before us men] eliciting what was recondite, or obscure, of knowledge, and opening what was closed thereof; from faqarotu Albiy^ora meaning “ I dug the well to draw forth the water: ” but the reading commonly known is [yataqaf~aruwna, q. v.,] with the q before the f. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- See also 2.

6 tfAqr *
He feigned the lowliness, or submissiveness, of poverty, humbling, or abasing, himself with men. (K * and TA in art. bA^s.)

8 Aftqr *
He clave, slit, or rent; and opened: [see also 1, fourth sentence:] hence its usage in a trad. of 'Omar, in which, after his saying that Imra-el-Keys was the foremost of the poets, and had made the source of poetry to well forth abundantly to them, [see xasafa,] he is related to have added, waA@fotaqara Eano maEAnK EuwrKA^aSaH~a baSarK: in saying this, he attributed a sound and an opened sight to the poetry, [which he thus personified,] and in like manner he described obscure and occult meanings by applying to them the epithet Euwr [generally meaning “ blind of one eye ”]: he meant that Imra-el-Keys had made the meanings of poetry clear and perspicuous, and unveiled them, and shunned substitution and obscure diction: Eano with what is [to be understood as] antecedently connected with it occupies the place of a noun in the accus. case as a denotative of state: it is as though he said, fataHa lil$~iEoriA^aSaH~a baSarK mujaAwizFA lilomaEaAniY AlEuwrimutaxaTiyFA lahaA [lit. He opened, to poetry, a most sound vision, passing over half-blind meanings]. (O.) -A2- Also, (O,) He was, or became, faqiyr [meaning poor, or needy, &c.]; (S, O, Msb, K, &c.;) and so ↓ faqira, aor.
faqara , inf. n. faqarN; (Msb;) and ↓ faqura, aor.
faqura ; (K;) or they said Aftqr, (Sb, Msb, TA,) like as they said Ai$otad~a, (Sb, TA,) but they did not say faqura, (Sb, Msb, TA,) like as they did not say $aduda, (Sb, TA,) Aftqr serving them instead of faqura; (Msb;) nor did they use any unaugmented form of this verb. (Sb, TA.) ― -b2- And one says, Aftqr A_ilayohi He, or it, wanted, needed, or required, him, or it; [a phrase of frequent occurrence; like faqiyrN A_ilayohi;] i. q. AiHotaAja Alyh. (TA in art. Hwj.)
10 Astfqr baEiyrFA * [He borrowed, or asked for the loan of, the back of a camel, for carrying a burden or for riding]. (See A^aromalu.)

faqorN * and ↓ fuqorN signify the same, (S, O, Msb, K,) but the latter is bad, (Lth, TA,) and sometimes they said ↓ fuqurN, (MF, TA,) Poverty, want, or need; contr. of ginFY: (K:) or the state of a man when he has [only] what suffices for his household, or those who dwell with him and whose maintenance is incumbent on him: (ISd, K:) [other meanings are indicated by explanations of the epithet faqiyrN, q. v.:] ↓ mafAaqiru [signifying needs, or wants,] is said by some to be a pl. of faqrN, anomalous, like ma$aAbihu [pl. of $abahN] and malaAmiHu [pl. of lamoHapN]: or it may be a pl. of ↓ mufoqarN, an inf. n. of A^afoqarahu; or pl. of ↓ mufoqirN; or it has no sing.: (TA:) you say, ↓ sad~a A@ll~`hu mafaAqirahu God rendered him, or may God render him, free from want; (S, Msb, K;) [lit.] God supplied, or may God supply, his various needs, or wants. (S, K.) ― -b2- And faqorN signifies also Anxiety; or disquietude, or trouble, of mind: pl. fuquwrN: (O, K, TA:) one says, $akaY A_ilayohi fuquwrahu He complained to him of his anxieties; &c.:
and it means also, his circumstances, and wants: (TA:) [for,] accord. to IAar, the phrase fuquwru Aln~afosi is like $uquwruhaA. (O.) -A2- See also faqorapN.
fuqorN * : see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- Also The side: pl. fuqarN, (K, TA,) which is extr. [in respect of analogy]: mentioned by Kr. (TA.) [See A^afoqaraka AlS~ayodu.]
faqurN * : see faqorapN.
faqirN * : see faqiyrN, former half, in two places.
fuqurN * : see faqorN.

faqorapN * : see faqaArN. -A2- Accord. to the K, it signifies also A certain plant; and its pl. [or rather the coll. gen. n.] is ↓ faqorN: but the sing. [or n. un.] is correctly ↓ faqurapN, with fet-h and then damm, mentioned by Sb as a word of a rare form, of which the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is ↓ faqurN, as it has no broken pl.; and expl. by Th. (TA.)

fuqorapN *
A hollow dug in the ground: pl. fuqarN. (O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And The [incision termed] quromap (IAar, O, TA) that is made in the nose [or muzzle] (IAar, O) of the camel, (IAar, O, TA,) [in order to render him tractable, (see 1, near the beginning,)] after which [if necessary] another is made, [above it,] and then another, until he becomes gentle: (IAar, O:) pl. [of pauc. A^afoqurN, occurring in the L, evidently as a pl. of fuqorapN in this sense, and, of mult., but also used as a pl. of pauc.,] fuqarN. (O, TA.) Hence the saying of 'Aacute;ïsheh, in relation to [the murder of] 'Othmán, [app. alluding to its involving three violations, namely, the violation of the sacredness of the city in which it was perpetrated and of the month in which it occurred and of the person of the Khaleefeh,] balagotumo minohu Alfuqara Alv~alaAva, meaning (tropical:) Ye have done to him the like of your deed to the camel above mentioned [upon which ye have inflicted the three fuqar]: thus expl. by AZ. (TA.) Accord. to AHeyth, fuqarN means (assumed tropical:) Great, or grievous, or formidable, events. (O.) And the three fuqaraAt of the son of Adam are said to be (assumed tropical:) The day of birth and the day of death and the day of resurrection. (O.) ― -b3- Also The part, of a shirt, that is the place into which the head is inserted. (K.) -A2- Also Nearness. (K.) And one says, huwa min~iY fuqorapF, meaning He is near to me. (K, * TA.) -A3- See also mufoqirN.

fiqorapN * : see faqaArN. ― -b2- [Hence] AlfiqaraAtu is a name of (assumed tropical:) The star [or stars] in the xarazaAt [meaning joints of the tail] of Scorpio. (Kzw in his descr. of Scorpio.) And fiqarN signifies (assumed tropical:) Certain ornaments, moulded, or fashioned, in the form of the vertebra of the back: (A, KT, TA, and Har p. 34:) one of which is termed fiqorapN. (Har ibid.) ― -b3- And hence, (KT,) or as being likened to a vertebra of the back, (S, O, KT,) (tropical:) The best verse in an ode is termed fiqorapN. (S, O, K, KT.) ― -b4- And hence, as being likened to the best verse in an ode, fiqorahN means (tropical:) (tropical:) Any choice phrase or sentence: (KT:) one says, maA A^aHosana fiqara kalaAmihi i. e. [How beautiful are] the points, or points of wit, (sukat [pl. of nukotapN]) of his speech, or language! (A, TA.) ― -b5- And in like manner it is applied to signify (assumed tropical:) The end [or final word] of every verse of an ode and [of every clause] of a xuTobap [which is in rhyming prose]. (Msb.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) [A pair of clauses of rhyming prose, both ending with the same rhyme; i. e.] the fiqorap is that which in [rhyming] prose is like the verse in poetry. (Kull p. 208.) -A2- Also A piece of land, such as is termed qaraAH [q. v.], for sowing. (O, K.) -A3- And A thing that serves as a mark, or sign, (Lth, K, TA,) to men contending, or competing, in shooting, or casting, (Lth,) such as a mountain, (K,) or such as a hill, or a hollow dug in the ground, (Lth.) or a hadaf [or butt, &c.], (Lth, K, TA,) and the like: (K, TA:) they say, in such contending or competing, A^uraAmiyka mino A^adonaY fiqorapK [I will contend, or compete, with thee in shooting, or casting, from the nearest fqrp] and mino A^aboEadi fiqorapK [from the furthest fqrp]. (Lth, TA.)
faqurapN * : see faqorapN.
fuqoraY * [The lending one a camel, &c., to be ridden or to carry a burden;] a subst. [similar to ruqobaY and EumoraY] from A^afoqarahu naAqatahu (S) or baEiyrahu. (K.)

faqaArN * The vertebra of the back; (S, * Msb, K;) the bones of the spine, which are set in regular order, one upon another, from the part where is the kaAhil to the Eajob: (K, * TA:) [it is sometimes used as a sing., as in the S and O and K voce TabaqN: but properly] the sing., (Msb, K,) or n. un., (S, TA,) is ↓ faqaArapN, (S, Msb, K,) for which one should not say fiqaArapN, with kesr: (ISk, Msb:) and ↓ fiqorapN, of which the pl. is fiqarN and fiqoraAtN and fiqaraAtN and fiqiraAtN, signifies the same as faqaArapN; (S, Msb, K:) as does also ↓ faqorapN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] faqaAru AljawozaA='i (assumed tropical:) The three very bright stars [d and e and z] disposed obliquely in the midst of the constellation AljwzA=' [i. e. Orion]. (Har p. 456. [See art. jwz.) ― -b3- And [hence also,] *uw AlfaqaAri (assumed tropical:) the name of A [celebrated] sword of the Prophet, (S, O, K,) and afterwards, of 'Alee: it had previously belonged to El-'As Ibn-Munebbih, who was slain at Bedr, (O, K,) by 'Alee, by whom his sword was given to the Apostle: (O:) accord. to Abu-l-'Abbás [i. e. Th]. it was thus named because there were in it small beautiful hollows [app. meaning small scallops in the edge, such as some modern swords have, for the more easy cleaving of coats of mail]: it is also, accord. to some, called *w AlfiqaAr; but this is said by El-Khattábee to be vulgar. (TA.) ― -b4- It (i. e. *uwAlfaqaAri) is also used, metaphorically, as meaning (tropical:) The spear. (TA.)

faqiyrN *
A hollow that is dug around the shoot, or offset, of a palm-tree, when it is planted: (S, O:) or a well [or the like thereof] in which the shoot, or offset, of a palm-tree is planted, (K, TA,) then alluvial soil with dung of camels or the like is pressed down around it: (TA:) pl. fuqurN, with two dammehs: (K, TA:) or this [app. the pl., but accord. to the TA the sing.,] signifies wells, (K, TA,) three, and more, together, (TA,) or communicating, one with another. (K, TA.) The sing. signifies also A well: (Mgh, O:) or an old well: (O:) or a well having little water: (TA:) pl. as above. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And A plain, or soft, place, in which wells are dug forming a regular series. (O, K,) And rakiy~apN faqiyrapN signifies A dug well. (TA.) And faqiyru baniY fulaAnK fiY Alr~akaAyaA is expl. by A 'Obeyd as meaning The share of the sons of such a one of the wells. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The mouth, (K, TA,) or the place whence the water issues, (S, O, TA,) of a subterranean channel, or conduit: (S, * O, * K, * TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b4- And it is said to signify A [hollowed] trunk of a palm-tree, by means of which one ascends to an upper chamber: but the word commonly known in this sense is naqiyrN [q. v.], with n. (IAth, TA.) -A2- As an epithet applied to a camel, it means Having an incision [or two incisions or three] made in his nose [or muzzle] in the manner explained in the first paragraph of this art.; and so ↓ mafoquwrN. (K, TA.) -A3- Also, applied to a man, (TA,) Having the vertebræ of the back broken; (S, O, K, * TA;) and so ↓ faqirN and ↓ mafoquwrN: (K:) or having a complaint of the vertebræ of his back, arising from fracture or from disease: (Msb:) or having his vertebræ pulled out from his back, so that his spine is interrupted: (T, L:) and ↓ faqirN, a man having a complaint of his vertebræ: (S, O, TA:) and fqyr and ↓ mafoquwrN, a man afflicted [lit. having the vertebræ of his back broken] by a calamity. (Msb.) -A4- Hence, as though having the vertebræ of his back broken, (IDrst, TA in art. jbr,) [but said to be irregularly formed from Aifotaqara, like maA A^afoqarahu, q. v.,] Poor: or needy; contr. of ganiY~N; (as implied in the K;) having [only] what suffices for his household, or those who dwell with him and whose maintenance is incumbent an him: (ISd, K:) or one who finds food sufficient to sustain life: (K:) or one who possesses only what is sufficient for life: (ISk, S, K: *) or one whose property is, or has become, little: further expl. in art. skn: (Msb:) or one who has what to eat; (Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà;) differing from misokiynN, which signifies one who possesses nothing; altogether destitute: (Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, ISk, S, O, K:) or both mean destitute, i. e. possessing nothing: (IAar, S, O:) Aboo-Haneefeh holds the opinion of ISk, (TA,) who cites the following verse from a poem of Er-Rá'ee in praise of 'Abd-El-Melik Ibn-Marwán;
A^am~aA Alfaqiyru Al~a*iY kaAnato Haluwbatuhu
wafoqa AlEiyaAli falamo yutorako lahu sabadu
[As to the fqyr whose milch camel was sufficient for his household, and nothing (more) was left to him:] (S, O, TA:) As says that the mskyn is better in condition than the fqyr: and Yoo says that the fqyr is better in condition than the mskyn; and adds, I asked an Arab of the desert, Art thou fqyr? and he answered, No, by God, but rather mskyn: (S, O, TA:) or the former signifies needy, needing, or wanting; a needer; and the latter, one abased by need or want, or otherwise; (Ibn-'Arafeh, O, K;) who, if abased by need or want, may lawfully receive of the poor-rate; but if abased otherwise than by
need or want, he may not receive of the poorrate; for he may be rich: (Ibn-'Arafeh:) [Alfaqiyru A_ilaY A@ll~`hi the needer of God, i. e., of God's help, &c., and Alfaqiyru A_ilaY raHomapi A@ll~`hi the needer of the mercy of God, are epithets which a man often writes before his name:] it is said in the Kur [xxxv. 16], A^anotumu AlfuqaraA='u A_ilaY A@ll~`hi waA@ll~`hu huwa A@loganiY~u A@loHamiydu, which is explained as meaning Ye are the needers, or they who stand in need, of God: [and God, He is the Self-sufficient, the Praised in every case:] (O, * TA: [see also the Kur xxviii. 24:]) or fqyr signifies one who is crippled, or deprived of the power of motion, by disease, or who suffers from a protracted disease, being weak, and who has no trade; and one who has a mean trade that does not suffice for his need; and mskyn, a beggar, who has a trade that stands in some stead, (HirofapN taqaEu mawoqiEFA,) but does not cause him and his household to be without want; (Esh-Sháfi'ee, T, O, K;) so that the former is in a harder condition than the latter accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee; (T;) and it seems that he is called fqyr because of crippleness, or protracted disease, which prevents his freely employing himself in making gain: (Khálid Ibn-Yezeed:) As also says that the latter is in a better condition than the former; (S, O, K;) and so says Ahmad Ibn-'Obeyd: (TA:) and as to the verse of Er-Rá'ee, cited above, it is said to mean that the person there mentioned had a milch camel in former times, but possessed it no longer, and that lamo yutorako lahu sabad means that nothing was left to him: (Mgh:) the pl. of the latter epithet is also applied in the Kur xviii. 78 to men possessing a ship, or boat, which is worth a considerable sum; (Mgh;) whence Aboo-Bekr holds the opinion of As to be correct: (TA:) but it is urged in reply, that these men were hirers, not owners, of the vessel, as appears from one reading, [app. yuEam~aluwna for yaEomaluwna,] with teshdeed: (TA:) or the former signifies one who has neither property nor gain that suffices for his need; and the latter, one who has property or gain not sufficient for him: or, as some say, the converse is the truth: (Bd in ix. 60:) or both signify the same, (IAar, S, K,) one who possesses nothing: (IAar, S:) or when they are used together, they differ in signification; and when used separately, they both [sometimes] signify the same: (El-Bedr El-Karáfee:) [see more voce misokiynN:] fem. with p: (Msb, K:) pl. masc. fuqaraA='u; (Msb, K;) pl. fem. faqaAy^iru, (K,) and fuqaraA='u (Lh, Msb, TA) like the masc., [said to be] the only instance of the kind except sufahaA='u as pl. of safiyhapN; (Msb;) [though fuqahaA='u, and perhaps some other instances, should be added;] but ISd says, I know not how this is. (TA.)
faqaArapN * : see faqaArN.
fayoqarN * : see the next paragraph.

faAqirapN * [An act that breaks, or will break, the vertebræ of the back: and hence,] (assumed tropical:) a calamity, or misfortune; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ fayoqarN: (S, O, K:) or, accord. to Lth and others, such as breaks the vertebræ of the back: (TA:) pl. fawaAqiru. (Har p. 399.) Eamila bihi AlfaAqirapa is a prov., meaning He did to him an act breaking, or that would break, his vertebræ; or a calamity, or misfortune, as in the Kur lxxv. 25: (Meyd:) [or, accord. to J, it app. means he did to him that which would render him tractable; for he says,] it is from the phrase faqarotu A^anofa AlbaEiyri. (S. [This phrase in the S has been strangely misunderstood by Golius; who has consequently, after mentioning the meaning “ infortunium, ” added “ et Habena seu capistrum, de quo in Conj. 1. ”]) ― -b2- And [hence] AlfaAqirapu signifies (assumed tropical:) The resurrection. (TA.)
A^afoqaru * [More, and most, poor or needy &c.: said to be formed irregularly from Aifotaqara, not from an unaugmented form of the verb; like maA A^afoqarahu]. (See Ham pp. 573-4.)
mufoqarN * : see faqorN.

mufoqirN * , applied to a man, (O, TA,) Strong (O, K, TA) in the vertebræ of the back; (TA;) and thus ↓ mufaq~arN, applied to a camel; and [in like manner] ↓ *uwfuqorapK, so applied, strong to be ridden: (O, TA:) and mufoqirN signifies also strong in the back; applied to a colt: (TA:) and, thus applied, that has attained to the time when he may be ridden. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says, A_in~ahu lamufoqirN lih`*aA AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) Verily he is equal to this affair, possessing firmness of mind, or strength, or power, for it; (ISh, O, L, K;) and lh*A AlEazomi for this determination, or resolution; and lh*A Alqironi for this adversary, or opponent. (L.) And ↓ rajulN mufaq~arN (assumed tropical:) A man sufficient for everything that he is ordered to do; (O, K, TA;) as thought by reason of the strength of his vertebræ. (TA.) -A2- See also faqorN.
mufaq~arN * A sword having notches, or indentations, in its maton [q. v.], (S, K,) forming depressions therein. (K.) -A2- See also mufoqirN, in two places.
mafoquwrN * : see faqiyrN, in three places.
mafaAqiru * : see faqorN, in two places.

A^aroDN mutafaq~irapN *
Land in which are many fuqar, meaning hollows. (O, K.)
mutafaAqirN * A man asserting himself to be in a state of faqor [i. e. poverty, or need, &c.]. (A, TA.)

1 faqaSa * , aor.
faqiSa , (Lth, Lh, M, O, K,) inf. n. faqoSN; (Lth, Lh, IDrd, M, O;) He broke; (Lth, Lh, M, O, K;) or crushed; (Lh, O, K;) an egg, (Lh, IDrd, M, O, K,) and the like thereof, (IDrd, O,) and any hollow thing; (Lth, M, O;) as also ↓ fq~S, inf. n. tafoqiySN: (M, TA:) and he (a bird) broke asunder an egg from over the young bird: (A and TA in explanation of the former verb:) and faqasa, aor.
faqiSa , inf. n. faqosN, signifies the same as faqaSa. (Lh, O.) ― -b2- faqaSa fulaAnN bayoDa Alfitonapi [lit. Such a one broke asunder the eggs of sedition, or the like,] is a tropical phrase [meaning (tropical:) such a one originated sedition, &c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [Golius has assigned to faqaSa, constr. with an accus., another signification (“ assecutus fuit rem ”), as on the authority of the K; app. from a mistranscription in the explanation of AlmifoqaAS, in a copy of that lexicon.]
2 faq~aSa see the preceding paragraph.
5 tafaq~aSa see what next follows.
7 AnfqSt AlbayoDapu * and ↓ tfq~St The egg broke [or broke asunder] Eani Alfaroxi [from over the young bird].
bayoDapN faqoSapN * : see mafoquwSapN.

faqiySN * as an epithet: see its fem. voce mafoquwSapN. -A2- Also An iron thing like a ring, among the apparatus of the tiller of land, (Lth, O, K,) which clasps together [app. at the upper parts, so as to form a support like a trevet, for his provisions &c.,] several separate sticks, or pieces of wood, set over against one another. (Lth, O.)

faq~uwSN * , (Lth, O, K,) or faq~uwSapN, (M,) [the former a coll. gen. n., and the latter its n. un.,] A melon (biTiyxpN) before it has become ripe: (Lth, M, O, K:) a word of the dial. of Egypt: (Lth, O, K:) [but now applied in Egypt to the cucumis sativus (or common cucumber); (Forskål's Flora Aegypt. Arab., pp. lxxvi., 169;) or, particularly, cucumis sativus fructu albo: (Delile's Floræ Aegypt. Illustr., no. 929:)] also mentioned as with s for the last letter. (TA.)
mifoqaASN * [A kind of mace;] a thing like a pomegranate, at the end of an iron rod, that breaks, or crushes, everything that it reaches. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)
bayoDapN mafoquwSapN * and ↓ faqiySahN (IDrd, O, K) and ↓ faqoSapN (CK [but not found by me elsewhere]) An egg broken, or crushed. (IDrd, O, K.)

1 faqaEa * , aor.
faqaEa and
faquEa , inf. n. fuquwEN (S, O, K) and faqoEN, (K,) said of the colour of a thing, (S, O,) It was intensely yellow: (S, O, K:) or its yellowness was free from admixture. (K, TA. [See also faqoEN below.]) [And] faqaEa said of a skin, or hide, or a tanned, or red, skin or hide, (A^adiym,) It was beautiful and clear [in colour]. (Ham p. 562.) -A2- faqaEa said of a boy, He became active, and grew, grew up, or became a young man; (K, * TA; [in both of which it is implied that the aor. of the verb in this and the next two senses is
faqaEa and
faquEa , as above;]) and so ↓ tfq~E. (TA.) -A3- And faqaEa (K, TA) said of a man, (TA,) He died from, or in consequence of, the heat. (K, TA.) -A4- faqaEati AlfawaAqiEu fulaAnFA The calamities of time, or fortune, crushed such a one. (K, * TA.) -A5- faqaEa, aor.
faqaEa , (K,) inf. n. faqoEN, (O,) He stole. (O, K. [Accord. to the TK, trans. in this sense.]) -A6- And He emitted wind from the anus, with a sound; (K, TA;) in which sense the inf. n. is
likewise faqoEN; accord. to some, peculiarly said of an ass: and bihi ↓ faq~aEa, and ↓ bimifoqaEK, and ↓ bimifoqaAEK, inf. n. tafoqiyEN, he did so vehemently. (TA.) -A7- faqiEa, i. e. like fariHa, (K, TA,) inf. n. faqaEN, (TK,) said of a man, (TA,) He became red. (K, TA.)

2 fq~E * , (TA,) inf. n. tafoqiyEN, (O, K, TA,) He twisted the sides of his mouth, or opened his mouth and was diffuse, in speech, (O, K, TA,) and uttered speech that had no meaning. (TA.) ― -b2- And fq~E A^aSaAbiEahu, (S, O, * TA,) inf. n. as above, (S, O, K, TA,) i. q. faroqaEahaA, (S, O, * K, * TA, *) [He cracked the joints of his fingers;] i. e. he pressed his fingers so that a sound was heard to proceed from their joints: (TA:) the action signified thereby is forbidden to be performed in prayer: (O, TA:) [but it is said that] this is the contracting of the fingers to the inner side of the hand and making a sound with the outer side [app. by pressing the fist upon the ground so as to make the joints of the fingers crack, when rising; for I think that any action more irregular than this would be too obviously wrong to need prohibition]. (O.) ― -b3- And fq~E Alwarodapa, inf. n. tafoqiyEN, He made the rose into a round form (A^adaArahaA), and then struck it so that it rent open, or asunder, producing a sound: (O:) or Alt~afoqiyEu signifies the striking a rose with the hand, (O, K,) or the making a rose-leaf into a round [and app. hollow] form, and pressing it with the fingers, (TA,) so that it produces a sound, (O, K, TA,) when rending open, or asunder. (TA.) ― -b4- [And fq~E signifies also It cracked with a sound: and it crackled: said of a flint-stone in fire: see Saw~aAnN: and said of salt thrown into a fire: see naArN.] ― -b5- See also 1, last sentence but one. -A2- fq~E AlA^diyma, (O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He made the hide red. (O, K, TA.)
4 AfqE * , (TA,) inf. n. A_ifoqaAEN, (O, K, TA,) He was, or became, poor, or needy: (TA;) or in an evil state or condition. (O, K, TA.)

5 tafaq~aEa see 1. ― -b2- [Reiske, as stated by Freytag, has explained this verb as signifying It was, or became, contracted; said of a hand: but probably, I think, in consequence of his having found tafaq~aEat erroneously written for taqaf~aEat.]

6 tfAqEt EayonaAhu *
His eyes became white: (O, K, TA:) or became cleft, or fissured: or had in them foul, or foul white, matter. (TA.)

7 AnfqE *
It became cleft, or fissured, or rent open or asunder. (O, K.)

faqoEN * [an inf. n., of faqaEa, q. v. Used as a subst.,] Intense whiteness. (TA.) [But it seems to signify more commonly, Intense yellowness: or yellowness free from admixture: see 1, first sentence.] -A2- And i. q. HuSaASN [app. as meaning An emission of wind from the anus, with a sound]. (S, O, TA. [See 1, last sentence but one.]) -A3- Also, and ↓ fiqoEN, (S, O, K,) the latter mentioned by ISk, (S, O,) A species of kamoA^ap [or truffles]; (S, O;) accord. to A 'Obeyd, (S, O,) the white and soft thereof: (S, O, K;) which is the worst thereof; or, as IAth says, a species of the worst [kind] of kmA^p, accord. to AHn, it comes forth from the ground so as to appear, white, and is bad; the good being that which is extracted by digging: Lth says, It is a kamo' [or truffle] that comes forth from the base of the plant called A_ijorid [q. v.], and is of the worst of kmA^p, and the quickest in becoming corrupt: (TA:) the pl. is fiqaEapN, (S, O, K,) which is of both forms of the sing.; (S, O, TA;) and faqoEN, with fet-h, has for pls. A^ufoquEN [a pl. of pauc.] and fuquwEN [a pl. of mult.]. (AHn, TA.) A vile man is likened thereto: (S, O, K: *) one says, huwa A^a*al~u mino faqoEi qaroqarK, (S,) or mino faqoEK bqaroqarapK, (O, K,) [He is more vile than the fqE of, or than fqE In, a (??) and soft tract of ground,] because the beasts kick it along, (S,) or because it offers not resistance to the gatherer thereof, or because it is trodden with the feet, (O, K,) and the beasts kick it along. (O.) ― -b2- [From a mention of the pl. faquwEN in art. *A^n, and in the present art. in the TA, it appears that faqoEN is also applied to The species of fungus called *uw^onuwn, and to the species called Turovuwv, &c.] ― -b3- And [hence, perhaps,] faqoEN [as a coll. a.] signifies also (assumed tropical:) Pointed toes (xaraATiym of a sort of boots (O, TA.)
fiqoEN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
faqaAEK * ; see what next follows.

fuqaAEK * ; (O, and thus in my MS, copy of the K; in other copies of the K fuqaAE or fuqaAEN; and in all the copies is added bAlD~am~i karubaAE or karubaAEK; [but there is no such word as rubaAEK. nor rubAEN; whence it seems to be meant that we should read karubaAEa; i. e. fuqaAEu, like rubAEu, imperfectly decl.; but see what follows;]) so says Ibn-Buzurj: (O:) or, (O, K,) accord. to AZ, (O,) ↓ fqAEK, (O, K, *) like rubaAEK, (O.) [i. e.] with fet-h, like vamaAnK (kavamaAnK): (K:) [which suggests that karubaAEK may be an early mistranscription for karbaAEK, and that fuqaAE is wrong, and only faqaAEK right, though it is said in one place in the TA that faqaAE is like saHaAb, i. e. that it is faqaAEN:] or it is ↓ faqiyEN, like A^amiyrN; (K, TA;) so accord. to El-Jáhidh, as mentioned by Az: (TA:) applied to a man, as meaning Red; (O, K, TA;) intensely so; by reason of A_igoraAb [i. e. app., goodliness of condition]: (O, TA:) and ↓ fuqaAEiy~N, as an epithet applied to a man, signifies red. (TA.)

faqiyEN * , (so in the O,) or ↓ fiq~iyEN, like sik~iytN, (K,) but the former, like A^amiyrN, is the right, [a coll. gen. n.,] and its n. un. is with p, (TA,) The white, of pigeons; (K, TA;) said by El-Jáhidh to be such, of pigeons, as are like the SiqolaAbiY~ [or Sclave] of men; (O, TA;) a kind of white pigeon; so called as being likened to a [white] species of truffle [i. e. the faqoE]. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aboyaDu faqiyEN, (so in the O,) or ↓ AbyD fiq~iyEN, like sik~iytN, (K,) White that is intense (O, K) in whiteness. (O.) [See also faAqiEN.] ― -b3- faqiyEN as an epithet applied to a man: see fuqaAEK.
fuq~aAEN * : see fuqaAEK: ― -b2- and see faAqiEN, in two places.
faq~aAEN * One who emits wind from the anus, with a sound, much, or frequently. (TA.) ― -b2- And Strong, or vehement; and bad, corrupt, or wicked. (Lth, O, K.)

fuq~aAEN * . 1 certain beverage, (S, O, L, K,) [a sort of beer.] made from barley: (L, TA:) [but there are several sorts thereof, perhaps peculiar to postclassical times: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, see, ed., vol. i., pp. 149-154:)] so called because of the froth that rises upon its head. (O, K. [See fuq~aAEapN.]) ― -b2- And A certain plant, (AHn, O, K.) such as is termed ↓ mutafaq~iEN, i. e., (AHn, O, K. *) which, when it dries up, becomes hard, and as though it were horns. (AHn, O, K.) [Now applied in North-Western Africa to The toadstool, which is called in other parts fuTorN.]
fiq~iyEN * : see faqiyEN, in two places.

fuq~aAEapN * , like rum~aAnapN, sing. of faqaAqiyEu, (TA,) which signifies The bubbles that rise upon water, (S, O, K, TA,) and upon wine, (O,) [&c.,] round, [or globular.] (TA,) like qawaAriyr [or vessels of glass]. (S, O, TA.)

fuq~aAEiY~N *
A seller of [the beverage called] fuq~aAE. (TA.)

faAqiEN * (S, O, K) and ↓ fuqaAEiY~N (K) Yellow intensely yellow; (S, O, K;) thus both signify: (Lh, K, TA:) or red intensely red: (K:) or red free from an admixture of whiteness: or purely red: (TA:) or faAqiEN is applied to white and to any other colour as signifying free from admixture; (K;) and ↓ fuqaAEiY~N is applied in this sense to white: (TA:) and ↓ A^afoqaEu, of which the pl. is fuqoEN, signifies intensely white. (K.)

faAqiEapN *
A calamity, or misfortune: (S, O, K:) pl. fawaAqiEu. (S, O, K. *)
A^afoqaEu * ; pl. fuqoEN: see faAqiEN.

faqorN mufoqiEN * , accord. to the K, signifies mudoqiEN [as though meaning Poverty causing to cleave to the dust or earth]: but the right phrase is faqiyrN mufoqiEN, signifying mudoqiEN [i. e. a poor person cleaving to the dust or earth: for A^adoqaEa is intrans. as well as trans.]; which denotes the worst condition, like majohuwdN. (TA.) [See 4.]
mifoqaEN * and ↓ mifoqaAEN [The anus (as being the instrument) with which wind is emitted vehemently, with a sound]: see 1, last sentence but one.

xaf~N mufaq~aEN *
i. q. muxaruTamN (O, K) i. e. A boot having its fore part pointed. (TA in art. xrTm.)

Almufaq~iEapu *
A certain black bird of which the base of the tail is white, (O, K,) that pecks camels', or similar, dung. (O.)
mifoqaAEN * : see mifoqaEN; and 1, last sentence but one.
mutafaq~iEN * : see fuq~aAEN.

1 faqima * , (S, K, * TA,) aor.
faqama , (TA,) inf. n. faqamN, It, or he, was, or became, full: (S, K, TA:) it is said of a vessel: (TA:) and one says [also] A^aSaAba mina AlmaA='i Hat~aY faqima [He obtained, or took, of the water until he became full]; mentioned by IDrd. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A^akala Hat~aY faqima He ate until he became affected with indigestion, or oppressed by much eating. (K.) ― -b3- faqima maAluhu His property, or wealth, became much, or abundant: or it has the contr. meaning, i. e., passed away; came to an end; or became spent, exhausted, or consumed. (K, TA.) -A2- faqima, aor.
faqama , (K, TA,) inf. n. faqamN (S, K, TA) and faqomN, (K, TA,) He had the lower central incisors prominent, (S, TA,) so that they did not close against the upper, (S,) or so that the upper did not close against them when he (the man) closed his mouth: so in the L: or he had the lower jaw long and the upper short: but accord. to the K, he had the upper central incisors prominent, so that they did not close against the lower: (TA:) the epithet applied to him is ↓ A^afoqamu; (S, K, TA;) fem. faqomaA='u. (TA [in which it is added that one says rjl fuqomN; but rjl is app. here a mistranscription for rijaAlN].) ― -b2- And [hence] faqima falaAnN i. q. baTira and A^a$ira (tropical:) [i. e. Such a one exulted; or exulted greatly, or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: &c.]: (K, TA:) because AlbaTaru and AlA^a$aru are departure from the limit of rectitude. (TA.) ― -b3- And faqima AlA^amoru, (K, TA,) aor.
faqama , (TA,) inf. n. faqamN and faqomN and fuquwmN, (tropical:) The affair did not proceed in a right course. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And faqima and faquma are syn. with tfAqm, q. v. (K.) ― -b5- And faquma signifies also It (a thing) was, or became, wide, or ample. (TA.) -A3- faqama AlmaroA^apa: see 3. -A4- faqama Atkaloba He took hold of the fuqom [i. e. muzzle] of the dog; (K;) as also ↓ tfq~mhu. (Z, K.)
3 fAqm AlmaroA^apa * , (S, * K, TA,) inf. n. mufaAqamapN and fiqaAmN, (S, TA,) He compressed the woman; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓ faqamahaA. (K.)
5 tafaq~ama see 1, last sentence.

6 tfAqm *
It (an affair, or a case,) was, or became, great, or formidable; (S, Mgh, K, TA;) and hard, or difficult; (Mgh;) said of what is disliked, or hated; (TA;) and ↓ faqima and ↓ faquma signify the same. (K.)
faqomN * : see what next follows.

fuqomN * (S, K) and ↓ faqomN (K) The laHoY [meaning lateral portion of the lower jaw]; (S, K;) or either one of the laHoyaAni. (K.) Hence the trad., mano HafaZa maA bayona faqomayohi warijolayohi daxala Aljan~apa [He who keeps from evil what is between his two lateral portions of the lower jaw (i. e. his tongue), and what is between his two legs (i. e. his *akar), enters Paradise]. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- [And] The upper part [of the interior] of the mouth: the lower part is the Hanak. (IAar, T in art. Hnk.) ― -b3- See also fugomN.
fuqumN * The mouth. (Sh, K, TA. [See also fugomN.])

A^afoqamu * ; fem. faqomaA='u: see 1. ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) Anything crooked, distorted, or uneven. (TA.) And A^amorN A^afoqamu (tropical:) An affair, or a case, of a crooked kind; contrary to what is right. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b3- [And Freytag adds, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees, Difficult, as an epithet applied to a thing: ― -b4- and, as a signification of the fem., A calamity, or misfortune.]

1 faqiha * , aor.
faqaha , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. fiqohN, the verb being like Ealima and the inf. n. like EilomN, in measure and in meaning, (TA,) or faqahN; (JK; [and the same seems to be implied in the Msb and the K;]) and faquha; (Msb, K;) He had, or possessed, what is termed fiqohN, meaning understanding, (S, K,) and knowledge, and intelligence, and especially knowledge of the law (Eilomu Ald~iyni): (K:) or both are syn. with Ealima: (Msb, TA:) or faquha, of which the inf. n. is faqaAhapN, (S, TA,) or fiqohN, (JK,) signifies [peculiarly] he had, or possessed, knowledge of the law (Eilom Al$~ariyEap): (S:) or this latter verb signifies he had, or possessed, what is termed fiqopN as a faculty firmly rooted in his mind: (Msb, TA:) or, accord. to IB, i. q. ↓ tafaq~aha [q. v., as intrans.]: and he was, or became, [a faqiyh, q. v., or] equal to the fuqahA='. (TA in art. Elm: see Elm.) One says, fulaAnN laA yanoqahu [which may be rendered Such a one will not understand nor comprehend: but the two verbs are exactly syn.]. (S.) And to the witness one says, kayofa faqaAhatuka limaA A^a$ohado naAka [app. meaning How is thy understanding of (or how understandest thou) what we have made thee to witness?]: it is not said to any other than the witness: (K, TA:) thus in the M: (TA:) or, accord. to Z, it is said to other than the witness. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And faqihahu, (Mgh, K,) aor.
faqaha , inf. n. fiqohN, (K,) He understood it, (Mgh, K,) namely, a meaning, (Mgh,) or a thing that one explained to him; (TA;) as also ↓ tfq~hhu. (K.) ― -b3- See also 3.

2 fq~hhu * , (S, K,) inf. n. tafoqiyhN, (K,) He (God) made him to know or have knowledge [or to understand, or instructed him], or taught him; (S, * K, TA;) and (K) so ↓ Afqhhu, (Msb, K,) or he made him to understand. (S, Mgh.) It is said in a trad., Aall~`hum~a Eal~imohu Ald~iyna wafaq~ihohu fiY Alt~aA^owiyli i. e. O God, teach him Aldyn [app. here meaning the science of the law] and [instruct him in] the tA^wyl [or interpretation, &c.,] and the meaning thereof. (TA.) And you say, Al$~aYo'a ↓ A^afoqahotuka I made thee to understand, (S, Msb, *) or I taught thee, (Msb,) the thing. (S, Msb.) And ↓ A^afoqanotuhu I explained to him the learning of Alfiqoh [meaning the science of the law]. (T, TA.)

3 fAqhhu *
He searched with him into [matters of] science, disputing with him, (S, K,) ↓ fafaqahahu, aor.
faquha , [inf. n. faqohN,] and he overcame him therein. (K.)
4 A^afoqaha see 2, in three places.

5 tfq~h *
He learned knowledge, or science: (M voce saw~ada:) [and particularly] he learned Alfiqoh [meaning the science of the law]: (JK:) or he took, or applied himself, to the acquisition of Alfiqoh [meaning thus]. (S, TA.) And tfq~h fiY AlEilomi is like taEal~ama [meaning He became, or made himself, learned, or thoroughly learned, in science]. (Msb.) liyatafaq~ahuwA fiY Ald~iyni, in the Kur ix. 123, means That they may task themselves to obtain understanding in Ald~yano [i. e. the law, or religion in general], imposing upon themselves the difficulties attendant on the acquisition thereof. (Ksh, Bd.) See also 1, in two places; in the latter of which it is mentioned as transitive.

fiqohN * [as a simple subst.] signifies Understanding (S, Msb, K) of a thing; (Msb, K;) and knowledge thereof; (Msb, K;) and intelligence: (K:) accord. to IF, any knowledge of a thing is thus termed: (Msb:) [hence fiqohu All~ugapi The science of lexicology is the title of a work written by him; and of another work, by Eth-Tha'álibee:] and, as used by the lawyers [and others], Alfiqohu denotes a particular science; (Msb;) it signifies particularly, (S, TA,) or predominantly, (K, TA,) The science of the law; [jurisprudence;] (S, K, TA;) syn. Eilomu Al$~ariyEapi, (S, TA,) or Eilomu Ald~iyni, [which is the same as Elm Al$ryEp,] because of its preëminence (K, TA) above the other kinds of science: (TA:) and more particularly, the science of the furuwE [or derivative institutes] of the law. (TA.)
faquhN * ; and its fem., with p: see the next paragraph.

faqiyhN * Any one possessing knowledge of a thing. (TA.) fafiyhu AlEarabi signifies The EaAlim [or man of knowledge] of the Arabs; (TA;) and was an appellation given to El-Hárith Ibn-Keledeh (AlH`rivu bonu kaladapa), who was also called Tabiybu AlEarabi [as is said in the S in art. Azm], because this appellation is syn. with the former; but IKh and El- Hareeree do not mean by fqyhA lErb any particular person. (Mz, close of the 39th nwE.) ― -b2- [Particularly and predominantly,] faqiyhN signifies One possessing knowledge of the law; [a lawyer;] (S, K;) as also ↓ faquhN; (Msb, K;) fem. faqiyhapN and ↓ faquhapN: pl. [of faqiyhN] fuqahaA='u; and [of fafiyhapN] faqaAy^ihu and fuqahaA='u;
(K;) the last of these pls. mentioned by Lh, and anomalous, as applied to women: ISd says, “ in my opinion, he, of the Arabs, who says fuqahaA=' [in speaking of women] takes no account of the fem. p: it is like fuqaraA='u applied to women. ” (TA.) [In Egypt, the appellation fiqiY, a vulgar corruption of faqiyh, is now applied to A schoolmaster; and to a person who recites the Kur-án &c. for hire.] ― -b3- faHolN faqiyhN means A stallion [camel] expert in covering, (K, TA,) that knows well the she-camels that are lusting, and the pregnant. (TA.)

Almusotafoqihapu *
The female companion of the wailing woman, who responds to her (K, TA) in what she says; because she catches and retains quickly, and understands, what she [the former] says, and to reply to it: [as though it signified “ she who seeks, or desires, to understand: ”] it is said in a trad. that each of these persons is cursed by God. (TA.)
1 faqawotu A^avarahu * or A_ivorahu I followed his track, or footsteps; i. q. qafawotuhu; (K, TA;) mentioned by Yaakoob among the words formed by transposition: so in the M. (TA.)
faqowN * : see its syn. faqo'N, in art. fqA^.

fuqowapN * The fuwq [or notch] of the arrow; (S, K, TA;) i. e. the part which is the place of the bowstring: (TA:) [also called fuwqapN, from which it is app. formed by transposition, like the other words mentioned in this art.:] pl. fuqFY, (S, K,) also written fuqFA. (TA.) An ex. of the pl. occurs in a verse cited in art. Erqb, voce EuroquwbN. (S.)

1 Alfak~u * , accord. to Er-Rághib, primarily signifies Alt~aforiyju [i. e. The opening a thing; and particularly by diduction, or so as to form an intervening space, or a gap, or breach]. (TA.) You say, fak~a, first pers. fakakotu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faku3a , inf. n. fak~N, (O, Msb,) He separated (S, O, Msb, K) a thing (S, O, K) from another thing; and any two things knit together, or intricately intermixed: (S, O:) or fakakotuhu I separated one part of it from another part thereof: (Msb:) and ↓ tafokiykN likewise signifies the separating two things knit together, or intricately intermixed. (Lth, S, TA.) And He broke [or broke open] a seal, i. e. a sealed piece of clay or wax; (Mgh, Msb, * TA;) in relation to which ↓ yafotak~uhu occurs as meaning yafuk~uhu, though we have not heard it [as a classical expression in this sense]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And fak~a AlEaZoma, (Mgh, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) He dislocated the bone; put it out of joint. (Mgh, Msb.) [This, or the like, is what is meant by its being said that] Alfak~u in the hand, or arm, is [i. e. denotes] less than Alkasoru. (K.) ― -b3- And fak~a yadahu, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He opened, or unclosed, his hand from what was in it: (K, TA:) so in the M. (TA.) ― -b4- And fak~a Alr~ahona, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faku3a , (TA,) inf. n. fak~N and fukuwkN; (K;) and ↓ Aftk~hu; (S, Mgh, O, K;) (tropical:) He redeemed the pledge; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA;) got it out from the hand of him to whom it was pledged. (Mgh.) ― -b5- And fakakotu signifies also I loosed, set loose or free, or let go, anything. (Msb.) ― -b6- [Hence,] fak~a AlA^asiyru, (Msb, K,) aor.
faku3a , (TA,) inf. n. fak~N and fakaAkN and fikaAkN, (K,) (tropical:) He liberated, or set free, the captive. (Msb, K, TA.) And fak~a Alr~aqabapa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
faku3a , inf. n. fak~N, (TA,) [lit. He loosed the neck,] means (tropical:) he emancipated [the slave]. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) fak~u Alr~aqabapi is expl. in a trad. as meaning (assumed tropical:) The assisting in paying the price [of the slave when one is unable to pay the whole of the price]. (O, TA.) In the Kur [xc. 13], fak~u raqabapK is said by some to mean (assumed tropical:) The emancipating of a slave: and by some. (assumed tropical:) the man's emancipating himself from subjection to God's punishment by the confession of the unity of God and by righteous doing and then by teaching the same to others. (TA,) fuk~a fulaAnN means (assumed tropical:) Such a one was set free, and at rest, from a thing. (IAar, Th, TA.) ― -b7- [Hence also,] one says, huwa yafuk~u Alma$aAkila (assumed tropical:) [He solves] the things, or affairs, that are dubious, or confused. (TA in art. $kl.) ― -b8- qadofak~a wafar~aja is said of a very old man, meaning far~aja laHoyayohi [i. e. He has parted his jaws, by hanging the lower jaw in consequence of weakness]; as is the case in extreme old age. (S, O,) And [hence.] fak~a, (AZ, S, O, K,) aor.
faku3a , inf. n. fak~N and fukuwkN, (AZ, S, O,) said of a man, means (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, extremely aged, or old and weak. (AZ, S, O, K.) [Or fak~a thus used may be from Alfak~u signifying “ the jaw: ” and so what next follows.] ― -b9- fakakotu AlS~abiY~a I put medicine into the mouth of the boy or young male child [opening his jaws for that purpose]. (S, O.) -A2- qado fakikota, [third pers. fak~a,] aor. tafak~u, inf. n. fakakN, Thou hast become such as is termed A^afak~u i. e. one whose manokib [here meaning shoulder-bone] has become unknit, or loosened, (Ainofaraja,) from its joint, in consequence of weakness and flaccidity. (S.) [See also fakakN below.] ― -b2- And qadofakikota, aor. tafak~u; (S, O, K;) and fakukota, (O, K,) a verb of a very rare form, [respecting which see dam~a, last sentence,] (MF, TA,) aor. tafuk~u; (O, K;) inf. n. fak~apN (S, O, K) and fak~N also; (TA;) (tropical:) Thou hast become foolish, or stupid, and soft, flaccid, or languid. (S, O, K, TA.)
2 fak~a3a see the preceding paragraph, second sentence.

4 Afk~t *
She (a camel) being near to bringing forth, her SalawaAni [app. meaning two parts on the right and left of the tail (see SlFA in art. Slw)] became lax, or flaccid, and her udder became large; (K, TA;) and so A^afokahat; (TA;) so too ↓ tfk~kt: or this last signifies she became vehemently desirous of the stallion. (O, K.) ― -b2- And Afk~ mina AlHibaAlapi He (a gazelle) got loose from the snare into which he had fallen. (TA: also mentioned, but not expl., in the O.)

5 tfk~k *
It (a thing) became much, or widely, separated: and became unclosed. (O, TA.) ― -b2- tfk~kt Als~afiynapu The ship parted asunder; became disjointed; became separated in its places of joining. (Mgh in art. xlE.) ― -b3- See also 7. ― -b4- And see 4. ― -b5- You say also, huwa yatafak~aku meaning (tropical:) He is [or acts] without power of self-restraint, in consequence of stupidity, or unsoundness of intellect, (S, O, K, TA,) in his gait, and in his speech: (TA:) or tafak~aka in walking is syn. with taxal~aEa, (S and K and TA in art. xlE,) i. e. [he was, or became, loose in the joints; or] he shook his shoulder-joints and his arms, and made signs with them. (TA in that art.)

7 Anfk~ *
It became separated: you say, Anfk~ Al$~aYo'u mina Al$~aYo'i The thing became separated from the thing: (O, TA:) and Ainofakakotu minoka [I became separated from thee]. (TA.) ― -b2- And, said of a bone, It became dislocated, or out of joint; (MA, Mgh, * Msb; *) it unknit, or loosened, and separated; syn. Ainofaraja wA@nofaSala; as also ↓ tfk~k. (Mgh.) [And it is also used in relation to a member of the body:] one says, saqaTa fulaAnN fA@nofak~ato qadamuhu A^awo A_iSobaEuhu i. e. Ainofarajato wazaAlato [Such a one fell, and his foot, or his finger, became unknit, or loosened, and dislocated]: (S, O:) [or] Anfk~t qadamuhu means zaAlato [i. e. his foot became dislocated; and Anfk~t A_SobaEuhu means Ainofarajato [i. e. his finger became unknit, or loosened in a joint]. (K.) ― -b3- One says also, Anfk~t raqabatuhu mina Alr~iq~i, meaning (tropical:) He became freed [lit. his neck became loosed] from slavery. (S, * O, * TA.) ― -b4- And Anfk~ Eano Eahodihi (assumed tropical:) [He became released from his compact, engagement, or promise]. (TA voce Ainofaraka.) ― -b5- And laAyanofak~u Eano quboHi fiEolihi (assumed tropical:) [He will not desist from his evil doing]. (O and K in art. Erf.) -A2- [It is also used in the sense and manner of the non-attributive verb zaAla; respecting which see art. zyl.] One says, maAA@nofak~a fulaAnN qaAy^imFA, meaning maAzaAla qaAy^imFA [i. e. Such a one ceased not to be, or continued to be, standing]. (S, O.) And maAA@nofakakotu A^a*okuruka, meaning maAzilotu A^a*okuruka I ceased not, or I continued, remembering thee]. (Fr, TA.) And it occurs in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, immediately followed by A_il~aA, which is [said by As and IJ and others to be] redundant. (S, O. [See that verse, and the remarks upon it, in art. AlA. p. 78, col. i.])
8 A_ifotaka3a see 1, former half, in two places.

fak~apN * [an inf. n.: see 1, last sentence]. -A2- Alfak~apu is the name of One of the northern constellations, [Corona Borealis,] (Kzw,) certain stars, (S, O, K,) eight stars, called in Pers. kAsh drwy$An, (Kzw,) behind Als~imaAk Alr~aAmiH [i. e. Arcturus], (S, O, K,) [near] behind the staff of AlS~ay~aAH [which is a name of Bootes], (Kzw,) having a circling form, (S, O, K, and Kzw,) but with a gap, or breach, in the circling, for which reason, [agreeably with the Pers. appellation mentioned above,] it is called qaSoEapu AlmasaAkiyni [the bowl of the paupers], (Kzw,) this being the name given to it by the children. (As, S, O, K.)

fakakN *
An unknit, or a loosened, state (AinofiraAj) of the manokib [or shoulder-joint]. (K. [But see 1, last explanation but one, where it is mentioned as an inf. n.]) ― -b2- And (K) A state of dislocation of the foot: (S, O, K:) hence the phrase, in a verse of Ru-beh, kamunohaADi AlfalakN: (S, O: *) but (in this instance, O), accord. to As, Alfalak is used by poetic license for Alfak~ [meaning “ the jaw, ” so that the phrase signifies like him whose jaw has become broken after its having been set]. (S, O.) ― -b3- And A state of fracture of the jaw: (K, TA:) or of dislocation thereof. (TA.)

fakaAku Alr~ahoni * and fikaAkuhu, (S, O, Msb, * K,) the latter mentioned by Ks (S, O, Msb) and ISk, (Msb,) That wherewith the pledge is, or is to be, redeemed: (S, O, Msb, * K:) so in a verse cited voce galaqa. (S, O.)

fak~aAkN * [One who separates, &c., much, or often]. ― -b2- [And hence,] fak~aAkN hak~aAkN (tropical:) One who does not make his words and their meanings congruous, or consistent, by reason of his foolishness, or stupidity. (Z, TA.)

faAk~N * [as an act. part. n., Separating, &c. ― -b2- And] (assumed tropical:) Extremely aged, or old and weak; applied in this sense to a man; (AZ, S, O, K;) and also to a camel: (K:) or, applied to a camel, disabled, or fatigued, by leanness, or emaciation: fem. with p. (En-Nadr, TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) Foolish, or stupid: (S, O: *) or very foolish, or stupid: (IAar, K, TA:) and you say faAk~N taAk~N, (IAar, S, O, TA,) making tAk~ an imitative sequent: or, accord. to Yaakoob, you say $ayoxN faAk~N wataAk~N: thus he makes tAk~ a substitute, not an imitative sequent. (TA.) And A^aHomaqu faAk~N wahaAk~N (tropical:) [A foolish, or stupid, person,] one who talks of that which he knows and of that which he knows not, and is more, or oftener, incorrect than correct. (El-Hoseybee, TA.) Pl. fakakapN and fikaAkN. (IAar, K.)

A^afak~u * , (S, K,) or A^afak~u Almanokibi, (K,) One whose manokib [here meaning shoulder-bone] has become unknit, or loosened, (Ainofaraja,) from its joint, in consequence of weakness and flaccidity. (S, K. * [See also maforuwkN.]) ― -b2- And rajulN A^afak~u [A man having the jaw broken]. (TA. [There expl. as signifying masokuwru Alfak~i; a mistranscription, for makosuwruAlfak~i: see fakakN, last sentence.]) -A2- See also Alfak~u.
mufik~apN * , applied to a she-camel, part. n. of A^afak~at [q. v.]: (O, TA:) and mufokihN and mufokihapN are syn. therewith. (TA.)
mutafak~ikapN * A mare desiring the stallion, (AO, O, K,) not offering opposition to him. (AO, O.)

munofak~iyna * in the Kur [xcviii. 1], (O, TA,) followed by the words Hat~aY taA^otiyahumu A@lobay~inapu, (O,) means, accord. to Mujáhid (O, TA) and Zj, (TA,) In the condition of desisting (O, TA) from their infidelity; (TA;) or, as Akh says, ceasing from their infidelity: (TA:) or, accord. to another, (O,) namely, Niftaweyh, (TA,) quitting the present state of existence, (O, TA,) i. e., sharing, one with another, in perdition, until the evidence came to them (O, TA) that had been affirmed to them in the Towráh, with respect to the description of Mohammad &c.; taA^otiyahum being lit. an aor., but in its meaning a pret.: (O:) Az says that it is not from maA A@nofak~a meaning maA zaAla, but from AinofikaAku Al$~aYo'i mina Al$~aYo'i meaning “ the thing's becoming separated from the thing: ” accord. to IAar, as mentioned by Th, fuk~a fulaAnN means “ Such a one was set free, and at rest, from a thing; ” and hence mnfk~yn in the Kur means experiencing rest: accord. to Er-Rághib, it means separated, or separated into several parties; for all [to whom the word, preceded by a negative, relates] were assenting to error. (TA.)

1 fakara fiyhi * , (O, * Msb, K,) aor.
fakura , (O, TK,) or
fakira , (Msb,) inf. n. fakorN; (S, O, Msb, K; *) and ↓ A^afokara; (S, O, Msb, K;) and ↓ fk~r, (S, O, K,) [which is more common than either of the first and second,] inf. n. tafokiyrN; (O, TA;) and ↓ tfk~r; (S, O, Msb, K;) and ↓ Aftkr, (Msb, TA,) but this last is vulgar; (TA;) He thought upon it, considered it, or examined it [mentally]; (Msb;) he considered it in order to obtain a clear knowledge of it; (S, O, * TA;) he employed his mind, (M, TA,) or his consideration, (K, TA,) upon it. (M, K, TA.) [See also fikorN.]
2 fak~ara 4, 5, and 8: see the preceding paragraph.

fakorN * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- layosa liY fiY h`*aA AlA^amori fakorN, (Yaakoob, S, O, K, *) which is more chaste than ↓ fikorN, [in this case,] (Yaakoob, S, O,) but the latter is sometimes used, (K,) means I have no want, or need, of this thing: (Yaakoob, S, O, K: *) or, as is said in the A, laA fakora liY fiY h`*aA i. e. I have no want, or need, of this, nor do I care for it. (TA.)

fikorN * and ↓ fikorapN (S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ fikoraY, (Lth, O, K,) are simple substs., (S, O, Msb, *) but the last is of rare occurrence, (Lth, O,) signifying Thought, consideration, or [mental] examination, fiY A^amorK [respecting a thing]; (Msb;) consideration [of a thing] in order to obtain a clear knowledge [of it]; (S, TA;) the employment of the mind, (M, TA,) or of the consideration, (K, TA,) upon a thing: (M, K, TA:) or repeated consideration for the purpose of seeking [to discover] meanings: or the arranging of things in the mind in order, by them, to arrive at some object of which the attainment is desired, though it be but a preponderating opinion: (Msb:) or the arranging of known things [in the mind] in order to attain to [the knowledge of] an unknown [thing]: (KT:) pl. of the first A^afokaArN: (IDrd, K;) but Sb says that neither fikorN nor EilomN nor naZarN has any pl.: (TA:) the pl. of ↓ fikorapN is fikarN. (Msb.) One says, lifulaAnK fikarN kul~uhaA fiqarN [Such a one has thoughts all of which are points of wit]. (A, TA.) -A2- See also fakorN.
fikorapN * : see the next preceding paragraph; the former in two places.
fikoraY * : see the next preceding paragraph; the former in two places.
fik~iyrN * [Thoughtful;] having much fikor; (IF, S, O, K;) as also ↓ fayokarN. (Kr, K.)
fayokarN * : see what next precedes.

8 Aftkl fiY fiEolihi *
i. q. AiHotafala [He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, &c., in his doing]; (IAar, O, K;) said of a man. (IAar, O.)

A^afokalu *
A tremour, (S, O, K,) from cold or from fear: (S:) hence, in a trad., A^axa*aniY A^afokalu [A tremour seized me]: (S, * O:) and in another, fabaAta walahu A^afokalu [And he passed the night having a
tremour, or shivering]: (O:) thus used, as indeterminate, it is perfectly decl.; but if used as a [proper] name of a man, it is imperfectly decl. because determinate and also of the measure of a verb: (S, O:) some say, (IF, O,) no verb is formed from it; (IF, S, O;) but such is not the case, for they said rajulN mafokuwlN [which shows that it had a verb though none is known to have been in use]. (IF, O.) [A^axa*ato biY naAqatiY A^afokalFA mina Als~ayori is a saying mentioned in the O and K, (in the former as from Ibn-'Abbád,) but the meaning is not expl., nor indicated by the context, in either of them; and the strangeness of its phraseology convinces me that it presents a mistranscription: I believe that the first word is mistranscribed for A^aHodavato, and, consequently, that the meaning is, My she-camel produced in me a tremour arising from the rate of journeying: some copies of the K, as is stated in the TA, for mina Als~ayori, have mn Als~aboqi, from the outstripping.] ― -b2- Also The [bird commonly called] $iqir~aAq [generally meaning the green wood-pecker]; (O, K;) because they regard it as of evil omen; so that when it presents itself to them, they are frightened at it, and tremble. (O.) -A2- And A company, or collective body, of men: one says, jaAw^uwA biA^afokalihimo They came with their company [i. e. all together]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) A^afaAkiylu [is app. a pl. thereof, and, as such,] signifies A^afowaAjN [pl. of fawojN, q. v.]: thus in the phrase A^afaAkiylu mino ka*aA [app. meaning Multitudes of such a kind of thing]: (K:) [or] thus in the saying, mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád, Einodahu A^afaAkiylu mino kalaAmK [app. meaning He has multitudes of sayings, or words; for kalaAmN (q. v.) is used in a pl. sense as well as in a sing. sense]. (O. [The difference of these two exs. in respect of the last word suggests that there may be in one of them a mistranscription.])
mafokuwlN * [the pass. part. n. of a verb which is not mentioned,] Affected with a tremour. (IF, O, K, TA. [See A^afokalu, first sentence.])

1 fakiha * , aor.
fakaha , inf. n. fakaAhapN (S, Mgh, K) and fakahN, (K, TA,) [the latter inf. n. correctly thus, agreeably with a general rule, in the CK with the k quiescent, but said in the TA to be bAltHryk,] (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, cheerful, happy, or free from straitness; (S, Mgh, K;) jocose, or given to jesting, (S, Mgh,) and to laughing: (Mgh, K:) or one who talked to his companions and made them to laugh. (K.) ― -b2- See also 5.

2 fak~ahahumo * , inf. n. tafokiyhN, He brought to them faAkihap [i. e. fruit]. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence] fak~ahahumo bimulaHi AlkalaAmi, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He entertained them in a novel manner with facetious sayings or talk. (K, TA.)

3 fAkhhu * , (K,) inf. n. mufaAkahapN, (S,) (tropical:) He jested, or joked, with him; (S, K, TA;) indulged in pleasantry with him. (TA.) It is said in a prov., laA tufaAkiho A^amapF walaAtabulo EalaY A^akamapK (tropical:) [Jest not thou with a female slave, and make not water upon a hillock, i. e. and publish not what is secret of thine affair: see art. Akm]. (S, TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce tazan~ada.]

4 A^afokahato *
She (a camel) yielded her milk plentifully on the occasion of eating the [herbage called] rabiyE, before her bringing forth: (S, TA:) or she being near to bringing forth, her SalawaAni [app. meaning two parts on the right and left of the tail (see SalFA in art. Slw)] became lax, or flaccid, and her udder became large; like A^afak~at. (TA in art. fk. [See also the part. n., below.])

5 tfk~h *
He ate fruit (faAkihap): (Msb, K:) and He took fruit with his hand, [he helped himself to it;] syn. tanaAwala AlfaAkihapa: and hence, as is said in the A, (TA,) the saying in the Kur [lvi. 65], faZalotumo tafak~ahuwna is ironical, meaning [And then ye would be in the condition of] making your fruit to be your saying A_in~aA lamugoramuwna Verily we are burdened with debt (which words occur in the next verse)]: or tafak~aha here [or rather in a case of this kind] means He threw away from himself the fruit: thus says Ibn-'Ateeyeh, (K, TA,) in his exposition: (TA:) [but see other explanations in what follows:] and it signifies also He abstained from fruit: thus it bears two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b2- And sometimes [it means (tropical:) He amused himself with talk; like as one amuses himself with the eating of fruit after a meal; i. e.] Alt~afak~uhu is metaphorically used as meaning Alt~anaq~ulu biAlHadiyvi. (Bd in lvi. 65.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) He affected jesting, or joking. (TA.) ― -b4- And tfk~hwA bifulaAnK (assumed tropical:) They spoke evil of such a one; or did so in his absence; and defamed him; and did thus with jesting, one with another. (TA.) ― -b5- And tfk~h bihi (assumed tropical:) He enjoyed it: (S, Msb, K:) and [particularly] (Msb) he enjoyed the eating of it. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b6- And tfk~h also signifies (assumed tropical:) He wondered, (S, Msb, K,) minohu at it; and so ↓ fakiha, followed likewise by mnh. (K.) And hence [accord. to some] the saying in the Kur cited above, faZalotumo tafak~ahuwna i. e. (assumed tropical:) [And then ye would be in the condition of] wondering at what had befallen you in respect of your seed-produce. (TA.) ― -b7- And He repented, grieved, lamented, or regretted: (IAar, S, K:) and the words of the Kur cited in the last sentence above, (S, TA,) as expl. by some, (TA,) mean [And then ye would be in the condition of] repenting, &c.: (S, TA:) and so tafak~anuwna, which is of the dial. of 'Okl; or, accord. to Lh, Temeem say tatafak~anuwna, and AzdShanoo-ah say tatafak~ahuwna. (TA.)
6 tafaAkuhN * signifies The jesting, or joking, [or indulging in pleasantry, (see 3,) of a number of persons,] one with another, (K.) [You say, tfAkhwA They jested, &c., one with another.]

fakihN *
Eating, or an eater of, faAkihap [i. e. fruit]; (K, TA;) a possessive epithet; applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, Mgh, K,) and ↓ faAkihN, (K, TA, in the CK faAkihapN,) and ↓ fykhAn [app. fayokahaAnN or fayokihaAnN, like ty~ahaAnN], (AZ, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Cheerful, happy, or free from straitness; (AZ, S, Mgh, K;) jocose, or given to jesting, (AZ, S, Mgh,) and to laughing: (Mgh, K:) or the first, (K, TA,) and second, (K,) one who talks to his companions and makes them to laugh: (K, TA:) and fakihaAtN, applied to women, cheerful, happy, or free from straitness. (TA.) ― -b3- And fakihN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Exulting, or rejoicing above measure; or exulting greatly, and behaving insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (S, TA:) and thus the pl. fakihiyna signifies in the Kur (S, Mgh) xlix. 26 [as some there read]: (S:) ↓ faAkihiyna [is the more common reading and] means enjoying an easy and a pleasant life; or enjoying case and plenty. (S, Mgh.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Wondering: and thus some explain the pl. fakihuwna in the Kur xxxvi. 55. (TA.) ― -b5- huwa fakihN biA^aEoraADi Aln~aAsi means (tropical:) He is one who delights in speaking evil of men, or in doing so in their absence. (K, TA.)

[
fakiyho * is said by Golius to signify “ Qui proloqui non potest, ” on the authority of the KL: but in my copy of the KL, I find that the word to which this meaning is assigned is fahiyhN.]
fukaAhapN * , a subst. [as distinguished from the inf. n. fakaAhapN], (S, K,) A jesting, or joking; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ fakiyhapN. (K.)
fakiyhapN * : see what next precedes.

faAkihN *
Possessing faAkihap [i. e. fruit]; (K, TA:) an epithet of the same class as taAmirN and laAbinN: or, accord. to Aboo-Mo'ádh the grammarian, one whose fruit has become abundant. (TA.) ― -b2- See also fakihN, in two places. ― -b3- And [the fem.] faAkihapN, (assumed tropical:) A palm-tree (naxolapN) inducing wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy; or pleasing, or (??) joicing; [app. by its having much fruit;] syn. muEojibapN. (K.)

faAkihapN * a word of well-known meaning, (S,) Fruit, of any kind; (K;) a thing, or things, the eating whereof is enjoyed, (Mgh, Msb,) whether moist or dry, as figs and melons and raisins and pomegranates: (Msb:) [the words, of the Kur lv. 68, fiyhimaA faAkihapN wanaxolN warum~aAnN have caused it to be much and vainly disputed whether dates and pomegranates be, or be not, included among the things termed fAkhp: it seems to be the general opinion of the lexicologists that they are included; but the contrary opinion is held by many of the lawyers, and by the Imám Aboo- Haneefeh among them:] the pl. is fawaAkihu, meaning kinds thereof. (S.) ― -b2- And (by way of comparison [thereto], TA) (tropical:) Sweetmeat; syn. HalowaA='; (K;) which is also applied by some to “ fruit ” (fAkhp), (T in art. Hlw,) or to “ sweet fruit. ” (K in that art.) ― -b3- And faAkihapu Al$~itaA='i [lit. The fruit of winter] is metonymically used as meaning (tropical:) the fire. (Har p. 594.)
faAkihiY~N * : see faAkihaAniY~N.
fykhAn * :see fakihN, second sentence.

faAkihaAniY~N *
A seller of faAkihap [i. e. fruit]; (S, K;) as also ↓ faAkihiY~N; (TA;) but not fak~aAhN. (Sb, TA.)
kaAna mino A^afokahi Aln~aAsi * occurs in two trads. [as meaning (assumed tropical:) He was of the most cheerful and jocose of men]. (TA [in which the meaning is indicated by the context].)

A^ufokuwhapN *
i. q. A^uEojuwbapN (assumed tropical:) [A wonderful thing]. (K.) You say, jaA='a fulaAnN biA^ufokuwhapK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one did, or uttered, a wonderful thing]. (TA.)

mufokihN * (AZ, S, K) and mufokihapN (K) A she-camel whose milk is thick, (K, TA,) like biestings: (TA:) or that yields her milk plentifully on the occasion of eating the [herbage called] rabiyE, before her bringing forth: (S:) or whose milk pours forth on the occasion of parturition, before her bringing forth: or, accord. to Sh, the meaning is that indicated by the second explanation of the verb, 4 [q. v.]. (TA.)

1 fal~ahu * , (M, K,) aor.
falu3a , inf. n. fal~N, (M, TA,) He broke it, or notched it, in its edge, (M, K,) namely, [a sword or the like, or] anything; (M;) and so ↓ fll~`hu, (K, TA,) [or this signifies he did so much, or in many places,] inf. n. tafoliylN. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. kasarahu [app. as meaning He broke it, in an unrestricted sense; as well as in another sense; as will be shown by what follows]. (S.) walaA fal~uwA lahu SaqApF, i. e. [lit.] Nor did they break a stone (kasaruwA HajaraA) belonging to him, was said by 'Áïsheh in describing her father: she alluded thereby to his strength in religion. (TA. [See also qaraEa SafaAtahu, in art. Sfw; and see also magomazN.]) And [in like manner] one says, garobahu ↓ Astfl~ meaning kasarahu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He broke his sharpness, or vehemence, or valour]. (TA.) And fal~a Aljayo$a, (S, O, Msb,) or Alqawoma, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, O, Msb,) He defeated (hazama, S, M, O, K, or kasara, Msb) the army, or military force, (S, O, Msb,) or the people, or party. (M, K.) And mano qal~a *al~a wamano A^amirafal~a, (S, Meyd, O,) a prov., (Meyd, O,) meaning He who has few aiders is overcome, [or becomes abased], and he who has many relations [or who possesses authority to command] defeats (fal~a) his enemies. (Meyd. [In Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 683, a different (and I think a wrong) reading is given, with qal~a in the place of fal~a; though the reading with fal~a is added.]) $aj~aki A^awo fal~aki A^awo jamaEa kul~FA laki, in the story of Umm-Zara, is said to mean, Whether he wound thee by smiting thy head, or break a limb [of thee], or combine the two deeds to thee: or by fl~k is meant altercate, or wrangle, with thee: (TA, in two places:) or the meaning [of fl~k] is defeat thee [so I render kasaraki]; or take away thy property; or defeat thee (kasaraki) with his altercation and his censure. (O.) -A2- fal~a Eanohu Eaqoluhu, aor.
fala3a , [in the CK (erroneously)
