falu3a ,] His intellect, or intelligence, departed from him, and then returned. (M, K.)

2 fal~a3a see above, first sentence. ― -b2- tafoliylN [as inf. n. of the pass. v. ful~ila] means The state of being broken, or notched, [much, or in many places,] in the edge of a knife, or in the edges of the teeth, (T, TA,) and the like, (T,) [i. e.] and also in [the edge of] a sword. (TA.)

4 Afl~t AlA^aroDu *
The land became such as is termed fil~ [q. v.]. (AHn, M.) ― -b2- And A^afal~, (Fr, T,) and A^afolalonaA, (S, O,) He (a man, Fr, T,) and we, (S, O,) became in a land such as is termed fil~, (Fr, T, S, O,) upon which rain had not fallen: (Fr, T:) or the latter means we trod a land (M, K) such as is termed fil~ (M) or such as is termed fal~. (K.) ― -b3- And Afl~ (assumed tropical:) He (a man, S, M, O) lost, or became deprived of, his property: (S, M, O, K:) from fil~N applied to land. (M.) ― -b4- And in like manner, one says, Afl~ Ald~horu maAlahu (assumed tropical:) [Time, or fortune, deprived him of his property]. (O.)
5 tafal~a3a see the next paragraph, in three places: -A2- and see also R. Q. 1, in two places [in each of which the verb is most probably, I think, mistranscribed].

7 Anfl~ *
It became broken, or notched, in its edge; as also ↓ Aftl~, and ↓ tfl~l; (M, K, TA;) said of [a sword or the like, or of] anything; (M;) the first quasi-pass. of fal~ahu, as is also the second; but the third is quasi-pass of fl~alahu [and implying that it was so much, or in many places, or said of several things or of several parts of a thing]; (TA;) [therefore] one says [of a sword], maDaAribuhu ↓ tafal~alato, meaning takas~arato [i. e. Its edges (for the swords of the Arabs in the older times were generally two-edged), or its parts for striking, became broken, or notched, much, or in many places]; (S, TA;) and one says, Anfl~ sin~uhu, (T, TA,) meaning [simply] His tooth became broken, or notched, in its edge. (TA.) And Anfl~wA They became defeated; (S, * M, Msb, K;) as also ↓ tfl~lwA [but this has an intensive signification]. (M, K.)
8 A_ifotala3a see the next preceding paragraph.

10 A_isotafola3a see 1, former half. ― -b2- Astfl~ Al$~aYo'a He took of the thing the least portion, (M, K,) because of its difficulty (liEusorihi), (M,) or such as the tenth part thereof (kaEu$orihi): (K:) or AlAistifolaAlu signifies the obtaining a little thing from a difficult place; from a place of the seeking of a right, or due, or of a gift; it having no other object than a thing of little account. (T.)

R. Q. 1 falofala *
He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; (T, O, TA;) as also ↓ tafalofala: (TA:) or both signify he walked thus, with short steps: (K:) or ↓ tflfl signifies [simply] he went with short steps; (En-Nadr, O;) or so ↓ tfl~l. (T accord. to the TT.) -A2- And He rubbed and cleaned his teeth with the [stick called] siwaAk; (T, O, K;) as also ↓ tflfl; (IAar, O, K;) or so ↓ tfl~l. (T accord. to the TT.) -A3- flfl AlT~aEaAma and Al$~araAba He peppered the food and the wine or beverage. (M.) -A4- [And flfl Al$~aEara He made the hair very crisp, or such as we term woolly, like that of the negro: see the pass. part. n., below.]

R. Q. 2 tafalofala * : see R. Q. 1, in three places. -A2- Said of the hair of a negro, It became very crisp [or such as we term woolly]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And tflfl qaAdimataA AlD~aroEi The two anterior teats of the udder became black. (S, O, K.)

yaA fulu * , (S in this art. and in art. fln, and K and TA in the latter art.,) meaning yaA fulaAnu [O such a one], (S &c.,) with refa and without tenween, (TA,) is sometimes said to one person, [i. e. to a man,] and yaA fulaAni to two persons, and yaA fuluwna to a pl. number; and yaA fulapu to a female, and yaA fulataAni to two females, and yaA fulaAtu to a pl. number of females, (K, TA,) and sometimes yaA fulaApu, (K, * TA,) thus correctly, of the dial. of some of the tribe of Temeem, in the copies of the K erroneously written yA fulaAtu, (TA,) is said, and some say yaA fula, [in the CK yAflu, but correctly yAfula, i. e., as is said in the TA, binaSobi All~aAmi,] meaning yaA fulapu: (K, TA:) [J says,] yaA fulu, without teshdeed, said in calling to a person, is apocopated from yaA fulaAnu; not formed in the way of taroxiym, for if it were an instance of trxym they would say yaA fulaA: (S in this art.:) [or,] accord. to Sb, yaA fulu is not held to be an instance of a word from which is elided something that is retained when it is not [thus] used in calling to a person, but the noun in this case is made to be of two letters in the manner of damN [which is originally damawN or damFY or damoYN], and it is thus made to be of two letters because a word that is used in calling to a person or thing is a subject for elision: (M in this art.:) and sometimes ful was used otherwise than in calling to a person, by poetic license, as in the saying of Abu-n-Nejm,
fiY laj~apK A^amosiko fulaAnFA Eano fuli
(S and M in this art.,) meaning En fulaAnK [i. e. In, or amid, a multitude of cries, or noises: (thus expl. in the S:) withhold thou such a one from such a one]: (S in art. fln:) and Sb disallowed the saying fulu as meaning fulaAn [in the CK (erroneously) yA fulu as meaning yA fulaAnu] except [in the vocative form of speech and] in poetry: (M and K and TA in art. fln:) [but] they said [also] fulu bonu fuli, [said to be] an instance of an elision, (T and M in art. fln,) i. e. of the elision of a final w [accord. to some, who hold fulaAnN to be originally fulowaAnN]; (T;) like as they said haY~u bonu baY~K: (T, M:) and A^aYo fulo, with the l quiescent, occurs in a trad. respecting the resurrection; meaning yaA fulaAnu: (TA:) Ibn-Buzurj
says that some of the tribe of Asd [i. e. Asd or Asad] say yA fl [app. yaAfulu, without any variation,] in calling to a man and to two men and to a pl. number of men and to a female: (TA in art. fln:) accord. to As, one says yaA fulu and yaA fulaAho; he who says yaA fulu saying thus [when he pauses after it and] when he goes on, making the noun marfooa without tenween; whereas he who says yaAfulaAho says thus when he is silent after it, retaining the h [which is termed the h of pausation]. but when he goes on he rejects the h and makes the noun to be mansoob, saying [for ex.] yaA fulaA qulo [O such a one, say]. (T and TA in art. fln.) [See also muDam~anN (in art. Dmn), last sentence.]

fal~N *
A break, or notch, in the edge, (ISk, T, S, M, O, Msb, K,) of a sword, (ISk, T, S, O, Msb, K,) [or the like,] or of anything; (M;) and so ↓ fal~apN [i. e. a single break, or notch, in the edge,] of a sword: (TA:) pl. of the former fuluwlN, (ISk, T, S, M, O, Msb, K,) of which an ex. occurs in a verse cited voce bayoda: (O, TA:) it has been said that fuluwlN is an inf. n.; but it is more correctly said to be pl. of fal~N. (M.) ― -b2- And A portion that has fallen off from a thing, like the filings of gold and of silver, and the sparks of fire: (M, K, TA:) pl. fuluwlN. (M, TA.) -A2- And A company (M, K, TA) of men; (TA;) as also ↓ faliylN: (M, K, TA:) pl. of the former fuluwlN. (TA.) -A3- And it is [an epithet] applied to a number of men, (S, M, O, K, [in the CK in this case, erroneously, ful~N,]) and to a single man, (S, O,) signifying Defeated; (S, M, O, K;) and ↓ ful~aY also signifies thus, applied to a katiybap [i. e. a military force, or troop, &c.]; (AA, T, O, K;) like fur~aY: (AA, T, O:) one says rajulN fal~N and qawomN fal~N, and sometimes [when speaking of a number of men] they said fuluwlN and filaAlN; (S, O;) accord. to the copies of the K, the pl. is fuluwlN and A^afolaAlN; but correctly the latter is ful~aAlN, like rum~aAnN, as in the M; (TA;) [i. e.] the pl. is fuluwlN and ful~aAlN: and [of fal~N used in a pl. sense it is said that] it must be either a quasi-pl. n. or [originally] an inf. n.: if the former, the sing. should by rule be faAl~N, the case being like $aAribN and $arobN, [of which the former is a sing, and the latter is a quasi-pl. n.,] and faAl~N is of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: and flwl is not necessarily pl. of fal~N, but is rather pl. of faAl~N; for the pl. of the quasi-pl. n. is extr., like the pl. of the pl.: (M, TA: *) and as to fal~aAlN, it is necessarily pl. of faAl~N, for faEolN is not of the forms that have fuE~aAlN as the measure of a pl.: (M, TA:) if it [i. e. fal~N] be [originally] an inf. n., [this accounts for its being applied alike to a number of men and to a single man, which is not mentioned in the M, or] it is like nasojN in the sense of manosuwjN in the phrase nasoju Alyamani. (M.) -A4- Also Land affected with drought or barrenness; as also ↓ fil~N: or [i. e. the former accord. to the K, but app. each accord. to the text of the M as given in the TT,] such as is rained upon but does not produce plants or herbage: (AO, M, K:) or such as the rain has failed to fall upon during several years: or such as is not rained upon between two lands that have been rained upon: (M, K:) or, accord. to AO, this is termed xaTiyTapN; fl~ having the second of the meanings expl. in this sentence: (M:) or upon which rain has not fallen: (TA:) [in this sense, in the TT, as from the T, written fil [for ↓ fil~]: and so in the same, as from the T and M, in the sense here following:] or in which is nothing; (T, M, * K; *) so says IAar; whence, he adds, AlfalaApu; but [Az says] I do not think that it is taken thence: (T:) the pl. is like the sing., [or rather the word used as a sing. is likewise used as a pl.,] and A^afolaAlN, (M, K,) this pl. form being sometimes used: (M:) or the pl. of ↓ Alfil~u is A^afolaAlN; and one says also A^aroDN A^afolaAlN. (T.) -A5- And A sort of cloth made of the hard fibres of flax. (TA.)

fal~N * a term for yaAsamiyn muDaAEa* [Double jasmine], which is [rendered so] either biAlt~arokiyb [an expression meaning, as used in the present day, by grafting], or by slitting the stem thereof and inserting into it the [additional] jasmine [app. meaning by budding]: it is a flower of pure whiteness; and the rubbing oneself with its leaves perfumes the body: (TA:) [this name, or, more commonly, ↓ fil~, is now applied to the Arabian jasmine (jasminum sambac), or, as Forskål says (Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. cii.), nyctanthes sambac, mentioned by him among the plants cultivated in El-Yemen.] ― -b2- [Freytag, misled by the CK, has assigned to this word a meaning belonging to fal~N.]

fil~N * Land in which is no herbage; (K;) or land not rained upon, and in which is no herbage. (S, O.) See also fal~N, in three places. ― -b2- gadaA fil~FA mina AlT~aEaAmi, with kesr, means [He went forth early in the morning] devoid of food. (O.) ― -b3- And fil~N mina Alxayori occurs in a verse, (S, O,) in the poetry of 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Rawáhah and in that of Hassán, (S, O,) meaning Devoid of good. (S, TA.) [See Eal~N.] -A2- And Such as has become thin, of hair. (K.) -A3- See also ful~N.
fal~apN * : see fal~N, first sentence.
falalN * , in a sword [or the like], The state of having breaks, or notches, in the edge. (S, O.)

faliylN * : see A^afal~u. ― -b2- Applied to the tusk, or canine tooth, of a camel, Broken (S, M, O, K) in the edge. (S, O.) -A2- See also fal~N, first quarter. -A3- Also, and ↓ faliylapN, a quantity of hair collected together: (S, M, O, K:) the two words are either of the class of sal~N and sal~apN [which are exactly syn., each with the other,] or are an instance of the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] that does not differ from its sing. [or n. un.] except in [its not having] the [affix] p: (M:) in one instance, occurring in a trad., the latter is said to signify a kub~ap [or portion convolved, or glomerated, or formed into a ball] of hair, or, as Z says, app. of [the silk called] dimaqos: the pl. [of either] is falaAy^ilu. (TA.) Hence, (O,) ↓ faliylapN signifies also The mane of the lion. (O, TA.) In the saying of Sá'ideh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh,
waguwdira vaAwiyFA wataA^aw~abatohu
mu*ar~aEapN A^umayoma lahaA faliylu
[And he was left remaining, and a hyena having stripes upon its arms, (thus mu*ar~aEapN as used in this verse is expl. in the TA in art. *dE, q. v.,) a young mother, (A^umayoma being an instance of taroxiym, used by poetic license, for A^umayomapu, a dim. of A^um~N,) and therefore unusually fierce, having a mane, or having convolved, or glomerated, hair, came to him at night, or in the beginning of the night], the last word is expl. by Suh, in the R, as meaning the Earof [so in my original, an obvious mistranscription for Eurof, with damm]; but by Skr as meaning $aEar makobuwb. (TA.) ― -b2- And faliylN signifies also [The membranous fibres that grow at the base of the branches of the palm-tree, called] liyf: (M, K:) so in the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) and ↓ fulifulN signifies the same. (K.)
faliylapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
ful~aY * : see fal~ufil~y~apN, in the former half.

fil~iy~apN * , (T, * K, TA,) like Eil~iy~apN, (TA,) or fal~iy~apN, (O, *) [in the TT, as from the T, and in the O. written without the sign of teshdeed to the l (app. because it is sufficiently indicated by the heading of the art. and by the pl. of this word), and in the CK, erroneously, filoyap,] Land upon which the rain [that should have been that] of its year has not fallen until the falling of the rain of the next year upon it: pl. falaAliY~u: (ISh, T, O, K:) [and Az says,] I have heard them call thus (i. e. by the sing.) land in which is nothing; like fil~N as expl. by IAar. (T.)

fulofulN * , (S, M, O, Msb, K,) also pronounced ↓ filofilN, (K,) but the vulgar pronounce it [thus] with kesr, (O,) and the pronouncing it with kesr is said to be not allowable, (Msb,) a word of Pers. origin, (M,) arabicized, from PiloPil, with kesr, (O,) [or PuloPul; i. e. Pepper;] a sort of berry, (Hab~N, S, O, K,) brought from India, (O, K, *) well known, (S, M, O,) not growing in the land of the Arabs, but often mentioned in their language: AHn was informed by one who had seen it that its tree is just like the pomegranate; (M, TA;) but Dáwood the hakeem adds that it is taller; (TA;) between the pair of leaves thereof are two fruit-stalks, regularly disposed, each fruitstalk of the length of the finger; and it is green, and is then plucked, and spread in the shade, and becomes black and shrivelled; and it [the tree] has thorns, like those of the pomegranate: when it [i. e. the fruit] is fresh and moist, it is preserved
with water and salt until it becomes mature, when it is eaten like as preserved herbs are eaten upon the tables of food, and it is a digestive: the n. un. is ↓ fulofulapN [app. meaning a peppercorn, like Hab~apu fulofulK: and Hab~u fulofulK means peppercorns, collectively]: (M, TA:) Dáwood says, in the “ Tedhkireh, ” that its leaves are thin, red next the tree and green in the other direction, and its wood is lank and soft: and it is white and black: (TA:) the white is the better. (TA.) [A long description of its properties, with additions in the TA, some of them well known and others fanciful, I omit as being needless.] ― -b2- daArufuloful, or ↓ daArufilofil, (accord. to different copies of the K,) [app. daArufulofulN, or perhaps daArafulofulN, a compound of two words (both originally Pers.) made one, as such written in the K with the article (Ald~Arflfl), and perfectly declinable, because (although a compound of two nouns) it is not a proper name,] is The tree of the fuloful when it first bears fruit, accord. to the K; but several writers declare that the tree of [the] dAr flfl is not the same as the tree of the flfl: (MF, TA:) [dAr flfl is one of the names now applied to long pepper, and is commonly pronounced daArofilofilo:] it is [generally] known in Egypt by the name of Eiroqu Al*~ahabi, [another term, now used, for long pepper,] and is called in Pers. PlPl drAz [i. e. PuloPildaraAz, the latter of which words signifies “ long ”]: (TA:) it increases the venereal faculty, causes the food to digest; removes colic, (K, TA,) and flatulence; (TA;) and is beneficial as a remedy against the bite, or sting, of venomous reptiles, applied as a liniment, with oil. (K, TA.) ― -b3- fulofulN is also a name sometimes applied to The fruit of the barowaq [q. v., in art. brq]; likening it to the fulofulN mentioned before [i. e. to peppercorns]: he who pronounces it, when thus applied, ↓ filofilN errs; for this signifies the fruit of certain trees of the [kind called] EiDaAh; and the people of El-Yemen call thus [particularly] the fruit of the [species of EiDaAh. termed] gaAf [q. v.]. (M.) ― -b4- fulofulu AlmaA='i is the name of A certain plant growing in the neighbourhood of water, lank, soft, or smooth, in the leaves, having berries (Hab~i) in bunches. (TA.) ― -b5- fulofulu Alquruwdi is The same as Hb~ Allym [but what this is I do not find]. (TA.) ― -b6- fulofulu AlS~aqaAlibapi is What is called [in Pers.] fnjnk$t [i. e. fanojanoku$ot: see Alfaqodu]. (TA.) ― -b7- [falaAfilu is pl. of fulofulN.] And falaAfilu Als~uwdaAni is the name of Certain berries (Hab~), round and smooth, in sheaths, or cases, (guluf,) and in receptacles (A^aboyaAt) like the Sanawobar [or cone of the pine, app. in form]. (TA.) -A2- See also faliylN, last sentence. -A3- fulofulN signifies also A sharp, or clever, servant; (T, O, K;) and ↓ filofilN is said to signify thus likewise by Mullà 'Alee, in his “ Námoos, ” and even more commonly: but this requires consideration. (MF, TA.)
filofilN * : see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence: and the same again, in three places.
fulofulapN * n. un. of fulofulN; q. v., former half.

A^afol~u * , applied to a sword [or the like], (T, S, O, K,) Having breaks, or notches, in its edge; (T, S, * O; *) or broken, or notched, in its edge; as also ↓ mafoluwlN and ↓ munofal~N. (M, K.) AlA^afal~u was the name of a sword of 'Adee Ibn-Hátim (O, K) Et- Tá-ee. (O.)
mufal~alN * , applied to a naDiY~ [app. as meaning an arrow-head] Broken by having hit stones. (S.) And, applied to front teeth (vagorN) Serrated. (T.)
mafolawlN * : see A^afal~u.
munofal~N * : see A^afal~u.

mufalofalN * , applied to food, (TA,) and to wine, (T, TA,) [Peppered, i. e.] having fuloful put into it, (T, M, * TA,) and consequently burning the tongue: (T, TA:) or wine that burns [the tongue] like fuloful. (S, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with round forms resembling fuloful [or peppercorns] in roundness and smallness; (T, O, TA;) i. e. (TA) figured with the like of the SaEaAriyr [pl. of SuEoruwrapN] of fuloful. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- And Very crisp hair, [such as we term woolly,] (T, O, K, TA,) like that of the negro. (TA.) ― -b4- And A hide worn, or eroded, by the tan, (nahiakahu Ald~ibaAgu, M, K, in the CK nahakahu Ald~ab~Agu,) the like of fuloful [or peppercorns] appearing in it. (TA.)
1 falata * , intrans. and trans., syn. with A^afolata, q. v. (Msb.) See also 8.
3 fAlthu bihi * , (A, TA,) inf. n. mufaAlatapN (A, O, TA) and filaAtN, (O, K, TA,) He came upon him suddenly, at unawares, or unexpectedly, with it. (A, O, * K, * TA.)

4 Aflt * , (T, S, O, Msb, TA,) inf. n. A_ifolaAtN; (T, Msb, TA;) and ↓ Anflt; (T, S, O, TA;) and ↓ tfl~t; (S, O, TA;) and ↓ falata, aor.
falita , inf. n. falotN; (Msb;) signify the same; (T, S, O, Msb, TA;) i. e. He, or it, (a bird, &c., Msb, or a thing, S, O,) escaped; got away; or became, or got, loose, clear, quit, free, or at liberty; (O, Msb, TA;) [or did so] suddenly: (TA:) or A_ifolaAtN and ↓ AinofilaAtN and ↓ tafal~utN signify a thing's going forth suddenly: (Mgh:) or ↓ Anflt signifies he, or it, went forth quickly: (Msb:) and one says A^afolataniY, (M, K,) for Aflt min~iY [he escaped, &c., from me]; (Sgh, TA in art. jrE;) and mn~Y ↓ tfl~t, and ↓ Anflt; (M, K;) all signifying the same. (TA.) [See exs. voce juroEapN; and another ex. in art. HS, conj. 7.] ― -b2- See also 5. -A2- Aflthu; (T, S, M, O, Msb, K;) and ↓ 2, aor.
falita , inf. n. falotN; both verbs being trans. as well as intrans.; (Msb;) He made him, or it, [and he suffered him, or it,] (namely, a man, M, or a bird, &c., Msb,) to escape, or get away, or to become, or get, loose, clear, quit, free, or at liberty; he set him, or it, loose, free, or at liberty; (T, M, O, Msb, TA;) he saved him, or freed him, from destruction. (T, TA.) [See, again, HuroEapN.]

5 tafal~ata see 4, in three places. ― -b2- tfl~t EalayonaA, (Mgh,) or Ealayohi, (O, K, TA,) He seized, (Mgh, O, K, TA,) or came suddenly, (TA,) upon us, (Mgh,) or upon him. (O, K, TA.) Hence, in a trad. of Umm-Háni, fatafal~ata EalayohimaA liyaqotulahumaA [And he seized upon them both to slay them]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And tfl~t A_ilayohi He was desirous of it, or he longed for it; (M, O, K, TA;) as also ↓ A^afolata; namely, a thing. (M, TA.) Hence the saying, A^araAhu yatafal~atu A_ilaY SuHobatika [I see him to be desirous of thy companionship]. (TA.) And one says, laA A^araYlaka A^ano tatafal~ata A_ilaY h~*aA walaA A^ano tatafl~ata Eanohu [I am not of opinion that thou shouldst be desirous of this, nor that thou shouldst be averse from it]. (TA.)
7 A_inofalata see 4, in four places.

8 Aftlthu *
He took it quickly, or hastily; namely, a thing: (M, TA:) or he seized it, or carried it off, by force; or took it hastily and openly; or snatched it at unawares. (As, O.) And it is doubly trans.: you say, AifotalatahaA A@ll~`hu nafosahaA [God took away from her suddenly her soul]: and hence, Aufotulitato nafosahaA [lit. She had her soul taken away from her suddenly]; (O, TA;) a phrase occurring in a trad., (T, O, TA,) meaning she died suddenly, without disease: (T, TA:) you say, Aufotulita nafosahu, meaning He died suddenly; (M, TA;) and Aufotulita nafosuhu; (S, TA;) with the nfs in the accus. case and in the nom. case; (TA;) and Aufotulita alone; meaning he died suddenly. (S4, O, K, TA.) [See also Aufotuy^ita, in art. fA^t; and Aufotiyta in the same.] And Aifotalatahu Almawotu; and ↓ falatahu; as also lafatahu; Death took him away suddenly. (IAar, T, TA.) ― -b2- And Aufotulita biA^mori ka*aA He was taken suddenly by such a thing, before his preparing for it. (O, K, TA: omitted in the CK.) ― -b3- And Aufotuilta Ealayohi The affair was decided against him exclusively of him [i. e. without his having any part in the decision]. (TA.) [See also 8 in art. fwt.] ― -b4- Aufotulita also signifies It (any affair) was done without pausing. (T, TA.) ― -b5- And one says, Aifotalata AlkalaAma, meaning He extemporized the speech; spoke it without consideration, or thought, or preparation, or without pausing, or hesitating. (S, M, O, K.)

falatN *
Escape: one says, layosa laka mino h`*aA AlA^amori falatN There is no escape for thee from this affair, or event, or case. (En-Nadr, T, K, * TA. *)
fulatN * and ful~atN: see falataAnN.

falotapN *
A sudden, or an unexpected, event; or a thing that comes upon one suddenly, or at unawares: and anything done without consideration: (IAth, L, TA:) and an affair, or event, that happens without its being soundly, thoroughly, or well, performed or effected: pl. falataAtN: it has no broken pl.: (M, TA:) and falataAtN signifies
slips, or faults, of an assembly, or a company of men sitting together. (T, O, K, TA.) One says, maAta falotapN [He died suddenly]. (M.) And kaAna *`lika falotapF That (meaning an affair, or event, S, O) was sudden, or unexpected; (S, M, O, Msb, K, TA;) without premeditation, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) and without a wavering in opinion: (S, O, K, TA:) or, as some say, it was [like] a thing hastily and forcibly seized, or snatched: (L, TA:) and, accord. to some, it is derived from falotapN in the sense next following. (O, * TA.) ― -b2- The last night of any of the sacred months, of which night people differ as to whether it be lawful to war therein or not, wherefore the avenger of blood hastens to obtain retaliation. (O, TA:) or the last night of the month; (S, M, O, K, TA;) i. e., of any month: (S, O, K, TA:) or the last day of a month after which is a sacred month; (S, M, O, K, TA;) as the last of Jumáda-l-Ákhireh; because a man might see therein him on whom he would take his blood-revenge, and if he delayed to do so, and the next day arrived, the sacred month commenced, and the opportunity escaped him: (M, TA:) or an hour observed by the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance; namely, the last hour of the last day of Jumáda-l-Ákhireh: they made hostile attacks, or incursions, during this hour, even when the new moon of Rejeb had risen: Rejeb not commencing until sunset: (AHeyth, T, TA:) or layolapu falotapK (or accord. to MF layolapu Alfalotapi, TA,) the night by [the deducting of] which the month becomes deficient, and by [the addition of] which it becomes complete; for sometimes some persons see the new moon when others do not see it, and these latter make a hostile attack, or incursion, upon the others; and it is thus called because it is like a thing that has been let loose after having been bound. (M, TA.) -A2- See also faluwtN.
fulatapN * : see the next paragraph.
filotaAnN * : see the next paragraph.

falataAnN *
i. q. tafal~utN: (M:) [or] it is from Alt~afal~utu, (T,) like SalataAnN (T, S) from AlAinoSilaAtu: (T:) an epithet signifying Brisk, lively, or sprightly, (Lth, T, S, O, K,) and sharp of spirit; (Lth, T, S, O;) applied to a man, (Lth, T,) or to a horse, (S, O,) as also ↓ fulatN and ↓ ful~atN and ↓ filotaAnN, (O,) the last of which is said by Kr to be pl. of falataAnN signifying swift, fleet, or quick; (M;) or all are applied in this latter sense to a horse: (K:) and ↓ fulatapN kulatapN, applied to a horse, that leaps, springs, or bounds, with his whole body and limbs. (K in art. klt.) Also, i. e. falataAnN, Strong, sturdy, hard, or hardy; (T, O, K; *) applied to a man. (T, O.) And Bold, or daring; (T, O, K;) applied to a man: (T:) and so falataAnapN applied to a woman. (T, O.) And Desirous of evil, or mischief. (M, TA.) And, some say, Fleshy; having much flesh. (M.) -A2- Also A certain bird, (M, K, TA,) of which they assert that it preys upon birds, (M,) or that preys upon apes, or monkeys, (K, TA,) said by AHát to be the zum~aj, (TA,) which, accord. to him, is the male eagle: (TA in art. zmj:) it is of a colour inclining to yellow; and sometimes it seizes the lamb, or kid, and the young child: thus in the “ Hayát el- Hayawán ” &c. (TA.)

faluwtN * A garment of which the two edges cannot be drawn together, by reason of its smallness; (A'Obeyd, T, S, O, K:) of which the two edges cannot be drawn together in the hand, (M, L,) so that they escape from the hand of the wearer when he wraps himself in the garment: (L:) applied as an epithet to a burodap, as also ↓ falotapN: (O, L:) or faluwtN signifies a garment that does not remain fixedly upon its wearer, by reason of its roughness or coarseness, or its smoothness or softness. (IAar, O.)
munofalitN * , for which one should not say mufolitN, as an epithet applied to a camel, That has got loose (ISh, T.)

1 falaja * , aor.
faluja , (S, M, O, L, Msb, K,) and
falija , (K,) or the latter only [when the verb is trans. as] in falaja Alqawoma, (TA,) inf. n. falojN, (S, O, K,) or fuluwjN, (Msb,) or both, and, accord. to Kr, fulojN and falajN, but it is said in the L that these two are simple substs: (TA;) and ↓ Aflj, inf. n. A_ifolaAjN; (K, TA;) the latter verb authorized by AO and Ktr and others, but omitted by Th in the Fs; (TA;) He succeeded; succeeded in an enterprise or a contest; overcame, conquered, or gained a victory: (S, O, K, &c.:) or he attained his object; gained what he sought. (Msb.) One says, mano yaA^oti AlHakama waHodhu yafolujo [He who comes to the judge by himself will succeed, or overcome, or gain his cause]: a proverb. (S, O.) And falaja EalaY xaSomihi, (S, O,) and ↓ Aflj, (TA,) He (a man) succeeded against, or overcame, his adversary; (S, O, TA;) and got before him, or got precedence of him. (TA.) And falaja biHuj~atihi, (Msb, TA,) and fiY Huj~atihi, (TA,) He established, (Msb,) or he overcame by and in, (TA,) his argument, plea, allegation, or proof. (Msb, TA.) And falajato Huj~atuhu [His argument, &c., was successful]. (A.) And falaja sahomuhu, and ↓ Aflj, His arrow was successful. (O, TA.) And falajato biqalobiY She (a woman) took away [or captivated] my heart. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And falaja Alqawoma, in which case only one says yafoluju and yafoliju, and falaja A^aSoHaAbaha, He (a man) succeeded against, or overcame, the people, or party, and his companions. (TA.) ― -b3- falaja, aor.
falija , (S, M, O, L, K,) and
faluja , (K,) or the former only, (MF. TA,) inf. n. falojN, He divided a thing; parted it; divided it in parts or shares; or distributed it: (S, O, K;) as also ↓ fl~j, inf. n. tafoliyjN: (O, K:) he divided property, (Mgh, TA,) or running water: (TA:) and he divided a thing in halves. (M, L, Msb, TA.) One says, falajatu Al$~aYo'a bayonahumo I divided, parted, or distributed, the thing between them, or among them. (S, O.) And falaja Al$~aYo'a bayonahumaA He divided the thing between them two in halves. (M, L, TA.) And falajotu A^alofFA, aor.
falija , inf. n. falojN and fuluwjN, I divided, parted, or distributed, a thousand [dirhems] by means of the filoj, a well-known measure of capacity. (Msb.) ― -b4- And falajotu Al$~aYo'a, (S, Msb, K, *) aor. in this case and in other cases following
faluja and
falija , (K,) or
faluja only, (TA,) [but it is implied in the S and O and Msb that it is
falija ,] inf. n. falojN, (K,) I split the thing, clave it, or divided it lengthwise: (S, O:) or I split the thing, &c., into two halves: (Msb, K:) or falajotu Al$~aYo'a falojayoni has this latter meaning. (S, O.) ― -b5- And falajotu AlA^aroDa lilz~iraAEapi, (S, O, K, *) inf. n. falojN, (K,) [like falaHotuhaA,] I furrowed, or ploughed, the land for sowing. (S, O, K.) ― -b6- And huwa yafoluju AlA^amora He looks into, and divides, or distributes, and manages, the thing, or affair. (L, TA.) ― -b7- And falaja, inf. n. falojN, He imposed the [tax called] jizuyap. (K.) One says, falaja Aljizoyapa EalaY Alqawomi, (T, S, Mgh, * O, &c.,) and falaja Alqawoma, (TA,) He imposed the jzyp upon the people, or party; (T, S, Mgh, O, &c.:) he di(??) the jzyp among the people, or party, (??) upon each person his portion: (As, Mgh; *) and falaja Aljizoyapa bayonahumo: (A:) [said to be] from filojN, or faAlijN, (As, Mgh,) or AlqafiyzuAlfaAliju; (A'Obeyd, S, O;) signifying a certain measure of capacity; because the jzyh used to he paid in wheat, or corn: (As, Mgh:) or the verb in this sense (??) arabicized word. (Shifá el-Ghaleel.) -A2- falija, aor.
falaja , inf. n. falajN and falajapN, He had what is termed falajN, meaning [as expl. below, i. e.] width. between the teeth, and feet [or legs, and arms], &c. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- falija, (Th, S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. faAlijN, one of the [few] inf. as. of the measure faAEilN; (ISd, TA;) and falija, aor.
falaja , mentioned by IKtt and Es-Sarakustee and others; (MF, TA;) but the former alone is mentioned by Th in the Fs, and by other celebrated lexicologists; (TA;) [and vulg. ↓ Anfj;] He had the disease termed AlfaAliju [expl. below]. (Th, S, O. Msb, K.)
2 fal~aja see 1, former half: ― -b2- and see also falajN, in two places.

3 fAljhu *
He contended with him, trying which of them should succeed, or overcome. (TA.) Hence one says, (TA,) A^ufaAlijuka A^umuwrFA mina AlHaq~i I will contend with thee, trying which of us shall succeed, to accomplish affairs of right. (A, TA.)

4 Aflj * as intrans.: see 1, former half, in three places. -A2- Afljhu A@ll~`hu Ealayohi God made him to succeed against him; to overcome him, conquer him, or gain the victory over him: (S, O, K: *) and made him to excel him. (TA.) ― -b2- And xaASayotu
faA^afolajanaY I contended in an altercation, disputed, or litigated, and he decided in my favour, and judged me to have prevailed against, or overcome, my adversary. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- And Aflj A@ll~`hu Huj~atahu, (S, O, Msb,) or burohaAnahu, (K, *) God made his argument, plea, allegation, or proof, right, and manifest, or clear: (S, O, K: *) or established it. (Msb.)

5 tfl~jt qadamuhu *
His foot became cracked, or chapped. (S, O, K.) [See also mutafal~iH, in art. flH.] ― -b2- [And tfl~jt said of a woman, She made open spaces between her front teeth: see the part. n., voce A^afolaju.]

7 Anflj AlS~uboHu *
i. q. Anblj [The daybreak shone, or shone brightly]. (TA.) -A2- See also 1, last sentence.

10 Astflj fulaAnN biA^amorihi *
Such a one mastered, or became master of, his affair: and so AstflH, with H. (A, TA.) [See the latter verb.]

falojN * an inf. n. of falaja [q. v.]. (S, O, K, &c.) ― -b2- And [probably as such] i. q. qamorN [app. as meaning An overcoming in a game of hazard]; as also ↓ fulojN. (L.) -A2- See also faAlijN, in two places. -A3- Also, and ↓ filojN, (S, O, K,) and ↓ fuluj~N, [q. v.,] (Seer, L,) [or perhaps this is a mistranscription for falojN or filojN,] The half of a thing: (S, O, K:) pl. of the first and second fuluwjN. (S, O.) One says, humaA falojaAni They two are two halves. (K.) ― -b2- And one says, fiY rijolihi fuluwjN, [pl. of falojN,] In his foot are fissures, or cracks; as also fuluwHN. (S in art. flH.) ― -b3- See also falajN.

fulojN * (S, O, K) and ↓ falajN (L) and ↓ fulojapN, (O, K,) substs., (or, accord. to some, the first and second are inf. ns., TA,) Success; success in an enterprise or a contest; conquest; or victory. (S, O, L, K.) One says, limana Alfuloju and ↓ Alfalaju To whom belongs success, or the conquest, or victory? (Lh, L.) ― -b2- See also falojN.

filojN * : see falojN. ― -b2- Also, (S, O, Msb, K,) and ↓ faAlijN, (TA,) or qafiyzN faAlijN, (AO, S, O,) A certain measure of capacity, (AO, S, O, Msb, K,) well known, (Msb, K,) with which things are divided, (TA,) of large size, said to be the same as the qafiyz [q. v.]; and ↓ faAlijN is said to be an arabicized word, from the Syriac fAlgA: (L: [but see fuluj~N:]) it is said that the ↓ faAlij [thus in my copy of the Mgh, but it is there strangely added that it is “ with fet-h, ” as though faAlaj,] is two fifths of what is termed Alkur~u AlmuEad~alu, [see art. kr,] and, by 'Alee Ibn-'Eesà, that it is larger than the filoj: in the T, the ↓ faAlij is said to be the half of the great kur~; and the filoj is the measure of capacity that is called in Syriac faAlagaA. (Mgh.)

falajN * : see fulojN, in two places. -A2- It is also an inf. n. of falija [q. v.]: (Lh, TA:) and signifies Distance, or width, between the teeth; (K;) as also ↓ tafoliyjN: (TA:) or, between the medial and lateral incisors, (T, S, O,) when natural; and tafoliyjN, distance, or width, between those teeth when it is the effect of art. (T.) falajN in all the teeth is disapproved, and not at all beautiful; but it is esteemed goodly when only between the two middle teeth. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Distance, or width, between the feet, (Lth, O, K, TA,) in the posterior direction: (O, TA:) or, between the shanks; like faHajN: (ISd, TA:) or crookedness, or curvature, [or a bowing outwards,] of the arms. (TA. [See A^afolaju.]) And The turning over of the foot upon the outer side, and displacement of the heel; in a neuter sense. (L.) -A3- Also, (S, K,) and, accord. to the S, falojN, but this is a mistake, (IB, K,) A river: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or a small river: (S, O, K:) a rivulet, or streamlet; syn. jadowalN: (A:) or a running spring of water: or running water: (R, TA:) or a large well: (Ibn-Kunáseh, TA:) pl. A^afolaAjN (S, O) and falajaAtN (R, TA) [or fulojaAnN, for] fulojaAnN signifies rivulets, streamlets, or small channels, for the irrigation of seed-produce: and ↓ fulujN, with two dammehs, signifies a rivulet, streamlet, or small channel, for irrigation, running to every part of a garden. (L.) ― -b2- falajN is also sometimes used as an epithet: one says maA='N falajN meaning Running water: and EayonN falajN a running spring of water. (L.) -A4- And Alfalaju signifies The daybreak. (TA.)
falijN * [part. n. of falija]: see an ex. voce A^afolaju.
fulujN * : see falajN, last sentence but two. ― -b2- It is also a pl. of faliyjN [q. v. voce faliyjapN].
falojapN * : see faliyjapN.
fulojapN * : see fulojN.

falajaAtN *
Fields, or lands, sown, or for sowing. (TA. [See also falaHapN, in art. flH.]) ― -b2- See also falajN, last sentence but two.

fuluj~N * , [thus in the L,] accord. to Sb, A sort of men: one says, Aln~aAsu fuluj~aAni The people, or men, are two sorts; [for ex.,] consisting of entering and going out: [but I think it most probable that fuluj~N and fuluj~aAni are mistranscriptions for filojN and filojaAni, for] Seer says that flj signifying “ a half ” and “ a sort ” is derived from filojN syn. with qafiyzN: thus he makes filojN an Arabic word. (L.) See also falojN.

filojaAnN * , [said to be] from filojN signifying “ a certain measure of capacity, ” [but app. from the Pers. finojaAn,] A [small porcelain or earthenware] cup out of which coffee &c. is drunk; commonly pronounced by the vulgar finojaAn and finojaAl [from the Pers. PinoGaAn and PinoGaAl, and also called ↓ filojaAnapN, vulgarly finojaAnap; and ↓ fiyaAlajap: (see sawomalapN:) pl. falaAjiynu and fanaAjiynu and fanaAjiylu]. (TA.)
filojaAnapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
faliyjN * : see the paragraph here following.

falyijapN *
One of the oblong pieces of cloth of a tent: (TA:) or, of a [tent of the kind called] xibaA=': (As, S, O, K:) As says, I know not in what part it is: (TA:) ↓ faliyjN appears to be used for it by poetic license; or the word may be one of those pronounced with and without p; or without p it may be a pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is with p: (M, TA:) [or] faliyjN signifies a single oblong piece of a bijaAd [q. v.]; and its pl. is fulujN: (L and TA in art. bjd:) and [in like manner] ↓ falojapN signifies a piece of a bijaAd. (TA in the present art.) ― -b2- See also faliyHapN, with H.

fal~uwjN *
A writer. (Ibn-Jembeh, O, K.) And A manager and reckoner: from the phrase huwa yafoluju AlA^amora, expl. above. (TA.)

fal~uwjapN *
Land that is put into a right, or proper, state for sowing; (S, O, K;) good, clear, land prepared for sowing: (TA:) pl. falaAliyju. (S, O, K.) And [hence, app.,] Any one town, or village, of the Sawád: (O, K: *) pl. as above. (O.)

rajulN faAlijN fiY Huj~atihi *
A man who succeeds, or overcomes, in his argument, plea, allegation, or the like; as also ↓ falojN. (TA.) And Als~ahomu AlfaAliju The arrow that is successful: (S, O, K:) the winning arrow in the game called Almayosir: or it may mean the arrow that is successful in a contest at archery. (TA.) -A2- See also filojN, in four places. ― -b2- faAlijN (S, O, L, K) and ↓ falojN (L) also signify A large, or bulky, camel, with two humps, that is brought from Es-Sind for the purpose of covering: (S, O, * K:) or a camel with two humps, between the Bukhtee (AlbuxotiY~) and the Arabian: so called because his hump is divided in halves, or because his two humps have different inclinations: (L:) pl. of the former fawaAliju. (S, M, K; all in art. Sr.) ― -b3- And AlfaAliju signifies [Palsy, or paralysis, whether partial or general; hemiplegia or paraplegia:] a disease arising from a flaccidity in one of the lateral halves of the body; (A;) or a flaccidity in one of the lateral halves of the body, (K, TA,) arising suddenly, (TA,) occasioned by an efflux of a phlegmatic humour, and causing the passages of the spirit to become obstructed; (K, TA;) this being its first effect; it deprives the patient of his senses and his motion; and is sometimes in one member: (TA:) or a flatus (riyHN S, O, L, TA) which attacks a man, and deprives him [of the use] of one lateral half of the body; (thus in the L, and the like is said in the 'Eyn; TA;) whence it is thus called:
(IDrd, S, O:) or a disease that arises in one of the lateral halves of the body, occasioning the loss of the senses and of motion, and sometimes in both lateral halves, and sudden in its attack; on the seventh [day] it is dangerous; but when it has passed the seventh, its acuteness ceases; and when it has passed the fourteenth, it becomes a chronic disease: (Msb:) it is called in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh daA='u AlA^anobiyaA='i [the disease of the prophets]: and is said by Et-Tedmuree, in the Expos. of the Fs, to be a disease that attacks a man when the venters (buTuwn) of the brain become filled with certain moistures, or humours, occasioning the loss of sensation and of the motions of the members, and rendering the patient like a dead person, understanding nothing. (TA.) -A3- A^anaA mino h`*aA AlA^amori faAliju bonu xalaAwapa, or kafaAliji boni xalaAwapa, is a saying expl. in art. xlw.

fayolajN * [The cocoon of a silk-worm;] the thing from which qaz~ is obtained: an arabicized word; [from the Pers. Piylaho pélah; but said to be] originally fayolaq, and thus some pronounce it. (Msb,)

fiyaAlajapN * : see filojaAnN. [fayaAlijap occurs in art. qz in the TA, as its pl.; being there expl. as meaning small cups (fanaAjiyn) in which wine ($araAb) is drunk: but I think that this may be taken from a mistranscription for fiyaAlajap.]

A^afolaju * , (TA,) or A^afolaju AlA^asonaAni, (S, Mgh, O, K, TA,) applied to a man, and falojaA='u AlA^asonaAni applied to a woman, (S, O,) for the teeth must be mentioned, (IDrd, S, O, K,) [but MF disputes this,] and AlA^asonaAni ↓ mufal~aju, applied to a man, accord. to one reading of a trad., (TA,) Having the teeth separate, one from another: (TA:) or, distant, or wide apart, one from another: (Mgh, * K:) or having the medial and lateral incisors distant, one from another, or wide apart. (S, O.) [See also A^aforaqu.] And Alv~anaAyaA ↓ mufal~aju A man having an interstice between the middle pair of teeth; (S, O, K;) as also Alv~anaAyaA ↓ faliju; (A;) contr. of mutaraAS~u Alv~anaAyaA. (S, O.) And ↓ mutafal~ijapN A woman that makes open spaces between her front teeth, for the purpose of improving their appearance. (L, from a trad., in which a curse is pronounced against her who does this.) And vagorN A^afolaju Front teeth that are separate, or distant, or wide apart, one from another; and ↓ mufal~ajN signifies the same [app. when they are rendered so artificially: see falajN]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^afolaju applied to a man, Having a crookedness, or curvature, [or bowing outwards,] in the arms: when it is in the legs, the person is termed A^afoHaju: (L:) or wide between the arms: (O, K:) or wide between the paps; (S, L;) which last explanation is said in the K to be erroneous; but he who is wide between the paps is also wide between the arms. (MF.) ― -b3- hinN A^afolaju A vulva, of a woman, whereof the labia majora are wide apart. (L.) ― -b4- farasN A^afolaju A horse having the prominent parts of the haunch-bones wide apart. (IDrd, O, L.)

[
A^afolajiY~N *
Having the fingers wide apart. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
mufolajN * [Rendered] successful, or victorious; and safe, or secure. (KL.) [See also its verb.]
mufal~ajN * : see A^afolaju, in three places. ― -b2- A^amorN mufal~ajN An affair not rightly disposed or directed. (O, K.)

mafoluwjN *
Having the disease termed AlfaAlijN. (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K.)
mutafal~ijapN * : see A^afolaju.

1 falaHa * , aor.
falaHa , inf. n. faloHN, He clave, split, slit, or cracked; and he cut: (K: [compare falaja, and falaqa, and fala*a:]) he clave, and cut, iron. (T, Msb.) Hence, the saying of a poet, (T, TA,)
A_in~a AlHadiyda biAlHadiydi yufolaHu
Verily iron with iron is cloven, and cut. (T, S, Mgh, * K. *) And falaHa raA^osahu, inf. n. as above, He clave, split, or cracked, his head. (TA.) And falaHa $afatahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, He slit, or cracked, his lip. (L.) And falaHa AlA^aroDa, (S, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb.) He furrowed, or ploughed, the land, to cultivate it; he tilled the ground. (S, Msb. [And falajahaA has a similar meaning.]) -A2- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He acted with artifice, fraud, or guile; (K, TA;) and so ↓ fl~H, inf. n. tafoliyHN. (K, TA.) You say, bihimo ↓ fl~H He acted with artifice, fraud, or guile, towards them, and said what was not true. (TA.) And bihi ↓ fl~H He mocked at him, or derided him, and acted with artifice, fraud, or guile, towards him. (L, K. *) ― -b2- And, aor. as above, inf. n. faloHN and falaAHapN, He defrauded him in a sale; syn. of the inf. n. baxosN fiY bayoEK: (so in the CK:) or he bade high for an article of merchandise in order to inveigh another into purchasing it at a high price: syn. of the inf. n. najo$N fiY bayoEK. (So in other copies of the K, and in the L and TA.) You say, falaHa bihi [He so acted towards him in a sale]: this is when one trusts to thee, and says to thee, “ Sell to me a slave, ” or “ an article of merchandise, ” or “ buy it for me, ” and thou comest to the merchants, and buyest it at a high price, and sellest by defrauding, and obtainest something from the merchant: or, accord. to the T, faloHN signifies a hirer's exceeding [in an offer] in order that another may do so; thus inciting him. (L.) -A3- faliHato $afatuhu Als~ufolaY, [aor.
falaHa ,] inf. n. falaHN, His under lip was slit, or cracked. (MA.) See also falaHN below.
2 fal~aHa see 1, former half, in three places.

4 AflH *
He prospered; was successful; attained, or acquired, that which he desired or sought, (MA, L, Msb,) or what was good, or felicity, or that whereby he became in a happy and good state: (L:) he was, or became, fortunate, happy, or in a happy and good state. (MA.) It is commonly known as an intrans. verb; but Talhah Ibn-Musarrif and 'Amr Ibn-'Obeyd, read qado A^ufoliHa A@lomuw^ominuwna, [the first verse of ch. xxiii. of the Kur-án,] with the verb in the pass. form. (MF.) [See also 10.] ― -b2- He was, or became, in a state of safety. (L.) ― -b3- He continued in a good, or prosperous, state, (MA, L,) and in the enjoyment of ease, comfort, or the blessings of life. (L.) ― -b4- AflH biAl$~aYo'i He lived [or continued in life] by means of the thing. (K.) The saying of 'Abeed,
A^afoliHo bimaA $iy^ota faqado yubolagu biA@??
(??) waqado yuxad~aEu AlA^ariybu
means Live thou by what thou wilt: whether by stupidity or by intelligence; for [one's object is sometimes attained by stupidity, and the intelligent, or sagacious, is sometimes deluded, or much deluded; or] the stupid is sometimes supplied with the means of subsistence, and the intelligent is [sometimes] denied: (T, L:) or the meaning is prosper thou, &c. (L.)

10 AisotafoliHiY biA^amoriki * , said by a man to his wife, (S,) a form of words used in divorcing (L, K) in the Time of Ignorance, (L,) Prosper thou in thy case, (AO, S, Mgh, TA,) and be independent therein: (AO, Mgh, TA:) when a man says thus to his wife and she consents, his saying so once separates her from him so that he cannot take her back: (L, from a trad.:) but as it is merely an allusive expression, intention is necessary to render it binding: as some relate the trad, it is with j [i. e. AstfljY: see art. flj]. (MF.) [See also 4, above.]

faloHN *
A fissure, cleft, slit, or crack: pl. fuluwHN. (Msb.) One says, fiY rijolihi fuluwHN In his (a man's, S) foot are fissures, or cracks, (S, K, TA,) preduced by cold: (TA:) as also fuluwjN. (S, TA.)

falaHN *
A fissure, or crack, in the under lip; (T, K;) [or] ↓ falaHapN has this meaning; (S;) or signifies the place of such a fissure or crack: (L:) [or the former is a coll. gen. n.; and the latter, its n. un.:] that which is in the upper lip is termed EalamN: (T, TA:) or falaHN signifies a fissure, or crack, in the lip: or, in the middle of the lip, less than what is termed EalamN: or a slitting, or cracking, in the lip, such as happens to the lips of the [Africans called] zanoj. (L.) ― -b2- [And] The having the under lip slit, or cracked. (S. [App. an inf. n. of which the verb is ↓ faliHa: like as it is of faliHat said of the under lip as mentioned above.]) -A2- See also falaAHN.

falaHapN * : see falaHN. ― -b2- Also A [field, or land, such as is termed] qaraAH, (AHn, L, K,) furrowed, or ploughed, for cultivation: its pl., falaHaAt, occurs in a verse of Hassán, as some relate it; but
as others relate it, it is falajaAt, with j. (AHn, L.)

falaAHN * (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ falaHN (S, L, K) the latter a contraction of the former, (L,) Prosperity; success; the attainment, or acquisition, of that which one desires or seeks, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) or of that whereby one becomes in a happy and good state. (L.) And Safety, or security. (S, L, K.) And Continuance, or permanence, in a good, or prosperous, state, (A, L, K,) and in the enjoyment of ease, comfort, or the blessings of life; and the continuance of good: (L:) and simply continuance, permanence, lastingness, duration, or endurance. (ISK, S, L.) There is not in the language of the Arabs any word more comprehensive in its significations of what is good in the present life and in the final state than AlfalaAHu. (TA.) HaY~a EalaY AlfalaAHo, in the call to prayer, means Come ye to the means of the attainment of Paradise, and of permanence therein: (IAth, L:) or hasten to the attainment of everlasting life: (L:) or come to safety, or security: (S:) or come ye to the way of safety and prosperity: (Msb:) or come to the continuance of good. (L.) And you say, laA A^afoEalu *`lika falaAHa Ald~ahori I will not do that while time lasts. (L.) A poet says,
wal`kino layosa lild~unoyaA falaAHu
meaning [But there is not to the present state of existence] lastingness, or endurance. (S, L.) ― -b2- Also (both words) (tropical:) The [meal, or food, called] saHuwr [that is eaten a little before daybreak previously to commencing a day's fast]: (S, A, L, K:) so called because thereby is the continuing of the fast; (S, A;) or because of the lastingness of its utility. (L.)
falaAHapN * : see what next follows.

filaAHapN * , (thus in my copies of the S, and in the L and Msb,) with kesr, (Msb,) [agreeably with general analogy,] or ↓ falaAHapN, with fet-h, (K, [but I think that fet-h is here a mistake for kesr, because falaAHahN deviates from general analogy, and because it is a general rule of the author of the K to omit the mention of the vowel of a word when it is fet-h,]) Agriculture; or the art, work, or occupation, of ploughing, tilling, or cultivating, land. (S, L, Msb, K.)
faliyHapN * The pericarp (sinofap) of the [tree called] marox, when it splits: (K, TA:) also mentioned as with j [i. e. faliyjapN]. (TA.)

fal~aAHN *
A plougher, tiller, or cultivator, of land; [a peasant;] (S, Msb, K, TA;) because he cleaves (yafolaHu i. e. ya$uq~u) the land: (TA:) [pl. fal~aAHuwna:] coll. gen. n. fal~aAHapN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence, as being likened to a plougher,] A seaman, or sailor; (K, TA;) a servant of ships or boats. (TA.) ― -b3- And One who lets asses, or other beasts, on hire; syn. mukaArK: (T, K, TA:) so called as being likened to the plougher, &c., of land. (TA.) -A2- And One who defrauds in a sale, in the manner described in the explanation of the phrase falaHa bihi. (L.)

A^afolaHu *
Having a fissure, or crack, in the under lip: (S, Mgh:) or a man having what is termed falaHN in his lip: fem. faloHaA='u. (L.) 'Antarah El- 'Absee was surnamed AlfaloHaA='u because of a fissure in his under lip; the fem. form of the epithet being used because Al$~afapu (the lip) is fem.; (S, L;) or because his name is fem. (L.) [See also A^aEolamu.]

qawomN A^afolaAHN * [i. q. mufoliHuwna] A people prospering; successful; attaining, or acquiring, that which they desire or seek, or what is good, or that whereby they become in a happy and good state: AflAH is a pl. of which ISd says, “ I know not any sing. of it. ” (L.)

mafolaHapN *
A cause, or means, of prosperity or success; or of the attainment, or acquisition, of that which one desires or seeks, or of what is good, or of that whereby one becomes in a happy and good state. (L, from a trad.)
rajulN mutafal~iHu Al$~afapi * , and Alyadayoni, and Alqadamayoni, A man having the lip chapped, or cracked, much, by cold, and so the hands, and the feet. (L.) [See also 5 in art. flj.]

1 fala*a * , aor.
fali*a , inf. n. falo*N, He cut, or cut off. (Msb.) One says, fala*a lahu qiToEapF mina AlmaAli He cut off for him a portion of the property: (T:) and fala*otu lahu mino maAliY, (S, M, O, L,) aor. as above, (M, L,) and so the inf. n., (M, L, K,) I cut off for him [a portion] of my property: (S, O, L:) or gave him [a portion] of it at once: or gave him [a portion] of it without delay, and without promising: or gave him much thereof. (M, L, K. *) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

2 fl~* * , (T, L,) inf. n. tafoliy*N; (T, O, L, K;) as also ↓ fala*a, inf. n. falo*N; (L, TA;) He cut in pieces (T, O, L, K) flesh-meat. (T, L.) Hence, in a trad., kabidahu ↓ A_in~a Alfaraqa mina Aln~aAri fala*a [Verily the fear of the fire of Hell cut in pieces his liver; but perhaps fala*a is here a mistranscription for fal~a*a]; said, by the Prophet, of one who had died from fear of the fire [of Hell]. (L.)

3 fAl* Aln~isaA='a * , inf. n. mufaAla*apN, He bandied words, or held colloquies, with women. (O, * K.) One says, fulaAnN *uw muTaAraHapK wamufaAla*apK Such a one has a habit of bandying words, &c., with women. (K, * TA.)

8 Aftl* minohu qiToEapF mina AlmaAli *
He cut off, or took, for himself, from him, a part, or portion, of the property. (T.) And Aifotala*otu minohu Haq~iY I cut off, or took, for myself, from him, my right, or due. (A, TA.) And Afotala*otuhu AlmaAla I took from him a part, or portion, of the property. (S, O, L, K.)
filo*N * The liver of a camel: (S, M, O, L, K:) pl. A^afolaA*N [also said to be a pl. of filo*apN, q. v.]. (S, M, O, L.)

filo*apN *
A piece, or portion, of liver, (S, M, O, L, K,) cut in an oblong from, (O,) and of flesh-meat, (S, O, L, K,) and of property, (S, O, L,) and of gold, and of silver, (M, L, K,) &c.: (S, O, Msb:) a piece of flesh-meat cut in an oblong form: (As, T, M, L:) pl. [of mult.] fila*N (T, S, L, K) and [of pauc.] A^afolaA*N, (T, M, L, K,) the latter irregular, as though the augmentative letter [in the sing.] were elided; or filo*N may be a dial. var. of filo*apN, and so this pl. may be regular. (M, L.) ― -b2- A^afolaA*u AlA^aroDi, (M, L, K,) or A^afolaA*u kabidi AlA^aroDi, occurring in a trad., (As, T, A, L,) relating to the signs of the day of resurrection, accord. to different relations thereof, (L,) means (tropical:) The buried treasures of the earth, (As, T, M, L, K,) and its riches. (L.) ― -b3- And A^afolaA*u kabidi mak~apa means (tropical:) The principal and choicest persons of the inhabitants of Mekkeh; of the tribe of Kureysh: so called because the liver is one of the noble parts of the body. (L.) ― -b4- Alfila*aAtu [(not to be mistaken for Alfiliz~aAtu) is a pl. of Alfilo*apu, and] signifies AlA^ajosaAmu Als~aboEapu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The seven material substances; namely, the four elements, (fire, air, earth, and water,) and the three products composed of these (which are minerals, vegetables, and animals)]. (MF. [But in the copy of his work which I use, AlAjsAd is erroneously put for AljsAm.])

faAluw*N * (T, S, M, O, L, K) and ↓ faAluw*aqN, but, accord. to Yaakoob, not ↓ faAluw*ajN, (S, O, L,) or this is the proper form, because the h in the original Pers. word is regularly changed into j, (MF,) [the word being] arabicized, (T, S, O, L,) from the Pers. (M, O, * L) baAluwdah [or faAluwdah or PaAluwdah], (O,) A kind of sweet food, (M, O, * L, K,) well known, (K,) prepared of the purest substance of wheat (lub~ AlHinoTap), (T, L,) or of starch, (TA in art. n$w,) [with water and honey:] pl. fawaAliy*u [of which see an ex. in the next paragraph]. (A.) ― -b2- Also i. q. fuwlaA*N, q. v. (M, L, K.)

fuwlaA*N * , (T, M, O, L, Msb, K,) an arabicized word, (T, O, Msb,) from the Pers. buwlaAd [or fuwlaAd or PuwlaAd], (O,) and ↓ faAluw*N also, (M, L, K,) Steel; i. e. purified and refined iron; or the pure part of iron; (T, M, O, L, Msb, K;) which is added in other iron: (M, L:) pl. fawaAliy*u. (A.) One says, AlD~arobu biAlfawaAliy*i xayorN mina AlD~aroabi fiY AlfawaAliy*i [The smiting with the weapons of steel in battle is better than the thick white honey in the sweet messes of the kind called fAlw*]. (A.)
faAluw*ajN * and faAluw*aqN: see faAluw*N, above.
mafoluw*N * A sword made of fuwlaA* [i. e. steel]. (O, K.)

filiz~N * (Lth, IDrd, S, A, O, K, &c.) and filaz~N and fuluz~N, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) the first of which is
what is commonly known, (TA,) White copper (nuHaAs A^aboyaD [app. a sort of bronze in which the relative quantity of the tin is unusually large] whereof are made cast cooking-pots (Lth, O, K, TA) of large size, and mortars in which substances are pounded: (TA:) or the metals; gold and silver and copper and the like: (A'Obeyd, A, O, K: *) or the substance [i. e. recrement] that is removed [or blown away] by the blacksmith's bellows from molten metals: (S, O, K:) or the dross, or recrement, of iron, (O, K,) that is removed [or blown away] by the blacksmith's bellows: (O:) or stones: (O, K:) its primary meaning is [said to be] hardness, and ruggedness. (IDrd, O.) Alfiliz~aAtu [pl. of Alfiliz~u (not to be mistaken for Alfila*aAtu)] signifies The seven metals; namely, gold, silver, copper, iron, lead, tin [thus I here render AlA^usorub~], and tutenag [thus I render AlxaArSiyniY, following De Sacy and others]. (Kzw.) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened to the flz~ above described, (TA,) (tropical:) A strong, hard, and thick, or coarse, man. (K, * TA.) And (tropical:) A niggard: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA:) as though he were hard iron, upon which nothing would make any impression. (TA.) ― -b3- And A thing upon which swords are tested by striking it therewith. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

2 fl~shu * , (S, A, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafoliysN, (S, O, Msb, K,) He (a judge) proclaimed him. (S, A, O, Msb,) or pronounced him, (O, K,) to be, or to have become, in a state of A_ifolaAs [meaning bankruptcy, or insolvency], (S, A, O, K,) or to have become mufolis [meaning bankrupt, or insolvent], and paraded him among the people as such. (Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says, ful~isa mino kul~i xayorK [app. meaning He was pronounced destitute of all good, or of all property]. (TA.) -A2- [ful~isa It was marked with spots differing in colour from the rest, resembling fuluws, or small copper coins. (See mufal~asN.)] tafoliysu All~awoni [used as a subst. properly so termed] signifies Spots in a colour, differing therefrom in colour, resembling fuluws. (M.)

4 Afls * , [inf. n. A_ifolaAsN,] He became mufolis [which in the common legal acceptation means bankrupt, or insolvent]: (S:) or he had no property remaining: (O, K:) as though his daraAhim [or pieces of silver] had become fuluws [or small copper coins], (S, O, K,) and base money: like as A^axobava signifies “ his companions, or friends, became bad, wicked, or deceitful: ” (S, O:) or he became in such a state that it was said he had not a falos [or small copper coin]; (S, O, K;) like as A^aqohara signifies “ he became in a state in which to be overcome, or subdued: ” (S, O:) or as though he became in a state in which to be overcome, or subdued: (Msb:) or he became a possessor of fuluws after he had been a possessor of daraAhim: (M, Msb:) but properly, [so in the Msb, but I would rather say secondarily, or tropically,] he became reduced from a state of ease, or competence, or richness, to a state of difficulty, or poverty. (Msb.) -A2- Afls Alr~ajula He sought the man and missed his place. (AA, O.)

falosN * [A small copper coin;] a thing well known, (M, A, K,) used in buying and selling; (Msb;) the forty-eighth part of a dirhem: [i. e., about half a farthing of our money:] so in Egypt: (Ibn-Fadl-Allah, cited by Es-Suyootee in his Husn el-Mohádarah:) pl. (of pauc., S, O) A^afolusN, and (of mult., S, O) fuluwsN. (S, M, O, Msb, K.) [The dim. of the former of these pls. is ↓ A^ufayolisN: see an ex. below, voce mufolisN. The pl. fuluws is the common term for Money in Egypt and some other parts in the present day.] ― -b2- [Hence, Anything resembling a small coin: as ― -b3- A counter of metal: ― -b4- and A scale of a fish: as Sgh says,] fuluwsu Als~amaki signifies what are on the back of the fish, resembling the [coins called] fuluws. (O.) ― -b5- And The seal of the jizoyap [or tax paid by the free non-muslim subject of a Muslim government], (T, S, K,) which was hung upon the neck, (T, S, TA,) or upon the throat. (O, K.)

Alfilosu *
A certain idol which belonged to the tribe of Teiyi, (IDrd, M, O, K,) in the Time of Ignorance; which 'Alee, being sent by Mohammad, destroyed, taking away the two swords, mixo*amN and rasuwbN, that El-Hárith Ibn-Abee-Shemir had given to it. (O, TA.)

falasN * , from A^afolasa, [app. signifying Bankruptcy or insolvency: or a state of indigence or destitution: and] lack of obtainment: (K, TA:) and failure of finding him whom [or that which] one seeks. (TA.) You say, waqaEa fiY falasK $adiydK [He fell into a severe state of indigence or destitution]. (TA.) And one says, fiY Hub~ihaA falasN, meaning With her love, or the love of her, is no obtainment: and the phrase Hub~uhaA falasN, occurring in a verse of El-Mo'attal El-Hudhalee, or of Aboo-Kilábeh, [in which the love thus described is afterwards termed ↓ Hub~u mufolisN, so that falasN is here used for mufolisN, or the phrase is elliptical,] Her love, or the love of her, is such that nothing is obtained from it. (O.)

fal~aAsN *
A seller of fuluws, pl. of falosN. (M, O, K.)
A^ufayolisN * : see falosN and mufolisN.

mufolisN * act. part. n. of 4 [q. v.]: pl., (Msb,) or quasi-pl. n., (A,) ↓ mafaAliysu; (A, Msb;) like as mfaATiyru is of mufoTirN, [and mayaAsiyru of muwsirN;] or pl. of ↓ mifolaAsN [which signifies the same as mafolisN but in an intensive degree]. (A, TA.) [The dim. is ↓ mufayolisN.] You say, fulaAnN mufayolisN maA nahu A_il~aA A^ufayolisN [Such a one is nearly a bankrupt, or nearly destitute; he has nothing but a few small copper coins]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also falasN.

mufal~asN *
Proclaimed [or pronounced] by the judge to be in a state of A_ifolaAs. (A.) [See 2.] -A2- Also, (Mgh,) or mufal~asu All~awoni, (O, K,) A horse, (Mgh,) or other thing, (O, K,) having upon his skin spots differing in colour from the rest, resembling fuluws [or small copper coins]. (Mgh, O, K.)
mifolaAsN * : see mufolisN.
mafaAliysu * , a pl. or quasi-pl. n.: see mufolisN.
mufayolisN * dim. of mufolisN, q. v.

div1.div2:
flst Q 2. tafalosafa He was, or became, a fayolasuwf [or philosopher]. (M.) ― -b2- He affected to be a philosopher. (PU.)
falosafapN * , a foreign word, Science; (M;) [philosophy; or] love of science: from the word here following. (O and K in art. swf.)
fayolasuwfN *
A man of science; (M;) [a philosopher;] a word meaning in Greek a lover of science. (O and K in art. swf.)

div2.entryFree:
Q. 1 faloTaHa *
He expanded, and made broad, or wide, a round cake of bread; (K, TA;) as also faroTaHa; both mentioned by Abu-l-Faraj: [see art. frTH: both are app. correct; but the former seems to be the more approved:] and he made broad, or wide, anything. (TA.)
filoTaAHN * : see the following paragraph.

mufaloTaHN * A cake of bread [expanded, and made broad, or] wide: (IAar, TA.) and a thing [of any kind (see the verb)] having breadth and width. (TA.) HasakapN mufaloTaHapN occurs in a trad. [meaning A broad, or wide, head of a thistle or the like]. (TA.) And raA^osN mufaloTaHN means A broad, or wide, head; as also ↓ filoTaAHN. (K.) ― -b2- A_i*aA Dan~uwA Ealayohi baAlmufaloTaHapi, occurring in a trad., is expl. by El-Khattábee as meaning [If they be niggardly, to him, of] the expanded cake of bread: and it is also expl. as meaning the dirhems [or money]: (TA:) or the phrase [accord. to one relation] is A_i*aA Dan~uwA Ealayoka biAlmuTalofaHapi, in which both of the meanings above mentioned are assigned to the last word. (L and TA in art. TlfH.)

1 falaEahu * , (S, K,) aor.
falaEa , (K,) inf. n. faloEN, (S,) He clave, split, or rent, it, (S, K,) i. e., a thing; (S;) or it signifies, or signifies also, (accord to different copies of the K,) he cut it, (K,) with a sword, &c.; and he broke, or crushed, it; like as one does the hump of a camel, with a knife: (TA:) and one says also ↓ fl~Ehu, (S, K,) inf. n. tafoliyEN; (S;) meaning the same; (K:) or this has an intensive signification. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And falaEotuhu [also] signifies I made it apparent, or manifest; or exposed it to view. (Sh, TA.)
2 fal~aEa see the preceding paragraph.
5 tafal~aEa see the paragraph next following, in three places.

7 AnflE * (S, K) and [in an intensive sense] ↓ tfl~E (K) It became cleft, split, or rent; &c. (S, K.) One says, AnflEt AlbayoDapu, and [in an intensive sense] ↓ tfl~Et, The egg became cleft, split, or cracked asunder. (IF, O.) And ↓ tfl~Et qadamuhu His foot became cleft in several, or many, places; or cracked, or chapped; syn. ta$aq~aqat. (S.)
faloEN * and ↓ filoEN A fissure, or crack, in the foot, (S, O, K,) &c.: (K:) pl. fuluwEN; (S, O, K;) like fuluwHN and fuluwjN. (O.)
filoEN * : see what next precedes.

filoEapN *
A piece of the hump of a camel: (O, K, TA:) pl. filaEN. (TA.) ― -b2- laEana A@ll~`hu filoEatahaA (S, O, K) is a foul phrase, (S,) a phrase used in reviling; (O, K;) or, as in the T, one says in reviling a female slave, qabaHa A@ll~`hu filoEatahaA, meaning [May God remove far from all that is good] her rima vulvæ; or what is cleft, or cracked, or chapped, of her heel: or, as Kr says, ↓ falaEatahaA, app. meaning farojahaA [her vulva]; for falaEapN, [thus] muHar~akap, means the faroj. (TA.)
falaEapN * : see what next precedes.
faluwEN * A very sharp sword; one that cuts much: pl. fuloEN. (K. [See also mifolaEN.])

faAliEapN *
A calamity, or misfortune: pl. fawaAliEu. (O, K.)
mifolaEN * A sharp, or cutting, sword. (TA. [See also faluwEN.])
mazaAdapN mufal~aEapN * [A leathern water-bag composed] of several pieces of skins sewed together. (O, K.)

1 falaqahu * , aor.
faliqa , (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. faloqN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) He split it, clave it, or divided it lengthwise; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ fl~qhu, (S, * K,) inf. n. tafoliyqN; (S;) or the latter has an intensive signification [or relates to a number of objects]. (O, * Msb.) 'Alee used often to swear by saying, waA@l~a*iY falaqa AlHab~apa wabaraA^a Aln~asamapa [By Him who clave the grain, making it to germinate, and created, or produced, man, or the soul]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] falaqa AlS~uboHa, (S,) or Alfajora, (TA,) said of God, (S, * TA,) He made the dawn [to break, or] to appear. (TA.) ― -b3- flqt Aln~axolapu [app. falaqat, the part. n. being faAliqN, q. v.,] means The palm-tree split, or clave, from [around, i. e. so as to disclose,] the spathe. (TA.) ― -b4- And falaqa fiY AlA^aroDi, aor.
faliqa , inf. n. faloqN, He ment far into the land; like galaqu. (Ibn-'Abbád, O and TA in art. glq.) -A2- And faloqN, (K,) as inf. n. of falaqa in the phrase falaqa Suwfa Aljilodi, (TK,) signifies The plucking of the wool of the bide when it has become stinking; like maroqN. (K, TA. [kAlmaraq~i, in the CK, is a mistake, for kAlmaroqi.])
2 fal~aqa see above, first sentence.

4 Aflq *
He did, or performed, or he uttered, what was admirable, or wonderful; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) said of a man, (S, O, TA,) and (TA) of a poet, (S, * O, * Msb, K, TA,) in his poetry; (TA;) as also ↓ Aftlq. (S, K.) [From filoqN, q, v.] ― -b2- And He brought to pass that which was a calamity; (K;) as also ↓ Aftlq. (Lh, TA.) One says to a man, A^aEolaqota waA^afolaqota i. e. jiy^ota biEulaqa fulaqa, meaning [Thou hast brought to pass] that which is a calamity. (S, O, K. *) ― -b3- And Aflq fiY AlA^mori He was, or became, skilled in the affair. (TA.)

5 tafal~aqa see 7, first sentence. [Hence] one says, taSad~aEati AlbayoDapu walamo tatafal~aqo [The egg cracked, or rather cracked in several places, but did not split apart, or did not split much]. (Az, S in art. qyD.) And of milk such as is termed raAy^ib [q. v.] one says tfl~q meaning It became dissundered, or curdled, by reason of intense sourness: or, as heard by Az from some of the Arabs, it, being collected in a skin, and smitten by the heat of the sun, became dissundered, or curdled, so that the milk [or curds] became separate [from the whey]: and of such milk they loathe the drinking. (TA.) ― -b2- And tfl~q AlS~aboHu: see 7. ― -b3- tfl~q said of a boy: see Q. Q. 2. ― -b4- See also 8, in two places.

7 Anflq *
It became split, cleft, or cloven, or divided lengthwise; it split, clave, or clave asunder; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ tfl~q; (S, Mgh, * K;) [or] the latter signifies ta$aq~aqa [i. e. it became split, &c., much, or in pieces, or in several or many places]. (O, Msb.) The former occurs in the Kur xxvi. 63, said of the sea [as meaning It clave asunder]. (O.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Anflq AlS~uboHu (S and K in art. ETs) and ↓ tfl~q (TA in the present art.) The dawn broke. (TA in explanation of the latter.)

8 Aftlq *
He (a man, TA) strove, or exerted himself, so that he excited wonder by reason of his vehemence in running; as also ↓ tfl~q and ↓ tafayolaqa. (K.) One says, mar~a yafotaliqu fiY Eadowihi, (S, O,) and fiyhi ↓ yatafal~aqu, and ↓ yatafayolaqu, (O,) He passed along doing what was wonderful by reason of his vehemence in his running. (S, O.) See also 4, in two places.
Q. Q. 2 tafayolaqa * , said of a boy, He became big, or bulky, and fat, or plump; (O, K, TA;) as also ↓ tfl~q; both mentioned in the “ Nawádir. ” (TA.) ― -b2- See also 8, in two places.

faloqN * , (AHeyth, TA,) or ↓ falaqN, (S, O, TA,) the former said by AHeyth to be the more correct, (TA,) A split, fissure, cleft, or longitudinal division; syn. $aq~N: pl. fuluwqN: (S, O, TA:) and ↓ falaqN (Lh, K, TA) [or faloqN?] signifies also [particularly] a fissure, or cleft, ($aq~N) in a mountain; (Lh, K, TA;) and so ↓ faAliqN: (K, TA:) and a $iEob [app. meaning gap, or ravine, or pass]. (TA.) One says, mararotu biHar~apK fiyhaA fuluwqN, meaning $uquwqF [i. e. I passed by a stony tract such as is termed Har~ap in which were fissures, or clefts]. (S, O.) And fiY rijolihi fuluwqN i. e. $uquwqN [In his foot, or leg, are fissures or clefts]. (As, S, O, * K.) And kal~amaniY mino faloqi fiyhi (Lh, S, O, K) and ↓ filoqi fiyhi, (Lh, S, K,) the former of which is the more known, (TA,) meaning mino $aq~ihi [He spoke to me from out the fissure of his mouth, i. e., with his lips, not by means of a spokesman]. (K.) And Drabahu EalaY faloqi raA^osihi He struck him on the place where his hair was separated, the middle of his head. (TA.) ― -b2- See also falaqN. -A2- And see the paragraph here following, last quarter.

filoqN * : see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- See also filoqapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A rod, or branch, that is split in two, (S, O, K,) [i. e., in halves,] and of which are then made two bows, each whereof is termed filoqN, (S, O,) [or] each half (kul~u $iq~K [in the CK $aq~K]) of what is thus split is termed filoqN: (K, TA:) and thus is termed a bow that is made of the half of a branch, (K, TA,) the branch being split in two; and it is also termed qawosN filoqN, the latter word being thus used as an epithet, on the authority of Lh: or, as AHn says, the bow termed filoqN is one of which the wood whereof it has been made has been previously split in two, or three, pieces: and he also says that ↓ faliyqN [app. for qawosN faliyqN] signifies a bow of which the piece of wood has been split in two pieces. (TA.) [See also $ariyjN, in two places: and see faroEN.] -A3- Also A wonderful thing or affair or case; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ faliyqN, (K,) and ↓ fayolaqN, (TA,) and ↓ faliyqapN, (O, * TA,) of which last an ex. occurs in the prov.,
yaA EajabiY lih`*ahi AlfaliyqahN
halo tagoliban~a AlquwabaA='u Alr~iyqahu
[O my wonder at this wonderful thing! Does the ringworm indeed overcome the spittle?]: AA says, the meaning is, that he was in wonder at the alteration of usual occurrences; for the spittle usually dispels the ringworm, so he spat upon his ringworm, but it did not become healed: AlqwbA=' is made an agent; and Alryqp, an objective complement. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And A calamity, or misfortune; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ filoqapN, (K, TA, accord. to the CK ↓ faloqN,) and ↓ faliyqN, (O, K,) and ↓ faliyqapN, (S, O, K,) and ↓ faloqaY (K, TA) or ↓ falaqaY, (TA,) and ↓ fayolaqN, (O and CK,) and ↓ mafolaqapN. (IDrd, O, K.) The Arabs say, ↓ yaA lilofaliyqapi O [come with succour] to the calamity. (S, O.) And ↓ jaA='a biEulaqa fulaqa, (S, O, K,) imperfectly decl., (S, O,) i. e. [He brought to pass] that which was
a calamity: (S, O, K:) and ↓ biEulaqF fulaqK: (O, K:) or this means a very wonderful thing. (TA.)

falaqN * : see faloqN, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- Also The daybreak, or dawn; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ faloqN, mentioned by Z and others; (TA;) and thus the former has been expl. as signifying in the Kur cxiii. 1: (S, O, TA:) or what has broken (Anflq) of the Eamuwd of the dawn; (Fr. K, TA;) i. e. [of the bright gleam of dawn; of the dawn that rises and spreads, filling the horizon with its whiteness; or] the extending light that is like the [long tent called] Eamuwd: (TA:) or [simply] the light of daybreak or dawn: (Msb, K: *) or the appearing of the daybreak or dawn: (Zj, TA:) and falaqu AlS~uboHi signifies the light, and shining, or bright shining, of the daybreak or dawn: (TA:) one says, huwaA^aboyanu mino falaqi AlS~uboHi and faraqi AlS~uboHi [It is more distinct than what has broken of the bright gleam of dawn]. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And [hence,] The plain appearing of the truth after its having been dubious. (TA.) -A2- Also A law, or depressed, place of the earth, between two kills, or elevated grounds; (As, S, O, K;) as also ↓ faAliqN, (S, O, K,) and ↓ faAliqapN, (K,) which last is said by Aboo-Kheyreh, or some other, of the Arabs of the desert, to be in the midst of mountains, giving growth to trees, a place where people alight and where camels, or other cattle, remain during the cold night, saying that the ↓ faAliq is of hard, or hard and level, ground; (TA:) and the pl. of falaqN is fuloqaAnN (S, K, TA) and A^afolaAqN also: (TA:) or falaqN, (K,) or ↓ faAliqN, (TA,) signifies a wide tract of land or ground, between two extended tracts of sand; (K, TA;) and the pl. of the latter word is fuloqaAnN, like as HujoraAnN is pl. of HaAjirN. (TA.) -A3- And Alfalaqu signifies Hell; syn. jahan~amu: (K:) or a certain well (jub~N) therein. (Es-Suddee, O, K.) -A4- And The whole creation; all the beings, or things, that are created. (Zj, S, O, K.) This, accord. to some, is the meaning in the Kur cxiii. 1. (S, O.) -A5- And What remains, of milk, in the bottom of the bowl; whence one says, (in reviling a person, attributing to him meanness, TA,) yaA A@bona $aAribi Alfalaqi [O son of the drinker of what remains &c.]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And The milk that is in a dissundered, or curdled, state, by reason of sourness; as also ↓ mutafal~iqN. (K.) -A6- And The miqoTarap of the keeper of a prison; (S, O, * K;) i. e. [a kind of stocks;] a piece of wood in which are holes of the size of the shank, wherein men are confined, (K, TA,) i. e. thieves and waylayers, (TA,) in a row: (K, TA:) whence the saying of Z, baAta fulaAnN fiY Al$~afaqi waAlfalaqi mina Al$~afaqi A_ilaY Alfalaqi i. e. [Such a one passed the night] in fear and the mqTrp [from the time of the redness of the region of sunset after the setting of the sun until the dawn]. (TA.) See also falaqapN.
jaA='a biEulaqa fulaqa * : and biEulaqK fulaqK: see filoqN, last sentence.

Alfaloqapu *
A certain brand, beneath the ear of a camel, (O, K,) in the form of a ring in the middle of which is a perpendicular line dividing it [from top to bottom, and, in some copies of the K, extending downwards so that about half of its length is below the ring]. (O, K. * [In some copies of the latter it is figured, but somewhat differently in different copies.]) ― -b2- See also falaqapN.

filoqapN *
A piece [properly that has been split off] (Mgh, Msb, KL) of a thing; as also ↓ filoqN: (KL:) or a fragment, or piece broken off, (S, O, K, TA) of bread, or of a [bowl such as is termed] jafonap, (TA,) or of this latter the half, (S, O, K, TA,) as in the saying A^aEoTiniY filoqapa Aljafonapi [Give thou to me the half of the bowl, perhaps meaning, of its contents], (S, O, TA,) or, as some say, one of the divided halves thereof: (TA:) the pl. of filoqapN is filaqN: (Mgh, TA; *) and [↓ filaAqN is app. a pl., like A^afolaAqN, (and perhaps fuluwqN, mentioned voce fulaAqN,) and ↓ fulaAqN a quasi-pl. n., of ↓ filoqN, all agreeably with analogy; whence] one says, SaAra ↓ AlbayoDu filaAqFA, and ↓ fulaAqFA, meaning A^afolaAqFA, (S, O, K,) i. e. [The eggs became fragments; or it means, became cleft in pieces; or] became much cleft, or cleft in many places. (K, TA. [See also falaAqN and filaAqN below.]) -A2- See also filoqN, last quarter.

falaqapN * [signifies, in the present day, A thick staff, to the ends of which are attacked the two ends of a rope, by means whereof a man's legs are secured, between the rope and the staff, when he is bastinaded; and it is also called ↓ falaqN: this may perhaps be meant by its being said in the TA, on the authority of Lh, that Alfalaqapu signifies Alxa$abapu; as also ↓ Alfaloqapu].
faloqaY * , or falaqaY: see filoqN, last quarter.
faloqaA='u AlD~ar~api * A ewe, or she-goat, ($aApN,) wide, or ample, in the udder. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

fuloqaAnN *
A sheer, or an unmixed, lie. (IAar, O, K.) [It is also a pl.: see falaqN, in two places.]

fulaAqN * : see filoqapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, (O, K,) and fuluwqN, (thus in the O,) or ↓ faluwqN, like SabuwrN, (thus in the K, [but this I think questionable,]) Milk becoming, or become, like cheese: (O, K:) [or fulaAqN may be here a quasi-pl. n. of filoqN (q. v. voce filoqapN), so that the meaning may be, that has become cleft portions of curd; and fuluwqN may also mean thus as a pl. of filoqN. See also the next paragraph.]

filaAqN * : see filoqapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The state of milk's becoming thick and sour, so that it curdles, or becomes dissundered: (IAar, K, TA:) [or it may be here a pl. of filoqN (q. v. voce filoqapN), for in a verse cited by IAar the milk in this case is termed *uw filaAqK, so that it may mean the separate portions of curd of milk that has become thick and sour; though it is said in the TA that its pl. is fuluwqN, for this I think very questionable. See also the next preceding paragraph]
faluwqN * : see fulaAqN.

faliyqN * : see filoqN, former half. ― -b2- Also The depressed place in the jiraAn [or under part of the neck] of the camel, where is the passage of the windpipe: (S, O, K:) or, accord. to Lth, the part that is [as though it were] cleft, of the interior of the neck of the camel: (O, TA:) or, as some say, the part between the [two sinews called the] EilobaAwaAni, when the fur between these is [as though it were] cleft: and it is not said in relation to a human being. (TA.) ― -b3- And Alfaliyqu also signifies [The cephalic vein;] a certain vein in the upper arm, (O, K,) that runs to the [cartilage called] nugoDi of the shoulder-blade: it is the vein of the waAhinap; and is [also] called AljaAy^ifu [q. v., and see also Alwariydu.] (O.) And A certain vein that swells up in the neck. (K.) -A2- See, again, filoqN, in two places.

fulaAqapu A=jur~K *
A piece of baked brick: (Lh, K:) pl. filaAqN. (So in copies of the K. [Probably a mistranscription for ↓ fulaAqN, which, if correct, is properly a coll. gen. n.])

faliyqapN * : see filoqN, in three places. -A2- Also A quantity collected together, (faliylapN, K, TA, in the O without any point to the first letter,) or a small quantity, (qaliylapN, thus in some copies of the K,) of hair: (O, K, TA:) mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád. (O, TA.) -A3- And A sort of broth; thus termed by the people of El-Medeeneh; occurring in a trad. as related by Ibráheem El-Harbee; (O;) or a pottage (qidorN) that is cooked, and into which fragments (filaq, i. e. kisar,) of bread are crumbled: (TA:) but accord. to AA, it is called fariyqapN only. (O, TA.)
ful~uwqN * : see mufal~aqN.
