ful~ayoqN * : see mufal~aqN.

faAliqN *
Splitting, cleaving, or dividing lengthwise. (TA.) faAliqu A@loHab~i waA@ln~awaY, (O, K, *) in the Kur [vi. 95], (O,) means The Cleaver of the dry grain so as to produce therefrom green leaves [and of the date-stone]: or, as some say, the Creator thereof. (O, K. *) And hence the saying of Áïsheh, A_in~a AlbukaA='a faAliqN kabidiY [Verily weeping is cleaving my liver]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, also, in the Kur [vi. 96], faAliqN AlA_iSobaAHi He who causeth the dawn to break: in which instance, also, fAlq has reference to the meaning of Creator: (O, TA:) so says Zj. (TA.) ― -b3- naxolapN faAliqN means A palmtree splitting, or cleaving from [around, i. e. so as to disclose,] the spathe: (O, K, * TA:) pl. fuloqN. (TA.) ― -b4- AlfawaAliqu as pl. of AlfaAliqu signifies The veins that divide [so as to form ramifying veins (thus I render ↓ AlEuruwqu Almutafal~iqapu)] in the human being. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.) ― -b5- See also faloqN, first sentence. ― -b6- And see falaqN, former half, in three places. ― -b7- Alwarikapi ↓ xal~ayotuhu bifaAliqapi, or, as in the T, bifaAliqi AlwrkA=', [thus in the TA, but I think that Alwrkp and AlwrkA=' are evidently mistran-
scriptions, and that the right reading is AlwadokaA='i, with dAl,] meaning [I left him in the low, or depressed, tract in the midst of] the sand [called El-Wedkà]. (TA.)

fayolaqN *
An army; a military force: (S, O, K:) or a great [military force such as is termed] katiybap: (Kt, Msb, TA:) this is the primary signification, and the only one known to Kt: (TA:) pl. fayaAliqu. (S, K.) One says, ramaAhumo bifayolaqK $ahobaA='a, meaning [He assailed them] with a formidable [great] katiybap. (TA.) ― -b2- And A great, big, or large, man: (O, K:) occurring in this sense in a trad., as an epithet applied to Ed-Dejjál: Kt doubted whether it were thus or fayolamN; but Az affirms that both have this meaning. (O.) And one says, buliYa fulaAno biA@moraA^apK fayolaqK, meaning [Such a one was tried, or afflicted, with a woman, or wife,] cunning, evil, and clamourous. (TA.) ― -b3- See also filoqN, in two places. -A2- Also [The cocoon of a silk-worm;] the thing from which qaz~ is obtained; an arabicized word. (Msb voce fayolajN, q. v.: mentioned also in the Mgh, in art. fr$.)
faAliqapN * , as a subst.: see falaqN, former half: and see also faAliqN, last sentence.

futila fulaAnN A^afolaqa qitolapK * means Such a one was slain with the hardest, or most violent, sort of slaughter. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- And maA raA^ayotu sayorFA A^afolaqa mino h`*aA I have not seen a journey further in extent than this. (Lh, TA.)
mufoliqN * A poet who poetizes admirably, or wonderfully. (S, O.)
mafolaqapN * : see filoqN, last quarter.

mufal~aqN * , applied to a peach, and an apricot, and the like, that splits, or cleaves, from [around, i. e. so as to disclose,] its stone, and becomes dry: and ↓ fal~uwqN, with damm to the f, and also to the l, with teshdeed, signifies such as does not become dry: (Msb:) or ↓ ful~ayoqN, (S, O, K,) with damm and [then] teshdeed, (S,) like qub~ayoTN, (O, K,) signifies, applied to a peach, that splits, or cleaves, from [around] its stone: and mufal~aqN, such as becomes dry. (S, K.)

mifolaAqN * A man low, ignoble, or mean, and poor, or destitute: (Lth, O, K:) or one who possesses no property: pl. mafaAliyqu: and to such is likened such as possesses no knowledge nor understanding of a juridical decision. (O.) And A man who does, or utters, evil, or disliked, or hateful, things. (TA.)
mafoluwqN * A camel marked with the brand termed faloqap [q. v.]. (O, K.)
mutafal~iqN * : see falaqN, last quarter: ― -b2- and see faAliqN.
faloqasN * : see the following paragraph, latter sentence.

falanoqasN *
One whose mother is Arab, but not his father: (Lth, O, K:) or one whose father is such as is termed mawolFY [i. e. a freedman under the patronage of his emancipator], and whose mother is Arab; (S, O, K;) thus says A'Obeyd, (S, O,) and thus Sh: (TA:) or one whose father and mother are Arabs, and whose two grandmothers are slaves; (O, K;) thus accord. to AZ and AHeyth (O) and ISk, and this is [said to be] the right explanation: (TA:) or one whose father is a mwlY [expl. above], and his mother the like, i. e. a mawolaAp; (S, O, K;) thus accord. to Abu-lGhowth. (S, O.) ― -b2- Also, (O, K,) and ↓ faloqasN, (K,) Niggardly, or a niggard; and vile, or ignoble. (O, K. *)
1 falVka see the next paragraph, in two places.

2 fl~k * , (S, O, K,) inf. n. tafokiykN, (S,) said of a girl's breast, It became round, (S, O, K, TA,) like the falokap [or whirl (of a spindle)], but less than is denoted by nuhuwdN [inf. n. of nahada, q. v.]; (TA;) as also ↓ tfl~k, (S, O, K,) and ↓ Aflk, (Th, O, K,) and ↓ falaka. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And fl~kt, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) She became round in the breast; as also ↓ falakato. (K, TA. [For the latter verb, the CK has falikat.]) -A2- See also falokapN, second sentence. ― -b2- Alt~afokiyku also signifies The pastor's making, of course hair (hulob), a thing like the falokap (AA, T, S, O, TA) of the spindle, (AA, T, TA,) and inserting it into the tongue of the young unweaned camel, (AA, T, S, O, TA,) having perforated the tongue [for that purpose], (AA, T, TA,) in order that he may not such: (AA, T, S, O, TA:) accord. to Lth, fal~akotu AljadoYa signifies I put a twig around the tongue of the kid in order that it might not suck: but Az says that the right explanation of Altfkyk is that of AA [given above]. (TA.) [See also 4 in art. jr, and 4 in art. lhj.] -A3- And fl~k, inf. n. as above, He (a man) persisted, or persevered, (laj~a,) in an affair; (K, TA;) and so ↓ Aflk. (TA.) -A4- And fl~kt She (a bitch) desired copulation, and discharged blood from the womb; syn. AjElt wHADt. (O, K.)
4 A^afolaka see 2, first sentence: ― -b2- and falokapN, second sentence: -A2- and see also 2, last sentence but one.
5 tafal~aka see 2, first sentence.

fulokN *
A ship: (S, O, Msb, K, &c.:) [also particularly applied to the ark of Noah; as in the Kur-án vii. 62, &c.:] the word is generally thus only; but some say ↓ fulukN also, with two dammehs; and it is held that this may be the original form; and that fulokN may be a contraction, like as EunoqN is [of gunuqN accord. to Sb]: (MF, TA:) it is masc. and fem., (S, O, K, *) and sing. and pl., (S, O, K,) and Ibn-'Abbád says that it has fuluwkN also for a pl.: (O:) [it is said that] it may be sing., and in this case masc.; and pl., and in this case fem.: (IB, Msb:) [but see what here follows:] it occurs in the Kur-án in the following (and other) places: in xxvi. 119, &c.; where it is sing. and masc.: (S, O, TA:) and in [xvi. 14 and] xxxv. 13; where it is pl. [and fem.]: (TA:) and in ii. 159; where it is fem., and may be either pl. or sing.: it seems that, when it is sing., it is regarded as meaning the marokab, and is therefore made masc.; or the safiynap, and is therefore made fem.: (S, O, TA:) or, (K,) as Sb used to say, (S, O, TA,) the fulok that is a pl. [in meaning] is a broken pl. of that, (S, O, K, TA,) i. e. of the fulok, (IB, O, K, TA,) that is a sing. [in meaning]: and it is not like Aljunubu, which is sing. and pl. [in meaning], and the like thereof (S, O, K, TA) among substs., such as AlT~ifolu &c.; (S, O, TA;) for fulokaAni has been heard from the Arabs as dual of fulokN, but not junubaAni [or the like] as dual of junubN [or the like]; and they say that what has not been dualized is not a pl. [form], but [is, or may be,] a homonym, and what has been dualized [is, or may be,] a pl. [form]: (MF, TA:) Sb then says in continuation, (TA,) for fuEolN and faEalN share in application to one thing [or meaning], as AlEurobu and AlEarabu, (S, O, K, TA,) &c.; (S, O, TA;) and as it is allowable for faEalN to have for its pl. fuEolN, as in the instance of A^asadN and A^usodN, so too fuEolN may have for its pl. fuEolN. (S, O, K, TA.) ↓ fulokiY~N is a dial. var. of fulokN; and Abu-d-Dardà read, [in the Kur x. 23,] kunotumo fiY A@lofulokiY~i [When ye are in the ships; where others read fY Alfuloki; and where the context shows that the pl. meaning is intended]. (IJ, TA.) -A2- [It may also be a pl. of the word next following].

Alfalaku *
The place of the revolving of the stars; (O, K, TA;) [the celestial sphere: but generally imagined by the Arabs to be a material concave hemisphere; so that it may be termed the vault of heaven; or the firmament:] the astronomers say that it is [a term applied to every one, by itself, of] seven A^aTowaAq [by which they mean surrounding spheres], exclusive of the samaA=' [or sky, as meaning the region of the clouds]; wherein have been set the seven stars [i. e. the Moon, Mercury, Venus, the Sun, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn], in every Tawoq [or surrounding sphere] a star, some being higher than others; revolving therein: (TA:) [it is also commonly imagined that above these is an eighth sphere, called by the astronomers falaku Alv~awaAbiti (the sphere of the fixed stars), and by others falaku AlkurosiY~i; and above this, a ninth, called falaku AlA^aTolasi and falaku AlEaro$i, and also called AlA^aviyru (q. v.):] the pl. is A^afolaAkN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, O, Msb, K, TA) and fulukN (K, TA) and fulokN may be another pl., like as A^usodN and xu$ubN are pls. of A^asadN and xa$abN (S, O, TA. [Thus accord. to both of my copies of the S, as well as the O and TA: but it may be that A^usodN and xu$obN are mistranscriptions for A^usudN and xu$ubN; and therefore that for fulokN (which is not mentioned as a pl. of falakN in the K) we should read fulukN.]) And falaku Als~amA='i signifies The pole of
heaven; [generally the north celestial pole;] likened to the pivot, or axis, of the mill-stone. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (i. e. Alfalaku) The revolving of the heaven [or celestial sphere]. (TA.) ― -b3- And falakN signifies also The circuit, and main part, of any- thing. (K.) ― -b4- And Waves of the sea in a state of commotion, (O, K, TA,) circling, (TA,) and going to and fro. (O, TA.) This, (O, TA,) or what is next mentioned, (TA,) or the place of revolving of the stars, (O,) or the pole of heaven, (TA,) is meant in a trad. where it is said of a horse smitten by the [evil] eye, that he was as though he were turning in a falak. (O, TA.) And Water put in motion by the wind, (O, K, TA,) going to and fro, in a state of commotion: (O, TA:) mentioned by Z. (TA.) ― -b5- Also A hill, or mound, of sand, having around it a wide expanse of land: (IAar, O, K, TA:) or falakN mina Alr~amoli signifies rugged, round A^ajowibap [app. a pl. of jawobap (though I do not find it mentioned as such), and meaning depressed and clear places], of the sands, like [tracts of] what are termed ka*~aAn [or soft stones resembling dry pieces of clay], hollowed out by the gazelles. (TA.) ― -b6- And Pieces of land, (S, O, K, TA,) or of sand, (S,) having a circular form, and elevated above what is around them, (S, O, K, TA,) with ruggedness and evenness; (TA;) one whereof is termed ↓ falokapN, (S, O, K, TA,) with the l quiescent; pl. filaAkN; (K, TA;) i. e. [this is pl. of falokapN,] like qaSoEapN and qiSaAEN: (TA:) in [the book entitled] El-Ghareeb ElMusannaf, [by Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, we find] ↓ falakapN and falakN, [each] biAlt~aHoriyk; [accord. to which, falakapN is a n. un., and falakN is a coll. gen. n.;] but in “ the Book ” of Sb, [agreeably with the K, we find] ↓ falokapN [as a sing.] and falakN [as a quasi-pl. n.], like HaloqapN and HalaqN. (IB, TA.) ― -b7- See also falokapN, in two places.

falikN * A slave (AA, O) having a buttock like the falokap [or whirl] of a spindle (AA, O, K) in shape; (AA, O;) resembling the Zenj; (K;) [for] the buttocks of the Zenj are round: (AA, O:) or large in the buttocks. (TA.) And (O, K) it is said to signify (O) Thick, or coarse of make, in the joints: (O, K:) and loose in the bones; (K;) or weak, loose in the bones, and flaccid; thus expl. by Ibn-'Abbád: (O:) and having a pain in his patella (fiY falokapi rukobatihi). (O, K.)
fulukN * : i. q. fulokN, q. v. -A2- And a pl. of falakN. (K, TA.)

falokapN * The whirl of a spindle: (MA:) [this is what is meant by the saying that] the falokap of the migozal is well known; (K;) [and] is thus called because of its roundness: (S, O:) [it is a piece of wood, generally of a hemispherical form, or nearly so, through the middle of which the upper part of the spindle-pin is inserted:] also pronounced ↓ filokap: (O, K:) the pl. [of the former] is ↓ falakN [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.] and [that of the latter sing. is] filakN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A thing that is made round, or hemispherical, (↓ yufal~aku, or ↓ yufolaku, accord. to different copies of the K,) like the falokap of the spindle, of coarse hair (hulob), then the tongue of the young unweaned camel is perforated, [and this thing is inserted into it, (see 2, and see also 4 in art. lhj,)] in order that he may be prevented from sucking. (K. [For ftaxoriqu lisAnu AlfaSiyli in the CK, I read fayuxoraqu lisaAnu AlfaSiyli, as in other copies of the K and in the TA: after these words, the copies of the K have fayuEoDadu bihi, app a mistranscription for some phrase meaning fayujoEalu fiyhi, which is necessary to complete the explanation.]) ― -b3- And An [eminence such as is termed] A^akamahN [formed] of one mass of stone; (K, TA;) accord. to ISh, [of] the smaller of the [eminences termed] A_ikaAm, compact in its head, as though this were the falokap of a spindle, not giving growth to anything, in height of the measure of two spears or a spear and a half. (TA.) ― -b4- See also flakN, near the end, in two places. ― -b5- Also Anything circular, (K.) ― -b6- And [particularly] The joint [or cartilaginous disk] between the two vertebræ [i. e. between any one of the vertebrœ and that next to it] of the camel: (K, TA:) and the pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] thereof, in this sense and in the last two of the sense following, is ↓ falakN. (TA.) ― -b7- [And The cap of the knee; (see falikN;) falokapu Alr~ukobapi signifying the patella: so in the present day.] ― -b8- And The small thing (Alhanapu [app. the foramen cæcum, from its round form, for, though the TA adds the epithet Aln~aA$iy^apu, which means “ rising, ” I think that this addition may be conjectural,]) upon the head of the root of the tongue. (K.) ― -b9- And The side of the [portion of the breast called the] zawor [q. v.], and the part thereof that is round, or circular. (K. [K. [But see balodapN: where it is said that “ the falak of the zawor of a horse are six in number: ” what they are I have been unable to determine: I incline to think that they may be spiral curls, such as are termed dawaAy^ir, pl. of daAy^irapN.])
filokapN * : see falokapN, first sentence.
falakapN * : see falakN, near the end.
fulokiY~N * : see fulokN, last sentence but one.
falakiY~N * [Of, or relating to, the falak as meaning the celestial sphere. ― -b2- And] One who occupies himself [as an astronomer, or astrologer] with the science of the stars. (TA.)
fulayokapN * [dim. of fulokN, which is sometimes fem. when used as a sing. as well as when used as a pl.,] A small ship: the vulgar say flwkp [i. e. faluwkap; whence the Italian “ feluca ”]. (TA.)

faAlikN * and ↓ mufal~ikN A girl whose breast is becoming round, (K, TA,) like the falokap [or whirl (of a spindle)]. (TA.) [And the former is also applied as an epithet to the breast: for] AA says that [the pl.] fawaAliku is applied to breasts (vudiY~) that are less than such as are termed nawaAhidu. (TA.)

fayolakuwnN * The $uwbaq [or baker's rolling-pin: see the latter word]: (O, K, TA: [in the CK, Als~awiyqu is erroneously put for Al$~uwbaqu:]) Az holds both of these words to be arabicized. (O.) ― -b2- And (TA) The barodiY~ [or papyrus]. (S; and K in art. flkn.) -A2- And Tar, or pitch; syn. qaArN, or zifotN. (K. n art. flkn.) -A3- And qawosN fayolakuwnN A great bow. (TA in art. flkn.)
A^afolaku * One who goes round about the falak, (IAar, O, K,) i. e. the hill, or mound, of sand that has around it a wide expanse of land. (IAar, O.)

AlA_ifoliykaAni *
Two portions of flesh which border, on each side, the lahaAp; (IDrd, O, K;) i. e. they are the gunodubataAni [q. v.]. (IDrd, O.)
mufal~ikN * : see faAlikN.

fulaAnN * is a substitute for the proper name of a human being, (S, Msb, * K, TA,) i. e. of a male; (S, TA;) and in like manner ↓ fulaAnapu, (Msb, K, TA,) for that of a female; (TA,) each without Al; (Msb:) [the former may be rendered Such a one, or Such a man; and the latter, Such a woman:] and AlfulaAnu and ↓ AlfulaAnapu for other than a human being, (S, K, TA,) i. e. for a [particular] camel, (Lth, TA,) or for a [particular] beast, as in the saying, rakibotu AlfulaAna [I rode such a beast, i. e. such a male beast], and ↓ Halabotu AlfulaAnapa [I milked such a beast]: (Msb, TA:) fulaAnN has no dual nor pl.: (IB, TA:) [but] sometimes one says to a single person, mase., yaA fulu; and to two, yaA fulaAni; and to a pl. number, yaAfuluwna: and in the fem., yaA fulapu; &c.; (K: [see more in art. fl:]) accord. to Kh, fulaAnN is of the measure fuEaAlN; and its dim. is ↓ fulayonN: (TA:) or, as some say, it is of the measure fulaAnN, [originally fulowaAnN,] with w rejected, therefore its dim. is ↓ fulay~aAnN [originally fulayowaAnN]; (T, L, TA;) like as A_nosaAnN is [said by some to be] A_nosiyaAnN, of which the Y is rejected. and therefore its dim. is A^unyosiyaAnN. (T, L.)
fuliyonN * : see the preceding paragraph.
fulaAnapu * , and AlfulaAnapu: see fulaAnN, in three places.

fulaAniY~N * the rel. n. of fulaAnN: it is rendered indeterminate by the affix Y; and by means of the article Aalo, it becomes determinate; therefore you say fulaAnN AlfulaAniY~u [meaning Such a one, the person named in relation to such a one], (TA,)
fulay~aAnN * : see fulaAnN, near the end.

falohadN * and fulohudN A boy, or youth, compact in make (HaAdirN), fat, that has nearly attained to puberty; as also ↓ fulohwdN and ↓ mufalohadN: (K:) or flhd [i. e. falohadN or fulohadN] signifies a fat boy or
youth, that has nearly attained to puberty; thus expl. by AA: [and so fawohadN is expl. by him: and farohadN and furohudN are similarly expl.:] or, as some say, a plump boy or youth: and accord. to Kr, a boy that fills the cradle. (TA.)
fulohuwdN * : see the preceding paragraph.
mufalohadN * : see the preceding paragraph.

1 falaAhu * , (M, K,) first pers. falawotuhu, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
faluwa , (TA,) inf. n. falowN, (M, K, TA,) with fet-h, and filaA='N accord. to the M, or falaA='N accord. to the K, (TA,) He withdrew him from sucking; namely, a colt, (M, K,) and a young ass, (M,) and a child; (M, K;) as also ↓ AflAhu, and ↓ AftlAhu: (M, K: *) or he weaned, or ablactated, him, as also ↓ AflAhu, and ↓ AftlAhu: (K:) or falaAhu Eano A^um~ihi and ↓ AftlAhu signify thus; relating to a colt and a young ass: (S: [and in a similar manner both are expl. in the T, on the authority of ISk:]) or falaAhu, (M,) or falaAhu Eano A^um~ihi, relating to a colt and a young ass, (T,) signifies thus; (T, M;) but ↓ AftlAhu, (M,) or AftlAhu linafosihi, (T,) signifies he took him for himself [app. from his mother]: (T, M:) or falawotuhu and ↓ A^afolayotuhu signify I separated him from him mother; namely, a colt: and fuliyat is said of a filly [meaning she was separated &c.]. (Msb.) [Hence,] the ↓ falaAp [q. v.] is [said to be] thus called liA^an~ahaA fuliyato Eano kul~i xayorK, [Because it is as though it were weaned, and removed, from everything good]. (M.) ― -b2- And falawotuhu I reared him, or brought him up; [namely, a youth, or boy;] as also ↓ Aifotalayotuhu: a poet says,
walayosa yaholiku min~aA say~idN A^abadFA
A_il~aA A@fotalayonaA gulaAmFA say~idFA fiynaA
[And a chief of us does not ever perish but we rear a youth to be a chief among us]. (S.) -A2- falaAhu biAls~ayofi, (M, K,) first pers. falawotuhu and falanotuhu, (T, S,) inf. n. falowN and faloYN, (M in this art. and in art. flY,) He struck (S, M, K) him, (K,) or his head, (S, M,) with the sword: (S, M, K:) or he struck, or cut, it, i. e. one's head, with the sword. (T * and M in art. flY.) ― -b2- And falawotu Alqawoma I entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the people; like falayotuhumo. (T, TA.) -A3- falaA as intrans., said of a man, He journeyed, or went forth to journey. (IAar, T, K.) ― -b2- And He became intelligent after being ignorant. (IAar, T, K.)

4 A^afolawa see 1, first sentence, in three places. ― -b2- Aflt said of a mare, (M, K,) and of a she-ass, (M,) means She was one whose colt had attained to the age for his being weaned, (M, K.) And the phrase qado A^afolayona A^amohaAraA, ending a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, and referring to wild animals, means, as expl. by AHn, that had become in the state in which their young ones were full-grown and in no need of their mothers. (M.) -A2- And AflY Alqawomu The people, or party, came to the falaAp [or desert, &c.]: (S, K: *) or, as Z says, entered it; which is nearly the same as the former explanation. (TA.)
8 A_ifotalawa see 1, in six places: -A2- and see also art. flY.
falFA * [a coll. gen. n.]: see falaApN.
yaAfulaA * and yaA fulaApu: see yaA fulu, in art. fl.
filowN * : see faluw~N.

falaApN *
A [desert such as is termed] qafor; (M, K;) so called for a reason mentioned above, in the first paragraph, q. v.; (M;) or [such as is called] mafaAzap; (T, S, K;) in which is no water; or, in the fewer cases, in which there is an interval of two days with a portion of the day preceding them and of the day following them between the waterings of camels and of one day between the waterings of asses and of sheep or goats (liloA_ibili riboEN waliloHamiyri waAlganami gab~N): (M, K:) or a land in which is no water: (Msb:) or a wide [desert such as is termed SaHoraA=': (M, K:) pl. falawaAtN, (T, S, M, K,) a pl. of pauc., (TA,) and ↓ falFA, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n. of which falaApN is the n. un.,] and fuliY~N, (M, K,) or this is pl. of falFA, (S,) and [so are] filiY~N (M, K) and fuluw~N [which is the original of fuliY~N and filiY~N], (CK,) A^afolaA='N is [likewise] pl. of falFA. (S, M, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- [A^axuw AlfalaApi A man of the desert: or one who travels in the desert or deserts.] ― -b3- And Aibonu AlfalaApi The HirobaA=' [or male chameleon]. (T in art. bnY.)
filaA='N * , mentioned in the paragraph here following as a pl. of faluw~N, signifies also Bones. (TA.)

faluw~N * (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and fuluw~N (M, K) and ↓ filowN (S, M, Msb, K) A colt, (S, Mgh,) because he is weaned; (S;) or a colt, and a young ass, (M, Msb, K,) when weaned, (M, K,) or separated from his mother: (Msb:) or when a year old; (K;) or faluw~N signifies also a colt that is a year old: (M: [see qaAriHN:]) and a light, or an active, ass: (IAar, TA voce yaEofuwrN:) and sometimes (S) the female is called faluw~apN: (S, Msb:) the pl. is A^afolaA='N, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) like A^aEodaA'N as pl. of Eaduw~N, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and like A^aHobaArN as pl. of HiborN, (TA,) and also falaAwaY, (S, K,) and fulowN, mentioned by Fr, (M, TA,) and filaA='N is mentioned as a pl. of faluw~ signifying a colt by Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee. (TA.)
badawiy~apN falawiy~apN * are epithets applied to a woman [each signifying Of, or belonging to, the falaAp, or desert]. (TA.)
mufolK * and mufoliyapN A mare having a faluw~. (S, TA.)

1 falaY rA^osahu * , (M, Mgh, K,) and viyaAbahu, (Mgh,) [aor.
faliYa ,] inf. n. faloYN; (M, Mgh;) and raA^osahu ↓ fl~Y also; (K; [but not in my copy of the TA;]) He searched his head, (M, Mgh, K,) and his clothes, (Mgh,) for lice: (M, Mgh, K:) [and it appears from an explanation below (see 8) that AftlY raA^osahu perhaps signifies the same:] or one says, falayotu raA^osahu mina Alqamoli [I searched his head for lice]: (S:) or falayotu raA^osiY, aor. as above, and so the inf. n., signifies I cleared my head of lice. (Msb.) [See also AlfilaA='u, below.] In the saying of 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-kerib,
taraAhu kaAlv~agaAmi yugal~~u misokFA
yasowo'u AlfaAliyaAti A_i*aA falayoniY
[Thou seest it (meaning the white hair intermixing with black) like the thagham (the plant so called) inserted in musk, grieving the lousing women when they louse me], falayoniY is for falayonaniY, (T, S,) the two n being deemed difficult of utterance; (T;) as Akh says, he has rejected the latter n because it is merely a preservative to the verb [lest its affix should be supposed to form an essential part of it], whereas the former n may not be rejected, because it is the pronoun of the verb. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] falaY Al$~iEora, (ISk, T, S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He considered, and endeavoured to understand, the poetry, and elicited its meanings, (ISk, T, S, K, TA,) and what was strange of it: (ISk, S, TA:) or, accord. to the A, he investigated the meanings of the poetry: one says, Aifoli h`*aA Albayota faA_in~ahu SaEobN (tropical:) [Investigate thou the meaning of this verse, for it is difficult]. (TA.) [Freytag has mentioned falaA, in art. flw, as signifying “ Disquisivit, ” and as followed by En; from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.] And falaY AlA^amora (assumed tropical:) He considered, or examined, the various modes of the affair, or case, endeavouring to obtain a clear knowledge of them, and looked to its result. (T, TA.) And falayotu Alquwma biEayoniY (assumed tropical:) [I examined the people, or party, with my eye, in order to know them]: and falayotu xabarahumo (assumed tropical:) [I examined their state, or case, in order to know it]. (TA.) And falaAhu fiY Eaqolihi, (T, M, K, TA,) aor. as above, (T, TA,) and so the inf. n., (M, TA,) (tropical:) He looked, or examined, to see what was his intelligence: (T, TA:) or he tried, or tested, him, in respect of his intelligence. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- falayotu Alqawoma I entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the people; (T, TA; *) as also falawotuhumo; (T;) and so ↓ A^afolayotuhumo. (TA.) And falaY AlmafaAzapa He passed through the mfAzp [i. e. desert, or waterless desert]. (TA.) ― -b4- falaAhu baAls~ayofi, aor. yafoliyhi, (K, TA,) inf. n. faloYN, (TA,) signifies the same as falaAhu, aor. yafoluwhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. falowN. (TA.) See the latter verb in art. flw. -A2- faliYa i. q. AinoqaTaEa [It, or he, was cut, or cut off, &c.]. (IAar, T, K.)
2 fal~aYa see the first sentence above.
4 A^afolaYa see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

5 tfl~Y *
He applied himself, as to a task, to the act of searching his head for lice. (T, * M, TA.)

6 tfAlt AlHumuru *
The asses scratched, scraped, or rubbed, one another; as though they were lousing one another. (M, TA.) ― -b2- See also 10.

8 yafotaluwna AlfalaApa * , (T,) or AlmakaAna, (K, *) (tropical:) They depasture the herbage (T, K *) of the flAp [or desert, or waterless desert, &c.], (T,) or of the place, (K,) and seek for the portions of herbage that are beginning to dry up therein; like as [is done when] the head is searched for lice (kamaA yufotalaY Alr~aA^osu or kmA yufolaY AlrA^s accord. to two transcripts from the T). (T in arts. flw and flY of the TT.) [This meaning of the verb is expl. (imperfectly) in art. flw, to which it does not belong.]

10 AstflY raA^osahu * , and ↓ tfAlY, (S, K,) i. e. tfAlY huwa [not tfAlY rA^sh], (S,) He desired that his head might be searched for lice. (S, K.) -A2- And AstflAhu He exposed himself to have his head struck and cut with the sword: (M, TA:) a poet says,
A^amaAtaraAniY raAbiTa AljanaAni
A^afoliyhi biAls~ayofi A_i*aA A@sotafolaAniY
[Dost thou not see me to be strong of heart? I will strike and cut his head with the sword when he exposes himself to be so struck &c.]

[
filoyapN * , mentioned in this art. by Freytag, with falaAliY~N as its pl., is taken by him from a mistranscription in the CK in art. fl: see fil~iy~apN in that art.]

AlflaA='u * , like kisaA=' [in measure], means flA=' Al$Er, [evidently, I think, filaA='u Al$~aEara, or the first word may be a mistranscription for faloYu,] i. e. Ax*k mA fyh [lit. Thy taking what is in it, in which “ it ” refers to the $Er: app. a euphemism for the taking of lice from the hair: if so, it may be an inf. n., like faloYN; (see 1, first sentence;) or it may be a simple subst., like what here follows]: mentioned by IAmb, from his companions. (TA.)
filaAyapN * [The act of searching the head for lice;] the subst. from falaY raA^osahu signifying “ he searched his head for lice. ” (Lth, * T, * K.) [See also the next preceding paragraph.]

[
faAlK * act. part. n. of 1: fem. faAliyapN.] faAliyaAtN and fawaAlK [are pls. of faAliyapN and] signify Women who search the head for lice. (T, TA.) See an ex. of the former pl. in the verse cited in the first paragraph. ― -b2- faAliyapu AlA^afaAEiY (in which the former word is a pl. [in meaning], M, TA) signifies [lit. The lousers of the vipers; meaning,] accord. to the A, certain species of the kind [of beetles] called xanaAfis [pl. of xunofasaA='], speckled, found at the holes of the serpents, which they louse: (TA:) or a certain xnfsA=', speckled (M, K) with [the colour termed] SuHomap, which is found at the holes [of serpents &c.], and is the mistress of xanaAfis; (M;) which is familiar with scorpions and serpents; so that when it comes forth from a hole [thereof], it makes known their existence [therein]: (K:) or certain small things like xnaAfs, speckled; which are familiar with scorpions and serpents; so that when they are seen in the hole [thereof] it is known that behind them are scorpions and serpents: (T:) or certain insects (dawaAb~u) that are found at the holes of the [lizards called] DibaAb [pl. of Dab~u]; so that when they come forth, it is known that the Dab~ is coming forth inevitably. (M.) Hence one says, Attkm faAliyapu AlA^afaAEiY, (IAar, T, M, K, *) meaning (assumed tropical:) The beginning of evil to be looked for [has come to you], (IAar, T,) or the beginnings of evil [hare come to you]; (K;) which is a prov. (IAar, T.) ― -b3- And [hence] Aibonu AlfawaAliY means The jaAn~; i. e. the serpent [so called]. (T in art. bnY.)
faAliyapN * [fem. of faAlK, q. v. ― -b2- And also] A knife. (T.)

famN * The mouth: (MA, KL, &c.:) it is originally fawahN, (S, K, and Msb in art. fwh,) with two fet-hahs, (Msb in that art.,) or fawohN; (so in some copies of the S;) the h being cut off from it, the w is not susceptible of declension, because it is quiescent, therefore m is substituted for it; but when you form the dim. or the pl., you restore it to its original state, saying [in the former case] fuwayohN and [in the latter case] A^afowaAhN, and not A^afomaA='N [in some of the copies of the S not A^afomaAmN]: but when you form the rel. n., you say ↓ famiY~N; and, if you will, ↓ famawiY~N, combining the substitute and the letter for which it is substituted, like as they say in the dual famawaAni; this being held to be allowable because of there being therein another letter rejected, i. e. the h, as though they made the m in this case to be a substitute for the h, not for the w: (S, TA:) and one says also famayaAni, which, like famawaAni, is anomalous; (IAar, K in art. fwh;) but one says famaAni also, as well as famawaAni: (Msb in art. fwh:) it has three forms, famN and fumN and fimN: (S, K, TA:) and some decline it doubly; saying in the nom. case fumN, accus. famFA, and gen. fimK; (S, TA;) like Aimoruw^N and AibonumN, which have been said to be the only other instances of the kind: (TA:) when it is prefixed to the [pronominal] Y, one says fiY~a and famiY: but when to [a pronoun] other than the Y, it is declined with the letters w and A and Y, so that one says fuwuhu and faAhu and fiyhi; but one also says famuhu: (Msb. in art. fwh:) and sometimes the m is musheddedeh, (S, K,) in poetry, as in the saying, (S, TA,) of Mohammad Ibn-Dhu-eyb El-'Ománee El-Fukeymee, the rájiz, (TA in this art. and in art. Tsm,) addressing Er-Rasheed, or, accord. to IKh, said in relation to Suleymán Ibn-'Abd-El-Melik and 'Abd-El- 'Azeez. (TA in art. Tsm,)
yaA layotahaA qado xarajato mino fum~ihi
Hat~aY yaEuwda Almuloku fiY A^usoTum~ihi
(S, TA) or A^uTosum~ihi i. e. [O, would that it had gone forth from his mouth, so that the dominion might return] to its rightful owner; (S in art. sTm, and TA in art. Tsm;) and it would have been allowable, (S, TA,) accord. to ISk, (S,) or accord. to Fr, (TA,) if he had said ↓ mn fam~ihi, with fet-h to the f: (S, TA:) the pl. of fm, with teshdeed, is A^afomaAmN; and its dim. is ↓ fumayomN, mentioned by Lh. (TA.) MF says that many of the expositors of the Tes-heel have collected the dial. vars. of this word, compounded and uncompounded, and they have exceeded twenty; that with fet-h, they say, being the most common and the most chaste. (TA.) [See more in art. fwh.] ― -b2- [Hence,] Alfm is metonymically applied to (tropical:) The teeth. (Ham p. 242.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] famu AlHuwti (assumed tropical:) The star [a] in the mouth of Piscis Australis. (Kzw &c.: see art. Hwt.) And famu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) The star [e] upon the lip of Pegasus. (Kzw.) ― -b4- [And famuAlr~aHimi (assumed tropical:) The mouth of the womb.] ― -b5- And famu Aln~ahori (assumed tropical:) The mouth of the river. (MA.) ― -b6- And [hence likewise,] famN is also used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Branch; opposed to AisotN meaning “ root. ” (TA in art. sth; in which see AisotN, last quarter.) -A2- famN mina Ald~ibaAgi means The quantity that is used at one time, of tan; (Fr, K, * TA;) like nafosN minohu. (Fr, TA.)
famiY~N * and famawiY~N: see the preceding paragraph, near the beginning.

fum~a * a dial. var. of the conjunction tum~a [q. v.]: (K:) or the f in the former is a substitute for the v in the latter: one says, raA^ayotu EamorFA fum~a zayodFA and vum~a zayodFA, both meaning the same [i. e. I saw 'Amr: then Zeyd]: (TA:) and in like manner one says fum~ata and fum~ato, meaning tum~ata and tum~ato. (M and TA voce vum~a.)
fum~N * and fam~N: see the first paragraph, latter half.
fumayomN * : see the first paragraph, latter half.

1 fan~ahu * , (M,) or fan~a AlA_ibila, (T, S,) aor.
fanu3a , (T, M,) inf. n. fan~N, (T, S, M, K,) He drove away (T, S, M, K *) him, (M,) or the camels. (T, S.) ― -b2- And [fan~ahu also signifies He delayed, or deferred, with him, or put him off, in the matter of his debt, by promising time after time to pay him; for] one of the significations of Alfan~u is AlmaTolu. (T, K.) ― -b3- And fan~ahu, aor.
fanu3a , (M,) inf. n. fan~N, (M, K,) He cheated, deceived, overreached, or defrauded, him; or made him to suffer loss or damage or detriment; syn. of the inf. n. gabon~N. (M, K.) ― -b4- And He caused him to suffer difficulty, distress, or trouble; or fatigue, or weariness; syn. Ean~aAhu; (M;) or the syn. of Alfan~u is AlEanaA='u [which is the subst. from Ean~aAhu; and signifies difficulty, distress, or trouble]. (T, K.) ― -b5- [And He, or it, adorned. or decorated, him, or it; for] Alfan~u signifies Alt~azoyiynu. (K.)

2 fn~n Aln~aAsa *
He made the men, or people, to consist of different sorts, or of a medley, not of
one tribe. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- fn~n AlHadiyva He diversified the narrative, or discourse. (MA.) And fn~n AlkalaAma [He diversified the speech, or language: or] he branched off into one mode after another [in speech]: and so ↓ tfn~n [alone, this verb being intrans.]. (T, TA.) And fn~n raA^oyahu He varied his opinion, not keeping steadily to one opinion. (T, TA.) ― -b3- And [the inf. n.] tafoniynN signifies The mixing or confusing [a thing or things]; or a state of confusion or disorder; syn. taxoliyTN. (S, K.) [Hence, as inf. n. of fun~ina,] in a garment, or piece of cloth, [the having] streaks differing from the rest: (S, K:) or the state of becoming dissundered, (T, M,) one part from another, (T,) when old and worn out, without becoming much rent: (T, M:) or difference (M, K) in its make (M) or in its texture, (K,) by thinness in one place and thickness in another: (M, K:) or Alt~afoniynu signifies [there being] what is a thin, or flimsy, unseemly place in the garment, or piece of cloth, that is [in other parts] thick, or compact. (T.) ― -b4- And fn~n signifies also He sought many [or various] things. (Har p. 612.)

5 tfn~n *
It was, or became, of various sorts, or modes, or manners. (KL.) ― -b2- See also 2. You say likewise tfn~n fiY AlkalaAmi [He practised, or took to, various modes, or manners, in speech; he diversified therein]. (TA in art. Trq, conj. 3. [Thus used, it is like Aftn~, q. v.]) ― -b3- And tfn~n fiY AlEuluwmi He was, or became, possessed of various acquirements in the sciences. (MA.) -A2- Also It was, or became, in a state of commotion: thus expl. by some; others add, like the fanan [or branch]. (M.)

8 Aftn~ *
He began, commenced, or entered upon, various sorts of speech. (M, K.) And Aftn~ fiY Hadiyvihi and fiY xuTobatihi He produced, or gave utterance to, various sorts and ways of speech, [i. e. he diversified,] in his narration, or discourse, and in his oration, or harangue: (S, TA:) it is like Ai$otaq~a [meaning he branched off in it]. (S. [See also 5.]) And Aftn~ fiY xuSuwmatihi He expatiated, and practised versatility, in his altercation, or disputation, or litigation. (TA.) ― -b2- And Aftn~ AlHimaAru biA^utunihi The he-ass betook himself to driving away his she-asses to the right and to the left and in a direct and an indirect course. (TA.)

10 Astfn~hu *
He incited, urged, or made, him to practise various sorts, or modes, or manners, of pacing. (K.)

R. Q. 1 fanofana *
He (a man, IAar, T) caused his camels to become dispersed, by reason of indolence and remissness. (IAar, T, K.)

fan~N *
A sort, or species, syn. DarobN, (T, M, K,) or nawoEN, (S, Msb,) of a thing; (Msb;) as also ↓ A^ufonuwnN [in this sense and in the senses here following; in the CK, erroneously, Aafonuwn]: (M, K:) and a state, or condition; syn. HaAlN: (M, K:) [and a way: (see what follows:)] and a mode, or manner: (MA:) pl. [of mult.] funuwnN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] A^afonaAnN. (T, M, K.) One says, raEayonaA funuwna Aln~abaAti [We pastured our cattle upon the various sorts of herbage]: and A^aSabonaA funuwna AlA^amowaAli [We obtained the various sorts of possessions]: and a poet says,
qado labisotu Ald~ahora mino A^afonaAnihi
kul~u fan~K naAEimK minohu Habiro
[I have enjoyed of the various sorts of fortune, every pleasant, soft, sort thereof]. (T.) [↓ A^ufonwunN has for its pl. A^afaAniyonu, which may also be regarded as pl. of A^afonaAnN pl. of fan~N like as it is said to be a pl. pl. of fananN: and] A^afaAniynu [alone], (S,) or A^afaAniynu kalaAmK, (TA,) signifies kinds [or sorts], and ways, or modes, or manners, [i. e. diversities, or varieties,] of speech; (S, TA, * PS;) like A^asaAliybu [pl. of A^usoluwbN]. (S, TA.) And funuwnN signifies Different sorts of men, or a medley thereof, not of one tribe. (M.) ― -b2- Also A wonderful thing or affair or case. (S, TA.)

huwa fin~u EilomK *
He is [a good student of science, i. e.] one who occupies himself well with science. (K.)

fan~apN mina Ald~ahori *
A particular period of time; [or a particular time;] as also fayonapN. (T, K. *) The Arabs say, kunotu biHaAli ka*aA waka*aA fan~apF mina Ald~ahori and fayonapF minaAld~ahori [I was in such and such a state, or condition, at, or during, a particular time]. (T.)

fun~apN *
Much, or abundance, of herbage. (IAar, K.)

fananN *
A branch of a tree: (S, M, Msb, K:) or such as is of just proportion in length or in breadth: (T:) said to be syn. with guSonN; but this latter signifies “ such as has been cut off ” i. q. qaDiybN meaning maqoDuwbN: (M:) pl. A^afonaAnN; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) said by Sb to be its only pl.; (M;) occurring in the Kur lv. 48; where some explain it as pl. of fan~N, and meaning “ sorts, ” or “ species ”; others, as pl. of fananN: (T, Bd:) and A^afaAniynu is a pl. pl., (T, S, K,) i. e. pl. of A^afonaAnN. (T, S.) ― -b2- And as a branch shelters like as does darkness, a poet uses it metaphorically, saying,
A^agaAva $ariydahumo fananu AlZ~alaAmi
(tropical:) [The shelter of the darkness aided him, or them, who fled]. (M.) ― -b3- And [in like manner also] the pl. pl. is used in a trad. describing the inmates of Paradise, as meaning (tropical:) Locks of hair; these being likened to branches: and El-Marrár says,
A^aEalaAqapF A^um~a Alwaliydi baEodamaA
A^afonaAnu raA^osika kaAlv~agaAmi Almuxolisi
(tropical:) [Dost thou feel attachment of love to Umm-ElWeleed after that the locks of thy head have become like the hoary thaghám?]; meaning the locks of the hair of his head when he had become hoary. (T. [See vagaAmN.])

faniynN *
A humour in the armpit [of a camel], with pain. (M, K.) ― -b2- And A camel having the tumour thus called; as also ↓ mafonuwnN. (M, K.)

$ajarapN fan~aA='u * and fanowaA='u, which latter is anomalous, A tree having branches; (S;) the latter thus expl. by AA; but by rule it should be fan~aA='u: (A'Obeyd, T:) or the latter, which is anomalous, signifies having long branches: (M:) or both signify having many branches. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence] AimoraA^apN fanowaA='u (assumed tropical:) A woman having much hair: but in this case, as in the former, the epithet, by rule, should be fan~aA='u. (M.) [See also fayonaAnN.]

fan~aAnN *
A wild ass that has various sorts, or modes, of running: (S, K:) used in this sense in the poetry of El-Aashà. (S.) [See also mifan~N.]

$aEarN fayonaAnN * (assumed tropical:) Hair having locks [lit. branches (A^afonaAn)] (M, * K) like the A^afonaAn of trees; [the latter word properly signifying having many branches, (see Ham p. 622,) of the measure fayoEaAlN, not faEolaAn;] therefore it is perfectly decl.: so says Sb: (M:) or it signifies long and beautiful hair; the latter word being of the measure fayoEaAlN from Alfananu, and the Y augmentative. (T.) ― -b2- And one says also, agreeably with analogy, rajulN fayonaAnN, (M,) and AimoraA^apN fayonaAnapN, (M, K,) meaning [A man, and a woman,] having much hair; (K;) for fayonaAn is perfectly decl., derived from A^afonaAnu Al$~ajari: IAar has mentioned AimoraA^apN fayonaY meaning [a woman] having much hair; and if the phrase be thus, fayonaAn must be imperfectly decl.; but [ISd says] I regard this as a mistake of IAar. (M.) [See also art. fyn.]

A^ufonuwnN * : see fan~N, in two places. -A2- Also A tangled, or luxuriant, or dense, branch. (T, K.) ― -b2- And Obscure, indistinct, or confused, speech, (T, K,) of a foolish, stupid, or dull, person. (T.) ― -b3- And A mixed, or confused, run, of a horse and of a she-camel. (T, K.) -A3- Also A serpent. (T, M, K.) ― -b2- And An old woman: so some say: (M:) or an old woman advanced in age: (T, K:) or one who is flaccid, or flabby: (K:) Yaakoob has explained it as having the first of these three meanings; but IB regards this as improbable, because a verse of Ibn-Ahmar which is cited as an ex. thereof is preceded by what shows that it is applied to his beloved. (TA.) [It is said in the M to be also the proper name of a certain woman; and as such it may be used by Ibn-Ahmar.] ― -b3- And i. q. daAhiyapN [A calamity, or misfortune, &c.]: (M, K:) so some say. (M.) -A4- And The first part of youth, or youthfulness; and of clouds. (M, K.)

mifan~N * A man who has various sorts, or modes, [i. e. diversities, or varieties,] of speech; (T, TA;) and so ↓ mutafan~inN: (S:) or a man who utters, or performs, wonderful things: (S, K, TA:) fem. with p. (T, S, K.) ― -b2- And A horse that performs various sorts, or modes, of running. (TA.)

mufan~anN * A garment, or piece of cloth, diversified; not uniform. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And Old, and evil in disposition, as an epithet applied to a man: (M:) and so with p applied to a woman. (M, K.) ― -b3- Also, with p, A she-camel that seems to one to have been ten months pregnant, vum~a tanoka$ifu mana Alki$aAfi [app. meaning then suffers, or exposes, herself to be compressed; from Alki$aAfu as inf. n. of ka$afat said of a she-camel: compare tnk$f as here used with takota$ifu said of a woman]. (K.)
mafonuwnN * : see faniynN.
mutafan~inu * : see mifan~N.

funotuqN *
A xaAn of the way or road; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) a dial. var. of funoduqN [q. v.]; disapproved by El-Khafájee; but heard by Fr from a desertArab of Kudá'ah, as meaning a funoduq, i. e. xaAn. (TA.)
finojaAn * and finojaAnap: see filojaAnN, in art. flj.

1 fanaxa * , aor.
fanaxa , (L,) inf. n. fanoxN, (L, K,) He bruised a bone without splitting, or cleaving, it, and without causing to bleed: (K:) or fanaxa raA^osahu bi$aYo'K he bruised the bone of his head with a thing without making an apparent cleft or causing blood to flow: or he struck his head with a thing, meaning a staff, or stick, cleaving it or not cleaving it. (L.) And fanaxa raA^osahu, and ↓ fn~xhu, He broke his head, and rendered him submissive, or abased him. (L.) And fanaxahu, aor.
fanaxa , inf. n. fanoxN and funuwxN, He weakened him, rendered him languid, or enervated him. (L.) And fanaxahu, (S, L,) aor.
fanaxa , (L,) inf. n. fanoxN; (L, K;) and ↓ fn~xhu, inf. n. tafoniyxN; (S, L, K;) and ↓ tfn~xhu; (L;) He, or it, (an affair, or event, S,) overcame him, overpowered him, subdued him, and rendered him submissive, or abased him: (S, L, K:) or did so in the worst, or most abominable, manner. (L.)
2 fan~axa see the preceding paragraph, in two places.
5 tafan~axa see 1, last sentence.

faniyxN * A man overcome, overpowered, subdued, and rendered submissive, or abased: or overcome, &c., in the worst, or most abominable, manner. (L.) And An old man: (L:) [a man] flaccid, or flabby, and weak. (L, K.)

mifonaxN * A man who abases his enemies, and breaks their heads, much, or often. (S, K.) In explaining this word, J uses raA^osahumo for zuw^uwsahumo; and the author of the K does the same, though in art. slE he charges J with error for using a similar expression. (MF.) [Or, perhaps, the meaning here intended may be, and defeats their head, or chief.]
gayoru mafonuwxK * , occurring in a trad., applied to a [garment of the kind called] burod, means Not old and worn out, nor weak. (TA.)

1 fanida * , aor.
fanada , (TK,) inf. n. fanadN; (S, M, A, O, L, K, TA;) or fnd, [perhaps fanada, not fanida,] inf. n. funuwdN; (IKtt, TA;) and ↓ Afnd, (S, IKtt, L,) inf. n. A_ifonaAdN; (S, L, K;) He lied; uttered a falsehood; said what was untrue: (S, M, IKtt, A, O, L, K:) this is [said to be] the primary signification. (L.) ↓ qawolK A_ifonaAdK is used by a poet for qawolK *iY A_ifonaAdK [A saying having, or characterized by, lying, or falsehood]. (M, L.) ― -b2- And fanida. aor.
fanada , (TK,) inf. n. fanadN, (M, O, K,) He erred, or committed a mistake or mistakes, (M, O, K, TK,) in extreme old age, (O,) in speech, or in judgment, or opinion: (M, K, TK:) and ↓ Afnd he made many mistakes in his speech. (As, TA in art. shb.) ― -b3- And fanida, aor.
fanada , (IKtt, TA, TK,) inf. n. fanadN; (T, S, M, IKtt, A, O, L, K;) and ↓ Afnd; (S, M, IKtt, L;) He became weak in judgment by reason of extreme old age (S, IKtt, A, O, L;) or he became unsound in mind, (M, L, K,) [in such a state that] his intellect, or intelligence, was denied, or disapproved. (T, M, K, TK, Alfanadu being expl. in the T and M and K by A_inokaAru AlEaqoli, and fanada in the TK by Ankr Eqlh [meaning A^unokira Eaqoluhu], and in like manner Afnd [of which see the part. n., mufonidN, below, as expl. in the A],) by reason of extreme old age, (T, M, K, TK,) or disease; (M, K, TK:) primarily thus restricted to the case of old age, but sometimes used without the being so restricted: (M:) and ↓ Afnd is also expl. as signifying he became weak in intellect, or doted: (IKtt, TA:) and as signifying he became extremely aged, because he who has become so speaks perverted language; from the same verb as signifying he lied. (L,) ― -b4- [And fanida, inf. n. fanadN, app. signifies also He was, or became, impotent: and unthankful for the favour of God: see finodN.]

2 fn~dhu * , inf. n. tafoniydN, He pronounced him to be a liar, an utterer of falsehood, or a sayer of what was untrue. (Fr, M, K.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- He blamed him, (S, O, L,) and pronounced his judgment to be weak: (S, A, O, L:) or he pronounced him, (Fr, T,) or it, i. e. his judgment, (IAar, T,) to be weak. (Fr, IAar, T.) And He pronounced him to be impotent, or lacking in ability. (Fr, M, L, K.) -A2- fn~d farasFA He acquired, or got for himself, a horse: (T, O, TA:) so says Hároon Ibn-'Abd-Allah, as mentioned by Sh: but (Az says) I know it not in this sense: thus in the T: (TA:) or [rather] he took him for the purpose of tying him, or keeping post, on the enemy's frontier, (T, TA,) and as a refuge to which to have recourse (T, O, TA) when suddenly attacked by the enemy; (T, TA;) from finodN, (T, O, TA,) signifying “ a $imoraAx, ” (O,) or “ a great $mrAx, ” (T, TA,) “ of a mountain, ” (T, O, TA,) or as signifying “ a great mountain: ” (O:) or i. q. Dam~arahu [as meaning he made him light of flesh for military service], (O, K, TA,) so as to be like the branch of a tree, termed finod. (O, TA.) -A3- fn~d fulaAnFA EalaY AlA^amori He desired, of such a one, [the performance of] the affair; (K, TA;) as also ↓ fAndhu, (O, K, TA, in the O fiY AlA^amori,) inf. n. mufaAnadapN; (TA;) and ↓ tfn~dhu. (O, K, TA.) -A4- fn~d fiY Al$~araAbi He kept constantly, or perseveringly, to be beverage, or wine. (AHn, M, K, TA.) -A5- And fn~d (inf. n. tafoniydN, TA) He sat upon a finod, (T, L,) i. e. a $imoraAx of a mountain. (T, O, K.)
3 faAonada see 2, near the end of the paragraph.

4 Afnd * , inf. n. A_ifonaAdN, as intrans.: see 1, in five places. -A2- Afndhu (inf. n. as above, TA) He charged him with error in judgment, or opinion; as also ↓ fn~dhu. (M, K.) ― -b2- And It (old age) rendered him weak in judgment, or unsound in mind: (L:) or it (extreme old age) caused him to have little understanding; [or to be] like a stone. (A.)

5 tfn~d *
He repented, (K, B, TA,) minohu [of it]. (T, K.) -A2- tfn~dhu: see 2, near the end.

8 Aufotunida *
He was caused to perish by reason of extreme old age. (O.)
fanodN * : see the next paragraph, first sentence.

finodN * (T, S, M, A, O, L, K) and ↓ fanodN (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K) A great mountain: (IF, O, K:) or a mountain apart from others: (Ibn-Abi-l- Hadeed, TA:) or a portion of a mountain, (Ibn- 'Abbád, S, O, K,) or a great portion thereof, (M, TA,) having tallness, or length, [app. the former,] (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O, K, TA,) and some add, with slenderness: (TA:) or a head, or round and tall and slender head, or peak, ($imoraAx,) of a mountain: (T, A:) or a great peak or head ($mrAx, T, L, or raA^os, M, L,) of a mountain: (T, M, L:) or a rukon [i. e. a side, or an outward part, or the strongest side or outward part,] of a mountain: (L:) pl. A^afonaAdN. (M, L.) One says of a bulky and heavy man, kaA^an~ahu finodN, meaning As though he were a head, or peak, ($imoraAx,) of a mountain. (A.) ― -b2- And the former (finodN) is the sing. of A^afonaAd in the phrase A^afonaAdu All~ayoli, (T,) which means The component parts, or portions, of the night. (T, O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And A congregated party (T, O, K, TA.) of men. (T, O.) One says, humo finodN EalaY HidapK They are a party by itself. (T, TA.) And it is said in a trad., (T.) respecting the Prophet, (T, O, K,) that, when he died, (O.) Sal~aY Aln~aAsu Ealayohi A^afonaAdFA A^afonaAdFA i. e. [The people prayed for him, or invoked blessing upon him,] one by one, without an Imám; (Th, T, O, K;) or companies after companies: (O, K:) and they were computed to be thirty thousand, with sixty thousand angels; two angels to every one (T, O, K) of the believers. (T, O.) And the Prophet
said, (T, O, K,) after announcing that he would be among the first that should die, (T, O,) tat~abiEuwniY A^afonaAdFA A^afonaAdFA yuholiku baEoDukumo baEoDFA, meaning [Ye will follow me] in scattered companies, company after company; [killing one another;] A^afonaAdFA being pl. of finod; (Nh, TA;) and in like manner is expl. a similar phrase in a trad. of 'Áïsheh: (T, TA:) or the former means ↓ *awiY fanadK i. e. [impotent; and unthankful; lit] having impotence; and unthankfulness for [God's] favour. (O, K, TA.) ― -b4- And A sort, or species: (K, TA:) pl. A^afonaAdN: one says, jaAw^uwA A^afonaAdFA They came being diverse sorts. (TA.) ― -b5- And A branch of a tree. (T, O, K. *) ― -b6- And Land upon which rain has not fallen; (T, O, K;) also termed ↓ findyp [app. finodiy~apN]. (T.)
fanadN * [inf. n. of fanida, q. v.: as a subst.,] i. q. fuHo$N [app. as meaning Exorbitance in speech]; and error in judgment: pl. A^afonaAdN. (Ham p. 112.) ― -b2- See also finodN, near the end.

finodapN *
A complete branch from which a bow is made. (O.)
findyp * [app. finodiy~apN]: see finodN, last sentence.
finodaA^owapN * (in the O and CK without hemz) A sharp qaduwm [or adz]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And A bold, or fearless, she-camel. (IAar and Sh, TA in art. EdA^.)

finodaA^oyapN *
An adz, or an axe, or a hoe; syn. faA^osN: (I'Aar, T, L:) or a broad-headed fA^s: (M, L:) pl. fanaAdiydu, which is anomalous. (IAar, T, L.)

faAniydN *
A sort of sweetmeat, made of concrete juice of the sugar-cane (qanod, q. v.,) and starch (na$FA): a foreign word; for the measure faAEiylN is not found in Arabic; and therefore the lexicographers have not mentioned it: (Msb:) it is also written with *; (MF;) and is an arabicized word, from [the Pers.] PaAniydo [or PaAniy*o]: (K voce faAniy*:) but is more properly with d. (MF.)

mufonidN * , (T, S, L, K,) or ↓ mufan~adN, [meaning Weak in judgment, or unsound in mind, &c., (see 1,) by reason of extreme old age, or disease,] an epithet applied to a man only: you do not use the fem. form, with p, applying it to an old woman, because [it is held that] she has not possessed judgment (T, S, M, L, K) in her youth (T, S, M, L) or at any time: (K:) or both mufonidN and ↓ mufan~adN signify [as above: or] one whose intellect, or intelligence, is denied, or disapproved, (A^anokira Eaqoluhu,) by reason of extreme old age: or who confounds [things] in his speech: (A:) or the former, or ↓ the latter, signifies loquacious by reason of unsoundness of mind: (As, T:) and the former signifies weak in intellect: (L:) [and extremely aged: (see 1:)] and the same, (T,) or ↓ the latter, (L,) weak in judgment; notwithstanding he may be strong in body: and weak in body; notwithstanding he may be right in judgment: and weak in judgment and in body. (Fr, T, L.)
mufan~adN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
fanodarN * and funodurN, applied to a boy or youth, Plump: and wanting in courage and generosity; stupid and heavy. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

finodiyrN * and ↓ finodiyrapN (K in this art., and S in art. fdr,) A great mass of rock that becomes detached (S, K) from the head (S) or from the side (K) of a mountain: (S, K:) pl. fanaAdiyru. (TA.) ― -b2- And, both words, A large lump of dates (K, TA) compacted together; as also fidorapN. (TA.)

Alfunoduwrapu *
The anus. (IAar, T, O, TA.)
finodiyrapN * : see finodiyrN. Accord. to some, the n in the words mentioned in this art. is augmentative. (O.)

funoduqN * The fruit of a certain tree, (Lth, O, K,) the same as the bunoduq, which has been mentioned before, [i. e. hazel-nut, or hazel-nuts,] (K,) or round, like the bunoduq, having a covering which, being removed, discloses a kernel (Hab~), like the fusotuq. (Lth, O.) -A2- And, (Lth, O, K,) in the dial. of the people of Syria, A [building of the kind called] xaAn [q. v.], where men alight and lodge, [and in which they deposit their goods,] of the xaAnaAt that are in the roads, (Lth, O, K, *) and in the cities: (Lth, O:) [said to be] a Pers. word, [app. from the Greek πανδοχεῖον occurring in Luke x. 34, as remarked by Golius,] mentioned by Sb: pl. fanaAdiqu. (TA.)

funodaAqN *
A register of accounts: (O, K:) thought by As to be an arabicized word: but the word commonly known [in this sense] is with q [i. e. qunodaAqN]. (TA.)

fanozajN *
A leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding; and so ↓ fanozajapN: (L:) or the game, or sport, called dasotabanod, [or dasutobanod, a Pers. word,] meaning the dance of the Magians, (Lth, O, L,) or a dance of the Persians (AlEajam), (S, K,) in which the performers hold one another by the hand; (Lth, S, O, K;) arabicized from [the Pers.] Panojaho [app. as meaning “ a gripe with the hand ”]: (S, K:) or a game, or sport, of the Nabathæans, 1. called in Pers. PanojaGaAno [app. from Panojaho and GaAno, from the joining of hands]; (ISk, O;) a game, or sport, played by the Nabathæans in joyous exultation: (IAar, O:) occurring in a saying of El-'Ajjáj cited in art. Ekf. (TA. See 1 in that art.) ― -b2- And, as some say, The five embolismal, or supplementary days, which are added at the end of the twelfth month of the Persians [and called by them Panojah'i duzodiydaho]. (IDrd, O, L.)
fanozajapN * : see the preceding paragraph.

finoTAsN * [The bottom of the hold of a ship or boat; i. e.] the part of a ship or boat where the water that is drawn out therefrom collects: (AA, O, K, TA:) this is the primary signification: (O, TA:) pl. fanaATiysu. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (O,) A tank made of boards, (O, K,) and tarred, (O,) borne in sea-going vessels, (O, K, *) and containing sweet water for drinking. (O, * K.) ― -b3- And, (O, K,) accord. to IAar, (O,) A bowl (O, K) of wood, the exterior of which is coloured with yellow and red and green, (O,) with which the sweet water is distributed (O, K) among the ship's crew. (O.) -A2- It is also applied to a nose, as signifying Broad. (IDrd, M, TA. [See also what next follows.])

finoTiysN * A nose wide in the nostril, and expanded in the end: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) pl. fanaATiysu. (K. [See also what next precedes.]) ― -b2- And, (O, K,) accord. to IDrd, (O,) A man broad in the nose. (O, K.) ― -b3- And Low, ignoble, or ungenerous, (O, K, TA,) accord. to some, in an absolute sense, (TA,) or in respect of birth; (O, K, TA;) thus accord. to Ibn-'Abbád: pl. as above. (O.) -A2- Also The penis; (O, K;) and so firoTiysN: accord. to some, peculiarly of the swine. (TA.)

finoTiysapN * The snout of the swine: (O, K: [mentioned also in art. fTs; the n being held by some to be augmentative:]) and so firoTiysapN. (TA.) And The nose of the wolf. (O.) And one says, A_in~ahu lamaniyEu AlfinoTiysapi (O, K *) and AlfiroTiysapi, (O,) meaning (assumed tropical:) [Verily he is] one who defends, or guards, from encroachment, or invasion, or attack, what is in his possession, or occupation; who refuses to submit to wrongful treatment: (O, K:) thus mentioned on the authority of As; and Aboo-Sa'eed [meaning As] says that his finoTiysap and firoTiysap [properly] signify his nose. (TA.)

1 faniEa * , aor.
fanaEa , (S, O, * K,) inf. n. fanaEN, (S, O,) He abounded, and increased, in wealth. (S, O, K.) mano qaniEa faniEa is a prov., (O, TA,) meaning [He who is contented] is free from want, or is rich. (TA.)

fanaEN * [as a simple subst.] Increase, and abundance, of wealth: (S:) increase (O, K, TA) in wealth and in what is little in quantity: (TA:) and i. q. xayorN [good, moral or physical; wealth, or much wealth; prosperity, welfare, or wellbeing; &c.]: and generosity: (O, K, TA:) and large, or ample, liberality or bounty or munificence: (TA:) and excellence; (O, K;) or much, or abundant, excellence. (TA.) One says maAlN *uw fanaEK and fanaA^K, but the former is more common and more known, i. e. Abundant wealth. (TA.) And farasN *aw fanaEK fiY sayorihi A horse having increase [in his rate of going], or having excess [therein]. (TA.) ― -b2- And Strength of odour of musk. (K.) misokN *uw fanaEK means Musk of which the odour is strong.
(S, O.) ― -b3- And Good report. (IDrd, O, K.) And The spreading, or diffusion, of eulogy. (TA.) -A2- Also Much of anything; and so ↓ faniyEN, and ↓ faniEN. (IAar, TA.)

faniEN *
Abounding, and increasing, in wealth; as also ↓ faniyEN. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also fanaEN, last sentence.
faniyEN * : see faniEN: ― -b2- and see also fanaEN, last sentence.
mifonaEN * A man (A'Obeyd, O) having a good report. (A'Obeyd, O, K.)

2 fn~qhu * , (S,) inf. n. tafoniyqN; (O, K;) and ↓ fAnqhu, (S, O,) inf. n. finaAqN; (TA;) He made him to enjoy, or lead, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; or a life of ease and plenty. (S, O, K.)
3 faAonaqa see the preceding paragraph.

4 Afnq *
He (a man, O) enjoyed, or led, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; or a life of ease and plenty; after straitness of the means of subsistence. (O, K.) [See also what next follows.]

5 tfn~q *
He (a man, S) enjoyed, or led, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; or a life of ease and plenty. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And tafan~aqotu fiY A^amorika*aA I affected daintiness, nicety, or refinement, and cleanliness, in such an affair. (TA.)

fanaqN *
Plentifulness, and pleasantness or easiness, and softness or delicacy, in living; as also ↓ funaAqN. (TA.)

funuqN * (S, O, K, TA) and ↓ mifonaAqN (O, K, TA) A woman, (S,) or young woman, (O, K, TA,) that has been made to enjoy, or lead, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; (S, O, K, TA;) large in body, beautiful, and youthful: As says that the former, applied to a woman, signifies having little flesh; but Sh knew not this, and he cites El-Aashà as applying this epithet to a woman whom he describes as one whose elbows are unapparent, and such, he says, is not one having little flesh: IAar says that it is applied to one who is as though she were a stallion-camel such as is termed faniyq. (TA.) ― -b2- And the former, applied to a she-camel, signifies Youthful, fat or plump, (S, O, K, TA,) fleshy, and bulky. (TA.) ― -b3- See also faniyqN. ― -b4- It is also pl. of afniyqN. (S, O, K.)
funaAqN * : see fanaqN.

faniyqN *
A stallion, (S, O, K,) [i. e.] a stallioncamel, (IAar, TA,) that is highly regarded, (S, O, K,) and is not molested, because of the high estimation in which he is held by his owner, or owners, nor is ridden: (O, K:) it is said by AZ to be one of the names for such a stallion: (S, TA:) or it is an epithet applied to a camel, meaning such as is acquired for covering: (TA:) the pl. is funuqN (S, O, K) accord. to AZ, and A^afonaAqN accord. to IDrd, (S,) or the latter is pl. of the former pl.: (O, K:) and ↓ funuq is applied as an epithet to a [single] camel, like faniyqN. (TA.)

faniyqapN *
A [sack such as is called] giraArap [q. v.]: (AA, O, K:) or a small grArp: or a receptacle smaller than the grArp: (TA:) [said by Meyd to be a sack in which clay, or mud, is carried away: (Golius:)] pl. fanaAy^iqu. (O, K.)
Eayo$N mufaAniqN * , (S, O, K,) and some say mufaAnaqN, (TA,) A life that is plentiful, and pleasant or easy, and soft or delicate; or a life of ease and plenty. (S, * O, * K, TA.)
mifonaAqN * : see funuqN.

1 fanaka biAlmakaAni * , [aor.
fanuka , (TK,)] inf. n. funuwkN, He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (El-Umawee, S, O, K.) ― -b2- fanaka fiY AlA^amori, (S, O, K, *) aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n., (S, O,) He persisted, or persevered, in the affair; (S, O, K; *) as also ↓ Afnk. (K.) [See also fataka; and see other explanations below.] And fanaka fiY Alka*ibi He persisted, or persevered, in lying: asserted by Yaakoob to be formed by transposition from fakana: and Aboo-Tálib says that ↓ fAnk and ↓ fn~k, of which latter the inf. n. is tafoniykN, signify he persisted, or persevered, in lying, and in evil; not in good; and denote the like of consecutiveness. (TA.) [See also fanokN, which may be an inf. n. of fanaka in this sense, and in others.] And fanaka Ealayohi, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) signifies [in like manner] He kept, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to it; as also ↓ Afnk. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And fanaka fiY AlT~aEaAmi, (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O, K,) aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n., (S, O,) He continued constantly, uniformly, or regularly, in the eating of the food, not loathing aught thereof; (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O, K;) as also fanika, (S, O, K,) with kesr, (S, O,) like Ealima, (K,) inf. n. funuwkN; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ fAnk: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) and AlT~aEaAma ↓ faAnakotu waAl$~araAba signifies [simply] I kept continually, or constantly, to the food and the beverage: and also I loathed them, or turned away from them with disgust. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ― -b4- And fanaka fiY AlA^amori [not fAnk as in the lexicons of Golius and Freytag, the latter of whom gives both forms of the v. in the sense here following, as does also the TK,] signifies also He entered into the affair. (K.) ― -b5- And He mastered the affair, and overcame it. (O.) ― -b6- fanakota fiY lawomiY, and fyh ↓ Afnkt, (both in the TA, but the latter only in the O,) Thou wast, or hast become, skilled in the blaming, or censuring, of me, and profuse, or immoderate, therein: so says Fr. (O, TA.) ― -b7- And fanakato and ↓ A^afonakato She (a woman) blamed, or censured, and kept continually, or constantly, to blaming, or censuring, or to some other thing [or act]. (Lth, O, TA. *) ― -b8- And the former, said of a girl, or young woman, She cared not for what she did nor for what was said to her. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) This meaning has also been assigned to fatakato. (TA.) ― -b9- And fanaka, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He lied, or said what was untrue; as also ↓ Afnk. (K.)
2 fan~aka see above, near the beginning.
3 faAonaka see 1, first quarter: and near the middle, in two places.
4 A^afonaka see 1, in five places.

fanokN *
i. q. EajabN: (IAar, O, K, TA:) [it app. means A wonderful thing: for] IAar cites as an ex.,
walaA fanoka A_il~aA saEoYu EamorKw warahoTihi
bimaA A@xota$abuwA mino miEoDadK wadadaAni
[And there is not anything wonderful except the conduct of 'Amr and his near kinsfolk in their having taken without selection a sword commonly used for lopping trees, and one that was blunt]: (TA:) and ↓ fanakN signifies the same. (K, TA.) -A2- Also Persistence, or perseverence; or the act of persisting, or persevering. (TA.) [In this and the following senses, it seems to be an inf. n. of which the verb is fanaka; as is indicated in the TA.] ― -b2- And The act of overcoming. (O, K, TA. [Accord. to the TA, from IAar; but said in the O to be from another, not there named.]) ― -b3- And The acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (IAar, O, K, TA.) ― -b4- And The lying, or saying what is untrue. (IAar, O, K, TA.)

fanakN *
A certain beast, (Kr, O, K,) of the skin of which the furred garment is made; (Kr, S, O;) [the marten;] the furred garment whereof is the best sort of such garments, and the highest in estimation, and the most equable, and is suitable to all temperate constitutions: (K:) it is said to be a species of the Turkish fox's cubs; and therefore Az and others say that the word is arabicized; some of the travellers relate that it is applied to the young-one of the jackal (Aibon A=waY) in the country of the Turks: (Msb:) it is also said to mean a certain skin that is worn; and to be an arabicized word: [in Pers. a furred garment is called fanak:] IDrd says, “ I do not think it to be Arabic: ” and MF mentions ↓ faniykN as signifying an animal like the fox; an arabicized word; from [a work entitled] gaAyap AlbayaAn; and he says that it appears to be the fanak that is mentioned in the K. (TA.) ― -b2- See also fanokN.

Alfaniyku *
The majomaE [or part in which is the symphysis] of the laHoyaAni [or two lateral portions of the lower jaw], (Lth, O, K, TA,) in the middle of the chin, (Lth, O, TA,) of a man; (Lth, O, K, TA;) this is when the word is used in the sing. form; (Lth, O; [see also Alfak~u;]) and it is also called ↓ AlA_ifoniyku; (Lth, O;) [and in like manner Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee explained what is meant by the upper faniyk as is stated by IF and in the O:] or the extremity [of each] of the laHoyaAni, at the place of the Eanofaqap [or tuft of hair
that is between the lower lip and the chin;] (S, K;) also called ↓ AlA_ifoniyku; but Ks knew not this: (S:) or the faniykaAni are the two extremities of the Eanofaqap: (O:) or (K, TA, in the CK “ and ”) the sing. signifies a bone [beneath the temple,] to which the shaving of the head reaches (EaZomN yanotahiY A_ilayohi Haloqu Alr~aA^osi): (K, TA:) and accord. to Lth, the dual signifies the two extremities of the [lower] jaw, of whatever has a jaw, that move in the act of chewing, below the temples: (O:) or, accord. to Sh, the two thin, rising bones, [app. the two coronoid processes of the jaw,] lower than the ears, between the temple and the ball of the cheek. (TA.) The lower faniyk is [app. The symphysis of the pubes; being] said by Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee to be the part where the two hip-bones meet together: (IF, O:) [hence, perhaps, and therefore it may be erroneously,] the fnyk is said by AA to be the root, or base, of the tail: (TA:) and it signifies, as also ↓ AlA_ifoniyku, (IDrd, O, K,) the zimik~aY, (K,) or zimij~aY, [i. e. the place of growth, or the root, or the whole, of the tail, of a bird, or] of a young bird; as they assert; (IDrd, O;) but IDrd says, “ I will not pronounce it to be correct: ” (O:) and the dual signifies two bones cleaving together: when, in the female pigeon, they are broken, she does not retain her eggs [sufficiently], but excludes them prematurely. (Lth, O.) -A2- See also fanakN.
AlA_ifoniyku * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
mutafan~ikapN * A foolish, or stupid, woman. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)
finowN * , said to be sing. of A^afonaA='N: see the latter, below.
fanFA * : see the next paragraph: -A2- and see also fanFY, in art. fnY.

fanaApN *
A bull or cow; syn. baqarapN; (AA, T, S, M, K;) [i. e.] a baqarap waHo$iyap [or wild bull or cow; an antelope of the bovine kind]: so says Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee: (TA:) it occurs in a verse of Lebeed; and is said, as on the authority of IAar, to be qanaAp, with q: (TA in art. qnw:) pl. fanawaAtN (AA, T, S, M, K) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ fanFA. (Aboo- 'Alee El-Kálee, TA.)

$aEarN A^afonaY *
i. q. fayonaAnN [i. e. Hair having locks like the branches of trees; or long and beautiful hair]; (M, K, TA;) [or] meaning long hair. (TA.) [The fem. of A^afonaY is fanowaA='u. Hence,] AimoraA^apN fanowaA='u A woman having much hair: (IAar, M, K:) and $ajarapN fanowaA='u A tree having A^afonaAn [or branches]; (AA, T, S, M;) or a tree having wide shade: (K:) by rule it should be fan~aA='u [q. v. in art. fn]. (S, M, K.)

A^afonaA='N mina Aln~aAsi * means Mixed sorts of men or people; like A^aEonaA='N: and the sings. are [said to be] finowN and EinowN: (IAar, T:) one says, huwa mino A^afonaA='i Aln~aAsi when it is not known of whom he is: (S:) or rajalN mino A^afonaA='i AlqabaAy^ili, meaning a man such that one knows not of what tribe he is: but some hold that one says only, qawomN mn AfnA=' AlqbAy^l; not rajulN; and that there is no sing. of A^afonaA=': (M in art. fnY:) accord. to AHeyth, one says, h`w^ulaA='i mino A^afonaA='i Aln~aAsi, meaning these are of the strangers from this and that place: but one does not say, speaking of one person, rajulN mn AfnA=' AlnAs: and Umm El-Heythem knew not a sing. of A^afonaA='. (T in art. fnY.)

1 faniYa * , (T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. yafonaY; (T, M, Msb, K;) and fanaY, aor. yafonaY, (M, K,) which is extr., mentioned by Kr, and said by him to be of the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab; (M;) the former of the two verbs being that which is commonly known; (TA;) inf. n. fanaA='N, (T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) which is of both of the verbs; (TA;) It (i. e. a thing, S, Msb, TA) passed away and came to an end; vanished away; became spent, or exhausted; failed entirely; ceased, perished, or came to nought; or was, or became, transitory, evanescent, or non-existent; the inf. n. being syn. with nafaAdN; (Aboo-'Alee El- Kálee, TA;) contr. of baqaA='N; (M, TA;) and the pret. being syn. with Eudima: (K, TA:) it is said of every created thing that it is subject to AlfanaA='. (Msb.) [Hence] daAru AlfanaA='i [The abode of transitoriness, evanescence, or perishableness,] means the present world. (T in art. dwr.) ― -b2- And, said of a man, (T, M, K,) i. e. faniYa, aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) (tropical:) He was, or became, extremely aged; or old and infirm; syn. harima: (M, K:) or he became on the verge of death by reason of extreme age or of age and infirmity. (T.) Lebeed says,
HabaAy^iluhu mabovuwvapN bisabiylhi
wayafonaY A_i*aA maA A^axoTaA^atohu AlHabaAy^ilu
(T, M,) meaning [His snares are spread in his way, and when the snares fail to catch him] he becomes old and infirm and so dies: (T:) or it means, when death misses him he becomes old and infirm. (M.)

3 fAnAhu * , (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. mufaAnaApN, (T, TA,) He (a man, S, M) soothed, or coaxed, him: (AA, T, S, M, K:) and, (M,) accord. to El-Umawee, (T, S,) he stilled, or quieted, him. (T, S, M.) El-Kumeyt says, (S, M,) mentioning anxieties, (M,)
tuqiymuhu taArapF watuqoEiduhu
kama yufaAniY Al$~amuwsa qaAy^iduhaA
[They rouse him at one time, and at another time they render him sedate like as her leader soothes, or coaxes, or like as he stills, or quiets, the refractory mare]. (S, M: in the T, accord. to the TT, the verse ends with raAy^iduhaA [her pastor], instead of qaAy^iduhaA.) Accord. to IAar, fAnAhu signifies wAijAhu [app. a mistranscription for waAxaAhu, originally A=xaAhu, He fraternized with him; or acted with him in a brotherly manner]. (TA.) [Hence the phrase] A^ufaAniY AlA^ay~aAma i. e. A^uzaj~iY Alz~amaAna [meaning I make the time to pass away easily; as though beguiling it]. (Har p. 607.) ― -b2- And one says, banuw fulaAnK maA yuEaAnuwna maAlahumo walaA yufaAnuwnahu i. e. The sons of such a one do not tend, or take care of, their cattle, or camels, or [other] property, and do not manage the same well. (T.)

4 AfnAhu *
He, or it, caused it, or him, to pass away and come to an end; to vanish away; to become spent, or exhausted; to fail entirely; to cease, perish, or come to nought; he, or it, did away with, destroyed, or annihilated, it, or him; (T, S, * M, Msb, * K, TA;) trans. of faniYa. (T, S, Msb, K.) The saying of a rájiz, (T, TA,) namely, Abu-n-Nejm, (TA,) describing a pastor of sheep or goats,
yaquwlu layota A@ll~`ha qado A^afonaAhaA
(T, TA,) may mean an imprecation against them, i. e. He says, would that God had destroyed them: (T:) ― -b2- or it means, would that God had made to grow for them [the plant called] AlfanaY, i. e. Einabu Alv~aEolabi; so that they might have abundance of milk, and become fat. (T, TA.)

6 tafaAnawA * , (S, K,) or tfAnwA qatolFA, (M,) They destroyed one another, (S, M, K,) [or they shared, one with another, in destruction, (see an ex. in a verse cited voce daq~a,) by slaughter,] in war, or battle. (S.)

AlfanaY * , thus, with Y, in the M, and thus it should be written accord. to Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee, in the T and S with A, and in like manner in the K, in which it is [mentioned in art. fnw, and] written without the article Al (fanFA), and said to be a pl., of which the sing. is ↓ AlfanaAp, (TA,) [The plant called] Einabu Alv~aEolabi; [see art. vElb; and see also AlA^afaAniY, in this art.;] (T, S, M, K;) whereof one is called ↓ fanaApN: (S:) or, as some say, another plant; (T;) [i. e.,] as some say, a species of trees, or plants, ($ajarN,) having red berries, (Hab~), (S,) of which necklaces are made, (S,) or the unbroken of which are made use of as qaraAriyT [meaning carat-weights] with which to weigh, every berry (Hab~ap) being a qiyraAT: and some say that it is a herb that grows in rugged places, rising from the ground to the height of the measure of a finger, and less, and depastured by the cattle. (M.)
fanaApN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places: -A2- and see also art. fnw.

finaA='N *
A yard, or an exterior court, i. e. a wide space, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in front, (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) or extending from the sides, (S, Msb,) of a house: (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. A^afoniyapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and funiY~N: (K:) and vinaA='N [q. v.] signifies the same. (T, M.)

faAnK * part. n. of faniYa [i. e. signifying Passing away and coming to an end; &c.]. (T.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) An old man extremely aged, or old and infirm; (M, * Msb, K, * TA;) so called because of his nearness to passing away, or perishing: (Msb:) or an old man whose faculties have entirely failed. (Mgh.) And faAniyapN occurs in a trad., applied to a she-camel, or to camels, as meaning (assumed tropical:) Advanced in age. (TA.) ― -b3- [faAnK fiY A@ll~`hi, in the language of the mystics, means (assumed tropical:) Lost in contemplation of God, and insensible to all else.]
A^afonaA='N mina Aln~aAsi * is expl. in art. fnw.

AlA^afaAniY * [without the article A^afaAnK] is the name of A species of plant, (T, S, K,) yellow, and red; (T;) [said to be so called] while fresh and succulent; (S;) accord. to AA, (T,) when it has dried up, it is called AlHamaATu; (S, T;) but this is a mistake; for AlAfAnY signifies a particular species of plant by itself, of the herbs, or leguminous plants, termed *ukuwr, which dries up, and becomes scattered; whereas the HmAT is the Halbp [a mistranscription for Halamap], and this does not dry up, because it is of the [kind called] janobap and Eurowap (T:) the n. un. is A^afaAniyapN, (T, S.) like vamaAniyapN [in measure]. (S.) And it is said to signify also [The plant called] Einabu Alv~aEolabi. (S. [See also AlfanaY, above.])

mafonaApN * A land (A^aroDN) suitable to those who alight and abide therein: (K, TA:) it occurs, in a verse of Keys Ibn-El-'Eyzár El-Hudhalee, with q, [as some relate that verse,] but As says that in the dial. of Hudheyl it is with f. (TA in art. qnY.)

1 fahiha * , (K,) [or perhaps fah~a, but originally fahiha], like fariHa, (K,) sec. pers. fahihota, [aor.
faha3a ,] inf. n. fahahN (S, TA) [and app. fah~apN and fahaAhapN], He (a man, S) lacked power or ability. (S, K.) And fah~a, inf. n. fahaAhapN and fah~apN, He made a slip, or committed a fault, from lack of power or ability, &c. (TA.) And fah~a fiY xuTobatihi, and Huj~atihi, He (a man) failed of being thoroughly effective [in his discourse, or oration, or harangue, and his argument, or plea, or evidence]. (TA.) ― -b2- And fahihotu Al$~aYo'a I forgot the thing. (ISh, K, * TA. [In the K the third pers. is mentioned, as being fahiha; but I think it should be contracted (agreeably with a general rule), as in what here follows.]) And fah~a Eani Al$~aYo'i, inf. n. fah~N [probably, I think, a mistake for fah~apN], He forgot the thing. (TA.) See also 4.
2 fah~a3a see what next follows.

4 Afh~hu *
He (i. e. God) made him to lack power or ability; as also ↓ fh~hhu. (S, K. [The former is omitted in one of my copies of the S.]) ― -b2- And He (another person) made him to forget. (TA.) One says, xarajotu liHaAjapK faA^afah~aniY fulaAnN EanohaA Hat~aY ↓ fahihotu i. e. [I went forth for a needful affair, and such a one] made me to forget it [so that I did forget it]. (S, TA. [Or Afh~nY may be here better rendered agreeably with the explanation next following.]) Accord. to IDrd, A^afah~aniY Eano faHaAjatiY signifies He busied me so as to divert me [from my needful affair, or the object of my want]. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 fahofaha *
He fell from a high station to a lower one. (IAar, TA.)

fah~N * , (S, K,) applied to a man. (S.) Lacking power or ability; (S, K;) as also ↓ fahihN, (CK, but omitted in other copies of the K,) and ↓ fahiyhN, (S, * K,) and ↓ fahofahN, (K,) which last is mentioned by IDrd as signifying dull of tongue, lacking power. or ability, to accomplish the object of his want: (TA:) and fh~ap is applied, in the sense first mentioned, to a woman (S;) or as meaning lacking power, or ability, to accomplish the object of her want. (TA) And kalimapN fah~apN means [A word, or a sentence, &c.,] having fahaAhap [i. e. a lack of power, &c.]. (TA.)

fah~apN * and ↓ fahaAhapN [each of which has been mentioned above as an inf. n.] Lack of power or ability; (S, K:) as also ↓ fahofahapN (K.) ― -b2- The first signifies also A case, or an (??), of fahaAhap: and [a case, or an instance, of] unmindfulness or forgetfulness: (TA:) and a (??) fault and a case, or an instance, of ignorance; and the like thereof. (A 'Obeyd. S. TA. *)
fahihN * : see fah~N.

fahiyhN *
