i. q. fah~N, q. v.: (S, * K:) or unable to speak. (KL. [See fakiyhN.]) One says safiyhN fahiyhN [Lightmitted, lacking power or ability] (S, TA.)
fahaAhapN * : see (??).
fahofahN * : see fah~N.
fahofahapN * : see fah~apo.
huwa fahofaAhN EalaY AlmaAli * means He is a good manager or tender or superintendent [of the camels or cattle &c.] (K.)

1 fahida * , (S, A, O, L, K,) aor.
fahada , (A, K,) inf. n. fahadN, (L.) He (a man. S, A, O) resembled the fahod [or lynx] (S, A, O, L, K) in his stretching himself and his sleeping. (L, K,) or in his much sleeping, and stretching himself. (S, A, O.) And He slept, and was, or feigned himself, heedless of what was requisite, or necessary to be done. (L, K.) Hence the saying, (S, L,) of a woman describing her husband, as related in the story of Umm-Zara, (L,) A_ino daxala fahida waA_ino xaraja A^asida walaA yasoA^alu Eam~aA Eahida, (S, * L,) i. e. If he come in and be with me in the tent, or house, he is gentle and quiet like the fahod, which is described as sleeping much; and is, or feigns himself, heedless of the things that are amiss therein, and that I ought to put into a right, or proper, state; such is his generosity, and goodness of disposition; and if he go out, and see his enemy, he is like the lion [in boldness; and he will not ask respecting what he has ordered]. (L.) And one says, fahidota Ean~iY, inf. n. fahadN, Thou wast, or hast been, heedless, or negligent, of me. (A.) -A2- fahada lahu, (O, L, K,) aor.
fahada , (K,) He did well, or kindly, in his affair in his absence; (O, L, K:) like faA^ada, and mahada. (O, L.)

fahodN * [The lynx; lupus cervarius;] a well-known beast of prey; (L, Msb, K;) with which one hunts; and which sleeps much; (L;) called in Pers. yuwzo: (Mgh:) fem. fahodapN: (L. Msb:) pl. of the masc. fuhuwdN (S, Mgh, O, L, Msb, K) and A^afohudN (O, L, K) which is a pl. of pauc.; (O:) and the pl. of the fem., accord. to analogy, is fahadaAtN (Msb.) A^anowamu mina Alfahodi [More sleepful than the lynx] is a proverb. (A.) ― -b2- And A nail in the wAsiT [or fore part] of the [camel's saddle called] raHol; (O, L, K;) also termed kalobN [q. v.]. (L.) To the creaking sound of this nail the similar sound of a stallion-camel's tushes is likened.

fahidN * and fihido [A man] resembling the fahod [or lynx] in his stretching himself and has sleeping [or in his doing thus much, or often]: and [a man] being. or feigning himself, heedless of what is requisite, or necessary to be done. (K.)

fahodapN * fem. of fahodN [q. v.] (Msb.) -A2- The Aisot [i. e. podex, or anus]. (L, K.) -A3- A small piece of butter. (L in art. nhd.) -A4- AlfahodataAni, (S, A, O.) or fahodataA Alfarasi, (L, K,) or fahodataA Sadori Alfarasi, (AO, TA,) Two prominent portions of flesh in the [part of the breast called] zawor [q. v.] of the horse, [S, A, O, K,) like two stones of the kind termed fihor: (S, O:) or the prominent flesh in the breast of the horse, on its right and left (L:) or two positions of flesh on the right and left of the breast of the horse. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- And fahodataA AlbaEiyri Two protuberant bones behind the ears of the camel; (O, L, K;) the same that are termed Alxu$a$aAwaAni. (O, L.)
fah~aAdN * The owner, or master, of a fahod [or lynx]: (L:) or one who trains the fahod for hunting. (T, O, L, K.)

fawohadN * A fat boy or youth, (AA, S, O, L,) that has nearly attained to puberty; (AA, S, L;) i. q. vawohadN; (O, K;) [and farohadN and furohudN:] and falohadN; (AA, L;) as also ↓ A^ufohuwdN: (O, K:) Yaakoob asserts that the f in fwhd is a substitute for the v in vwhd, or that the converse is the case; and both signify a boy perfect in make; or, accord. to AA, soft and plump: or both signify perfect, and soft, thin-skinned, and plump: (L:) fem. fawohadapN. (S, O, L, K).
A^ufohuwdN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 fahara * , aor. a, (Msb, K,) inf. n. fahorN (S, O, Msb,
K) and faharN; (S, O, K;) and ↓ Afhr, (IAar, O, * K,) inf. n. A_ifohaArN; (TA;) He compressed a woman, (IAar, S, O, Msb, K,) one of his young women, (IAar,) without consummating the act, i. e. without A_inozaAl, (IAar, S, O, Msb,) and then removed to another and consummated the act (IAar, S, O, Msb, K) with the latter, (IAar, O, Msb,) who was with him in the house, or chamber; (IAar;) the doing of which is forbidden (S, O, Msb) by the Prophet: (O:) and ↓ the latter verb signifies also He was alone with one of his young women, (K, TA,) liqaDaA='i HaAjatihi, (TA,) when another of them heard the sound proceeding from him, which [sound] is termed Alwajosu, (K, TA,) and Alr~ikozu, and AlHafoHafapu; (TA;) which [also] is forbidden. (K, TA.)

2 fh~r * , inf. n. tafohiyrN, He compressed without consummating the act, i. e. without A_inozaAl, by reason of weariness and languor. (Msb in art. Ezl. [See also 1.]) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, He (a man) was, or became, weary, or fatigued. (S, TA.) Said of a horse, as also ↓ fayohara and ↓ tafayohara, He was, or became, out of breath by reason of fatigue or running; (K, TA;) and interrupted, or stopped short, in running; and jaded: (TA:) or he fell back by degrees from running, by reason of weakness, and being interrupted, or stopped short, in running: (K, TA:) or the first deficiency of the rate of running of the horse is termed Alt~araAd~u [the falling back by degrees]; the next, Alfutuwru [the becoming languid]; and the next, Alt~afohiyru. (S, TA.)

4 A^afohara see 1, in two places. -A2- Afhr baEiyruhu His camel became jaded, and broke down with him, or perished, so that he was unable to prosecute his journey. (IDrd, O, K.) -A3- And Afhr (said of a man, TA) His flesh became compacted and lumpy (O, K *) and wrinkled by reason of fatness: (O:) when such is the case, it is the ugliest sort of fatness. (O, K.) -A4- Also He was present at the festival of the Jews, (IDrd, O, K, TA,) called Alfuhor: (TA:) or he came to their synagogue: (K, TA:) or it signifies also he was present in their synagogue. (IDrd, O.) -A5- And A^ufohirato, said of a girl, She was circumcised. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

5 tfh~r fiY AlmaAli *
He became, or made himself, ample, or abundant, in wealth, or in camels, or the like; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ tafayohara; (K;) as though the former verb were formed by substitution from tabaH~ara: or it may mean he was, or became, weary, fatigued, or jaded, and languid, or remiss. (S, O.) And tfh~r fiY AlkalaAmi He took a wide, or an ample, range in speech. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1 fayohara * : see 2.
Q. Q. 2 tafayohara * : see 2: ― -b2- and see also 5.

Alfuhoru * , (Msb, K,) or fuhoru Alyahuwdi, (S, Mgh, O,) The synagogue of the Jews, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) in which they assemble (O, Msb, K) for prayer (Msb) on the occasion of their festival: (K:) or a certain day on which they eat and drink: (K:) or it signifies also a certain festival of the Jews: (O:) [app. the feast of Purim (written in the Book of Esther פּוּרִים pl. of פּוּר)]: accord. to A 'Obeyd, (O, Msb,) a Hebrew word, (S, O, Msb,) or Nabathæan; (Msb;) arabicized; (S, Msb;) originally buhor; (S, O, Msb;) and the Christians say fuxor. (TA.)

fihorN * , (S, O, K,) masc. and fem.; (Fr, S, O, K;) or, accord. to Lth, the Arabs in general made it fem.; but it occurs in the K as masc.; (TA;) A stone such as fills the hand: (S, O, K:) or a stone of the size of that with which one crushes walnuts (K, TA) and the like: (TA:) or a round stone with which one bruises, or brays, perfume: (Ham p. 643:) or a stone, absolutely: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^afohaArN (S, O, K) and [of mult.] fuhuwrN: (O, K:) As used to say fihorN and ↓ fihorapN, (S, O,) [indicating the former to be a coll. gen. n. and the latter to be the n. un.,] like sidorN and sidorapN: (O:) the dim. is ↓ fuhayorapN. (S, O.)
fihorapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

fahiyrapN *
Pure, unmixed, milk, into which heated stones are put; and when it boils, flour is sprinkled upon it, and it is mixed, and stirred about, and beaten, therewith; and is then eaten: (ISk, S, O, K:) it has also been mentioned as with q. (TA.)
fuhayorapN * [dim. of fihorN and of fihorapN]: see fihorN.
naAqapN fiyoharapN * and fayoharN, (O, K,) the former mentioned by IDrd, and the latter by Ibn-'Abbád, A she-camel that is hard and strong, (O,) or hard and large. (K.)

A^aroDN mafoharapN *
Land having in it [stones such as are termed] A^afohaAr [pl. of fihorN]. (O, TA.)

mafaAhiruka * , (K, TA,) thus we find it, with fet-h, but in some copies of the K with damm, (TA,) The flesh of thy breast. (K, TA.) IF says that there is not in the original language [of the Arabs] more than one word having in it the letters f and h and r, and that is Alfihoru. (O.)

Q. 1 fahorasa Alkutuba * [He made, or wrote, a catalogue of the books or writings], (O,) or fahorasa kitaAbahu [he made an index, or a table of contents, to his book or writing], (K,) inf. n. fahorasapN. (TA.) See what follows.

fihorisN *
A book, or writing, in which [the names or titles or descriptions] of [other] books, or writings, are collected; [i. e. a catalogue of books or writings: but more commonly, accord. to modern usage, the index, or table of contents, of a book or writing; in an Arabic book, generally placed at the beginning:] an arabicized word; (Lth, O, K;) from [the Pers.] fihorisot: (O, K:) pl. fahaArisu. (TA.)

1 fahimahu * , aor.
fahama , inf. n. fahomN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and fahamN, (Msb, K,) which is the more chaste, (K,) but the former is a dial. var. [more] extensively obtaining, or, as some say, it is a subst. used as an inf. n., (Msb,) and fahaAmiyapN (S, K) and fahaAmapN and fihaAmapN, (K,) He understood it, or knew it with the mind; he apprehended its meaning; syn. Eaqalahu, (JK,) and Ealimahu (S, Msb, K) and Earafahu biAlqalobi. (K.) And fahima Eanohu [He understood what he (another) said]. (A in art. xrs; &c.) [See also fahomN below.] ― -b2- fahuma, meaning He was, or became, such as is termed fahiym [i. e. one having much understanding], is like Ealuma, meaning “ he was, or became, such as is termed Ealiym. ” (TA.)
2 fah~ama see what next follows.
4 A^afohamotuhu * and ↓ fah~amotuhu, (S, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. of the latter tafohiymN, (S, TA,) I made him to understand, or know, a thing; (S, * Msb, * K, * TA;) syn. jaEalotuhu yafohamuhu. (TA.)

5 tfh~mhu *
He understood it, or knew it, (fahimahu,) one thing [or one particular thereof] after another; (S, K;) namely, speech, or language. (S.) ― -b2- [And He endeavoured to understand it. (See its inf. n. as used in the former half of the second paragraph of art. dbr.)] And ↓ Alt~afaAhumu signifies the same as Alt~afah~umu [app. as meaning The endeavouring to understand; or the affecting, or pretending, to understand]. (TA.)
6 tafaAohama see what next precedes.
7 Anfhm * , (K, TA,) as quasi-pass. of fah~amahu, inf. n. tafohiymN, [or of A^afohamahu, i. e. as meaning He was made to understand, or know,] (TA,) is an incorrect word, (K, TA.)

10 AisotafohamaniY Al$~aYo'a *
He sought, or desired, of me, the understanding of the thing [i. e., that he might be made to understand it]; (S, * K, * TA;) syn. Talaba min~iY fahomahu. (TA.)

fahomN * is an inf. n. of 1, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) or a subst. used as an inf. n.: (Msb:) [see 1, first sentence:] it is expl. as signifying The conception of the meaning from the word, or expression: or the quickness of the transition of the mind from extrinsic to other [i. e. intrinsic] things: or a condition of the mind whereby it ascertains what is approvable: or, as in the “ Ahkám ” of El- Ámidee, excellence of intelligence in respect of its readiness to apprehend quickly subjects of inquiry that present themselves to it. (TA.)
fahimN * , an epithet applied to a man, (S,) Quick of understanding; syn. sariyEu Alfahomi. (K.)

fahiymN *
Having much understanding; syn. kaviyru Alfahomi; an intensive epithet; like ↓ fah~aAmapN [except that the latter is doubly intensive]. (TA.)
fah~aAmapN * : see what next precedes.
faAhimN * [act. part. n. of fahima; Understanding, or knowing, a thing].

mafohuwmN * [pass. part. n. of fahima; Understood, or known. ― -b2- And hence, lafoZK mafohuwmN The acceptation of a word or an expression; i. e. the meaning, or sense, in which it is understood: see also maEonFY, in art. EnY].

1 fahawotu Eanohu * , (JK, K,) aor. A^afohuw, inf. n. fuhuw~N, (JK,) I was unmindful, forgetful, or neglectful, of it. (JK, K.) ― -b2- ISd says, fahaA fuw^aAduhu is like hafaA, [which, said of the heart, accord. to explanations in the TA in art. hfw, means It fluttered, or palpitated: and it was flurried by reason of grief or of beating:] and no inf. n. of it has been heard, therefore I think it to be formed by transposition. (TA.) ― -b3- And fahaA signifies also He spoke clearly, or distinctly, after doing the contrary thereof. (TA.)
3 fAhAhu * , inf. n. mufaAhaApN; i. q. fAwhhu, inf. n. mufaAwahapN; i. e. He talked, or discoursed, with him: and he contended with him for superiority in glory, or excellence. (TA in art. fwh.)

4 AfhY *
He was weak, or erroneous, in his judgment, or opinion. (IAar, K, TA.)

faAhK * , formed by transposition from faAy^ihN, A man who reveals, or discloses, everything that is in his mind; like faAwuwhapN; (Fr, in S and TA, art. fwh;) and so faAhN: (Fr, in TA ibid.:) and faAhK bijuwEihi one who reveals his hunger. (TA ibid.)

[
AlAfhyAni * , said by Freytag to signify The elephant and the buffalo, is a mistranscription for AlA^aqohabaAni.]
A^afohaA='N * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] i. q. bulohN [pl. of A^abolahu; signifying Heedless; or heedless of evil by reason of their goodness; &c.]. (IAar, TA.)

fuw * , with the w quiescent, [Valerian;] a certain medicine, (K, TA,) a diuretic, (CK,) beneficial as a remedy for pain of the side and for alopecia. (K, TA.) -A2- As a prefixed noun, signifying The mouth, see voce fuwhN, in art. fwh.

fuw~apN * , (T, S, M, K,) like quw~apN [in form], (S, K,) [Madder; the species thereof used by dyers; rubia tinctorum;] certain roots (Lth, T, S, M, K) of a plant (M) which are extracted from the earth, (Lth, T, M,) with which they dye (Lth, T, S, M, K) clothes, or garments: (Lth, T:) AHn says, red roots of a plant which rises slender, having upon its head berries intensely red and having much juice used for writing therewith and variegating: (M:) called in Pers. ruwyan: (PS: [in a copy of the T ruwayn or duwayn: and in my copies of the S rwaynh and ruwyanahN:]) it is [also used as] a medicine, having the property of causing abortion, (K,) producing a flow of the urine and of the men strual discharge, (K, * TA,) aperient, clearing the complexion or skin, clearing the skin from every mark of the ringworm and of the white [species of leprosy termed] yahaq: (K:) it has been mentioned also in the K as ending with [a radical] h [i. e. written fuw~apN, in art. fwh]; but, as is said by Lth, [and in the T,] the final letter is that which denotes the fem gender. (TA.)
mafowaApN * ; pl. mafaAwK: see the following paragraph.

mufaw~FY *
Dyed with fuw~ap; applied to a garment; (T, S, M, K;) and to a hide. (M.) ― -b2- And mufaw~aApN A land (A^aroDN) abounding with fuw~p: (AHn, M, K:) or having in it fuw~p: (M:) and mufab~aApN signifies the same: (TA in art. gbY:) or you say ArD mafwAp mn AlmfAwiY [i. e. ↓ mafowaApN. of which the pl., without the article, is mafaAwK]; (T;) AlmafaAwiY signifying the lands (AlA^araDuwna) that give growth to fuw~ap. (TA.)

1 faAta AlA^amoru * , aor. yafuwtu, inf. n. fawotN and fawaAtN, originally signifies faAta waqotu fiEolihi [i. e. The time, or opportunity, of the doing, or performing, of the affair passed, passed away, elapsed, or escaped, neglected by him, without his doing it or performing it]; and hence the phrase faAtati AlS~alaApu, meaning The time of prayer passed, passed away, elapsed, or escaped, without his performing it therein (Msb:) and ↓ AftAt is syn. with faAta. (M, O.) [And both of these verbs are trans.:] one says faAtahu Al$~aYo'u, (S, O, Msb,) or AlA^amoru, (M, K,) aor. as above, (O,) and so the inf. ns.; (S, * M, O, * Msb, K;) and ↓ AftAthu: (K;) The thing, (??) affair, passed, or passed away, from him [neglected by him]; (M, K;) [or the time, or opportunity, of the doing, or performing, thereof passed, or passed away from him neglected by him;] or the thing escaped him, [or became beyond his reach,] so that he was unable to attain it, or to do it, or to accomplish it. (Msb.) But this explanation is not applicable except in the case of prayer, and the like: in other cases, faAtahu signifies He, or it, preceded him; was, or became, or got, before him; outwent him; passed beyond him; or had, got, or look, precedence of him: and went, or passed, away from him: and the like. (MF, TA.) One says, faAtaniY ka*aA, meaning sabaqaniY [i. e. Such a thing preceded me, &c., app. so as to become beyond my reach]: and fut~uhu A^anaA [I preceded it, &c.]: (T:) and jaArayotuhu Hat~aY fut~uhu I ran with him until I passed beyond him, or outwent him: (A, TA:) and faAtahu fulaAnN bi*iraAEK Such a one preceded him, or outwent him, by a cubit. (Msb.) falaA fawota, in the Kur xxxiv. 50, means falaA fawota lahumo min~FA [And there shall be for them no escaping from us], i. e. laA yafuwtuwnanaA [they shall not escape us]. (Jel. [And Bd says the like; adding, “ by flight, or fortifying themselves. ”]) An Arab of the desert is related to have said, AlHamodu lil~`hi Al~a*iY lA yufaAtu walaA [expl. in art. lyt) (T. And they assert that a man went forth from his family, and when he returned, his wife said to him, “ If thou hadst been present with us, we would have related to thee what hath happened; ” whereupon he said to her, lamo tufaAtiY fahaAtiY (M, Meyd) i. e. It has not escaped thee [lit. thou hast not been escaped], so adduce what thou hast [to tell]: the saying is a proverb. (Meyd.) ― -b2- See also 5: and see 8, in three places. ― -b3- faAta is also syn. with faAda [as signifying He died; in which sense the aor. is yafuwtu, and the inf. n. fawotN]. (A in art. fyd.) And ↓ A^fotiyta signifies He died suddenly. (TA in art. fA^t, q. v.)

4 AfAthu Al$~aYo'a * , (S, MA,) or AlA^amora, (K,) He made the thing, or affair, to pass, or pass away, from him [neglected by him; or he made the time, or opportunity, of the doing, or performing, thereof to pass, or pass away, from him neglected by him; or he made the thing to escape him, or become beyond his reach, so that he was unable to attain it, or to do it, or to accomplish it: see 1, second sentence]. (M, A, K.)

5 tfw~t Ealayohi fiY maAlihi * means bihi ↓ faAtahu, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, O, K,) i. e. He acted exclusively of him, (M,) [or passed him over], namely, his father, (A 'Obeyd, T, M, O, *) in respect of his property, (A 'Obeyd, T, &c.,) i. e. his own property, (A 'Obeyd, T,) by giving it away, (A 'Obeyd, T, M, O,) and squandering it, (A 'Obeyd, T, M.) without consulting him, or asking his permission: (O, TA:) occurring in a trad., relating to a case in which the Prophet ordered the father to cause the property to be restored to his son; and informed him that the son had no right to act thus to his father. (A 'Obeyd, T, O. *) ― -b2- See also 8 latter half, in two places: ― -b3- and see the paragraph here following, in two places.

6 tfAwt * has for its inf. n. tafaAwutN and tafaAwatN and tafaAwitN, (S, M, O, K,) the second and third of which are mentioned by AZ; the second is said by ISk (who mentions this and the third, M) to be of the dial. of the Kilábees, and the third is mentioned by El-'Ambaree; both anomalous, for the inf. n. of a verb of the measure tafaAEala is tafaAEulN. [in the copies of the S ytfAEl, and said to be so in J's handwriting,] with damm to the E except in this instance (S. O:) but Sb said that there is not among inf. ns. an instance of tafaAEalN nor of tafaAEilN. (M.) maA taraY fiY xaloqi A@lr~aHom`ni mino tafaAwutK, (T, M, O, K,) or ↓ tafaw~utK, (T, O, K.) [the former in the CK and the latter in other copies of the K,] the latter being the reading of Hamzeh and Ks, in the Kur [lxvii. 3], (O,) means Thou seest not in the creation of the Compassionate, (M, O,) i. e. in his creation of the heaven, (M,) any incongruity, or discordance; (T, M, O;) or any fault, defect, or imperfection, so that the beholder might say, “ If it were thus, it were better; ” (T, O, K;) thus the latter reading is expl. by Es-Suddee; (T, O, TA;) and Fr says that both readings have one meaning: (T, TA:) you say of a thing ↓ tfw~t and tfAwt. (M.) ― -b2- And one says, tfAwt Al$~ayoA=ni The two things were far apart, one from the other; or widely distinct or separated; (S, O, K;) or
differed, or were different. (Msb.) And tafaAwataA fiY AlfaDoli They two were distinct, or dissimilar, in respect of excellence, (Msb,) or fiY Al$~arafi [in eminence, or nobility]. (A.)

8 A_ifotawata see 1, first and second sentences. ― -b2- As, relating the verse of Ibn-Mukbil,
yaA Hur~a A^amosayotu $ayoxFA qado wahaY baSariY
waA@fotiyta maA duwna yawomi lbaEovi mino EumuriY
[which may be rendered O ingenuous woman, (Hur~a being an abbreviation of Hur~apN,) I have become an old man, my sight has become weak, and what is anterior to the day of resurrection, of my life, has been passed, or has run out like water poured forth (fariga)], says, it is from Alfawotu, and AlAifotiyaAtu [app. as the inf. n. of the pass. v. Aftyt used in this verse] signifies AlfaraAgu. (T.) ― -b3- See also 1, last sentence. ― -b4- AlAifotiyaAtu signifies also The betaking oneself, or applying oneself, before another or others, or hastily, (S, O, Msb,) to a thing, (S, O,) or to the doing of a thing, (Msb,) without obeying him who should be obeyed, (S, O,) or following his own opinion only, without consulting him who had the best right to order in the case: (Mgh, * Msb:) you say, AftAt Ealayohi biA^amori ka*aA i. e. bihi ↓ faAtahu [app. meaning He so betook himself, &c., in opposition to him: or fAth bh may be here used in the sense in which it is expl. above voce tafaw~ata]. (S, O.) And you say, fulaAnN laA yufotaAtu Ealayohi Such a one, nothing is to be done without his order; (S, O, K; *) and so Elyh ↓ laA yufaAtu; (Har p. 63;) or laA yufotaAtu Ealayohi $aYo'N duwna A^amorihi [which means the same]. (Msb.) A^amivoliY yufotaAtu Ealayohi fiY banaAtihi, (T, M, O,) or fiY A^amori banaAtihi, (S, TA,) occurs in a trad., (S, M, Mgh, O, TA,) meaning Shall such a one as I [am] have anything done in respect of his daughters without his order? (Mgh, * TA;) and was said by 'Abd-Er-Rahmán the son of Aboo-Bekr to his sister 'Áïsheh, on the occasion of her having given in marriage his daughter, the elder Hafsah, during his absence, to El-Mundhir the son of Ez-Zubeyr. (T, * O, TA. *) And you say, AftAt Ealayohi fiY $aYo'K, and b$aYo'K ↓ faAtahu, meaning He brought to pass a thing exclusively of him [i. e., of another person, without the latter's having any part therein]. (TA.) And AftAt Ealayohi fY ka*aA, and Ealayohi fiyhi ↓ tfw~t, He followed his own opinion only, exclusively of him [i. e., of another], in the disposal, or management, of such a thing: the verbs being trans. by means of EalaY because implying the meaning of Alv~agal~ub. (TA.) And AftAt Ealayohi fiY AlA^amori, (M, K, * TA,) and ↓ tfw~t Ealayohi fiyhi, (MA,) He decided against him in the affair. (M, MA, K, * TA.) ― -b5- And AftAt biA^amorihi He effected, or executed, his affair without consulting any one: thus accord. to As, without hemz: (T, TA:) and, as is related on the authority of ISh and ISk, one says, AftA^t bA^mrh, with hemz, meaning he was alone in his affair; and in like manner one says, biraA^oyihi in his opinion. (TA. [See also art. fA^t.]) ― -b6- And AftAt AlkalaAma He originated, or excogitated, the speech: (O, K, TA:) and he extemporized the speech; spoke it without consideration, or thought, or preparation, or without pausing, or hesitating; as also Aifotalatahu. (TA.)

fawotN * an inf. n. of 1. (S, * M, &c.) ― -b2- fawota famihi and fawota rumoHihi and fawota yadihi [lit. Beyond the reach of his mouth and of his spear and of his hand, or arm (in several copies of the K erroneously written fawotu)] mean where he sees it but will not [be able to] reach it, or attain it. (K, TA.) A man said to another, reviling him, [or rather said of him,] jaEala A@ll~`hu rizoqahu fawota famihi i. e. [May God make his sustenance to be beyond the reach of his mouth,] where he shall see it and shall not attain it. (S, O. [And the like is said in the M and A.]) And one says, huwa min~iY fawota Alr~umoHi [He, or it, is] where my spear will not reach him, or it. (S, A, O.) And huwa min~iY fawota Alyadi [He, or it, is] beyond the reach of my hand, or arm: mentioned by Sb among what are peculiarly adverbial expressions. (M.) And A^afolatanaA fulaAnN fawota Alyadi and fawota AlZ~ufori [Such a one escaped from us beyond the reach of a hand, or an arm, and beyond the reach of a finger-nail]. (A. [Golius, as on the authority of the A, has ZuforK ↓ fuwayota, which he explains as syn. with fawota yadK; but it signifies A little beyond the reach of a finger-nail.]) ― -b3- A^asomaEu SawotFA waA^araY fawotFA means I hear a sound, or voice, but I see not a deed, or no deed. (TA in art. Swt.) ― -b4- fawotN signifies also The space between two fingers [when they are extended apart (see buSomN)]: (S, M, O, K:) pl. A^afowaAtN. (S, M, O.) ― -b5- And you say, ↓ bayonahumaA fawotN faAy^itN like as you say bawonN baAy^inN [i. e. Between them two (meaning two men) is a wide distance; app. in respect of rank or estimation: the last word being in this case a corroborative, like the latter word in mawotN maAy^itN and liyolN laAy^ilN]. (M.)

fawoAtN * an inf. n. of 1. (S, * M, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] mawotN AlfawaAti Sudden death: (S, M, A, O, K:) likewise termed Almawotu AlfawaAtu and Almawotu AlfuwaAtu. (IAar, TA.) You say, maAta mawota AlfawaAti He died a sudden death. (S, O.) The Prophet, passing by a leaning wall, quickened his pace; and being asked wherefore he did so, answered, A^axaAfu mawota AlfawaAti [I fear sudden death]. (O.)

fuwayotN * One who follows his, or her, own opinion only, (M, O, K,) not consulting any one: (O:) applied alike to a man and to a woman: (M, O, K:) on the authority of Er-Riyáshee: pronounced by AZ with hemz. (O.) ― -b2- See also fawotN [of which it is the dim.]
faAy^itN * act. part. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (T.) ― -b2- See also fawotN, last sentence.

1 faAja * , [aor. yafuwju,] said of musk, i. q. faAHa [i. e. It diffused, or exhaled, its odour]. (O, K.) ― -b2- And, said of the day, (tropical:) It became cool. (O, K, TA.) And one says, faAjati Al$~amosu Einoda barodi Aln~ahaAri (assumed tropical:) [The sun became moderated at the cool time of the day]. (O.)

2 lasotu biraAy^iHK Hat~aY A^ufaw~ija * means [I am not going in the evening] until I refresh myself by the coolness of the air. (K: there expl. by the words A^aYo A^ubar~ida Eano nafosiY [in which, for A^ubar~ida, I read A^uborida]: in some copies [erroneously] EalaY nfsY.)

4 AfAj * , (K,) inf. n. A_ifaAjapN, (S,) He hastened, or went quickly; (S, K, and O and Msb in art. fyj:) and he ran. (S, K.) ― -b2- And AfAj Alqawomu fiY AlA^aroDi The people, or party, went away, and spread, or dispersed themselves, in the land. (L in art. fyj.) ― -b3- And AfAj fiY Eadowihi He was slow in his running. (L in art. fyj.) [Thus AfAj has two contr. significations.] -A2- Also He sent the camels to the watering-trough, or tank, drove by drove. (O, * K.)

10 Ausotufiyja fulaAnN *
Such a one was desired, or incited, to be [quick, or] brisk, or prompt; syn. Ausotuxif~a. (K, and O in art. fyj.)

fawojN *
A company, congregated body, party, or group, of men; (S, A, O, L, Msb, K; *) as also ↓ faAy^ijN, (L,) and ↓ faAy^ijapN, (K,) and ↓ fayojN, (O, K, and Msb in art. fyj, q. v.,) which last is said by Az to be originally fay~ijN, from faAja, aor. yafuwju, like hay~inN from haAna, aor. yahuwnu, for which they say also hayono: (O, and Msb * in art. fyj:) or a crowd, or dense company &c.: (so accord. to an explanation of the first of the following pls. by Z in the Ksh and by Bd, both in Kur cx. 2:) or a company, &c., of the followers, or dependants, of chiefs: or a great crowd of men: (L:) [and app. (assumed tropical:) a multitude of things: (see an ex. voce A^afokalu, in art. fkl:)] pl. [of pauc.] A^afowaAjN [also used as a pl. of mult.] (S, O, Msb, K) and [of mult.] fuw^uwjN and pl. pl. A^afaAwiyju (S, O, Msb, K) and A^afaAwiju (S, O, K) and A^afaAy^iju, as though pl. of A^afiyjapN. (O.)
fayojN * : see the next preceding paragraph: -A2- and see also art. fyj.

faAy^ijN * : see fawojN. One says, mar~a binaA faAy^iju waliymapi fulaAnK, meaning The company (fawoj) of those that were at the repast of such a one [passed by us]. (TA.) -A2- It is said that faAy^ijN, applied to a she-camel, signifies Fat: or such as is termed HaAy^il, and fat: but the word commonly known [thus used] is faAy^ijN [q. v.]. (TA.)
faAy^ijapN * : see fawojN: -A2- and see also art. fyj.

1 faAHa Almisoku * , (Msb, K,) aor. yafuwHu and yafiyHu; (Msb;) or faAHato riyHu Almisoki, aor. tafuwHu and tafiyHu; (S;) inf. n. fawoHN (S, Msb, K) and fuw^uwHN and fawaHaAnu, (S, K,) and fayoHN (S, Msb, K) and fayaHaAnN; (S, K;) The musk diffused [or exhaled] its odour; (Msb, K;) or the odour of the musk diffused itself [or became exhaled]; and fAH AlT~iybu the perfume diffused [or exhaled] its odour; (S;) or this last signifies the perfume became perceptible; or it clung and remained; [in a garment or person;] syn. Eabiqa: (Msb in art. fyH:) the verb is not used in relation to a foul, or disagreeable odour or thing: (S, A, Msb, K:) of such an odour one says hab~ato: (Msb:) or the former verb is common to both: (K:) but this assertion is outweighed [by the other]: (TA:) fawoxN signifies the giving forth, and exhaling, a sweet, or pleasant, odour: (KL:) and the perceiving such an odour: Fr says that faAHato riyHuhu and faAxato are syn.; but AZ says the fawoxN is attended by sound. (TA.) ― -b2- For other significations of this verb, see art. fyH.
4 AfAH * : for this verb, see art. fyH.

entryFree.key: nazalonaA fiY busotaAnK tanaAwaHato A^aToyaAruhu watafaAwaHato A^anowaAruhu

div2.entryFree: 6 nazalonaA fiY busotaAnK tanaAwaHato A^aToyaAruhu watafaAwaHato A^anowaAruhu * [We alighted in a garden the birds of which warbled plaintively, one to another, and the flowers of which exhaled sweet odours, one with another]. (A.)

fawoHN AlHayoDi *
The chief and first portion of the menstrual discharge. (L.)
fawoHapN * [A spreading, or an exhalation], of perfume. (TA in art. ESr.)

1 faAxati Alr~iyHu * , aor. tafuwxu, inf. n. fawaxaAnN; (K;) as also fAxt, aor. tafiyxu, (K in art. fyx,) inf. n. fayoxN and fayaxaAnN; (TA in art. fyx;) The wind, or odour, rose, or diffused itself: (K:) you say, faAxato minohu riyHN Tay~ibapN, aor. tafuwxu and tafiyxu, a sweet odour diffused itself from him, or it; like fAHt: (AO, As, S:) or fAxt Alr~iyHu, aor. tafuwxu, (AZ, S, K,) inf. n. fawoxN (AZ, TA in art. fwH,) or fawaxaAnN, (AZ, TA in the present art.,) signifies the wind made a sound, or noise, (AZ, S, K, TA,) in its blowing. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- And fAx AlHar~u The heat became allayed, or assuaged. (L.) -A2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

4 AfAx * , (AZ, S, K,) inf. n. A_ifaAxapN, (Lth, AZ, S, IAth,) He (a man) emitted wind, (Lth, AZ, S, K,) with a sound, (AZ, S,) from the anus; (Lth;) and ↓ fAx, aor. yafuwxu, inf. n. fawaxaAnN (K, TA) and fawoxN, (TA,) signifies the same: (K, TA:) or the former, he voided excrement with an emission of wind: (IAth, TA:) [mentioned also in art. fyx:] and he (a man, or a beast,) emitted wind in voiding urine: (ISh, S:) and ↓ fAx, aor. yafuwxu, it (the emission of excrement) made a sound. (L.) ― -b2- AfAx bibawolihi He emitted his urine from a dilated aperture. (L.) And AfAxt She (a camel) made a sprinkling with her urine. (L.) ― -b3- AfAx Alz~iq~a, inf. n. as above, He opened the mouth of the zq~ [or skin for wine &c.] to give vent to the air within it: thus accord. to Fr; who says that he heard a sheykh, of those having knowledge in the Arabic language, explain this phrase as meaning he smeared the inside of the zq~ with rub~ [or rob]. (L.) ― -b4- A^afixo Eanoka mina AlZ~ahiyrapi, (L, TA,) in the K Ean~aA, but correctly Enk, as in other lexicons, (TA,) [as also A^afiH,] means A^aborido, (L, K,) i. e. Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool. (L, TA.)

1 faAda * , aor. yafuwdu, (S, Mgh, O, K, and T in art. fyd,) inf. n. fawodN; (AA, K, and T in art. fyd;) as also faAda, aor. yafiydu, (S, O, K, and T &c. in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN; (IAar, K, and T in art. fyd;) He died. (T, S, Mgh, O, K.) -A2- And fAd, aor. yafuwdu, (M,) inf. n. fawodN, (K,) It (property) continued, or belonged, or appertained, syn. vabata, (M, K,) liSaAHibihi to its owner; (M;) as also fAd, aor. yafiydu, (S, L, K, in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN: (K:) or (so in the K) it went away, passed away, or departed; (K;) as also fAd, aor. yafiydu, (K in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN. (K. [See also art. fyd.]) -A3- fAdhu, (As, Yaakoob, T, M, L,) aor. yafuwduhu, (Yaa- koob, M, * L,) inf. n. fawodN, (K,) He mixed it, (M, L, K,) namely, saffron [&c.], (M, L,) or perfume &c., (As, T,) or moistened it with water &c.; (L;) syn. daAfahu; (As, Yaakoob, T, M, L;) from which it is formed by transposition [accord. to the lexicologists; but not accord. to the grammarians, because it has an inf. n.]: (M, L:) and so fAdhu, aor. yafiyduhu, (S, L, K, in art. fyd,) inf. n. fayodN. (L. [See also art. fyd.])

4 A^afadotuhu *
I killed him; destroyed him. (O, K. [See also art. fyd.]) -A2- And I gave him property. (M, L, K.) It belongs to this art. and to art. fyd [q. v.]. (L.) ― -b2- See also 10.

5 tfw~d fawoqa Aljabala *
He (a mountain-goat) ascended (A^a$orafa) upon the mountain. (O, * L, K.)

6 humaA yatafaAwadaAni AlEiloma * (ISh, K) is a phrase used by the vulgar, (ISh,) but the correct expression is yatafaAyadaAni, meaning They two impart knowledge, each to the other: (K:) or ytfAydAn baAlomaAli bayonahumaA They two give, of the property, each to the other; or profit, or benefit, each other therewith: (ISh:) or, in the opinion of MF, each is allowable. (TA. [See also art. fyd.])

10 AstfAdhu * , (M, L, K,) and ↓ AfAdhu, (M, K,) [respecting which latter see 10 in art. fyd,] as also tqy~d, (K, [but this belongs to art. fyd only,]) He gained it, acquired it, or got it, for himself, namely, property [&c.]. (M, L, K.) [See more in art. fyd.]

fawodN *
Each of the two sides of the head: (As, S, M, A, O, L, Msb, K:) pl. A^afowaAdN: (M, L, Msb:) one says, badaA Al$~ayobu bifawodayohi [Hoariness appeared in the two sides of his head]. (S, O, L.) And The main, or chief, portion of the hair of the head, next the ear; (M, L, K;) or of the hair that descends below the lobe of the ear, next the ear: (IF, L, Msb:) or fawodaAni signifies [two locks, or plaited locks, of hair, such as are termed] DafiyrataAni (ISk, S, O, L, Msb) of a man (ISk, S, O, L) and of a woman. (O.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The side (K, TA) of anything; (TA;) each of the two sides (M, L) of a thing. (L.) You say, AirofaEo fawoda AlxibaA='i (tropical:) Raise thou the side of the tent. (A.) And nazaluwA bayona fawodaYi AlwaAdiY (tropical:) [They alighted, or abode, between the two sides of the valley]. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Each of the two equiponderant halves of the load of a beast: (S, M, O, L, K, TA:) one says, qaEada bayona Alfawodayoni (tropical:) [He sat between the two equiponderant halves of the load of the beast]. (S, O, L, TA.) And [hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) A [sack such as is termed] juwaAliq. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The part that is abundant in plumage of each of the wings of the eagle: (M:) [or each of the wings; for] one says, A^aloqati AlEuqaAbu fawodayohaA EalaY Alhayovami (tropical:) [The eagle cast] its wings [upon, or over, the eaglet]. (A.) ― -b5- One says also, jaEalotu AlkitaAba fawodayni, meaning (tropical:) I doubled the upper part of the letter, or writing, over the lower part, so that it became two halves. (A, O.) ― -b6- And Aisotalamotu fawoda Albayoti (tropical:) [I touched, by kissing, or with the hand,] the corner of the House [of God; i. e., of the Kaabeh]. (A.) -A2- Also A company, congregated body, party, or group, of men; or a crowd, or dense company &c.; or a great crowd of men; syn. fawoj: (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K:) pl. A^afowaAdN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

fawaAdN * , (O, K,) with fet-h to the f, (O,) like saHaAb [in form], (K,) i. q. fuw^aAdN [generally meaning The heart (see other explanations in art. fA^d)]; (O, K;) a dial. var. of the latter word. (O.)
faAy^idapN * a subst. from faAda AlmaAlu, (M, K, and L in art. fyd,) in the sense of vabata: (M, and L in art. fyd:) it belongs to this art. and to art. fyd. (TA. [See the latter art.])
mafuwdN * , applied to perfume &c., i. q. maduwfN [Mixed, or moistened with water &c.]; (As, T;) as also mufiydN. (S and O and L in art. fyd.)

rajulN mitolaAfN mifowaAdN *
A destructive man; as also mifoyaAdN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

1 faAra * , (M, Msb, K,) aor. yafuwru, said of water; (Msb;) and faArato, aor. tafuwru, said of a qidor [or
cooking-pot]; (T, S;) inf. n. faworN and fawaraAnN (T, S, M, Msb, K) [the latter of which is the more common] and fuw^uwrN (M, K) and fuwaArN; (M, TA;) It boiled, or estuated. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [fAr said of a liquor, It fermented. (See nabiy*N.) ― -b3- Said of blood, and of wine, It flushed, or mantled, in the cheeks or head.] ― -b4- fArt nafosuhu His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; i. q. vArt [q. v.]. (T in art. vwr.) ― -b5- ↓ fAr faAy^iruhu i. q. vAr vaAy^iruhu (T, S, K) His anger boiled [or became roused or excited]; (S;) or he was, or became, angry. (TA.) ― -b6- [And ↓ the same phrase is expl. in the M, accord. to the transcript in the TT, as signifying Ainota$ara gaDabuhu; but I think that the right reading is evidently EaSabuhu; and the meaning, His sinews became swollen; said of a horse or the like: see art. n$r; and see also faAy^irN, below.] ― -b7- fAr AlEiroqu, inf. n. fawaraAnN, The vein became excited, or in a state of commotion, and flowed forth [with blood]: (M, K, TA:) to which is added in the K, waDaraba; but this is a mistake, occasioned by a false reading of the next words in the M, which are waDarobN faw~aArN ragiybN waAsiEN. (TA. [See faw~aArN.]) ― -b8- faworu AlEiroqi, in a horse means The vein's having inflations, or knots, [or a varicose condition,] apparent in it; which is disapproved. (ISk, TA.) ― -b9- fAr said of water signifies also It welled, and came forth, from the earth, or ground: (Mgh:) it appeared, pouring forth, from the spring, or source. (TA.) ― -b10- fArwA is said of men assembled in market-places [app. as meaning They bustled, or were in a state of commotion]. (TA.) ― -b11- fAr Almisoku, inf. n. fuwaArN and fawaraAnN, [The odour of] the musk spread. (M, K.) -A2- furotuhu: see 4. -A3- Also (furotuhu) I made for it, i. e. the balance, what are termed fiyaAraAni [dual of fiyaArN, q. v.]. (Th, M, K.)

2 fw~r liln~ufasaA='i *
He made what is termed fiyrap [q. v.] for the woman in the state following childbirth. (M, K.)
4 A^afarotuhu * and ↓ furotuhu I made it to boil, or estuate. (IAar, M, K.)

AlfaAru *
The muscles of a man: (M, K:) also mentioned in art. fA^ri, as written with '. (TA.) A^aborizo naAraka waA_ino hazalota faAraka [Put forth thy fire, that passengers may see it and be attracted by it, though thou make lean thy muscles,] is a saying meaning (assumed tropical:) give food though thou injure thy body [by doing so]. (M, L.) -A2- See also faA^orN (with which it is syn. in other senses), in art. fA^r.

faworN * [originally an inf. n.: see 1.] The burning, or heat, and boiling, of Hell. (TA.) And Intenseness, or vehemence, of heat; (TA;) as also ↓ faworapN. (S.) ― -b2- faworu Al$~afaqi The remains of the redness in the western horizon after sunset: as also vaworuhu. (TA.) [See also faworapN.] -A2- And A time: (TA:) [or rather] the present time in which is no delaying. (Msb.) Thus in the saying, Al$~ufoEapu EalaY Alfawori [The right of pre-emption is to be had] in the present time in which is no delaying. (Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, A state in which is no delay. (Msb.) You say, jaA='a fulaAnN fiY HaAjatihi vum~a rajaEa mino faworihi [Such a one came for the object of his want,] then returned immediately, or at once: or, as some say, with the same motion with which he came, not ceasing from motion after it; properly, conjoining what was before the coming with what was after it, without tarrying. (Msb.) And A^atawoA mino faworihimo, meaning mino wajohihimo [i. e., app., They came in a headlong manner; like the phrase maDaY EalaY wajohihi]; (M, K, TA; but the M has jaAw^uwA instead of A^atawoA;) and this is said by Zj to be the meaning of mino faworihimo in the Kur iii. 121: (M, TA:) or qabola A^ano yasokunuwA [before their resting, or ceasing from motion]: (K, TA:) or mino faworihimo in the Kur ubi suprà means in the commencement of their procedure: (O:) or in, or at, their instant of time; (Ksh, Bd;) i. e. [in, or at, the same instant, or] immediately: (Bd:) and A^atayotu fulaAnFA mino faworiY, meaning qabola A^ano A^asokuna [i. e. I came to such a one before my resting, or ceasing from motion]. (S, O.) And you say, faEalotuhu mino faworiY, meaning I did it at once, or instantly. (T, TA.)

fuwrN *
Gazelles: (T, S, M, K:) a word having no sing.; (T, S, M, TA;) accord. to IAar and Yaakoob: (TA:) or its sing. is ↓ faAy^irN; (M, K, TA;) accord. to Kr. (TA.) One says, laA A^afoEalu ka*aA maA laA^olaA^ati Alfuwru I will not do such a thing while the gazelles wag their tails. (IAar, T, S.)

faArapN Almisoki *
The odour of musk: or the bag, or receptacle, [i. e. the follicle, or vesicle,] thereof: (M, L:) [Sgh says that] this and what next follows have been mentioned in art. fA^r, [q. v.,] but should more properly be mentioned in the present art., both being from faAra, aor. yafuwru. (O.) ― -b2- faArapu AlA_ibili means The sweet exhalation from the skins of the camels when they are moist after returning from the water. (M, K.)

faworapN * : see faworN: ― -b2- and fuwaArapN. ― -b3- Also An ebullition of anger, rage, or passion; syn. haAy^ijN. (S and K in art. hyj.) ― -b4- And Freshness, or newness: so in the saying A^axa*otu Al$~aYo'a bifaworatihi [I took the thing in its fresh, or new, state]. (TA.) ― -b5- [And hence,] faworapu Aln~ahaAri The first part, or beginning, of the day. (T, TA.) And faworapu AlEi$aA='i The time [next] after the Ei$aA=' [or nightfall]. (S, TA.) ― -b6- faworapu Aln~aAsi The place where people congregate, and where they bustle, or are in a state of commotion, (yafuwruwna,) in their market-places. (TA.) ― -b7- faworapu Aljabali The higher, or highest, part; and the elevated and hard, or elevated and plain or level, part; of the mountain. (K.)

fuwrapN *
i. q. fuw^orapN [expl. in art. fA^r] meaning A certain flatus in the pastern of a horse [&c.]. (O, K.) ― -b2- And i. q. kuwfapN [A round piece, or collection, of red sand; or a piece, or collection, of sand mixed with pebbles; &c.]. (Kr, M, K.)

fiyrapN *
Fenugreek (HulobapN) mixed [in the manner described voce fay^iyrapN (q. v.) in art. fA^r] for the woman in the state following childbirth. (M, K.)

fiyaArN * sing. of fiyaAraAni, (T,) which signifies The two things (T, S, M, O, K) of iron (M, K) between which is the tongue of the balance: (T, S, M, O, K:) originally with w in the place of the Y, (M, O,) changed into Y because of the kesreh before it. (O.)

fuwaArapN * The froth, or foam, that boils, or boils over, of a cooking-pot: (S and K in this art. * and voce TubaAxapN:) and ↓ mafaAwiru signifies the same, mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád. (O.) And [in like manner] ↓ faworapN signifies The mantling foam upon the surface of wine. (TA.)

faw~aArN * [an intensive epithet from faAra; signifying Boiling much; &c.: ― -b2- and Water, &c., welling forth abundantly; gushing]. ― -b3- [Hence,] DarobN faw~aArN A smiting [that inflicts a wound] such as is wide, (IAar, M, TA,) so that the blood flows [abundantly]: (M:) a poet says,
biDarobK yuxaf~itu faw~aAruhu
waTaEonK taraY Ald~ama minohu ra$iy$FA
A_i*aA qataluwA minokumu faArisFA
Damin~aA lahu baEodahu A^ano yaEiy$aA
(IAar, M, TA. [The text of the M as given in the TT, for taraY Ald~ama, has yurY Aldm; and for A^ano yaEiy$aA, it has Aw yEy$A: and the right reading of the first hemistich seems to be, biDarobK tuxaf~itu faw~aArapK; for an inf. n. is sometimes made fem.: see an instance of Darob as fem. in the EM p. 157: the poet means, With a smiting that silences, or kills, inflicting a wide and gushing wound; and a piercing with the spear in consequence of which thou seest the blood sprinkled: when they slay a horseman of you, we are responsible for him after it that he shall live: i. e., as is said in the M, his blood shall be revenged, so that he will be as though he had not been slain: and it is also there said that by yxf~t fw~Arh is meant lnhA wAsEp fdmhA ysyl wlA Swt lh; in which the two fem. pronouns and the fem. epithet all relate to the word Darob, agreeably with what I have stated to be in my opinion the right reading of the first hemistich.])

fay~uwrN *
Sharp, as an epithet applied to a man; syn. HadiydN. (O, K.) See also Tay~uwrN.

faw~aArapN * , (accord. to the K,) or ↓ fuw~aArapN, (accord. to a copy of the M,) A source, or spring, of water: (M, K:) [the latter word is app. the right in this case; for] IAar says that ↓ fuw~aArapN is applied to a wave: and to a birokap [i. e. watering-trough, or the like; or basin, pool, pond; &c.]: and faw~aArapN, to anything that is not water: and in one place he says that daw~aArapN and faw~aArapN are applied to anything that does not move nor turn round; and duw~aArapN and ↓ fuw~aArapN to such as moves and turns round. (T,
TA.) ― -b2- faw~aArapu Alwariki, with fet-h and teshdeed, signifies The hole, or perforating aperture, of the wrk [or haunch]: (S, O:) or the faw~aArap, (K,) or ↓ fuw~aArap, (so in a copy of the M,) is an aperture in the warik [or haunch], to the belly, or interior of the body, not obstructed by bone: (M, K:) [these two explanations plainly apply to the sacroischiatic foramen: but what here follows is consistent with what precedes, though somewhat less clear:] or the faw~aArataAni, (K,) or ↓ fuw~aArataAni, (accord. to a copy of the M,) are [two parts, in the region of the pelvis, described as being] sik~ataAni [a word which I do not find to have any proper meaning that would be here apposite, but which seems to be applied in this case, by a kind of catachresis, to two parts through which a weapon or the like may pass,] between [each of] the haunch-bones or hip-bones (bayona Alwarikayoni) and the quHoquH [or ischium], towards the side of the warik [or hip-bone], (M, K,) not intervening as obstacles in the way to the belly, or interior of the body; and they are what become in a state of commotion in the act of walking, or going along. (M.) [See also AlfaAy^ilu, in art. fyl] And accord. to Lth, the term faw~aArataAni, (O, and so in a copy of the T,) or ↓ fuw~aArataAni, (so in another copy of the T,) is applied to Two appertenances of the kari$ [or stomach, properly of a ruminant animal], having within them two small nodous lumps (gud~ataAni), which latter are not eaten, and each of which is a piece of flesh in the midst of red flesh. (T, O.)
fuw~aArapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in six places.

faAy^irN * [part. n. of 1: ― -b2- hence, faAra faAy^iruhu]: see 1, in two places. ― -b3- Applied to a beast, of the equine and other kinds, Swollen in the sinews; syn. munota$iru AlEaSabi. (K. [In the TA, this is said to be a mistake for mnt$r AlgaDabi, and thus I find it to be written in the L, and in a copy of the M accord. to the TT: but see what I have said, in the first paragraph of this art., respecting the phrase above mentioned.]) -A2- See also fuwrN.
mafaAwiru * : see fuwaArapN.

1 faAza * , aor. yafuwzu, inf. n. fawozN (S, A, O, Msb, K) and mafaAzN and mafaAzapN, (TA,) He attained, acquired, gained, or won, good, or good fortune, (S, A, O, Msb, * K,) or his wish or desire, or what he desired or sought; (Bd in iii. 182, and TA;) he met with, or experienced, that for which one would be regarded with a wish to be in the like condition, without its being desired that it should pass away from him; he became far from what was disliked, or hated, or evil: (TA:) he succeeded, or was successful: he won, or gained the victory: (Msb:) [he had his arrow drawn, or] his arrow came forth [from the ribaAbap], in the game called Almayosir: and (tropical:) it (an arrow) won; or came forth before its fellow [or fellows in that game]. (O, * TA.) You say, faAza bihi He attained it, acquired it, gained it, or won it; (Kh, A, O, Msb, K;) namely, good, or good fortune; (Kh, O;) or reward: (A:) and he took it away, went away with it. (S, K.) ― -b2- He became safe, or secure; he escaped. (S, A, O, Msb, K.) You say, faAza minhu He became safe, or secure, from it; he escaped it; (A, O, K;) namely, evil; (TA;) or punishment. (A, O, TA.) And TuwbaY limano faAza biAlv~awaAbi wafaAza mina AlEiqaAbi A happy end is his who gains reward and escapes punishment. (A.) -A2- And faAza, (S, O, K,) aor. yafuwzu, (TA,) inf. n. fawozN, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) He perished: (S, A, K:) he died; and so ↓ faw~azN: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) thus the former bears two contr. significations: (A, K:) but IB says that, accord. to some, the latter is not used in this sense unless preceded by another phrase such as in the following ex.: fulaAnN baEodahu ↓ maAta fulaAnN wafaw~aza [Such a one died and such a one died after him]: and accord. to others, ↓ fw~z signifies (tropical:) he became in the mafaAzap [or state of temporary safety] which is between the present life and that which is to come. (TA.) [This last signification is given in the A.] ― -b2- See also 2.

2 fw~z * (assumed tropical:) He went, or his course brought him, to the mafaAzap: (IAar, TA:) or (tropical:) he went upon the mfAzp: (A, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) he went away. (IAar, O, K:) or (tropical:) he went away into the mfAzp: (A:) and ↓ faAza signifies (assumed tropical:) he traversed the mfAzp. (Msb.) You say, fw~z biA_ibilihi (S, A, O, K) (tropical:) He entered upon the mfAzp with his camels. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He went forth from one land or country to another: and ↓ tfw~z signifies the same as fw~z. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, latter part, in three places. -A2- And, said of a road, It was, or became, apparent: (O, K:) and Sgh adds. [but not in the O,] and it stopped, or came to an end. (TA.)

4 AfAzhu bika*aA *
He (God, S, O, K, or a man, Msb) caused him to attain, acquire, gain, or win, such a thing. (S, O, Msb, K.)
5 tafaw~aza see 2.
faAzN * : see what next follows.

faAzapN *
A [tent such as is called] miZal~ap, (S, K.) with two poles, (K,) or that is extended with a pole: (S; in which is added, “ it is in my opinion an Arabic word: ”) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] ↓ faAzN. (ISd, TA.)

faAy^izapN * (tropical:) A thing that rejoices one, and by which one attains good or the object of his desire: you say, faAza bifaAy^izapK (tropical:) He attained, acquired, gained, or won, a thing that rejoiced him, &c. (A, O, * TA.)
mafaAzN * : see the following paragraph, near the end.

mafaAzapN *
A place of safety, security, or escape. (S, A, O, K.) So in the Kur [iii. 185], falaA taHosiban~ahumo bimafaAzapK mina AlEa*aAbi [Do thou by no means reckon them to be in a place of security from punishment]: (S, A, * O:) or, accord. to Fr, the meaning here is, far from punishment. (TA.) ― -b2- A cause, or means, of prosperity, or success, or of the attainment or acquisition of that which one desires or seeks, or of what is good, or of that whereby one becomes in a happy or good state; syn. mafolaHapN. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) [The state of temporary safety which is between the present life and that which is to come. See 1, last signification.] -A2- (tropical:) A place of perdition, or destruction: (Msb, K: *) or i. q. falaApN: (A:) [i. e.] a desert; syn. bar~iy~apN; any [desert such as is called] qaforN: (TA:) or a desert in which is no water: (ISh, O, K:) and a desert in which is no water for the space of a journey of two nights or more: when there is none for the space of a journey of a night and a day, it is not thus called. (ISh, O, TA:) or a tract in which two wateringplaces are so far apart that camels are kept from drinking two days, with a portion of the day preceding them and of the day following them, [accord. to that which is generally preferred of the explanations of the term riboEN which is here employed,] and other animals [that journey quicker] drink on alternate days; as also falaApN: or such as is between that in which camels are kept from drinking two days &c. as above, and that in which other animals drink on alternate days; as also fayofaApN: (TA:) so called to prognosticate good fortune, and safety. (As, IF, S, A, O, Msb,) as meaning a place of safety, (A,) from faAza signifying “ he became safe: ” (Msb:) or from faw~aza, (IAar, S, O, * Msb,) or faAza. (AHei, TA.) signifying “ he perished, ” (IAar, S, O, * AHei,) or “ he died: ” (Msb, TA:) AHei condemns the former of these assertions; but Az and ISd say that it is the more commonly approved, though the latter is the more agreeable with analogy: (TA:) or it is so called because he who comes forth from it, having traversed it, is safe: (IAar, TA:) the pl. is mafaAwizu: (S:) and ↓ mafaAzN signifies the same as mafaAzapN. so in a trad. of Kaab Ibn-Málik; faA@sotaqobala safarFA baEiydFA wamafaAzFA [And he saw before him, or looked forward to, a far journey and a desert, or a waterless desert, &c.]. (TA.)

3 AlmufaAwaSapu * signifies The being clear, or perspicuous, syn. AlbayaAnu, (S, O, K,) in talk or discourse (fiY AlHadiyvi). (S. [In the O, and K, mina AlHadiyvi; and hence it is said in the TK that faAwaSa AlHadiyva signifies bay~anahu He made the talk, or discourse, clear, or perspicuous: but for this I do not find any authority.]) Some say AlmufaAyaSapu. (IB, TA in art. fyS.) [See also 4 in art. fyS.]
4 maA A^afaASa bikalimapi * : see art. fyS. [It seems to be indicated in the S that this is from AlmufaAwaSapu, expl. above: and the like of this is app. said by IB.]

6 Alt~afaAwuSu * signifies Alt~abaAyunu [The being, or becoming, separated, one from another]; from Albayonu, not from AlbayaAnu: (O, K:) originally Alt~afaAyuSu; mentioned also [in a different sense] in art. fyS. (TA.) See the latter art.

2 fw~D A_ilayohi AlA^amora * , (S, M, A, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafowiyDN, (Mgh, O, Msb,) He committed to him the thing, affair, or case; syn. rad~a (S, A, O, K,) or Say~ara, (M,) or sal~ama; (Mgh, Msb;) abstaining from contention, or litigation; (Mgh;) and made him arbiter thereof. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xl. 47], (TA,) waA^ufaw~iDu A^amoriY A_ilaY All~`h (A, TA) And I commit my case unto God, making Him arbiter thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- Alt~afowiyDu fiY Aln~ikaAHi, (S, O,) or nikaAHu Alt~afowiyDi, (TA,) is The giving [a woman] in marriage without [requiring] a dowry. (S, O, TA.) You say, fw~D AlmaroA^api He gave the woman in marriage without [requiring] a dowry. (K.) And faw~aDato buDoEahaA A_ilaY zawojihaA, (Mgh,) or faw~aDato nikaAHahaA A_ilaY Alz~awoji, (Msb,) She married herself to her husband without a dowry: (Mgh, Msb:) or faw~aDato signifies She gave up, or renounced, the ordinance of the dowry. (Msb.)

3 mufaADapN * signifies The being copartner, or copartners, in everything; (O, K;) [as though each of two persons, or every one of more than two, committed all that he had to the other, or others;] as also ↓ tafaAwuDN. (K.) [See 6.] Hence, (TA,) $irokapu AlmufaAwaDapi Copartnership in everything; (Lth, M, S, A, * Mgh, * TA;) in which everything is common property; (Lth, M, TA;) opposed to $irokapu AlEinaAni, which is copartnership in one thing: (Lth:) or copartnership of two persons in all that they possess: (Msb:) or copartnership of two persons in all that is in their hands, or that they may afterwards acquire; which is null and void accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee, but allowable accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh and his two companions [Aboo-Yoosuf and Mohammad]. (TA.) You say, $aArakotuhu $irokapa mufaAwaDapK I was copartner with him in all the property that we both together possessed. (Az, TA.) Hence also, (TA,) mufaAwaDapu AlEulamaA='i The conversing and conferring of the learned on matters of science; each of two persons receiving what the other had [to communicate], and giving what he himself had to the other; as though each committed what he had to his companion. (O, * TA.) ― -b2- The commixing [in social intercourse]. (A.) ― -b3- The being coequal. (A, O, K.) ― -b4- The competing (mujaAraApN) in an affair. (K.) You say, faAwaDahu fiY A^amorihi, (S, O, TA,) or fiY ka*aA, (Mgh,) He competed with him, (jaAraAhu, S, Mgh, O, TA, [for which Golius has read jAzAh, whence he has been led to assign to fAwD a wrong meaning, which Freytag has inadvertently copied,]) and did like as he did, (Mgh,) in his affair, (S, TA,) or in such an affair. (Mgh.) And faAwaDotuhu I competed with him; syn. jaArayotuhu: and kaAna bayonahumaA mufaAwaDapN [There was, between them two, competing]. (A.)

6 tafaAowaDa see 3. You say, tafaAwaDa Al$~ariykaAni fiY AlmaAli The two partners were sharers in the property altogether: (S, O, TA:) or tfAwD Al$rykAn signifies the two partners were coequal. (A, Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence, tfAwDwA They conversed and conferred together; every one receiving what the others had to communicate, and giving what he himself had to the others: see 3. ― -b3- And They mixed together in social intercourse: see, again, 3.] ― -b4- tfAwDwA AlHadiyva They [discoursed together; or] began, or commenced, or entered upon, discourse. (M, Msb.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. zhw.] ― -b5- Also, tfAwDwA fiY AlA^amori They competed (faAwaDa baEoDuhumo baEoDFA, [every one doing like as the others did,]) in the affair. (S, O, K.)
fawoDapN * a subst. from mufaAwaDapN (O, TA) [signifying, app., Copartnership: &c.].

qawomN fawoDaY *
A party, or company, of men who are equals, having no chief: (S, O, Msb, K:) or separated, or in a state of dispersion; (Lth, O, K;) fwDY being pl. of faAy^iDN, which is not in use: (Lth, O:) or mixed, (S, O, M, K,) one with another; (S, O, K;) in which sense, also, fwDY is applied to a number of ostriches: (S, O:) or having no commander, nor any to collect them together: (M:) or mixed, and having no commander over them. (A.) You say, Aln~aAsu fawoDaY fiY h`*aA The people are equals in this; there is no distinction to be made between them. (Mgh.) And jaA='a Alqawomu fawoDaY The party, or company, of men came mixed together. (S.) And AlwaHo$u fawoDaY The wild animals are in a state of separation, or dispersion, (O, TA,) going to and fro. (TA.) A^amowaAluhumo fawoDaY bayonahumo Their possessions are property which they share among themselves; as also fayoDuwDaA='u and fayoDuwDaY. (S.) And mataAEuhumo fawoDaY bayonahumo, and fawoDaY faDFA, Their goods are common property among them. (M.) And AlmaAlu fawoDaY bayonahumo The property is promiscuous among them: whosoever desireth of them a thing taketh it. (Msb.) And kaAnato xayobaru fawoDaY Kheyber was promiscuous (Mgh) common property (Mgh, Msb) among the Companions; not divided. (Msb.) ― -b2- A^amoruhumo fawoDaY, and ↓ fawoDaA='u, (M,) or fawoDaY bayonahumo, and fayoDaY, (TA,) Their case is mixed, or promiscuous: or is equal among them: (Lh, M, TA:) or A^amoruhumo fawoDaY bayonahumo, (AZ, O, K,) or bayonahumo ↓ fawoDuwDaA='u, (TA,) or both, (O, TA,) Their case is mixed, or promiscuous, (AZ, O, K,) every one of them making free use of that which belongs to another, (K,) one wearing the garment of another, and one eating the food of another, none of them consulting his companion respecting that which he does without his order. (AZ, O.) [See a similar phrase voce ma$owarapN.]
fawoDaA='u * : and see fwDY, last sentence.
fawoDuwDaA='u * : see fwDY, last sentence.

tafowaADapN *
Remains of life: (O, TA:) so in the saying, raA^ayotu Alt~afowaADapa lifulaAnK (O) or bifulaAnK (TA) [I saw the remains of life pertaining to, or in, such a one].

mufaw~iDapN * A woman who marries herself to her husband without a dowry: (Mgh, Msb:) or who gives up, or renounces, the ordinance of the dowry: (Msb:) or, accord. to some, the word is mufaw~aDapN, (Mgh, Msb,) meaning married by her guardian without the naming of the dowry: (Mgh:) or meaning having the affair of the dowry committed to her by the law, so that she may make it obligatory or annul it: (Msb:) or meaning married without the mention of a dowry, or on the condition of her having no dowry. (KT.)
2 fw~Thu * , inf. n. tafowiyTN, He clad him, or attired him, with a fuwTap. (TA.)

fuwTapN * sing. of fuwaTN, which signifies Cloths that are brought from Es-Sind, (Lth, O, K, TA,) thick, or coarse, and short, used as waistwrappers: (Lth, O, TA:) or striped waistwrappers: (K:) Az says, I have not heard this word in aught of the language of the Arabs, and I know not whether it be an Arabic word or of the language of the foreigners, but I have seen in El-Koofeh striped waist-wrappers, which are sold, and are bought by the camel-drivers and the Arabs of the desert and the servants and the people of the lowest sort, who use them as waist-wrappers, and call them thus; sing. fuwTapN: IDrd says that it is not an Arabic word: (O, TA:) it is added in the K, or it is a word of the language of Es-Sind: Sgh says, (TA,) fwTh is a word of the language of Es-Sind, arabicized, from Puwtah, with a dammeh not fully sounded: (O, TA:) [and SM adds,] it is called with us in El-Yemen, A^azohariy~ap: and by reason of frequency of usage, they have derived from it the verb above-mentioned. (TA.) The dim. of fuwTapN is ↓ fawayoTapN. (Har p. 294.) [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, see. ed., i. 195.] ― -b2- It (the pl.) is also applied to Short napkins, with striped extremities, woven at El-Mahalleh ElKubrà, in Egypt, which a man puts upon his knees to preserve himself therewith [from being soiled] at meals [and with which the hands are wiped after washing]. (TA.)

fuwTiY~N *
Blue, but not of a clear blueness. (TA.)
fuwayoTapN * dim. of fuwTapN, q. v.

faw~aATN *
A weaver, or seller, of fuwaT, pl. of fuwTapN. (TA.)
mufaw~aTN * A man clad, or attired, with a fuwTap. (TA.)
1 faAZa * , aor. yafuwZu, inf. n. fawoZN and fawaAZN: see faAZa in art. fyZ.

1 maA faAfa bixayorK * , (T, M, O,) or maA faAfa Ean~iY bixayorK, (K.) walaA zanojara, (T, O, K,) aor. yafuwfu, (K,) inf. n. fawofN, (T, M, O, K,) [may be rendered He did
not benefit, or he did not benefit me, with what might be taken between the nail of his thumb and that of his forefinger, nor did he with what might be taken by the inside of the nail of the thumb from the extremity of the fore tooth; i. e., with a thing inconceivably small; or with anything; being] a phrase meaning one's answering (T, M, O, K) a person who has asked for a thing (T, O, K) by putting his thumb-nail upon the nail of his fore finger, (T, M, O, K,) and by taking away the inner side of the nail [of the thumb] from the extremity of the fore tooth, (T, O,) and saying “ Not [even] this [will I give thee], ” (T, O, K,) or “ Not [even] the like of this. ” (M.)
fawofN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

fuwfN * The whiteness that is upon the nails of young persons; (S, M, O, K;) as also ↓ fawofN; (T, M, K;) the latter mentioned by Fr, but not known by IAar; (T;) or the former is the more common: (K:) n. un. with ↓ p; (M, K;) meaning a portion thereof. (M.) ― -b2- And The integument [or pellicle] that is upon [what is termed] the core of the heart, and the stone of the date. (EalaY Hab~api Alqalobi waAln~awaApi,) beneath the flesh [or pulpy substance] of the date: (M, K:) of the white grain [i. e. the embryo, which resembles a white grain,] in the interior of the date stone, from which the palm-tree grows forth [or germinates]: and it is said that ↓ fuwfapN signifies the integument [or pellicle] that is upon the date stone (S, O:) [i. e.] the thin integument that is upon the date-stone; also called the qiTomiyr. (T.) ― -b3- [Hence, or from one of the significations mentioned above,] one says, maA A^agonaY Ean~iY fuwfFA i. e. [He (a man, S, O) did not avail me] aught. (S, O, K.) And maA *aAqa fuwfaA [He tasted not] aught. (T, K.) ― -b4- And fuwfN signifies also Any integument; (M, K;) and so ↓ fuwfapN. (K) ― -b5- And The bladder of an animal of the bovine kind; as also ↓ fawofN: (K.) mentioned by Sgh in the TS. (TA.) ― -b6- Also A sort of the [garments called] baruwd of El-Yemen: (M, K:) thin, variegated, or figured, garments of El-Yemen: (IAar, T:) and one says also burodN ↓ fuwfiY~N, and vuwviY~N, which is formed by substitution, and mentioned by Yaakoob, and burodu A^afowaAfK meaning a burod having white stripes. (M.) and so ↓ burodN mufaw~afN; (S, M, K;) or this last and burodu A^afowaAfK signify a thin burod; (S, O, K, TA;) and in like manner one says Hul~apu A^afowaAfK. (TA.) A^afowaAfN is pl. of fuwfN: (S, O:) and accord. to Lth, the A^afowaAf are of the [buruwd called] EaSob [q. v.] of ElYemen. (O.) ― -b7- Also Flowers or blossoms, syn. zahorN: [in the CK zahar;] used in this sense by Ibn-Ahmar; being likened by him to the garments called fuwf. (T, K, TA.) ― -b8- And Portions of cotton: (O, K, and so in some copies of the S:) [perhaps meaning] a white thing [resembling cotton] which is in the Eu$ar [q. v.]. (Ham p. 784.) ― -b9- [And Freytag mentions its signifying The extreme portion of the penis; as on the authority of the K: but he seems to have confounded fuwfN with fuwqN.]

fuwfapN * the subst. denoted by the verb faAfa: (M, TA:) [as such,] it is coupled by a poet with zinojiyr [which is similar to it is meaning: see this last word]. (S, O, TA.) ― -b2- Also n. un. of fuwfN. (S, M, O, K.) See this latter word, in three places.
burodN fuwfiY~N * : see fuwfN, latter half.

burodN mufaw~afN * : see fuwfN, latter half. ― -b2- gurofapN mufaw~afapN, the mention of which occurs in a trad. of Kaab, means [An upper chamber] whereof one brick is of gold and another of silver [i. e. constructed of gold and silver bricks alternately]. (TA.)

Anfwfl * , (K, [there said to be biAlDam~i waAlfatoHi, app. indicating that it is Alfuwfulu and Alfawofalu, but accord. to the CK and TK Alfuwfalu, and thus only, as though it were said to be baAlD~am~i faAlafotiH.]) or $ajarapN Alfawofali, (thus written in the (??) [in the TT, as from the M, $jr Alfwfl, thus, without the affix p to the former (??), and without any vowel sign,]) accord. to AHn, (M,) or Aboo-Ziyád, (O,). A palm-tree, (??), or betel nut palm,] like the (??), that (??) racemes (??) which are the fwfl, resembling (??), (M, O, K,) of which some are (??) and some (??), not of the growth of the land of the Arab: (O:) [in one of my copies of the S, the fwofal (thus the word is there written) is said to be a tree like the coco(??) not in the other copy it is not mentioned:] the fwfl is said by AHn to be the fruit of a certain palm-tree, (??) as though it were (??): (M:) in the T(??) (??) it is said to be a fruit like the Syrian jawoz [(??)], of (??) astringent quality, found upon trees resembling the (??): (TA:) it is good for (??) and gross (??), (K, TA.) (??) (??); (TA;) and for infla(??) of the (??), (K, TA,) (??) dressing and (??) and (??) (??) digestive. (TA.)

1 faAqahumo * , (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) derived from fawoq as signifying the contr. of taHot, Mgh.) aor. yafuwquhumo, (S, O.) inf. n. fawoqN (O, K) and fawaAqN (K) and fawoqaAnN, (CK.) He (a man, S, (??) Msb) was, or became, above them, or (??) to them, or (??) (??) them, or (??) them, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) namely, his (??), (S, O, Msb, K,) (??) others (Mgh) (??), or signify, or nobility. (S, O, K;) and (??) them; (Msb, TA:) and (??) argument (??) fuqotu fulaAnFA I became (??) (??) as though above him in station. (TA.) And faAqati AljaAriyapu biAljamaAli The young woman ex(??) (??)]. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., Hub~iba A_ilaY~a AljamaAlu Hat~aY maA A^uHib~u A^ano yafuwfaniY A^aHadN bi$iraAki naEolK [Comeliness has been made lovely to me so that I love not that any (??) should (??) in the though of a sandal] (TA.) -A2- fAq, (S, O, K,) aor. yafuwqu, (O,) inf. n. fuwaAqN, (S, O, K,) said of a man, (S,) means that The wind rose from his chest; (S, O, K;) [i. e. he hiccoughed, or hickuped; a signification indicated by its being said that] fuwaAqN means the reiterating of an overpowering [or involuntary] sobbing sound: (Msb, TA:) and ↓ fuwaAqN [as a subst.] signifies also the wind [itself] that rises from the chest (S, O, K) of a man. (S, O) ― -b2- And, accord. to Az, (Msb,) fAq, (Msb, TA,) aor. (??). (Msb,) inf. n. fuwaAqN (Msb, TA) and fuw^uwqN, (TA.) He was affected, or taken with a p(??)ting, or breathing [shortly, or] uninterruptedly. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And fAq binafosihi, (S, * O, K,) aor. yafuwqN, (S, O,) inf. n. fuwuwqN [or fuw^uwqN (S, O, K) and fuwaAqN. (K,) said of a man, (S.) His spirit was about to pass forth: (S, O, K:) or he gave up his spirit. (S, * O, * K:) as also fAq [alone] aor. yfyq (IAar, O and K in art. fyq:) or he died. (K;) or ↓ fuwaAqN [is app. held by some to be a simple subst., and] accord. to IAar signifies death itself: (TA:) or it signifies, (S, O, Msb,) (??) signifies also, (K.) an affection [i. e. a gasping, or show catching of the breath,] incident to a man at the point of death: (S, O, Msb, K:) and one says [of the man], fAq, aor. yafuwqu, inf. n. fwq [app. fawaqN]; the verb being of the class of Talaba of which the inf. n. most commonly used is Talaba; or, if the saying that the verb is of the (??) of Talaba be not meant to indicate the form of its inf. n. as well as that of its aor., fwq may (??) mistranscription for fuw^uwqN or fuw^uwqN] (Msb.) -A3- fAqt, (O, K,) aor. tafuwqu, inf. n. fuwaAqN, (TA.) She (a camel) had in her udder the fiyqap, or milk that had collected between two milkings. (O, K, TA;) and (K) so ↓ A^afaAqato (S, O, K) or the latter verb signifies she (a camel) attained to the time for the being milked: and the inf. n. is A_ifaAqapN and (??) inf. n.] ↓ fuwaAqN: (IAar, TA:) or A_ifaAqapN (??) (??) the she-camel means her (??) back from the pasturing, and left (??) and (??) [her milk]. (ISb, TA:) and A_ifaAqapN Ald~ir~api signifies the returning of the milk. (??) Ibn-Kethweh, TA.) [See also fuwaAqN, below.] -A4- fawoqN signifies A bending, or [thus in the TA is from the K, but in copies of the K “ and ” a breaking. (K, TA,) in the (??) (fiY Alfawqi) (K,) or in one of the two (??) of the (??), (TA.) of an arrow: (K, TA:) or its verb said of an arrow, is fAq, aor. yafaAqu, inf. n. faAqN and fawoqN, in which the w is then made movent with fet-h. [so that the word becomes fawqN,] because this verb is of the class of faEila, aor. yafoEalu: (K, TA.) or one says of an arrow fawiqa, [aor yafowaqu,] inf. n. fawaqN, meaning its notch broke: (Msb;) and ↓ AnfAq said of an arrow signifies thus; (S, Msb;) (??) notch became much broken. (O, K, TA;) or became split, or cracked. (TA.) ― -b2- And fuqotu Als~hom, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. fawoqN, (Msb,) I broke the notch of the arrow. (S, O, Msb, K.) And fAq Al$~aYo'a, aor. yafuwqu, He broke the thing. (TA.) -A5-
fAq in the sense of AftAq [from faAqapN] is not allowable. (S, O.)

2 fw~qhu * , inf. n. tafowiyqN, He made him, or judged him, to excel, or to have excelled. (TA.) -A2- fw~q AlfaSiyla, (S, O, K,) inf. n. as above, said of the pastor, (TA,) He gave to the young unweaned camel to drink the quantities of milk that had collected in the udder between two milkings time after time. (S, O, K, TA. [See fuwaAqN.]) ― -b2- And [hence] one says, ↓ faw~aqaniY AlA^amaAniY~a waA^aroDaEaniY A^afaAwiyqa bir~ihi (tropical:) [He made me to obtain on repeated occasions the things wished for, and nourished me with the recurrent supplies of his bounty]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Alee, A_in~a baniY A^umay~apa layufaw~iquwnaniY turaAva muHam~adK, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Verily the sons of Umeiyeh] give to me by little and little of the property [constituting the heritage of Mohammad]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 10. -A3- fw~q Als~ahoma, (inf. n. as above, Msb,) He made to the arrow a fuwq [i. e. notch for the bow-string]. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] fw~q AlmaroA^apa (assumed tropical:) He slit the vulva of the woman. (TA in art. sws.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph, last sentence.

4 A_ifaAqapN * , (O, K, TA,) some say, (O, TA,) signifies A resting; (O, K, TA;) from ↓ fuwaAqN signifying a resting between two milkings; (O, TA;) which latter meaning, as well as the former, the K erroneously assigns to the former word. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^afaAqato said of a she-camel, signifies the same as faAqato expl. above: see 1, latter half, (O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And [hence, perhaps,] AfAq mino maraDihi, (S, O, K, TA,) and mino sukorihi, (S, O,) and mino ga$oyatihi, (O, TA,) inf. n. A_ifaAqahu; (TA;) and ↓ AstfAq; both signify the same; (S, O, K;) i. e. He returned to a healthy, or sound, state [of body and of mind, from his disease, and from his intoxication, and from his swoon, or fit of insensibility]: (O, K, TA:) or one says of the diseased, AfAq and ↓ AstfAq meaning he became convalescent; or recovered, but not completely, his health and strength: and the subst. [or quasi-inf. n.] is ↓ fuwaAqN: (TA:) and one says of the insane, or possessed, AfAq, inf. n. A_ifaAqapN, meaning he recovered his intel-ligence; and of the intoxicated, likewise, AfAq, originally AfAq mino sukorihi, like as one says AisotayoqaZa mino nawomihi: (Msb:) [and it is said that] ↓ AlAisotifaAqapu as syn. with AlA_ifaAqapu is derived from fawoq meaning the contr. of taHot, like as taEal~aY mino maraDihi and tamaAvala are from AlEuluw~u and Almuvuwlu: (Har p. 132:) but accord. to 'Alee Ibn-'Eesà, ↓ AstfAq signifies he sought, or desired, AlA_ifaAqap. (Ham p. 541.) ― -b4- And [hence,] AfAq Alz~amaAnu (tropical:) The time became abundant in herbage after barrenness or drought. (O, K, TA.) -A2- A^afaqotu Als~ahoma, (inf. n. A_ifaAqapN, Msb,) I put the fuwq [or notch] of the arrow upon the bowstring, (S, O, Msb, * K,) to shoot with it; (S, O, Msb;) as also A^awofaqotuhu: but A^afowaqotuhu is extr., (S, O, K,) and should not be said, (S, O,) or, accord. to Yoo, one says A^afowaqotuhu also: (O:) and, accord. to the A, Als~ahoma ↓ fw~q signifies [in like manner] he put the bow-string into the notch of the arrow on the occasion of shooting. (TA.)

5 tfw~q EalaY qawomihi *
He exalted himself above his people, or party. (O, * K, * TA.) -A2- tfw~q said of a young unweaned camel, He drank [or sucked] the quantities of milk that had collected in the udder between two milkings time after time. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And tafaw~aqahaA He milked her, namely, a camel, drawing from her the quantities of milk that had collected in her udder time after time; (O, K;) as also ↓ AstfAqhA. (K. [But see this latter below.]) ― -b3- Hence the trad. respecting Aboo-Moosà, that he was discoursing with Ma'ádh, of reciting the Kur-án, and said, A^am~aA A^anaA faA^atafaw~aquhu tafaw~uqa All~aquwHi [As for me, I draw it forth in the manner of the drawing forth of the milk of the milch camel at the times when it has collected in her udder], meaning (tropical:) I do not recite my set portion at once, but piecemeal, in my night and my day. (S, O, TA.) ― -b4- One says also tfw~q $araAbahu i. e. (tropical:) He drank his wine, or beverage, part after part. (TA.) Sb has mentioned that yatajar~aEahu and yatafaw~aqahu are said of that which is not a labouring to do a thing at once, but is an act after an act, performed in a leisurely manner. (O, TA.)

7 AnfAq *
It (a thing) broke, or became broken; quasi-pass. of faAqa Al$~aYo'a meaning kasarahu. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the end. ― -b3- Said of a camel, He became lean, or emaciated: ― -b4- and He perished, or died. (O, K.)

8 AftAq *
He was, or became, poor, or in want, or need: (S, O, Msb, K:) faAqa in this sense is not allowable. (S, O.) -A2- And He died with much fuwaAq [which may here mean either hiccoughing (which often occurs at the close of a fatal fever &c.), or gasping, or short catching of the breath]. (O, K.)

10 A_isotafowaqa see 4, in four places. -A2- AstfAqhA: see 5. [It signifies as there explained: or it signifies, or signifies also,] He delayed the milking her, namely, a camel, until her milk collected in her udder, or in order that it might collect; and so ↓ fw~qhA, inf. n. tafowiyqN. (TA.) One says, Aisotafiqi Aln~aAqapa Milk not thou the she-camel before the time. (O, * K.) ― -b2- ― -b3- And maA yasotafiyqu mina Al$~araAbi He does not abstain [from drinking wine]: (O, K, TA:) or he does not drink it in the set time: or he does not appoint a time for drinking it, but drinks it always. (TA.)

faAqN *
A [large bowl such as is termed] jafonap, filled with food. (Lth, T, O, K.) -A2- And Cooked olive-oil. (O, K, TA.) So in the saying of Shemmákh, (O, TA, *) describing the hair of a woman, (TA,)
qaAmato turiyka A^aviyva Aln~aboti munosadilFA
mivola AlA^asaAwidi qado mus~iHona biAlqaAfi
[She stood showing to thee hair abundant and luxuriant, or abundant and long, in respect of growth, let down, like the black serpents that have been anointed with cooked olive-oil]: or, as some say, meaning AlA^anofaAq, meaning fresh olive-oil [from A_inofaAq, a Pers. word signifying “ olive-oil ”]: or, as AA relates it, the poet said, qado $ud~ixona biAlfaAqi [that have been crushed in the fAq]; and accord. to him the last word has the meaning here next following. (O, TA.) -A3- And The desert; syn. SaHoraA='u: (O, K, TA:) so says AA: and on one occasion he says that AlfAq means a certain land: (O: a meaning also mentioned in the K:) or a certain wide land. (TA.) -A4- It is also expl. as signifying baAn [i. e. Oil of ben]: and also A comb: on the authority of Th: and it may have either of these meanings in the verse cited above. (TA.) -A5- And accord. to the K, it signifies Tall, and incongruous in make; and so ↓ fuwqN and ↓ fuwqapN and ↓ fiyqN and ↓ fuwaAqN and ↓ fuyaAqN: but these words are all correctly, in this [or a similar] sense with two káfs. (TA.) -A6- Also, accord. to the K, A certain aquatic bird, long in the neck: but this, likewise, is correctly with two káfs. (TA.)

fawoq * is the contr. of taHot; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) [primarily signifying The location that is above, or over;] and is an adv. n. (Mgh, Msb, K) of place; (Mgh, Msb;) and a simple noun, indecl., [with dammeh for its termination, when the noun to which it should be prefixed is suppressed, and the meaning of this is intended to be understood, but not the word itself;] but when it is prefixed to another noun [which is either expressed or itself (and not merely its meaning) meant to be understood, and when the noun to which it should be prefixed is suppressed and neither this nor its meaning is meant to be understood,] it is declinable. (K. [For the words yakuwnu A@somFA waZarofFA maboniY~N, the reading of the K in the TA and CK, my MS. copy of the K (which I follow in this case) has ykwn ZrfA wAsmA mbny~A.]) One says, zayodN fawoqa Als~aToHi [Zeyd is above, or rather upon, the house-top]. (Mgh, Msb.) And AlEimaAmapu fawoqa Alr~aA^osi [The turban is above, or upon, the head]. (Mgh.) And TafaA fawoqa AlmaA='i It floated upon the water. (S &c. in art. Tfw.) Ks has mentioned the saying, A^afawoqa tanaAmu A^amo A^asofala [Dost thou, or wilt thou, sleep in the part that is above of the house &c., or in the part that is below? i. e., in the upper part, or in the lower part?] with fet-h, as suppressing the noun to which fwq is [meant to be understood as] prefixed. (TA.)
