Lth says that he who uses it as a Sifap [by which (like other old writers) he means an adv. n. of place] should use the accus. case, as when one says, Eabodu A@ll~`hi fawoqa zayodK ['Abd-Allah is above Zeyd]: but if you make it simply a noun, you use the nom. case, and say, fawoquhu raA^osuhu [His superior (meaning upper) part is his head]; for in this instance it is the head itself, and you make each to be governed in the nom. case by the other. (TA.) In the saying in the Kur [xvi. 28], faxar~a Ealayohimu A@ls~aqofu mino fawoqihimo [And the roof fell on them from above them], the utility of the phrase mn fwqhm is hardly apparent,
because Elyhm sometimes serves in its stead: but IJ says that mn fwqhm may here have a useful office; for EalaY is sometimes used in relation to deeds [or events] that are difficult, and deemed onerous; [for instance,] you say, qado sironaA Ea$orFA wabaqiyato EalayonaA layolataAni [We have journeyed ten nights and the journeys two nights have remained as though incumbent on us]; &c.; so that if it were said fxr~ Elyhm Alsqf without the adding mn fwqhm, it might be supposed to be like the saying Ealayohimo daAruhumo qado xaribato [Their abode had become in a state of ruin as a punishment upon them]; but when He [referring to God] says mn fwqhm, that meaning which was supposable ceases to be so; and the meaning becomes this, that it [the roof] fell when they were beneath it. (TA.) A_i*o jaAw^uwkumo mino fawoqikumo wamino A^asofala minokumo [When they came to you from above you and from below you], in the Kur [xxxiii. 10], relates to Benoo- Kureydhah, who came to them from above them; and to Kureysh and Ghatafán, who came from the district of Mekkeh, from below them. (TA.) waA@l~a*iyna A@t~aquwA fawoqahumo yawoma A@loqiyaAmapi, in the Kur [ii. 208], means (assumed tropical:) [But those who have been careful of their religious duties] shall be above them in station [on the day of resurrection]. (O.) And one says, [agreeably with what has been stated in the first sentence of this paragraph, A^axa*ahu mino fawoqu, and A^axa*ahu mino fawoqK, [meaning (assumed tropical:) He overcame him, or overpowered him, and in like manner A^ataAhu mn fwq, as expl. in the Ham p. 128. i. e. qaharahu namely, his adversary; and so a hawk, his pr? or quarry. (M and K in an expl. of A^adal~a Ealayoh, in art. dl.) And [in a similar manner] fawoq is metaphorically used as denoting excess, (Mgh, Msb.) and excellence: (Msb:) thus one says, AlEa$arapu fawoqa Alt~isoEapi (Mgh, Msb) i. e. (tropical:) Ten is above nine; meaning ten exceeds nine: (Msb:) and h`*aA fawoqa *aAka (Mgh, Msb) i. e. (tropical:) [This is above, or superior to, that;] meaning this is more excellent than that; (Msb:) and hence, (Mgh, Msb,) in the Kur iii. 24], (S, O,) baEuwDapF famaA fawoqahaA i. e. (tropical:) [A gnat and] what exceeds it (Mgh, Msb) in smallness, or in largeness; (Mgh, Msb, K;) what is smaller than it, (AO, S, O,) or what is larger than it, by the latter being meant the fly [mentioned in the Kur xxii. 72] and the spider [mentioned in xxix. 40], (Fr, S, O,) and the phrase as expl. in the former sense being like the reply to him who says “ Such a one is small ” *`lika wafawoqa i. e. (assumed tropical:) And smaller than that: (AO, O:) hence also, in the Kur iii. 12], faA_ino kun~a nisaA='F fawoqa A@vonatayoni (Mgh, Msb) i. e. (tropical:) [And if they are women,] exceeding two. (Msb.)

fuwqN * The part, of the arrow, which is the place of the bow-string; [i. e. the notch thereof;] (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ fuwqapN: (Msb, K;) the former is masc., and also, like the latter, fem. (IAmb, Msb:) and AlfuwqaAni signifies the (??) [or two cusps of the fuwq, between which is put the bow string]; (O, K;) thus these are termed by the tribe of Hudheyl; but a poet who has used the dual form is said by AO to has mead thereby a single fuwq: (O:) the pl. [of mult.] is fuwaqN and [of pauc.] A^afowaAqN; (S, O, Msb, K;) or, accord. to ISk, these are pls. of fuwqapN; (TA;) and qufFA also is a pl., formed by transposition; [see an ex. in a verse cited voce EuroquwbN;] (K, TA;) one says fuqowapN and fuqFA [for fuwqapN and fuwaqN]. (TA.) sahomN *uw fuwqK means An arrow rendered complete by its having a fuwq: ― -b2- and hence *aA fuwqK occurring in a trad. [as meaning (assumed tropical:) A complete share; for sahomN signifies “ a share ” as well as “ an arrow ”]. (A'Obeyd, O.) And A^aEolaAhumo fuwqFA, meaning (tropical:) He, or they, of them, haring the largest share of religion, is a metaphorical phrase, from the fuwq of the arrow. (TA.) ― -b3- And they say, A^aqobilo EalaY fuwqi nabolika, [or, app., fuwaqi nabolika, for nabolN is a coll. n., meaning “ arrows, ” or “ Arabian arrows, ”] meaning (assumed tropical:) Betake thyself to thy affair, and that which concerns thee. (TA.) ― -b4- And ramayonaA fuwqFA, (O, K,) or fuwqFA waAHidFA, (TA,) meaning ri$oqFA [i. e. (tropical:) We shot in one direction; or we shot one bout, in one direction], (O, K, TA.) ― -b5- [Hence, app.,] one says, kAn fulaAnN liA^aw~ali fuwqi, meaning (tropical:) Such a one (??) [for the first discharge from the bow, i. e.,] the first shot and dying. (A, TA.) ― -b6- And [hence, perhaps.] fuwqN signifies also (tropical:) A mode, or manner, of speech: (A, O, K:) pl. fuwaqN. (TA) One says to a man when he enters upon a mode, or manner, of speech, xa*o fiY fuwqi A^aHosana minohu (tropical:) [Enter upon a mode, or manner, of speech better than it]. (A, TA.) ― -b7- And (tropical:) The first way (AA, O K, TA.) ― -b8- Hence. app., [they say, (??) (tropical:) Return(??) (??) (??)
(??)
(??)
meaning (assumed tropical:) [What is the case of my wife that she is choked by her spittle (??) Then, or afterward,] may it (her spittle) not return to its channel [i. e. her throat, the way whence it came (??) that she may be suffocated). (O.) ― -b9- And one says (O, K) or a man when be l(??) gone away, (O,) maA A@rotad~a EalaY fuwqihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He went away and he did not return [ to the place whence he departed] (O, K) ― -b10- fuwqN also signifies, (O, K.) accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, (O, TA.) (assumed tropical:) The (??) of a woman: (O, K. TA) (??) As says that this is with q [in the place of the f]: (TA:) [it is, however, also said that] fuwqu Alr~aHimi signifies (tropical:) the rima of the vulva, by way of comparison [to the notch of the arrow]. (TA, in the supplement to this art.) ― -b11- [And app(??) the ear see 1 (??) art Hrm, when it is ment(??) in such (??) manner as seems to pre(??) its being a mistranscription for qawf] ― -b12- And (??) (maforaj, O. TA, (??) the (??) maxoraj, TA, (??) (??) (??) say, O) the extremity of the tongue. (O, K, TA.) ― -b13- And (assumed tropical:) The uppermost part of the penis, (En-Nadr, O, K, TA,) or of the glans thereof. (TA.) -A2- And, accord. to the K, A certain bird; mean ing a certain aquatic bird: but this is correctly [quwqN,] with two káfs. (TA.) ― -b2- See also faAqN, last sentence but one.
fiyqN * [originally fiwoqN]: see fiyqapN. -A2- Also, as mentioned in this art and in art. fyq, in the K: see faAqN, last sentence but one.
fayaqN * and fiyaqN: see mufiyqN.

faAqapN *
Poverty, (S, O, K,) want, or need. (S, O, Msb, K.) One says, huwa *uw faAqapK He is one who is in [poverty or] want or need. (Msb.) (See 8.] It has no (unaugmented] verb. (TA.)
fuwqapN * : see fuwqN, first sentence. -A2- And see also faAqN, last sentence but one.
fawaqapN * : see faAy^iqN [of which, as a part. n., it is a pl.].
fayoqapN * : see what next follows.

fiyqapN * , (S, O, &c.,) originally fiwoqapN, (TA,) the w having become Y because of the kesreh before it, (S, O, TA,) The milk that collects (S, O, K) (??) the udder (K) between two milkings: (S, O, K:) and srAj [or this is a mistake for Aibon Als~ar~aAj] has mentioned Aln~aAqapi ↓ fayoqapN, with fet-h: but ISd says, “ I know not how that is: ” (TA:) pl. ↓ fiyqN (S, O, K.) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n. and faAqapN is its n. un.,] and fiyqN (IB. K) and fyqaAtN (K.) and A^afowaAqN, [a pl. of pauc.,] (S, O, K.) or (??) be pl. of the pl. fiyaqN. (IB. TA.) and A^afaAwiyqa, (S. O, K,) which is a pi pl. (O, K) [or pl of A^afowaAqN]. [See also EuraAkapN.] ― -b2- See also above, (??)]. 2, an ex. of A^afaAwiyq in a tropical sense. ― -b3- A^afaAwiyqu also signifies (tropical:) The water that has collected in the clouds and then falls in rain. (S, O, K, TA ? time after time. (S, K. TA.) ― -b4- Also, i. e. A^afaAwiyqu, (tropical:) The greater part of the night: (Lh, O, K, TA) so in the saying, xarajnaA baEoda A^afaAwiyqa mina All~ayoli (??) went forth] after the greater part of the night had passed: (Lh, (??):) or, accord. to Th, after pertions (A^aqoTaAE) of the night. (TA.) ― -b5- fiyqapu AlS~uHaY means (tropical:) The period of the [early portion of the forenoon called the] DHY when the sun has become high: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to Z, the first part of the DHY. (TA.)

fawoqaAniY~N * [Of, or relating to, the location that is above, or over; superior; upper;] rel. n. of fawoq, like as taHotaAniY~N is of taHot: A and n being very often added in the rel. n. (TA. in art. tHt.) ― -b2- And [hence, but more commonly fawoqaAniy~apN,] A gar ment worn by a man over that which (??) the body; [an upper-coat; generally long, reaching to the heels, ample in width, and with long sleeves: it seems to have been formerly peculiar to men of the learned professions:] of the dia(??) Mekkeh: posts-classical. TA [See Dezy's Dict. des Noms des Vétements (??)hea les Aral(??) p. 343].
fawaAqN * The returning supply of milk after sucking or milking. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in three places.

fuwaAqN * : see 1, former half, in two places: -A2- and see 1 again, latter half: ― -b2- and 4, in two places. ― -b3- Also (tropical:) The time between two milkings; (S, O, Msb, K;) for the she-camel was milked, and then left a little while for her young one to suck her in order that she might yield her milk copiously, after which she was milked again; (S, O;) and likewise the time between two suckings; (Ksh in xxxviii. 14;) and ↓ fawaAqN signifies the same; (S, O, Msb, K:) or, (Msb, TA,) accord. to IF, (Msb,) the fwAq of the she-camel is the retuning of the milk into the udder after the milking: (Msb, TA:) or fuwaAqN signifies the time between the opening of one's hand and the grasping with it the udder (K, TA) of the camel: or when the milker grasps the udder and then lets it go, in milking: (TA:) the pl. is A^afowiqapN and A=fiqapN; (O, K;) and Fr says that fwAq has for its pl. A^afiyqapN, originally A^afowiqapN, the kesreh of the w being transferred to the f, and the w being then changed into Y because of the kesreh before it; and A^afowiqapN has for its pl. A^afowiqaAtN. (TA.) One says, maA A^aqaAma Einodahu A_il~aA fuwaAqFA (tropical:) [He did not remain at his abode save as long as the time between two milkings]. (S, O, TA.) And it is said in a trad., AlEiyaAdapu qadoru fuwaAqi Aln~aAqapi (assumed tropical:) [The period of the visiting of a sick person is the space of time between the two milkings of the she-camel]. (S.) And in a trad. of 'Alee occurs the saying, qaAla lahu AlA^asiyru A^anoZironiY fuwaAqa naAqapK i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The captive said to him,] Grant thou me a delay, or respite, as long as the time between two milkings [of a she-camel]. (TA.) maA lahaA mino ↓ fawaAqK and fuwaAqK in the Kur [xxxviii. 14], accord. to different readings, (S,) the latter the reading of the Koofees except 'Ásim, and the former that of the rest, (O,) means (assumed tropical:) [There shall not appertain to it] any postponement, or delay, and resting: (S:) or, accord. to AO, the latter is the meaning of the former reading; and the latter reading means, any waiting, or expecting: (TA:) or [both mean] any pausing as much as the time between two milkings, (Ksh, Bd,) or two suckings: (Ksh:) or any returning, and repeating; (I'Ab, Ksh, Bd;) from A^afaAqa “ he (a sick man) returned to a healthy, or sound, state ”; and the fwAq of the she-camel, when the supply of milk returns to her udder; (Ksh;) or because in it [i. e. the fwAq] the milk returns to the udder; (Bd;) i. e. the blast [to which the words refer] shall be one only; it shall not be repeated. (Ksh.) The saying (Mgh, O, TA) of the Prophet, (O,) related in a trad., (O, TA,) qasama ganaAy^ima xayobara Eano fuwaAqK, (Mgh,) or qasama ↓ AlganaAy^ima yawoma badorK Eano fawaAqK (O, TA) and fuwaAqK, (TA,) means (assumed tropical:) He divided the spoils [of Kheyber, or on the day of Bedr,] in the space of the rest between two milkings of a she-camel: (TA:) or quickly; (Mgh, O;) En fwAq meaning SaAdirFA Eano suroEapK [i. e. qasomFA SaAdirFA Eano suroEapK with a dividing proceeding from quickness]: (Mgh, O: *) or, as some say, the meaning is, making some of them [i. e. of those who composed his army] to be more highly distinguished (↓ A^afowaq) than others (O, TA *) in the proportion of their spoils and of the trial undergone by them. (TA.) -A3- See also faAqN, last sentence but one.
fuyaAqN * , mentioned in this art. in the K: see faAqN, last sentence but one.

faAy^iqN *
Superior, excellent, or surpassing: (Mgh, Msb: *) anything excellent, or choice, (O, K, TA,) and pure, in its kind. (TA.) You say, huwa faAy^iqN fiY AlEilomi [He is superior, excellent, or surpassing, in knowledge], and fiY AlfinaY [in wealth, &c.]. (Mgh.) And jaAriyapN faAy^iqapN [A young woman excelling in beauty, or comeliness]. (Msb.) And fawaqapN [an irreg. pl. of faAy^iqN, like as xawanapN is of xaAy^inN, for by rule these pls. should be faAqapN and xaAnapN,] signifies Elegant scholars, and orators. (IAar, O, K.) -A2- Also The place of junction of the neck with the head: (S, O, K:) therefore when this is high, the neck is long. (S, O.)

A^afowaqu * : see fuwaAqN, last sentence but one. -A2- Also An arrow of which the fuwq [or notch] is broken: (S, O, Msb, K, TA:) [and] an arrow having no fuwq: (L voce A^aqa*~u:) pl. fuwaqN [perhaps a mistranscription for the regular form of pl., i. e. fuwoqN; or it may be that the w is with fet-h to distinguish it from fuwqN signifying “ a notch ” of an arrow]: but IAar explains this as signifying arrows of which the heads have fallen. (TA.) One says, rajaEa fulaAnN biA^afowaqa naASalK (assumed tropical:) Such a one returned with an arrow having a broken notch and without a head upon it; meaning, with an incomplete share of good fortune: (S, O:) or, disappointed of attaining what he desired, or sought: a proverb. (TA.) And radadotuhu biA^afowaqa naASilK (assumed tropical:) [I turned him back, or away, with a paltry benefit; or] I made his share of good fortune to be little, or incomplete. (TA.) And maA balilotu mino fulaAnK biA^afowaqa naASilK, expl. in the first paragraph of art. bl. ― -b2- maHaAlapN fawoqaA='u [A large sheave of a pulley] of which every sin~ [or tooth, perhaps meaning cog, though I do not remember to have met with any description of a cogged mHAlp,] has two cusps (fuwqaAni), (O, K,) like the fwqAn [of the notch] of the arrow. (O.) [The strangeness of this explanation induces me to think that fawoqaA='u is here a mistranscription for fawohaA='u, (see maHaAlapN fawohaA='u, in art. fwh,) and that the explanation is partly conjectural.] ― -b3- And kamarapN fawoqaA='u A glans of a penis whereof the extremity is tapering in form, (O, K,) like that which is termed HawoqaA='u. (O.)

mufiyqN * and mufiyqapN A she-camel having in her udder the milk that had collected between two milkings: (AA, S, O, K:) pl. mafaAwiyqu (S, O, K) and mafaAwiqu, (Akh, TA,) and ↓ fuyuqN also is pl. of mufiyqN signifying as expl. above, mentioned by AA in the third vol. of his “ Nawádir, ” and said by IB to be, accord. to analogy, pl. of fuwuwqN, and to be originally fuwuqN; but accord. to one relation of a verse in which it occurs, it is ↓ fiyaq, which is more agreeable with analogy. (TA.) -A2- And the former, applied to a poet, is syn. with mufoliqN [i. e. One who poetizes admirably, or wonderfully.]. (Aboo-Turáb, K. [But its verb is mentioned in the O and K in art. fyq.])

mufaw~aqN * (tropical:) Food, and beverage, that is taken by little and little. (IAar, O, K, TA. [See its verb.]) -A2- Applied to an arrow, [Having a notch made for the bow-string. (See 2.) ― -b2- And] Having the bow-string put into its notch on the occasion of shooting: [see 4, last sentence:] ― -b3- whence the saying, laA zilota Alxayori muwaf~aqFA wasahomuka fiY Alkarami mufaw~aqFA (assumed tropical:) [Mayest thou not cease to be rightly disposed in beneficence, and thine arrow made ready with the bow-string put into its notch in generosity]. (A, TA.)
musotafiyqN * A man who sleeps much: (O, K, TA:) mentioned by IAar; but this is strange.

fuwlN * [Beans; or the bean; faba sativa of Jussieu; vicia faba of Linnæus; i. e.] i. q. baAqil~FY [q. v.]: (T, IF, S, Msb:) or i. q. Him~aS [i. e. chick-peas; or the chick-pea]: (so in one of my copies of the S: [in most of the copies of the S, this word is mentioned at the end of art. fyl; but in the older of my copies, before that art.:]) or a certain grain, or seed, (Hab~,) like the Him~aS: but with the people of Syria [and of Egypt], i. q. baAqil~FY: or (as some say, M) specially the dry [thereof]: n. un. with p: (M, K:) mentioned by Sb. (M.)

faw~aAlN *
A seller of fuwl. (TA.)
fuwlaA*N * : see art. fl*.

2 faw~amotu Alxuboza *
I made bread, or the bread. (IJ, M.) [And] faw~imuwA lanaA Make ye bread for us: (T, S:) a phrase said by Fr to have been heard from the Arabs as meaning thus. (T.)

fuwmN * , a word occurring in the Kur ii. 58, (T, S, M, &c.,) is expl. as signifying the same as vuwmN [which generally means Garlic; but is said to have also the meaning here next following]; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) said to be a dial. var. of the latter word, but app. [if meaning “ garlic ”] formed, as IJ says, by the substitution of f for v; (M;) and 'Abd-Allah [Ibn-Mes'ood] read [in the Kur ubi suprà] wavuwmihaA [instead of wafuwmihaA]: (Fr, T, S:) it is also expl. as signifying wheat; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) which is said by Lh to be a meaning of vuwm and fuwm; and if Ibn-Mes'ood read the word as vwm, the meaning is fwm, i. e. “ wheat; ” (T;) accord. to Fr, it is an old word, signifying thus, (T, S, *) and also bread; (T, S, K;) Zj says that there is no difference of state-
ment among the lexicologists as to its having the former of these two meanings, that it is said to have the latter also, and that it also signifies the other grains, beside wheat, whereof bread is made [which last meaning is also mentioned in the K]; (T;) and IJ holds that it is rightly expl. as having the first of these three meanings (i. e. “ wheat ”) and the last of them: (M:) another meaning assigned to it is Him~aSN [i. e. cicer arietinum; or chick-peas]; (S, K;) which is of the dial. of Syria: (S:) and it signifies also any Euqodap [app. meaning head of a plant, such as that] of an onion, or of a garlic: or a great gobbet of food: (K: [for A^awo luqomapK EaZiymapK in the CK, I read Aw luqomapN EaZiymapN as in other copies of the K:]) in the dial. of Azd-es-Saráh, it is applied to ears of corn; and ↓ fuwmapN is its n. un.; (M;) this latter signifying an ear of corn, (S, K, TA,) as expl. by IDrd: (TA:) fuwmN has fuwmaAnN [of the measure fuEolanaAnN] for a pl., this being [virtually] a pl. pl.; mentioned by IJ, who says that the dammeh in fuwmN is different from the dammeh in fuwmaAnN. (M, TA.)
fuwmapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, near the end. ― -b2- Also A thing that one carries between his two fingers. (K.)
qaTaEuwA Al$~aApa fuwamFA fuwamFA * (M, K, *) means [They cut the sheep, or goat,] into a number of pieces; (M;) like fuw^amFA. (K.)

faAmiY~N * , altered from fuwmiY~N, A seller of fuwm [app. 3]. in any of its senses, but accord. to the TA as meaning wheat, or chick-peas]: (S, K:) [or] a seller of fruit: (MA:) accord. to Az, (TA,) AlfaAmiY~u means Als~uk~ariY~u, (Mgh, TA,) who is called by the vulgar Albay~aAEu [generally signifying the seller, or vender; perhaps here meaning the seller of sugar, though I do not anywhere find Als~uk~ariY~u thus explained]; (Mgh;) but he says, “ I do not think it genuine Arabic. ” (TA.)

1 faAha bihi * , (S, Msb, K,) aor. yafuwhu (S, Msb) and yafiyhu also, (ISd, TA,) inf. n. fawohN, (MA,) [and inf. n. of unity fawohapN, (see Har p. 434,)] He uttered it, or pronounced it, (S, Msb, K,) namely, a saying; (S;) as also ↓ tfw~h. (S, K.) One says, maA fuhotu bikalimapK, and ↓ mA tafaw~ahotu, i. e. I opened not my mouth with a word, or sentence. (S.) faAha lisaAnN, a phrase used by El-Hareeree, the Arabs did not say: they only said, fAh Alr~ajulu bika*aA [The man opened his mouth with such a thing, i. e., with such a saying, &c.]. (Har p. 191.) And h`*aA A^amorN maA fuhotu Eanohu, inf. n. fuwuwhN [or fuw^uwhN ?], is a saying mentioned by Fr, as meaning This is a thing, or an affair, which I mentioned not, or have not mentioned. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2. -A2- fawiha, aor. yafowahu, [inf. n. fawahN,] He (a man) had what is termed ↓ fawahN, (S, TA,) which means width of the mouth, (S, K, TA,) and largeness thereof: (TA:) or protrusion and length of the upper central incisors: (S, TA:) or length of all the teeth; length of the upper central incisors being termed rawaqN: (IB, TA:) or protrusion of the teeth from the lips, with length thereof. (K, TA.)

2 fw~hhu *
He (i. e. God) made him to be A^afowah [or wide in the mouth, &c.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- $ad~a maA faw~ahota fiY h`*aA AlT~aEaAmi, [thus accord. to the TA, but an explanation of mufaw~ahN seems to show that the right reading is fuw~ihota, in the pass. form,] and ↓ tafaw~ahota, and ↓ fuhota, means $ad~a maA A^akalota [app. Much indeed, or greatly indeed, didst thou eat, or hast thou eaten, of this food; see $ad~a: and see also 10]. (TA.)

3 fAwhhu * , (K, TA,) inf. n. mufaAwahapN; (TA;) and faAhaAhu, [formed from the former by transposition,] (K, TA,) inf. n. mufaAhaApN; (TA;) He talked, or discoursed, with him: [see also 6:] and he contended with him for superiority in glory, or excellence. (K, TA.)

5 tfw~h *
He spoke. (KL.) See also 1, first and second sentences. ― -b2- And see 2. -A2- tfw~h AlmakaAna (assumed tropical:) He entered the fuw~ahap of the place; (K, TA;) i. e., the mouth thereof; likened to the fam [properly thus called] as being the first place of ingress to the interior thereof. (TA.)

6 tfAwhwA *
They talked [app. one to another: see 3]. (K.)

10 AstfAh * , (S, K,) inf. n. AisotifaAhapN and AisotifaAhN, (K,) the latter mentioned by Lh, (TA,) He (a man, S) ate, (S, K,) or drank, (K,) vehemently, after scantiness, (S, K,) or after weakness; (so in a copy of the S;) but seldom used in relation to drinking: or you say, AstfAh fiY AlT~aEaAmi, meaning he ate much of the food: so says IAar, not particularizing the act as being after scarcity or not. (TA.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- And He quenched his thirst by drinking. (K.)
faAhN * : see what next follows: and see the next paragraph again, in the latter half: -A2- and the same word, and faAhK, (the latter in two places,) see voce faAwuwhapN.

fuwhN * and ↓ faAhN and ↓ fiyhN (K, TA) and, accord. to the copies of the K, fuwhapN, [or, as in the CK, fawohap,] but correctly ↓ fuw~ahapN, (TA,) and famN, all signify the same [i. e. The mouth]: (K, TA:) the pl. is A^afowaAhN, (S, K, TA,) pl. of fuwhN, (S, TA,) and as such its case is plain; as pl. of fiyhN, it is like A^arowaAHN as pl. of riyHN; as pl of faAhN, it is allowable as having w for its original medial radical; but as pl. of fuw~ahapN, it is anomalous: (TA:) and another pl. is A^afomaAmN, (K, TA,) said by some to be pl. of fum~N or fam~N, with teshdeed, of which an ex. occurs in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. fm; but some disallow this pl.; and accord. to some, (TA,) it has no sing. (K, TA) agreeable with rule, (TA,) for famN is originally fawahN, (K, TA,) with the w movent by fet-h, or [fawohN, as in some copies of the S,] with the w quiescent, on the authority of IJ; (TA;) the h is elided, and the w becomes a movent final, therefore it must be changed into A, because of the fet-hah preceding it, so the word becomes fA; but a noun may not be of two letters whereof one is [the n of] the tenween, (K, TA,) thus the passage is expressed in the M, but MF remarks that correctly we should say whereof one is the A, (TA,) and therefore a hard letter is substituted for it, one similar to it in kind, which is m, for they are both labials, and in the m is a sort of humming sound (hawiY~N, in the CK huwiY~N,) in the mouth, [or rather in the nose,] resembling [the sound of] the prolongation of the w: (K, TA:) [several similar disquisitions, added in the TA, respecting the change from fwh to fm, I omit, regarding them as needless: what is said on this subject in the S, in art. fm, I have mentioned in that art.:] in the present art., J says that the m of fm is a substitute for the h, not for the w, of fwh; but this is a mistake: (IB, TA:) the dual of famN is famaAni and famawaAni (IAar, S, Msb, K) and famayaAni, the second and third of which are anomalous: (IAar, K:) of the second, which occurs in a verse of ElFarezdak, [and respecting which see the first paragraph of art. fm,] Sb says that it is used by poetic license. (TA.) In using it as a prefixed noun, in the phrase h`*aA fuwhuhu, they deemed the combination of the two hs difficult in respect of utterance; therefore they suppressed the [radical] h thereof [in this case, and then in other, similar, cases], and said, h`*aA fuwhu, and fuw zayodK, and raA^ayotu faA zayodK, and mararotu bifiY zayodK: and when prefixing it to [the pronoun denoting] thyself, thou sayest, h`*aA fiY~a; and this thou dost alike in using it in the nom. case and in the accus. and in the gen., because the w [of fuw] is changed into Y and is then incorporated [into the pronominal Y]: (S, and the like is said in the Msb:) and sometimes, though rarely, they did the like in other cases, when not prefixing it; for instance, faA occurs at the end of a verse of El-'Ajjáj, without an affix, in this case for faAhaA. (S.) ― -b2- In the saying kal~amotuhu faAhu A_ilaY fiY~a, meaning I spoke to him, his mouth being near to my mouth, fAh is in the accus. case as a denotative of state: (S, TA: *) or by reason of the derivative [mukal~imFA] meant to be understood: or, as Sb says, it is an instance of one of the nouns that are put in the place of inf. ns., and it is not to be separated from what should follow it, so that you may not say kal~amotuhu faAha [alone], for you tell of your nearness to the person, and that there is not any one between you and him: and if you will, you may use the nom. case, meaning wah`*ihi HaAluhu [this being his state], (Sb, TA,) i. e. fuwhu A_ilaY fiY~a [his mouth was near to my mouth], the clause [following kl~mth] occupying the place of a denotative of state. (TA.) ― -b3- The saying faAhaA lifiyka, (Meyd, K, TA,) which is a prov., (Meyd, TA,) means May God make the mouth of misfortune to cleave to thy mouth; (Meyd, K, * TA;) [but lit. signifies, only, her, or its, mouth
to thy mouth; and is [likewise] an instance of one of the nouns that are used in the manner of inf. ns. expressive of imprecation, by reason of a verb not mentioned: Sb says, fAhA is without tenween, meaning faA Ald~aAhiyapi, as is shown by the saying,
wadaAhiyapK mino dawaAhiY Almanuw
ni yarohabuhaA Aln~aAsu laA faA lahaA
[Many a misfortune is there, of the misfortunes of time, which men fear, that has no mouth, wherewith to bite]: (Sb, TA:) A'Obeyd says that its primary meaning is, may God make the ground to be in thy mouth; that it is like the sayings bifiyka AlHajaru and bifiyka AlA^avolabu; (S, Meyd;) and [hence] it means disappointment [cleave] to thee: (S, * Meyd:) a man of Belhujeym, (S, Meyd,) cited by A'Obeyd, (S,) addressing a wolf that sought to get his she-camel, (Meyd,) says,
faqulotu lahu faAhaA lifiyka faA_in~ahaA
qaluwSu A@moriy^K qaAriyka maA A^anota HaA*iruhu
[And I said to him, fAhA lfyk, for she is the youthful she-camel of a man who will give thee as a guest's entertainment that which thou fearest]; (S, Meyd; but in the S, as IB has observed, faA_in~ahu is erroneously put for faA_in~ahaA;) i. e. [who will entertain thee with] the shooting of arrows; (Meyd;) [by qaAriyka] he means yaqoriyka, from qiraY AlD~ayofi: (S:) it is also said that faAhaA is metonymically used as meaning the dust of the earth, which is termed the mouth of the earth because it drinks the water; and it is as though the saying meant the dust be in thy mouth: (Meyd:) Sh is related to have said, I heard IAar say lifiyka ↓ faAhFA, with tenween, meaning may God make thy mouth to cleave to the ground; [or rather, ground to thy mouth; lit., simply, a mouth to thy mouth;] and some say faAhaA lifiyka, without tenween, as an imprecation meaning (assumed tropical:) may God break thy fam [i. e. thy teeth, to which fam is often metonymically applied, as is also fuwh]. (TA.) ― -b4- One says also, saqaY fulaAnN A_ibilahu EalaY A^afowaAhihaA, meaning (tropical:) Such a one drew for his camels the water when they came to it, while they were drinking; not having stored it for them in the drinking-trough: and jar~a fulaAnN A_ibilahu EalaY A^afowaAhihaA (tropical:) Such a one suffered his camels to pasture while going along [by his driving them gently: see art. jr]: so says As: and so accord. to the A and other lexicons; but the author of the K, by an omission, has assigned the latter explanation to the former phrase. (TA.) ― -b5- lawo wajadotu A_ilayohi faA kari$K, meaning A^adonaY TariyqK, (K, TA,) has [with other, similar, phrases] been explained in art. kr$ [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b6- fuw farasK HamirK [Mouth of a horse that is suffering indigestion in consequence of his having eaten barley and so made it to stink] is an appellation applied to him who has stinking breath. (TA. [An ex. of it occurs in a verse of Imra-el-keys cited in the TA in art. Hmr as in Ahlwardt's “ Divans of the Six Ancient Arabic Poets, ” p. 125; and differently in De Slane's “ Diwan d'Amro-'kaïs, ” p. 36 of the Arabic text.]) ― -b7- And fuw juradK [Mouth of a large fieldrat] and fuw dabFA [Mouth of a sort of small wingless locust, or perhaps correctly fuw dabaApK mouth of a small wingless locust,] are nicknames applied to a little man. (TA.) ― -b8- One says also, laA fuD~u fuwhu, meaning (tropical:) May his teeth, or front teeth, not be broken. (K, * TA.) And saqaTa fuwhu (assumed tropical:) His teeth fell out. (TA in art. fD [q. v.]) ― -b9- And maAta lifiyhi i. e. liwajohihi [meaning (tropical:) He died upon his face; prone: like saqaTa liwajohihi (assumed tropical:) He fell upon his face: the l in both being used in the sense of EalaY; as it is in the phrase xar~uwA liA^a*oqaAnihimo (expl. in art. xr), &c.]. (A, K, TA. [The explanation in the TK, being somewhat ambiguous (though correct), has misled Freytag in this case.]) And [in like manner, using li in the sense of ElY,] kb~ahu A@ll~`hu lifiyhi, one of their forms of imprecation, meaning (assumed tropical:) May God cause him to die: or prostrate him [upon his face; as also kab~ahu liwajohihi]. (TA.) ― -b10- [See also fuw~ahapN as syn. with fuwhN; like which it has A^afowaAhN for a pl.] -A2- fuwhN also, having for its pl. A^afowaAhN, and pl. pl. A^afaAwiyhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) [which last is of very frequent occurrence,] signifies Perfume, or an odoriferous substance: (Mgh, Msb:) or a thing, or substance, with which a perfume, or an odoriferous substance, is compounded or prepared (yuEaAlaju); like as tawaAbilu signifies things, or substances, with which sorts of food are compounded or prepared: (S, Mgh:) or the tawaAbil [or seeds used in cooking] with which food is compounded or prepared (yuEaAlaju) are also called A^afowaAhu AlT~iybi: (Msb:) [the pl. and pl. pl. are now generally applied to spices, or aromatics:] or AlA^afowaAhu, the pl. mentioned above, signifies [the seeds called] Alt~awaAbilu: and also what diffuse fragrance [I read nawaAfiHu, as in my MS. copy of the K, pl. of naAfiHN, q. v., instead of nawaAfiju (with jiym), the only reading that I find in other copies of the K, regarding the latter as indubitably a mistranscription,] of perfumes, or odoriferous substances: (K:) and the sorts, or species, of flowers; (K, TA;) thus says AHn; and in one place he says that AlAfwAH signifies what are prepared for perfume, of sweetsmelling flowers; and sometimes they are of herbs, or leguminous plants: (TA:) and also sorts, or species, of a thing [app. of any kind]: (K:) and one says, huwa mino A^afowaAhi AlTyb, and A^afowaAhi Albuquwli, meaning It is of the sorts, or species, and of the mixtures, or compounds, of perfume, and of herbs, or leguminous plants: (Mgh:) but fuwhN is not applied to anything that is termed Eaq~aArN. (AHeyth, TA in art. Eqr.)
fawahN * : see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- Also The quality of a maHaAlap [or large sheave of a pulley] such as is termed fawohaA=', fem. of A^afowahu, q. v. (TA.)
fiyhi * : see its syn. fuwhN.
fuwhapN * : see fuw~ahapN, in five places.

fuw~ahN *
Certain slender, long, red roots, with which one dyes; beneficial for the liver and the spleen and the nasaA [app. as meaning sciatica or the sciatic nerve] and pain of the hip and of the flank, powerfully diuretic, and kneaded with vinegar and applied as a liniment it cures the [leprosy termed] baraS: (K, TA:) but the word was not known to Az in this sense, [which is the only meaning, except one which I think doubtful, that I find assigned to it;] and it is said to be the fuw~ap [which see in art. fw, i. e. madder]. (TA.) -A2- See also fuw~ahapN.
fay~ihu * , originally fayowihN: see mufaw~ahN.

fuw~ahapN * : see its syn. fuwhN. ― -b2- [Hence] it signifies also (tropical:) The fam [i. e. mouth] of a place; likened to the fam [properly so called] as being the first place of ingress, or entrance, to the interior: (TA:) [and so too as being the place of egress, or exit, from the interior:] it is of a river, or rivulet, (Lth, S, Msb, TA,) and of a valley, or water-course, or torrent-bed, (K, TA,) and of a street, and of a road; (S, Msb, K, TA;) signifying the fam [or mouth]; as also ↓ fuwhapN, (K, TA,) without teshdeed; mentioned by IAar: (TA:) or it signifies thus in relation to a river, or rivulet; (Lth, Msb, TA;) the foremost part thereof: or, as some say, the place of its pouring into the kiZaAmap [q. v.]: and accord. to Lth, in relation to a valley, or water-course, or torrent-bed, its raA^os [or head, as though in this case having one, or each, of two contr. meanings, unless, as I believe it to be, the mouth, or outlet, of a valley or water-course or torrent-bed be sometimes called its rA^s as being its foremost part]: (TA:) and of a street, it is the place of egress, or exit; (Msb;) the foremost part thereof: (TA:) and of a road, it is the fam [or mouth], which is the upper part thereof (AElAh): (Msb: [thus in my copy; but I think that AElAh is a mistranscription, in my copy, for A^aw~aluhu, and that the correct meaning is therefore the foremost part thereof, agreeably with what is said above in relation to a road and to a river or rivulet:]) but accord. to some, ↓ fuwhapN, without teshdeed, is not allowable; and one should say, AlT~ariyqi qaEada EalaY fuw~ahapK, and ↓ fuw~ahihi [probably, I think, a mistranscription for fwhihi, with the w quiescent, both meaning He sat at the mouth of the road]; not ↓ fuwhatihi, without teshdeed: (TA:) and fuw~ahapN signifies also (assumed tropical:) the first, or foremost, part, of a thing; (K, TA;) like that of the street and that of the river or rivulet: [whence] one says, TalaEa EalayonaA fuw~ahapu A_ibilika i. e. (tropical:) The first, or foremost, portion of thy camels [came to us, or came forth upon us]; like the phrase fuw~ahapu AlT~ariyqi: (TA:) the pl. of fuw~ahapN is A^afowaAhN, (Ks, S, Msb, TA,) which is anomalous, (S, Msb, TA,) and (TA) fuw~ahaAtN [in the CK fuwohAtN] and fawaAy^ihu. (K, TA.) [Hence] one says, daxaluwA fiY A^afowaAhi Albaladi waxarajuwA mino A^arojulihi, (A, K, * TA,) in the copies of the K A^arojulihaA, which is wrong, (TA,) i. e. (tropical:) They entered into the foremost parts of the country, or town,
and went forth from the hindermost parts thereof: (A, K, TA:) the sing. of A^afowaAh as here used is fuw~ahapN. (TA.) -A2- It signifies also A say, or saying, or speech; (S, K, TA;) from 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above: hence one says, A_in~a rad~a Alfuw~ahapi la$adiydN (S, TA) Verily the retracting of that which has been said is difficult: (Har p. 434:) and [hence] one says also, huwa yaxaAfu fuw~ahapa Aln~aAsi [He fears the say, or speech, of men]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The Muslims' rending one another's reputation by evil speech, or by backbiting; (K, TA;) as also ↓ fuwhapF. (TA.) ― -b3- A_in~ahu la*uw fuw~ahapK means Verily he is strong in speech, and free, or unconstrained, in tongue. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says, maA A^a$ad~a fuw~ahapa baEiyrika fiY h`*aA AlkalaA^i, meaning [How vehement is] thy camel's eating [of this herbage]! and in like manner, fuw~ahapa farasika [the vehement eating of thy horse]: whence their saying A^afowaAhuhaA majaAs~uhaA [which may be well rendered as it has been in art. js, q. v.], meaning Their good eating shows thee their fatness, causing thee to be in no need of feeling them to test their condition. (TA.) -A3- And Milk, as long as there remains in it the taste of sweetness; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ fuwhapN; and sometimes correctly said with q, i. e. [quwhapN,] without teshdeed. (TA.)

faAwuwhapN * A man who reveals, or discloses, everything that is in his mind; as also ↓ faAhK, (Fr, S, TA, [but omitted in one of my copies of the S,]) and ↓ faAhN: (Fr, TA:) and bijuwEihi ↓ faAhK one who reveals his hunger; originally faAy^ihN, like as they said haArK and haAy^irN. (TA.)

A^afowahu *
Having what is termed fawahN, meaning as expl. in the last sentence of the first paragraph [i. e. width of the mouth, &c.]; fem. fawohaA='u; (S, K, TA;) the former applied to a man, and the latter to a woman; (S, TA;) and in like manner to horses. (TA.) fawohaA='u $awohaA='u, applied to a woman, means Wide-mouthed, ugly: and, applied to a mare, wide-mouthed, long-headed: or sharp in spirit. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] biy^orN fawohaA='u A widemouthed well. (K.) ― -b3- And TaEonapN fawohaA='u A wide wound made by piercing. (K.) ― -b4- And maHaAlapN fawohaA='u [A large sheave of a pulley] (S, K, TA) that is wide (K, TA) and (TA) whereof the teeth between which runs the well-rope are long. (S, TA.) [See also maHaAlapN fawoqaA='u, in art. fwq.]

mufaw~ahN * and ↓ fay~ihN, (S, K,) the latter originally fayowihN, (S,) Eloquent; (S, K, TA;) and so fay~ihapN applied to a woman; (S, TA;) able in speech; an able speaker: or fay~ihN signifies good in speech; a good speaker: (TA:) or both signify good and eloquent in speech; as though taken from Alfawahu meaning “ width of the mouth: ” (IAar, TA:) or having an inordinate desire, or appetite, for food; a vehement eater; (K, TA;) applied to a man and to other than man: (TA:) and the latter (fay~ihN), having an inordinate and insatiable desire, or appetite, for food: (TA:) and this also signifies a man who eats much; syn. A^akuwlN; (S, K;) and so does ↓ musotafiyhN: (K [in some copies of which, kwfY is strangely put in the place of Akwl in the explanation here given]:) or ↓ musotafiyhN signifies a man eating vehemently after scantiness, (S,) or after weakness: (thus in a copy of the S:) and mufaw~ahN is also expl. as meaning a man who eats vehemently. (TA.) And one says minoTiyqN mufaw~ahN (K, TA) meaning [Very] eloquent in speech: (TA:) and manoTiqN mufaw~ahN (K, TA) Good, or excel-lent, speech, or diction. (TA.) -A2- $araAbN mufaw~ahN means [Beverage, or wine,] perfumed (K, TA.) with [the odoriferous substances called] A^afaAwiyhu [pl. pl. of fuwhu, q. v.]. (TA.) -A3- And vawobN mufaw~ahN (Lth, K) and mufaw~FY (K) A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with fuw~ah [or fuw~ap, i. e. madder]. (Lth, K.)
musotafiyhN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

fiY * is a particle governing the gen. case [and used in the manners and senses expl in what here follows]. (T, S, M, Mughnee, K.) ― -b2- It relates to a receptacle; (Sb, S, M;) and, when used in a wider sense, to that which has some near resemblance thereto; (Sb, M;) [i. e.,] and also to what is considered as a receptacle: (S:) [in other words,] it denotes inclusion, or inbeing, (Msb, Mughnee, K, TA,) either in relation to place or in relation to time: (Mughnee, K, TA;) properly and tropically. (Msb, Mughnee, TA.) gulibati A@lr~uwmu fiY A^adonaY A@loA^aroDi wahumo mino baEodi galabihimo sayagolibuwna fiY biDoEi siniyna [The Greeks have been overcome in the nearer, or nearest, part of the land, and they, after the overcoming of them, shall overcome in some few years], in the Kur [xxx. 1 — 3], is an ex. of its relation to place and to time. (Mughnee.) And walakumo fiY A@loqiSaASi Hay`wpN (tropical:) [And there is, to you, in retaliation, life, or an advantage, (respecting the meaning of which see art. HY,) in the Kur ii. 175,] is an ex. of its being used tropically, (Mughnee.) A^adoxalotu AlxaAtama fiY A^uSobaEiY is an ex. of its relation to place, but the proposition is inverted [i. e. the meaning is I inserted my finger into the signet-ring]. (Mughnee.) [Using it properly,] you say, AlmaA='u fiY AlA_inaA='i [The water is in the vessel]: (S:) and huwa fiY AljiraAbi [It is in the wallet,] and fiY Alkiysi [in the purse]: and huwa fiY baToni A^um~ihi [He is in the belly of his mother]: and huwa fiY Algul~i [He is in the shackle for the neck]: (M:) and zayodN fiY Ald~aAri [Zeyd is in the house], (S, M, * Msb,) or within the house, and in the midst of it, for fiY Ald~aAri, means daAxilihaA, and wasoTahaA: (T:) and [using it tropically, you say,] Al$~ak~u fiY Alxabari (assumed tropical:) [Doubt, or uncertainty, is in the information]. (S.) The saying fiyhi EayobN [In him is a fault, or blemish], if relating to a real Eayob, is proper; and if relating to an ideal Eayob, tropical: the former is such as the amputation of the hand of the thief, and the redundance of a hand; and the latter, such as the runningaway of a slave. (Msb.) [When relating to time, it may in some cases be rendered In, or during; as in the phrase fiY A^ay~aAmK maEoduwdaAtK, in the Kur ii. 139, i. e. In, or during, certain numbered days. A_in~a A^aSoHaAba A@lojan~api A@loyawoma fiY $ugulK faAkihuwna, in the Kur xxxvi. 55, may be rendered (assumed tropical:) Verily the inmates of Paradise this day shall be in the midst of diverting occupation, cheerful, or happy. The phrase A^am~aA qawoluhu ka*aA fiyhi maA fiyhi, lit. (assumed tropical:) As to his saying thus, in it is what is in it, is used as a polite expression of objection, or contradiction; like fiyhi taA^am~ulN, q. v. In many instances, fiY may be rendered Of, or concerning, or in respect of; as in qaAla fiyhi ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He said of, or concerning, him, or it, thus; for qaAla fiY *ikorihi ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He said in mentioning him, or it, thus, or fiY waSofihi in describing him, or it; or the like hence, for ex., one says kataba kitaAbFA fiY Eilomi All~ugapi (assumed tropical:) He wrote a book of, or concerning the science of lexicology: and hence, in the Kur ii. 133, A^at~uHaAj~uwnanaA fiY A@ll~`hi (assumed tropical:) Do ye argue with us concerning, or in respect of, God?] ― -b3- It also denotes concomitance, (Mughnee, K,) and (K) in this ease (Mughnee) it is syn. with maEa. (Msb, Mughnee, K.) Thus in the phrase, qaAla A@doxuluwA fiY A^umamK [He shall say, Enter ye with peoples]. (Msb, Mughnee, TA,) in the Kur [vii. 36]: (Msb, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, fiY jamaAEapi A^umamK [in the company of peoples]. (Mughnee.) Thus. too, in the phrase, in the Kur [xlvi. 15], fiY A^aSoHaAbi Aljan~api [With the inmates of Paradise]. (Msb, TA.) [Or in these and similar instances, fiY may be rendered, more agreeably with the primary signification, as meaning Among.] In the K, the meaning as denoting concomitance and that which is identical with maEa are made distinct: and it has been said that bi denotes the continuance of concomitance and maEa denotes its commencement; though this is not invariably the case. (MF, TA.) [Hence it is used to denote a combination of two qualities: as in the phrase TuwlN fiY A@sotiroxaA='K (assumed tropical:) Length together with laxness: (occurring in the K voce TanabN:) and sawaAdN fiY HumorapK (assumed tropical:) Blackness blending with redness: and the like. And in like manner it is used to denote the combination of the length and breadth of a thing: as in the phrase Tuwluhu Ei$oruwna *iraAEFA fiY valaAvi A^a*oruEK EaroDFA Its length is twenty cubits with (or as we say by) three cubits in breadth: in which case the number of square cubits is expressed by the phrase Ei$oruwna fiY valaAvK as though meaning Twenty as a multiplicand with three as its multiplier; i. e. twenty multiplied by three: see Daraba as signifying “ he multiplied. ”]. ― -b4- It also denotes the assigning of a cause. (Msb, Mughnee, K.) Thus in the phrase fiY A^arobaEiyna $aApN i. e. On account, or because, of completing [the possession of] forty sheep or goats, [the giving of]
a sheep or goat [for the poor-rate] is incumbent [on the possessor: or this may be rendered, in the case of the possession of forty, a sheep or goat is to be given]. (Msb.) And thus in the saying, [in the Kur xii. 32,] fa*`likun~a A@l~a*iY lumotun~aniY fiyhi [And that is he because of whom ye blamed me]. (Mughnee.) Thus also in the saying, in a trad., A_in~a A@moraA^apF daxalati Aln~aAra fiY hir~apK HabasatohaA [Verily a woman entered the fire of Hell because of a she-cat which she confined without food]. (Mughnee.) [And thus in the phrase A^asolafa fiY ka*aA He paid in advance, or beforehand, for, or on account of, such a thing.] ― -b5- It also denotes superiority; (Mughnee, K, TA;) i. e. (TA) it is used in the sense of EalaY. (T, S, M, Msb, TA.) Thus in the saying, in the Kur [xx. 74], walaA^uSal~iban~akumo fiY ju*uwEi A@ln~axoli [And I will assuredly crucify you upon the trunks of palm-trees]. (T, S, Msb, Mughnee, TA.) And so in the verse of 'Antarah cited voce saroHN. (T, M, Mughnee, TA.) And Yoo asserts that the Arabs say, nazalotu fiY A^abiyka, meaning Ealayohi [i. e. I alighted, or descended and stopped, &c., at the abode of thy father]. (S.) ― -b6- It is also syn. with bi, (T, S, M, Mughnee, K,) sometimes. (S.) Thus in the saying of Zeyd-el-Kheyl,
watarokabu yawoma Alr~awoEi fiyhaA fawaArisu
baSiyruwna fiY TaEoni AlA^abaAhiri wAlkulaY
(S, Mughnee, TA,) meaning, biTaEoni AlAbAhr wAlklY [i. e. And horsemen skilful in piercing the aortas and the kidneys ride in the day of fear therein]. (S, TA.) And thus in a verse cited by Fr, A^arogabu is made trans. by fiY and Eano instead of bi and Eano. (T, TA.) [Thus, also, layosa fiY $aYo'K is sometimes used for layosa bi$aYo'K, meaning It is nought; or not of any account or weight; &c.: see more in art. $yA^.] ― -b7- It is also syn. with A_ilaY. (Mughnee, K.) Thus in the Kur [xiv. 10], farad~uwA A^ayodiyahumo fiY A^afowaAhhm [And they put their hands to their mouths]. (Mughnee, TA.) ― -b8- It is also syn. with mino. (M, Mughnee, K, TA.) Thus in the Kur [xxvii. 12], fiY tisoEi A=yaAtK [Of, or among, nine signs]. (M, TA.) And in the saying, xu*o liY Ea$orFA mina AlA_ibili fiyhaA faHolaAni [Take thou for me ten of the camels; of, or among, them let there be two stallions. (M, TA.) [Thus too in the saying huwa fiY A^aSoli qawomihi He is of, or among, the purest in race, &c., of his people: and the like thereof.] ― -b9- It also denotes comparison; and this is when it occurs between a preceding [mention of a] thing excelled and a following [mention of a] thing excelling: as in the saying, [in the Kur ix. 38,] famaA mataAEu A@loHay`wpi A@ld~unoyaA fiY A@loA=xirapi A_il~aA qaliylN [But the enjoyment of the present life, in comparison with that which is to come, is no other than little]. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b10- It is also used for compensation; and this is when it is redundant as a compensation for another [fiY] which is suppressed: as in the saying, Darabotu fiymano ragibota for Darabotu mano ragibota fiyhi [I beat, or struck, him whom thou desiredst]: (Mughnee, K:) but this is allowed by Ibn-Málik alone. (Mughnee.) ― -b11- And it is used for corroboration: (Mughnee, K:) this is when it is redundant without its being for compensation: and this El-Fárisee allows in a case of necessity in verse; citing as an ex.,
A^anaA A^abuwA saEodK A_i*aA All~ayolu dajaA
taxaAlu fiY sawaAdihi yaranodajaA
[I am Aboo-Saad; when the night becomes dark, thou imagining its blackness to be black leather]. (Mughnee.) And it is thus used in the saying, in the Kur [xi. 43], waqaAla A@rokabuwA fiyhaA [for A@rokabuwhaA, i. e. And he said, Embark ye therein, the like of which occurs also in xviii. 70 and xxix. 65], (Mughnee, K,) accord. to some. (Mughnee.) -A2- fiY as a prefixed noun in the gen. case, syn. with fam, and fiY~a as syn. with famiY, see voce fuwhN, in art. fwh.

faY~a * is a word expressive of wonder: they say, yaA faY~a maA liY A^afoEalu ka*aA [O my wonder! What has happened to me that I do thus?]: or it is expressive of regret on account of a thing that is passing away [so that this exclamation may be rendered Oh! What has happened to me &c.]: Ks says that it is not to be written with' [though it is so written in several of the lexicons in art. fyA^, i. e. faYo'a]; and that it means yaA EajabiY [as first expl. above]: and in like manner one says, yaA faY~a maA A^aSoHaAbuka [O my wonder! What are thy companions? i. e. what manner of men are thy companions? mA here denoting interrogation respecting qualities, or attributes; as in the Kur xxvi. 22]: and he says that mA in this case occupies the place of a noun in the nom. case. (M, TA.) Ks is also related to have said that some of the Arabs express wonder by faY~a and haY~a and $aYo'a; and some add maA, saying yaA fay~amaA and yaA hay~amaA and yaA $ayoy^amaA, meaning How good, or beautiful, is this! the K is faulty here; mentioning only yaA fay~amaA, and explaining it as denoting wonder. (TA.)
tafiy~apN * : see tafiyoy^apN, in art. fyA^.

1 faA='a * , aor. yafiYo'u, inf. n. faYo'N (S, O, Msb) and fuyuwo'N, (O,) He (a man, Msb) returned; (S, O, Msb;) and so ↓ AfA=', and ↓ AstfA=': (M, TA:) faYo'N, as also ↓ fayoy^apN and ↓ fiyy^apN, [or the former of these, accord. to analogy, is an inf. n. of unity, and the latter an inf. n. of modality,] and A_ifaA='apN and AistifaA='apN al' signify rujuwEN: (K:) or, accord. to some, faA='a signifies particularly he returned to a good state or condition. (MF, TA.) One says, faA='a mino gaDabihi He returned [to a good state, or recovered, from his anger]: (M, TA:) and fulaAnN sariyEu AlfaYo'i mino gaDabihi [Such a one is quick in respect of the returning &c. from his anger]: (S, M, * O:) and ↓ A_in~ahu lasariyEu Alfiyoy^api, (M,) or ↓ laHasanu Alfiyoy^api, (S, O,) i. e. [Verily he is quick, or good, in respect of] the returning [to a good state, or from his anger, or in respect of the manner of returning &c.]: (S, M, O:) and ↓ huwa sariyEu AlgaDabi sariyEu Alfiyoy^api [He is quick in respect of anger, quick in respect of returning, or recovering, therefrom]. (A, TA.) And faA='a A_ilaY AlA^amori, and faA='ahu [i. e. faA='a AlA^amora], inf. n. faYo'N and fuyuwo'N, He returned [to the affair, or to the command, i. e. to that which was commanded]. (M, TA.) Hat~aY tafiYo'a A_ilaY A^amori A@ll~`hi , in the Kur xlix. 9, means Until it [referring to a party (TaAy^ifap) before mentioned] return to the ordinance of God, or to that which God has commanded: (Bd:) or until it return (T, Msb) to obedience, (T,) or to that which is right. (Msb.) And faA='a A_ilaY AlA^amori, inf. n. faYo'N, signifies also He reconsidered the affair, or case. (TA.) ― -b2- faA='a Almuw^oliY (M, Msb, K) mini A@moraA^atihi, (M, K,) inf. n. faYo'N, (TA,) or ↓ fayoy^apN, (Msb,) means The man who had sworn to abstain from conjugal intercourse with his wife expiated his oath and returned to her. (M, Msb, * K. [See Kur ii. 226.]) But MF observes that this usage of faA='a to signify He expiated an oath belongs to the conventional language of the law. (TA.) In the case of a man who has sworn that he will abstain from conjugal intercourse with his wife, a period of four months is appointed to him in the Kur-án; and if he have such intercourse with her in the four months, it is said of him, qado faA='a, meaning He has returned [or reverted] from his oath, to the doing that which he swore that he would not do, and is bound to expiate his oath: if he have not had such intercourse with her until the end of the four months from the day of his swearing, then, Ibn-'Abbás and a number of the Companions pass upon her a single sentence of divorce, making the [said sentence of] divorce to have effect at the end of the months; but many of the Companions and others say that in this case he must return, and expiate his oath, or he must divorce. (T, TA.) And [hence] one says ↓ lahu EalaY A@moraA^atihi fayoy^apN He has the right of returning to his wife: (Msb, TA:) and huwa yamoliku ↓ fayoy^atahaA He possesses the right of returning to her; namely, a wife whom he has divorced. (A, TA.) ― -b3- AlfaYo'u EalaY *iY Alr~aHimi occurs in a trad. as meaning The being favourably inclined, or affectionate, to the relation; and returning to kind treatment of him. (TA.) ― -b4- faA='a said of the shade, (M, Msb,) aor. yafiYo'u, (Msb,) inf. n. faYo'N, (M, Msb, K, *) It shifted, or removed; (M, K; *) or [rather] it returned from the side of the west to the side of the east: (Msb:) and AlZ~ilaAlu ↓ tafay~aA^ati The shades became changed in their manner of being; (S, O;) or [rather] they returned [towards the east] after midday. (T, TA. [See the Kur-án xvi. 50.]) ― -b5- And faA='ati Al$~ajarapu; and ↓ tfy~A^t; (M;) and ↓ fy~A^t, inf. n. tafiyoy^apN; (S, O, TA;) The tree had much shade. (M, TA.) faA='ati AlHadiydapu The iron implement became blunt after its being sharp. (T, TA.)
-A2- fiy^otu Alganiymapa, (mentioned, but not expl., in the K,) inf. n. faYo'N, (TA,) means I took the spoil. (TK.) [See also 10.]

2 fy~A^ AlZil~a * , and ↓ AfA='hu He (God) made the shade to return [in the afternoon]. (El-Khafájee, MF, TA.) -A2- qay~aA^at said of a tree: see 1, near the end. ― -b2- Said of the wind, It put in motion the seed-produce, or standing corn, and the trees. (M, TA.) And, said of a woman, She put in motion her hair, from self-conceit, or vanity. (M, TA.)

4 A^afaA^otuhu *
I made it to return. (O.) See also 2. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, A^afaA='a A@ll~`hu EalaY Almusolimiyna maAla Alkuf~aAri [God restored to the Muslims, as though it were theirs by right, or gave to them as spoil, the property, or wealth, of the unbelievers]; (S, O;) inf. n. A_ifaA='apN. (S.) And A^afaA='a A@ll~`hu Ealayohimu AlganaAy^ima [God restored, or gave, to them the spoils]. And A^afaA='a EalaY qawomK fayoy^FA He took for a party the spoil of another party and brought it to them: and he took for a party spoil that had been taken from them. (T, TA.) ― -b3- And A^afaA^otu ka*aA I made such a thing to be a faYo' [or spoil]. (TA.) ― -b4- And A^afaA^otu fulaAnFA EalaY AlA^amori I turned him to the thing, or affair, when he had desired another thing, or affair. (AZ, T.) -A2- See also 1, first sentence.

5 tafay~aA^ati AlZ~ilaAlu * : ― -b2- and tfy~A^t Al$~ajarapu: see 1, near the end. ― -b3- tfy~A^ fiyhi means He shaded himself in it; i. e., in the shade termed faYo'. (M.) One says, tafay~aA^otu fiY faYo'i Al$~ajarapi [I shaded myself in the afternoon-shade of the tree]. (S, O.) And tfy~A^ biAl$~ajarapi [He shaded himself by means of the tree; or] he entered into the A^afoyaA=' [or afternoon-shades] of the tree: (MA:) and [it is said that] tafay~aA^otu Al$~ajarapa signifies I entered into the A^afoyaA=' of the tree, and shaded myself thereby: (Har p. 500:) and Aboo-Temmám has made it trans. by itself [i. e. without a prep.] in his saying,
fatafay~aA^otu Zil~ahu mamoduwdFA
[as though meaning And I protected myself from the sun by its shade, when it was extended]: but [perhaps he has thus used the verb in the last of the senses here following, for] it is said that this is irregular. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence] one says, tafay~aA^otu bifayoy^ika meaning (tropical:) I have had recourse to thee for protection. (A, TA.) ― -b5- tfy~A^ is said of a branch or twig [as meaning It bent, in a languid manner]. (T, M, L, K, voce taraA^~ada; &c.) And one says, tfy~A^t lizawojihaA, meaning She bent herself over her husband, and affected languor, or languidness, to him, feigning coyness, or opposition, and threw herself upon him: (T, * TA:) from AlfaYo'u signifying “ the act of returning: ” and some say tqy~A^t, with q; but Az says that this is a mistake, and that it is correctly with f (TA.) -A2- tfy~A^ signifies also tatab~aEa [He sought a thing time after time, or repeatedly, &c.]. (Har p. 500.) And one says, fulaAnN yatafay~aA^u AlA^axobaAra and ↓ yasotafiyw^uhaA [app. meaning Such a one seeks after news, or tidings, time after time, or repeatedly, &c.]. (A, TA.)

10 AstfA=' *
He took as spoil. (S, M, * O, K.) One says, AisotafaA^otu h`*aA AlmaAla I took this property as spoil. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also 5. -A2- As intrans., see 1, first sentence.

faYo'N *
Afternoon-shade; shade after the declining of the sun from the meridian; (T, * S, O;) [i. e.] the faYo' is what was sun, and has been annulled, or superseded, by shade; (M, K;) or that from which the sun has departed: so called because of its “ returning ” from side to side: (S, O: [see 1, first sentence:]) ISk says, (S, O,) the Zil~ is what sun has annulled, or superseded; [correctly, what sun annuls, or supersedes; (see Zal~N;)] and the faYo' is what has annulled, or superseded, sun: (S, Mgh, O:) but AO says, on the authority of Ru-beh, that on which the sun has been and from which it has departed is faYo' and Zil~; and that on which the sun has not been is Zil~: (S, O:) [see more under this latter word:] pl. [of pauc.] A^afoyaA='N and [of mult,] fuyuwo'N. (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And Spoil, booty, or plunder; syn. ganiymapN [q. v.]; (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) thus called, by the inf. n., because it returns from one party to another; (Msb;) and fay~N in this sense is not allowable; (Mgh, Msb;) nor is it in the preceding sense: (Mgh:) or such as is obtained without difficulty: and therefore likened to shade. (MF.) And The [tax, or tribute, termed] xaraAj [q. v.]: (S, O, K:) frequently occurring in trads. as meaning such, of the possessions of the unbelievers, as accrues to the Muslims without war: (TA:) or such as is obtained from the believers in a plurality of gods after the laying-down of arms: (A 'Obeyd, Mgh and Msb voce ganiymapN:) or such as God has restored [as though it were theirs of right] to the people of his religion, of the possessions of those who have opposed them, without fighting, either by the latter's quitting their homes and leaving them vacant to the Muslims, or by their making peace on the condition of paying a poll-tax or other money or property to save themselves from slaughter: such is termed faYo' in the Kur-án. (T. [See more under ganiymapN.]) -A2- Also A flock of birds: (O, K:) [or a number of birds disposed in a row:] also termed EaraqapN and Saf~N. (O, TA.) -A3- yaA faYo'a, (M, O, K, in the CK [erroneously] yA faYo'u,) or, accord. to Ks, correctly yA faY~a [q. v.]. (M,) [Oh! or O my wonder?] an expression of regret, (M, O, K,) accord. to most, (TA,) or of wonder, (Ks, M, K, TA,) meaning yaA EajabiY. (Ks, M.) [See $aYo'N, last three sentences.]

fiy^apN *
A [party, portion, division, or distinct body, of men, such as is termed] TaAy^ifap: (S, O, K, TA:) or a company (Msb, TA) of soldiers who fight in the rear of an army, and to whom the latter has recourse in the case of fear or defeat: (TA:) or a company of men who [in war] have recourse, for aid, one to another: (Er-Rághib, TA:) a word having no proper sing.: (Msb, TA:) originally fiYo'N; (S, O, K;) the p being substituted for the medial Y, which is dropped: (S, O:) or its original form is fiy^owN [or fiy^oYN or fiy^owapN or fiy^oyipN (see art. fA^w and fA^Y)]; the final [radical] letter being that which is elided; for it is from faA^awotu [or faA^ayotu] “ I divided; ” and fiy^apN is syn. with firoqapN: (IB, L, TA:) pl. fiy^aAtN and fiy^uwna, (S, O, Msb, K,) in which latter the w and n are for the making good what is deficient [in the sing.]. (Msb.)

fayoy^apN * : see 1, in four places. ― -b2- [Hence] *uw fayoy^apK a term applied to Date-stones (nawaY Alt~amori) when they are hard: [because,] being given as fodder to cattle, and eaten by them, they pass forth as they were at first. (T, TA.) -A2- Also A time; syn. HiynN. (K.) One says, jaA='ahu baEoda fayoy^apK He came to him after a time. (TA.) ― -b2- And The HidaA^ap [or kite], that seizes as its prey the chickens from the dwellings: (O:) or a certain bird resembling the eagle, (L, K,) which, when it fears the cold, migrates to El-Yemen. (L.)
fiyoy^apN * : see 1, first quarter, in four places.

tafiyoy^apN * , (M and K in art. tfA^,) as also tafiy~apN, both mentioned by Lh, and the latter reckoned as a dial. var. of the former, (M in that art.,) and tay^if~apN and A_if~u and A_if~apN and A^af~apN and A_if~aAnN and A^af~aAnN, (see art. Af,)] The time of a thing: (M and K in art. tfA^:) one says, A^atayotuhu EalaY tafiyy^api *`lika I came to him at the time of that: (M in that art.:) and [by extension of the signification] one says, daxala EalaY tafiy^api fulaAnK meaning A^avarihi [i. e. He entered near after such a one; as though treading in his footsteps]: (K in the present art.:) the t in tafiyoy^apN is an augmentative letter; the word being [originally] of the measure tafoEilapN, but formed by transposition: Z says that the t would not be augmentative if the composition of the word were as it is here, without transposition: that it is not of the measure tafoEilapN from AlfaYo'u; for, if it were, it would be of the same measure as tahoyiy^apN [i. e. it would be tafoyiy^apN]; therefore, if not formed by transposition, it would be of the measure faEiylapN [i. e. it would be from tfA^, as some hold it to be], because of the A_iEolaAl [or alteration for the sake of alleviating the sound, such as takes place in yasiyru for yasoyiru, which cannot be in a noun of the measure tafoEilapN from a triliteral root like fyA^, whose medial radical is infirm], the last radical being hemzeh: but its formation by transposition from tay^if~apN [originally taA^ofifapN] to taf~iy^apN, which is then changed to tafiyoy^apN, as Z says in the “ Fáïk, ” is what determines the t to be augmentative, and the [original] measure to be tafoEilapN. (L and TA * in arts. tfA^ and fyA^.)

mufaA='N * A thing that has been made a faYo' [or spoil, &c.]. (TA.) And A person whose country,
or province, or town, has been conquered, and become a faYo' to the Muslims. (IKt, O, TA.) It is in a trad. of some of those who have gone before, ↓ laA yuw^am~aru mufaA='N EalaY mufiYo'K, meaning An emancipated slave shall not be made governor over an Arabian; (K, TA;) or, as in the Nh [and O] and L, lA yaliyan~a [shall by no means rule]; (TA;) as though it were said, none of the people of the Sawád (which was conquered by force and became a faYo' to the Muslims) shall rule over the Companions (O, TA) and their next successors. (TA.)
mufiYo'N * A person who makes a thing [or a country or the like] to be a faYo'. (TA.) See also mufaA='N.
mafiyoy^apN * : see the paragraph here following.
mafoyaA^apN * : see the paragraph here following.

mafoyuw^apN *
A place of faYo', i. e. of the shade thus termed; [a place of afternoon-shade;] (M, K;) as also ↓ mafoyaA^apN; (K;) and, as AAF says, on the authority of Th, ↓ mafiyoy^apN; (M, L, TA;) and so ↓ mafoyuwo'apN, like masomuwEapN [in measure]: (L, TA:) accord. to Lth, (TA,) mafoyuw^apN is syn. with maqonuw^apN, (S, TA,) which signifies a place on which the sun does not come: so says Az; and he adds that it is probably correct, but that he had not heard it on any other authority than of Lth. (TA.)

mafoyuwo'N *
i. q. maEotuwhN [Idiotic, or an idiot, i. e. deficient, or wanting, in intellect; &c.]: so called from his keeping long [or much] in the shade. (M, TA.)
mafoyuwo'apN * : see mafoyuw^apN.
1 faAjato birijolihaA * , aor. tafiyju, She (a camel) kicked with her hind legs, backwards. (TA.)
4 AfAj * , mentioned in the O and L and Msb in this art.: see art. fwj.

fayojN *
A foot-messenger; a courier who journeys on foot: (S:) or a Sultán's foot-messenger: (L, Msb:) or one who journeys with letters: (L:) or a quick courier who carries tidings, or communications, from one town, or country, to another: (Nh, TA:) originally Pers., (S, O,) arabicized, (S, O, K,) from Payok: (O, K:) pl. fuyuwjN. (S, TA.) It is also expl. as meaning One going, or journeying, alone: thus in a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, in which it is opposed to zaraAfapN meaning “ a company [of men]. ” (TA.) And [the pl.] fuyuwjN, (O, K,) as used in a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, (O,) means Men who enter the prison and go forth from it, keeping guard. (O, L, K: in some copies of the K, and keep guard.) ― -b2- And A company [of men]; (Msb;) syn. with fawojN: (O and K in art. fwj:) and sometimes applied to a single person: pl. [of pauc.] A^afoyaAjN and [of mult.] fuyuwjN. (Msb.) -A2- Also A low, or depressed, place, such as is termed wahod, of the earth, or ground. (AA, O, K.) -A3- And A state of dispersion; as also ↓ fiyjN. (TA. [See 4 in art. fwj.])
fiyjN * : see what next precedes.
fay~aAjapN * A she-camel that kicks with her hind legs [much or often], backwards. (TA. [See 1.])

faAy^ijN *
A wide [expanded and even tract such as is termed] basaAT, of land. (AA, O in art. fwj.)

faAy^ijapN *
A wide tract between two elevated portions, (S, O, K, all in art. fwj,) of rugged ground, or of sand: (S, O:) or what has the form of a valley between two mountains, or between two rugged tracts containing stones and sand and earth, like a xaliyf [q. v.], but wider: thus expl. by ISh: pl. fawaAy^iju. (TA in art. fwj.)

1 faAHa * , aor. yafiyHu, inf. n. fayoHN and fayaHaAnN: see art. fwH. ― -b2- fAH Ald~amu, inf. n. fayoHN (L, Msb) and fayaHaAnN, (L,) It poured out, or forth: (L:) or it flowed; as also ↓ AfAH, inf. n. A_ifaAHapN: or, accord. to AZ, the latter is trans., and signifies as expl. below in relation to blood. (Msb.) ― -b3- And faAHati Al$~aj~apu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. tafiyHu, inf. n. fayoHN, (TA,) (tropical:) The wound upon the head spirted forth blood; (S, Msb, K;) or poured forth much blood. (A.) ― -b4- And fAH AlHur~u, aor. yafiyHu, inf. n. fayoHN; and aor. yafwHu, inf. n. fawoHN; (assumed tropical:) The heat rose, or diffused itself, and raged vehemently. (L.) It is said in a trad., $id~apu AlqayoZi mino fayoHi jahan~ama (tropical:) [The intenseness of the heat of summer is from the vehement raging of the heat of Hell]. (TA.) And one says, AlHum~aY mino fayoHi jahan~ama (tropical:) The fever is from the vehemence of the heat of Hell. (A.) ― -b5- And faAHati Alqidoru, (S, K,) aor. tafiyHu (S, TA) and tafuwHu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The cooking-pot boiled; (S, K, TA;) as though it were the fire of Hell, in its heat. (TA.) ― -b6- And faAHati Aln~aAru (assumed tropical:) The fire spread. (Msb.) And [hence, app.,] faAHati AlgaArapu, aor. tafiyHu, i. e. (tropical:) [The troop of horsemen making an attack, or incursion, upon a people] spread themselves. (S, TA.) See fayaAHi. ― -b7- And fAH, (L, Msb, TA,) aor. yafaAHu, (L, TA,) [inf. n., app. fayaHN, which signifies “ width ” accord. to the S and K, and is agreeable with general analogy in this case, as the aor. of the verb is originally yafoyaHu, though it seems to be implied in the Msb that the aor. is not yafaAHu, but yafiyHu,] It (a sea, S, * L, K, * TA, and a place, L, or a valley, Msb) was, or became, wide. (S, * L, Msb, K, * TA.)

entryFree.key: lawo madakota Ald~unoyaA lafay~aHotahaA fiY yawomK waAHidK

div2.entryFree: 2 lawo madakota Ald~unoyaA lafay~aHotahaA fiY yawomK waAHidK * means (tropical:) [If thou possessedst all that the world contains,] thou wouldst dissipate it, or squander it away, in one day. (A, TA. *)

4 AfAH *
He poured forth, spilled, or shed, blood. (S, Msb, K.) See also 1, first sentence. ― -b2- AfAH Alqidora (assumed tropical:) He made the cooking-pot to boil. (S, K.) ― -b3- A^afiHo Eanoka mina AlZ~ahiyrapi i. q. A^aborido, (K,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool: (M, L, TA:) [as also Afixo:] the medial radical letter is both w and Y. (M.)

fayoHN * and ↓ fuyuwHN Abundance of herbage of the [rain, or season, called] rabiyE, with ample extent of land: (K:) [accord. to the TK, both are inf. ns., of which the verb is faAHa, and the agent is Alr~abiyEu: but this, I think, is rendered doubtful by what here follows:] fywH occurs in a verse [as some relate it]; but accord. to the relation of IAar, it is fatuwH, with t, [and with fet-h to the f,] and this, which signifies “ rain, ” is said by Az to be the right reading: the pl. [of fayoHN] is fuyuwHN. (TA.)
fayaAHN * : see A^afoyaHu.

fayaAHi * , like qaTaAmi, [indecl.,] (T, S, L, K,) of the fem. gender, (L,) a name for The gaArap, (T, S, L, K,) meaning troop of horsemen making a hostile attack, or incursion, upon a people. (T, L.) ↓ fiyHiY, fayaAHi, (S, A, K, &c., [in the CK, erroneously, fayoHiY,]) said by the people of the Time of Ignorance, (S,) when they impelled horses making a hostile attack, or incursion, and they spread out, (L,) means Spread out, O attacking troop of horsemen: (S, A, K:) or spread out upon them, or against them, and disperse yourselves, &c. (Sh, L.)
fuyuwHN * : see fayoHN.

fay~aAHN * : see A^afoyaHu, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Profuse in bounty: (S, A:) so in the saying, A_in~ahu lajawaAdN fiy~aAHN (tropical:) [Verily he is liberal, munificent, or generous; profuse in bounty]. (S.) ― -b3- And naAqapN fay~aAHapN (tropical:) A she-camel that yields much milk, (A, K,) and has a large udder. (K.)

A^afoyaHu * A sea, (S, L, K,) and a valley, (Msb,) and any place, (L,) wide, or extensive; (S, L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ fay~aAHN: (S, L, K:) ↓ fay~aAHN occurs in the story of Umm-Zara, accord. to A 'Obeyd, applied to a bayot [i. e. house, or tent]; but accord. to others, it is ↓ fayaAHN, without teshdeed: (L:) [the fem. of A^afoyaHu: and pl. fiyHN:] one says daArN fiyoHaA='u A wide, or an ample, house or abode: (S, K:) and in like manner rawoDapN [a meadow, &c.]. (L, Msb.) ― -b2- And fayoHaA='u signifies also A sort of thin cooked food, such as is supped, or sipped, (HasaA='u,) seasoned with seeds such as are used in cookery. (S, K.)

1 faAxati Alr~iyHu * , aor. tafiyxu, inf. n. fayoxN and
fayaxaAnN: see 1 in art. fwx. Accord. to Kr and the K, fayoxN signifies A spreading, or becoming diffused; like fiyoHN: (TA:) but ISd expresses doubt of the correctness of this: (L, TA:) it is [said to be] an inf. n. in this sense. (TK.) ― -b2- See also 4.

2 fy~x AlEajiyna *
He made the dough like the sukur~ujap [or fayoxap (q. v.) in form]. (TA.)

4 AfAx * , (L,) inf. n. A_ifaAxapN, (L, K,) He (a man, L) emitted wind from the anus, with a sound; (L, K;) as also ↓ faAxa: (L:) or he voided excrement with an emission of wind. (L, K.) [See also art. fwx.] ― -b2- AfAx, said of a man, signifies also suqiTa fiY yadihi [i. e. He repented of what he had done; &c.]. (K.) ― -b3- And AfAx mino fulaAnK He (a man, TA) turned away from, avoided, shunned, and left, such a one; syn. Sad~ Eanohu. (K.)

fiyoxapN *
A state of dilatation of the place of exit of the urine. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- And A tangled, luxuriant, or dense, and abundant, state of herbage. (K.) ― -b3- And Vehemence, or intenseness, of heat. (K, TA.) -A2- And A [kind of small saucer, or cup, such as is called] sukur~ujap [q. v.]: (K:) pl. fayoxaAtN. (O and K voce $ufaArijN.)

1 faAdato lahu faAy^idapN * , (T, S, A, O, L, Msb, K,) aor. tafiydu, (S, A, O, &c.,) inf. n. fayodN, (Msb,) [Profit, or advantage, or the like, (see faAy^idapN,)] accrued to him; (T, * S, * A, O, * L, * Msb, K;) or came to him. (IKtt, TA.) ― -b2- And fAd, aor. yafiydu, (T, S, M, O, L, K,) inf. n. fayodN, (M, O, L,) said of property, It continued, or belonged or appertained, syn. vabata, (T, S, M, O, L, K,) lahu to him; (T, S, M, O, L;) as also fAd, aor. yafuwdu, (M in art. fwd,) inf. n. fawodN: (K in that art.:) or went away, passed away, or departed. (K. [But this last meaning, which I find only in the K, in relation to fAd, in this art. and in art. fwd, may be taken from what next follows, and relate to property as applied to cattle.]) ― -b3- And fAd, aor. as above, (T, M, L, K, and S &c. in art. fwd,) and so the inf. n., (IAar, T, L, and K in art. fwd,) He (a man, M, TA) died; (T, M, L, K, and S &c. in art. fwd;) as also fAd, aor. yafuwdu, (S and K &c. in art. fwd,) inf. n. fawodN; (K &c. in that art.;) and so faAza and faAZa; (TA;) i. q. faAta. (A.) One says, maA faAda Hat~aY balaga rizoquhu Aln~afaAda, meaning maA faAta [i. e. He did not die until his means of subsistence became exhausted]. (A.) ― -b4- And fAd, aor. as above, (S, M, O, L, K,) and so the inf. n., (S, O, L,) He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; (S, M, O, L, K;) as also ↓ tfy~d. (T, S, M, L, K.) ― -b5- And, (M, L, K,) accord. to some, (M, L,) He was cautious of a thing, and turned aside from it. (M, L, K.) [See also 2.] -A2- fAd said of saffron, and of the plant called warosa, It became pulverized, or reduced to powder by its being bruised or brayed. (IKtt, TA.) -A3- fAdhu, aor. yafiyduhu, (S, L, K,) inf. n. fayodN, (L,) He mixed it, (namely, saffron, K,) or moistened it with water &c.; syn. daAfahu; (S, L, K;) from which it is formed by transposition [accord. to the lexicologists; but not accord. to the grammarians, because it has an inf. n.]; (TA;) as also fAdhu, aor. yafuwduhu, (T, M, L, &c., in art. fwd,) inf. n. fawodN: (K in that art.:) and he bruised, or brayed, it, (namely, saffron, and the plant called waros,) and then wetted it with water: (L in art. fwd:) and faAdatohu she (a woman) rubbed it (namely perfume) in water, in order that it might dissolve. (M, L.) -A4- Eani fAd Almal~apa Alxubozapi, inf. n. fayodN; and ↓ AfAdhA; He removed the hot ashes from the cake of bread; syn. A^azaAlahaA (TK. [In the O and K, this meaning of these two verbs is vaguely intimated, only by the words, Alfayodu A^ano tufiydu biyadika Almal~apa Eani Alxubozapi.])

2 fy~d mino qironihi * (Th, M, L) He turned away from, or avoided, his adversary: (Th, L:) or he fled from him. (M.) [See a similar meaning of fAd, above.] -A2- And fy~d, (T, O, K,) inf. n. tafoyiydN, (L, K,) He augured evil from the cry of the [bird called] fay~aAd. (T, O, L, K.)

4 AfAdhu *
He gave it, namely, property, (AZ, Ks, T, S, M, O, L, K,) to another: (AZ, Ks, T, S, M, L:) and AfAdhu maAlFA, inf. n. A_ifaAdapN, He gave him property. (Mgh, Msb.) It belongs to this art. and to art. fwd. (L in art. fwd.) ― -b2- [And He, or it, profited, advantaged, or benefited, him; faAy^idapF being understood. Hence,] one says, A_ino A^afadotaniY HarofFA faqado A^aSofadotaniY A^alofFA [If thou teach me a word, thou givest me what is worth a thousand dirhems]. (A in art. Sfd.) ― -b3- [Hence, also, AfAd said of a word, and a phrase, It had, or performed, a useful office, as expressive of a meaning, or as contributing to the expression thereof, or as adding to a meaning previously expressed. And hence, It imported, or conveyed, a meaning; and particularly, when said of a phrase, a complete meaning, so that a pause might be well made after uttering it; faAy^idapF being understood.] -A2- See also 10. ― -b2- And see 1, last signification. ― -b3- Also, AfAdhu, inf. n. as above, He killed him; destroyed him; slaughtered him; namely, a man, and a beast. (T, * L, and K * in art. fwd.)
5 tfy~d * , as intrans.: see 1, latter half. -A2- tfy~dhu: see 10.

6 humaA yatafaAyadaAni biAlmaAli bayonahumaA *
They two give, of the property, each to the other; or profit, or benefit, each other therewith: (ISh, T, O, K:) you should not say yatafaAwadaAni: (K:) and hmA ytfAydAn AlEiloma They two impart knowledge, each to the other: (K in art. fwd [q. v.]:) or, in the opinion of MF, both of these verbs are allowable. (TA.)

10 AstfAdhu * (T, S, M, &c.) He gained it, acquired it, or got it, for himself, namely, property [&c.]; (T, * M, * Mgh, Msb, and L and K in art. fwd;) and ↓ AfAdhu is syn. therewith, (S, M, A, Mgh, O, L, Msb, K,) as used by some, (Msb,) having two contr. significations, (K,) though disallowed by others, (Msb,) or it is more chaste than the former; (Mgh;) and ↓ tfy~dhu signifies the same. (M, and K in art. fwd.) ― -b2- [And He derived it, learned it, or inferred it. ― -b3- And AstfAd mnohu He gained, or derived, profit, advantage, or benefit, from him, or it; faAy^idapF being understood.]

fayodN *
Saffron: (IAar, TA voce malaAbN:) or the leaves of saffron: (L:) or saffron mixed, or moistened with water &c. (S, O, L, K.) ― -b2- And The hair upon a horse's lip. (T, S, O, K.)

[
fayiydN * expl. by Golius as signifying (on the authority of Meyd) Vir pusillanimus pavidusque, is app. a mistake for fay^iydN.]

fay~aAdN * (T, S, M, A, O, L, K) and ↓ fay~aAdapN, (T, S, O, L, K,) in which latter the p is added to render the epithet intensive, (T, L,) A man who walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side. (T, S, M, A, O, L, K.) One says, fulaAnN yamo$iY EalaY AlA^aroDi fay~aAdFA may~aAdFA [Such a one walks upon the ground] with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, &c. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, Alfay~aAdu is said to signify The lion. (O.) ― -b3- And The male of the buwm [or owl]: (T, S, M, O, K:) or i. q. AlS~adaY [which is also said to signify the male of the buwm: for other explanations see SadFY] (S, O.) ― -b4- And ↓ fay~aAdapN, (M,) or this and fay~aAdN, (T, S, O, K,) One who collects together what he can, and eats it. (Lth, T, S, M, O, K.)
fay~aAdapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

faAy^idapN * a subst. from faAda AlmaAlu, (M, L, and K in art. fwd,) in the sense of vabata; (M, L;) or an act. part. n. from faAdato lahu faAy^idapN; (Msb;) Profit, advantage, benefit, or good, which God bestows upon a man, and which he [the latter, consequently] gains, or acquires, and which he produces: (T, L:) an accession which accrues to a man: (Msb:) what one gains, or acquires, of knowledge, (S, A, O, L, Msb, K,) and polite accomplishments, (Msb,) and property: (S, A, O, L, K:) what one has recently acquired, of property, of gold or silver, or a slave, or the like: (AZ, Msb:) and [simply] profit, advantage, benefit, or utility: and good: and knowledge: and wealth, or property: (KL:) pl. fawaAy^idu: (T, O, L, Msb, K:) it belongs to this art. and to art fwd: (TA:) some improperly derive it from Alfuw^aAdu. (MF.) ― -b2- [Hence, Utility as expressive of a meaning, or as contributing to the expression thereof, or as adding to a meaning previously expressed, or a word or phrase. And hence, A meaning, or an import, of a word or phrase; and particularly a complete meaning of a phrase, such that a pause may be well made after the uttering thereof.]
mafiydN * [Perfume, &c.] mixed, or moistened with water &c.; (S, O, L;) as also mafuwdN. (As, T in art. fwd.)

rajulN mitolaAfN mifoyaAdN *
A destructive man; as also mifowaAdN. (Ibn-'Abbád and O and K in art. fwd.)
