fiyruwzajN * [an arabicized word from the Pers. fiyruwzahu or Piyruwzahu The turquoise;] a well-known kind of stone. (TA.) ― -b2- And A certain sort of dye [probably of the colour of the stone so called]. (TA.)

1 faA$a * , (O, K,) aor. yafiy$u, inf. n. fayo$N, (O, TA,) He gloried, or boasted, (O, K,) and magnified himself, imagining [in himself] what he did not possess; (K;) as also fa$~a; like as you say *aAma, aor. ya*iymu; and *am~a, aor. ya*um~u; (TA;) he was boastful, or proud, pretending to possess a thing and not being as he pretended; (TA;) and ↓ fAy$ [signifies the same; or] he gloried, or boasted, vainly, and praised himself for that which was not in him. (AHeyth, in L, art. Trm*.) [See also 5.] -A2- fA$ AlA^ataAna, aor. as above, (IDrd, O, K,) and so the inf. n. (IDrd, O,) He (the ass) mounted the she-ass: (IDrd:) said by Yoo to be from Alfayo$apu. (O, K. *)

3 qAy$hu * , (TA,) inf. n. fiyaA$N (S, O, K) and mufaAya$apN, (O, K,) He vied, or contended, with him in glorying, or boasting, or in glory, or excellence. (S, * O, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also, (TK,) inf. n. mufaAya$apN, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) He threatened him much in fight, and then was pronounced a liar. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K, TK.) ― -b3- See also 1.

5 tfy~$ Al$~aYo'a *
He arrogated the thing falsely; (Ibn-'Abbád, * O, * K, * TA;) without merit. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, TA.) ― -b2- tfy~$ Eani Al$~aYo'i He turned back from the thing (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) through weakness and impotence; (TA;) like Anf$~. (TA.)

fayo$N * and ↓ fayo$apN The head [or glans] of the penis: (S, O, K:) or a swollen penis: (TA:) or ↓ the latter word has the former meaning; and fayo$N is its pl., [or rather coll. gen. n.,] like as tamorN is of tamorapN: (O:) and ↓ fayo$alapN signifies the same as fayo$apN; and some say that its l is augmentative: (TA:) or fayo$N signifies a weak fayo$alap. (Lth, TA.)
fayo$apN * : see fayo$N, in two places. ― -b2- Also The uppermost part of the head. (TA.)
fiyaA$N * : see fayo$uw$apN. -A2- [See also 3.]
fayuw$N * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

fay~aA$N * A man who glories, or boasts, and magnifies himself, imagining [in himself] what he does not possess; (K;) vainly boastful, without merit; (TA;) who contends for superiority in that which he does not possess; (K;) and [in like manner] ↓ fayuw$N one who pretends to possess a thing, not being as he pretends; (TA;) both signify one who glories, or boasts, vainly, and praises himself for that which is not in him: (AHeyth, in L, art. Trm*:) and ↓ the latter is said to signify a cowardly and weak man. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, A chief, or lord, abounding in excellence, or generosity, or bounty, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) who vies with others in glory. (TA.)

faA$uw$N *
A weak and lax man. (TA.)

fayo$uw$apN *
Weakness and laxness; (O, K;) and so ↓ fiyaA$N. (TA.)
fayo$alapN * : see fayo$N.

1 faASa fiY AlA^aroDi * , aor. yafiySu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. fayoSN, (TA,) He went away into the country, or in the land. (S, O, K.) In the following verse of Imra-el-Keys,
manaAbituhu mivolu Als~uduwsi walawonuhu
ka$awoki Als~ayaAli fahowa Ea*obN yafiySu
respecting which As said, I know not what is [the meaning of] yafiyDu, this word is said to be from fAS signifying as expl. above: (S, O:) [but I do not see what meaning that would be apposite in this case could be thence derived without straining:] but fAS signifies also it shone, or glistened; syn. baraqa; (TA;) and some say that yfyS in this verse means yaboruqu; (O, TA;) and the pronoun in manaAbituhu relates to the front teeth; (O, * TA;) by Ea*obN yafiyDu being meant the lustre (maA=') thereof: (O:) [accordingly, the verse may be rendered, The places of growth thereof, i. e. their gums, were like the (garment called) suduws, and their colour was like the thorns of the sayaAl (q. v.), so that they were sweet and glistening: (see the context in “ the Divans of the six ancient Arabic poets, ” edited by Prof. Ahlwardt:) or, as some relate the verse, the last word is ↓ yufiySu, (IB, O, TA,) from maA A^afaASa bikalimapK [q. v.], (O,) so that it is a denotative of state, the meaning being Ea*obN fiy HaAli kalaAmihi [i. e. sweet when [displayed in] speaking; or rather, clearly uttering; but it will be seen below that yafiySu, as well as yufiySu, may, accord. to the M and K, be used in this sense:] (IB, TA:) see 4. ― -b2- maA A@sotaTaEotu A^ano A^afiySa minohu, meaning I was not able to turn aside, or away, from, or to avoid, him, or it. (S, O.) [See also mafiySN: and see 4.] ― -b3- And waA@ll~`h maA fiSotu, like as one says wAll~`h mA bariHotu [perhaps meaning By God I did not quit my place; as well as I did not cease:] (S, O, K: *) mentioned on the authority of AHeyth: (TA:) [that it has the latter meaning is clear; for] one says, maA fiSotu A^afoEalu I did not cease (maA bariHotu) doing [such a thing]: (M:) and ↓ AstfAS, likewise, signifies bariHa. (IB, TA.)
3 faAoyaSa see 3 in art. fwS.

4 AfAS AlD~ab~u Eano yadihi * [The lizard called Db~ escaped, or slipped, from his hand, is expl. as meaning] his fingers became unclosed (Ainofarajat) from [the grasp of] the Db~, so that it escaped from him. (M, TA.) And one says, qabaDotu Ealayohi falamo yufiSo I grasped him and he did not escape, or get loose. (AHeyth, TA.) And qabaDotu EalaY *anabi AlD~ab~i faA^afaASa mino yadiY Hat~aY xal~aSa *anabahu [I grasped the tail of the Db~ and it slipped from my hand so that it freed its tail]: (Lth, S, O, TA:) [but in the O, mino is omitted before yadiY; not intentionally, for the verb before mn is there masc., as above:]) this is when thy fingers become unclosed (tatafar~aju) from the grasp of its tail: (Lth, O:) and this [state of the fingers] is termed ↓ Alt~afaAwuSu. (TA.) [It is also said that] A^afaASati Alyadu signifies The fingers of the hand became unclosed (tafar~ajato) from the grasp of the thing. (K, TA. [But I doubt the correctness of this.]) ― -b2- And AlA_ifaASapu signifies The being clear, or perspicuous; syn. AlbayaAnu; (O, K;) like AlmufaAwaSapu, expl. in art. fwS;] and the being fluent. (O.) [And also The making speech clear, or perspicuous.] One says, fulaAnN *uw A_ifaASapK A_i*aA takal~ama Such a one is a person endowed with clearness, or perspicuity, and fluency, when he speaks. (O.) And AfAS lisaAnuhu biAlkalaAmi His tongue made speech, or the speech, clear, or perspicuous; and so ↓ faASa, aor. yafiySu; (M;) and maA yafiySu bihi lisaAnuhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. fayoSN, (TA,) his tongue does not make it clear, or perspicuous (K, TA.) And maA A^afaASa bikalimapK He did not make clear, or distinct, or perspicuous, a word, or a sentence. (Yaakoob, S, O, TA.) See also 4 in art. fwS: and see 1 in the present art. [And it is said that maA A^afaADa bikalimapK signifies the same. Or, accord. to Mtr, if he be correctly cited in Har p. 447, the verb in this sense, and app. as thus used in all the phrases mentioned above, is correctly with D, and not so with S: but this I greatly doubt.] ― -b3- One says also, AfAS bibawolihi He ejected his urine: (O, K:) or AfAD bh. (ElGhooree, in Har ubi suprà.)

6 Alt~afaAyuSu * is said to be the original and regular form of Alt~afaAwuSu, which signifies The speaking, talking, or discoursing, each to another, or each with another: the Y being changed into w because of the dammeh. (M in this art. and in art. fwS, and TA.) ― -b2- See also another explanation in art. fwS: and see 4 in the present art.
10 A_isotafoyaSa see 1, last sentence.

maA Eanohu mafiySN *
There is not any place to which to turn aside, or away, from it: or there is not any turning aside, or away, from it: syn. maHiydN [which may be meant either as a n. of place or as an inf. n.]: (As, S, O, K:) or maEodilN. (IAar, M.)

1 faADa * , (S, M, Mgh, &c.,) aor. yafiyDu, inf. n. fayoDN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and fayoDuwDapN (S, O, K)
andfuyuwDN (M, O, K) and fiyuwDN and fuyuwDapN (M, K) and fayaDaAnN, (M, O, K,) It (water) overflowed: poured out, or forth, from fulness: (Mgh:) it (water, S, O, K, or a torrent, Msb) became abundant, (S, O, Msb, K and flowed from [over] the brink of the valley, (Msb,) or so as to flow over the side of the valley, (S, O,) or so as to flow like a valley; (K;) and ↓ AfAD signifies the same: (Msb, TA:) it (water) became abundant: (TA:) [contr. of gaADa, aor. yagiyDu:] it (water, and that of the eyes, and the like, M, or anything fluid, Msb) ran, or flowed: (M, Msb:) or it poured out, or forth; or poured out, or forth, vehemently; gushed out, or forth: (M:) and it (water, and blood,) fell in drops. (Msb.) ― -b2- It (a vessel) became full: (Msb:) [or it overflowed: for you say,] faADa Aln~ahoru bimaAy^ihi The river overflowed with its water: and faADa AlA_inaA='u bimaA fiyhi The vessel overflowed with what was in it: (Msb:) and a poet says,
$akawotu wamaA Al$~akowaY limivoliYa EaAdapF
wal`kino tafiyDu AlkaA^osu Einoda A@motilaAy^ihaA
[I complained; and complaint is not a custom of the like of me; but the cup overflows on the occasion of its being full]. (A) You say also faADato Eayonuhu, aor. as above, inf. n. fayoDN, The eye flowed [with tears]. (TA.) And faASa EaraqFA, said of a man, [He sweated;] sweat appeared upon his body, on an occasion of grief. (IKtt) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) was, or became, much, abundant, many, or unmerous. (O, K.) You say, faADa All~iy^aAmu (assumed tropical:) The mean became many: (S, O:) opposed to gaADa, q. v. (S and A in art. gyD.) And faADa Alxayoru (tropical:) Good, or wealth, &c., became abundant, (A, Msb,) fiyhimo among them. (A.) ― -b4- Aor. as above, (S,) inf. n. fayoDN, (TA,) (tropical:) It (a piece of news, or a story,) spread abroad; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ AstfAD; (S, M, A, Msb, K, TA;) it spread abroad among the people. (Msb and TA in explanation of the latter verb,) like water. (TA.) ↓ The latter is also said of a place, meaning (tropical:) It became wide, or ample. (A.) And you say, faADa Ealayohi Ald~iroEu (tropical:) [The coat of mail spread over him; or covered him]. (A.) ― -b5- Aor. as above, inf. n. fayoDN and fuyuwDN, (tropical:) He (a man, S, O, K) died: (S, M, O, K:) and, (S, M, O, K,) in like manner, (S, O,) faADatN nafosuhu, (S, M, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (M,) inf. n. fayoDN, (M, Msb,) (tropical:) his soul departed, or went forth; (S, M, A, * Mgh, * O, Msb, K;) of the dial. of Temeem; (S, M, O;) on the authority of AO and Fr; and AZ says the like; but As says that one should not say, fAD Alr~ajulu, nor fADt nfsh, for fAD is only said of tears and of water: (S, O:) to which is added in the O, but one says, faAZa, with Z, [as is also said in the Mgh,] as meaning “ he died, ” and not fAD, with D, decidedly: (TA:) [see, however, the remarks of IB below:] or the more chaste expression is fAZ, with Z, without the mention of the nfs; and some do not allow any other: (Msb:) but in the L we find as follows: IAar says. fAD Alrjl and fAZ, meaning “ the man died: ” and Abu-l-Hasan says, fAZt nfsh, the verb relating to the nfs; and fAD Alrjl and fAZ: but As says, I heard AA say that one should not say, fAZt nfsh, but fAZ, meaning “ he died; ” and not fAD, with D, decidedly: IB, however, says that what IDrd has cited from As is different from that which J has ascribed to him; for IDrd cites the words of As thus: the Arabs says, fAZ Alrjl, meaning “ the man died; ” but when they speak of the nfs, they say fADt nfsh, with D; and he quotes the ex.
fafuqiy^ato EayonN wafaADato nafosu
[And an eye was put out, and a soul departed]: and he [IB] adds that this is what is commonly known to be the opinion of As: but J has committed and error; for As quotes from AA that one should not say, fAZt nfsh, but fAZ, meaning “ he died; ” not fAD, decidedly and he also says, nor does it necessarily follow from what he relates that he firmly believed it: AO says that fAZt nfsh is of the dial. of Keys; and fADt, of the dial of Temeem and AHát says, I heard AZ say that Benoo-Dabbeh alone say, fADt nfsh: in like manner also El-Mázinee says. on the authority of AZ. that all the Arabs say, fAZt nfsh. except Benoo-Dabbeh, who say, fADt nfsh with D. (TA.) [See also art. fyZ. It is further said, that] AlfayoDu signifies Death: (A, K;) as occurring in a trad respecting Ed-Dejjál, where it is said, vum~a yakuwnu EalaY A^avari *`lika AlfayoDu [Then shall be, after that, death] (A, TA:) Sh says, I asked El-Bekráwee respecting this, and he asserted AlfyD, in this case, to signify “ death; ” but I have not heard it from any other; unless it be from faADato nafosahu signifying His slaver collecting upon his lips at the departure of his soul [flowed]. (TA.) ― -b6- You say also faADa Sdoruhu mina AlgayoZi (tropical:) [His bosom overflowed with wrath, or rage], (A, TA.) And faADa Sadoruhu biAls~ir~i His bosom disclosed, or concealed, the secret; (S, O, K;) his bosom could not conceal the secret; (M;) his bosom was full with the secret, and disclosed it, not being able to conceal it. (TA.) ― -b7- And fayoDN is used as meaning (assumed tropical:) God's suggesting (A_iloqaA=') [of a thing]: what the Devil suggests (yuloqiyhi) is termed Alwasowasapu. (Kull p. 277.) ― -b8- faADa AlbaEiyru bijir~atihi: see 4, latter half.

4 AfAD * : see 1, first sentence. -A2- He filled a vessel so that it overflowed: (S, M, O, K:) or [simply] he filled a vessel, (M, Msb,) accord. to Lh; but the former. [says ISd,] in my opinion, is the correct signification. (M.) ― -b2- He made water, and tears, and the like, to run, or flow; or to pour out, or forth; or to pour out, or forth, vehemently; to gush out, or forth: (M:) he poured [water &c.] out, or forth: (A, TA:) or he poured water out, or forth, copiously. (Mgh.) You say, AfAD AlmaA='a EalaY nafosihi, (S, O, K,) or ElY jasadihi, (Msb,) He poured the water (S, O, Msb, K) upon himself, (S, O, K,) or upon his body. (Msb.) And AfAD dumuwEahu, (S,) or damoEahu, (Msb,) He poured forth his tears. (Msb.) And AfADt AlEayonu Ald~amoEa [The eye poured forth tears]. (TA.) ― -b3- AfAD A@ll~`hu Alxayora (tropical:) God made good, or wealth, &c., to abound. (Msb.) ― -b4- AfAD Ealayohi Ald~iroEa (tropical:) He put on him the coat of mail: like as you say Sab~ahaA [lit he poured it]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- A^afaADuwA mino EarafaAtK (tropical:) They pushed on, pressed on, or went quickly, syn. dafaEuwA, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) or AinodafaEuwA, (M, A,) with multitude, (M, Mgh, O,) from 'Arafát, (S, M, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) to Minè, (S, M, O,) exclaiming lab~ayoka: (M:) or they returned, and dispersed themselves from 'Arafát: (O, K:) or they hastened from 'Arafát to another place: (K:) the last rendering is taken from Ibn-'Arafeh; and agreeably with all of these renderings, the phrase in the Kur [ii. 194], faA_i*aA A^afaDotumo mino EarafaAtK, has been explained: (TA:) and [in like manner,] you say AfADwA mina minaY A_ilaY mak~ipa (tropical:) They returned from Mine to Mekkeh; on the day of the sacrifice: (Msb:) A_ifaADapN signifies (tropical:) the advancing, and pushing on, or pressing on, in journeying, or pace, (A, * TA,) and the like, (A,) with multitude, and is only after a state of separation and congregation: (TA:) it is from the same word as signifying the “ pouring out, or forth; ” (A, O, TA,) or from AfAD AlmaA='a signifying “ he poured the water out, or forth, copiously ” (Mgh:) and the original expression is AfAD nafosahu. or raAHilatahu; but they omit the objective complement, and hence the verb resembles one that is intrans.: (O, TA:) or AfADp signifies the quickly impelling or urging [a beast] to run, with one's foot or leg, or feet or legs: and AfAD, he (a (??)) made his camel to exert himself beyond measure, (??) quick run, between the utmost (??) and what is (??) than that; AfADp denoting the half [of the fall (??) of the run of camels having riders upon these; and being only applied when they have riders upon them: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh:) and every dafoEap [or act of pushing on, or pressing (??),] is termed A_ifaADapN. (S, Msb, K.) Hence, TawaAfu AlA_ifaADapi, signifying The (??) [around the K(??) the return from Mine to Mekkeh; (Msb, TA) on the day of the sacrifice: (TA:) or the circuiting of visitation. (Mgh.) ― -b6- AfADwA fiY AlHadiyvi (tropical:) They pushed on, or pressed on, in discourse; syn. AinodafaEuwA: (Lh, S, M, A, O,) they entered thereinto; launched forth, or cut, thereinto: (Lh, M, O;) they were large, or copious, or profuse, therein; (O, TA:) or they dilated therein (M:) or they began, commenced, or entered upon, discourse: (Msb;) as also ↓ AstfADwhu, (M, Msb,) accord. to some; (Msb;) but this latter is disallowed by most; (M;) or by the skilful, (Msb.) You say also, AfAD fiY EamalK (assumed tropical:) He entered into an action, or employment; and pushed on, or pressed on, therein: (Bd in x. 62:) or he began it, commenced it, or entered upon it. (Jel, ibid.) ― -b7- AfAD baAl$~ayo'i He impelled, or thrust, with the thing: (M:) he cast, or threw, the thing. (M, TA.) ― -b8- AfAD AlbaEiyru bijir~atihi, (Lh, S, M, A, O,) and (S, O) AfAD alone, (S, O, K,) and bijir~atihi ↓ faADa, (TA,) (tropical:) The camel propelled his cud (Lh, S, M, A, K) from his inside,
(Lh, M, A,) or from his stomach, (S, K,) and expelled it, or ejected it: (S:) or cast it forth in a scattered and copious state: or it means [he made to be heard] the sound of his cud, and of his chewing. (M.) ― -b9- maA AfAD bikalimapK (assumed tropical:) He did not make clear, or distinct, or perspicuous, a word, or sentence. (Msb, TA.) [And mA AfAD bklmp signifies the same.] ― -b10- AfAD biAlqidaAHi, (S, M, A, O, K,) and EalaY AlqidaAHi, meaning biAlqidaAHi, for prepositions stand in the places of other prepositions, (S, O,) and AfAD AlqidaAHa, (O, K,) (tropical:) i. q. Daraba biAlqidaAHi [which has two significations: He turned about, or shuffled, the gaming-arrows: and he played with the gaming-arrows]: (S, M, A, O, K:) and A^ajaAlahaA [which has the former of the above significations]: or he dealt them forth. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, describing a [wild] he-ass and his she-asses,
fakaA^an~ahun~a ribaAbapN wakaA^an~ahu
yasarN yufiyDu EalaY AlqidaAHi wayaSodaEu
(S, TA) (tropical:) [And it was as though they were a bundle of gaming-arrows, and as though he were a shuffler thereof, shuffling or] dealing out the arrows, and deciding, and making known what he produced: (TA:) or, accord. to Kh, and speaking with his loudest voice, saying “ The arrow of such a one has won, ” or “ This is the arrow of such a one: ” or, accord. to some, distributing, or dispensing, by means of the arrows: (TA in art. SdE:) by EalaY AlqidaAHi is meant biAlqidaAHi. (S voce EalaY.) One relation of this verse substitutes yaxuwDu for yufiyDu. (TA.) Az says that A_ifaAD [a mistranscription for A_ifaADapN] is always a consequence of a state of separation, or dispersion, and abundance, or copiousness. (TA.) ― -b11- Hence the saying in a trad. respecting a thing picked up from the ground, vum~a A^afiDohaA mino maAlika, [app. a mistake for fiY maAlika,] i. e. (assumed tropical:) Then put thou, or throw thou, it, and mix it, among thy property. (TA.) ― -b12- A^ufiyDato She (a woman) became wide in the belly: [as though spread out:] or she became large in the belly, and flabby in flesh. (M.) -A3- AfAD AlmaroA^apa He made the masolakaAni [i. e. vagina and rectum] of the woman to become one, on the occasion of devirgination; (M;) i. q. A^afoDaAhaA [from which it is app. formed by transposition, as is indicated in the M.]. (O, TA.)

5 tfy~D *
It flowed. (Har p. 610. [But this I do not find elsewhere.])

10 AstfAD *
He asked for the pouring out (A_ifaADap) of water, (K, TA,) &c. (TA.) -A2- Said of a piece of news: and of a place: see 1, in the first half of the paragraph. You say also, AstfAD AlwaAdiY $ajarFA (tropical:) The valley became wide, and abundant in trees. (S, O, K, TA.) -A3- AstfADwA AlHadiyva: see AfADwA fiY AlHadiyvi. [It seems to be indicated in the S and O that it signifies They spread abroad the story among the people; as used by some: see musotafiyDN.]

fayoDN *
A river, (M, TA,) in general: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^afoyaADN and [of mult.] fuyuwDN: the pluralization thereof shows that it is not an inf. n. used as a subst.: (M, TA:) [and a river, or water, that overflows.] AlfayoDu is [hence] applied to The Nile of Egypt: (S, O, K:) or, accord. to the Tekmileh, to a place in the Nile of Egypt: (TA:) and to the river of El-Basrah: (As, S, K:) or this last is called fayoDu AlbaSorapi, because of its greatness. (M.) You say also A^aroDN *aAtu fuyuwDK Land in which is water: (Lh, M:) or in which are waters that overflow. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- A horse (tropical:) that runs much; (S, M, O, K;) that is fleet, or swift; (M;) that runs vehemently; likened to water pouring forth; as also sakobN. (Eth-Thaalebee, in TA, art. skb.) ― -b3- A man (tropical:) bountiful, or munificent; as also ↓ faAy^iDN, (A,) and ↓ fay~aADN: (S, O:) or, as also ↓ the last, a man abounding [or profuse] in beneficence or bounty. (M.) ― -b4- Much, or abundant, water. (M.) ― -b5- (tropical:) Much, or abundance: as in the saying, A^aEoTaAhu gayoDFA mino fayoDK (tropical:) He gave him little from much. (S, M, O.) Anything much in quantity. (KL.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A large gift: [and simply a gift, favour, or grace:] pl. fuyuwDN. (KL.) ― -b7- [See also 1, last sentence but one. Hence biTariyqi AlfayoDi meaning (assumed tropical:) By way, or means, of instinct; instinctively.] ― -b8- (tropical:) Death: [as being the outpouring of the soul:] see 1. (Sh, on the authority of El-Bekráwee; and K.) ― -b9- *ahabonaA fiY fayoDi fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) We went with the corpse and bier of such a one. (M.)
faADapN * : see mufaADN.
A^amoruhumo fayoDaY bayonahumo * : i. q. fawDaY, q. v. (TA in art. fwD.)
A^amoruhumo fayoDuwDaY bayonahumo * , and fayoDiyDaY, and fayoDuwDaA='u, and fayoDiDaA='u, and ↓ fayuwDaY, i. q. fawoDaY, q. v. in art. fwD. (AZ, K.)
fayuwDN * : see mufaADN.
A^amoruhumo fayuwDaY bayonahumo * : see fayDuwDaY.
fay~aADN * A river containing much water: (S:) or that flows much. (Ham p. 375.) ― -b2- Applied to a man: see fayoDN, in two places.
faAy^iDN * A watering-trough full: a sea, or great river, [overflowing: see 1: or] pouring, or pouring vehemently. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a man: see fayoDN.

mufaADN * pass. part. n. of 4 [q. v.]. ― -b2- HadiyvN mufaADN fiyhi (tropical:) Discourse in which people have pushed on, or pressed on: (K:) [or into which they have entered: or in which they have been large, or copious: or in which they have dilated: or begun: see 4; and see also musotafiyDN.] ― -b3- diroEN mufaADapN (tropical:) A wide, or an ample, coat of mail; (S, M, A, O, K;) as also ↓ faADapN (IJ, M) and fayuwDN. (M.) [In the CK, this word is erroneously written mufAwaDap, as applied to a coat of mail and to a woman.] mufaADN applied to a man, (tropical:) Wide in the belly: fem. with p: (M:) or the latter, a woman large in the belly, (S, M, A, O, K,) and flabby in flesh, (M, A,) and, as some add, inordinately tall: (TA:) : or, as some say, the latter signifies a woman having her masolakaAni [i. e. vagina and rectum] united; as though formed by transposition from mufoDaApN: (M:) and, accord. to some, mufaADN signifies having a fulness. (TA.) It is said of the Prophet, kaAna mufaADa AlbaToni, meaning (tropical:) He had the belly even with the breast: (O, K:) or he had a fulness in the lower part of the belly. (TA.)
musotafaADN * : see the next paragraph

musotafiyDN * One who asks for the pouring out (A_ifaADap) of water &c. (S, O.) -A2- A story, or a piece of news, (tropical:) spread abroad (S, M, A, * O, Msb, K) among the people, (S, O, Msb,) like water; (TA;) as also musotafaADN fiyhi; (S, O, K;) but you should not say musotafaADN [alone], (As, Fr, ISk, and the lexicologists in general, and Az, S, O, Msb, and K,) for this is a mistake of the inhabitants of the towns and villages: (As, Fr, ISk, &c., and Msb:) or this last is a word of weak authority: (K:) it is, however, used by some; (S, O;) for instance, by Aboo-Temmám; (TA;) as meaning begun, commenced, or entered upon; but most disallow it unless followed by fiyhi. (M.)

1 faAZa * , aor. yafiyZu, inf. n. fayoZN (ISk, T, S, M, K) and fuyuwZN and fayaZaAnN (S, M, K) and fayoZaAnN (Lh, TA) and fayoZuwZapN, (Lth, M, K,) He (a man, S) died; (ISk, T, S, M, K;) as also, (sometimes, S) ↓ faAZa, aor. yafuwZu, inf. n. fawoZN (ISk, T, S, M, K) and fawaAZN; (S, K, TA; but in the CK, fuwaAZN, and there said to be with damm;) or, accord. to IJ, only the inf. n., fawoZN, of the latter verb is used, though the verb itself is allowable on the ground of analogy. (M.) You say also, HaAna fayoZuhu and ↓ fawoZuhu, [in the CK fuwoZuhu,] The time came for his dying. (M, K.) In like manner, (S,) you say also, faAZato nafosuhu His soul departed, or went forth; Lth, T, S, M;) on the authority of AO and Ks; and the like is related on the authority of AZ; (S;) aor. tafiyZu, (M,) inf. n. fayoZN (Lth, T, M) and fayoZuwZapN; (Lth, T;) and [accord. to some,] faAZato nafosuhu, inf. n. fawoZN: (M:) or, when the nfs is mentioned, you say, faADato, with D: (K:) As says, I heard Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà say that one should not say faAZato nafosuhu, (T, * S, M, *) but fAZ, (S, M,) meaning “ he died; ” and not faADa, with D, decidedly; (S;) or not faADato: (T:) [but what was said by As respecting these two verbs has been stated more fully, and variously, in art. fyD, q. v.:] AO says that fAZt nafosuhu is of the dial. of Keys; and fADt, of the dial. of Temeem: Fr says that the people of El-Hijáz and Teiyi say the former; and Kudá'ah and Temeem and Keys say the latter: AHát says, I heard AZ say that Benoo-Dabbeh alone say the latter; and ElMázinee relates the like on the authority of AZ.
(TA.) ― -b2- You say also, faAZa nafosahu, (Ks, S, M, K,) aor. yafiyZu, (Ks, T,) He vomited forth his soul: (Ks, S, M, K:) the verb being trans. as well as intrans. (Ks, S.)

4 AfAZhu *
He (God) caused him to die. (K, TA.) And you say also, Darabotuhu Hat~aY A^afaZotu nafosahu [I beat him, or smote him, until I made his soul to depart, or go forth]. (S.) And laA^ufiyZan~a nafosaka [I will assuredly cause thy soul to depart, or go forth] (M.) And AfAZhu A@ll~`hu nafosahu [God caused him to vomit forth his soul]. (Ks, T, S, M.)

tfy~ZwA A^anofusahumo *
They constrained themselves to vomit forth their souls. (S, TA.) [But in one copy of the S, I find yufiyZuwA A^anofusahumo, expl. as meaning They cause to vomit forth their souls; which suggests that the right reading may perhaps be yufiyZuwA: or it may be yafiyZuwA, from faAZa nafosahu.]

fayofN *
A place that is even, level, or flat: (S, O, K:) or, (K,) accord. to Lth, (T, O,) a waterless desert, (T, M, O, K,) such as is even, level, or flat, and wide, or spacious; (T, O;) and ↓ fayofaApN and ↓ fayfaA='u (M, K) and ↓ fayofaY (K) also signify [thus, or] a waterless desert: (M. K:) and, (K,) accord. to El-Mu-arrij, (T, O,) fayofN signifies a portion of the earth that is a place whereof the winds are variable; (T, O, K;) and this is the explanation that is preferred by Sh: (T:) and accord. to AA, it signifies [also] any road between two mountains: (T, TA:) its pl. is A^afoyaAfN [a pl. of pauc.] and fuyuwfN [a pl. of mult.]. (T, S, M, O, K.)
fayofaY * : see the preceding paragraph.
fayofaApN * : see fayofN: and see also mufaAzapN, in art. fwz.

fayofaA='u * is syn. with fayofN, q. v.: therefore its A is augmentative, (S, M,) accord. to Sb (M) and Mbr: (S:) and it signifies (S, M, O,) also (M) a smooth [desert such as is termed] SaHoraA=': (S, M, O:) its pl. is fayaAfK. (S, M, O, K. [In the CK, this pl. is written fiyAfN, as though it were a pl. of fayofN.])
1 faAqa * , aor. yafiyqu: see fAq binafosihi, in art. fwq.
4 A^afiyqa * , said of a poet, i. q. A^afolaqa: (K:) or an imitative sequent thereto. (Aboo-Turáb, O.)
fiyqN * : see art. fwq.
fuyuqN * and fiyaqN: see art. fwq.
fayoqapN * and fiyqapN: see art. fwq.
fuyaAqN * : see art. fwq.
mufiyqN * : see art. fwq.

1 faAla raA^oyuhu * , aor. yafiylu, (S, M, O, K,) inf. n. fuyuwlapN, (S,) thus in some copies of the K and in the A, (TA,) or fayoluwlapN, (M, O,) thus in other copies of the K, (TA,) and fayaAlapN, thus in the O, but in the copies of the K fayolap, (TA,) His judgment, or opinion, was weak, (S, M, O, K,) and erroneous; (M, K;) as also ↓ tfy~l; (M, Z, K, TA;) and [in like manner] fiY raA^oyihi ↓ fay~ala [not fuy~ila] he was incorrect in his judgment, or opinion; and ↓ fay~aluwA occurs in a trad. as meaning fAl raA^oyuhumo: (TA:) [and faAla alone, said of a man, signifies the same as fAl raA^oyuhu, as is shown by a verse of El-Kumeyt cited in the T and M and O and TA: but it seems from what here follows (taken from a passage unconnected with the foregoing) that the first and third of what are mentioned above as inf. ns. are regarded by some as simple substs.:] and one says, ↓ fiY raA^oyihi fayaAlapN, (T, M, K, TA,) the last word like saHaAbapN, (TA, [in the CK, erroneously, fY riwaAyapK fiyaAlapN,]) and ↓ fuyuwlapN, (M, K, TA,) meaning [In his judgment, or opinion, is] a weakness. (TA.) -A2- And fAl signifies also He (a man) magnified himself, and became like the elephant (Alfiyl); or he showed a morose aspect: (TA:) [or it may so signify: IAar cites the following verse:
mina Aln~aAsi A^aqowaAmN A_i*aA SaAdafuwA AlginaY
tawal~awoA wafaAluwA lilS~adiyqi wafax~amuwA
which may mean [Of mankind are folks who, when they find riches, turn the back, and] magnify themselves and become like the elephant [to the friend, and aggrandize themselves] or show a morose aspect to the friend [&c.]; for the elephant is morose in aspect. (M.)

2 fy~l raA^oyahu * , (S, M, K,) inf. n. tafoyiylN, He declared [or esteemed] his judgment, or opinion, to be weak, (S.) or bad, and erroneous. (M, K.) Umeiyeh Ibn Abee-'Áïdh says,
falawo gayorahaA mino wulodi kaEobi boni kaAhilK
madaHota biqawolK SaAdiqK lamo tufay~ali
meaning lamo yufay~alo raA^oyuka (SKr, M) i. e. [But hadst thou praised other than her, of the children of Kaab Ibn-Káhil, with a true saying,] thy judgment, or opinion, would not have been declared weak. (SKr.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places.
3 faAyala * , [inf. n. mufaAyalapN and fiyaAlN, (see AlfayaAlu below,)] He played [at the game called AlfayaAl: see its part. n. below]. (O.)

5 tfy~l * : see 1. -A2- Also He (a man, K, [or a camel, as is indicated in the O,]) became fat, (O, K,) as though he were a fiyl [or an elephant]. (O.) [See also 10.] ― -b2- And, said of youth, or young manhood, (Al$~abaAb,) It increased, (Lth, T, M, O, K,) and became in its prime and fulness. (Lth, T, O.) ― -b3- And, said of herbage, It became tall, and full-grown; or became of its full height, and blossomed. (Th, M, K.)

10 Aisotafoyala *
He (a camel) became like the fiyl [or elephant] (M, K, TA) in bigness: (TA:) mentioned by IJ among the class of AsotaHowa*a and the like: part. n. musotafoyilN. (M.) [See also 5.]
faAlN * : see fiylN, latter half: -A2- and the paragraph commencing with faAy^ilu Alr~aA^oYi, near its end: -A3- and see also faA^olN, in art. fA^l.
fayolN * : see the paragraph here following.

fiylu * [The elephant; Pers. Pyl;] a certain animal, (TA,) well known: pl. [of pauc.] A^afoyaAlN and [of mult.] fuyuwlN and fiyalapN; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) not A^afoyilapN: (ISk, S, O, Msb:) accord. to Sb. fiylN may be originally of the measure fuEolN, (S, M, O,) pronounced with kesr because of the Y, like as they said A^aboyaDu and byDN; but Akh says, this is not the case in the sing, but only in the pl.: (S, O:) fem. with p. (M, K) ― -b2- Hence, layolapN mivolu lawoni Alfiyli [lit. A night like the colour of the elephant;] meaning a night that is black. (M, TA,) and dust-coloured; (M;) in which one knows not the right course to pursue: the colours of the fyl being of this kind. (M, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, also, daA='u Alfiyli The disease called by us the tumid Barbadoes leg; because the leg of the patient resembles that of the elephant by reason of its enormously-swollen state: not (as some have supposed it to be) elephantiasis; this latter being termed ju*aAm (q. v.) [― -b4- And hence, likewise, used as an epithet,] fiylN signifies also (tropical:) Heavy [or dull]; and low, ignoble, or mean. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And one says rajulN fiylu Alr~aA^oYi, meaning A man weak in respect of judgment, or opinion; (T, S, M, O, K;) and so ↓ fiyoluhu; (M, K;) and ↓ faAy^iluhu: (T, M, O, K;) and ↓ fay~iluhu, (ISk, T, S, M, O, K,) of the measure fayoEil; (O:) and ↓ faAluhu, (T, M, O, K,) and faAlN alone. (S, K.) meaning weak in respect of judgment, or opinion; (T, S, M, O, K;) erring in insight: (S:) pl. of the first] A^afoyaAlN: (S, M, O, K:) but AO says, the ↓ faAy^il is one who, inspecting, forms an opinion and errs; if he err after examining a horse in all its states or conditions and forming an opinion respecting it from his inspection, [not while doing so,] he is not reckoned to be fAy^l. (TA.)

AlfayaAlu * and AlfiyaAlu, (Lth, T, M, O, K) the former a subst, and the latter an inf. n. [of 3], (Lth, T, O,) and ↓ AlmufaAyalapu [which is likewise an inf. n. of 3], (M, K,) A certain game, (Lth, T, M, O, K,) well known, (O,) of the children, (T,) or of the youths, or young men, of the Arabs (M, K) of the desert, (M,) with earth, or dust: (Lth, T, M, O:) a thing is hidden in earth, or dust, which is then divided (T, M) into two portions; then the hider says to his companion, In which of them twain is it? (T;) and if he [who is thus questioned] mistake, the hider says to him faAla raA^oyuka: (T, M, * K; *) ISk termed it Alfiy^aAlu, with '; (O;) and it has been mentioned before in art.
fA^l: (T, O, K:) accord. to some, (TA,) this game is called AlT~abanu and Alsud~aru. (T, TA. [But see the former of these two words.])
fayaAlapN * : see the first paragraph.
fuyuwlapN * : see the first paragraph.

fay~ilu All~aHomi * A man having much flesh: (T, O, * K:) some pronounce it with ', (T, O,) saying fayA^al, (T,) or fay^il; (O;) both mentioned before [in art. fA^l]. (TA.) ― -b2- fay~ilu Alr~aA^oYi: see fiylN, latter half.
fay~iAlN * The attendant, or master, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) or the keeper, or driver, (MA, KL,) of the fiyl [or elephant], (S, MA, O, Msb, KL,) or of the fiylap. (So in the M and K.)

faAy^ilu Alr~aA^oYi * : see fiylN, latter half, in two places. -A2- AlfaAy^ilu [as a subst.] signifies The flesh that is upon the xurobap, (S, O,) or xurob, (K, [in the M, accord. to the TT, Hrf, app. a mistranscription,]) of the warik; (S, M, O, K;) [which, I think, will be plainly seen from what follows to mean the flesh that is upon the sacro-ischiatic foramen; though xurobapu Alwariki and xurobu Alwariki are said in the TA, in art. xrb, to mean “ the hole where the head of the thigh-bone is inserted; ”] so says A 'Obeyd: (S, O:) or, (S, M, O, K,) as some say, so adds A 'Obeyd, (S, O,) a certain vein (T, S, M, O, K) in the xurobap of the warik, descending into the leg, (T,) or in the thigh: (S, O:) As says, in “ the Book of the Horse, ” in the warik is the xurobap, which is a nuqorap wherein is flesh, no bone being in it; and in that nuqorap is the faAy^il, and there is no bone between the said nqrp and the belly, but only skin and flesh; (T, * S, O;) and he cites the saying of El-Aashà,
qado naxoDibu AlEayora fiY makonuwni faAy^ilihi
waqado ya$iyTu EalaY A^aromaAHinaA AlbaTalu
[Oft we stain the ridge of the spear-head in what is concealed in the interior of his fAy^l, and oft the man of valour dies by means of our spears]; makonuwnu AlfaAy^ili means his blood: he says [by implication], we are skilful in respect of the place of piercing: (S, O:) but As said mino in the place of fiY; and AA, qado naToEunu; which has been pronounced to be wrong: (O:) or the faAy^ilaAni, (T, M,) or the ↓ faAy^ilataAni, (so in the K, [app. a mistranscription,]) are two veins entering into the interior parts of the thighs (T, M, K,) in the hinder parts thereof; (M, K;) and they adduce as an evidence thereof the verse of El-Aashà cited above, saying that the epithet mknwn would not have been used if the fAy^l were not a vein; but others say that [the poet meant that] he made the spear-head to become concealed in the furthest part of the flesh; and if the fAy^l were a vein, it would not have been mentioned as it has been in a phrase of Imra-el-Keys which will be cited in what follows: (M:) [hence it is said,] or they are two portions of flesh [between which is the lower part of the os sacrum, i. e.] the lower parts of which are upon the SalawaAn [dual of SalFA], from the region of the lower portions of the HajabataAni to the Eajob, bordering upon the EuSoEuS on either side, descending in the two sides of the two thighs; [so in a human being,] and thus in the horse: (M, K: [for the meanings of the words that I have here left untranslated, I must refer to their several proper arts.; as they are variously explained:]) ↓ AlfaAlu is a dial. var. of AlfaAy^ilu; (M, K, TA;) which is expl. by Sgh [in the O] as meaning a certain vein issuing from the faw~aArap of the warik [i. e. from the sacro-ischiatic foramen]: (TA:) [but the assertion that AlfAl is a dial. var. of AlfAy^l seems to be founded only upon what here follows:] Imra-el-Keys says, [describing a horse,]
lahu HajabaAtN mu$orifaAtN EalaY AlfaAli
(S, M; or ElY AlfaAliY, as in the O and TA;) [i. e. He has edges of the haunch-bones projecting above, or beyond, the fAy^l; for] he means ElY faAy^ili, having altered the latter word by transposition. (T, S, O, TA.)
faAy^ilapN * : see its dual in the next preceding paragraph, near the middle.

A^afoyalu * [More, and most, weak, or erroneous; relating to a judgment, or an opinion]. A^afoyalu mina Alr~aA^oYi Ald~abariY~i is a prov., meaning [More weak] than an opinion that is given after the affair [to which it relates] has passed. (Meyd.)
mufaAyilN * [in the S and O in art. fA^l, with ', i. e. mufaAy^ilN,] Playing at the game called AlfayaAlu. (M, O.)
AlmufaAyalapu * expl. as a subst.: see AlfayaAlu.
mafoyuwlaA=' * [a quasi-pl. n. (like ma$oyuwxaA='u &c.), but one of which the sing. (if it have one) is not mentioned,] The young ones of the fiyl [or elephant]. (O, K.)
musotafoyilN * part. n. of 10, q. v. (M.)
1 faAna * , aor. yafiynu, (K,) inf. n. fayonN, (TA,) He, or it, came. (K.)

fayonapN *
A time; syn. waqotN, or waqotN mina Alz~amaAni; (T;) or HiynN; (T, S, M, K;) and saAEapN. (S, K.) You say, laqiytuhu Alfayonapa baEoda Alfayonapi [I met him time after time]: (AZ, S, M, K; but some copies of the K omit the words bEd Alfynp:) and laqiytuhu fayonapa [I met him at a certain time]: (AZ, S, M, K; but in some copies of the S and K, fayonapF:) thus fynp is made determinate in two different ways; by its having the article Al prefixed to it [in the former case], and as a proper name [in the latter case; with which compare what is said of bukorapa &c.]: (AZ, M:) and you say, A_in~iY laA=tiY fulaAnFA Alfayonapa baEoda Alfayonapi i. e. [Verily I come to such a one] time after time; not continually repairing to him: (AZ, T:) and, accord. to ISk, maA A^aloqaAhu A_il~aA Alfayonapa i. e. [I do not meet him save occasionally, or] time after time. (TA.) [See also fan~apN.]

fayonaAn *
Having beautiful and long hair: (K:) or so fayonaAnu Al$~aEari; applied to a man: (S:) fayonaAn [is also applied as an epithet to hair; and] has been mentioned in art. fn q. v.: (K:) if it be from fananN, meaning “ a branch, ” it is [of the measure fayoEaAlN, and therefore] perfectly decl. when indeterminate, and likewise when determinate [as a proper name]; but if from fayonapN, meaning “ a time, ” [which seems to be hardly reasonable,] it is [of the measure faEolaAn, and therefore] perfectly decl. in the former case and imperfectly decl. in the latter case. (Lh, T.) ― -b2- One says also Zil~N fayonaAnN, meaning Wide, extensive, shade. (TA.)
A^afoyuwnN * , also written A^ufoyuwnN and A_ifoyawonN, held by some to belong to this art. and by others to belong to art. Afn, has been mentioned in page 70.
1 faAha * , aor. yafiyhu: see faAha, aor. yafuwhu, in art. fwh.

fayohajN *
A wine-measure: (S, O, K:) a Pers. word arabicized [and therefore all its letters are regarded as radical]. (S.) ― -b2- And A strainer (O, K, TA) for wine. (TA.) ― -b3- And (sometimes, S, O) a name for Wine: (S, K:) or clear wine: (O, TA:) or an epithet applied to wine [app. signifying clear]: (TA:) or wine such as is mxtlq [app. a mistranscription for muxal~aq, a word now used as signifying aromatized]; like qinodiydN [q. v.] and A^um~N zanobaqK. (IAmb, TA.)
